title: Not Public Financings Fault
Vows: Can a Captain Marry Us?
description: Hollywood gave a big boost to the myth that captains could legally join couples on the open seas. In New York, Captain Arnold Wonsever, an ordained minister, is making this myth a reality.

title: Change Your Style, Youll Survive
description: This years edition of the Flamenco Festival, which opens on Thursday at City Center, comes on the tail of the worst recession Spain has seen since the end of the Franco period. But the festival, now in its 14th year, is larger than ever. It has expanded its scope, adding Los Angeles and San Francisco to its itinerary. In New York, it has spread to six additional spaces. The festivals organizers are looking to new markets in the Arab world and Asia. Flamenco is one of Spains most successful exports.

title: Rise in Sales for Neiman, Despite Loss
description: Neiman Marcus reported a rise in second-quarter sales on Friday, during what was a difficult season for retailers. The company also reported substantial expenses from the sale of the company in the fall.

title: Julien Davids Wild, Woolly Platforms
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Health Security and Infectious Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Transgender Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Diversity on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamas Chases Protesters From Gaza-Israel Border
description: JABALIYA, Gaza  Each Friday, Salah al-Najjar, 17, has made his way east of the Jabaliya refugee camp in the northern Gaza Strip, where he lives, to hurl rocks at the Israeli forces stationed along the fence that separates Gaza from Israel.

title: Swimming and Multitasking
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Cyberweapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoffman Killed by Toxic Mix of Drugs, Official Concludes
description: Philip Seymour Hoffman was killed by a poisonous mix of drugs that included not only heroin but also cocaine, amphetamines and sedatives, the New York City medical examiner announced on Friday.

title: In Battle for First Base, Mets Duda and Davis Impress
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  After just one game in the Grapefruit League this spring, the Mets competition at first base is already hot. Lucas Duda, inserted as the designated hitter against the Washington Nationals, smacked a broken-bat, ground-rule double. Then Ike Davis smashed a long, two-run home run to right.

title: Carnival Events Around the World
description: Carnival is celebrated not just in Brazil.

title: A Big Decision at the Minnesota Orchestra  But What?
description: The board of the Minnesota Orchestra, which is trying to rebuild itself after a bitter labor dispute and a debilitating 16-month lockout, has found itself facing an unusual choice of whether to side with its musical leadership or its administrative leadership.

title: No Charges in Death of Alzheimers Patient Mistaken for Intruder
description: ATLANTA  A man who shot to death an Alzheimers patient he feared was trying to break into his house will not be charged with a crime, a Georgia prosecutor said Friday.

title: McCann and a Prospect Display Power for the Yankees
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Brian McCanns shot took flight in the second inning, and Gary Sanchezs came two innings later, a succession of home runs that may presage the succession of Yankees catchers in the years to come.

title: Rail Inspections Ramp Up in Albany and Buffalo
description: New York State regulators conducted a series of inspections over the last week at the Port of Albany and on rail tracks in Albany and Buffalo to increase the safety of the surging oil-by-rail business, according to a statement by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Shepherd of the Citys Rebirth, Rios Mayor Feels the Strains, Too
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  IN his fits of rage, Eduardo Paes, the mayor of Rio de Janeiro, has thrown a stapler at one aide. He threw an ashtray at another. He berated a councilwoman in her chambers, calling her a tramp. Stunning diners at a crowded Japanese restaurant where he was being taunted by one constituent, a singer in a rock band, he punched the man in the face.

title: Uniqlos Parent Said to Seek Deal for J. Crew
description: The owners of J. Crew, the fashion purveyor of choice for the likes of Michelle Obama, are in the early discussions to sell the company to Fast Retailing, the Japanese retailer whose holdings include Uniqlo and Theory, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Engineers Allege Hiring Collusion in Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Tech companies love new ideas, unless they belong to someone else. Then any breakthroughs must be neutralized or bought. Silicon Valley executives know all too well that a competitors unchecked innovation can quickly topple the mightiest tech titan.

title: E.P.A. Says It Will Fight Mine Project in Alaska
description: SEATTLE  Federal environmental regulators, citing risks to water quality and salmon spawning grounds in one of the worlds richest fisheries, moved on Friday to block the development of a giant open-pit copper mine in the watershed of Bristol Bay in southwest Alaska.

title: The Bitcoin Blasphemy
description: Whenever I read a story about bitcoin, the virtual currency that has been so much in the news these days, I think about a man named Dee Hock. In the early 1970s, Hock created the credit card system that we now know as Visa. Hock was a man who liked to think grandiose thoughts. When it came to Visa, and credit cards in general, Hock used to describe them not just as a way to get a short-term loan but as a new kind of payment system, an exchange of value that was on par with, and that competed with, cash.

title: New Health Fix Offers Subsidies for Insurance Policies Bought Outside Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday that it would allow some people to receive federal subsidies for health insurance purchased in the private market outside of health insurance exchanges. The sudden shift was the latest in a series of policy changes, extensions and clarifications by federal officials trying to help beneficiaries and minimize political damage to Democrats in this election year.

title: Archbishop of Cologne, Germanys Largest Diocese, Retires
description: Cardinal Joachim Meisner, the archbishop of Cologne whose conservative positions found him apologizing more than once during the years that he led Germanys largest and wealthiest diocese, has retired, the archdiocese said Friday. Pope Francis accepted Cardinal Meisners request to retire, the archdiocese said in a statement. The cardinal, 80, had offered to step down after his 75th birthday but was asked by Pope Benedict XVI to stay on. After he was named to the position in 1988 by Pope John Paul II, he became known for his provocative statements, including comparing abortion to the Holocaust and using the Nazis term for the modernist artworks they despised  degenerate  to describe art with no religious connection. But he earned respect for refusing to bow to political pressure from Communist-era leaders while he was the leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Berlin and East Germany from 1980 to 1988.

title: American Envoy to Syria Steps Down
description: The United States top representative to the Syrian opposition, Robert S. Ford, retired from the Foreign Service on Friday, the State Department said. Lawrence Silverman, the acting deputy assistant secretary for Near Eastern affairs, will serve as his replacement until a successor is chosen. State Department officials said this month that Mr. Ford was expected to retire soon. As the American ambassador to Syria, Mr. Ford played an active role in challenging President Bashar al-Assads crackdown on the political opposition. In February 2012, as the security situation in Syria worsened, the American Embassy was closed. Mr. Ford later became the chief American envoy to the moderate Syrian opposition. Mr. Ford played a central role during the first two rounds of the peace talks in Geneva.

title: President of the Garden Is Replaced by an Executive at Cablevision
description: In October, Hank Ratner, the president and chief executive of the Madison Square Garden Company, proudly showed off the Gardens $1 billion renovation. Ratner had become the public face of the project, leading hard-hat tours for the news media while James L. Dolan, the executive chairman of the company, stayed behind the scenes.

title: Renting Judges for Secret Rulings
description: NEW HAVEN  SHOULD wealthy litigants be able to rent state judges and courthouses to decide cases in private and keep the results secret?

title: President of Sri Lanka Spurns an Inquiry
description: President Mahinda Rajapaksa on Friday rejected calls for an international investigation into accusations of massacres and human rights violations during the final phase of Sri Lankas civil war, which ended in 2009. If there is evidence, let them show us, Mr. Rajapaksa said. We will look into it. Meeting with an association of foreign journalists in Sri Lanka for the first time in three years, Mr. Rajapaksa said that recent resolutions criticizing Sri Lanka at the United Nations Human Rights Council could arise from a hidden agenda. On Thursday, the State Department released a report that was highly critical of the Rajapaksa government, claiming that in 2013 attacks, harassment, and threats by pro-government loyalists against critics of the government were prevalent, contributed to widespread self-censorship by journalists, and diminished democratic activity. On Friday, Mr. Rajapaksa likened the friction between the United States and Sri Lanka to Cassius Clay fighting with a schoolboy, a reference to the boxer now known as Muhammad Ali. But he said that the two countries were still friends.

title: Preparing Teachers for the Common Core
description: The panel convened by Gov. Andrew Cuomo to review New Yorks troubled rollout of the Common Core learning standards will present its recommendations this spring. Among its most important tasks is to offer ways to remedy the most serious weakness in the states Common Core effort  the shortage of high-quality programs that are supposed to train teachers to carry out new Common Core-based curriculums.

title: The N.F.L. Begins to Wake Up
description: Last years National Football League season was tainted by on-field racial slurs and the bullying of a Miami Dolphins player. Of course, professional football players operate in an emotional, intensely competitive and physically punishing environment. It is obviously not your normal workplace. But, as employees, there is no reason they should be immune from modern standards of workplace conduct.

title: A Bastion for Israel, Seething Inside
description: When John Judis, a longtime senior editor at The New Republic, published a book examining the role of the pro-Zionist lobby in persuading President Harry S. Truman to support the founding of the Jewish state in 1948, he expected strong criticism, and he has certainly gotten it.

title: De Blasio Picks More Liberal Activists Than Managers for City Posts
description: In Bill de Blasios City Hall, it seems more and more, there is only a left wing.

title: What Is Russias Aim in Ukraine?
description: Update March 1, 2014: The Russian Parliament granted President Vladimir Putin authority to use military forcein Ukraine as Russian security forces effectively seized control of the Crimean peninsula.

title: A Bigger Role for Relatives in N.C.A.A. Transfers
description: ATLANTA  Mark Harrow supports the Georgia State mens basketball team from a front-row seat at home games. Although a stroke a year and a half ago weakened his left side, his facial expressions are unrestrained.

title: Fathers Sons and Brothers Keepers
description: Frederick Douglass once noted, It is easier to build strong children than to repair broken men.

title: Korean Scientists New Project: Rebuild After Cloning Disgrace
description: SEOUL, South Korea  No one galvanized South Koreas national pride as he did, and no scandal in recent years unsettled the country as much as his.

title: Arizona Sort of Helps Out
description: Its been quite a week in Arizona. First, the Legislature passed a bill that, in effect, gave businesses the right to discriminate against gay couples. The states actual business community was horrified. Everybody from Mitt Romney to Newt Gingrich was ticked off.

title: Woods Makes Cut, but Barely
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Tiger Woods managed a few grins even as he tried to spin forward a Friday in which he moved backward. He had just missed a 10-foot birdie putt at No. 18, an agonizing yet fitting end to another round in the debate about the worthiness of Woodss game.

title: High Tech
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE This Saturday puzzle was a collaborative effort constructed by Ian Livengood and the crossword class at the J.A.S.A. (or Jewish Association Serving the Aging). Down below, Ian talks a bit about what the class does and what their creative process is like.

title: Litigant Against Social Welfare Agency Will Be Its Leader
description: For 30 years, Steven Banks has been among the most persistent, consistent and successful thorns in the side of New York City mayors.

title: End of an Era? Clinton Media Strategy May Be Due for an Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  Soon after Hillary Rodham Clinton left the State Department, her longtime spokesman talked wistfully about their paradise lost.

title: Slum Dwellers in Caracas Ask, What Protests?
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  On the east side of this capital city, where the rich people tend to live, most children have stayed home from school for more than a week, protest bonfires burn in the streets at night, stores shut early and carnival celebrations have been canceled.

title: Obama Vows Aggressive Campaign for Partys Congressional Candidates
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama vowed on Friday to wage an aggressive political campaign this year on behalf of Democratic congressional candidates, telling members of the Democratic National Committee that he will work to make the election a choice between opportunity for a few or opportunity for all.

title: Christies Plan: To Shift the Publics Attention From Scandal
description: Over the past few days, Gov. Chris Christie has reignited a reliably popular battle, crusading against unaffordable perks for public workers and promising extreme measures if he does not get his way.

title: Reynolds and Verducci to Fill McCarvers Spot as Lead Baseball Analysts on Fox
description: Fox Sports knew last season that it would have to replace Tim McCarver, its lead analyst for Major League Baseball since 1996, who turned 72 during last years postseason.

title: Let the U.N. Unmask the Criminals of Sri Lankas War
description: BRUSSELS  IN early 2009, as many as 40,000 civilians were killed in the final days of Sri Lankas civil war, having been herded into an area about the size of Central Park and subjected to relentless shelling. No one has been held accountable for these crimes, and even now the government in Colombo remains intent on burying the past. Only an international commission of inquiry stands any chance of rectifying this omission. So when the United Nations Human Rights Council meets Monday in Geneva, it should seek an investigation. It would be a decisive step toward justice and reconciliation in Sri Lanka.

title: Generals Bid for Dismissal of Sex Case Is Countered
description: In new court papers, Army officials have acknowledged that the lead prosecutor in the court-martial of a brigadier general accused of sexual misconduct believed that the most serious charges would be very difficult to prove at trial because of questions about the credibility of the main accuser, a junior officer. But the officials said they did not doubt the womans central claim that the general forced her to perform oral sex on him while they were serving in Afghanistan.

title: 2 Ukrainian Mayors Play Different Hands in Crisis
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The silver-haired mayor of this raw mining city in eastern Ukraine had just delivered a pep talk to about 100 uniformed police officers, beseeching them to ensure law and order in these turbulent times of revolution, when a bearded man in dark glasses took the microphone.

title: New York Will Consider Nonlethal Ways to Reduce Swan Population
description: Score one for swan fans.

title: Sartorial Pluck Has No Place in Washington, the City of Fancy Fridays
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Jared Polis, Democrat of Colorado, wore a purple polo shirt with a silver clip-on bow tie this week when he spoke about a cellphone bill on the floor of the House. His ensemble, which quickly lit up Twitter, so offended the sensibilities of GQ magazine that it offered the congressman a makeover, which Mr. Polis promptly embraced.

title: Tussling Over Ukraine; Gains and Grave Setbacks for Gay Rights
description: The romance and risk of political upheaval has been a recurring theme of the post-Communist world, as another mass uprising on Kievs smoldering Maidan left Ukraine, at least for now, fragmented, threatened and flat broke.

title: Ukrainian Ex-President Speaks Out From Russia
description: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia  Ukraines humiliated fugitive president appeared at a shopping center here on Friday to declare himself the countrys lawful leader, calling on President Vladimir V. Putin to act but vowing to oppose military intervention by Russia or anyone else. He spoke hours after mysterious Russian-speaking gunmen took up positions around two airports in Crimea, prompting Ukraines new leaders to announce that an intervention had already begun.

title: Related Press Release
description: A Georgia man who fatally shot an Alzheimers patient he feared was breaking into his house will not be charged with a crime, a prosecutor said.

title: Discovery Leads Yale to Revise a Chapter of Its Black History
description: On the campus of Yale University, Edward Bouchet has long been a venerated name. Hailed as the first African-American to graduate from Yale College, in 1874, he went on to be the first African-American to earn a Ph.D. (and only the sixth person nationwide to earn one in physics).

title: Warriors Soar, Knicks Lag, and Boos Rain Down
description: With 8 minutes 26 seconds remaining in the first quarter of Fridays game against the Golden State Warriors, Knicks Coach Mike Woodson called his first timeout. The Knicks already trailed, 13-6, but it was still early, and there was still a game plan. The tone  for either team  could still be determined.

title: In Rockaways, Infusion of Sand Will Soon Raise Beaches Hit by a Hurricane
description: Finally, the sand is coming back. This month, a contractor will start to dredge and spread 2.9 million cubic yards of sand on the Hurricane Sandy-depleted beaches of the Rockaways, in Queens, significantly expanding and raising six miles of beach. Thats a lot of sand castles or, put another way, enough sand to fill more than two Empire State Buildings.

title: After Arrest, Pastor Linked to de Blasio Is Under Scrutiny for Tangled Finances
description: Within the Caribbean-American community in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, Bishop Orlando Findlayter is widely respected for his involvement in social justice issues and beloved by his congregation for his warmth. As the chairman of a group of politically engaged Caribbean clergymen, he can provide a coveted entree to a network of local leaders.

title: Alabama: No Prison for Resentenced Rapist
description: The State Court of Criminal Appeals on Thursday upheld a judges ruling that a man convicted of raping a teenage neighbor should not serve prison time. The man, Austin Clem, was sentenced in December to probation by a judge in Limestone County after the appellate court ruled that his original punishment, which included a stint in a corrections program, was unlawful. Under both sentences, Mr. Clem faced decades in prison if he violated his terms of release. Although the district attorney also sought to have Mr. Clems second sentence overturned, the appeals court ruled that the judge acted appropriately.

title: Politics at the Oscars
description: Last year, First Lady Michelle Obama announced the Oscar winner for best picture live from the White House.

title: Effort to Delay Terror Trial of a Bin Laden Relative Fails
description: The terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, will not be delayed despite a claim by his lawyers that the government might have mixed up their client with a man who has a similar name.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 28, 2014
Bratton Not Following de Blasios Lead on Parade
description: When William J. Bratton said this week that he intended to march in the St. Patricks Day Parade, the declaration came as a bit of a surprise.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) THE IMPOSSIBLE (2012) Naomi Watts received an Oscar nomination for her role as Maria, an Englishwoman living in Japan, who is spending Christmas 2004 with her husband (Ewan McGregor) and three sons at a luxurious beach resort in Thailand when the tsunami hits. Maria is washed inland with her oldest son (Tom Holland, above, with Ms. Watts), leaving her badly injured and unable to find the rest of her family. Survivors are also witnesses, and The Impossible shows us, through the eyes of one unbelievably lucky family, some terrible things, including mangled bodies and parents in despair, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this second feature from the Spanish director Juan Antonio Bayona, based on a real-life account, which uses digital imagery, sound design and editing techniques to recreate both the violence and desolation that resulted from the natural disaster. But there is a troubling complacency and a lack of compassion in The Impossible, which is less an examination of mass destruction than the tale of a spoiled holiday. You could also say that it is a movie about the consequences of global inequality, but unfortunately only by accident.

title: Huber Matos, Comrade of Castro, Then Adversary, Dies at 95
description: Huber Matos, a top commander in Fidel Castros army who broke from the Cuban revolution in 1959 over its tilt toward Communism, endured a harsh imprisonment for 20 years and became a leader of anti-Castro exiles in Florida, died in Miami on Thursday. He was 95.

title: Valery Kubasov, 79, Russian Who Helped Bring Cold War Thaw to Space, Is Dead
description: Valery N. Kubasov, who pioneered international cooperation in space when he joined with a fellow cosmonaut in the linkup of Soviet and American spaceships in July 1975 amid the tensions of the Cold War, died on Feb. 19 in Moscow. He was 79.

title: Phyllis Krasilovsky Dies at 87; Wrote Childrens Books
description: Phyllis Krasilovsky, an author of popular childrens books, died on Wednesday in Redding, Conn. She was 87.

title: Corrections: March 1, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: South Korea Assails Japan on Wartime Brothels
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Unleashing fresh criticism of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, President Park Geun-hye of South Korea on Saturday urged him to be honest and courageous enough to face his countrys history of aggression in the early 20th century, especially its enslavement of Asian women in Imperial Army brothels.

title: Ukraine Mobilizes Reserve Troops, Threatening War
description: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine  Russias move to seize control of Ukraines Crimean Peninsula on Saturday led Ukraine to call up its military reserves on Sunday and warn Moscow against further incursions as Western powers scrambled to find a response to the crisis.

title: Document | Venus in Furs
description: Chest hair, that 1970s signifier of strength and virility, isnt the sex symbol that it once was  especially in this youth-obsessed era, when even alpha males are as waxed as a figurine. Ingrid Berthon-Moine plumbs deeper into the matter with V, her photo series of hirsute men. The images are cropped so tightly that they resemble female pubic hair. By using humor, you make a connection, says the 36-year-old French artist, who has explored  and upended  other beauty and gender tropes, including the masochistic nature of pedicures (in one of her short films she took a cheese grater to her heels) and the male ideal (satirized in a photography project that centered on the anatomy of Greek classical statues). Berthon-Moine knows her work isnt for everyone. You have to accept that people will like it or hate it and that is fine, she says. Art will not change the world but it can shift the way we look at it.

title: Some Tech Interns Make More Than U.S. Workers
description: Heres a quiz for you: Who makes more money, a median American household or an intern at Facebook? If you guessed the latter, the tech company, youre right.

title: Live Stream | Viktor & Rolfs Fall 2014 Collection at Paris Fashion Week
description: The latest womens collection from Viktor & Rolf at Paris Fashion Week.

title: The Evolution of First Lady Media Strategy
description: Political reporters scrutinized a trove of White House documents released on Friday, not just for insights into the inner workings of the Clinton administration, but also for revelations about Hillary Rodham Clinton that could inform her potential 2016 presidential campaign.

title: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Happy to Take a Front-Row Seat to Him
description: David Cangelosi tends to draw an audience, so its not surprising that many of the pivotal moments in his relationship with Tracy Lawrence have happened in front of one. Take how they met.

title: Threes a Trend | Space Is the Place
description: Will Gravity get the Oscar for best picture? Well have to wait till Sunday to find out  but the fashion world seems to have deemed it a winner, if the astronaut-inspired clothing hitting the runway this season is any evidence. This microtrend hit the catwalk like a rocket at one of the first runway shows in New York: Organic by John Patrick. The designer riffed on the NASA suit with quilted metallic Ts, silver pants and mod boots reminiscent of 60s space age fashion. Flash forward to Paris, where the designer Gareth Pugh presented a collection of cloudlike white dresses and mirrored silver trousers and tops that sculpted the body like futuristic armor. Finally, at Rick Owens, where the clothing always looks as if it is from the future, the designer showed white quilted motocross pants and high-necked zip-front jackets that winked at Hollywoods interpretation of space-ship uniforms.

title: From 1939, Somerset Maughams List of Must-Reads
description: Seventy-five years ago, the Paris edition published a list of books recommended by W. Somerset Maugham, the British novelist, to help you live more fully. Here is the top 10:

title: Buffett Hints at More Heinz-Like Deals in Annual Letter
description: Updated, 2:49 p.m. | The challenge looming over Warren E. Buffett is whether Berkshire Hathaway, the vast business empire he has built over five decades, can continue to make the sort of large acquisitions that will help it grow at a pace that will sustain his reputation as the nations shrewdest investor.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, March. 2
description: Mt. Gox is in the past, and the brightest minds in the room are hard at work building a responsible and secure future.

title: Viktor & Rolf: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: The Education of a Craftsman
Theres a Place for Us, Just Not the Kitchen
description: I was in bed with my new boyfriend, discussing the bloodshed in Ukraine, Gov. Chris Christie and the quixotic pneumatics of middle-age lust, when the talk turned to movie sex. I think this was because the Academy Awards are coming and we were thinking of having a few people over.

title: Where Sounds Have No Barrier
description: Open-plan offices are good for several things: saving money, flexibility, collaboration. But they are also hard on our ears  not because they are loud but because they are so very quiet.

title: Give Fees an Inch, and Theyll Take a Mile
description: Watch out for investment expenses. They will cut down your return, shrink your nest egg and may well prevent you from achieving your financial goals.

title: In Search of a Stable Electronic Currency
description: Bitcoin, an experiment with a radically new kind of electronic money, has exhibited many of the characteristics of a speculative bubble. That was clear long before the collapse of the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox last week.

title: Rose-Colored Words, but Gray Outcomes
description: When all the words you hear about the economy are bullish, you may want to run in the other direction. This counterintuitive finding  that positive visions of the future precede downturns  appears to be the case both for people and the economy as a whole.

title: The Third Replacement Phone Wasnt a Charm
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: Silicon Oligopsony
description: This story about top tech firms agreeing not to compete for workers is really amazing. Were accustomed to the notion that technology firms that win the race to dominate some segment become temporary monopolists; indeed, that temporary monopoly is the reward for successful innovation (although sometimes it ends up being a reward for just establishing an early market lock, rather than being either first or best with the technology.) What isnt often mentioned is that the top few tech firms dominate certain specialized labor markets, too; this gives them an incentive to collude to hold down wages, and collude they do or at any rate did.

title: The Rolling Robot Will Connect You Now
description: A few years ago, the introduction of remote-controlled robots on wheels brought a new dimension to Internet video chats, keeping the conversation going as people moved from room to room. But their costliness has made them a rarity in real life. Now that is changing, and the robots are becoming inexpensive enough that they may soon have many practical uses.

title: Sheila Talton, on Helping Employees Up the Ladder
description: This interview with  Sheila Talton, chief executive of Gray Matter Analytics, a consulting firm for financial services and health care, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Break Up the Bank? Its Not for You to Ask
description: JPMorgan Chase is trying to put its troubles behind it. Having agreed to pay a $13 billion settlement to the government for its past mortgage-lending misdeeds, it wants to move on. At the big Investor Day meeting with shareholders last week, Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, and his top lieutenants extolled the banks strong and diversified position in its four main businesses. I am so damn proud of this company, Mr. Dimon exclaimed.

title: American Austerity, Charted Yet Again
description: OK, I dont know why I havent done this before.

title: Pampered Guests and Feuding Hosts at Claridges Hotel
description: Few trophies, it would seem, are more seductive to tycoons than Claridges, the grande dame of luxury London hotels, which has a long history of tempting buyers and provoking gentlemens quarrels.

title: Peering Into Techs Monuments of Innovation
description: Increasingly, Silicon Valley companies are fusing their buildings with values of change, productivity and their perceived corporate smarts and quirkiness.

title: March 1 Updates on Ukraine Crisis
description: The Lede is following events in Ukraine and Russia on Saturday, following a unanimous vote in the upper house of the Russian Parliament approving a request from President Vladimir Putin to send a military force to Ukraine until, state media reports from Moscow, the the socio-political situation in the country is stabilized. Updates below mix breaking news with dispatches from Times correspondents and firsthand accounts of events on the ground posted on social networks by bloggers and journalists in Crimea and other parts of Ukraine.

title: CBO Mix-And-Match
description: Floyd Norris makes a really good point in criticizing the Congressional Budget Office; he argues that the offices latest budget projections arent consistent. CBO has marked down its expectations for future growth, but it hasnt marked down its expectations for future interest rates. And that leads to excessive fiscal pessimism.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Gather around, code breakers, and bust out your Enigma machines, because our variety puzzle this weekend is a cryptic crossword constructed by Fraser Simpson. Cryptics are usually much trickier than an ordinary puzzle, and this one is no exception.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: February 28, 2014
description: Cities and states across the country are grappling with how to pay for pensions and retiree health care costs. In New Jersey, Chris Christie is proposing a $34.4 billion budget that includes more than $2 billion in pension payments, the largest outlay yet to shore up a retirement plan for public workers that the governor calls a looming crisis. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar discuss why cities and states are facing pension crises and what they can do to solve the problem.

title: Kristy Kaurova Transforms Backstage at Haider Ackermann
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Kristy Kaurova (left) and after (right) makeup by Yadim and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

title: Making Russia Pay? Its Not So Simple
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has warned Russia that there will be costs for a military intervention in Ukraine. But the United States has few palatable options for imposing such costs, and recent history has shown that when it considers its interests at stake, Russia has been willing to pay the price.

title: The Journey to 700 for Jaromir Jagr
description: Only six players have scored 700 N.H.L. goals  Gordie Howe, Phil Esposito, Marcel Dionne, Wayne Gretzky, Mike Gartner and Brett Hull. A look at Jagrs 699 goals by the teams he scored for and against.

title: Amid More Signs of Russian Force in Crimea, Delight Mixes With Dismay
description: BALAKLAVA, Ukraine  Reduced to a ghoulish tourist attraction by the collapse of the Soviet Union, the former pride of the Black Sea Fleet  a top-secret nuclear submarine base burrowed into a rocky hill and worthy of a James Bond villain  was closed on Saturday for technical reasons, announced a handwritten note taped to the ticket window.

title: After Initial Triumph, Ukraines Leaders Face Battle for Credibility
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The United States and the European Union have embraced the revolution here as another flowering of democracy, a blow to authoritarianism and kleptocracy in the former Soviet space. But successful revolutions, as the interim government here has been learning, are a lot harder to maintain than it can seem in the bright dawn of first victories.

title: Car of Ref Slated to Call U.S. Game Is Bombed in Cyprus
description: This weeks friendly match between the United States and Ukraine seems to be cursed.

title: With Vacancies High, G.O.P. Primaries in Texas Set Up a Scramble to the Right
description: HOUSTON  What happens to a party after Rick Perry heads toward the exit and Ted Cruz walks in the door?

title: Paris Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: End of the Ride for Lance Armstrong
description: The $10 million estate of Lance Armstrongs dreams is hidden behind a tall, cream-colored wall of Texas limestone and a solid steel gate. Visitors pull into a circular driveway beneath a grand oak tree whose branches stretch toward a 7,806-square-foot Spanish colonial mansion.

title: Think Back: Obama's Cold War
description: In addressing crises in Ukraine, Syria and elsewhere, President Obama seems to be drawing on the memory of old-time superpower struggles, says Sam Tanenhaus.

title: A History Lesson That Needs Relearning
description: SUDDENLY the specter of the Cold War is back. Prompted by the political crisis in Ukraine, some conservatives have called for President Obama to stand up to Vladimir V. Putin in the grand tradition of previous American presidents who stared eyeball to eyeball with Soviet leaders from Joseph Stalin to Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Yohji Yamamoto Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: First Touch Eludes German Keeper
description: Word is that goalkeeper Marc-Andre ter Stegen is headed to Spain and Barcelona next season. But the proposed move might be subject to revision after his horrendous error cost Borussia Mnchengladbach a couple of points Saturday in Germanys Bundesliga.

title: Comme des Garons: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: How to Love the Cold
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass.  BECAUSE part of me hates winter, I go ice fishing.

title: The Downside of Inciting Envy
description: THE Irish singer Bono once described a difference between America and his native land. In the United States, he explained, you look at the guy that lives in the mansion on the hill, and you think, you know, one day, if I work really hard, I could live in that mansion. In Ireland, people look up at the guy in the mansion on the hill and go, one day, Im going to get that bastard.

title: Regulating Electronic Cigarettes
description: European lawmakers last week adopted strong tobacco regulations that will increase government oversight of electronic cigarettes. The rules should serve as a model for the Food and Drug Administration, which has said that it also intends to regulate the nicotine-delivery devices.

title: Brace Yourself for Hillary and Jeb
description: WASHINGTON  OY. By the time the Bushes and Clintons are finished, they are going to make the Tudors and the Plantagenets look like pikers.

title: Antonin Baudry
description: Antonin Baudry is the French governments cultural counselor in the United States. His graphic novel, based on his experiences working for the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is the basis for the farcical film Quai dOrsay, which will open March 21 in the United States, retitled The French Minister.

title: The Terms of Our Surrender
description: IT now seems certain that before too many years elapse, the Supreme Court will be forced to acknowledge the logic of its own jurisprudence on same-sex marriage and redefine marriage to include gay couples in all 50 states.

title: Fear Mongering With Medicare
description: The Obama administrations proposed cuts to Medicare Advantage plans  the private insurance plans that cover almost 30 percent of all Medicare beneficiaries  are fair and reasonable. As it happens, they are also mandated by law. Yet Republicans, sensing a campaign issue, are telling older and disabled Americans that the administration is raiding Medicare Advantage to pay for Obamacare. The health insurance industry, for its part, is warning that enrollees will suffer higher premiums, lower benefits and fewer choices among doctors if the cuts go into force.

title: Is Success in Our DNA?
description: Readers discuss a claim that social status is strongly determined by your lineage.

title: Support Your Local Slaughterhouse
description: BOLINAS, Calif.  LATE on Saturday, Feb. 8, news broke of the recall of 8.7 million pounds of beef that had come through a Northern California slaughterhouse. Social media buzzed with tweets and posts pronouncing it the latest example of a dysfunctional industrialized food system incapable of producing safe meat. Buy local! Know your farmer! Eat grass-fed beef!

title: Arizona Did Us All a Favor
description: YOURE a fundamentalist Mormon  that is, the breakaway sect, not recognized by the main church, with a scary compound in Northern Arizona. Women wear long prairie dresses, men rule with an iron fist. You believe in a host of things that violate civil and even criminal law. But your beliefs are sincerely held. They come directly from God.

title: The Compassion Gap
description: SOME readers collectively hissed after I wrote a week ago about the need for early-childhood interventions to broaden opportunity in America. I focused on a 3-year-old boy in West Virginia named Johnny Weethee whose hearing impairment had gone undetected, leading him to suffer speech and development problems that may dog him for the rest of his life.

title: The Dying Art of Legislating
description: Nearly half of the current House members were not yet alive when John Dingell first walked onto the floor in 1955. Though he became one of the eras most consequential legislators over six decades, he endured his share of setbacks, including being ousted as chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee in 2008. But not until this year did he decide the atmosphere was so toxic, so obnoxious, that he could not continue serving.

title: How Did Hungarys Election Become a Circus?
description: BUDAPEST  THE most visible poster on the streets here is not the one advertising the Deep Purple concert at the Papp Laszlo Sportarena. And its not the one for Balkan Kobra, a theatrical comedy featuring a stubbly hero sporting tight jeans and a Kalashnikov. And its definitely not the one for the Budapest Dance Festival.

title: Sum izzamples of whuddah Filelfian seawns luyk
description: (Some examples of what a Philadelphian sounds like.)

title: The Sound of Philadelphia Fades Out
description: THE Philadelphia regional accent remains arguably the most distinctive, and least imitable, accent in North America. Lets not argue about this. Ask anyone to do a Lawn Guyland accent or a charming Southern drawl and that person will approximate it. Same goes for a Texas twang or New Orleans yat, a Valley Girl totally omigod. Philly-South Jersey patois is a bit harder: No vowel escapes diphthongery, no hard consonant is safe from a mid-palate dent. Extra syllables pile up so as to avoid inconvenient tongue contact or mouth closure. If you forget to listen closely, the Philadelphia, or Filelfia, accent may sound like mumbled Mandarin without the tonal shifts.

title: Soviet-Era Sex Ed
description: A FEW months ago my 15-year-old raised her eyes from her homework and asked me if I knew what smegma was. I had no idea. She explained the term and then invited me to identify the Cowpers glands on a diagram of the male genitalia. I pointed at something that looked glandish to me. No, Mom! she said with a patronizing smile, thats a seminal vesicle.

title: From the Pyramid to the Square
description: THE Egyptian strongman Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi was recently in Moscow visiting with Russian strongman Vladimir Putin. Putin reportedly offered Sisi $2 billion in arms  just what a country like Egypt, where half the women cant read, needs. The whole meeting struck me as so 1960s, so Nasser meets Khrushchev  two strongmen bucking each other up in the age of strong people and superempowered individuals. Rather than discuss arms sales, Sisi and Putin should have watched a movie together.

title: College, the Great Unleveler
description: When the G.I. Bill of Rights of 1944 made colleges accessible to veterans regardless of socioeconomic background, Robert Maynard Hutchins, the president of the University of Chicago, worried that it would transform elite institutions into educational hobo jungles. But the G.I. Bill was only the first of several federal student aid laws that, along with increasing state investment in public universities and colleges, transformed American higher education over the course of three decades from a bastion of privilege into a path toward the American dream.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Haider Ackermann Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: George Karl Sees a Talent Adrift as Carmelo Anthonys Knicks Fade
description: Lets assume, for the moment, that Carmelo Anthony will decide to re-sign with the Knicks after what has so far been a dreadful season. That the extra money along with ownership guarantees of a roster upgrade will be enough to quell whatever wanderlust Anthony may have.

title: By One Measure, 76ers May End Up Historys Worst
description: The good news for the Philadelphia 76ers is that the team has no chance of finishing with the worst record in team history. The bad news is that the current team may be just as bad as  or worse than  the 1972-73 team, which produced the lowest winning percentage for an 82-game season in league history, .110.

title: Red Wings Looking to Sell at Deadline? Dont Buy It
description: The Detroit Red Wings have been the N.H.L.s gold standard for a long time: 22 straight seasons in the playoffs, the longest current streak in the major North American sports, during which they have won four Stanley Cups. Six times in that stretch, they have won the Presidents Trophy for the leagues best record.

title: The Cuban Evolution
description: HAVANA  MAYBE it was the Robin Thicke music video playing on a half-dozen flat-screen TVs, or the black-and-white image of the Brooklyn Bridge splashed above the V.I.P. area, or perhaps it was just the nightclubs name: Sangri-LA. All I knew, as I sipped my $4 rum, was that this was not the Cuba of Fidel Castros 1959 revolution.

title: An Island Nation Starts to Catch Up
description: Cuba is slowly expanding its private enterprise.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Viktor & Rolf Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: In 20th Season, Hawkins Targets 1,000th Game
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The young pitcher looked up from his iPad, jolted by the conversation at the next locker in the Colorado Rockies clubhouse. LaTroy Hawkins was talking about his performance at Yankee Stadium on May 17, 1998, when he threw seven decent innings while his opponent, David Wells, pitched a perfect game.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Perfectly Messy Hair at Viktor & Rolf
description: Models were made to look romantically disheveled for todays whimsical show.

title: From One Louisville Neighborhood, Big Leaguers on the Field and in Film
description: TAMPA, Fla.  They ran up and down the residential streets of Indian Hills in metropolitan Louisville, Ky., playing basketball, football and baseball by day and flashlight tag at night. It was a group of friends like so many millions across the nation, just regular youngsters playing regular games.

title: Responding To Readers, About Blaming Poverty on the Poor
description: My Sunday column is an outgrowth of one a week earlier from West Virginia. As the latest column notes, the earlier one triggered a number of responses from people who focused their wrath on a young mom because of her tattoos and weight. Normally, when I write about poverty I look at wonkish evidence-based solutions, but this time I step back and argue that fundamentally what we need is not so much technical solutions as greater compassion and less name-calling.

title: Masahiro Tanaka Pitches 2 Scoreless Innings in Debut for Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Masahiro Tanaka took the mound at the Rakuten Golden Eagles stadium with a complete game on the line in the ninth inning, the public address system blared a song called Ato Hitotsu by the Funky Monkey Babys to inspire him.

title: Attackers With Knives Kill 29 at Chinese Rail Station
description: HONG KONG  A group of assailants wielding knives stormed into a railway station in southwestern China on Saturday, slashing employees and commuters and leaving at least 29 people dead and 130 wounded, according to Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency. The local government indicated that the attackers were Uighur separatists seeking an independent homeland in the Xinjiang region in Chinas far west.

title: Heavy Rains in Los Angeles
description: More rain fell in Los Angeles over the course of 12 hours on Friday than had fallen over the last eight months, according to the National Weather Service.

title: The Monuments of Tech
description: Big Internet companies love to talk about how they are disrupting one thing or another, but they still want what big companies have always wanted: workplaces that memorialize their products and values.

title: Yearning for the Fields of Summer
description: Something strange appeared in front of my house recently: a little patch of grass and dirt, peeking out from the icy crust that has enveloped Long Island for most of the past two months. A sign of life. On the news, I caught glimpses of David Wright making those loose, easy first throws of training camp. George Harrisons voice filled my head.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Female Missionaries Talk Priesthood
description: While many Mormon women embrace growing leadership roles and mission opportunities, they stop short when asked about the desire to be ordained as priests.

title: Meet, Greet, Converse, Repeat
description: Nicolle Ensign and Victoria Julayne Scott, Mormon missionaries, spend long days in South Korea, saying hello to everyone they encounter, hoping a casual chat will lead to real interest in their faith.

title: A Bus Ride Is an Opportunity
description: Depending on their language skills, missionaries can turn a short bus trip into an opportune moment to befriend fellow passengers and collect phone numbers.

title: The New Face of Mormons on a Mission
description: Ashley Farr spends one of her first few days in Daejeon, South Korea, singing hymns in Korean and meeting fellow missionaries, more and more of whom are women.

title: Mormon Missionaries
description: The number of missionaries increased in 2013 after the church lowered the minimum age for new missionaries, to 19 from 21 for women and to 18 from 19 for men.

title: The Disappearing Mormon Bachelor
description: As unmarried Mormon women in Utah get older, they outnumber unmarried Mormon men by wide margins.

title: Missions Signal a Growing Role for Mormon Women
description: DAEJEON, South Korea  Ashley Farr, once Miss North Salt Lake Teen USA, is the first in her familys long line of Mormon women to become a missionary, and in December she embarked on her new life in this gray corner of Asia. She packed her bag according to the churchs precise instructions: skirts that cover the knee, only one pair of pants, earrings that dangle no longer than one inch, and subtle but flattering makeup, modeled in  photos on the churchs website.

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: Rangers Rally From Two Down, Then Go Cold
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Rangers had goalie Henrik Lundqvist back in the net and defenseman Dan Girardi signed and off the trading block, just the formula for a successful Saturday afternoon in Philadelphia. But instead the Rangers stumbled, 4-2, against the Flyers, and found their hold on second place in the Metropolitan Division reduced to a single point.

title: Jaromir Jagr Gets 700th Goal, and Devils Rout the Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Jaromir Jagr was an opposing star for the Pittsburgh Penguins when Wayne Gretzky played his last game, for the Rangers in 1999. Jagr, a 42-year-old Czech, and Gretzky, the N.H.L.s career scoring leader, now share another milestone: career goal No. 700 at Nassau Coliseum against the Islanders.

title: British Weather and Nominees at a California Party
description: LOS ANGELES  Its been raining here. Have you heard?

title: Ukraine Finds Its Forces Are Ill Equipped to Take Crimea Back From Russia
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The new government of Ukraine called an emergency session of its national security council on Saturday in the face of the Russian militarys seizure of Crimea, but the leaders are facing a grim reality: Their armed forces are ill equipped to try to reconquer the region militarily.

title: Helen Mirren Takes on the Gender Gap
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD  Shut up, said Helen Mirren, cause Mamas in the house.

title: At Rick Owens, Not Your Usual Models
description: Rick Owens sees his runways as more of a blank canvas than many of his contemporaries do. Hes a showman, and theres not a part of the show he wont rethink if it suits his purpose. His are the rare fashion events at which you truly dont know what to expect.

title: At Acne, Its Hip to be Square
description: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

title: Oscar Double Features
description: Administrivial Alert! Theres still time to register for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, which will be held March 7 through March 9 at the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott. Not only that, but spaces are still available for the annual Cru dinner. Click on the links for more details.

title: Lanvin: 125 Years of Style
description: The French designer Jeanne Lanvin created a brand that put women first, a legacy that Alber Elbaz honors today.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Comme des Garcons Fall/Winter 2014
description: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Rise in Bigotry Fuels Massacre Inside Myanmar
description: DU CHEE YAR TAN, Myanmar  Under the pale moon of Jan. 13, Zaw Patha watched from her bamboo house as Mohmach, 15, her eldest child, was dragged from the kiosk where he slept as guardian of the family business.

title: An Eye on Runoffs, Candidates Mind Tactics in Primaries
description: In the highest-profile races of Tuesdays primaries, a large number of candidates will be happy to come in second.

title: Looking Ahead and Seeing a Different Mix
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Pro-Hezbollah Song Opens Musical Front in Civil War Over Syria
description: NABATIYE, Lebanon  The insults and threats flow to the singer, Ali Barakat, around the clock. Men call from unknown phone numbers and say nasty things about his mother. Others send him photos of dead bodies and tell him to join them in the grave. Still others threaten to dispatch car bombs and suicide attackers.

title: Lotterys Own Personal Watchdog Intends to Remain on Guard
description: Dawn Nettles chuckled when she talked recently about how her friends and family hated her passion for the Texas Lottery, which has consumed many of her waking hours for more than 20 years.

title: Popular Tech Gathering Faces Growing Pains
description: The 21st annual South by Southwest Interactive Conference, which starts Friday in Austin, is on track to be the most popular edition yet of the technology-oriented festival. More than 30,000 people are expected to descend upon Austin for five days of panels, parties and trade demonstrations. Attendance has nearly tripled since 2009.

title: Act of Killing Film Fails to Stir Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The American director of the chilling Indonesian documentary The Act of Killing has won dozens of awards so far for the film and could add one of the movie industrys most coveted honors Sunday at the Oscars.

title: Senator Expresses Concerns About Nuclear-Waste Tanks
description: WASHINGTON  Most of the youngest and sturdiest of the giant tanks that the Energy Department uses to store high-level radioactive waste at its Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State show some of the same construction problems as a tank that began leaking in late 2012, according to documents released by Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, whose state is across the Columbia River from the site.

title: Pakistani Taliban, Announcing Cease-Fire, Urge the Revival of Peace Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani Taliban announced a monthlong cease-fire on Saturday and urged the government to revive peace talks that broke down last month.

title: Deal Would Allow Gays to March in Bostons St. Patricks Day Parade
description: BOSTON  South Bostons St. Patricks Day parade, the second-largest in the country after New Yorks, could be on the verge of a historic breakthrough  the participation of a gay advocacy group that had been banned from the parade for two decades.

title: Parnell Takes Positive Step in Return From Injury
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the first time since July, Bobby Parnell, the Mets closer, was on a mound Saturday facing batters. David Wright, Daniel Murphy and Eric Young Jr. rotated in, and, for 36 pitches, Parnell let loose. It was another step in his recovery from the neck surgery he had Sept. 10.

title: Rubio Proposes Steps U.S. Should Take With Russia
description: WASHINGTON  For months, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a possible contender for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, has struggled to raise his voice above more senior Republicans on foreign policy even as he has offered a third way between older military traditionalists and newly emerging isolationists.

title: Troubles at Womens Prison Test Alabama
description: WETUMPKA, Ala.  For a female inmate, there are few places worse than the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women.

title: Obamas New Political Chief Tries to Reassure Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  David Simas left nothing to chance when he ran for the Taunton, Mass., school board at the age of 22. He packed the kickoff fund-raiser at the Portuguese-American Civic Club with his extended family, took his mother with him to knock on 5,000 doors and left a handwritten note if no one was home: Sorry I missed you. David.

title: McIlroy Displays Composure in Place Where He Once Lost It
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  The putt was for bogey, a 10-footer that Rory McIlroy knew would carry significance. Miss it, and his lead and game might come apart Saturday at the Honda Classic.

title: Afghan Broadcaster Says U.S. Soldiers Abused Him
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Qazi Nasir Mudassir said he had expected that if armed men climbed over the walls of his radio stations compound, they would probably be Taliban insurgents coming to make good on death threats because of his broadcasts.

title: Lee Lorch, Desegregation Activist Who Led Stuyvesant Town Effort, Dies at 98
description: Lee Lorch, a soft-spoken mathematician whose leadership in the campaign to desegregate Stuyvesant Town, the gargantuan housing development on the East Side of Manhattan, helped make housing discrimination illegal nationwide, died on Friday at a hospital in Toronto. He was 98.

title: Big-Money Donors Demand Larger Say in Campaign Strategy
description: The Republican donors who have financed the partys vast outside-spending machine are turning against the consultants and political strategists they once lavished with hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Harvard Coach Ties Ivy League Record for Wins; UConn Remains Undefeated
description: Kathy Delaney-Smith tied Pete Carril for the most basketball victories by an Ivy League coach as visiting Harvard defeated Columbia, 64-51, on Saturday night at Levien Gymnasium.

title: Antigay Laws Gain Global Attention; Countering Them Remains Challenge
description: UNITED NATIONS  After Uganda criminalized homosexuality, the White House immediately warned that the law would complicate the countrys relationship with Washington, and the Netherlands and Norway cut off bits of development aid.

title: The 2014 Senate Landscape
description: Dozens of states are holding Senate primaries this year. Here is a look at the key races in every state.

title: Carlos Gracida, a Celebrated Member of a Family Dynasty in Polo, Dies at 53
description: Carlos Gracida, one of the most accomplished players in the history of polo and a member of a legendary Mexican family in the so-called sport of kings, died on Tuesday after falling from his horse during a match at the Everglades Polo Club in Wellington, Fla. He was 53.

title: U.N. to Assess Residents Risk in Southern Yemen City
description: GENEVA  Alarmed by reports of rising civilian casualties in the southern Yemen city Al Dhale, United Nations aid officials are preparing a mission this week to assess the plight of residents caught in the crossfire between government troops and rebels fighting for the souths secession from the north.

title: A Players Attacks Pay Off at a Tournament in Minsk
description: It was a fitting finish at the International Open Tournament in Minsk, Belarus, last month, with the title going to a competitor whose style is so similar to that of the legendary champion the event honored.

title: Lewis Yablonsky, 89, Sociologist Who Learned From the Streets, Is Dead
description: Lewis Yablonsky carried a switchblade before he became a sociologist.

title: Home Prices in China May Hurt Families
description: HONG KONG  Chinas banks may not be directly exposed to losses from the countrys soaring housing prices, but any slump in those prices could set off widespread public anger, data from a broad new survey of household finances indicates.

title: Crimean Tatars Ponder the Return of Russian Rule
description: KHOSHKELDI, Ukraine  In a narrow convenience store here in Khoshkeldi, a village of about 1,000 ethnic Tatars just outside the Crimean capital, shoppers came in one after another on Saturday, heads drooping, asking the disconsolate clerk if she had heard the latest.

title: Crimea, the Tinderbox
description: WASHINGTON  The Russian military intervention in Ukraines autonomous republic of Crimea has brought relations between the United States and Russia to their lowest level in a quarter century. It has transgressed the sovereignty of one of the most populous countries in Europe, violated the terms of a diplomatic agreement to respect Ukraines borders, and placed Russia on a war footing with one of the few states in the post-Soviet world that has managed to hold multiple free elections. It is a military operation that is unsanctioned by any international body, wholly open-ended, and blessed only by the Russian Parliament.

title: Bernadette DiPrisco, John Kasnicki
description: Bernadette Theresa DiPrisco and John Ted Kasnicki were married Saturday at the Church of St. Anne, a Roman Catholic church in Garden City, N.Y. Msgr. Edward A. Ryan performed the ceremony.

title: Meghan Gourley, Kristofer Goddard
description: Meghan Ann Gourley and Kristofer Ryan Goddard were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Damaris Acosta, a deputy city clerk at the New York City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Christina Murphy, Albert Pisa
description: Christina Marie Murphy and Albert Anthony Pisa were married Saturday at St. Edward Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Thomas Klinzing performed the ceremony.

title: Lara Samet and David Buchwald
description: Lara M. Samet and David Evan Buchwald were married Saturday evening at Tarrytown House Estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Alan Silverstein officiated.

title: Jane Gao and Connor Raso
description: Jane Yinghua Gao and Connor Nathaniel Raso were married in a nondenominational ceremony Saturday at the Peninsula Hotel in Chicago. The Rev. Bruce A. Otto, ordained as a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: A Captive Audience
description: Blythe Lawton Winchester and Jordan William Winters Brock were married Saturday evening at the Cathedral of Christ the King in Atlanta. Msgr. Francis G. McNamee performed the ceremony.

title: Jessica Cohen and Brian Benvenisty
description: Jessica Dawn Cohen, a daughter of Beth Gold Cohen and Mark Cohen of Roslyn, N.Y., was married Thursday to Brian Matthew Benvenisty, the son of Terri H. Benvenisty and Dr. Alan I. Benvenisty of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi David-Seth Kirshner officiated at the Tribeca Grill restaurant in New York.

title: Sarah Seyfer, Adam Davis
description: Dr. Sarah Joy Seyfer, a daughter of Joy E. Seyfer and Pete R. Seyfer of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, was married Saturday to Dr. James Adam Davis, a son of Lisa M. Davis and J. Glen Davis of Spring, Tex. The Rev. Dwight C. Davis, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Rice University Chapel in Houston.

title: Brandon Charles and David Foster
description: Dr. Brandon Todd Charles, a son of Linda S. Charles and Glen R. Charles of Coram, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to David Collis Foster, a son of Jyl J. Josephson and a stepson of James L. Nelson of Jersey City. Timothy M. Pittman, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated at the Wythe Hotel in Brooklyn.

title: Danielle Miller and Robert Garcia
description: Danielle Beth Miller, a daughter of Robin Schweibel Miller and Alan J. Miller of Tenafly, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Robert Michael Garcia, the son of Maralyn A. Garcia and Ernesto Garcia, also of Tenafly. Rabbi Laurie Phillips officiated at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

title: Ailie Silbert and David Gold
description: Ailie Laura Silbert and David Allen Gold were married Saturday evening in Central Park in New York. Rabbi Marc A. Gellman officiated at the Loeb Boathouse.

title: Corrections: March 2, 2014
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 1, 2014
description: March 1, 2014

title: Bolstered by Their Depth, Nets Head Home on the Rise
description: MILWAUKEE  Jason Collins is finally heading to his new home. He will be bringing along an ascending team that continues to play rock-solid basketball.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 86TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Ellen DeGeneres makes her second appearance as the host of the ceremony, broadcast live from the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are predicting that Matthew McConaughey will take home the Oscar for his portrayal of an H.I.V.-positive man in Dallas Buyers Club, and that his co-star Jared Leto will win for supporting actor. In the best actress category, Cate Blanchett is the frontrunner for her portrait of a wealthy socialite fallen from grace after her husbands financial fraud, while Jennifer Lawrence, as a highly emotional wife in American Hustle, is the favorite for supporting actress. And Steve McQueens 12 Years a Slave may squeak by in the best picture category, which is filled out by David O. Russells American Hustle, Paul Greengrasss Captain Phillips, Jean-Marc Valles Dallas Buyers Club, Alfonso Cuarns Gravity, Spike Jonzes Her, Alexander Paynes Nebraska, Stephen Frearss Philomena and Martin Scorseses Wolf of Wall Street. Mr. Russell, Mr. Cuarn, Mr. Payne, Mr. McQueen and Mr. Scorsese are also nominated for best director. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 5 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Red-carpet coverage begins at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E! Above, a worker decorates the front of the theater.

title: Thousands in Hong Kong Support Wounded Editor
description: HONG KONG  Thousands of Hong Kong residents marched peacefully on Sunday to voice their support for press freedom and to denounce violence after a near-deadly assault on a former newspaper editor who has become a symbol of the pressures squeezing the local news media.

title: China Blames Xinjiang Separatists for Stabbing Rampage at Train Station
description: KUNMING, China  The group of about 10 attackers, dressed in black and wearing cloth masks, arrived in front of Kunming Railway Station in southwest China on Saturday night and began slashing at employees and commuters, sometimes repeatedly plunging their long knives and daggers into people too stunned or slow to flee.

title: Kenzo: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: My Life as a Writer
description: The following is an interview Philip Roth gave to Daniel Sandstrom, the cultural editor at Svenska Dagbladet, for publication in Swedish translation in that newspaper and in its original English in the Book Review.

title: How the Trophy for Just Showing Up Is Earned
description: My sons eight soccer trophies are lined up above his bed. One is a fake-metal bobblehead, and one has a little soccer ball that spins. He received each one for merely being on the roster.

title: At the Indie Spirits, Oscar Warm-Ups and Also-Ran Quips
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  12 Years a Slave was the top winner at the Indie Spirits here on Saturday, earning best picture, best director, best adapted screenplay and best supporting actress prizes.

title: Ukrainian Government Rushes to Dampen Secessionist Sentiment
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Ukraines besieged interim government raced to head off violence that might set off a Russian invasion of its eastern provinces on Sunday, recruiting wealthy eastern businessmen to become provincial governors in an effort to dampen secessionist sentiment there.

title: Growth and Interest Rates: I Appear To Be Wrong
description: In my last post I followed Floyd Norris in criticizing the CBO, which has marked down its estimates of future economic growth without marking down its estimates of future interest rates. I still think thats a fair criticism. But I also offered a hypothesis: that interest rates fall more than one-for-one with slower growth, so that the crucial difference r-g  interest rate minus growth rate  actually falls, making debt easier, not harder, to handle.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: War Among The Economists
description: I have real doubts about whether this class  at 8:30 AM tomorrow  is going to happen. I guess Ill be up at 6 shoveling out my driveway so I can get out if it does happen. Anyway, slides for the lecture (pdf) are posted.

description: Alain Resnais, the French filmmaker who helped introduce literary modernism to the movies and became an international art-house star with nonlinear narrative films like Hiroshima Mon Amour and Last Year at Marienbad, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 91.

But this weekend, music lovers in the New York area had rare opportunities to hear this historic player-run ensemble in its other official capacity: the pit band of the Vienna State Opera.

title: Excerpt: 'Stage Kiss'
description: A scene from the new Sarah Ruhl play at Playwrights Horizons.

title: Liam Neeson Tops Box Office Once Again With Non-Stop
description: Non-Stop, over the weekend leading into the Oscars, became the latest successful action movie starring Liam Neeson, taking in an estimated $30 million, for first place at the North American box office. Mr. Neeson, 61, improbably became one of Hollywoods leading action stars with Taken in 2009 after a career largely spent in higher-brow movies like Kinsey and Schindlers List.

title: Kerry Plans to Visit Ukraine in Show of Support and Warns Russia of Penalties
description: WASHINGTON  As Western governments scrambled on Sunday to respond to the Russian military advance in Ukraine, Secretary of State John Kerry made plans to visit Kiev on Tuesday in a gesture of support for the new Ukrainian government, a senior American official said.

title: Ukraine Turns to Its Oligarchs for Political Help
description: KIEV, Ukraine  As tensions rose on the streets of the Russian-speaking eastern portion of Ukraine, the response of the new government in the capital on Sunday was not to send troops, but to send rich people.

title: Backstage Beauty Report | Feeling Blue at Kenzo
description: Backstage at Kenzo, Aaron de Mey pulled his references from the world of David Lynch, who orchestrated the labels runway set design and soundtrack. Its inspired by the cinema, by Sherilyn Fenn, by Blue Velvet, de May explained of the brilliant blue eye. Im giving it a 50s feel with an arched eyebrow, and using an Yves Klein blue gel liner. That would be MAC Chromaline in Marine Ultra, boldly painted on in a thick stripe, with a lifted edge, using a small-angled MAC 263 brush. The eye area was otherwise untouched: lashes left uncurled, no mascara. For the rest of the face, de Mey applied pearlized cream highlighter on the cheekbones, Cupids bow and bridge of the nose; last, he misted the visage for a dewy finish. To match the eyes, the models nails were painted electric blue, using a velvet flocking-finish varnish that the manicurist had brought over from Japan.

title: Akris: Fall 2014 RTW
description: Paris

title: As One of Few Americans Left in England, Camerons Stock Is Rising
description: Since the inception of Major League Soccer in 1996, the league has served as a place for top young American players to begin their careers before eventually moving overseas to the elite leagues of Europe. The past year has seen a sharp departure from this pattern: several top Americans have elected to either sign new deals to remain in M.L.S. while others, like Michael Bradley and Clint Dempsey, have returned stateside while still in their prime.

title: Clashes Between Fans and Players Draw Greater Scrutiny
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  When New Mexico State left the court Saturday night, nobody ran for his life. When the buzzer sounded on a comfortable 72-57 victory over California State-Bakersfield before several hundred fans in a 10,000-seat arena, the host Aggies shook hands with their opponents and walked single file toward their locker room to the applause of a few friends and family members.

title: Oscars 2014: 12 Years A Slave Is Best Picture and Gravity Wins Seven Awards
description: The Times live-blogged the 86th Academy Awards, with interviews from the red carpet and backstage, video updates from David Carr and A. O. Scott, live commentary during the telecast, reviews of the nights best and worst looks and star turns, social media features and more.

title: Comme des Garons: Knit One, Curl One
description: PARIS  Like a Medusas head entwined with serpents, the body was covered from neck to thighs with fat twists of wool. The skeins were wrapped like sausages around the neck, shoulders and arms  maybe even the head. They finished at the point where pretty, patterned hose appeared, or where a pair of sparkly underpants peeped out.

title: Rare Mutation Kills Off Gene Responsible for Diabetes
description: A new study based on genetic testing of 150,000 people has found a rare mutation that protects even fat people from getting Type 2 diabetes. The effect is so pronounced  the mutation reduces risk by two-thirds  that it provides a promising new target for developing a drug to mimic the mutations effect.

title: Hundreds Face Arrest at Anti-Pipeline Protest
description: Updated, March 5, 11:26 a.m. | The United States Park Police on Sunday afternoon arrested hundreds of demonstrators participating in an act of civil disobedience in front of the White House to protest the proposed Keystone XL pipeline.

title: Its the Gas Gas Gas
description: Mostly a note to myself: short-run fluctuations in the inflation rate are more or less entirely about gasoline prices, which affect headline and even, to some extent, core inflation via their impact on costs. The picture:

title: Comment Etiquette: A Reminder
description: Every once in a while it seems necessary to put out a reminder of what you should and shouldnt be doing if you comment on this blog, or indeed anywhere at the Times.

title: Knicks Out of Answers as Fan Offers Suggestion
description: CHICAGO  Carmelo Anthony was stuck in the present when he saw a sign Sunday afternoon that predicted his future: Melo to Chicago. It was held by a fan of the Bulls, a team that was in the process of joining a conga line of opponents that have humiliated the Knicks this season.

title: Between the Liquid and Solid
description: Theres a new jazz group called the Spring Quartet, and thats spring as in the seasons muddy, generative part, not the pale and pretty part.

title: A Landmark Oscar Win for 12 Years a Slave
description: LOS ANGELES  In a triumph long deferred, 12 Years a Slave won the best picture Oscar at the 86th Academy Awards on Sunday night, the first time Hollywood conferred its top honor to the work of a black director.

title: Echo, Echo
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Happy Monday, everyone. Whos ready to get this week started?

title: Cameras Shooting in Battle: Five Auteurs and Their World War II Films
description: Mark Harris, a columnist at Entertainment Weekly and the author of the marvelous Pictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood, from 2008, bets again on his lucky number for an excursion into a very different motion picture revolution. Five Came Back, modestly subtitled A Story of Hollywood and the Second World War, is a tough-minded, information-packed and irresistibly readable work of movie-minded cultural criticism. Like the best World War II films, it highlights marquee names in a familiar plot to explore some serious issues: the human cost of military service, the hypnotic power of cinema and the tension between artistic integrity and the exigencies of war. Mr. Harris shows how  more than Technicolor, CinemaScope or even the collapse of the Production Code  World War II changed the way Americans looked at the movies.

title: Explorations With Moves and Words
description: Liz Casebolt and Joel Smith, two amiable Los Angeles choreographers who have worked together since 2006, have a mission: to demystify the choreographic process and make dance accessible. They strive to appeal, as Mr. Smith explained to an audience on Friday, to non-highfalutin dance communities.

title: Report Calls for Better Backstops to Protect Power Grid From Cyberattacks
description: WASHINGTON  Despite rising anxiety over the possibility of a cyberattack on the power grid, the industry and government are not set up well to counter the threat, according to a report produced by leading energy security experts. Companies are reluctant to share information with one other, a critical step in reducing vulnerability, because they are afraid of being accused of failing to comply with cybersecurity rules, committing antitrust violations or giving away proprietary information, the report found.
