description: Paige Joost likes the awkward, nave, but dark quality she sees in the themes of Wes Anderson, the fabulist moviemaker, and she loves the washed-out Polaroid palette he often works in, which reminds her of the 1970s, a place she has never visited.

title: Justices May Limit Securities Fraud Suits
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday seemed ready to impose new limits on securities fraud suits that would make it harder for investors to band together to pursue claims that they were misled when they bought or sold securities. But the justices did not seem inclined to issue a ruling that would put an end to most such suits.

title: Examining a Generation Tied to Smartphones
description: SO attached to their cellphones are 18- to 24-year-olds that 61 percent of them sleep next to their devices, compared with just 22 percent of cellphone owners over 65 who do so, according to the Pew Research Center. While that might depress those who yearn for simpler times, such devotion delights AT&T, and now the phone carrier is introducing a major effort that highlights how connected young Americans are to their devices.

title: Massachusetts: Ruling Favors Man Accused of Taking Upskirt Images
description: The State Supreme Judicial Court ruledWednesdaythat a law prohibiting the secret photographing of nude or partly nude people who could reasonably expect privacy does not apply to upskirt photos taken of clothed people in public. The court ruled in the case of Michael Robertson, who was arrested in 2010 and accused of taking cellphone photos and videos of womens crotches on the Boston subway. The ruling reversed a lower courts denial of his motion to dismiss the case. House Speaker Robert A. DeLeo pledged to update state law to conform with todays technology.

title: Break It and No Allowance
description: In one corner of the room, playing on a thin glass screen dangling from the ceiling by wires, was a moody animated video from The Last Clown installation by the artist Francis Alys on a continuous loop: a solitary man making his way along a path in an anonymous park.

title: De Blasio Drops Challenge to Law on Police Profiling
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Wednesday that his administration would drop a lawsuit against the City Council, brought in the waning months of the Bloomberg administration, that sought to block a new law intended to prevent police profiling in New York.

title: Illinois: Council Goes on Record to Oppose Honor for Eliot Ness
description: Passing a symbolic resolution Wednesday, Chicagos City Council unanimously opposed naming a federal building in Washington after Eliot Ness, the Prohibition-era agent whose team of lawmen in Chicago inspired The Untouchables book, movie and television series. Three United States senators have proposed naming the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives headquarters after Ness, who is often credited with bringing the mobster Al Capone to justice. Critics of the plan say Ness does not deserve the honor because his role in imprisoning Capone, who was convicted of tax evasion, has been exaggerated.

title: After a Dazzling Early Career, a Star Trader Settles Down
description: When Paul Tudor Jones II began his career as a Wall Street trader in the 1980s, some colleagues spoke admiringly of his ability to shoot the lights out by scoring huge profits on big market swings.

title: Banned in Bangalore
description: CHICAGO  LAST month a retired Hindu schoolteacher named Dinanath Batra, who had brought a lawsuit against me and Penguin Books, India, succeeded in getting my book, The Hindus: An Alternative History, withdrawn from publication in India. The book, the court agreed, was a violation of Indias blasphemy law, which makes it a crime to offend the sensibilities of a religious person.

title: Yankees Will Assess Tanaka and Teixeira (and Technology)
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  Spring training usually signals several firsts for clubs, and for the Yankees it will be no different Thursday.

title: Florida: Woman Drives Van With Children Into Ocean
description: The authorities in Daytona Beach are investigating an episode in which a pregnant woman drove her minivan into the Atlantic Ocean with her three children strapped in the back seat. Sheriff Ben F. Johnson of Volusia County said officials would interview the woman, who was in the hospital Wednesday and would undergo a mental health evaluation, before determining whether there was criminal intent or a mental health crisis in the episode on Tuesday. Her children were in state custody. Video showed the woman walk away as bystanders and rescuers rushed to pull her children to safety while the van bobbed in the surf. No one was seriously injured.

title: In Health Care, Choice Is Overrated
description: LAST spring, a 48-year-old mother of two young girls in Colorado discovered that she had colon cancer. Her surgeon and oncologist disagreed about whether she needed chemotherapy. So a friend recommended she go to MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston for a second opinion. Just before she booked her plane ticket, a representative from MD Anderson called, informing her that its oncologists were outside her insurance companys network and that she should bring $10,000 for the consultation.

title: Heroin Scourge Overtakes a Quaint Vermont Town
description: BENNINGTON, Vt.  Stephanie Predel, a stick-thin 23-year-old freshly out of jail, said she was off heroin. But she knows precisely where she could get more drugs if she ever wanted them  at the support meetings for addicts.

title: A Call for General Motors to Fill Gaps in Safety Inquiry
description: Federal safety regulators indicated on Wednesday that General Motors had yet to turn over significant information related to a defective ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths and the recall of 1.6 million cars.

title: Governing Party Candidate Pulls Out of Costa Ricas Presidential Campaign
description: Sinking in the polls a month before Costa Ricas presidential election, Johnny Araya, the candidate for the countrys governing party, pulled out of the campaign on Wednesday. Although his name remains on the ballot, Mr. Araya effectively conceded the election to Luis Guillermo Sols, a history professor and former Foreign Ministry official from the progressive Citizens Action Party. Under President Laura Chinchilla, the centrist National Liberation Party had become deeply unpopular over corruption scandals and increasing crime.

title: Tracy McGrady Hopes to Trade Slam Dunks for Sliders
description: SUGAR LAND, Tex.  Tracy McGradys training began in early November, but it was not geared toward a return to the basketball court  it was to fulfill a nagging dream of playing professional baseball.

title: Republicans Place the Wrong Bet
description: Republicans may have bet too heavily on the wrong issue going into the midterm elections.

title: Army General Offers Plea to Narrow Assault Case
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  Hoping to narrow his court-martial to a showdown with a woman who accused him of sexual assault, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair said on Wednesday that he would plead guilty to less serious counts of misconduct, including adultery, soliciting explicit images and impeding an investigation.

title: Billion Dollar Babies
description: The Koch brothers are in the news more than Justin Bieber.

title: Cat in Albany Is Outfoxing New York Citys Mouse
description: Maybe the problem was with the metaphor.

title: Pakistans Talks With Taliban Resume
description: Public contact between the representatives of the Taliban and Pakistani government resumed on Wednesday as Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif made another push to put a wavering peace dialogue back on track. Mr. Sharif has invited a team of Taliban representatives to his official residence in Islamabad on Thursday, according to government officials. Maulana Sami ul-Haq, a religious leader who represents the Taliban, said he has accepted the invitation and would discuss ways to carry the peace talks forward. Earlier, committees representing the government and the Taliban met at Mr. Haqs seminary in northwestern town Akora Khattak, the first such meeting since Feb.17, when talks were suspended after a faction of the Taliban claimed responsibility for the killing of 23 paramilitary soldiers. Despite a Taliban announcement of a cease-fire, terrorist attacks have continued across the country in recent days and have been claimed by obscure militant groups. The latest attack occurred Wednesday in northwestern Hangu district where a roadside bomb killed six paramilitary soldiers and wounded eight others.

title: Whos the Villain Here?
description: Shrewd reporting about the Ukraine crisis comes from The Onion, which declared that American reaction is evenly divided  between the wholly indifferent and the grossly misinformed.

title: Two Arrested at Brooklyn Bank With A.T.M. Fraud Device
description: It was meant to be a quick crime, the police said: Place a skimming machine over the card reader outside a Chase branch after dark, stick a couple of cameras above the keypads on the cash machines inside and wait to collect the numbers from unsuspecting customers.

title: Ukraine Defeats United States in an Exhibition With Deeper Meaning
description: LARNACA, Cyprus  It is often said that exhibition matches are played only for pride, but that is rarely true. Someone is always playing for something.

title: Israels Choice
description: In Washington this week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel sounded two different notes about peace negotiations with the Palestinians, which are nearing a critical juncture. In a speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the pro-Israel lobby, he enthusiastically advocated a peace agreement as a means to improve Israels ties with its Arab neighbors and catapult the region forward on issues like health, energy and education.

title: Video of Pregnant Woman Who Drove Minivan Into the Atlantic
description: A pregnant woman who was captured on video driving her minivan with three children in it into the Atlantic Ocean in Daytona Beach, Fla., remained in the hospital Wednesday, undergoing a mental health evaluation, law enforcement officials said.

title: Snow Mania
description: What did Spring Festival mean to a child like me, growing up in rural China in the early 1970s, in the aftermath of the Cultural Revolution? Chocolate? Not at a time when even table sugar was a luxury good. We hadnt even heard of chocolate. Candy? Impossible. How could a poor family like ours, which was never even issued the official ration coupons, purchase it? Rice, then? No, not even that.

title: Bin Laden Aide Began Qaeda Propaganda Day After 9/11, U.S. Says
description: It was just hours after the Sept. 11 attacks when Osama bin Laden turned to an associate for help in rallying his troops and recruiting new suicide bombers and other fighters, a federal prosecutor told a jury on Wednesday.

title: To Spur Traffic at News Sites, Just Travoltify
description: Which of the following interactive features drove record traffic to its respective news sites in recent months: a) How Much Time Have You Wasted on Facebook? for Time; b) The interactive dialect quiz for The New York Times; c) The Adele Dazeem Generator: Travoltify Your Name, which appeared on Slate; or d) all of the above?

title: Jail Sentence in France Over Cyber Jihad
description: A French convert to Islam was convicted of using the Internet to disseminate terrorist propaganda and promote participation in terrorist acts and was sentenced by a Paris court to one year in prison and two more on probation late Tuesday. The case is the first using a law passed in 2012 that makes cyber jihad a crime and potentially has serious consequences for freedom of expression in France. The law was passed in response to the attacks in Toulouse by Mohammed Merah, who killed seven people including three children and apparently was inspired in part by extremist Internet postings. The maximum sentence in Tuesdays case could have been five years in prison, and the relatively light term given to Romain Letellier, 27, suggested that both prosecutors and judges were still considering how to apply the new law. The prosecutor said that the trial was happening in a context where young people become radicalized rapidly after reading material on the Internet.

title: China Remodels an Ancient Silk Road City, and an Ethnic Rift Widens
description: KASHGAR, China  Visitors walking through the mud-brick rubble and yawning craters where close-packed houses and bazaars once stood could be forgiven for thinking that the ancient Silk Road city of Kashgar had been irrevocably lost to the wrecking ball. A billboard looming over the ruins tries to counter that impression: Inherit and preserve the historical culture to showcase a brand new Kashgar.

title: Saratoga Springs Voices Opposition to Casino Law
description: ALBANY  In a symbolic rebuke from the leaders of a gambling-rich upstate enclave, the Saratoga Springs City Council unanimously passed a resolution this week declaring its opposition to a new state law that could permit a full-scale casino in their town.

title: Colluding Against Programmers
description: A class action lawsuit brought on behalf of software programmers and other technical professionals against seven large employers in Silicon Valley, including Apple and Google, has lifted the curtain on secret, anti-competitive deals that would warm the hearts of robber barons from the Gilded Age.

title: Officials Investigating Spending by Director of Queens Library
description: The director of the Queens Library system is under investigation after reports that he may have improperly used money designated for improving the libraries in the system for costly renovations to his personal office, including a private outdoor deck, and steered contracts for the work to a friend.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for March 5, 2014
description: March 5, 2014

title: One Year After Chvezs Death, a Divide in Venezuelans Fervor
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In the year since the death of Hugo Chvez, this countrys longtime socialist president, one thing has remained constant: He is still loved and hated with almost equal fervor.

title: Venezuela Honors Chvez One Year Later
description: Venezuelans marked the first anniversary of the death of Hugo Chvez with a military parade in Caracas.

title: After the Veto
description: Once Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona yielded to the countrys political, business and sports establishment last week and vetoed the nasty measure known as S.B. 1062, the furor died down. The bill would have offered a legal defense for business owners who claim a religious reason for failing to abide by nondiscrimination laws in their dealings with the public. But the question remains what lesson to draw from the outcome of this particular effort to privilege claims of religious conscience over the general societal principle of nondiscrimination.

title: Shakespeare Hits the Beach
description: You know that Caribbean vacation youve been dreaming about in these last draggy days of winter? Well, you may want to rethink such fantasies after you see the Tarell Alvin McCraneys squishy, misbegotten Antony and Cleopatra, which resets Shakespeares tragedy on the island of Hispaniola during the reign of the French.

title: Scrub Up
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Erno RUBIK, the Hungarian architect who is best known for inventing the Rubiks Cube, once said that the problems of puzzles are very near the problems of life.

title: Time for David Samson to Go
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey fired two associates involved in creating a four-day traffic jam at the George Washington Bridge to punish Fort Lees Democratic mayor, apologized for the mess and agreed to cooperate with various related investigations.

title: Computer Searches at Center of Dispute on C.I.A. Detentions
description: WASHINGTON  For four years, investigators working for the Senate Intelligence Committee toiled away at a secret facility in Northern Virginia, poring over C.I.A. documents in an attempt to compile a history of the agencys detention and interrogation program. Outfitted with secure computers and encrypted locks, it was set up by the C.I.A. so that the committee staff members could review millions of highly classified documents and stitch together a report that would eventually grow to 6,000 pages.

title: StubHub to Penalize Ticket Sellers Trying to Cash In on Jeter
description: Cashing in on Derek Jeter just got more expensive.

title: Court Says Massachusetts Law Doesnt Ban Photos Up Skirts
description: BOSTON  Massachusetts highest court ruled Wednesday that a law prohibiting the secret photographing of nude or partly nude people does not apply to upskirting  taking photos of areas beneath peoples clothes  in public.

title: In Iraq, Celebration and Then Violence
description: While Iraqis were enjoying the victory of the national soccer team with celebratory gunfire, gunmen took advantage of the sounds of the shooting and opened fire on three police checkpoints in Baghdad, killing seven officers, according to police sources. Iraqs national soccer team had just defeated China, 3-1, to advance in the Asian Cup championship in Australia. Earlier Wednesday, the city witnessed a wave of six car bombings that killed at least 18 civilians and wounded more than 50 in public markets in Shiite neighborhoods, security forced said. In Anbar Province, two suicide bombers drove into two security checkpoints and killed at least ten officers, the government said.

title: Now Wearing No. 13 for the Mets, Another Mazzilli
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  When L. J. Mazzilli arrived at the Mets minor league complex for spring training last week, his blue jersey was already hanging in his locker. Mazzilli, No. 13, it read. He had not known that his name would be on it. And that he would be wearing one of his fathers old numbers, for one of his fathers old teams. And that it would be a real number, not some absurdly high one, like 75 or 63, that rarely shows up in the regular season. Ecstatic, he snapped a photo and sent it to his parents.

title: No Longer Clashing, Wearable Tech Embraces Fashion
description: WEARABLE electronics have been stuck in a design rut. Bulky watches, bright wristbands and Roman-gladiator-meets-the-Jetsons arm straps have been the go-to look for manufacturers like Nike and Jawbone.

title: A Smartwatch Gains Some Style, but Few New Tricks
description: THE Pebble smartwatch ignited interest in watches that put the functions of your phone  texts, calls, emails, calendar and even apps  on your wrist. The second version of the Pebble, called Pebble Steel, is at once more grown-up and less useful than it should be.

title: New Democratic Strategy Goes After Koch Brothers
description: WASHINGTON  Charles G. and David H. Koch, the billionaire brothers who are perhaps the best-known patrons of conservative Republican politics, are bespectacled and in their 70s. They look genial enough.

title: 10 Students Who Overcame Odds Are Awarded Times Scholarships
description: Most of Brianna Albaneses goals sound like those of other promising, bright-eyed students headed for college next year: A lover of science fiction and a writer for her high school literary magazine, she wants to study psychology and literature in college. Someday, she said, she will write her own books.

title: When the Doctor Is No Longer the Boss

description: The Islanders traded the high-scoring left wing Thomas Vanek to the Montreal Canadiens on Wednesday, just over four months after acquiring him from the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Debate Over Who, in U.S., Is to Blame for Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  In Moscow, especially in the not-so-good old days, the question almost always asked is kto vinovat: Who is to blame? The American capital now finds itself engaged in that very Russian exercise ever since President Vladimir V. Putins troops entered Ukraine.

title: Kevin Love Continues to Put Up Big Numbers
description: MINNEAPOLIS  More than three years ago, on the night of his greatest triumph as an N.B.A. player, Minnesota Timberwolves forward Kevin Love walked into the Loon, a sports bar down the street from the Target Center, to a conquerers welcome.

title: For Russian TV Channels, Influence and Criticism
description: MOSCOW  The conflict in Ukraine can be difficult to sort out, but on the most recent edition of Vesti Nedeli, Russias most popular evening news program, a sober-voiced announcer broke it down into very simple terms. Experts, he intoned, are more and more comparing the actions of these nationalists with those who came to power in Germany in the 1930s.

title: Nets Burst to an Early Lead, Then Cruise Past .500
description: The Nets have worked relentlessly to dig themselves out of the hole they created early in the season. On Wednesday night, with a 103-94 win over the Memphis Grizzlies at Barclays Center, they can finally call themselves a winning team, with a record of 30-29.

title: An Evacuation of Jews, With Help From Japan
description: It is not the usual subject for a tourism video: how Japanese officials  including a Japanese diplomat in Lithuania and an employee of a tourist bureau  helped Jews flee the Nazis just before World War II.

title: The Americans Recap: A Fake Rock and a Fake Relationship (or Two)
description: So last season The Americans offered up a camera hidden in a bra, and in Season 2s latest episode, it goes a step further with what is perhaps the hoariest of spy gadgets: the hollow, fake rock carrying secret data.

title: Knicks End Skid, but Its Still a Struggle
description: MINNEAPOLIS  In the midst of an introspective interview at the morning shootaround Wednesday, in which he maintained he was still the right man to coach the Knicks, Mike Woodson succinctly broke down his nose-diving teams biggest problem.

title: Pope Moves to Deflate Breathless Portrayals of Stardom
description: ROME  Declaring his frustrations with being portrayed as a superman or a star, Pope Francis used an interview to depict himself as a normal person who laughs, cries and misses his ailing sister, while defending the Roman Catholic Churchs handling of the clerical sexual-abuse scandal and reiterating his belief that women should play a larger role in church decision making.

title: Mystery Men at De Facto Crimean Border Help Fuel Suspicion and Dread
description: ARMYANSK, Ukraine  If anyone wonders if Russia and its supporters in Crimea are serious about holding on to territory that is still formally part of Ukraine, the de facto border checkpoint near this shabby garrison town on the northern edge of the peninsula dispels any doubt.

description: McALLEN, Tex.  There was no Ted Cruz, coming out of nowhere in a blaze of Tea Party fervor, to upend the establishment in a marquee race when Texas Republicans went to the polls Tuesday in the nations first round of 2014 primaries.

title: Friends. New Yorkers. Countrymen.
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio praise each other publicly, insisting that they disagree only on the means to achieve more prekindergarten education for New York, not upon the ends.

title: Observing Ash Wednesday
Golfers Will to Win Gets a Boost From Pit Crews for Aching Bodies
description: DORAL, Fla.  Winning multiple PGA Tour titles is hard, even if Tiger Woods made it look ridiculously easy as recently as last year, when he collected five titles in 16 starts to raise his career total to 79. The Australian Jason Day, a two-time tour winner, suggested that Woods, in his drive to become golfs career leader in tour wins and major championships, developed an automatic pilot that few athletes could access.

title: Point by Point, State Department Rebuts Putin on Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials watched President Vladimir V. Putins defiant news conference on Tuesday with barely concealed scorn. Time after time, they argued, Mr. Putin had distorted reality.

title: London SE8 3JF

title: A Post-Fashion-Week Pampering Getaway
description: Tulum, a walled seaside city on the southern edge of Mexicos Riviera Maya, has long been a popular getaway for the fashion set and yoga enthusiasts. Now, serious spa devotees are also flocking to the luxe oceanside hotel there, Be Tulum, thanks to the recent opening of Yaan Energy Wellness Spa. Guests like Demi Moore, Sting and his wife, Trudie Styler, have been among the first to receive massage, Mayan healing and energy treatments in one of the five new personal cabins on-site, which are situated across from the hotel on the jungle side of the road. A designer friend says it looks like some extraterrestrials came to Tulum to do a co-venture with the Mayans, says Sebastian Sas, an Argentinian architect and Be Tulums owner.

title: One Goal in Hand, Kievs Demonstrators Vow to Stay Until the End
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Vasil V. Puhalskyi, a farmer scarred about the face and ringed by veterans of the lethal street clashes here last month, offered an explanation for why, even after chasing President Viktor F. Yanukovych from power, he and his friends had fortified their barricades anew.

title: Picking Up the Pace at the S.E.C.

title: Francis Has Changed American Catholics Attitudes, but Not Their Behavior, a Poll Finds
description: One year into the era of Pope Francis, a new poll has found that a broad majority of American Catholics say he represents a major change in direction for the church, and a change for the better. But his popularity has not inspired more Americans to attend Mass, go to confession or identify as Catholic  a finding that suggests that so far, the much-vaunted Francis effect is influencing attitudes, but not behavior.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 7:40 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE LADY (2012) In this biopic from the director Luc Besson, Michelle Yeoh, left, portrays the Burmese opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who was elected to Parliament in April 2012 after more than 20 years of house arrest. She came from her home in England in 1988 to what is now Myanmar to tend her dying mother. When asked, she refused to leave the country and was arrested. Though she is isolated in her familys compound in the capital, Suu is not alone in The Lady, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. While it is a chronicle of political courage, the film is also a love story, illuminating the remarkable relationship between Suu and her husband, a British academic named Michael Aris, (David Thewlis), who has received a terminal cancer diagnosis. Tears are shed, but no inkling of doubt or tension is allowed to penetrate the aura of idealistic selflessness that shrouds Suu and Michael, Mr. Scott added. One result is a film that is programmatically inspirational but not quite as inspiring as it should be.

title: Cuomo Burnishes His Political Brand, Using de Blasio as His Foil
description: ALBANY  In his first two months in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio has found himself repeatedly at odds with New Yorks governor, Andrew M. Cuomo. And at every turn, Governor Cuomo has not only stymied the mayor, but also seized the moment for his own gain.

title: Charges Dropped Against Briton Accused of Transmitting Tennis Scores
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australian officials dropped a charge Thursday against a man who had been accused of illegally relaying information from the Australian Open for the possible benefit of bettors elsewhere, the police said.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: North Korea Rejects Plans for More Family Reunions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Thursday rejected South Koreas proposal to hold Red Cross talks to discuss arranging more family reunions families separated by the Korean War to meet long-lost relatives members for the first time in six decades.

title: U.S. Airstrike Kills 5 Afghan Soldiers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American airstrike killed five Afghan National Army soldiers and wounded eight more Thursday morning, according to Afghan and American officials.

title: Blowing Away the Smog in Beijing, Politically Speaking
description: With blue skies, sunshine and clean air in Beijing this week  all rare commodities now that oppressive smog has become the new normal  a joke is making the rounds that has many Chinese chortling.

title: Crimea Vote Deepens Crisis and Draws Denunciations
description: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine  The pro-Russian regional Parliament in Crimea voted behind closed doors on Thursday to secede from Ukraine and become part of Russia  an aspirational, even quixotic, gesture that had no immediate practical effect but deepened the political crisis here, drawing swift denunciations from the West and from the fledgling national government in Kiev.

title: Beijing Goes Quiet on Rise of Local Security Budgets
description: Xie Yue is a political science scholar at Tongji University in Shanghai who has spent years studying the budgets and expenditures of local governments in China. More people are scrutinizing such figures, because the financial practices of local governments can have profound effects on the structural integrity of the Chinese economy, the lives of ordinary Chinese and the legitimacy of the Communist Party.

title: Chinese Workers at IBM Factory on Strike Amid Company Sale
description: HONG KONG  More than 1,000 workers have gone on strike this week at an IBM factory in southeastern China in the latest sign of labor activism as companies acute shortage of blue-collar workers makes employees increasingly willing to take to the streets.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 6, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: Hilary Mantel Stage Adaptations Headed to the West End
description: LONDON  The Royal Shakespeare Companys stage adaptations of Hilary Mantels award-winning novels about Thomas Cromwell will transfer from Stratford-upon-Avon to the West End here on May 1, the Royal Shakespeare Company and Playful Productions announced today. Ms. Mantels historical novels, Wolf Hall (2009) and Bring Up the Bodies, (2012), which earned her two Man-Booker prizes, chart the rise to power of Cromwell, Henry VIIIs deal-maker and right-hand man. They have sold close to two million copies in the U.K, and their stage adaptation, by Mike Poulton, has attracted packed houses since the Royal Shakespeare Company began to perform the plays, directed by Jeremy Herrin in December last year. The Stratford-upon-Avon run closes on Mar. 29. A bright, bustling political soap opera that, condenses more than a thousand pages of fiction into two plays and a brisk six hours of stage time, Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic, wrote in his review in The New York Times.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Major Changes in SAT Announced by College Board
description: In Major Changes in SAT Announced by College Board, Tamar Lewin reports on a new redesign for the college entrance exam.

title: The Story Behind the SAT Overhaul
description: In July 2012, a few months before he was to officially take over as president of the College Board, David Coleman invited Les Perelman, then a director of writing at M.I.T., to come meet with him in Lower Manhattan. Of the many things the College Board does  take part in research, develop education policy, create curriculums  it is perhaps most recognized as the organization that administers the SAT, and Perelman was one of the exams harshest and most relentless critics. Since 2005, when the College Board added an essay to the SAT (raising the total possible score from 1,600 to 2,400), Perelman had been conducting research that highlighted what he believed were the inherent absurdities in how the essay questions were formulated and scored. His earliest findings showed that length, more than any other factor, correlated with a high score on the essay. More recently, Perelman coached 16 students who were retaking the test after having received mediocre scores on the essay section. He told them that details mattered but factual accuracy didnt. You can tell them the War of 1812 began in 1945, he said. He encouraged them to sprinkle in little-used but fancy words like plethora or myriad and to use two or three preselected quotes from prominent figures like Franklin Delano Roosevelt, regardless of whether they were relevant to the question asked. Fifteen of his pupils scored higher than the 90th percentile on the essay when they retook the exam, he said.

title: Deutsche Telekom and Orange Post Weaker Quarterly Pretax Earnings
description: LONDON  Two of Europes largest telecommunications companies, Deutsche Telekom and Orange, reported declines in their quarterly pretax profits on Thursday, as the industry grapples with a new round of consolidation and ongoing regulatory uncertainty.

title: What Did You Once Hate but Now Like?
description: A recent article in the Dining section suggests that there are no foods that we dont like, just foods that we havent liked yet. What do you think? Are there foods  or other things  that you hated when you were younger but now enjoy? Why do you think your tastes changed?

title: Niger Extradites a Son of Qaddafi to Libya, Saying He Didnt Stay Quiet
description: CAIRO  Niger on Thursday extradited Saadi el-Qaddafi, the third son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, back to Libya, where he is accused of participating in the corruption and abuses of his fathers more than 40-year rule.

description: Good Thursday morning in this freezing, somewhat safer city.

title: A Call From My Friend in Afghanistan
description: About once a month, when he has a little extra money, my friend Daoud calls me from Kabul. He always asks the same question: What is America going to do in Afghanistan after 2014? He thinks I must know more than he does, because I live in the United States.

description: MILAN  The Oprichniks were the murderous henchmen of Ivan the Terrible, torturing and killing the czars enemies.

title: Iris van Herpen: Fearless and Approachable
description: PARIS  The discomfiting sight of three women, each laid vertically inside a giant hanging plastic bag, legs squirming and head thrown back to gasp the air pumped from a hefty pipe, was the overwhelming image of Iris van Herpens show in Paris. The scene sucked the attention away from the clothes, yet at the same time the images of the three figures seemed mesmerizing.

title: Making Cloud-Computing Systems More Efficient
description: Computer scientists at Stanford have developed software that works like the recommendation engines for Amazon shoppers and Netflix movie subscribers, only for the distribution of workloads across large computing environments. The results, they say, can triple the efficiency of cloud-computing systems.

title: M.B.A. Students Hit the Road to Help Small-Business Owners
description: At a party in the fall of 2012, Casey Gerald, Michael Baker, Amaris Singer and Hicham Mhammedi Alaoui  all first-year students at Harvard Business School  were talking about potential summer jobs. We thought, What if we ditch the cubicle and spend the next summer on the road learning from and working with entrepreneurs?  Mr. Gerald said.

title: Bank of England Keeps Benchmark Rate at Record Low
description: LONDON  The Bank of England on Thursday decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low, as Britains economic recovery continues and inflation appears to be stable.

title: Daily Report: To Ensure a Secure Future, Bitcoin Might Need Oversight
description: Nearly half a billion dollars has gone missing, and nobody knows how, Farhad Manjoo reports. Some say there was outright theft. Others suspect fraud. Many blame lax controls, poor oversight and, above all, a reckless, globe-spanning, Wild West culture  a culture that everyone agrees is ripe for wholesale reform.

title: Clinton Ratchets Up Criticism of Putin and Backs Obama
description: LOS ANGELES  Hillary Rodham Clinton continued her sharp condemnation of Russian President Vladamir V. Putin here on Wednesday, calling him a tough guy with a thin skin and saying she supports the Obama administrations call for Russia to resist further intervention in neighboring Ukraine.

title: Vivendi Gets Bids for SFR From Bouygues and Altice
description: LONDON  The French media and telecommunications conglomerate Vivendi said on Thursday that it had received offers for SFR, its cellphone unit, that could value the business at more than $20 billion.

title: European Central Bank Holds Rates Steady
description: FRANKFURT  Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, offered a spirited defense of the wisdom of doing nothing Thursday. That was after he and his fellow policy makers dashed expectations for an interest-rate cut or other action to stimulate the still ailing euro zone economy.

title: More Trouble For a Once-Mighty Law Firm
description: Three former top executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the giant law firm that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2012, are expected to be charged on Thursday with misleading other lawyers and lenders about the financial health of the firm, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. The details of the charges are still unclear, but two people said the lawyers might be accused of grand larceny.

title: Lloyds Bank Seeks to Swap More Than $8 Billion of Bonds
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group said on Thursday that it would offer to exchange as much as 5 billion pounds worth of bonds it issued to shore up its capital during the financial crisis for new securities or cash.

title: A Climate Analyst Clarifies the Science Behind Californias Water Woes
description: Theres no question that residents of California and much of the West face a collision between high water demands driven by growth and outdated policies and a limited and highly variable water supply.

title: A Dog and His Boy Take a Joy Ride Through History
description: If you think of Mr. Peabody & Sherman as the latest attempt to turn small-screen baby boomer nostalgia into big-screen fun, you have plenty of reason to be afraid. Hollywoods obsession with cashing in on old television shows has yielded a grim harvest  remember Nicole Kidman in Bewitched? Sorry to have reminded you  and the work of Jay Ward has been singled out for particular abuse.

title: Let the Conservative Circus Begin!
description: Did you wake up this morning wondering what would happen at the Conservative Political Action Conference? No? Good, youre a normal person. CPAC, like Christmas, only comes once a year. Its an occasion for far-flung conservatives to come together in the Washington, D.C., area and snuggle in that big tent theyre always talking about. At CPAC, conservatives take stock of all things right wing and set the tone for the year ahead. Theres nothing like it on the liberal side, unless you count Burning Man.

If youre a parent and spend any time on social media, its been hard to avoid her essay, which millions of people have now read.

description: The New York Police Department, under the leadership of a new commissioner who cut his teeth in the city tackling subway crime, has already begun ramping up arrests of panhandlers and peddlers in the transit system, according to newly available department statistics.

description: Ukraines economy minister, Pavlo Sheremeta, said that a planned referendum on whether Crimea should become part of Russia was unconstitutional.

title: Bittersweet Chocolate on the Pillow
description: Its a tough choice, but if I had to pick the most Wes Anderson moment in The Grand Budapest Hotel, it would be the part when inmates escape from a prison using tiny sledgehammers and pickaxes that have been smuggled past the guards inside fancy frosted pastries. This may, come to think of it, be the most Wes Anderson thing ever, the very quintessence of his impish, ingenious and oddly practical imagination. So much care has been lavished on the conceit and its execution that you can only smile in admiration, even if you are also rolling your eyes a little.

description: Ben Uretsky, the chief executive of a cloud computing start-up called DigitalOcean, uttered what may be the ultimate Silicon Valley humblebrag when he explained why his company had to raise millions from venture capitalists just months after an earlier financing round.

description: Middle and high school students who used electronic cigarettes were more likely to smoke real cigarettes and less likely to quit than students who did not use the devices, a new study has found. They were also more likely to smoke heavily. But experts are divided about what the findings mean.

title: Senate Rejects Blocking Military Commanders From Sexual Assault Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday rejected a controversial bipartisan bill to remove military commanders from decisions over the prosecution of sexual assault cases in the armed forces, delivering a defeat to advocacy groups that argued that wholesale changes are necessary to combat an epidemic of rapes and sexual assaults in the military.

title: Why This Isnt Chinas Bear Stearns Moment
description: Once again, investors are facing warnings about Chinas Bear Stearns moment.

title: 36 Hours in Raleigh, N.C.
description: Raleigh has traditionally been lumped with Durham and Chapel Hill as part of the Research Triangle  the land of science, technology and, in the run-up to this months N.C.A.A. tournament, college basketball. But this geographic shorthand has become increasingly outdated in recent years, as each city has developed a distinct personality. Today, North Carolinas capital is awash in entrepreneurial energy from homegrown clothing labels and converted art galleries to craft breweries and ambitious restaurants. More than merely one of the Triangles three vertexes, Raleigh is now defining itself as a destination worth exploring on its own merits, regardless of what lies beyond the city limits.

title: King Kong Out, On the Town In, at Foxwoods Theater  Now Renamed the Lyric
description: Broadways next mega-budget show, the Australian musical King Kong, will no longer open as planned at the Foxwoods Theater next winter, which will instead become home to a revival of the musical comedy On the Town, the producers of both shows said in separate statements on Thursday. At the same time, the theaters new leaseholders announced they were renaming the 1,900-seat house  one of Broadways biggest  to the Lyric.

title: Experiencing New Orleans With Fresh Eyes and Ears
description: On a recent Monday night the usual suspects gathered at BJs, a dive in the Ninth Ward of New Orleans. They were there, as many are every Monday, to see one of the citys premier bands, King James & the Special Men. Grizzled rockers in leather jackets leaned against the worn walls, smoking. Regulars hunched over the sticky bar drinking cheap draft beer. A group of clean-cut guys on a bachelor party binge swayed unsteadily near a vat of free red beans and rice and eyed a klatch of college girls in fluorescent hair and fishnets.

title: Kashmiri Students Briefly Charged With Sedition for Rooting for Wrong Cricket Team

title: Image of the Day: March 6
Issa Hands Democrats Weapon to Use on Him
description: WASHINGTON  Since Republicans took control of the House in 2011, Representative Darrell Issa has tried gamely to play the thoughtful, even-tempered investigator, even as he has accused the Obama administration of the most heinous crimes: thuggery, political witch hunts, even homicide, in the case of Benghazi.

title: On View | The Private Works of a Gallerist Who Changed Art Forever
description: These days, art dealers are almost as important as the artists whose careers they cultivate. But just one  Alexander Iolas  can be credited with mounting Andy Warhols first and last gallery show in his lifetime, bringing Surrealism to the United States and introducing the East Coast to Ed Ruscha. Unlike Iolass contemporaries  who included Ileana Sonnabend, Leo Castelli and Bruno Bischofberger  Iolass legacy has nearly faded into obscurity after he succumbed to AIDS in 1987 at 80, but a new exhibition may change that.

description: Battered in the press over his position on charter schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday took to a friendly news outlet to defend himself and argue that his actions were being distorted.

title: Red Bull Music Academy to Return to New York
description: It turns out New York wont have to wait long for the next Red Bull Music Academy, an innovative and semi-educational series of concerts, lectures, workshops, D.J. sets and other happenings that takes root in a different city every year, and came to New York last May. description: The photographer and author of Open City and Every Day Is for the Thief says the novel is overrated. The writers I find most interesting find ways to escape it.

title: Caucus Click: Coburns Got a Gun
A Silent Killer of Women  Suicide
description: There is an epidemic silent killer of women and girls in the developing world that nobody is talking about and its not malaria, HIV, or childbirth. The leading killer of girls and women of childbearing age (15-49) in countries like India and Nepal is, actually, suicide. A 2013 British Medical Journal analysis estimates a 126 percent rise in suicide among women between 1990 and 2010.

title: Living With Cancer: Finding Calm in the Storm
description: Every Sunday evening, I phone a friend in another college town who has not yet found a cancer support group in her community. Lets call her Melanie. Melanie had recovered from surgery and completed chemotherapy. Physically, she had gained strength. Yet she continued to feel overwhelmed by negative thoughts.

title: Russia Today Anchor Resigns on Air
description: A Washington-based anchor from Russia Today, Liz Wahl, resigned on air, stating that she could not be part of a network funded by the Russian government that whitewashes the actions of Putin.

title: On Persecution
description: In my Sunday column, I wrote about the possible culture-war scenarios that await us once same-sex unions are recognized as marriages from sea to shining sea, and contemplated the kinds of pressure, legal and otherwise, that might be brought to bear against individuals and institutions that hew to the older understanding of matrimony. (This contemplation was occasioned by Jan Brewers veto of Arizonas religious-liberty bill last week, which followed a massive and massively misleading media campaign against the legislation.) Along the way, I included the following comment, trying to contextualize the kinds of pressure that religious conservatives could face:

title: Greek Bank Set to Be First in 5 Years to Tap Capital Markets
description: ATHENS  Piraeus Bank, Greeces largest lender, is set to became the first Greek bank to tap the capital markets since the euro zone crisis erupted five years ago.

title: Tunisia Lifts 3-Year State of Emergency
description: TUNIS  President Moncef Marzouki of Tunisia lifted a state of emergency on Thursday that had been in force since the 2011 uprising, in a sign of growing confidence in the country since political accords were reached in December.

title: President Obama and Aide Speak on Ukraine
description: Though Western allies are divided over whether to bring to bear heavy pressure on Russia or take a more conciliatory path toward encouraging Moscow to reverse course in the occupied Crimea, President Obama said during a brief address to journalists at the White House that the world can see that we are united with our allies.

title: The Gun Report: March 6, 2014
description: Cities, which are often home to the worst gun violence, are losing their power to regulate firearms, the Atlantic reports. For instance, a Sedgwick County, Kan., law bans guns, concealed or not, from all bars, but in 2007, the state legislature quietly stripped municipalities of their authority to regulate most aspects of gun ownership and use.

title: Paul Ryans Contradiction
description: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md.  The G.O.P. may look, to outsiders, as if its sharply divided between establishment politicians and Tea Party upstarts willing to defy Ronald Reagans so-called Eleventh Commandment (dont speak ill of fellow Republicans) even at the risk of losing very winnable Senate contests  as they did in 2012.

title: Allergies Are Everywhere
description: People hoping to find an allergy-free haven may be out of luck. A new study has found that no region of the United States is allergy-free, but the kind of allergy people are likely to suffer from varies by region, race and socioeconomic status.

title: Providers of Medical Marijuana Face New Fears
description: SEATTLE  There should be, one might think, a note of triumph or at least quiet satisfaction in Muraco Kyashna-tochas voice. Her patient-based cooperative in north Seattle dispenses medical marijuana to treat seizures, sleeplessness and other maladies. And with the state gearing up to open its first stores selling legal marijuana for recreational use, the drug she has cultivated, provided to patients and used herself for years seems to be barreling toward the mainstream.

title: As Expected, President Karzais Brother Exits Afghan Election
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Qayum Karzai, a brother of President Hamid Karzai, announced Thursday that he was pulling out of the campaign for president of Afghanistan and throwing his support behind a candidate believed favored by the president, Zalmay Rassoul, a former foreign minister.

title: Branded Saloon Offers Bits of Texas and Bytes of Music
description: The Miser cant decide whether 21st-century Brooklyns peculiar predilection for mastering country traditions (the old-time Appalachian music preserved at the Jalopy Theater and the Texas tastes of the Hill Country franchise, for example) is just baffling or makes perfect sense.

title: Four People Dead After Jersey City Fire
description: JERSEY CITY  Four people died on Thursday in an early morning fire in Jersey City in which firefighters were sent to a wrong address first, officials said.

title: How to Choose an Auditor
description: One unfortunate fact about the auditing business is that those who depend on the audit  investors, lenders and customers  are not the ones who choose the audit firm. At the places where an audit is most needed, the people choosing the auditor may be the ones who have the most to fear from a good audit.

title: Mu Ramen on Temporary Hold
description: Mu Ramen has always been elusive. When Joshua and Heidy Smookler were serving noodle soup by night inside Bricktown Bagels in Long Island City, Queens, the hours and reservations policy seemed to change week to week. Then the location changed, as the Smooklers began serving guests in their apartment or at other addresses that were disclosed upon making a reservation.

title: Fiddler on the Roof Returning to Broadway (In Case You Missed It the 5 Previous Times)
description: Fiddler on the Roof, one of the most frequently revived musicals on Broadway, will have its fifth revival in the fall of 2015 under the direction of the Tony Award winner Bartlett Sher (South Pacific), the producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel announced on Thursday.

title: Lin-Manuel Mirandas  Hamilton Heading to Public Theater
description: Hamilton, a much-anticipated new musical by Lin-Manuel Miranda (In the Heights), who sets the story of Alexander Hamilton and the founding fathers to contemporary hip-hop, will have its world premiere next winter at the Public Theater, executives there announced Thursday. Mr. Miranda won the 2008 Tony Award for best score for In the Heights, a Broadway hit that also won the best musical Tony and ran for three years, with Mr. Miranda starring as a bodega owner besotted with his Washington Heights neighborhood.

title: High-Jump Stars Aim for a Venerable Record
description: BOSTON  It has been an indoor season for beating gravity and venerable world records, and with the once-supreme pole vaulter Sergei Bubka already relegated to second place, the still supreme high jumper Javier Sotomayor could be next.

title: Obama Affirms Support for Ukraine
description: The president said: Any discussion about the future of Ukraine must include the legitimate government of Ukraine.

title: Sodden Savages in Their First Flush
description: Probably the last two people youd want to invite into your living room for a spell are the husband and wife who stage a three-act war in their own in Edward Albees classic 1962 play Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? George, the defeated academic, and Martha, his bellowing harpy of a wife, engage in the kind of take-no-prisoners warfare that leaves total destruction in its wake. And yet, theater lover, I hereby urge you to tuck away the delicate china, remove breakables from exposed surfaces, lock up the liquor cabinet and fling open your doors to these two majestic monsters, a feat that can now be accomplished with just a click or two at the computer.

title: Egypt Pulls Ambassador From Qatar
description: CAIRO  Egypt on Thursday became the fourth Arab state in two days to pull its ambassador from Qatar over its support for Islamists around the region, including the deposed Egyptian president Mohamed Morsi and his supporters in the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Paris Fashion Week Street Style
description: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for Paris Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

title: Facebooks Gun Sale Changes Could Be Hard to Enforce Around the World
description: LONDON  Facebook is clamping down on gun sales on its site.

title: Bitcoin Is a Protocol. Bitcoin Is a Brand.
description: Updated with additional reporting. | So it appears the creator of Bitcoin may not have been a young Japanese mathematical wizard as had been long rumored. Instead, as Newsweek has first reported, he is believed to be a 64-year-old Japanese-American man named Satoshi Nakamoto who clearly does not care for attention.

title: Chris Christie Speaks at CPAC
description: The governor of New Jersey gives a speech at the 2014 Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington, a year after he was denied a slot at the same event.

title: Back in Spotlight, Christie Offers G.O.P. Subtle Advice
description: OXON HILL, Md.  In a return to the national political stage, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey sought Thursday to both ingratiate himself with conservative activists and press them to broaden the appeal of the Republican Party, warning that weve got to start to talk about what we are for and not what we are against.

title: American Ends Bereavement Fares
description: American Airlines has ended its practice of offering discounted bereavement fares to customers booking last minute travel because of a family members emergency medical problem or death.

title: Westchester Leader Begins Campaign for Governor
description: BUFFALO  Rob Astorinos first day campaigning for governor started on Thursday in the freezing cold in the Bronx, paused because of a fuel truck at La Guardia Airport and wound up at a biotechnology laboratory where everyone donned white lab coats and, at least for a moment, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was not discussed.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Announces Spotlight Films
description: New films from the directors Ira Sachs and Kelly Reichardt and the actress Courteney Cox will screen as part of the Spotlight series at the Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced Thursday.

title: How to Raise Both Take-Home Pay and Tax Fairness
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Test Your SAT Essay Writing Skills
description: Pencils up, everybody.

title: Stamping With a Smile of Approval
description: Three chefs stand behind the counter at Sushi Katsuei, neckties tucked inside white coats, eyes downcast. The rest of the room clatters, but they work in silence, as if of one clear mind. There is no hierarchy, no need for diners to jockey for position in front of one or another. From each chef will come the same pristine pieces of fish, sliced, patted and delivered with an economy of motion and, just possibly, a slip of a smile.

title: The Cost of Not  Looking Backwards at Torture
description: In the last few days, Americans were treated to an appalling battle between the Central Intelligence Agency and its Congressional overseers over the Senates attempt to investigate the C.I.A.s post-9/11 detention and interrogation practices. The fight is over two still-secret documents  a 2009 C.I.A. inspector generals report on those practices, and a four-year-long investigation by the staff of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: Guardian to Make Management Changes
description: The Guardian will make broad changes among its most senior editors this year, the newspaper said Thursday, announcing that Janine Gibson, the editor in chief of its operations in the United States, will return to London.

title: Abortion Law Pushes Texas Clinics to Close Doors
description: McALLEN, Tex.  Shortly before a candlelight vigil on the sidewalk outside, employees of the last abortion clinic in the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas shut the doors early Thursday evening, making legal abortion unavailable in the poorest part of the state in the wake of tough new restrictions passed last year by the Texas Legislature.

title: Assemblyman Is Convicted in Second Corruption Trial
description: William F. Boyland Jr., an assemblyman from one of Brooklyns most prominent political families, was convicted on Thursday of bribery and several other federal crimes.

title: More Than One Way to Buy a Plan
description: When the federal online marketplace for the Affordable Care Act stumbled out of the gate last fall, leaving would-be applicants unable to sign up for care or even to view their plans, three young programmers thought they might be able to help frustrated users. In October, they packaged reams of publicly-available data into a website, healthsherpa.com, that allowed users to immediately view exchange plans in their area. But the site was intended for research only; users still had to purchase them through the federal and state health exchanges or, in some cases, directly through insurers.

title: Obama Delivers Statement on Ukraine
description: President Obama said, Any discussion about the future of Ukraine must include the legitimate government of Ukraine.

title: The Hurdles in Getting Past a Wall of Silence
description: Attorney-client privilege and protection for attorney work product are often seen as the core of the relationship of trust between lawyers and their clients. But that shield of confidentiality can be enormously frustrating in an investigation of possible wrongdoing because it puts a wall around potentially valuable evidence.

title: Getty to Let Bloggers and Others Use Photos Free
description: In a move that promises to increase the use of photography across the Internet, the Getty Images photo agency announced that it would allow noncommercial websites and social media users to publish the agencys images at no cost using an embedding tool.

title: Poll Finds Shaheen With Big Lead in New Hampshire Senate Race With Brown
description: The latest polling in New Hampshire shows that Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts senator, would lose to Senator Jeanne Shaheen by a hefty 13 percentage points.

title: Book Deal Falls Apart for Parodist of Goldman
description: Updated, 9:19 p.m. | Two weeks ago, with a huge online following and a new six-figure book contract, John LeFevre was riding as high as some of the Wall Street traders he parodied in his Twitter account, @GSElevator.

title: Jack Griffin Appointed Chief of Tribune Publishing
description: Jack Griffin, who was ousted as chief executive of Time Inc. in 2011, will become the new head of Tribune Publishing in mid-April, the Tribune Company announced Thursday.

title: The Journalist and the Masquerader
description: With its lurid title and bloodstained cover, Walter Kirns latest book is bound to be shelved in the crime section. But its actually about class. A novelist, journalist and memoirist, Kirn is his generations aspirational Midwesterner, a boy who goes East and sneaks into the magic circle of the American aristocracy. But no matter how close to the center he gets, he still feels like the little match girl, nose pressed against the window.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: obesity and exercise, H.I.V. and electronic cigarettes. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Facing Sexual Assault Trial, General Pleads Guilty to Misconduct
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  An Army judge on Thursday accepted guilty pleas from Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair to misconduct charges, including possession of pornography and inappropriate relationships with female soldiers. But the general, a former deputy commander of American forces in southern Afghanistan, still faces court-martial on charges that he sexually assaulted a junior officer with whom he had an extramarital relationship.

title: Reading Into a Murky Past
description: Walter Kirns new book, Blood Will Out, reviewed by Nina Burleigh this week, details his friendship with Clark Rockefeller. Rockefeller was eventually unmasked as Christian Gerhartsreiter, and in 2013 was convicted of a murder that had occurred nearly 30 years earlier. He confessed to Kirn that the inspiration for his alter ego came from The Great Gatsby. Surprisingly, he told me he didnt identify with the character of Gatsby so much as he did with Nick, the narrator, Kirn said in an email interview. I think he was lying about this. I think he knew that I, like Nick, and like Fitzgerald, had grown up in Minnesota; he wanted to get in good with me by creating a sense of having something in common.

title: The Long Road Home
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: MoMA to Show Jasper Johnss Regrets Series
description: JASPER JOHNSS REGRETS

title: Letters: Bad Boys, Heschel and Kennans Diaries
description: Bad Boys and Others

title: She Walked Into My Office on a Tuesday, Dressed in Chandler
description: Among the tentative book and story titles that Raymond Chandler left behind were The Diary of a Loud Check Suit, The Man With the Shredded Ear, Stop Screaming  Its Me and The Black-Eyed Blonde. So we can be glad that last one became Chandlers latest gift from beyond the grave: a much slinkier moniker that summons Chandlers Philip Marlowe and the kinds of women who matched wits with him, slyly wrapping him around their dainty, lacquered fingers.

title: What Lou Reed Taught Me About Love
description: When Lou Reed died last year, I learned via Facebook just how many friends had chosen Ill Be Your Mirror as their wedding song. I wasnt one of them, but that song, more than any other, taught me about love.

title: Wheelies: The Anxious AAA Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Mothers and Sons
description: My boyfriend and I are in our mid-20s. Weve been together for five years and just moved in together. His mother texts him incessantly, even on Saturday nights, to find out where he is and what hes doing. If she does not receive a prompt reply, she becomes indignant and follows up with more texts until he responds. I often feel as if shes with us wherever we go. My boyfriend is also bothered by her stalker-ish behavior, though not as much as I am. I appreciate the importance of family, but how do we set some boundaries?

title: Like the Common Core? Then Youll Like the New SAT
description: The SAT is undergoing a major redesign, ending its longstanding reliance on knowledge of obscure vocabulary words as well as the penalty for guessing wrong, and removing the essay requirement added in 2005. It is returning to the old 1,600-point scale and reinstating the bragging rights of generations of parents who found their high scores reduced to apparent mediocrity when an additional 800 points were tacked onto the exam taken by their children.

title: 10 Lies? Russians Fire Back
description: MOSCOW  Russias Ministry of Foreign Affairs was not amused by the unorthodox statement from the State Department under the title President Putins Fiction: 10 False Claims About Ukraine, which rebutted a series of assertions by the Russian president in the eye-catching format of a top-10 list.

title: A Restless Spirit Spans Generations
description: More than half a century ago, Paul Taylor was a promising new talent in the emerging field of modern dance. Today, he is the last living patriarch of a diverse and thriving art form, celebrating his companys 60th anniversary for three weeks at Lincoln Center. The program showcases an eclectic selection of works  some playful, some disquieting  from his trove. Among them is a world premiere, because at 83, Mr. Taylor is still looking forward. (Tuesday through March 30, David H. Koch Theater, 212-496-0600, ptdc.org.)

title: The Reality Behind the Stock-Picking Prowess of S.E.C. Staff Members
description: Is the Securities and Exchange Commission a warren for insider trading? If youve read recent headlines like The Incredible Stock-Picking Ability of SEC Employees, youd think so.

title: Bitcoins Mysterious Creator Is Said to Be Identified
description: Updated, 1:31 p.m. | Even as it has grown into a new type of digital money worth billions of dollars, Bitcoin has always retained an air of mystery.

title: True Detective, Lost and the Problem of Endings
description: Even though its replaced Breaking Bad as my Sunday night obsession, I havent dipped a toe into the debate about HBOs True Detective is it philosophically-rich or a philosophically-pretentious? baldlymisognyistic or a critique of toxic masculinity? a retread of the anti-hero genre or a brilliant refashioning of detective-genre cliches? in part because I find myself torn between its critics and its fans. Im unapologetically addicted, but I can read a good takedown and find myself nodding along to some of its points.

title: Serious Silliness:  High School Reading and Writing Inspired by Dr. Seuss
description: This week marks the 110th anniversary of Theodor Seuss Geisels birth, and the 17th annual Read Across America event that celebrates the day.

title: A Nations Soul, Tapping and Twirling
description: WASHINGTON  Whats the uniting factor here? A Richard Avedon photograph of a nude Rudolf Nureyev; an astonishing film clip of the Nicholas Brothers in Stormy Weather; a surreal photo of the tap virtuoso Ann Miller, hilariously placed amid a garden of violins? All appear in Dancing the Dream, an exuberantly diverse exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery that surveys dance in America over the last 100 years.

title: Let Them Eat Dignity
description: Were getting reports about Paul Ryans performance at CPAC, the big conservative gathering  and theyre actually kind of awesome, in the worst way.

title: West Point Sergeant Pleads Guilty to Videotaping Female Cadets
description: WASHINGTON  A sergeant responsible for advising students at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y., has pleaded guilty in a case that included accusations that he secretly videotaped female cadets, some as they undressed in the locker room, and will serve a 33-month sentence, the Army said Thursday.

title: Wait Until Wages Start Rising
description: And then wait some more  a lot more.

title: Cerberus in $9 Billion Deal for the Safeway Grocery Chain
description: A group led by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management agreed on Thursday to buy Safeway in a deal worth more than $9 billion, giving it control of the big grocery store chain in the largest leveraged buyout this year.

title: 12 Ways to Move Grapefruit Beyond Breakfast
description: Salads, sauces and stir-fries can all benefit from a bright hit of sweet and sour.

title: Opera Star Fills Same Role for 2 Companies in a Week
description: There is never a good time to lose your leading man to illness on the eve of opening night, particularly when the work in question is Alban Bergs early-20th-century masterpiece Wozzeck, which is not exactly a staple of many singers repertoires.

title: First to Die in Sweeney Todd: Decorum at the Philharmonic
description: Despite the body count to rival an action movie, the scenes of human flesh put through a sausage grinder, and the protagonist who announces in ringing tones that we all deserve to die, Sweeney Todd has an uncanny way of sending musical theater audiences into raptures of glazed-eyed bliss. That was certainly the case on Wednesday night, when the New York Philharmonic presented a starry concert version, featuring the opera luminary Bryn Terfel as the bloodthirsty barber and the Oscar-winning Emma Thompson as his adoring helpmate, the meat-pie-making Mrs. Lovett.

title: Bombings Kill at Least 30 in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A series of bombings in Iraq on Thursday killed at least 30 people, according to security officials.

title: Man in Subway Is Injured in Antigay Attack, Police Say
description: A man yelling antigay slurs accosted a couple on a subway platform this week in Greenwich Village and punched one of the men in the face, the police said on Thursday.

title: Classic Stage Season to Begin With Rodgers and Hammersteins Allegro
description: The Classic Stage Company added musicals to its roster of revivals last year and this year it is continuing the tradition, kicking off its 2014-2015 season with a production in October of Rodgers and Hammersteins Allegro directed by the Tony winner John Doyle.

title: The Trippy 60s, Courtesy of a Master
description: IN the world of Mad Men, whose seventh season begins on April 13 on AMC, one of the central dramatic devices is the client meeting, the scene where the advertising gurus and the people who pay them gather in their glassed-office agora to wrestle over the nature of commerce, persuasion, art and desire.

title: United Nations to Consider Large Peacekeeping Force for Central African Republic
description: UNITED NATIONS  The violence in the Central African Republic jolted the United Nations Security Council into rare accord on Thursday, with France announcing that it would soon propose a resolution to establish a large and robust United Nations peacekeeping force and the United States expressing full-throated support.

title: 2 Senior Citigroup Executives Retiring
description: Two senior executives are retiring from Citigroup, the company said Thursday, leading to changes at the top of the banks international and consumer banking operations.

title: A Texas Painter Worked Under the Radar in New York
description: Early-1900s paintings signed with variations on the name Chas. Turner are potentially very valuable.

title: Trips from Outside Magazine
description: Outside magazine has long taken readers on armchair trips. Now the monthly, which covers adventure, has linked up with travel outfitter Uncharted Outposts to create a new travel company called Outside Go.

title: Official at Helm of Federal Health Marketplace Is Resigning
description: WASHINGTON  Gary M. Cohen, the official in charge of the federal health insurance marketplace, who repeatedly told Congress before its troubled rollout that it would work well, said on Thursday that he was resigning.

title: Harvard and Yale Pick Up the Pace, Reshaping Ivy League Basketball
description: Forty minutes before the start of another late-season game with Ivy League title implications at the Palestra, Yale Coach James Jones strolled through the buildings concourse looking at exhibits celebrating Pennsylvanias storied basketball history.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, India and Britain.

title: Republicans Tax Plan Awkwardly Aims at Rich
description: Tax the rich.

title: Lamenting a Rejection by the Bosss Daughter
description: The vast cavern of Carnegie Hall is a tough space in which to present Schuberts Die Schne Mllerin (The Beautiful Maid of the Mill), an intimate song cycle better suited to a smaller hall. But on Wednesday evening, the baritone Matthias Goerne and Christoph Eschenbach, the conductor who often performs as a pianist, drew in listeners with an exemplary performance that traversed the myriad shades of optimism and despair.

title: Its Obamas Fault. But Ignore That.
description: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md.Whatever else might divide them, the speakers at the Conservative Political Action Conference today seemed united on the important matter of what to say at the Conservative Political Action Conference.

title: Companies Test Plans to Cut Their Health Costs
description: At Walgreen, the giant drugstore chain, employees now have a much broader choice of insurers and plans. Once limited to two options, either from a local Blue Cross plan or UnitedHealthcare, workers can now choose among as many as 25 plans from five insurers, depending on where they live, including Kaiser Permanente, the well-known California-based H.M.O.

title: A Former Phenom Belts Her Way Back
description: Karen Wyman has the kind of old-fashioned belters delivery associated with her idol Eydie Gorme, who, like Ms. Wyman, was born in the Bronx and came from a Sephardic Jewish background. Lainie Kazan and Pia Zadora share the same sock-it-to-em approach.

title: Julia Rommel: The Little Match Stick
description: Bureau

title: Yishay Garbasz: Ritual and Reality'
description: Ronald Feldman Fine Arts

title: Lauren Silva: I tried to catch the fog. I mist.
description: ZieherSmith

title: Roe Ethridge: Sacrifice Your Body
description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: Half Drop
description: Kerry Schuss

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, India and South Korea.

title: Off With the Face Paint
description: In the suburbs they say good fences make good neighbors; in Manhattan the corollary is good party walls.

title: Financing for Foreclosed Homes
description: Buyers looking for a deal on a foreclosed property have good reason to scroll through the thousands of homes listed by Fannie Mae. In addition to low-down-payment financing and priority status for owner-occupants, the government-controlled mortgage giant has begun offering closing-cost assistance to qualified buyers.

title: As if the River Itself Were Alive
description: Something about a flood must call to experimental filmmakers. In January, Bill Morrison explored the 1927 calamity along the Mississippi River in The Great Flood, a lovely, wordless documentary with a jazz score by Bill Frisell. And now, from Kevin Jerome Everson, comes The Island of St. Matthews, an even more unorthodox look at 1973 flooding on the Tombigbee River near Columbus, Miss.

title: Earthlings and Martians in a Rematch
description: Considering that the fate of humankind is at stake, War of the Worlds: Goliath is remarkably uninvolving.

title: Creatures of the Wind Take Paris
description: Like many American designers, Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters of Creatures of the Wind travel to Paris each season for sales appointments with international buyers. This time around, they arrived early to present their collection for judging as finalists for the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize. Here, they share highlights from their nine days of fashion, food and fun.

title: Danger Undercover
description: You know theres something wrong with a martial arts movie when the only character worth caring about is the heros mother. Making sense in the sea of nonsense that is Special ID, this middle-aged woman (played by the talented Paw Hee-ching) has very little screen time  and spends most of it getting her hair shorn and her kisser punched  but at least we understand her.

title: On the Piers, Armory Show Evokes Cut and Paste
description: After nearly four hours of scanning thousands of artworks displayed by the Armory Shows international roster of 205 exhibitors, I had an epiphany. A hypothesis about the nature of art making in the industrialized world took shape in my exhausted, overstimulated brain. I call it the cut-and-paste theory, which has to do not with actual scissors, paper and glue but with the actions people perform on Windows-equipped computers.

title: Warning: Teenagers May Like These Movies
description: IN 1999, Eric Beckman ran into a teenage neighbor in the elevator. Eager to promote his growing venture, the New York International Childrens Film Festival, he gave the girl a brochure. She looked at it, saw the word children, curled her nose and handed it back, he said with a laugh.

title: In Blue-Chip Precincts, a Shout-Out for the Undersung
description: In catering to established tastes, art fairs tend to mirror or even exacerbate the art worlds imbalances. And of all the art fairs that visit New York in March, the Art Show, organized by the Art Dealers Association of America, is normally the safest and most blue-chip of the bunch (that is, heavily white and male).

title: Alejandro Zaffaroni, Entrepreneur on Biotech Frontier, Dies at 91
description: Alejandro Zaffaroni, a prolific biotechnology entrepreneur and Silicon Valley legend who played a significant role in the development of the birth control pill, the nicotine patch, the DNA chip and corticosteroids, died on Saturday at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 91.

title: Russia Experts See Thinning Ranks Effect on U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON  I have to do a TV broadcast now, can I call you back in maybe an hour? Angela Stent, the director of the Russian studies department at Georgetown University, said when she picked up the phone. An hour later she apologized again. Im afraid Ill have to call you back.

title: One Last Dance in the Old Place
description: For its 2014 Biennial, the last before taking the plunge downtown, the Whitney went a little wild with the recipe. It picked three curators from outside the museum and outside New York. (One just recently arrived.) It gave each of them free rein on a floor in the museums Breuer building to work solo, with no cross talk required, though, of course, there was some, and some space sharing, too.

title: An Art Fair That Tries to Be Something Else
description: In its fifth year, the Independent continues to assert its maverick identity. Its an art fair that pretends not to be an art fair. And because it takes place in Dia Art Foundations former exhibition space, youre almost convinced. If fairs are part of the new necessary evil for small galleries to stay afloat, this one offers a good concentrated roundup of artists and exhibitors: nonprofit institutions, alternative spaces along with a few commercial galleries that might be barely paying their bills.

title: A Couples Getting-to-Know-You Phase Takes a Chilling Wrong Turn
description: Considering that In Fear unfolds almost entirely inside a moving vehicle, its remarkable how firmly it grasps our attention. Economical in the extreme  but without appearing cash-poor  this tightly wound thriller proves that minimal resources can sometimes produce more than satisfying results.

title: Chris Christie Speaks to Conservatives
