description: The governor of New Jersey addresses the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington, a year after he was denied a slot at the same event.

title: Arundhati Roy on Gandhi, the Bomb and Being a Woman
description: In this weeks magazine, Siddhartha Deb writes about the novelist-turned-activist Arundhati Roy, whom some call a provocateur, others courageous. (She makes no claim to heroism and prefers to think of herself as naughty.) Below, a sample of some of her more memorable statements may help you decide which adjective you prefer.

title: Events in Westchester for March 9-15
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Theater Listings for March 7-13
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for March 7-13
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Strollers Not Welcome
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Movie Listings for March 7-13
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Last Day for Last Abortion Clinic in the Rio Grande
description: The last clinics in two poor and working-class regions of Texas were shutting down, and the number of clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for March 7-13
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Keeping Your Insurance Policy
description: The Obama administration announced a new policy on Wednesday that will allow many people to renew their existing insurance policies for two more years even though the policies dont provide the comprehensive coverage and consumer protections required by the Affordable Care Act. The move is designed to provide political cover for Democratic senators facing tough re-election campaigns in Republican-leaning states where the president is especially unpopular.

title: Understanding Social Conflict
description: Alma Abdul-Hadi Jadallah, founder of Kommon Denominator in Virginia.

title: Jazz Listings for March 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for March 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Crimeans Speak Out on Referendum
description: In Yalta and Simferopol, Crimean citizens spoke about the planned referendum on whether to break from Ukraine and join the Russian Federation.

title: Dance Listings for March 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Harley-Davidson Brings Back the 70s With Low Rider Model
description: Although retro motorcycles have become all the rage over the past few years, retro style has long been part of Harley-Davidsons image. The motorcycle manufacturer released two models Thursday that it promised would deliver old-school attitude paired with modern-day performance: the Low Rider and the SuperLow 1200T.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for March 7-13
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for March 7-13
description: LOSAR FAMILY DAY

title: Events in Connecticut for March 9-15
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Spare Times for March 7-13
description: 40TH ANNIVERSARY OF FREE TO BE ... YOU AND ME (Saturday, Sunday and Tuesday) Those who grew up in the 1970s  as well as pop culture mavens  will probably know this Emmy Award-winning after-school television special with the message that everyone is capable of achieving great things.

title: Art Matters | At the Armory Show, China Takes the Spotlight
description: The Armory Show anchors what has held on as a robust art week for New York, in spite of similar events organized in the city during the milder month of May. The art fair on Piers 92 and 94 on the West Side Highway opened to the public this morning, and while one might say its theme is the same as ever  to make as much money as possible in five days selling contemporary (and modern) art  each year is more distinctively characterized by a regionally driven focus as well, and 2014s is China.

title: Events in New Jersey for March 9-15, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The New SAT, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: How Many Patients a Day?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bipartisan on Drug Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Role in Afghan Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Casablanca Names 6 Candidates for Cliffs Natural Resources Board
description: The activist hedge fund pressing for change at Cliffs Natural Resources started a proxy fight at the mining concern on Thursday, naming six candidates for the companys board.

title: Events on Long Island for March 9-15
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Mass Slaughter in Indonesia
description: To the Editor:

title: On February Jobs Data, Its Anybodys Guess
description: Buckle your seatbelts.

title: Restrain the Data Brokers
description: To the Editor:

title: Many to Lust For, and Some You Might Afford
description: GENEVA  The mood was exuberant as the Palexpo convention center here opened on Tuesday for two days of press previews that served up a generous helping of important new production models as well as some intriguing design studies.

title: This Week's Movies: March 7, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics on "The Grand Budapest Hotel," "The Face of Love" and "Bethlehem."

title: And a Child Will Lead Them
description: Unlike Vladimir V. Putin, Americans would rather be liked than feared.

title: A Mentor Recalled by Talking Pianos
description: Mary Lou Williams, who was born in 1910 and died in 1981, was a jazz pianist, composer and arranger of trailblazing accomplishment, and a bighearted mentor to countless others who sought her counsel. Its hard to imagine she would have been anything but pleased by Mary Lou Williams Tribute: The Next Generation, an admirably focused concert held on Wednesday night at Harlem Stage Gatehouse, as the curtain raiser for a larger celebration that runs from Thursday through next Saturday.

title: Curtain Call | Paris Fashion Week
description: To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of select fashion visionaries.

title: Jerry Browns Revenge
description: SANTA BARBARA, Ca.  Lets review. Just a few years ago California was a punching bag for conservative scolds  a failed state, profligate with its spending and promiscuous with its ambition. Ungovernable. And everybodys leaving.

title: Venezuela in Black-and-White
description: Though famed for chromatic installations, Carlos Cruz-Diez was first taken by the magic of light as a young photographer documenting Venezuelas emergence as a modern state.

title: Not the Kind of Bonding a Father Might Have Wanted
description: Awful Nice is a crass bro comedy about brothers. When the responsible Jim (James Pumphrey) seeks out the errant Dave (Alex Rennie) to tell him their father has died, he finds Dave passed out and naked in a tepee. They have inherited a vacation home in Branson, Mo., but Dave refuses to sign the deed unless they have a bonding experience while repairing the house and their relationship.

title: Save Us From the SAT
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  I WAS in trouble. The first few analogies were pretty straightforward  along the lines of leopard is to spotted as zebra is to striped  but now I was in the tall weeds of nuance. Kangaroo is to marsupial as the giant squid is to  I dont know, maybe D) cephalopod? I looked up for a second at the back of the head of the girl in front of me. She had done this amazing thing with her hair, sort of like a French braid. I wondered if I could do that with my hair.

title: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Fashion Week Take Their Bows
description: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows  some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above  of 15 fashion visionaries.

title: Spain Struggles to Halt Migrants at Two Enclaves
description: MADRID  About 80,000 African migrants are heading for Spains two enclaves along the Moroccan coast, leaving Spain struggling to contain the efforts that are coming in larger and increasingly coordinated surges in recent days.

title: Raging Hormones, an Unsettling New Home and Ghostly Wrath
description: For a red-blooded teenage boy, the unexpected bedtime appearance of a willing young woman whispering, Protect me! is bound to send hormones ricocheting. And so it is with Evan (Harrison Gilbertson), the moody center of Haunt and middle child of the Asher family, recent buyers of a cursed home whose previous residents have been virtually wiped out.

title: Lone Star Loyalists Connect in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Ask a Texas transplant about living in the nations capital, and you are likely to get an answer involving a wistful memory about the Lone Star State, sometimes one embedded in a complaint.

title: Bullet Train Failed Once, but Its Back
description: In 1989, former Lt. Gov. Ben Barnes joined a group of investors hoping to develop a bullet train in Texas.

title: Dodging the Bullets of Loyalty, Terror and Death in Mideast
description: As its title suggests, Bethlehem, a tightly wound thriller about an Israeli secret-service officer and his Palestinian informant, has a biblical undertow. A story of attraction and repulsion evocative of Cain and Abel, it pivots on intimate antagonists who, in another world and geopolitical time, might have been brothers. Razi (Tsahi Halevy) is an Israeli operative working in an antiterrorism unit; Sanfur (Shadi Mari) is a 17-year-old Palestinian whose older brother, Ibrahim (Hisham Suliman), is a warrior or militant or terrorist. (Take your pick.)

title: F.C.C. Seeks Limits on TV Stations, to Curb Cable Costs
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to address what critics say is one of the biggest contributors to the ever-rising price of cable television subscriptions, the Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday that it would consider new rules that prevent local broadcasters from working together to negotiate deals with cable companies and advertisers.

title: Chinese Governor Signals Crackdown on Separatists
description: BEIJING  A government leader in the western region of Xinjiang said Thursday that officials would rigidly crack down on separatist groups in the area and that foreign forces were behind the separatist activities.

title: David Barrett, Dogged Graft Investigator in Washington, Dies at 76
description: David M. Barrett, a Washington lawyer with Republican ties, was one of six so-called independent counsels sworn in during the Clinton administration to investigate allegations of wrongdoing by government officials. His inquiry concerned Henry G. Cisneros, the secretary of housing and urban development, who was accused of lying in 1993 during an F.B.I. background check about payments he had made to a former mistress while he was mayor of San Antonio.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Double Time: Seeing a Ghost, Romantically
description: Sometimes its best to forget a movies story and concentrate on whatever else you can. If the camera movements dont seduce, something else might. Because while a director may not leave much of an impression narratively or visually, he or she can edge into your consciousness with how well the actors are making the thing work, despite its frayed, disjointed pieces. In the case of The Face of Love, the main attractions are Ed Harris and a deeply appealing Annette Bening as two  actually, make that three  characters brought together by fate and a screenplay that promisingly flirts with fantasy only to come crashing down to bummer earth.

title: Five Years Later, Tea Party Is a Faction Republicans Must Court
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Okapi Partners, a Proxy Solicitor, Adds a Senior Executive
description: Okapi Partners, one of the younger players in the business of advising companies and hedge funds in proxy contests, plans to announce on Friday that it has hired Michael Fein as a senior managing director.

title: Angel of Mercy, Angel of Death
description: Figures observed through frosted glass as they engage in semi-audible conversation: That mysterious tableau, which begins Valeria Golinos film Honey, defines the detached sensibility of the title character. Honey (miele in Italian) is the code name for Irene, a fiercely free-spirited woman in the shadowy business of assisted suicide.

title: N.Y.U. Women Are Back in Bracket
description: In her second season at New York University, Coach Lauren Hall-Gregory has helped invigorate the womens basketball program, which was once a Division III powerhouse. Among those most impressed were opposing coaches and the N.C.A.A. committee that granted N.Y.U. an at-large tournament slot this year.

title: Foreign Influx Gives Annual Tech Event an International Flavor
description: Going to the South by Southwest technology, music and film festival has long been about discovering the next big thing.

title: Stage Fright, and Then Some, at a Soloists Do-or-Die Recital
description: In Eugenio Miras gaudy, amusingly preposterous new thriller, Grand Piano, the worlds foremost young classical pianist returns to the concert stage after a five-year sabbatical and finds himself in a deadly line of fire. A perfectionist prone to stage fright, Tom (Elijah Wood) discovers a warning scrawled in red ink inside his piano score: Play one wrong note and you die.

title: New Hampshire: Brown, Not in Race, Behind in Poll
description: The latest polling in New Hampshire shows that Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, would lose to Senator Jeanne Shaheen by 13 percentage points if the election were held today. The poll, by Suffolk University in Boston, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. Mr. Brown, a Republican who represented Massachusetts in the Senate for three years, has been toying with challenging Ms. Shaheen but, despite increasing pressure from Republicans, has not indicated whether he will jump in. He has owned a home in New Hampshire for several years, recently moved there full time and must decide by June 13 whether to enter the race.

title: NBCUniversal to Combine Upfront Presentations for Its Cable Channels
description: THIS year, for the big television industry event called upfront week, NBCUniversal will borrow a page from the playbook of its parent, Comcast, and bundle together its cable channels.

title: Massachusetts: Bill Passes Banning Upskirt Images
description: The State Legislature passed a bill on Thursday prohibiting upskirting, or secretly photographing up someones clothing in public without his or her consent. The move came one day after the states highest court ruled that an existing law prohibiting secret photographing of nude or partly nude people did not apply to the case of Michael Robertson  who was arrested in 2010 and accused of using his cellphone to take images of womens crotch areas on Bostons public transit  because the women he photographed were dressed. The measure would make the secret photographing or videotaping of sexual or intimate parts, either naked or clothed, when a person could reasonably expect them not to be visible to the public, punishable by more than two years in prison and/or a $5,000 fine.

title: Hes Glad She Came Along
description: One rule of comedy is to make it big. Instead of a single pie to the face, try a fusillade and a slippery shoving match. Rather than a couple of anchormen trading insults, why not a street fight? And when it comes to a battle royal, you really cant top Buddha for administering a beat down.

title: Saving Daylight, at What Cost?
On the Brink of Eviction
description: Kevin McCrary, the son of radio and television celebrities of the 1950s, is practically famous for his hoarding.

title: The Archipelago of Pain
description: We dont flog people in our prison system, or put them in thumbscrews or stretch them on the rack. We do, however, lock prisoners away in social isolation for 23 hours a day, often for months, years or decades at a time.

title: New Hampshire Senate Votes to Expand Health Insurance Coverage
description: CONCORD, N.H.  The states Republican-dominated Senate voted Thursday to expand health care coverage to an estimated 50,000 adults using Medicaid funding made available through the Affordable Care Act.

title: Hacked Heads, Hot Sex and a Whole Lot of Sea
description: Classical historians disagree, but it was probably Herodotus who first posed a question that would ring out across the ages, unanswered till now: Wouldnt Eva Green look awesome kissing the severed head of an insolent captive? 300: Rise of an Empire puts the issue to rest (the answer: yes, but itll never last) and strives to uphold the rah-rah style of visuals and rhetoric established by its popular predecessor, 300.

title: The Hammock Fallacy
description: Hypocrisy is the tribute vice pays to virtue. So when you see something like the current scramble by Republicans to declare their deep concern for Americas poor, its a good sign, indicating a positive change in social norms. Goodbye, sneering at the 47 percent; hello, fake compassion.

title: A 47-Foot St. Patricks Day Parade Thats Long on Fun
description: Sipping a drink at a fine pub in the Bronx, and reading a magazine article, Pat Gilheany was struck by a lightning bolt. Hot Springs, Ark., he read, holds an annual St. Patricks Day parade that it claims is the worlds shortest. It runs along Bridge Street in Hot Springs, which is 98 feet from top to bottom.

title: In an Industrial Space, Homemade Pies
description: The word fabbrica means factory in Italian, and Pizza Fabbrica, a three-month-old restaurant in Hicksville, looks the part. In its spacious dining room, stainless-steel industrial lights hang from a ceiling with exposed heating ducts. The open kitchen has three large, wood-burning, volcanic-rock pizza ovens imported from Italy. Covered with tile, they bear the surnames of the owner, Paul Presta, and his two associates, John LaForte and Charles Fusco. Mr. Presta has a background in the construction business and was involved in the building of the restaurant, and Mr. LaForte and Mr. Fusco have run pizzerias.

title: Red Lights Dim in Chinas Sin City
description: DONGGUAN, China  His cellphone is not ringing. His online chat programs sit idle. His condoms stay wrapped. People are no longer approaching Denny to pay for sex.

title: Russian Riot Grrrls Assaulted on Camera
description: The two best-known members of the Russian protest group Pussy Riot were assaulted on Thursday by six young men who hit the women and tossed acidic liquid and green dye on their faces while cursing at them for coming to the city of Nizhny Novgorod, five hours east of Moscow.

title: Where Mexico Befriends Peru
description: With 12 tables and a collection of Latin American folk art tucked into a dining area not much larger than some suburban living rooms, the restaurant El Tule would be easy to mistake for just another outpost of uninspired ethnic fare.

title: Why Darrell Issa Turned Off the Mic
description: House Republicans were in the minority for many decades, and those who remember that long period know what it was like to be regularly steamrollered by Democratic leaders. For the most part, theyve agreed to a basic understanding in the House that members of the minority have a right to speak up in disagreement. They can be ignored, and they usually are, but if theyre muzzled, it makes the majority look like a bunch of insecure authoritarians. And it could come back to haunt them if the majority shifts again.

title: A Hobbit House, With Chickens
description: Double-takes and disbelief are common reactions to the white stone farmhouse with green shutters at 18-20 Flushing Avenue in Ridgewood on the Queens-Brooklyn border. The Dutch Colonial Vander Ende-Onderdonk House materializes like Brigadoon on what is otherwise a dreary corridor of squat warehouses.

title: Then and Now, a Test That Aims to Neutralize Advantages of the Privileged
description: When the College Board announced Wednesday that it was overhauling the SAT in ways that would curb the advantages enjoyed by affluent students, it sounded a bit like the people who first designed and popularized the test decades ago.

title: Need for Full-Day Kindergarten Is Lost in Pre-K Debate, Critics Say
description: HUNTINGTON, N.Y.  Jennifer Simon has paid thousands of dollars for private preschool, she said, and it was worth every penny.

title: New York Citys Jobless Rate Drops to Lowest Level in 5 Years
description: In Mayor Bill de Blasios first month in office, New York Citys unemployment rate continued its long, gradual decline, falling below 8 percent for the first time in five years.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 6, 2014
description: March 6, 2014

title: The Sweet, Streaming Sound of Data
description: Once, all you needed to succeed in the music business were a pair of golden ears and some hustle. Now, it also takes mountains of data.

title: A Smart Retreat on Immigration
description: South Carolina has just abandoned key parts of its harsh, Arizona-style immigration law. Its a setback for devotees of the state-by-state, do-it-yourself approach to immigration enforcement, and good news for those who have been fighting to turn back that toxic legislative tide.

title: Worlds Biggest Arms Importer, India Wants to Buy Local
description: NEW DELHI  Of the 30 countries that attended a defense exposition last month to sell weapons to India, the worlds largest arms importer, only the Russians had the chutzpah to dress up their tanks and guns with women in tightfitting camouflage.

title: Natural Gas as a Diplomatic Tool
description: In response to the crisis in Ukraine, some American lawmakers and energy companies are urging the United States to export natural gas to Europe in an effort to undercut Russias influence over the Continent. The Obama administration should move to increase exports, which would help allies like Germany, Turkey and Britain, but the effects of such exports would likely be modest and wouldnt be realized for several years.

title: Knicks Fans, Do You Believe in ... 1999?
description: The Knicks broke a seven-game losing streak and picked up a game on the Atlanta Hawks by notching their 22nd victory Wednesday. Inside their front office, Larry Johnson bent his arms in tribute to James L. Dolans middle initial and told Dolan, the Madison Square Garden chairman, Its all happening.

title: Latin Atmosphere With a Carefree Message
description: From the moment you enter its small, softly lit dining room, Mambo 64 grabs you with its warm hospitality, the mouthwatering scents of Latin home cooking and the rhythms of dance music.

title: U.N. Voices Concern Over Reports of Excessive Force in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A group of United Nations human rights experts voiced concern on Thursday over reports of excessive use of force against protesters and journalists during the recent wave of antigovernment demonstrations that has spread across the country.

title: Ukraine Weighs Boycott of Paralympics in Russia
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  The chant echoed throughout the plaza of the Paralympians mountain village here, and it grew only louder as the Ukrainian delegation marched on. Peace for Ukraine, its members shouted in their native language, again and again, their words grounded more in hope than in confidence.

title: 2 Marines Disciplined After 4 Die at Pendleton
description: LOS ANGELES  An explosion during a training exercise that killed four Marines at Camp Pendleton last year was most likely caused by a dropped or kicked grenade, and two Marines have been relieved of duty as a result, military officials announced Thursday.

title: Pitfalls Seen in a Turn to Privately Run Long-Term Care
description: NASHVILLE  Even as public attention is focused on the Affordable Care Act, another health care overhaul is underway in many states: an ambitious effort to restrain the ballooning Medicaid cost of long-term care as people live longer and survive more disabling conditions.

title: Decades After London Racial Killing, Inquiry Shows Police Spied on Victims Parents
description: LONDON  More than 20 years after the murder of a young black man became a symbol of Britains troubled race relations, an inquiry published Thursday disclosed that undercover officers spied on the victims parents as they campaigned for a thorough investigation into their sons killing.

title: For Nets, New Scoring Threat Proves a Bargain
description: Sometimes even the smallest trade can make a big difference. The Nets have found that out quickly with Marcus Thornton, a 26-year-old guard, who has established himself as a go-to scoring option off the bench.

title: Canadian Oil Will Take New Route Across U.S.
description: OTTAWA  Canadas energy producers received a rare boost in their efforts to expand the market for oil sands bitumen on Thursday when the countrys National Energy Board approved the reversal of a Canadian pipeline.

title: Trying to Revive His Prospects, Rubio Pushes Strength Abroad
description: OXON HILL, Md.  Alarmed by the rise of noninterventionist voices in his party, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, is aiming to revive his political prospects in an unlikely way: trying to become the leading voice for a muscular brand of foreign policy.

title: Serving Southern Hospitality
description: Somehow I expected to find Mamas Boy Southern Table and Refuge, a 10-month-old restaurant in South Norwalk, in a homier setting than the ground floor of a commercial building on North Water Street, diagonally across from the Norwalk Maritime Center.

title: Paramounts Noah Is Said to Face Ban in Middle East
description: LOS ANGELES  With the help of its newly added disclaimer acknowledging artistic license in its biblical storytelling, Darren Aronofskys Noah might make peace with religious viewers at home. But the film has a new headache: censorship in the Middle East.

title: Heralding War With Springy Step
description: On Sept. 21, 1939, only weeks into World War II, Alfred Hitchcock  recently imported from Britain by the mighty David O. Selznick to direct Rebecca  was taken to lunch by the independent producer Walter Wanger. The meeting went swimmingly.

title: TV Time
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  For a puzzle whose theme revolves around television shows, this Friday crossword from Matt Ginsberg draws a lot of material from the classical world.

title: Supernatural? Magician Has Doubts
description: Harry Houdini was apparently a complex fellow, and the Axis Theater Company gives him a complex treatment in Nothing on Earth Can Hold Houdini, by Randy Sharp. Like Ms. Sharps look at the Dust Bowl, Last Man Club, produced by the company in 2012, it is a play that bracingly refuses to be a straightforward historical treatment.

title: Washington Power Play
description: Its not personal, Dick, its just politics, Lyndon Johnson says to a good friend who has suddenly turned into a vanquished foe in the new play All the Way, by Robert Schenkkan. Johnson, played by Bryan Cranston in the mighty slab of history that opened at the Neil Simon Theater on Thursday night, infuses that glib phrase with palpable urgency and a whisper of tenderness. Theres no question that he really means what hes saying.

title: Robert Ashley, Opera Composer Who Painted Outside the Lines, Dies at 83
description: Robert Ashley, an American composer who helped wrestle opera into the 20th century and in so doing broadened the genre in strange, unexpected ways, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: With Netanyahu, Obama Plays Bad Cop to Kerrys Good Cop
description: WASHINGTON  An icy snowstorm was blowing in when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel landed here on Sunday night for a meeting with President Obama. But the weather was mild compared with the wintry welcome he got from the White House.

title: A Record of Courage May Add a New Mark
description: Coach Kathy Delaney and her Westwood High School girls basketball team returned from a road game in the mid-1970s to find their locker room occupied by a visiting boys squad. The girls, tired, sweaty and eager to retrieve their belongings, were told to wait.

title: Iran Disputes Israeli Arms Claim
description: Iran accused Israel on Thursday of falsifying claims that it had seized an Iranian shipment of weapons bound for Palestinian militants in Gaza aboard a merchant ship. Irans foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said that Israels assertion, made Wednesday, was suspiciously timed, coming during a meeting in Washington of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the powerful pro-Israel lobbying organization that is one of Irans most influential critics in American politics. The Israeli military said a Panamanian-flagged ship was seized by Israeli commandos 1,000 miles from the southern Israeli city of Eilat and was carrying dozens of Syrian-made M-302 rockets that Iran had helped to transport to Iraq, where the ship had loaded them. An Iranian ship carrying arms for Gaza. Captured just in time for annual AIPAC anti-Iran campaign, Mr. Zarif said on Twitter.  Amazing Coincidence! Or same failed lies.

title: Free Options for Filing Your Income Tax Return Electronically
description: If you have low to moderate annual income, youre most likely eligible for a variety of free or reduced-rate options for completing and electronically filing your federal income tax return.

title: New York City Comptrollers Office Names Chief Diversity Officer
description: Faced with a decreasing percentage of city money going to businesses owned by female and minority contractors, the New York City comptrollers office has named a new official and also announced that it will grade city agencies on how much they spend with these certified businesses.

title: Turkish Court Backs Generals Appeal
description: The Constitutional Court on Thursday ruled in favor of a former army chief who was appealing the legality of his initial detention in 2012 in a case that resulted in his conviction and life sentence last year for plotting a coup against the government, according to a written statement posted on the courts website. The ruling, which said that the rights of the former officer, Gen. Ilker Basbug, who served as military chief of staff from 2008 to 2010, had been violated, paved the way for his possible release from an Istanbul prison. The Constitutional Court said the lower court that held the five-year trial failed to publish its detailed reasoning for its verdict and send it to the appeals court, obstructing the defendants right to an appeal and violating a constitutional clause concerning personal freedom. The ruling could also be used as a precedent for the release of many of the more than 270 defendants who spent several years in prison before their convictions last year in the case known as the Ergenekon affair. The governments prosecution of that case was seen as an effort to curb the role of Turkeys military in politics, but it was also criticized for ensnaring people who were opponents of the government, including politicians, academics, journalists and writers.

title: U.S. Seems Unlikely to Accept That Rights Treaty Applies to Its Actions Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  In 1995, Conrad Harper, the Clinton administrations top State Department lawyer, appeared before a United Nations panel in Geneva to discuss American compliance with a global Bill of Rights-style treaty the Senate had recently ratified, and he was asked a pointed question: Did the United States believe it applied outside its borders?

title: Witness Says Defendant Spoke to Qaeda Trainees
description: A Buffalo-area man who went to Afghanistan and received military training at a camp run by Al Qaeda in the months before the Sept. 11 attacks testified on Thursday that he saw Sulaiman Abu Ghaith at a Qaeda guesthouse telling trainees about the concept of swearing an oath of loyalty, or giving bayat, to Osama bin Laden.

title: How de Blasios Narrative Got Hijacked
description: Last week on the 64th day of his mayoralty, Bill de Blasio, criticized for his too hardy approach to snow days, for the slow pace of his appointments, for displays of petulance, achieved a predicted but still significant victory. The City Planning Commission unanimously approved a reimagining of the Domino Sugar refinery on the Brooklyn waterfront, which the de Blasio administration had worked to ensure would have a greater number of apartments priced below market rate than had originally been proposed. Proving that he could compromise with developers, that he could alienate factions of a left that find excessive height distasteful as they clamor for more affordable housing, the mayor permitted the projects buildings to go to 55 stories, rather than 30 or 40.

title: De Blasio and Dolan Announce a Push for More Pre-K Classes
description: They exchanged chitchat about Michelangelo with 4-year-olds, spoke about the promise of early childhood education, and joked about which one of them should field a question directed at Your Eminence.

title: Memo on the Scope of States Parties Obligations
description: The State Departments former top lawyer, Harold Koh, concluded in October 2010 that the best reading of the accord is that it does impose certain obligations on a State Partys extraterritorial conduct.

title: Tanaka Is Praised by Phillies, Even One Who Homered Off Him
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  As rain pounded and smartphones buzzed with tornado warnings, fans fretted that there would be no game Thursday, while the Yankees cooled their cleats at their Tampa clubhouse, waiting for the word to make a 20-mile spring training trip.

title: Memo on the Convention Against Torture
description: The State Departments former top lawyer wrote in 2013, In my legal opinion, it is not legally available to policy makers to claim it has no application abroad.

title: To Change Indias Preference for Sons, Start With the Women
description: I first visited India as a tourist in 1971 at the age of 27. I spent six months backpacking through the country and was surprised to find so many people everywhere, even in the remote countryside. Mothers were always surrounded by small children, only a year or so apart in age.

title: Frank Jobe, Surgeon Who Saved Pitchers Careers, Dies at 88
description: On a July night in 1974, Dr. Frank Jobe, the orthopedist for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was sitting in the stands at Dodger Stadium watching the ace left-hander Tommy John face the Montreal Expos.

title: In Meeting of Mayors, de Blasio Holds His Own
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, the mayor of this Midwest metropolis, spoke of opening parks and libraries and renovating playgrounds. Eric Garcetti, the mayor of Los Angeles, boasted that he monitored Hollywood parking spaces in real time on his iPhone.

title: Cakes Galore at Bakery
description: Mrs. Maxwells Bakery in Brooklyn usually has about 240 finished cakes on display at a time.

title: Your Next Word Is Sardonic
description: The most delicious language in Bad Words, Jason Batemans debut as a feature-film director, has no place near tender ears. But the films premise is as wholesomely all-American as the tradition it skewers: Guy Trilby, a misanthrope with a serious case of lingering adolescent angst, played by Mr. Bateman, tries to earn some respect by wheedling his way onto the spelling bee circuit and stringing together letters into luxuriant polysyllabic parts of speech  all the way to nationals.

title: A Brooklyn Bakery Named for No One
description: It was a peaceful late Sunday morning at Mrs. Maxwells Bakery in East New York  but not for long. Services at the Brooklyn neighborhoods churches were about to conclude. We got crowd control ropes, so were ready, said Jenny Laruy, 57, who works the counter. And then a procession of cars and minivans began to stream into the bakerys parking lot. Doors slammed, and an army of well-dressed women in hats headed purposefully for the door.

title: The Mets Big Game: Four Batters, Three Pitchers
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Tradition Field was almost empty. The clubhouse was mostly cleared out. The majority of the Mets were scheduled to play in two games in Kissimmee, Fla., against the Astros. But here, on Thursday morning, there was to be a third game, if you could call it that. It consisted of Bartolo Colon, Jon Niese and Bobby Parnell taking turns facing live batters, in a gamelike situation, with no fans in the stands.

title: Japan Wont Impose Banking Laws on Bitcoin
description: TOKYO  Bitcoin trading platforms can, for now, operate freely under Japanese law, the government said Friday in a note that signaled a hands-off approach to the virtual currency.

title: The Case of the Accidental Superstar
description: In the peculiar-looking, former cross-dressing Shakespearean actor Benedict Cumberbatch, Hollywood has found an unlikely leading man.

title: J.P. Donleavy is Still Standing
description: Indeed, at 87, the author of the best-selling cult novel The Ginger Man merrily lives as a semi-reclusive gentleman farmer in shabby Grey Gardens-style splendor on his Irish estate. Meet Americas pre-eminent literary bohemian.

title: Dark Romance
description: Moody florals, ecclesiastical collars and voluminous silhouettes give poetic license to the softer side of dressing.

title: The Significance of the Minimum Wage for Women and Families
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Clinton.

title: Why High-Impact Exercise Is Good for Your Bones
description: This article appeared in the March 9, 2014 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Times Minute | The Fight for Crimea
description: Zeroing in on Crimea. Understanding the upcoming referendum, a look at Crimeas history and diplomatic reactions.

title: Times Minute | The Fight for Crimea
description: In the Video

title: Word of the Day | lineament
description: lineament \li-ne--mnt\ noun

title: 3 World Cup Warm-Ups for U.S. Men
description: The United States mens national team announced that it would play three home games before departing for Brazil and the 2014 World Cup, against Azerbaijan on May 27 in San Francisco; Turkey on June 1 at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J.; and Nigeria on June 7 in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: 2014: Rubios Speech at CPAC
description: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, spoke at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) FRIDAY NIGHT SPOTLIGHT: FOOD IN THE MOVIES A visual feast begins with Eat Drink Man Woman (1994), above, Ang Lees Oscar-nominated drama for best foreign-language film about a father, Mr. Chu (Sihung Lung)  the greatest chef in Taipei  who has lost his joie de vivre, and his three beautiful star-crossed daughters (Chien-Lien Wu, Kuei-Mei-Yang and Yu-Wen Wang), who cannot escape his spell. Tensions are so high that at their extravagant Sunday dinners, the family can barely eat. And so he begins to supply spectacular lunches to the daughter of a family friend, who is too young to realize that his cooking is flawed: He has lost the use of his taste buds. Wonderfully seductive, and nicely knowing about all of its characters appetites, Eat Drink Man Woman makes for an uncomplicatedly pleasant experience, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. This films use of food is both voluptuous and serious, amplifying the story even as it offers an irresistible diversion. The film succeeds in presenting Mr. Chus intricate cooking (rendered for the camera by three amazingly artful chefs) as an expression of larger traditionalism and as an endangered art. Of the title, she added: Food and sex, one character says succinctly, amplifying that four-ideogram phrase. Basic human desires. Cant avoid them. In Mostly Martha (2002), at 10:15, Martha (Martina Gedeck), a single, workaholic chef in Hamburg, Germany, finds her carefully organized life in disarray when she must care for her dead sisters 8-year-old daughter (Maxime Foerste). Enter Mario, the Italian sous-chef (Sergio Castellitto) who can charm everyone but Martha. The movie succeeds because the writer and director, Sandra Nettelbeck, seems as obsessive as her titular heroine, Elvis Mitchell wrote in The Times. The final confection is extremely enjoyable, though a few degrees shy of perfection.

title: Default Signals Growing Maturity of Chinas Corporate Bond Market
description: HONG KONG  A small producer of solar panels on Friday became the first company in recent history to default in Chinas domestic bond market. The development was welcomed by analysts as a sign that the nations huge but protected corporate debt market may be growing up.

title: Corrections: March 7, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: For First Time, Kremlin Signals It Is Prepared to Annex Crimea
description: MOSCOW  Russia signaled for the first time on Friday that it was prepared to annex the Crimea region of Ukraine, significantly intensifying its confrontation with the West over the political crisis in Ukraine and threatening to undermine a system of respect for national boundaries that has helped keep the peace in Europe and elsewhere for decades.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, March 7, 2014
description: Use the following question for practice in identifying the subject and verb of a sentence.

title: Part Owner of British Soccer Club Is Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison
description: HONG KONG  Carson Yeung, the Hong Kong businessman who partly owns the British soccer club Birmingham City, was sentenced on Friday to six years in prison for money laundering.

title: Adding Elders and Children to a Domestic Violence Law
description: A long-awaited law against domestic violence in China must address elder abuse, which happens quite a lot despite Chinas cultural tradition of respect for the elderly, said Sun Xiaomei, a delegate to the National Peoples Congress, which is meeting now in Beijing.

title: 6 Qs About the News | E-Cigarettes, by Other Names, Lure Young and Worry Experts
description: In E-Cigarettes, by Other Names, Lure Young and Worry Experts, Matt Richtel writes about a subgenre of the fast-growing e-cigarette market that is being shrewdly marketed to young people.

title: Venezuela in Black-and-White
description: Carlos Cruz-Diez is known for his work with color  paintings where tightly packed stripes seem to vibrate as the viewer shifts perspective, light chambers where participant-observers saunter through drenching color lights. But an exhibit at the Americas Society in New York puts the artist himself in a new light, showcasing his early fascination with photography.

title: How Much Does the SAT or ACT Matter in Your Life?
description: For millions of high school students, the SAT or ACT serves as a gatekeeper helping to determine where they go to college. Some families spend thousands of dollars on test preparation courses or private tutors because they think so much is riding on test scores.

title: Londons Laundry Business
description: LONDON  THE city has changed. The buses are still dirty, the people are still passive-aggressive, but something about London has changed. You can see signs of it everywhere. The townhouses in the capitals poshest districts are empty; they have been sold to Russian oligarchs and Qatari princes.

title: New York Today: Art Abounds
description: Good Friday morning. The temperature is climbing. But its still pretty cold  32 degrees.

title: Two Banks Said to Suspend Employees in Currency Investigation
description: LONDON  Two more banks have suspended employees in the latest escalation of an investigation into potential manipulation of the $5 trillion-a-day foreign exchange markets, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: The Macho Cops of Honduras
description: SAN SALVADOR  WHEN Hondurass new president, Juan Orlando Hernndez, took office a little more than a month ago, he promised to apply mano dura  the iron fist  against criminals. His plans include granting police officers more freedom to arrest suspects and greater use of the army for public safety. This strategy is a continuation of the hard-line policies of the last few years, which have done nothing to change the fact that Honduras still has the worlds highest homicide rate.

title: Censors Hit Delete on a Party Chiefs Censorship Remarks
description: The question runs through the minds of many Chinese microblog users: What catches the eye of an online censor on any given day?

title: Thoughts That Cant Be Spoken
description: MONDION, France  ONE early evening a week before last Christmas, I sat down at my desk to answer a letter. But just as I was about to write the first words, I felt as if they were escaping me, vanishing into air before reaching the paper. I was surprised but not concerned. I was very tired and promised myself to stop work after finishing the note.

title: For Entrepreneur in Conflict Resolution, Business Is Good
description: In January, Alma Abdul-Hadi Jadallah was in Geneva, helped run a meeting of Syrian women for the United Nations. Last year, she took four or five trips to Yemen, to assist in talks to create the countrys new political system. Before that, she developed processes to ease religious tensions in Iraq.

title: Daily Report: Mystery Swirls Around Unmasking of Bitcoin Inventor
description: Central to Bitcoins cachet has been the mythic status of the systems creator, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams report. Its developer went by the name Satoshi Nakamoto, but that is all that Bitcoins adopters seemed to know  or wanted to know. After all, Bitcoin was a project dedicated in part to making it easier to avoid the all-seeing gaze of the government and corporate America.

title: As Kerry Visits Jordan, Abbas Holds His Ground
description: JERUSALEM  Secretary of State John Kerry made an unannounced visit to Jordan on Friday to consult King Abdullah II about the Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, even as the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, reiterated positions that underscored the challenge Mr. Kerry faces in trying to shrink gaps between the two sides.

title: In Kolkata, Reminders of Why We Help the Last Girl
description: The womens rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem kept a diary of their travels throughout India as they met the countrys young feminists, writers and thought leaders (previous posts are here, here and here). In this installation for India Ink, Ms. Gupta and Ms. Steinem visit Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal.

title: Cerberus and Safeway Strike $9 Billion Deal
description: SUPER DEAL: CERBERUS TO BUY SAFEWAY FOR $9 BILLION | In one of the largest leveraged buyouts since the financial crisis, a group led by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management agreed on Thursday to acquire Safeway in a deal worth more than $9 billion, Michael J. de la Merced and William Alden write in DealBook. The deal, which will be financed by $7.6 billion worth of borrowed money, is the biggest leveraged buyout so far this year. Cerberus plans to merge Safeway with Albertsons, a smaller grocery store chain that it owns.

title: Digital Trade School Raises $35 Million in Financing Round
description: With more people looking to jump into the Internet economy, General Assembly, a school of sorts for digital business skills, is growing as well.

title: Police Detain Government Employee in Beating of Nurse
description: The police in Nanjing have detained a government employee after a video of the beating a nurse generated widespread outrage online, the state news media reported.

title: U.N. Womens Rights Group Seeks Mens Support
description: In a campaign from the United Nations that seeks to promote womens rights, there is not a woman in sight  and that is deliberate.

title: Teenagers in The Times | February 2014
description: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson Teaching With Teenagers in The Times.

title: A Deeper Conversation on Women in Hedge Funds
description: Whitney Tilson is the managing partner of the hedge fund firm Kase Capital Management, which he founded more than 15 years ago. Mr. Tilson is also the co-founder of Value Investor Insight, an investment newsletter, and the Value Investing Congress, a biannual investment conference.

title: As Job Creation Increases in February, Economists See Signs of a Spring Thaw
description: The American economy appeared to emerge from a winter hibernation in February, creating more jobs than in either of the previous two months and suggesting that momentum in the labor market might gradually build with the arrival of spring.

title: Coffee Comeuppance
description: Dear Diary:

title: A.C.P.T. 2014: On Your Marks  Get Set Wait! First, Theres Work To Do
description: SPECIAL POST  Molo, sawubona and hallo! I just spent some time in Cape Town, South Africa, and I honestly think I left my heart there. What a beautiful, lively place: its a city abuzz with artistic energy that just happens to be nestled luxuriously between captivating mountains and the sea. Most of all, its warm there, which is definitely a plus these days.

title: What the Jobs Report Means for the Fed
description: The February jobs report doesnt change the strong likelihood that the Federal Reserve will cut monthly bond purchases by another $10 billion later this month.

title: Judge Dismisses Charges Against Whistle-Blower in Sexual Abuse Case
description: In a case that riveted the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn, a judge on Friday dismissed all charges against Samuel Kellner, a whistle-blower who had been charged with trying to extort money from the family of an accused molester and bribing a grand jury witness to testify falsely.

title: A Rare Government Success Story for Womens Empowerment in Kerala
description: ERNAKULAM, Kerala  In a country that has been criticized as lacking commitment to womens rights, one program in the southwest state of Kerala has been quietly serving as an example that a government can indeed successfully empower women, both economically and socially.

title: Nation of CRINOs
description: A term we really need: Center-Right In Name Only.

title: Plcido Domingo, by the Numbers
description: One of the worlds most famous tenors has continued performing into his 70s by expanding his repertoire. A look back at his career highlights.

title: More On Wages And Monetary Policy
description: Todays employment report gives us another data point on private-sector wages, which continue to run well below pre-crisis levels:

title: Into the Mouths of Babes
description: Oh, my  not only was Paul Ryans hunger=dignity speech appalling on the merits, the anecdote he used to make his point was fake  a distortion of a real story with a completely different point.

title: Court Orders Kansas Legislature to Spend More on Schools
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  Kansass highest court ruled on Friday that funding disparities between school districts violated the states Constitution and ordered the Legislature to bridge the gap, setting the stage for a messy budget battle in the capital this year.

title: Ukrainian Team Remains at Paralympics, for Now
description: SOCHI, Russia  Citing a desire to promote peace, Ukraines delegation to the Paralympics said Friday that it would compete in the Games instead of withdrawing in protest of Russias intervention in the Crimean Peninsula. But the leader of its delegation cautioned that Ukraine would return home immediately if the conflict in Crimea intensified.

title: Domingo Undimmed
description: Plcido Domingos day began with a morning dress rehearsal on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, where he traded jokes with the cast and crew at a theater where he has been singing for nearly half a century, and then, in full regalia as the sea god Neptune, ran through a new Handel aria he was learning for the revival of The Enchanted Island, a Baroque pastiche.

title: Rising Rents Leave New York Artists Out in the Cold
description: Artists have wedged their canvases and supplies into their apartments. Others are working in hurricane-torn basements or in temporary, borrowed spaces. As their creative spaces have shrunk, so, too, has their art  if, that is, they still make art.

title: Dont Blink, Youll Miss the Scenery
description: Chat with the people behind Love and Information, the new play by the British playwright Caryl Churchill, and they sound like game geeks, not theater makers.

title: In Our Pages: March 8
description: 1914: Girl Poses As Boy to Join Navy

title: Incomplete Recovery for Working-Age Men
description: Men between the ages of 25 and 54 are in their prime working years. Generally speaking, theyre too old for college and too young for retirement.

title: Whose Anxiety Is It?
description: One morning, after the superintendent closed our towns schools for the third snowstorm of the season, I looked out my kitchen window to see packs of neighborhood kids dragging brightly colored sleds down our cul-de-sac. No doubt they were heading for Hospital Hill, the favorite sledding mecca of the local orthopedists union.

title: For Pessimist or Optimist, Jobs Report Is More of the Same
description: In these last three years, there have been countless times when a couple of months in a row of surprisingly good or surprisingly bad jobs readings have given a false signal, prompting either a sense of glum disappointment or (with hindsight) misplaced optimism about whether a meaningful economic recovery is underway. It has made fools of many good economic analysts who have been too quick to detect turning points.

title: Behind Barclays About-Face on Bonuses
description: Barclays wants you to know that it tried.

title: Chancellor Says She Regrets Remarks About a Harlem Charter School
description: The New York City schools chancellor, facing criticism for denying public classroom space to a Harlem charter school, said on Friday that she would work to find space for about 200 children affected by the decision.

title: Fiction in Translation
description: KARATE CHOP  Stories  By Dorthe Nors. Translated by Martin Aitken.A Public Space/Graywolf, paper, $14.

title: Blood Relations
description: In early 1945, a German radiologist left his post at a hospital in Weimar and attempted to make his way across the war-ravaged countryside to his family. Before entering the American zone, he buried his gun and, while sheltering in an attic, hid letters from his new wife urging him in coded language to desert. During a home renovation in the 1980s, the bundle of letters was discovered, hidden in a wall, and returned to the doctors family. The correspondence revealed the trials of a young woman raising the three sons from her husbands first marriage. That the soundtrack to her struggle was the whine of air-raid sirens and the thud of bombs made it all the more remarkable.

title: Editors Choice
description: BOY, SNOW, BIRD,  by Helen Oyeyemi. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Taking Snow White as a cultural touchstone, Oyeyemis novel offers up a cautionary tale on post-race ideology, racial limbos and the politics of passing.

title: Paperback Row
description: WHY PRIESTS?: A Failed Tradition,  by Garry Wills. (Penguin, $16.) Wills  who as a young man spent more than five years in a Jesuit seminary  finds only a dubious foundation for the Roman Catholic priesthood, and its religious powers, in the books of the New Testament. Using his linguistic skills and his impressive command of both secondary literature and patristic sources, the author doesnt advocate its elimination, but asks, Why did the priesthood come into a religion that began without it and, indeed, opposed it?

title: Strangers to Themselves
description: On a quiet side street in a dusty, unremarkable Beijing neighborhood in the last days of autumn, 1989, a young woman named Shaoai drinks a glass of Tang  an exotic delicacy  and becomes strangely ill. Taken to the hospital, she slips quickly into a coma. At home, waiting anxiously for her return, are her parents (here simply called Uncle and Aunt); a distant teenage cousin, Ruyu, who lives with them and shares a room with Shaoai; and two intimate friends of Ruyus, Moran and Boyang.

title: A Walk Through Time
description: In the winter of 1933, an 18-year-old named Patrick Leigh Fermor set out from the Hook of Holland to cross Europe on foot. His goal was Istanbul, which he bookishly insisted on calling Constantinople. He had little more in his rucksack than a volume of Horace and a few blank notebooks. He also had a bad reputation: The masters who expelled him from school  for a flirtation with a local girl  saw only a dangerous mixture of sophistication and recklessness. He spent the next year charming his way through a doomed prewar landscape of landed aristocrats, feudal peasants and benevolent monks, sleeping alternately in schlosses and hayricks. It was a journey that would become legendary, not so much for the extraordinary things he saw and recorded as for his prose  an utterly unique, hybrid vehicle that combines youthful exuberance with a dense, dauntingly erudite display of verbal artifice. Unlike most authors of travel literature (a rattlebag genre that doesnt really do him justice) Leigh Fermor does not confine his role to that of camera obscura. He builds dense whorls of wordplay to echo the carvings in an old church door; he slips into baroque historical fantasias, scattering a shrapnel of words like gabions, hydromel, eyot and swingletrees at the unsuspecting reader. In between salvos, there are moments of ferocious humor and quiet, lyrical beauty.

title: Shrinking Governments: Good or Bad?
description: One accomplishment  well, to the Tea Party it would seem to be an accomplishment  of the Obama administration is the recession in government hiring.

title: The Deconstructionist Deconstructed
description: Stories about charming scoundrels have a built-in appeal, especially if the scoundrel is young and handsome  and of course he must be very smart. Think of Leonardo Di Caprio in Catch Me if You Can, or of Thomas Manns comic con man Felix Krull. How do they fool so many people for so long?

title: A Life in Pieces
description: Which feels more true: a memoir told in fits and starts, stutters and sighs, a blend of sensual details and analytic asides? Or one that hews to the conventions of narrative with a beginning, middle and end? All memoirists know order is a contrivance, but readers also rely on the writer to create art by organizing the mess of life.

title: A Suspect With an Incriminating Tattoo Saves Face
description: The robbery case, now two years old, at first had seemed pretty open-and-shut.

title: In Over His Head
description: The surf at Far Rockaway, Queens, is typically small, wind-tattered and weak, and for most of the year its freezing cold. Yes, there are days when the waves are passably good, and rare days when they are powerful and shapely, but thats true of breaks in the Great Lakes and Italy. What sets Far Rockaway apart is that its a subway ride away from Manhattan, a fact recently rediscovered by a younger crop of culture workers who took up surfing and by dint of beginners zeal have added a wholesome, sun-spangled dimension to the hard-soled, mean-streets experience of life in New York, retrofitting Far Rockaway with smoothie stands and half-million-dollar surf shacks among the grim low-income high-rises.

title: The Bailey Bunch
description: Think of the opening sections of The Splendid Things We Planned, Blake Baileys achingly honest memoir, as a kind of personality test or perhaps an obstacle course. Not every reader is going to pass, but then again, not every reader is entitled to such a fearless, deeply felt and often frightening book.

title: Devils Deeds
description: In the three decades since the Jonestown mass murder-suicides left 918 dead in Guyana, journalists and academics have struggled to make sense of the senseless tragedy, producing hundreds of books, articles and scholarly papers on the topic. Recently, the F.B.I. released its Jonestown files  almost 50,000 pieces of paper and 1,000 audiotapes that agents collected from the compound after the massacre  giving researchers a trove of primary sources that document the fatal downward spiral of Jim Jones and his promised land.

title: Dreaming in Code
description: In June of this year, the World Cup in Brazil will begin not with a flashy musical number or a team of flying acrobats but with a simple scientific demonstration. A paralyzed teenager will make the ceremonial first kick. This feat will be accomplished through an exoskeleton directly controlled by the teenagers thoughts and read through a helmet-mounted EEG machine. That kick, guided by an extraordinary brain-to-machine interface, may be our initiation into our post-human future. In that brave new world our memories will be recorded and swapped like old videotapes, self-aware robots will be our companions, and our consciousness, downloaded onto machines, will live forever. Its a future Michio Kaku, the string theorist turned popular scientist, believes is inevitable and closer than we think.

title: Mouths to Feed
description: The story goes that when Andr Breton visited Mexico in 1938, he was struck by the beautiful handicrafts and asked an artisan to make him a chair. Breton sketched a design in crude perspective, with a fourth leg hidden by the square of the seat. The artisan built a splendid chair, with only three legs. Breton proclaimed Mexico the most surrealist country in the world. Salvador Dal supposedly agreed and swore he would never return to a country more surrealist than his paintings.

title: Too Many Cooks
description: Nothing on the dessert menu is really working for Leo, one of the owners of Winesap, an upscale restaurant in the economically struggling, fictional Pennsylvania town of Linden. But theres one item in particular thats really killing him: the individual chocolate cake in crme anglaise. It had been years since the dessert was new, he realizes, and whether restaurants called it mi-cuit or chocolate lava . . . it didnt change the fact that this little round cake now crushed Leo with a mighty ennui, nor that Winesap sold as many of them as the kitchen could make.

title: Inside the List
description: The Nabokov Code: Lorrie Moores new story collection, Bark, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 13  her third consecutive best seller, after the novel A Gate at the Stairs (2009) and the collection Birds of America (1998). Reviewing Bark on the cover of the Book Review a few weeks ago, David Gates noted that Moore shares Vladimir Nabokovs affinity for obsessive wordplay, although her outlook is darker; she is, he wrote, the most Beckettian of Nabokovians. What Gates didnt mention (but surely knew) was that Bark contains a direct tribute to Nabokov: Moores story Referential, about a couple visiting the womans son in a mental hospital, borrows its premise and some of its language from Nabokovs 1948 story Signs and Symbols, in which the patient imagines that everything happening around him is a veiled reference to his personality and existence. A story about a story about a man who thinks everything is about him: Hows that for referential?

title: F.D.R. Makes the Case for the Minimum Wage
description: In the more than 75 years since Congress first enacted a federal minimum wage  at 25 cents an hour  lawmakers have increased it nine times, reaching the current level of $7.25 an hour in 2009. And with every increase the same objections have been raised.

title: DNA of a Polymath, Restlessly Mutating
description: Not long into the New York premiere of Vijay Iyers Time, Place, Action at the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan last weekend, there came a moment of deep, transfixing confluence between the composer and his partners for the evening, the Brentano String Quartet. It arrived in a largely improvised second movement, as a single sustained note slowly morphed into something as layered and ephemeral as a rolling cloud bank. Mr. Iyers first piano chord brought a bolt of clarity, and with it a blush of instant communion.

title: New Cold War Would Differ From Old
description: RUSSIA had some real economic problems even before the Ukrainian crisis led the United States and European countries to threaten sanctions on the country after the Russian flag was raised in Crimea, a part of Ukraine, and troops who spoke Russian appeared to take over a significant part of the region.

title: Skills Practice | Proofreading and Fact-Checking
description: How carefully do you read? Do you catch errors in your own work? In published pieces?

title: BlackBerry Boss Says Company Must Be About More Than Phones
description: LOS ANGELES  John S. Chen has signed a five-year contract to be chief executive of BlackBerry, and has a plan that runs just about that length of time.

title: RuPauls House of Mirrors
description: A low-fat brandy Alexander; hangin with the Osmonds.

title: Reply All: The 2.23.14 Issue
description: ON THE ROAD ACROSS SOUTH AMERICA

title: The Guardians Alan Rusbridger: Its Essential to Be Paranoid
description: Youve played piano since you were a child, and youve written about parallels between this pursuit and digital news. Can you explain that? Amateur music-making used to be very commonplace and was valued in its own right. When recorded sound came along, most people became the passive receivers of other peoples music. I do think that mirrors something thats going on in journalism at the moment, which is that anybody can blog, anybody can tweet, anybody can write and publish.

title: Who Made That Progress Bar?
description: People wait for all sorts of things every day, sometimes more happily than others, wrote the interface designer Bob Stahl in a 1986 article for Computerworld. The problem is how the user feels about waiting. At the time, machines were often slow and unreliable, and users didnt always know when their programs crashed. A progress bar might mitigate frustration, Stahl suggested, by signaling that bits were flipping with a purpose somewhere deep inside the C.P.U.

title: All the Single Ladies
description: The day had been hot and long, beginning on the Cape Cod beach where we watched the bride marry her now-husband as the tide came in a few minutes too soon  or, more likely, the wedding happened just a few minutes too late  despite careful timing based on the lunar calendar. Afterward, a string quartet led us through the tall sand grass and up into the dunes to the country club, where we ate and drank and drank some more in celebration of our friend, who was now a wife.

title: Domestic Surveillance?
description: Last summer, my wife and I drove around Palm Springs to look at houses designed by famous architects. At the entrance to one house was a sign with fairly threatening language regarding trespassing. It made us feel like we were invading someones privacy, which leads me to my question: Does a person who buys a home of historic or architectural significance have a different relationship to the public than a person who owns a home of no significance? MIKE MILEY, METAIRIE, LA.

title: Yoga Poses in Israel
description: In 1997, Rachel Kolberg was newly married, pregnant and living in Tel Aviv when she went to her first yoga class. It was a revelation. Her husband, Avraham, soon began practicing with her. I was looking for some spiritual support, he says. Yoga gave that to me. Seven years later, the couple opened their own studio, determined to introduce yoga to fellow Orthodox Jews in Beit Shemesh. They teach Iyengar yoga, a discipline that encourages the use of props to assist with poses. While yoga is increasingly popular in Israel, Avraham says, it is revolutionary in their neighborhood. Their students, taught in single-sex classes, are encouraged to come as they are, even in day clothes or long skirts, if necessary. The Kolbergs say yoga helps people who spend long days in prayer and study and arent physically active. But, Rachel says, in our studio, we will never have practices that contradict our religion, such as mantras and chanting. Julie Bosman

title: Animating Owen
description: Roger Ross Williams, the Academy Award-winning filmmaker, spent time with Ron Suskind and his son, Owen, who has autism, to show how they learned to communicate using dialogue from Disney movies.

title: Reaching My Autistic Son Through Disney
description: In our first year in Washington, our son disappeared.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Phil Klays Redeployment
description: This week, Phil Klay talks about Redeployment; John B. Judis discusses Genesis; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Phil Klays Redeployment
description: This week, Phil Klay and John B. Judis.

title: Malaysian Opposition Leader Sentenced in Sodomy Case
description: A Malaysian appeals court sentenced Anwar Ibrahim, the countrys opposition leader, on Friday to five years in prison on charges of sodomy, a conviction that critics described as an attempt to block the oppositions ascendancy at a time when the governing partys popularity is waning.

title: Peeling Back the Layers of Naxos, Greece
description: At dusk we walked up a path along the stream that stitches together Pano Potamia and Kato Potamia, two villages in the most fertile part of Naxos, the Greek island. While most of the other Cycladic islands are as dry as toast, Naxos is covered in verdant valleys and mountain villages, clusters of whitewashed houses nestled into a Bruegel-like landscape.

title: Video Reviews of The Grand Budapest Hotel, Bethlehem and The Face of Love
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on The Grand Budapest Hotel, The Face of Love and Bethlehem. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Following an 8-Year-Old to Atlantis
description: The warm drizzle swelled the corridors and shops and casino with teenagers in dripping beachwear and toddlers splashing their wet, bare feet on the marble as their parents trailed along at an unconcerned pace. Still, sun blasted through the windows and bathed the gilded statues of heroes from a mythical island in a soft, golden hue.

title: George Takei Reflects on Travel, Both Painful and Pleasurable
description: George Takei is a man of many speaking engagements. He talks at Star Trek conventions about his role as Mr. Sulu. He tells soldiers and students about the role of Japanese-Americans during World War II, a subject in which he is well versed. In a new musical, Allegiance, based on his familys experience living in internment camps during the war, he actually sings the story.

title: Cabbage Torta
description: If theres one dish that will persuade your family to like cabbage, its a golden torta filled with sauteed cabbage, browned onions and creamy cheese.

title: Home Tweet Home
description: They are questions that can upend a workday without warning: did you remember to turn the stove off? Did you leave the air-conditioning on? Did the house burn down? These quotidian worries, banal but sometimes all-consuming, have nagged at generations of homeowners and renters.

title: Cabbage Goes Undercover
description: Savory pastries  pies, tarts, quiches, tortas and the like  are so inherently appealing that it doesnt really matter what you fill them with.

title: Pensive Trumpet, Long on Nuance
description: The 31-year-old trumpeter and composer Ambrose Akinmusire brings a watchful, simmering, hazy-beauty sensibility to his interactions with the post-bop lineage, where lines often tend to be more sharply drawn. His second album on Blue Note, the imagined savior is far easier to paint,is full of moments that lean toward the expressionistic, sometimes featuring a string ensemble or a vocalist delving into what amounts to art song.

title: Islamic Accents in Dutch Dcor
description: Carpets of the East in Paintings from the West, which opens Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a small show drawn from the museums collection that delves into the pictorial effects of the European taste for Islamic carpets, which dates from the 14th century. These textiles became staples of artists studios, initially in religious paintings, especially to spruce up settings for Madonna and child images. One kind of boldly bordered rug appeared so often in the 16th-century paintings of Lorenzo Lotto that it came to be known as the Lotto pattern.

title: Art of Variations, Debussy to Berio
description: Classical music in New York is full of tough choices. On Monday, while the star pianist Evgeny Kissin plays Carnegie Hall, two rising soloists with wide-ranging tastes will have recitals of their own. Upstairs, at Carnegies Weill Recital Hall, the adventurous cellist Jay Campbell will be joined by the pianist Conor Hanick and the percussionist Mike Truesdell. Their program, presented by the Concert Artists Guild, includes Debussys Sonata in D Minor for Cello and Piano, Stravinskys Suite Italienne, a new piece by David Fulmer and recent works by Matthias Pintscher and Simon Steen-Andersen. (7:30 p.m., 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

title: A Cheesy Hercules, A Slasher and More
description: A lot has happened since Conan the Destroyer came out in 1984. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who played the title role, has completed one of the weirdest circles in movie history, from monosyllabic star to governor and back to monosyllabic star. The genre  muscles, swords and skimpy outfits  has found new life on pay-cable television. And the films director, Richard Fleischer, who died in 2006, has come to be appreciated for his versatility, if not always for his quality.

title: Chase a Stranger, Then Make a Scene
description: On a cold December afternoon, Billy Eichner is running full speed on 23rd Street in Chelsea, holding a potato aloft.

title: Hey, a Strip Club Might Be Fun
description: Mi network is su network is how the director Robert Rodriguez describes El Rey, his new English-language cable channel aimed at Hispanic audiences. And how better to make the network his own than with From Dusk Till Dawn: The Series, a spinoff of his 1996 supernatural cult western.

title: Book Review Podcast: Redeployment
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Dexter Filkins reviews Redeployment, a collection of stories by Phil Klay, a former Marine who served in Iraq. Mr. Filkins writes:

title: Wage Gains for Middle-Wage Workers Are a Good Sign, Not a Threat
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Times Minute | Highlights From CPAC
description: Also on the Minute, intrigue over the inventor of Bitcoin and Plcido Domingo makes a second career as a baritone.

title: Times Minute | Highlights From CPAC
description: In the Video

title: Aurora Hunters
description: Rafael de Cardenas, a Manhattan-based architect with a coveted furniture line who has also designed interiors for the likes of Nike and Baccarat, and Robert Storey, a London-based set designer/art director whose client list has included Victoria Beckham and British Vogue, have been in each others lives for about three years. And though their creative careers might suggest that they mostly collaborate professionally, its actually the classic bond of friendship that ties the two together.

title: Today in Small Business: Is It the End of the Supermarket?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: A Hoarder Tries to Let Go
description: Kevin McCrary, a Manhattan hoarder, is running out of space and time. After receiving a final notice of eviction, he is trying to save what he can from a 30-year build-up of "trash" and "treasure."

title: Russia Has Already Lost the War
description: KIEV, Ukraine  OVER the past two weeks, residents of Kiev have lived through its bloodiest conflict since the Second World War, watched their reviled president flee and a new, provisional team take charge, seen Russian troops take control of part of the country, and heard Russias president, Vladimir V. Putin, assert his right to take further military action. Yet the Ukrainian capital is calm.

title: Bill Cunningham | Winter Blues and Pinks
description: Two popular color trends brightening this drawn-out winter are sapphire blue and dusty pastels.

title: Stepping In for Foreign Apartment Owners
description: When the dishwasher broke in Chaim Chisics two-bedroom condominium in a luxury building in Lower Manhattan and couldnt be fixed, his tenant proposed that he buy a new one for $2,000 and deduct it from the rent. Mr. Chisic, who is in the diamond business and lives in Tel Aviv, had a better idea: call Dylan Pichulik, the chief executive of XL Real Property Management, who manages the apartment for him.

title: Image of the Day: March 7
Bill Cunningham | Winter Blues (and Pinks)
description: WINTER BLUES (AND PINKS) Two popular color trends brightening this drawn-out winter are sapphire blue, which popped up last fall and came into full flower in February (complete with blue-eyed Eskimo dogs), and dusty pastels, in soft pinks and sweet-pea shades of blue, green and mauve.
