Those pastels owe a lot to the many Asian women attending the February fashion shows in colors much subtler than the shocking pinks prevalent in the West.

title: After the Deluge, Its Back to the Stage
description: On the night of Oct. 29, 2012, the basement storage of the Martha Graham Dance Company was overrun with water from the nearby Hudson River, pushed across the West Side Highway by Hurricane Sandy. The company had moved into its new studios at the Westbeth artists complex in the West Village three months earlier, taking possession of what had for decades been the home of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. Costumes and sets dating back to the 1940s and 50s, some designed and worn by Graham herself, lay in grimy water for days. Starting on March 19, at City Center, nearly 16 months later, the Graham troupe will present its second New York season since the storm.

title: Martha Graham: Myth and Transformation
description: After losing costumes and sets to Hurricane Sandy, the Martha Graham Dance Company rebuilds, recreates and reinvents itself.

title: Movie Review: 'The Face of Love'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Face of Love."

title: Share Your Moment of New York Redemption
description: As I descended the subway staircase at 28th and Broadway just before 8 a.m., I experienced that moment every New Yorker fears: The woman in front of me suddenly ran toward the turnstiles as soon as she reached the bottom of the stairs, suggesting a train was at the platform. I was about to do The Sprint, sure to leave me with either just-made-it glory or just-missed-it agony.

title: Buried by His Past
description: Kevin McCrary stood just inside the doorway of his Upper East Side apartment the other day, looking at photographs.

title: Movie Review: 'The Grand Budapest Hotel'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Grand Budapest Hotel.

title: Vijay Iyer, Jazz Weather Vane
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the jazz composer and musician Vijay Iyer and his new classical album, Mutations.

title: Movie Review: 'Bethlehem'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Bethlehem."

title: Bringing Hollywoods Attention Back Home
description: LOS ANGELES  Once, everyone who knew movies knew the neon clown at the North Hollywood liquor store in Clueless. The green harbor bridge from the bungee jump in To Live and Die in L.A. The boulevard palms in Beverly Hills Cop.

title: 5 Baggage Handlers Are Accused of Stealing From Mail at Kennedy Airport
description: Five baggage handlers responsible for loading mail onto international flights at Kennedy International Airport were arrested on Thursday and accused of stealing thousands of dollars worth of checks, credit cards and money orders, according to the authorities.

title: Playing for Pleasure
description: From the seasoned professional to the amateur, chamber musicians from around the globe dusted off their instruments for Worldwide Play-In Weekend at the beginning of March.

title: An It Artist Makes Her Mark on Smythsons Storied Leather Goods
description: After being commissioned last fall by the British leather goods and stationery maker Smythson to make a series of collages for its London Fashion Week presentation, the mixed-media artist and filmmaker Quentin Jones is returning to the brand, this time applying her work directly onto the labels signature stationery and accessories. The collaboration, available Monday at Colette in Paris and at smythson.com beginning March 31, features pouches, bags and notebooks from the brands Panama Legacy collection, designed by Rory OHanlon. These, together with coordinating keychains, bear the whimsical, surrealist illustrations and calligraphy that the 30-year-old Jones has become renowned for in the worlds of art and fashion. I thought about my favorite examples of artists who work with pure lines: Miro, Picasso, early Hockney and Ben Nicholson, says Jones of her approach to the visuals. Smythsons classic Soho notebook has been rebelliously tagged in gold with the phrases Soho Saint and Soho Sinner; a winking cat adorns a zippered pouch and cross-body bag; a sharp white leather tote bears a cluster of floating eyes. And starting on March 31, the brands Panama notebooks can be custom-embossed with Joness motifs in Smythsons New York store. It is so fun for me to work in 3-D, says Jones, and to make things that I want to own and wear myself.

title: Let There Be Chamber Music
description: In cafes and churches, in living rooms and waiting rooms around the world, the Worldwide Music Play-In welcomed classical musicians.

title: Inheriting Stress
description: WE intuitively understand, and scientific studies confirm, that if a woman experiences stress during her pregnancy, it can affect the health of her baby. But what about stress that a woman experiences before getting pregnant  perhaps long before?

title: Home League, National Goal
description: Math has never been my strong suit, but there is one logic progression that has been spouted so often by so many people in soccer that it has become hard not to believe. A universal theory about American mens soccer, such as it is, goes something like this:

title: Musicians Old and Young, Experienced and Not, Join a Global Play-In
description: For brief, blissful moments last weekend, the cacophony of New York City fell to a hush. Children put down their phones to listen to one another play Haydn. Old friends picked up where they had left off decades ago.

title: Streaming Home Movies Online
description: Q. Is there a way to take old family movies on DVD and convert them to digital files on the computer that can then be uploaded to the web and privately streamed online by family members?

title: Building Bridges Between the Military and Universities
description: The music of the brass and drum section set the cadence for the midshipmen marching into the hall, turning sharp corners and snapping to attention in front of the distinguished guests, faculty and veterans eager to celebrate the return of the Naval Reserve Ofcers Training Corps to Columbia University after an absence of more than 40 years.

title: More Money Needed to Avert Disaster in Central African Republic, U.N. Warns
description: GENEVA  Urgent action is needed to avert more carnage and deaths from hunger and disease in the Central African Republic, but relief agencies are acutely short of funds, the United Nations chief aid coordinator, Valerie Amos, warned on Friday.

title: Court Upholds Ruling Against Ryanair
description: PARIS  A British court on Friday upheld an order that Ryanair sell most of its 29 percent stake in Aer Lingus, agreeing with regulators findings that the holding gives the low-cost carrier too much influence over its Irish rival.

title: Bitcoins Purported Founder Speaks Out
description: Newsweek reported that Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto was the founder of the digital currency Bitcoin. But Mr. Nakamoto denied the claim in an exclusive interview with The Associated Press.

title: Why Russia Cant Afford Another Cold War
description: Russian troops pour over a border. An autocratic Russian leader blames the United States and unspecified radicals and nationalists for meddling. A puppet leader pledges fealty to Moscow.

title: In Parched California, Town Taps Run Nearly Dry
description: LAKE OF THE WOODS, Calif.  People in this mountain town straddling the San Andreas Fault are used to scrapping for water. The lake for which it is named went dry 40 years ago. But now, this tiny community is dealing with its most unsettling threat yet: It could run out of water by summer.

title: The Glory of Irish Food, Captured in a Whole Fish
description: Ill admit I was rather ignorant about Ireland in general, and Irish food in particular, when I stepped off the plane in Dublin for the first time last spring.

title: Wheelies: The Mulallys Millions Edition
description: UPDATED: March 14, 2014

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: As Generals Sex Assault Trial Opens, Accuser Describes Violence and Threats
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  At one point putting her head in her hands and sobbing, the Army captain who has accused Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair of sexual assault took the witness stand on Friday on the first day of his closely watched court-martial. During five hours of testimony, the 34-year-old captain chronicled in detail a three-year affair that included casual sex at an operating base in Iraq and in a hotel room in North Carolina, but also, she said, violent moments where he forced her to perform oral sex and threatened to kill her if she disclosed their relationship.

title: Until the Wells Run Dry
description: Lake of the Woods, a small community north of Los Angeles, is running dry amid a deep California drought. Residents are changing water habits, but many worry about the future.

title: Grover Norquist for Conservative (Not Liberal) Prison Reform
description: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md.  Grover Norquist, founder of Americans for Tax Reform and shadow enforcer of Republican orthodoxy, has an odd way of agreeing with liberals.

title: Bitcoin's Purported Founder Speaks Out
description: Newsweek reported that Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto was the founder of the digital currency Bitcoin. But Mr. Nakamoto denied the claim in an exclusive interview with The Associated Press.

title: Art Matters | A Biennial With Another Whitney in Mind
description: The idea began with a joke. I imagined that if I was tapped as the curator of the Whitney, I would show three floors of women artists, says the artist Christine Finley, known professionally as C. Finley. When I told this to my friend  the artist Eddy Segal  she immediately blurted out, The Whitney Houston Biennial!' Finley laughed  hard  but couldnt quite shake the idea. Deriving inspiration from Phong Buis Surviving Sandy show, Antony Hegartys handwritten future-feminist manifesto and, naturally, Whitney Houstons live performance of One Moment in Time from the 1989 Grammy Awards, Finley set about to design an exhibition that would showcase a wide swath of work from New Yorks female artists. She culled a dream list of more than 80 local women whose art she admired, paying special attention to include a cross-section of mediums.

title: Popcast: Vijay Iyer, Jazz Weather Vane
description: The pianist Vijay Iyer, 42, has established himself through the last decade as a weather vane in the practice and theory of jazz. Not the only one, and not one of use to everybody  especially musicians who prize more traditional or popular virtues, some of whom resent his success  but a weather vane all the same.

title: For G.O.P., Hard Line on Immigration Comes at a Cost
description: WASHINGTON  After signing the Civil Rights Act of 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson famously told an aide: We just delivered the South to the Republican Party for a long time. He was right. But he had also done something else: delivered African-American votes to Democrats in overwhelming proportions.

title: Building a Meal Around Roasted Vegetables
description: I was so cold in New York recently that I just wanted to cook in my sisters small apartment kitchen. Turning on the oven seemed like a very good idea, so I decided I would roast vegetables every day and make them the foundation of our meals, and consequently, for this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Red Square's government-sanctioned rally
description: A huge crowd gathered at a government-sanctioned rally in Moscow's Red Square in support of the Crimean people.

title: An Aging Population Also Poses Opportunities for Retirement Careers
description: A SCENT of sage hovers in the air. The soothing, ambient strands of New Age music fill the warm room. Carefully, the 80-year-old woman climbs aboard the heated massage table for her rub down, as she calls it.

title: In Safeway Buyout, a Reminder of a Painful Takeover Years Ago
description: Safeway, the latest target of a big private equity buyout, once caused a huge headache for the private equity industry.

title: Higher Prices Migrate to Far Upper East Side
description: Third Avenue has long been a dividing line on the Upper East Side. West of Third serves as shorthand for the stylish neighborhood in the TV show Gossip Girl, where private-school girls live in stately Park Avenue co-ops and shop in boutiques along Madison Avenue. East of Third refers to the delis and bagel shops that make up many of the storefronts around York Avenue, and the tenement style walk-ups filled with recent college graduates who flock to the cheap rent.

title: Big Ticket | Sophisticated Estate Orphan at $19 Million
description: A full-floor apartment at the exclusive 810 Fifth Avenue co-op that the billionaire Charles R. Bronfman bought for $21 million in 2010 sold for $19 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Stopping Ads From Slowing Down NYTimes.com
description: A major goal of the recent redesign of NYTimes.com article pages was to improve page load speed and perceived performance. We focused on one of the more challenging sources of slow performance: third-party code, and, in particular, ads. Ads often load JavaScript files, which block the browser from loading other files until the script finishes executing. Combine that with the fact that ads are often placed near the top of the page and we have a recipe for a lot of blocked loading that will slow things down. By addressing the ad problem, we were able to make our new articles about 50 percent faster (these changes arent on the home page yet, but they will be soon).

title: Vodafone Said to Submit Tentative Bid for Ono
description: LONDON  Vodafone is turning out to be a persistent suitor.

title: With New Antipoverty Initiative, Salesforce C.E.O. Puts Silicon Valley on Spot
description: For all the  tension and media coverage of San Franciscos rising rents and tech shuttle buses, there have not been a whole lot of people stepping forward with solutions.

title: Clinton Highlights Record on Womens Rights at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  Hillary Rodham Clinton continued her tour of speaking engagements and events related to womens rights on Friday, with a panel discussion at the United Nations in New York.

title: Online Map Tracks Frauds Against Older Americans
description: David Burdette, a retired executive in Concord, N.H., narrowly missed becoming a victim of financial fraud last summer after criminals were apparently able to crack the password to an online account that he used to manage his telephone service.

title: When You Evaluate a Fund Manager, Look Beyond Results
description: THIS Sunday will be five years to the day since the low point for the Standard & Poors 500 stock-index during the Great Recession. Since bottoming out on March 9, 2009, at 676.53, the index has risen some 170 percent.

title: Working Copy of Welless Citizen Kane Script Auctioned for $164,000
description: Orson Welless personal copy of the working draft script for Citizen Kane was sold at auction by Sothebys in London on Thursday.The mimeograph typescript, written by Welles withHerman J. Mankiewicz and JohnHouseman, was estimated to bring between 15,000 and 20,000 British pounds (about $25,000 to $33,000) but went forfor a final price, with the buyers premium, of 98,500 pounds (about $164,000).

title: Congolese Militia Leader Convicted in Attack on Village
description: PARIS  The International Criminal Court on Friday convicted a militia leader from the Democratic Republic of Congo in an attack on a Congolese village in 2003 in which more than 200 people were shot and hacked to death, and women were raped and abducted to serve as sex slaves.

title: New Yorkers: Earl Strickland
description: The legendary pool professionals career declined such that he now performs trick shots free at Steinway Billiards in Astoria, Queens.

title: Its Unclearly Defined, but Telecommuting Is Fast on the Rise
description: WE all know what telecommuting is and who does it. Its working from home (or maybe a Starbucks), and its usually done by someone in their 20s, or a mother with small children.

title: In California, Worries Over Water
description: As a deep drought continues, Lake of the Woods, Calif., and other rural communities in the state are facing a threat to their drinking water.

title: Women Made Jobs Gains in February
description: After losing jobs in January, women took the majority of the new jobs in February, gaining 99,000 jobs to mens 76,000. Women have more than made up their losses in the recession, gaining 2.5 million jobs in the recovery, compared to 2.1 million jobs lost, while men have been struggling more, gaining 4.2 million jobs after losing 5.3 million in the downturn.

title: Fact-Finding Envoys in Crimea Face Hostility
description: UNITED NATIONS  As the United Nations sent an eight-member human rights fact-finding mission to Ukraine on Friday, an envoy with the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said she had faced noisy, threatening crowds chanting pro-Russian slogans in the Crimea regional capital of Simferopol earlier this week and had been forced to cut short her visit.

title: The Shapes of Things to Come
description: Not long ago, Zaha Hadid took to her drafting table to create a pair of shoes. Chrome and rubber platforms that were conceived with her fellow starchitect Rem Koolhaas, they looked like nothing so much as a Slinky, its serpentine coils neatly fused.

title: French Court Convicts 3 Who Tried to Join Militants in Syria
description: PARIS  A Paris court on Friday sentenced three men to prison terms of up to five years for trying to join the rebellion in Syria, the first such convictions in France.

title: Big Fish, Small Pool
description: On Monday afternoon, a lithe man with a blond mustache and a Southern twang leaned over a pool table under a pair of hanging lamps at Steinway Billiards Cafe in Astoria, Queens.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Sweating It Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a 25-year-old man who had recently given up heroin, cocaine and marijuana had a sudden attack of nausea and vomiting so severe that he had to go to the hospital. Two big clues were provided. His nausea and vomiting eased when he took a hot shower, and he regularly used an herbal product that he bought in a neighborhood store called Spice, said to be synthetic marijuana.

title: When May Catches Up to December
description: When Tony Perkins moved to New York from Leakesville, Miss., in April 1986, he wasnt looking for love. Like most, he came in pursuit of a dream: a career in fashion and a life that his one-stoplight hometown could not offer.

title: Just Another Great Role for Whats-Her-Name
description: LONDON  Lindsay Duncan was freezing. She had just spent an hour on Primrose Hill, having her portrait taken.

title: Donna Tartt and Eleanor Catton Among Nominees for Womens Fiction Prize
description: Donna Tartt, the author of the widely acclaimed novel The Goldfinch, and Eleanor Catton, whose novel The Luminaries has already won the 2013 Man Booker Prize, are among the 20 women nominated for the Baileys Womens Prize for Fiction. The award, which honors works written in English by women, was known as the Orange Prize until last year, when the liquor company Baileys took over as sponsor.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 97
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: A Love Not Strong Enough to Climb Barriers
description: In 1982, John Reid, now 55, met Patty Reid, 52, in a San Francisco bar. Less than an hour later, Mr. Reid announced his intention to marry her. Twenty years later, a financial misstep led to the breakup of the couple.

title: Automakers Talk Optimistically About Electric Cars in Geneva
description: Automakers do not talk about electric cars with quite the same bravado they did a few years ago. But judging from the talk at the Geneva Motor Show this year, at least some remain bullish on the future of plug-in vehicles.

title: On Money and Marriage
description: In this weeks Unhitched column, John and Patty Reid discussed issues that led to their divorce after 26 years of marriage, including a failed attempt to go into business with her sisters family. We asked a therapist about dealing with money issues in marriage. Did you face a similar issue in your divorce? Or were you faced with other challenges? If so, wed like to hear from you for this series.

title: Geriatricians Question Five Common Treatments
description: It tells you something about American health care that scores of medical societies have joined a major campaign aimed at telling patients and doctors what not to do.

title: Safeway Customers May Be Big Winners With Cerberus
description: Could Cerberus pay more for Safeway than the $9.4 billion it has offered? Based on the A.&P.-Pathmark merger in 2007, the synergies could be worth well over $5 billion to Cerberus, since it plans to combine the chain with its Albertsons operations. In theory that leaves room for a higher offer. But competition from the likes of Walmart means cost savings may need to go to shoppers, not investors.

title: Theres Been a Change in River City
description: Robert OHara, an Obie Award-winning playwright and director, has seen only the movie version of the Broadway classic The Music Man, not the theatrical production. He knows, though, that the concert version he will direct this month, Meredith Willsons The Music Man, at Two River Theater, in Red Bank, and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, in Newark, will look different from the one most theatergoers are accustomed to. And he does not plan to offer any explanations.

title: After Debit Card Fraud, a Chicago Bank Feels Its Customers Frustration
description: People should no longer use debit or credit cards in Chicago taxicabs. Bank of America should shut off the card-swiping terminals in the back of those cabs. And MasterCard ought to learn to share more information with its customers.

title: Is There a Doctor in the House? Yes, 17. And 3 in the Senate.
description: LAKE OSWEGO, Ore.  First thing on a recent Monday, Monica Wehby could be found in the operating room performing brain surgery on a child. But the Saturday before, she was shooting guns, because sometimes thats what you do when youre running for office.

title: What an Israeli-Palestinian Peace Framework Might Look Like
description: The Obama administration will soon publish a set of principles that is intended to serve as the basis for negotiations on an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement.

title: With Its Stock Riding High, FireEye Sells More Shares for $1.1 Billion
description: With the Target hacking scandal, Edward Snowden and Chinese cyberattacks all in the news, there could hardly be a better environment for FireEye, the security software company that went public last fall.

title: Film Society of Lincoln Center Names New Director
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center on Friday announced the appointment of Lesli Klainberg as its new executive director.

title: Evening Hours | Revelers With a Cause
description: Galas for dance companies, museums and babies.

title: Guy Hands Drops Lawsuit Against Citigroup in U.S.
description: The British financier Guy Hands has agreed to end a lawsuit against Citigroup in the United States, though the legal battle may continue in England.

title: Few Are Expected to Mourn the Loss of a Gilded Age Building
description: The brownstone may be the oldest building on Fifth Avenue  a 143-year-old townhouse that witnessed the dawn of the Gilded Age, the completion of Central Park and an unsolved murder. But even the Landmarks Preservation Commission did not raise much objection when a developer proposed demolishing most of it for a highrise.

title: Painting a Picture of Creative Growth
description: Time changes nothing; time changes everything. You can align with either axiom, but for Creative Growth Art Center, celebrating its 40th anniversary this month, theres a case to be made for both. What began in 1974 as the first arts facility dedicated to adults with developmental, mental and physical disabilities has since become a testament to the power of imagination, with a singular vision: when it comes to art, there is no right or wrong.

title: Former Trader at Jefferies Found Guilty of Fraud
description: A federal jury on Friday found Jesse C. Litvak, a former senior trader at the Jefferies Group, guilty of deceiving his customers about the prices of mortgage-backed securities he sold to them after the financial crisis.

title: Ukraine and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day
description: Photographs from Ukraine, Syria, South Africa and Siberia.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, India and Russia.

title: M.L.S. to Open Season With Replacement Referees Amid Lockout
description: Major League Soccer will open its 19th season Saturday, but with replacement referees, after the organization that supplies the league with on-field officials announced Friday that it was locking them out because of a labor dispute.

title: The Hot Accessory: A Real, Live Pop Star
description: Here, there and everywhere throughout Paris Fashion Week, like Zelig in face-masking shades, was the pop starlet Rihanna. On Thursday, she was front row at Lanvin. On Friday, Dior. Saturday afternoon, Comme des Garons. At Chanel, she hopped gamely into a shopping cart for a spin around Karl Lagerfelds Costco-size supermarket set.

title: The Gun Report: March 7, 2014
description: Harold Mitchell, the chairman of South Carolinas Legislative Black Caucus, has introduced a bill to repeal the states Stand Your Ground law, The State reports. The bill, which has 17 co-sponsors, would eliminate the controversial legal defense employed by those who kill or wound people in public places, then claim they feared for their lives. But it would not do away with the right to defend yourself inside your home, vehicle or business.

title: The Technology of Voting
description: BARCELONA, Spain  When New York overseas voters cast ballots in elections, few likely know theyre relying on a small tech company based in Barcelona, Spain.

title: The Doctor With a Razor Blade in India
description: The ancient practice of bloodletting as a medical treatment continues in India. Despite their access to modern medical care, some patients believe it is the best cure.

title: French Beauty
description: Said to have been displayed at the 1939 Worlds Fair in Queens, this 1937 Delahaye roadster was the object of one collectors boyhood dreams.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Celebrities Behaving Well
description: Justin Biebers rap sheet over the past year would have been an afternoons work for Keith Richards.

title: The Playground Set Gets Its Own Bras
description: Not long ago, Stephanie Sorkin, an author of childrens books who lives in Roslyn, N.Y., was faced with an unexpected request from her daughter Lea, then age 5.

title: In West Chelsea, a Temporary Emporium
description: The sales offices that woo buyers while condominium projects are still clanging construction sites are generally tucked inside other structures, whether office towers, art galleries or storefronts.

title: No, His Name Is Not Ted
description: Chris Anderson was sitting in a very low-power pose. Off to the side at an all-staff meeting at TEDs Hudson Street headquarters in January, he was folded forward with his hand on his neck, a posture that communicates self-protection according to the 2012 TED Talk on body language by the social psychologist Amy Cuddy (15.7 million views).

title: The Herald Above the Reeds
description: The call of the red-winged blackbird announces spring while the snow still falls. As black as pitch, with flame orange shoulders, the male perches on tall grasses and leafless branches high above New Yorks bleak winter marshes. He is an unlikely herald, but he is one of the most reliable signs of spring. His call  a powerful conk-a-ree-e  trails off and settles over the reeds, embodying the ancient promise that spring will return.

title: The McDonalds Beef With Moschino, Chanels Rising Prices and Mary-Kate Olsens Big New Bling
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Review: 2014 BMW 335i GT
description: The latest version of BMWs highly successful 3 Series is the GT. It stands for Gran Turismo, but it could mean giant trunk, since this 335i is a hatchback.

title: Weather and the Jobs Report
description: Rah, rah, rah. That was the dominant feeling among Wall Street analysts after the jobs report exceeded expectations despite the dismal winter weve been having. Employers added 175,000 jobs even though the week covered by the jobs survey, Feb. 9 through 15, was perfectly nasty.

title: City Ballet Dancers Agree to New Contract
description: The dancers and stage managers of New York City Ballet, who have been working under an expired concert since the summer of 2012, have ratified a new labor agreement, according to their union, the American Guild of Musical Artists.

title: Wozzeck
description: Listen to the orchestral interlude from Act III of Wozzeck.

title: Turkeys Leaders Spar Over Plan to Muzzle Social Media
description: ISTANBUL  Just hours after the prime minister of Turkey threatened to shut down Facebook and YouTube, the countrys president voiced reassurance on Friday that reversing course on civil liberties was out of the question.

title: Some Amelia Auction Cars May Bring 7-Figure Prices
description: Not far from the gleaming trailer queens treated to the white glove touch at the Amelia Island Concours d'lgance in North Florida, an eclectic assembly of autos and motorcycles will cross the block on Saturday at the RM Auctions sale.

title: Whistle-Blower Gets $63.9 Million as a Result of JPMorgan Settlement
description: A Louisiana man who helped federal prosecutors make their case against JPMorgan Chases mortgage lending practices has earned $63.9 million for his efforts.

title: Icahn Discloses Hes Now on Facebook
description: Carl C. Icahn is liking Facebook a bit more these days.

title: A London Hotel Has a Focus on Sustainability
description: According to Londons Draycott Hotel, encouraging guests to just reuse towels doesnt cut it anymore when it comes to being eco-friendly. Its new Keen to be Green initiative is part of an effort to become the most sustainable boutique hotel in the city, including finding creative ways for travelers to reduce their carbon footprint.

title: Video: BMWs Balloon-Backed 3 Series GT
description: The latest version of BMWs highly successful 3 Series is the 335i GT. Although GT stands for Gran Turismo, it could mean giant trunk in this case, since  hide the children, folks  this 335i is a hatchback.

title: Perceptions of Beauty, and Their Cost
description: A dress stretched so tightly on a rack that it could not fit even the skinniest of women is the first piece a visitor is likely to spot upon entering the Amelie A. Wallace Gallery at State University of New York College at Old Westbury. Called Thinner Than You, it is one of the works in an art exhibition, Body Conscious, that explores womens concerns about their size and weight, including dieting, obesity and eating disorders.

title: Rand Pauls Style
description: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md.The idea that Rand Paul is the 2016 Republican front-runner, advanced recently by Peter Beinart in The Atlantic, seems dubious. (There is no front-runner.) But the libertarian was the favorite at the Conservative Political Action Conference, where he spoke to a packed audience. Young people in suits who could not find seats milled around the back of the room.

title: Friday Night Music: Lake Street Dive
description: OK, Im way behind the curve here  theyve already been on Colbert and Letterman, and their upcoming concerts in New York are sold out (alas). But thats no reason not to share 3 minutes and 51 seconds of happiness:

title: The Nearby Wozzeck Changes His Address
description: Last-minute cast changes happen routinely in opera, but seldom with the mix of anxiety and, in the end, triumph that took place on Thursday when the Metropolitan Opera revived its 1997 production of Bergs Wozzeck.

title: Art Matters | At the Independent Art Fair, Thinking Outside the White Box
description: When Elizabeth Dee and Darren Flook founded the Independent Art Fair in 2010, the art landscape in New York was a different place. Frieze had yet to enter the American market, and the vast Armory Show dominated the fair scene. There was really a need for something more than the model that was imposed on us, says the fairs director, Laura Mitterrand.

title: Drones, Notes of Discord and a Sip of Cognac
description: The organ was already playing when Charlemagne Palestine sat down to the keyboards of the Aeolian-Skinner instrument at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn Heights on Thursday night. Flat wooden pegs had been wedged under a few keys, creating a hovering tone cluster, a drone that seemed (as an acoustic phenomenon) to ripple gently as its overtones reverberated around the church. For the next hour or so, Mr. Palestine, in a concert presented by the Issue Project Room, filled the room with one continuous piece, changing gradually but thoroughly, luxuriating in the organs infinite sustain and tonal depth.

title: Russia Backs Rally in Support of Crimea
description: A huge crowd gathered at a government-sanctioned rally in Moscow's Red Square in support of the Crimean people.

title: Western Businesses in Russia, Watchful and Wary
description: PARIS  Shortly after pro-Russian troops infiltrated Crimea last weekend, the phone in Alexis Rodziankos Moscow office started ringing. He is president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia, and local managers for some of the worlds biggest brands were calling to discuss the safety of their operations and the risks that might arise if the West were to impose sanctions.

title: Time to Stop and Drink the Wine
description: As president of the Rockefeller Foundation, which focuses on issues like environmental protection and urban planning, Judith Rodin often has to travel for business on Sunday evenings. But when in town for the day, Dr. Rodin, 69, enjoys setting out into the city from the Midtown Manhattan apartment she shares with her husband of 20 years, Paul R. Verkuil, chairman of the Administrative Conference of the United States, an independent government agency. Mr. Verkuil, 74, takes the train to Washington on Mondays and returns Thursday night or Friday; Sunday is important together time.

title: Cartoon Network Aims at Devices With Its Micro-Network Launch
description: Cartoon Network will release an app later this year that will deliver original 15-second content bites  videos, games, polls, and trivia  solely to mobile devices, the company said Friday.

title: Hitchhiking in a Starry Reboot of a Journey Through the Universe
description: Its like trying to remake Citizen Kane.

title: Lets Get Lost
description: By chasing a gonzo new adventure every summer, the viral filmmaker Casey Neistat and his son, Owen, embrace the unfamiliar and forge a closer bond.

title: A Rare Opera Whose Dance Is in Step With Its Drama
description: Alexander Borodins opera Prince Igor is pervaded by contrasts and dualisms. While it features, in its long Polovtsian scene, some of the most famous dance music ever written, much of its overall stage action is remarkably inactive. My most visceral response to it is prompted by nothing visual: Many of its melodies affect me so powerfully that its hard for me to sit still, even when nobody is moving onstage.

title: Realism Splashing a Screen Near You
description: The HBO series Girls may have its cutting-edge moments, but what comes out of the mouth of its star early in Sundays episode is increasingly a television clich. Its vomit, straight from Lena Dunhams lips into your living room, the latest example of a TV trend that deserves to die.

title: When Studies Are Wrong: A Coda
description: My first Raw Data column, published in January, was about the controversy over irreproducibility  experiments whose outcomes cannot be verified independently by another lab. Featured in the piece was a study by Dr. John P.A. Ioannidis that has been a source of contention since it appeared in 2005. It was called Why Most Published Research Findings Are False.

title: Rhythmic Flourishes, Poise, Posture and the Forceful Whirl of Skirts
description: New Yorks Flamenco Festival is back with us. The crowd that thronged City Center on Thursday for the first of two Gala Flamenca evenings abounded in Spanish speakers and flamenco aficionados. The performers onstage, most of them strongly individual, all won eager applause.

title: Ordinary People, Extraordinary Detail
description: We know youre busy, but try to slow down for a moment. The city captured on this page by Jerome Liebling, who died in 2011, doesnt reveal itself right away. Mr. Liebling, who became known as a member of the Photo League, a group of socially minded photographers that disbanded in 1951, dug deeply into his subjects, using still photography almost like film, to explore a condition rather than an instant. He and his subjects are looking at each other, said Rachel Liebling, who curated an exhibition of her fathers work, which is to run at the Steven Kasher Gallery from March 13 to April 19. Theyre looking at him and hes looking at them. He felt the regular people were the superstars. Those portraits are about that.

title: Study Finds a Gender Gap at the Top Museums
description: Women run just a quarter of the biggest art museums in the United States and Canada, and they earn about a third less than their male counterparts, according to a report released on Friday by the Association of Art Museum Directors, a professional organization.

title: Disappearing Act at the Gold Coast Congress
description: The winners of the main team event at the Gold Coast Congress in Queensland, Australia, last month were Fiona Brown, Tony Nunn and Matthew Thomson from Australia; Hugh McGann from Ireland; and Geo Tislevoll and Michael Ware from New Zealand.

title: Stilts Arent the Only Way to Rise Above It All
description: Shows by the performance and installation artist Aki Sasamoto have a signature smell. Its the chemical fragrance of the felt-tip markers she uses to write out key words as she, annoyed and amused, shares her observations and theories about people. Her shows also have a signature image: Ms. Sasamoto inside or under or atop one of the many sculptural objects that litter the stage, talking away as if there were nothing unusual about her predicament.

title: In Debt to Art? So Actors Piggy Bank Attests
description: A Living Documentary, Cynthia Hopkinss new one-woman show at New York Live Arts, is small-scale and stripped down, with a barely-there set and minimal technical accouterments. Its a departure from some of her recent, more involved productions; Ms. Hopkins s name is the only one in the program.

title: New Jersey Images, Unbound by Galleries
description: In December 1967, Robert Smithson published a photographic essay in Artforum magazine that would become a landmark of 1960s art. Not only did the essay, The Monuments of Passaic, signal a shift by artists to making and showing art outside galleries  including the exhibition space of a mass-produced, illustrated magazine  but it also put the artist in the unusual role of writer, a position usually reserved for critics and historians. Smithsons essay was a clever combination of genres: travelogue, science fiction and philosophical tract. But it was also a poignant meditation on time and entropy (one of his favorite terms) in postindustrial suburbia.

title: Life and Happiness in Siberias Cold
description: Departing from the images of frozen exile and gulags, a group of Russian photographers has complied a nuanced portrait of a legendary, if misunderstood, region.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 7
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: Ned OGorman, 84, Dies; Poet Founded Innovative Harlem School
description: Ned OGorman, an award-winning poet who gained his widest attention for starting a storefront school in Harlem  a liberation camp, he called it  to bring literature, Latin and love to disadvantaged children, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: A New Verdict on Tammany Hall
description: Drawing on earlier books by Leo Hershkowitz and Kenneth D. Ackerman, Terry Golways Machine Made: Tammany Hall and the Creation of Modern American Politics (Liveright) delivers a refreshingly revisionist verdict on the Irish-dominated Democratic organization whose ring reverberated mightily in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and then faded into a faint echo.

title: A Discussion About Bright Lights, Big City
description: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and he did not demand that we read his own newly published memoir, Little Failure, about his upbringing as a Russian migr in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected Bright Lights, Big City, Jay McInerneys touchstone novel of the hedonistic 80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m. on The Timess City Room blog.

title: A Name and a Spirit From the Dead
description: Tom Bailey, general manager of the Capitol Theater in Port Chester, sat nursing a beer at Garcias, the theaters lobby bar, on a recent Tuesday evening. But like the 50 or so patrons who filtered in from the cold outside to join him, he wasnt there just for the beer.

title: $66,400 Answer, but Whats the Question?
description: Kias start in America was clandestine. It built the forgettable Festiva two-door hatchback for Ford, using plans cribbed from Mazda. With its front wheels powered by a 58-horsepower 4-cylinder engine, that 1988 Festiva wasnt much more than a stripped-down, 1,800-pound, 12-foot-long penalty box on four 12-inch wheels. According to Car and Driver magazine, it shuddered from 0 to 60 miles per hour in a lugubrious 12.5 seconds. But at least its base price was only $5,765.

title: Art Matters | The Whitney Biennials Last Upper East Side Hurrah
description: After almost a week of previews and vernissages, today 945 Madison Avenue opened its doors for the public to descend upon the last Whitney Biennial to take place on the Upper East Side. Two years from now, the Whitney Museum of American Art will have settled into its new building beside the High Line, and the days of several hundred people in festive attire snaking all the way down to Park Avenue as they wait to ooh, aah and roll their eyes at the latest and greatest in ostensibly American art will be a thing of the past. In the future when the museum is at capacity, all the excess people will be pushed into the Hudson River.

title: Head of Retail Investing Departs K.K.R.
description: Michael M. Calbert, a 14-year veteran of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts who led the team that invests in the retail industry, has left the private equity giant, a spokeswoman said on Friday.

title: A Mixed Breed Gets a Pedigree
description: For years, buyers of large work trucks have pieced together their vehicles from a variety of suppliers, ordering engines, transmissions and even minor components on an  la carte basis from lengthy menus. That practice is about to fade from Ford Motors commercial-vehicle dealerships, a result of the automakers push to streamline manufacturing and offer more efficient packages.

title: A Worlds Fair Visit, Not Over Yet
description: Malcolm Pray told the story over and over again.

title: Nissan Mirror Is Also a Monitor for Rear Camera
description: Nissan has developed a rearview mirror that lets the driver see around the sloping rooflines and chunky roof pillars that are in vogue in todays car designs.

title: I Didnt Recognize You From Behind
description: There was a time when cars could be identified at night, even from a distance, by the shape of their taillights. Buicks often wore horizontal red bands stretching from fender to fender, Chevrolet designers favored circles in pairs or threes and Cadillac has kept finlike vertical blades to the present day, decades after it retired the tailfins it started wearing after World War II.

title: Under Cover: Visualizing Changes to the SAT
description: What better way to signal the sea change coming to the SAT  the subject of this weekends cover story  than with the telltale signs of an erased word: faded, but still visible, with eraser shavings scattered about?

title: Wing Cracks Delay Boeing 787 Assembly
description: Boeing said on Friday that it had discovered tiny cracks in the wings of about 40 Dreamliners currently in production. It was the latest setback for the advanced airliner, though the plane maker said it was confident the problem did not involve any of the 787s in service.

title: Looking Back on a Double Life
description: In 1965, when Nol Coward wrote A Song at Twilight for the London stage, the words out and closeted did not mean what they do today. How could they? Homosexual sex was still a criminal offense under English law, and being openly gay could  and did  land people in jail. But the ethical and emotional ramifications of a life lived in secret, especially for a writers life, are at the heart of this very late work by a playwright whose homosexuality was well-known but never acknowledged.

title: The Holdouts on Same-Sex Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Movin On Up
description: How far can a brand extend itself? With the K900, a new luxury sedan, Kia explores the limits.

title: Drew Barrymore and Robert Osborne on Classic Movies
description: As far as on-screen duos go, Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore seem like an unlikely pair. He was raised in the small town of Colfax, Wash. (population 2,800) during the 40s and amused himself with reading books while his parents worked. She grew up amidst the glitz and glamour of Hollywood in the 80s, the youngest in a long family line of legendary actors, and made her first television appearance before she was even a year old. But they share an almost obsessive love for movies, particularly black-and-white films made decades ago. Its this connection that makes Osborne and Barrymore light up together as the host and co-host, respectively, of TCMs The Essentials. The show, which premiered in 2001 and airs on Saturday nights, puts timeless, classic films in the spotlight with commentary and fun bits of trivia supplied by the hosts (in the past those duties have been taken up by everyone from Rob Reiner to Alec Baldwin). This season marks Barrymores third as Osbornes wingwoman, and the two clearly enjoy the back-and-forth banter  as well as the goofy handshakes, thumb wars and screwball comedy moments that often happen after the cameras stop rolling. T caught up with the actors on set to talk about the films that forever changed them, the characters theyve admired and crushed on, and whats missing from the box office today.

title: Among the Wounded in Syrias War: Ancient History
description: PARIS  For the French archaeologists Pierre Leriche, 73, and Jean-Claude Margueron, nearly 80, who both spent decades uncovering Syrias rich past, it is almost too painful to look at its grim present.

title: New Rules to Reshape Telecom in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  In a ruling intended to break virtual monopolies in Mexican telecommunications and television broadcasting, a recently created regulator issued tough new conditions for two of the countrys largest companies, the wireless carrier Amrica Mvil and the media company Televisa.

title: Into the Provinces of Angels and Ladies Powdering Noses
description: One way to create a ballet is to take a familiar subject and replicate it as directly as possible onstage. This seems to be the preferred approach of Tom Gold, a former New York City Ballet soloist who founded his own company, Tom Gold Dance, in 2007. On Thursday at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, in a triple bill featuring two premieres, those subjects included angels (Urban Angels), a beach party (La Plage) and women convening in the powder room (The Ladies Room) to divulge their deepest secrets.

title: Making City Streets Safer: A Design Solution
Maidan Faces Its Future
description: Weeks after protesters drove President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine from power, Maidan protesters in Kievs Independence Square mourn the dead and ponder where their revolution has left them.

title: M.L.S. Talking Points: New Stars for Toronto, New Expectations for Red Bulls
description: Chivas USA and Toronto F.C. are separated by thousands of miles but are united in mediocrity.

title: The Heroin Epidemic, in Vermont and Beyond
description: To the Editor:

title: Access to Justice for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Making a Case for the Trans-Pacific Partnership
description: To the Editor:

title: Meat Makes the Planet Thirsty
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  CALIFORNIA is experiencing one of its worst droughts on record. Just two and a half years ago, Folsom Lake, a major reservoir outside Sacramento, was at 83 percent capacity. Today its down to 36 percent. In January, there was no measurable rain in downtown Los Angeles. Gov. Jerry Brown has declared a state of emergency. President Obama has pledged $183 million in emergency funding. The situation, despite last weeks deluge in Southern California, is dire.

title: Ukrainian Officials in East Act to Blunt Pro-Russian Forces
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Officials loyal to the new central government in Kiev, Ukraines capital, have mobilized here in the countrys east to end a pro-Russian protest movement that has called for greater regional autonomy from Kiev and has raised the specter of separatism in the largely Russian-speaking regions of Ukraine.

title: Civil Rights Sermon Is Mislaid but Not Forgotten
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Bishop Clay F. Lee knelt down in his study on Thursday and peeled the lid off a plastic bin labeled Sermons A-Z. Then he beheld the contents, nearly a half-century of his homily manuscripts. His wife, Dot, had spent weeks assembling them in alphabetical order, partly in anticipation of their guest on this particular afternoon.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Reshaping the Military
description: Readers discuss what kind of armed forces we need to face the threats of the 21st century.

title: Snowden Says He Reported N.S.A. Surveillance Concerns Before Leaks
description: WASHINGTON  Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked a trove of documents revealing the agencys surveillance operations, said he raised his concerns to more than 10 officials, none of whom took any action to address them, before he decided to give the documents to journalists.

title: Course and Conditions Do a Number on Scorecards
description: DORAL, Fla.  Donald Trump described the reconstructed Blue Monster course at the Doral resort that bears his name as a layout worthy of being named among the top 10 in the world, as it was by a European magazine, he said. The four-time major winner Ernie Els described it as a masterpiece, Trump said, adding, I think our players are blown away.

title: Breaking Out of the Library Mold, in Boston and Beyond
description: BOSTON  An old joke about libraries goes like this: A boy walks into a library and asks for a burger and fries. Young man! the startled librarian reprimands. You are in a library. So the boy repeats his order, only this time, he whispers.

title: After Shots, Pistorius Kept Quiet, Guard Says
description: A security guard testified on Friday that Oscar Pistorius, the South African double-amputee track star, insisted that everything is fine just minutes after the shots that killed the girlfriend he is accused of murdering in the early hours of Feb. 14, 2013.

title: Newsweek Returns to Print and Sets Off a Bitcoin Storm
description: After being out of print for 14 months, Newsweek wanted its return to the newsstands to land with a splash. So it put out an issue with a darkened cover featuring a theatrical silver mask, and made an explosive claim: It had uncovered the mysterious founder of the digital currency Bitcoin.

title: The Self(ie) Generation
description: A fascinating new survey by the Pew Research Center finds that millennials (defined by Pew as Americans ages 18 to 33) are drifting away from traditional institutions  political, religious and cultural.

title: Malaysia Airlines Loses Contact With Jet Carrying Over 200
description: HONG KONG  Malaysia Airlines announced Saturday morning that it had lost contact five hours earlier with one of its flights, which was carrying at least 239 people to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur, and had activated a search-and-rescue team.

title: Martin Gottfried, 80, Theater Critic and Scholar
description: Martin Gottfried, a drama critic and the author of several biographies of entertainers and playwrights as well as two influential studies of the Broadway musical, died on March 6 in Manhattan. He was 80, and had homes in Manhattan and Amagansett, N.Y.

title: Art Week in New York
description: This is the weekend when art lovers crowd New York to attend the panoply of art fairs throughout Manhattan. There are the Art Dealers Association of America Art Show, at the Park Avenue Armory (at 67th Street), and the sprawling Armory Show, at Piers 92 and 94 (12th Avenue and 55th Street in Clinton) and the Independent Art Fair (548 West 22nd Street in Chelsea). They draw hundreds of participating galleries, and this year there is an added attraction for contemporary-art fans: The Whitney Biennial has opened, the last Biennial at the museums Marcel Breuer home. Follow the reviews by the New York Times critics Holland Cotter, Ken Johnson, Karen Rosenberg and Martha Schwendener:

title: A Revolutionary Surgery, Now as Typical as a Sinker
description: Pitchers who had Tommy John surgery might have felt like raising a toast to Dr. Frank Jobe on Thursday night. But that very motion might not have been possible, at least without triggering elbow pain, if not for Jobes pioneering technique.

title: Recall at G.M. Is Early Trial for New Chief
description: DETROIT  Only weeks into her tenure as chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra has been increasingly consumed by a crisis over the recall of 1.6 million defective cars linked to 13 deaths.

title: Cloudy and Cold
description: People, have you noticed that the news has been really depressing lately? These are the times when you come to understand why theres so much interest in watching kitten videos. Do you think its the weather?

title: Carmen Berra, Yogis Wife, Dies at 85
description: Carmen Berra, Yogis companion for nearly 70 years, was one of the famous Yankees baseball wives who could be identified by their first names, like Eleanor (Gehrig), Merlyn (Mantle) and Cora (Rizzuto).

title: Border Patrol Instructed to Show Restraint
description: WASHINGTON  The Border Patrol on Friday instructed its agents to show restraint when people on the border throw rocks or flee in cars, after a series of fatal shootings by agents provoked outrage from human rights activists and the Mexican government.

title: Car Designs at the Geneva Auto Show
description: Driverless cars and futuristic 3-D printing-inspired designs were just some of the vehicles on display in Switzerland.

title: Oh, Man
description: If this magazine is any indication, the idea of masculinity is a bit of a ruse, or at least a fluid social construct that shifts around quite a bit over time and depending on whos talking. The issue begins with an essay by Troy Patterson examining the meaning behind a mans bag  be it a backpack, briefcase or messenger  and ends with a photo series of hairy chests. A briefcase certainly doesnt convey the security and power it once did, and whether you find chest fuzz sexy or gross, this totem of Burt Reynolds-era manliness is certainly not what it was before manscaping entered our lexicon.

title: Offering More Than Luxury, Supercars Draw a Crowd of Makers and Buyers
description: GENEVA  European automakers are having a tough time moving their $15,000 models off the lot these days. But selling a $200,000 car seems to be getting easier and easier.

title: Saudis Put Terrorist Label on Muslim Brotherhood
description: CAIRO  Saudi Arabia on Friday declared the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist organization, escalating a new campaign against the group across the region with a sweeping ban that imposes lengthy prison sentences for even expressing sympathy with it.

title: Shortchanging New Yorks Environment
description: A mere $250 million a year to protect air and water quality, manage solid waste, conserve open space and save family farms is a trifle in New York States enormous annual budget. Yet that modest sum was the prerecession high point for the Environmental Protection Fund, the states main source of revenue for these and other important purposes.

title: The Sulfur Rule, Tardy but Welcome
description: To its commendable list of clean air initiatives, the Obama administration can now add one more: a new rule requiring refiners to reduce the sulfur content in gasoline by two-thirds. The rule will impose manageable costs on industry while bringing big benefits to the public by enhancing the effectiveness of catalytic converters, which trap pollution, in both old and new cars. This will further reduce harmful tailpipe emissions, associated with a range of heart and respiratory diseases.

title: Gun Safety on Facebook
description: Facebook, the social media powerhouse, is attempting some new controls to deal with growing complaints that it is being used to facilitate dangerous and illegal gun sales, particularly to minors. With more than a billion users engaged in endless communications, Facebook wont have an easy task.

title: Jobs at a Turning Point
description: Measured against low expectations, the employment report for February was a relief. The news that the economy added 175,000 jobs last month was better than anticipated, and much better than the dismal reports in December and January. That has raised hopes for a spring bounce, a safe bet given the probable hit to employment in the past few months from bad winter weather.

title: In Gay Marriage Suit, a Battle Over Research
description: DETROIT  It was, like a dozen others in recent months, a court battle over gay marriage. But this one was punctuated by charges of scholarly groupthink, the public repudiation by a university department of its own tenured professor, a reference to witch-burning and an economists assertion that in his view, those engaging in homosexual acts are destined for hell.

title: Spring Mens Fashion Issue
description: Ts spring mens fashion issue looks at the changing face of masculinity in 2014. On the cover is the chameleonic actor Benedict Cumberbatch, whose unconventional looks, unassuming personality and ability to embody any role (he got his start playing womens parts in Shakespeare) have made him an unlikely megastar. We visit estates in Austria and Ireland, where, respectively, the mischievous sculptor Erwin Wurm and the reclusive novelist J.P. Donleavy are living out their idiosyncratic visions. We also dive into the supersize life of the boxing champ Floyd Mayweather Jr., whose taste for excess and bold proclamations are a throwback to the days of Muhammad Ali. And we round things out with a group of men unafraid to share their passions and opinions: Gary Shteyngart and CeeLo Green, who consider Justin Bieber socks and bathe with beer soap; the writer Troy Patterson, who waxes poetic about the many meanings of man bags; and the designer Dries Van Noten, whose original collage lays bare the inspirations that have shaped his 30-year career. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Havana Highball
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Im going to open todays discussion with a couple of questions: Why is it so hard to get restaurants in countries that are not the United States to put an ice cube in a drinking glass? Also, how is it that these same countries, with their high standards of education, do not understand the singular concept of Diet Coke?

title: Disgraced Musician Faces an Angry Japan
description: TOKYO  A man once hailed as Japans deaf musical genius and likened to Beethoven faced the wrath of his nation on Friday, appearing in public for the first time since he was exposed as a fake.

title: For St. Anthony, Lack of Home Court Is Least of Its Problems
description: JERSEY CITY  The only indicator that the Hall of Fame coach Bob Hurley Sr. had just won his 1,100th game was the bigger-than-average milk chocolate bar sitting on the scorers table that displayed the win total in white chocolate.

title: Mets Confront Replay System; Its Not as Easy as It Looks
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets were playing the Cardinals at Tradition Field on Friday when, with two outs in the bottom of the third, Eric Young took off for second base. He slid and appeared to be safe, but he was called out. The Cardinals started jogging off the field.

title: Russias Move Into Ukraine Said to Be Born in Shadows
description: MOSCOW  The day after he returned from the Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia gathered the 12 members of his national security council for a crisis meeting to manage a political implosion in Ukraine that, by all accounts, had surprised Russias political and military elite and, above all, infuriated Mr. Putin himself.

title: Costs Have Piled Up Along With the Snow of a Difficult Winter
description: This has been not only a long, cold winter, but also an expensive one. Replacing lost mittens, buying a snow shovel, having a car towed or paying higher heating bills may not seem like a significant expense, but the costs  some of them unexpected  have kept piling up, as relentless as the snowstorms.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 7, 2014
description: March 7, 2014

title: The President Does Not Drop Out of Sight, but Does Get Out of Town
description: KEY LARGO, Fla.  President Obama and his family disappeared behind the gates of a lush oceanfront resort here on Friday afternoon to begin a weekend getaway that was in doubt until the evening before because of the tumultuous events in Crimea and Ukraine.

title: Ukraine, Bibi and, of Course, the Oscars
description: The public debate in past days was rich in Cold War talk of confrontation, credibility, punishment, sanctions, winners and losers. Senator John McCains blast that the crisis in Ukraine was another result of a feckless American foreign policy  made at the annual convention of Aipac, the conservative pro-Israel lobby, where the dominant talk was of tough sanctions against Iran  was widely cited.

title: Seeking to Bridge the Arab-Jewish Divide With Music
description: JERUSALEM  TRILINGUAL since he was a teenager, the Israeli singer-songwriter David Broza has for nearly four decades performed in Hebrew, Spanish and English. But his latest project, in the forlorn Shuafat Refugee Camp here, employs a more universal language: boys banging on things.

title: Richard Boone, Johnson Aide and Advocate on Poverty, Dies at 86
description: Richard W. Boone, who played a central role in President Lyndon B. Johnsons war on poverty in the 1960s and led private organizations pursuing political and social change, died on Feb. 26 at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86.

title: Ted Turner Expected to Undergo Emergency Medical Treatment in Argentina
description: Ted Turner, the American media magnate, was expected to undergo emergency medical treatment in Buenos Aires, Tlam, Argentinas national news agency, reportedFriday. Mr. Turner, 75, who founded CNN and is worth $2.2 billion, according to Forbes, had been at a ranch he owns in southern Argentina, local news media reported. He was taken to a private clinic in the city of Bariloche earlyFridaymorning after he complained of a sharp pain in his abdomen, an official at the clinic told Tlam. After a brief stay, Mr. Turner was moved to Buenos Aires.

title: Missing 26 3-Point Shots, Nets Fail to Add to Streak
description: BOSTON  The Nets status as a winning team lasted one game. Having finally risen above .500 on Wednesday  and with an excellent opportunity to win again Friday against the Boston Celtics, a team bound for the draft lottery  the Nets reverted to their 2013 ways and dropped a 91-84 decision at TD Garden.

title: Pre-K Special Education Contractor Pleads Guilty to Fraud Charge
description: A man who ran preschool programs for developmentally disabled children pleaded guilty on Friday in a case that became a showcase example of corruption in New York States special education financing system.

title: Behind Clash Between C.I.A. and Congress, a Secret Report on Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  It was early December when the Central Intelligence Agency began to suspect it had suffered what it regarded as an embarrassing computer breach.

title: Eyes Are Off the Court as the Knicks Get a Rare Win on It
description: Basketball again felt like a backdrop for the Knicks on Friday. The team, one of the N.B.A. leaders in off-court distractions, was preparing for a game against the Utah Jazz, but the focus was instead on whether Carmelo Anthony might be headed to Chicago and Phil Jackson might be headed to New York.

title: Judge Declares Mistrial in Hip-Hop Managers Trial
description: A judge in the federal trial of a hip-hop manager accused of ordering the murder of one of 50 Cents associates declared a mistrial on Friday, the United States attorneys office in Manhattan said.

title: Yankees Like What They See From Pineda, So Far
description: TAMPA, Fla.  All the attention on whether Masahiro Tanaka can find the same success in the majors as he did in Japan has taken some of the focus off Michael Pineda.

title: In South Bronx, Visions of a Bustling Shoreline
description: The Harlem River flows along the western edge of the South Bronx, much of it hidden behind rambling warehouses and metal fences topped with barbed wire.

title: An A.T.V. Driver Is Accused of Running Down an Officer
description: After a five-day manhunt, the police on Friday arrested a Queens man suspected of running down a New York City police officer on a four-wheel all-terrain vehicle and dragging him nearly 200 feet down a Brooklyn street.

title: Juror Loses Job for Serving in Terror Trial
description: To be chosen as one of the jurors in the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama Bin Laden, would understandably cause some unease.

title: Florida: Mother Faces Charges for Driving Van Into Ocean
description: Authorities in Daytona Beach have charged a pregnant South Carolina woman with attempted murder for driving her minivan into the ocean with her three children strapped in the back seat. The Volusia County sheriff arrested the woman, Ebony Wilkerson, 32, on Friday at Halifax Health Medical Center, where she had been taken for a mental health evaluation after the episode on Tuesday, which the sheriff said was premeditated. Ms. Wilkerson faces three counts each of first-degree attempted murder and child abuse. Her children, ages 3, 9 and 10, are in state custody until they can be released to family members.

title: Ukraine-Russia Ties, Explained
description: To understand the current conflict between Ukraine and Russia, look to the interconnected history of the two countries.

title: Ramp to Tappan Zee Will Close for 4 Years
description: Tarrytown is in for some traffic problems. Another ramp to another bridge is about to be closed, but New York State officials reject any suggestions that this might be a sequel to the infamous lane-closing gridlock in Fort Lee, N.J., last September.

title: Debate Over Park Eateries Is Older Than Aged Wine
description: The recent kerfuffle over a planned restaurant for Union Square Park seemed to have a singular set of issues. The restaurant, which received a green light from the state Court of Appeals last month, was proposed for an unusually small park in a part of Manhattan that has seen the arrival of an unusually large number of restaurants.

title: Corrections: March 8, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) QUARTET (2013) Four former opera singers  above, from left, Billy Connolly, Maggie Smith, Tom Courtenay and Pauline Collins  who performed together in Verdis Rigoletto at the height of their careers, reunite, against their better judgment. Theyre to sing that operas third-act quartet at the gala meant to keep their palatial retirement home from financial ruin. Michael Gambon plays the maestro who oversees the annual affair, held on Verdis birthday. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film, the first feature directed by Dustin Hoffman, a sincere but sloppy piece of work. Mr. Hoffman dotes on his cast of first-rate British actors of a certain age, Mr. Scott added, and invites us to savor their energy and professionalism. This is not difficult, though the efforts of these fine actors might have yielded greater delight if they had been given more to do.

title: Chinas Hard Line: No Room for Compromise
description: BEIJING  The Chinese foreign minister took a strong stand Saturday on Chinas growing territorial disputes with neighboring nations, saying that there is no room for compromise with Japan and that China would never accept unreasonable demands from smaller countries, an apparent reference to Southeast Asian nations.

title: Passport Theft Adds to Mystery of Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Investigators trying to find out what happened to a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared en route to Beijing on Saturday morning were examining the usual causes of plane crashes: mechanical failure, pilot error, bad weather. But the discovery that two of the passengers were carrying stolen passports also raised the unsettling possibility of foul play.

title: A.C.P.T. 2014: Retail Therapy to Soothe the Nerves
description: SPECIAL POST  When youre getting ready to speed solve seven difficult crossword puzzles against hundreds of hardcore solvers, your nerves can get the best of you. Some people deal with this by getting a good nights sleep. Others indulge in a little retail therapy.

title: A Finger Lakes Womens History Focus
description: Its the wineries of New Yorks Finger Lakes that usually get the most attention from tourists, but a trail of restored homes, parks and museums may have visitors picking up a bit of womens history with their cabernet franc.

title: Planes Landing Gear Catches Fire After a Landing in Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  The rear landing gear of an Indian airliner caught fire shortly after the plane landed here at Tribhuvan International Airport on Saturday afternoon. One person among the 182 passengers and crew members aboard the Air Indigo flight sustained a minor injury as he rushed to escape the aircraft.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, March. 9
description: Those at the top of the firm directed employees to hide the firms true financial condition from creditors, investors, auditors and even partners of the firm.

title: Jeff Lawson of Twilio: When Ideas Collide, Dont Duck
description: This interview with  Jeff Lawson, chief executive of Twilio, a cloud communications company in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: How Big Business Can Take the High Road
description: Its been a long time  maybe never  since Ive read a book that made me feel proud or even a little encouraged about the moral compass of the worlds largest companies. Corporations, after all, exist to make money. Last I checked, doing good deeds is not listed as a fiduciary duty. But Christine Baders thought-provoking book, The Evolution of a Corporate Idealist: When Girl Meets Oil (Bibliomotion, 264 pages), argues that this may be changing, at least among some of the people who work at these companies.

title: Reaching Out, via the Kitchen
description: Lawrence Blake, 61, works for Bethesda Cares, a community outreach program in Maryland for the homeless.

title: Beauty Tips an Employee Can Do Without
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: For Nonprofits, a Bigger Share of the Economy
description: The overall economy has been expanding slowly, but at least one sector is vibrant: nonprofits, which have been growing at a breakneck pace.

title: Beware the Market Whiplash of Geopolitics
description: Investing is hard enough when youre focused on fundamentals like earnings, debt loads and cash flow.

title: A Top-Heavy Focus on Income Inequality
description: I worry about growing income inequality. But I worry even more that the discussion is too narrowly focused. I worry that our outrage at the top 1 percent is distracting us from the problem that we should really care about: how to create opportunities and ensure a reasonable standard of living for the bottom 20 percent.

title: A Whistle Thats Lost in the Crowd
description: Late last month, deep in the annual financial statement filed by SunTrust Banks  on Page 197, to be exact  there was this nugget of news: The Justice Department is investigating mortgages that SunTrust, a large bank holding company operating in the Southeast, underwrote and sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the home loan finance giants.

title: On Instagram, a Bazaar Where You Least Expect It
description: Instagram, the photo-sharing app owned by Facebook, is my favorite place to skim through pictures of friends. I like to see them celebrating their birthdays, eating at lavishly decorated dinner tables and enjoying their midday coffees.

title: The Youngest Technorati
description: Ryan Orbuch, 16 years old, rolled a suitcase to the front door of his familys house in Boulder, Colo., on a Friday morning a year ago. He was headed for the bus stop, then the airport, then Texas.

title: A.C.P.T. 2014: And Away We Go
description: SPECIAL POST  Its 11:00 a.m. on a Saturday, a time when most normal people are either just rousing after sleeping in, or perhaps getting ready for a relaxing brunch. Here at the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott, however, a large group of crossword lovers are making sure their pencils are sharp. The first puzzle of the annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is about to drop.

title: Silence of Knicks Mills Veers From Early Plan
description: There was a time when Steve Mills was forthcoming about his role as general manager of the Knicks. He had big plans, and he wanted to tell the world all about them.

title: Investment Fees and Expertise
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Architects Role
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Plot to Kill Jeff Davis
description: Samuel Kingston, a Union soldier and prisoner of war, languished in a dungeon on a late winters day in March 1864. The cell was in the basement of infamous Libby Prison in Richmond, Va., the capital of the Confederacy. A severe cough and cold racked his body. His cellmates were similarly affected. Ten in all, they were crammed into a dank, drafty cell not much larger than a common tent. Rebel guards provided Kingston and the others with nothing more than scraps of food for subsistence and an open bucket for a toilet. If some of the guards had had their way, the prisoners would be left to rot in the filth and cold of the converted brick warehouse.

title: Variety: An Expressive Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I liked this look into the history of speech etiquette, especially since I tend to lean toward the casual side as a writer (you might not have noticed.)

title: A Body of Work R. A. Dickey Prefers as His Legacy
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  He knows what is coming from the way the mail feels in his hands. About two of three letters to R. A. Dickey have the telltale pieces of cardboard inside. Those are baseball cards fans want him to sign. The ones without the cardboard seek something more important.

title: Out, and Serving
description: Images and interviews attest to the struggles and triumphs, the dignities and indignities, of gay and lesbian service members.

title: Tensions Remain High in Crimea Amid Renewed Effort to Mediate
description: MOSCOW  Even as Russia and Ukraine signaled a modest willingness to seek a diplomatic resolution to the widening crisis over Crimea on Saturday, there were new reports of Russian reinforcements there, and Russia raised the possibility of suspending inspections required under arms control treaties because of stepped-up operations by NATO.

title: Mercy and Social Media Slow the Noose in Iran
description: TEHRAN  Born into a poor family in one of Tehrans most desolate neighborhoods, at age 17 Safar Anghouti had little to look forward to beyond a lifetime in his fathers business  rummaging through trash on the streets of the city for bottles, cans and anything else of value.

title: Partnerships on Powder
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  During his race Saturday morning, Mac Marcoux rocketed down the slope at nearly 75 miles per hour.

title: Reconstructing a Recall
description: General Motors is recalling more than 1.6 million vehicles because of defective ignition switches in six different models.

title: Sheila MacRae, Wife in 60s Honeymooners Sketches, Dies at 92
description: Sheila MacRae, the actress and singer best known for playing Alice Kramden in the 1960s version of The Honeymooners, died on Thursday in Englewood, N.J. She was 92.

title: To Ensure Future Fans, Anaheim Ducks Grow Hockey Players
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  What would Alex Kalau know of the way his parents grew up, one in speck-on-the-map Milk River, Alberta, and the other in quaint Antigonish, Nova Scotia?

title: The Pressure Test
description: DORAL, Fla.  Closing out a PGA Tour victory is like starting a family. Many dream of doing it, but the reality is often more stressful than imagined. No matter how many times a golfer visualizes it or how thoroughly he prepares for it, there is no way of knowing how he will react until he is in the situation.

title: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Documents
description: Letters from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to consumers and then-Representative Barney Frank.

title: Auto Regulators Dismissed Defect Tied to 13 Deaths
