description: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off while being driven, but they declined to investigate the problem, which G.M. now says is linked to 13 deaths and requires the recall of more than 1.6 million cars worldwide.

title: Sleeves Hurt LeBron James but Not Most Shooters
description: N.B.A. players have spent their entire lives working on jump shots. They hold the ball in a certain way, try to replicate the same release time and again, and resist any attempts to change their mechanics, even if they are in a slump.

title: U.S. Paralympic Skier Is Stable After Crash
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  An American skier was stable and conscious Saturday at a hospital, where he was taken by helicopter after he crashed during the mens sitting downhill competition at the Paralympic Games. The skier, Tyler Walker of Aspen, Colo., tumbled several times and lay motionless before members of the medical staff rushed to his side.

title: The Boys in the Bunkhouse
description: For decades, dozens of men with intellectual disabilities lived in an old schoolhouse and worked in a turkey plant. No one knew just what they endured.

title: With Medium, Evan Williams Is Tackling the Future of Writing Online
description: As a founder of both Blogger and Twitter, Evan Williams helped change the way people write online. Now, with his latest start-up, Medium, he is trying to figure out how we will write in the future.

title: The Men of Atalissa
description: For decades, a group of men with intellectual disabilities seemed happy living in a small Iowa town. Then their neighbors found out the truth.

title: Hall of Famer Whose Pen Charted Path for Jackie Robinson
description: Jackie Robinson had a stellar 1945 season with the Kansas City Monarchs of the Negro leagues but was virtually unknown to most of America. That fall, he picked up a pen to write a letter to the sportswriter Wendell Smith, whose name he spelled with one L.

title: The Teeth of Memory
description: WEST CORNWALL, Conn.  WHEN I was 18, I worked for a summer as a dishwasher at a retirement and nursing home, in the hills above the Santa Clara Valley, in Northern California. I remember the friend who got me the job, Nancy, who waitressed there, telling me one evening that an old man cried that day when she informed him there were no more bananas.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Stop Glorifying Hackers
description: I WAS at the Museum of Modern Art in New York not long ago, soaking in Edward Hoppers retro downer mystique, when I got a call that opened up brave new all-night-diners of doom and gloom.

title: Californias Smart Egg Rules
description: California voters and lawmakers have decided that, starting next year, all eggs sold in that state must come from hens that can stand up, lie down and extend their wings fully without touching another bird. This is a perfectly reasonable effort to improve, at least for one creature, the deplorable conditions associated with modern industrial farming. It could also improve public health. Astonishingly, the attorney general of Missouri, Chris Koster, has decided to sue to overturn the rule in federal court. The court should dismiss the case.

title: The Fat Drug
description: IF you walk into a farm-supply store today, youre likely to find a bag of antibiotic powder that claims to boost the growth of poultry and livestock. Thats because decades of agricultural research has shown that antibiotics seem to flip a switch in young animals bodies, helping them pack on pounds. Manufacturers brag about the miraculous effects of feeding antibiotics to chicks and nursing calves. Dusty agricultural journals attest to the ways in which the drugs can act like a kind of superfood to produce cheap meat.

title: To End the Abuse, She Grabbed a Knife
description: ATLANTA  WHAT strikes one American woman in four and claims a life in the United States every six hours?

title: Francisco Costa
description: Francisco Costa is a Brazilian-born fashion designer and the creative director for womens wear at Calvin Klein.

title: Eulogy for a Source
description: EACH piece of reportage has many authors and it is only thanks to long-established custom that we sign the text with a single name, wrote the literary journalist Ryszard Kapuscinski. They arrange contacts, lend us their homes, or quite simply change our lives.

title: Lodestars in a Murky Media World
description: ARE todays college-age journalists doomed, entering a business in free fall that is incapable of allowing most of them to earn a living? Or are they lucky, coming into a media world bursting with new possibilities?

title: Great Hope for Babies With H.I.V.
description: Americas National Institutes of Health will soon sponsor clinical trials abroad to evaluate whether early and very aggressive drug treatments for babies infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, can effectively clear the virus from their bodies. The hope is that such treatments might cure at least some of them, as seemingly happened in one famous case in the United States. But no one yet knows whether such therapy can be successful on a broad scale.

title: Can We Learn About Privacy From Porn Stars?
description: LOS ANGELES  I DIDNT expect to become a porn star. People rarely do. I was 19 years old, and my photographer roommate had an offer from a website to buy some nude pictures. We did a shoot and then waited two weeks in case I woke up in a panic over the idea of releasing naked photos of myself into the world. But I didnt, and so I turned to the required paperwork. One of the boxes to fill in read Stage Name (if applicable).

title: Dont Quote Me on This
description: I HATE quotation. Tell me what you know, Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote in his journal one spring day in 1849. He was talking about a very specific tendency. When were faced with an issue thats meant to be thought provoking (in this particular case, immortality), we reach for the easy way out. I notice, he writes, that as soon as writers broach this question, they begin to quote. Quotation becomes a way not to add depth to your thinking, but to avoid thinking in the first place.

title: Four Factions, No Favorite
description: THIS is a season of possibility for Republican politicians. Their party is poised to do well in November. Their Democratic opponents are stuck in neutral  waiting for Hillary, praying for Obamacare. And thanks to a few strategically placed traffic cones, there is no front-runner for the G.O.P. nomination in 2016, which means that more prominent Republicans than usual are dreaming the presidential dream.

title: When Health Costs Harm Your Credit
description: LIKE most people, I am generally vigilant about paying my bills  credit cards, mortgage, cellphone and so on. But medical bills have a different trajectory. I (usually) open the envelopes and peruse the amalgam of codes and charges. I sigh or swear. And set them aside for when I have time to clarify the confusion: An out-of-network charge from a doctor I know is in-network? An un-itemized laboratory bill from a doctor Ive never heard of? A bill for a huge charge before my insurer has paid its yet unknown portion of a hospitals unknowable fee?

title: Little R-S-P-E-C-T
description: WASHINGTON  IF you cant spell it, you cant get it.

title: The Men of Atalissa
description: For decades, a group of men with intellectual disabilities seemed happy living in a small Iowa town. Then their neighbors found out the truth. This film is being shown in collaboration with POV.org.

title: Global Warming? Not Always
description: BOULDER, Colo.  CALIFORNIA is now in the midst of the third year of one of its worst droughts on record. As our planet gradually warms from our rampant burning of fossil fuels, its only natural to wonder what role climate change has played in Californias troubles.

title: No Quick or Clear Solution in N.F.L. Settlement
description: When the N.F.L. and the lawyers for the 4,500 retirees who sued the league said in August that they had reached a $765 million deal to end their dispute, there was hope on all sides that a resolution to the standoff would come soon.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 96
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: The Uninhibited Press, 50 Years Later
description: Perhaps no one understood both the necessity and the costs of a free press better than Thomas Jefferson. In a 1787 letter to a friend, he wrote, Were it left to me to decide whether we should have a government without newspapers, or newspapers without a government, I should not hesitate a moment to prefer the latter.

title: The Bamian Buddhas
description: An inside look at the site of the destroyed Buddhas of Bamian in Afghanistan.

title: Once Heir Apparent at Shortstop, Nunez Joins Crowd at Second and Third
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The line forms to the right, and also to the left, of the Yankees infield.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 9
description: Crimeas future remains uncertain even as Russia and Ukraine signaled a willingness to seek a diplomatic resolution on Saturday. The day before, Russian parliamentary leaders said they would support an annexation of Crimea, and the Kremlin allowed a large pro-secession rally in Moscows Red Square.

title: Who Is Susceptible to Concussions?
description: They are not the kind of statistics anyone likes to keep, but several seasons worth of data have begun to give researchers an idea of which elite hockey players are more likely to sustain concussions. The profile, in simplified form: short players, defensemen or those who take a lot of penalties.

title: Gary Thorne in Full Voice for High School Event
description: ST. PAUL  In the television booth at the top of Xcel Energy Center on Friday night, the broadcaster Gary Thorne had everything he needed in sight. A cup of coffee. Lozenges for his throat. And a spirited hockey game on the ice far below.

title: The Somewhat Inside Story of the U.S. Team
description: Jonathan Hock does not want anyone to confuse his coming ESPN series about the United States mens soccer team with Hard Knocks on HBO.

title: Sovereignty vs. Self-Rule: Crimea Reignites Battle
description: WASHINGTON  They wanted to break away from a country they considered hostile. The central government cried foul, calling it a violation of international law. But with the help of a powerful foreign military, they succeeded in severing ties.

title: Redistribution and the Lesser Depression
description: Ive finally gotten around to a careful read of the new IMF paper on redistribution and growth (pdf)  which concludes that there is no negative effect of redistributionist policies, at least within the range we normally see, and quite possibly a positive effect from the reduction in inequality. I like this conclusion, politically  which is a good reason to kick the tires, and Ill present some cautions in a later post. For now, however, a quick-and-dirty piece of data analysis inspired by the papers method.

title: Readers Commenting on Domestic Violence
description: When I lecture about our book Half the Sky, which focuses on womens rights in the rest of the world, Im always asked about gender issues here in the United States. And I answer that the two most serious issues are probably two that dont get as much attention as they should: domestic violence and human trafficking. Today my column is about domestic violence, but its something that we in the news business dont cover enoughconsidering that it strikes one American woman in four, and a higher share of women worldwide. Its a complicated issue, but its also one where I think we have the tools to do much, much better. Police are attentive in some jurisdictions, but not nearly enough in others, and thats a crucial step to reduce the toll.

title: De Blasio, Critic of Taxi Commission, Picks Its Ex-Counsel to Lead It
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Saturday that he would nominate a veteran of the Taxi and Limousine Commission as its chairwoman, moving to fill a lingering vacancy at the agency, which he chided frequently during the mayoral campaign.

title: Plaintiff in Police Lawsuit Is Ordered to Pay New York Citys Legal Fees
description: Initially, the case sounded reminiscent of the police brutality scandals that have haunted the New York Police Department for years. A young man returning from celebrating his birthday at a Brooklyn bar had a tart exchange with two police officers, who he said then handcuffed him and slammed his head onto the hood of their car.

title: Gators Overwhelm Wildcats to Cap SECs First 18-0 Season
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  The timeout came with 36.9 seconds to play and history convincingly secured. Fittingly, four Florida seniors huddled and headed to the bench one last time at home, having stamped their legacy on the Gators record-setting season.

title: Ukraines Fight to Fix Economy Is Also a Fight for Legitimacy
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Young men in fatigues, bulletproof vests and masks patrol one of Kievs better hotels, the Dnipro, and they have occupied several floors. Armed with clubs, pistols and even slingshots, they are the militant Ukrainian nationalists of Pravy Sektor, or Right Sector.

title: For Families of Missing on Airliner, Memories Mix With Fading Hope
description: A Canadian couple returning from vacation in Vietnam. An American who worked in Asia for IBM. A group of Chinese calligraphers who had attended an exhibition in Malaysia.

title: A.C.P.T. 2014: After the First Four Puzzles
description: SPECIAL POST  After the first four puzzles, we have reigning champ Dan Feyer in the lead with 6,150 points and a tie for second place between Anne Erdmann and former champ Tyler Hinman with 6,125 points each. Jeopardy! champion Joon Pahk is in third place with 6,075 points.

title: Mets Top Prospect Has Shaky Outing but Remains Upbeat
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  This was a reminder that the Mets top prospect, Noah Syndergaard, is not invincible, that he is just 21 years old and that this is only spring training.

title: Vows: Salon Serendipity
description: Julia Khanbalinova always wished she would walk out of work one day and walk into her future husband. She walked into his mother instead.

title: For Ski Break Without Crowds (or Rebels), an Afghan Town Beckons
description: BAMIAN, Afghanistan  It will be a long time before anyone calls this mountain town a tourist trap, especially at 9,000 feet when lows in the winter can plunge to 20 degrees below zero.

title: Florida Election a Crash Course for Midterm Races
description: MADEIRA BEACH, Fla.  Pinellas County, with its off-the-clock retirees and gentle Gulf Coast beaches, cultivates a life of flip-flops and easy breathing.

title: When Employees Confess, Sometimes Falsely
description: When an AutoZone investigator approached Chris Polston, asking for his help investigating a theft, Mr. Polston was happy to oblige.

title: Nosy Nonsense
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Todays Sunday offering is a nice, tight theme set where the zee sound (using different spellings) is added to familiar phrases and clued in a punny way. Of course, the ensuing hilarity is just what you would expect in a Brendan Emmett Quigley puzzle, and this one doesnt disappoint. It also happens to be an exceptionally clean grid for its size and, as a special bonus, Mr. Quigley has been kind enough to keep the under-the-radar music references out of this puzzle, which shows a good understanding of his audience.(But if you would like to delve further into his indie puzzles and all that that implies, you can have a taste of them here. Please help support your constructors, who are generally freelancers, and think about throwing a few shekels his way if you like what you see.)

title: Kerry Warns Russia Against Annexation of Crimea
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry warned his Russian counterpart on Saturday that steps by the Kremlin to annex Crimea would close any available space for diplomacy, a State Department official said.

title: Rios Race to Future Intersects Slave Past
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Sailing from the Angolan coast across the Atlantic, the slave ships docked here in the 19th century at the huge stone wharf, delivering their human cargo to the fattening houses on Valongo Street. Foreign chroniclers described the depravity in the teeming slave market, including so-called boutiques selling emaciated and diseased African children.

title: Long Wielding Power Behind the Scenes, Now Taking Her Leave
description: WASHINGTON  Not so long ago, when Alyssa Mastromonaco was still in her 20s, she had retreated to her apartment after two nonstop years as the scheduler for Senator John Kerrys 2004 presidential campaign, when her phone rang from an unfamiliar number. She let the caller go to voice mail  and only later heard the job offer she had been waiting for.

title: A Rocking Farewell From a Band in the Homestretch
description: Early in January, the guitarists Warren Haynes and Derek Trucks announced that they would be leaving the Allman Brothers Band at the end of this year. That means the end of a 25-year run for Mr. Haynes, who joined the group when he was 28, and a 15-year run for Mr. Trucks, who joined when he was 19. A bit later that month, Gregg Allman, the bands singer, keyboardist, and nominal leader, announced that the group as a whole would stop its regular touring after 2014.

title: Ruling Clears Way for Skakel Libel Suit
description: A federal judge ruled that Michael C. Skakels libel claim could proceed against the television personality Nancy Grace and her associates over comments made on her current affairs show that falsely suggested DNA evidence tied him to Martha Moxleys 1975 murder.

title: Farm Bill Reflects Shifting American Menu and a Senators Persistent Tilling
description: WASHINGTON  The farm bill signed by President Obama last month was at first glance the usual boon for soybean growers, catfish farmers and their ilk. But closer examination reveals that the nations agriculture policy is increasingly more whole grain than white bread.

title: Texas Voters Seem to Have Kicked One Habit
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: As SXSW Begins, Eyes Are on the Local Bands
description: The South by Southwest Music Festival has 2,200 acts playing 110 stages across six days, and the numbers do not include the slew of unofficial showcases and corporate parties.

title: Rand Paul Wins Conservative Straw Poll
description: OXON HILL, Md.  Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, won a presidential straw poll at a prominent conservative conference here on Saturday, capturing 31 percent of the vote among no fewer than 10 potential candidates.

title: Drought Hastens End of a Regions Hydropower Era
description: The yearslong drought in Central Texas could eventually snuff out a renewable power source that fueled the regions early growth: hydropower.

title: Libyan Militia Selling Oil, Defying the Government
description: CAIRO  A militia group that has blockaded Libyas main oil ports for more than six months began on Saturday to sell the oil for its own accounts as the weak transitional government appeared powerless to stop it.

title: Years After Hurricane, Political Storm Still Blows Over Claims
description: It has been five and a half years since Hurricane Ike pounded the Gulf Coast, killing dozens of people, pushing homes off their slabs and inflicting tens of billions of dollars in damage.

title: Reed Leads Tight Field as Doral Shows Soft Side
description: DORAL, Fla.  If the reconstructed course at Doral had not kept its nickname, it could have gotten a new one this past week: Sybil. In the first three days of its relaunch at the World Golf Championships event here, the 7,481-yard Blue Monster has flashed multiple personalities, from bloated on Thursday to plundering on Friday to all sweetness and light on Saturday.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: March 7, 2014
description: As the political crisis escalates in Ukraine, its worth remembering that a debate over trade was a major contributor to the uprising that led to recent turmoil. Should the country develop closer economic ties with Europe and the West, or with Russia, its neighbor to the East? This week on Money Talking, Joe and Rana Foroohar examine the economic backdrop of a political crisis iand what it means for the world economy.

title: Leading Republicans Move to Stamp Out Challenges From Right
description: WASHINGTON  As conservative activist groups stirred up trouble for establishment Republican Senate candidates in 2010 and 2012, party leaders in Washington first tried to ignore the insurgents, then tried to reason with them, and ultimately left it to primary voters to settle the matter.

title: A.C.P.T. 2014: After Puzzle 6
description: SPECIAL POST  At the end of the sixth puzzle, Howard Barkin has risen in the standings to a strong third place. He displaces Anne Erdmann, who fell in the rankings after the infamous Puzzle 5, and Mr. Barkin now defends his third place against Joon Pahk, who needs to recover two minutes in order to beat him.

title: Suspicion Falls on Russia as Snake Cyberattacks Target Ukraines Government
description: WASHINGTON  Since the first major protests in Kiev that triggered the current crisis with Moscow, American intelligence agencies have been on high alert for cyberattacks aimed at the new government in Ukraine. They were a bit late: the attacks started long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, and as might be expected, no one can quite pinpoint who is behind them, although some suspicion is falling on Russia.

title: League Play Pays Off for a Former Champ, Too
description: Earning a living at chess is not easy, and only a handful of elite competitors can count on a steady income. Many of the others teach, or work as assistants to their better-ranked peers.

title: Shockers Are in Rarefied Air, but History Offers Lesson: Dont Breathe Easy
description: ST. LOUIS  As the seconds ticked down Saturday afternoon at Scottrade Center, the scoreboard told a familiar story: Wichita State defeated Missouri State, 67-42. The Shockers have played 33 games this season. They have won them all.

title: Tough Outing for Banuelos, but Good Sign for Yankees
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  It had been 659 days since Manny Banuelos last pitched in a game, so just seeing him on a mound, throwing against an opponent, was enough for the Yankees.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 8, 2014
description: March 8, 2014

title: Scorned but Still in Love, Cleveland Beckons James
description: CLEVELAND  LeBron James returned home Sunday for an enthusiastic celebration not meant for him, but that did not keep many at Quicken Loans Arena from fantasizing that he might rejoin the team he once rejected.

title: Queens Man, 64, Dies After Being Struck in Hit-and-Run
description: A 64-year-old man died on Saturday after he was struck in a hit and run in Queens the night before, the police said.

title: Knicks Win Third Straight and Gain Ground in East
description: Break up the Knicks. Their third straight victory, a 107-97 triumph Saturday night in Cleveland, moved them into a tie with the Cavaliers for 10th place in the woebegone Eastern Conference and left them three and a half games behind the free-falling Atlanta Hawks for the conferences eighth and final playoff spot.

title: To Have and to Hold
description: Once upon a time, a mans bag indicated his trade. But these days, men have an increasingly complicated relationship with the things they carry their things in.

title: The Shape Shifter
description: The dissonant humor and beauty of the sculptor Erwin Wurms biomorphic riffs are also present in his home, where blue-chip art, grand architectural space and his own whimsical work create an odd harmony.

title: Fabric of Thought
description: The designer Dries Van Noten creates an original collage inspired by his upcoming museum exhibition.

title: Sarah Conde and Jeffrey Marcus
description: Sarah Nicholson Conde and Jeffrey Lee Marcus were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerks office officiated. On Saturday, Justice William P. Robinson III of the Rhode Island Supreme Court led another ceremony for family and friends at the Yale Club of New York.

title: Pamela Blechman, Alec Ellison
description: Pamela Jean Blechman and Alec Lindsay Ellison are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Gordon Tucker at Locanda Verde, a restaurant in New York.

title: Deirdre Foley-Mendelssohn, Peter Stella
description: Deirdre Jane Foley-Mendelssohn, the daughter of Kathy Foley and Roy Mendelssohn of Santa Cruz, Calif., is to be married Sunday to Dr. Peter Alexander Stella, a son of Dr. Harriet E. McGurk and the artist Frank Stella of New York. Mary-Beth Holland, a Universal Life minister and friend of the grooms family, is to officiate at the home of the grooms parents.

title: Hilary Falb and Philip Kalisman
description: Hilary Bell Falb and Philip Taubman Kalisman were married Saturday evening at the Boston Public Library. Rabbi Carl M. Perkins officiated.

title: Michele Zatzkis, Matthew Slaine
description: Michele Elaine Zatzkis and Matthew Justin Slaine were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton in New Orleans. Rabbi Alexis Berk officiated.

title: Sascha Weiss and Scott Simpson
description: Sascha Aibel Weiss and Scott Evan Simpson were married Saturday in a ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions at the Landmark Loews Jersey Theater in Jersey City. Taylor Asen, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Julia Khanbalinova, Justin Leventhal
description: Julia Khanbalinova, the daughter of Kamilla R. Khanbalinova of West New York, N.J., was married on Friday to Justin Alan Leventhal, a son of Denise A. Leventhal and Alan H. Leventhal of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Ugo R. Nacciarone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Jessica Karr, Jeffrey Gurtman
description: Jessica Rae Karr and Jeffrey Samuel Gurtman were married Saturday evening at the Amli Restaurant in New York. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated.

title: Alissa Grad and Michael Kestenbaum
description: Alissa Tara Grad and Michael Ari Kestenbaum were married Saturday evening at the New York Public Library. Judith S. Kaye, a former chief judge of the State of New York, officiated.

title: Joshua Gold, Joseph Harris
description: Joshua Chase Gold and Joseph Harris were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Winery. Elizabeth A. Harris, the sister of Mr. Harris, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated with Mr. Golds sister, Jennifer G. Clark, taking part.

title: Pamela Segal and Jason Shedlock
description: Pamela Hope Segal and Jason Alan Shedlock were married Saturday at the Wakefield Chapel in Annandale, Va. The Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Harold White taking part.

title: Elizabeth Wilson and Michael Brown Jr.
description: Elizabeth Burns Wilson, the daughter of Patricia E. Wilson and G. Larry Wilson of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there Saturday evening to Michael Charles Brown Jr., the son of Marianne Brown and Mr. Brown Sr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel.

title: Finally Arriving at Romance
description: Dr. Diana Cristina Montoya-Fontalvo, a daughter of Miryam I. Fontalvo-Montoya and Luis F. Montoya of Gainesville, Fla., was married there Saturday evening to Dr. Brendan Alexander Williams, the son of R. Kay Tolle and Wendell S. Williams of Silver Spring, Md. Dr. Daphna Yasova Barbeau, a Florida notary, officiated, with the Rev. Alberto Esposito, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part in the ceremony, at the home of the brides parents.

title: Intrigue Over Jackson Continues to Percolate
description: As far back as 15 years ago, the Knicks looked to Phil Jackson to help rescue them. Now, after all these years of yearning, it seems possible that he will rejoin the team, with whom he was a championship player more than 40 years ago.

title: Corrections: March 9, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: North Korea Uses Election To Reshape Parliament
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Sunday held its first parliamentary elections under the leadership of Kim Jong-un, who was expected to use the polls and a newly elected legislature to elevate officials loyal to him and further consolidate his power.

title: Search for Jet Compounds the Mystery
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  More than 48 hours after Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 vanished, the mysteries over its fate have only multiplied.

title: The Languages of Twitter Users
description: Twitter styles itself as the global town square for public conversations  a place for fans to gossip about an actress falling at the Academy Awards and for critics of Tunisias government to publicly decry the death of an opposition leader.

title: Gerard Mortier, Opera Visionary and Patron of New Work, Dies at 70
description: Gerard Mortier, a visionary opera company leader whose bold theatricality and updating of the canon helped define the art forms modern history, died on Saturday at his home in Brussels. He was 70.

title: Out of the Shadows, a Tech Hub in Luxembourg
description: LUXEMBOURG  The towering, rusty blast furnaces of the industrial wasteland in Belval stand in stark contrast with Luxembourgs fairy-tale image of wealth and stability. But the former industrial area about 20 kilometers south of Luxembourg City is undergoing a radical metamorphosis. Where the countrys largest steel works once spewed smoke into the sky above the French border, the government has been erecting an entire new neighborhood, aiming to position Luxembourg as Europes next hub for technological innovation.

title: The Cleft-Lip Smile I Never Knew Id Miss
description: We knew from ultrasound photos that our son Dylan would arrive in this world with the same birth defect as the babies weve all seen in those Smile Train ads, the ones featuring children with faces and stories so desperate and concerning that they compel people to donate. I never imagined having a baby with a face like that in the same way that one doesnt foresee giving birth to a child with an unexpected birthmark or color of hair. I also never pictured growing to love a defect so intensely that I would feel crushed when the time came to let it go.

title: Welfare States in the Euro Crisis
description: A followup on my last post, on redistribution and its role or lack thereof in the economic crisis. One thing we can do instead of looking at measures of redistribution  which is, in a way, the output of the welfare state  is look at social expenditures, which are in effect the input. And this gives us data on a few more countries. If we look at the relationship between social expenditures in 2007, on the eve of the crisis, and performance in the next five years, we get this:

title: The French Comparison
description: I promised that I would share some nagging concerns about the Ostry et al paper on redistribution and growth (pdf); I think I can usefull phrase my concerns in terms of my favorite comparison on these matters, which is between the United States and France.

title: Clashes in Ukraine as Rallies Take a Turn
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Rival rallies turned violent in Crimea on Sunday, as Ukraine celebrated the 200th anniversary of the birth of its greatest poet and the White House announced that President Obama would host the Ukrainian prime minister just days before a controversial referendum on Crimean secession next week.

title: In Our Pages: March 10
description: 1889: Queen Victoria Visits Biarritz

title: Mourinho's Coaching Moves Lift Chelsea Again
description: LONDON  Chelsea appears to be moving inexorably, almost reluctantly toward another Premier League title.

title: You Talking to Me?
description: Dropcam is like a nanny cam for your dog. With it, its easy to communicate with your pet remotely  but obedience is not included.

title: Every Dog Has Its Data
description: A half-century ago, dogs lived in barns or backyards, domiciled in shabby little doghouses. Now they have the run of our houses and apartments. They sleep in our beds (full disclosure). In some cases, they are considered by their owners to be like children, and possibly a bit cleaner.

title: 300  Sequel Adds Up to $45.1 Million
description: Ram them! With that cheese-tastic command, navies collide on computer-generated waves in 300: Rise of an Empire, but the words could just as easily have come from Warner Brothers marketers, who aggressively advertised the R-rated sequel and were rewarded with $45.1 million in North American ticket sales over the weekend.

title: Aska to Close, for a Move
description: Fredrik Berselius, an acclaimed New York chef whose cooking is linked to the ideals and ingredients of the New Nordic movement, has decided to close his Brooklyn restaurant, Aska, in order to move it to a still-to-be-found location later in the year.

title: A.C.P.T. 2014: Striding Up to the Big Boards
description: SPECIAL POST  David Kahns Puzzle 7, the last to be solved by all of the competitors, is completed, and the weary solvers straggle into the lobby with a palpable sense of relief. That wont last long for nine of the solvers, who will be competing in the final round of the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

title: A.C.P.T. 2014: For All the Money
description: SPECIAL POST  The A Division clues are the hardest, so the best solvers in the world get an extra five minutes to solve, for a total of twenty minutes.

title: Among de Blasios Priorities, Minimum Wage Waits Behind Pre-K
description: Roberto Guzman was savoring a quiet evening with his wife and two boys in their Harlem apartment last month when the news flashed across his television screen. Mayor Bill de Blasio was vowing to create a new city minimum wage so that full-time workers werent relegated to the ranks of the poor.

title: Basquiat Auction by Christies Is Postponed
description: Christies auction house has postponed an online auction of Jean-Michel Basquiat works owned by a former roommate of his after Basquiats sisters filed a federal lawsuit last week, arguing that some of the items may not be authentic. After initially saying that the auction would proceed, Christies quietly reversed itself, posting a notice on its website: Our goal is to allow time for all parties involved to reach an equivalent level of confidence in the validity of these items, so that the sale may resume at a later date.

title: Warlord Who Tamped Conflicts as Afghan Vice President Dies
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Vice President Muhammad Qasim Fahim of Afghanistan, a formidable power broker and former warlord who played a crucial role in ousting the Taliban and shaping the political order that followed, died on Sunday, less than a month before Afghans are to elect a new leader.

title: 2016 Republican Prospects Spar Over Ukraine
description: Three Republicans said to be considering presidential runs tried to distinguish themselves on Russias invasion of the Crimean Peninsula, previewing their approaches to foreign policy in television appearances on Sunday.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 45 at Checkpoint in Southern Iraq
description: A suicide bomber driving a truck loaded with explosives attacked a security checkpoint in the southern Iraqi city of Hilla on Sunday, killing at least 45 people and wounding more than 100, security officials said.

title: No Guarantee of Final Nuclear Deal With Iran, E.U. Official Says
description: TEHRAN  The European Unions foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said Sunday that there was no guarantee that Iran and world powers would be able to reach a final, comprehensive agreement over Irans nuclear program.

title: Friends Return, but Cant Go Back
description: Shotgun Lovesongs is about a hometown in Wisconsin and the close band of friends who will always feel its magnetic pull. Its first-time author, Nickolas Butler, was raised in Eau Claire, which is mentioned in the book as a nearby and even more cosmopolitan place than the tiny, fictitious Little Wing.

title: A Pakistani Fianc Meets the Indian Parents
description: Can a Pakistani boy and an Indian girl find happiness together? Thats the serious question posed by the Bollywood comedy Total Siyapaa. At least it would be, if the movie, directed by E. Nivas and written by Neeraj Pandey, didnt smother its story in uninspired high jinks.

title: Roller Coasters of Emotion, but Keeping a Tight Grip
description: Emotion Unbound was the title of a program of works by Dvorak, Schumann and Ernst von Dohnanyi that the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented on Friday at Alice Tully Hall. The society has grown fond of such Harlequin Romance-like titles (up next: Russian Twilight), and no doubt a certain amount of simplification is inevitable in marketing.

title: Bringing Vocal Life to a Scholarly Endeavor
description: In the acclaim that is doled out to composers and musicians, editors tend to fall through the cracks. But the contributions of these hardworking, often anonymous individuals  who pore over manuscripts, adjudicate divergent details and create playable written versions  should not be underestimated, nor should their role in creating the musical canon. What is performable, after all, tends to overlap significantly with what is performed.

title: William Clay Ford, Auto Family Scion and Detroit Lions Owner, Dies at 88
description: William Clay Ford, who once steered a car from his grandfather Henry Fords lap but, overshadowed by his brash older brother Henry II, never got the chance to run the family business, died on Sunday at his home in Grosse Pointe, Mich. Fords last surviving grandchild, he was 88.

title: Forget Your Troubles With Songs of Hollywood
description: If youre nostalgic for those perky TV variety shows when celebrities dropped in to chat and share a song and dance, Jim Carusos Cast Party, a decade-long Monday evening series at Birdland, is a welcoming oasis of traditional show business bonhomie. Its subliminal message: Yes, you can go home again.

title: Barely Keeping Up in TVs New Golden Age
description: Not long ago, a friend at work told me I absolutely, positively must watch Broad City on Comedy Central, saying it was a slacker-infused hilarity.

title: Inhabiting a Mentor and Heroes of the Stage
description: A few years back, Jim Brochu had a hit with his one-man show, Zero Hour, in which he reincarnated the great Zero Mostel. Now, in Character Man, a blend of cabaret, theater and scrapbook, he pays homage to a much larger lineup of actors and produces a solidly satisfying evening.

title: English Team Wins the Junior Camrose
description: The more we encourage young players, the better. The British hold two annual junior international events. The Junior Camrose is for players under 25 on Jan. 1. The Peggy Bayer is for under 20s.

title: After a Lover Flits Away, a Lifetime Spent Waiting
description: Fantasies of love vary across time and culture. What seems a dream to some may seem a nightmare to others. Aesthetic ideals vary similarly. When the China Ningbo Performance & Arts Group first presented The Red Dress in China, audiences were apparently rapturous. But when I saw the same dance spectacle at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday, my response was much more subdued.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: The Spread of the Crisis
description: Slides here (pdf).

title: After Prison, Finding Bumps on the Road to Normalcy
description: The word good comes up often in Emily Schwends incisive Take Me Back, now at Walkerspace, almost always when applied to Bill (James Kautz), an ex-convict living with his mother, Sue (Charlotte Booker), in Muskogee, Okla. She believes in him; after all, he grudgingly dotes on her, urging her to pursue a healthier diet. His high school sweetheart, Julie (Boo Killebrew), has faith in him, too. Married now but disillusioned with her husband, shes up from Garland, Tex., for her brothers wedding, and susceptible to the passion that once possessed her and Bill.

title: Revisiting a Scholar Unmasked by Scandal
description: When the Yale literary theorist Paul de Man died in 1983, he was hailed as a brilliant teacher who had helped turn deconstruction, the critical approach originated by Jacques Derrida, into an insurgent force in American intellectual life.

title: Glimpsing a Lost Paris, Before Gentrification
description: You might almost think of Charles Marville, the 19th-century photographer, as akin to the guys who drive around mapping streets for Google. He was a hired hand, an illustrator turned photographer near the dawn of the medium. Paris officials enlisted him to document, among other things, new parks and squares but also the streets, shops and tenements scheduled for demolition  to make, in essence, a historical record of a city soon to be lost.

title: Models Preserve Wrights Dreams
description: Broadacre City was Frank Lloyd Wrights vision of a utopian metropolis, an orderly version  some would say omen  of the suburban sprawl that would ultimately spring up around American cities starting in the 1950s.

title: Lazy Scrabble Players, Heres Your Book
description: Stephin Merritt, the songwriter for the Magnetic Fields, has channeled his side passion for Scrabble into a book chronicling all the two-letter words allowed in the game. 101 Two-Letter Words, to be published in October by W. W. Norton, is a collection of four-line poems by Mr. Merritt, with color illustrations by Roz Chast. My mother is a former English teacher who always expected me to write the Great American Novel, thunderous and profound, so she was not impressed to learn that my first book is going to be amusing light verse, Mr. Merritt said by email. But now that Ive got her hooked on Words With Friends, she sees the immense value of remembering the two-letter words, and what fascinating little oddities they are, so shes begging for a copy of the book.

title: Some Renewals on Fox
description: Fox announced that it had renewed four shows for next season: one drama, The Following, and three comedies, New Girl, Brooklyn Nine-Nine and The Mindy Project. The ratings for Brooklyn Nine-Nine have been low  its last four episodes averaged only 2.8 million total viewers  but the show won two Golden Globes in January, for best comedy and best leading comedy actor (Andy Samberg). The Following and New Girl have also struggled when judged by traditional ratings of viewers who watch programs live, but both shows continue to rank among the best in broadcast programming when including viewers in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic who watch using DVRs. The renewal for The Mindy Project is more of a surprise. This season it has averaged 2.6 million total viewers, and it is now on a two-month hiatus. It is scheduled to return with new episodes on April 1.

title: President Xi Strikes Back
description: Playing Whack-a-Separatist in Chinas Far West.

title: Lineup Announced For Encores! Off-Center
description: City Center has announced the lineup for its second Encores! Off-Center series, which is intended to showcase new interpretations by contemporary artists of older Off Broadway musicals.

title: What It Means to Be Catholic Now
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  ONE year into his astonishingly popular papacy, Pope Francis has become the perfect divining rod for uncovering assumptions about the future of the Catholic Church.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: JWT Plans to Celebrate 150 Years With a Focus on the Future
description: THE agency that once proclaimed, Theres a Ford in your future is looking to its own future as it begins to mark a milestone anniversary.

title: Titanfall Demo
description: Titanfall, a science-fiction shooter for Xbox from Respawn Entertainment and Electronic Arts, is meant to be played online with other players, and features giant robotic suits known as titans.

title: Microsoft Pins Xbox One Hopes on Titanfall, a Sci-Fi Shooting Game
description: A video game that depicts a battle between corporate mercenaries and local brigands in far-off space colonies has already won the hearts and minds of Microsoft executives.

title: Competing Rallies Before a Referendum
description: As a referendum on the future of Crimea approaches, demonstrators in Ukraine and elsewhere in Europe gathered. Some waved Russian flags while others compared Vladimir V. Putin to Hitler.

title: Get Comfortable
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Well, the big boards of the 37th A.C.P.T. have been put away until next year, and solvers from all over the country are on their way home. If youre thinking of attending next year, you can always start your training early with this smooth puzzle by Kelly Clark. Ms. Clark offers us a theme that has been seen before (as she mentions in her notes below), but what I liked about her puzzle was the Monday morning smoothness that is so crucial to my solving self-esteem. It reminds me of the kind of flow we experience with an Andrea Carla Michaels puzzle.

title: Is the Wolf a Real American Hero?
description: FOR a field biologist stuck in the city, the wildlife dioramas at the American Museum of Natural History are among New Yorks best offerings. One recent Saturday, I paused by the display for elk, an animal I study. Like all the dioramas, this one is a great tribute. I have observed elk behavior until my face froze and stared at the data results until my eyes stung, but this scene brought back to me the graceful beauty of a tawny elk cow, grazing the autumn grasses.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 95
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: 2014: Clinton Dodges 2016 Questions
description: A selection of clips showing how Hillary Rodham Clinton responded to variations of the question: Will she run for president in 2016?

title: Any Thoughts, Mrs. Clinton, on the Year After Next?
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is accustomed to hearing The Question. So if you have a chance to ask it, make it count.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: The Surprising Suns Are Battling for a Playoff Berth
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Checking Noise Complaint, Officers Stumble Upon a Heroin Mill
description: Friday night did not go as planned for Frank Giardina.

title: Red Bull Rewind: Vancouver Horror Movie
description: You can be forgiven if you thought the Red Bulls were playing with replacement players Saturday night at Vancouver, rather than both teams enduring a game called by replacement referees.

title: Report Cites Devastating Toll on Health of Syrias Children
description: The Syrian civil wars impact on the health of Syrias children is far more insidious than has been widely understood, a leading childrens advocacy group reported Sunday, with large numbers dying or at risk from chronic and preventable diseases that have flourished because the countrys public health system has basically collapsed.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

For-Profit Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 10
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: What Philly Accent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Save the Stacks
description: To the Editor:

title: In Rent Plan for Charters, Mayor Faces a Hard Road
description: As a candidate for mayor, Bill de Blasio electrified crowds of parents and education activists with a pledge to charge rent to charter schools, one of the starkest policy departures from his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Canada Challenges Erotic TV on Level of Domestic Content
description: OTTAWA  Canadas broadcasting regulator says that its rules mandating minimum levels of Canadian programming are related to Canadian artists having access to Canadian airwaves. An order it issued last week suggests that it has a broad view of what might constitute art.

title: Shockers Get a Pause to Celebrate Their Run at Perfection
description: ST. LOUIS  When it was over, the Wichita State players stood on a podium and looked up as the scoreboard at Scottrade Center played highlights from the Shockers run to the Missouri Valley Conference tournament title.

title: Bridge Scandal Relegates Traffic Study to Punch Line
description: The slights can come from anywhere now, engineers say, on once-sleepy conference calls and at increasingly charged community meetings, at the dinner table where relatives had typically cared little for details of the job and, unflinchingly, on late-night television.

title: Liberty, Equality, Efficiency
description: Most people, if pressed on the subject, would probably agree that extreme income inequality is a bad thing, although a fair number of conservatives believe that the whole subject of income distribution should be banned from public discourse. (Rick Santorum, the former senator and presidential candidate, wants to ban the term middle class, which he says is class-envy, leftist language. Who knew?) But what can be done about it?

title: Little-Known Health Act Fact: Prison Inmates Are Signing Up
description: In a little-noticed outcome of President Obamas Affordable Care Act, jails and prisons around the country are beginning to sign up inmates for health insurance under the law, taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults  a major part of the prison population.

title: Putting Star Power Behind Horse Carriage Industry
description: In terms of star wattage, the animal-rights activists fighting to drive horse carriages out of Central Park for good would seem to have the advantage: Alec Baldwin, Gloria Steinem, Lea Michele and Miley Cyrus have all lined up in support of a ban.

title: Nuns Released by Syrians After Three-Month Ordeal
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian insurgents released 13 nuns and three attendants who disappeared three months ago from their monastery in the ancient Christian town of Maaloula, Lebanese and Syrian officials said early Monday, ending a drama in which rebels said they were protecting the women from government shelling and Syrian officials said they were abducted in an act of intimidation against Christians.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 9, 2014
description: March 9, 2014

title: Credit Suisse Documents Point to Mortgage Lapses
description: The email from a Credit Suisse executive was blunt: The bank seemed to be pushing through risky home mortgages from questionable applicants.

title: Louisville Confronts Elephant in Its Room
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  For all the strides the Louisville women have made in becoming a perennial basketball power, the climb to the top remains daunting. Connecticut, the Cardinals opponent in the final of the American Athletic Conference tournament Monday night, has won 14 straight against them.

title: Chinas Disturbing Defense Budget
description: China is causing new anxieties in Asia with a defense budget for 2014 that totals $132 billion, up 12.2 percent over the previous year. These numbers should not be used as an excuse to ratchet up Americas military spending. But they do raise legitimate concerns about Chinas motives that Beijing should seek to dispel, especially at a time when regional tensions are rising.

title: An Expensive and Unnecessary Election
description: New York State is poised to put voters through another needlessly expensive election year. Instead of taking the sensible route  one primary to pick party candidates and one general election to pick ultimate winners  New York is scheduled to have an extra primary. That means three elections when two are enough. The extra primary will cost state taxpayers $50 million for their trouble.

title: Good Steps Against Unpaid Internships
description: The National Association of Colleges and Employers reported last year that nearly half of the internships taken by college students in the class of 2013 were unpaid. Many of these arrangements (often temporary, low-level jobs with dubious educational merit) may violate federal labor guidelines, which say that unpaid internships at for-profit companies must be for the benefit of the intern and that the employer may not derive an immediate advantage from the activities of the intern. Yet colleges, through their career sites, frequently end up promoting internships that disregard these guidelines.

title: A Sentencing Commission for California
description: Twenty years ago, California voters overwhelmingly passed the three strikes law that has come to symbolize Americas deeply irrational and misguided obsession with harsh and inflexible sentencing. It set a life sentence for anyone with a third felony conviction, no matter how minor or nonviolent  even for stealing a pair of socks.

title: Emails Show Shared Concern of False Testimony in Army Sexual Assault Case
description: Lawyers defending Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on sexual assault charges are renewing claims that the case against him has been tainted by the influence of senior officials in the Pentagon, citing emails that military prosecutors turned over during the weekend.

title: Mexican Drug Lord, Thought Dead in 2010, Is Reported Killed
description: MEXICO CITY  In the annals of the Mexican criminal underworld, the son of a powerful drug lord was announced captured and paraded before cameras only for the authorities to later discover they had the wrong guy. Another gang leader was killed, but then associates stole the body. On Sunday, a kingpin presumed dead for more than three years reappeared in the news, to be declared really dead this time.

title: Deconstructing God
description: This is the third in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is John D. Caputo, a professor of religion and humanities at Syracuse University and the author of The Prayers and Tears of Jacques Derrida: Religion Without Religion.

title: What a Way to Make a Living
In a Native American Sport, a Familys Giant Leap
description: ALBANY  The Albany lacrosse coaches stared at a small projector screen, searching for the black streak of a three-foot-long ponytail swooping toward the goal.

title: Jackson Mourns Mayor With Militant Past Who Won Over Skeptics
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Many people here still do not entirely know what to make of the mayor with the unusual name and even more unexpected rsum, who proudly embraced the term militant and to many was still the same dashiki-wearing firebrand who first came to prominence advocating an independent black nation in the South in the early 1970s.

title: Dressed Like Woods, but With Better-Looking Swing, Reed Wins at Doral
description: DORAL, Fla.  From his first shot on the practice range to his final stroke in a par 72, the man in red and black was dialed in Sunday at the World Golf Championships at Trump National Doral. Patrick Reed had decided to adopt Tiger Woodss signature Sunday outfit after he took his first 54-hole lead in a PGA Tour event, at last years Wyndham Championship.

title: Renters Hope for Promised Freeze as de Blasio Prepares to Fill Guidelines Board
description: For years, tenants have complained that the city board that sets rents for about one million New York apartments has favored landlords.

title: New York Public Radio Receives Grant for $10 Million
description: New York Public Radio will announce on Monday that it has received a $10 million grant from the Jerome L. Greene Foundation, which it says is the largest single gift ever made to a public radio station.

title: Nets Shrug Off More Injuries to Rise Above .500 Again
description: The Nets bounced back from an unsightly loss with a 104-89 win over the Sacramento Kings at Barclays Center on Sunday, but they lost forwards Paul Pierce and Andrei Kirilenko to injuries in the process, raising more concerns about the health of some of their veterans as the regular season enters its final stretch.

title: Lessons From Fukushima
description: Three years after a meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant, the crisis is still unfolding. In the United States, the disaster served as a warning to the nuclear industry.

title: After Fukushima, Utilities Prepare for Worst
description: PEACH BOTTOM, Pa.  Stored near the twin nuclear reactors here, safely above the flood level of the Susquehanna River, is a gleaming new six-wheel pickup truck with a metal blade on the front that can plow away debris from an earthquake or other disaster. Attached to the back is a trailer that carries a giant diesel-powered pump that can deliver 500 gallons of water a minute.

title: Game With No Winner Ends in Shared Title
description: CLEVELAND  As each overtime gave way to the next, the expectation for a thrilling and historic conclusion multiplied during the Ohio high school hockey state championship Saturday night in Columbus.

title: Now Comes Hard Part for G.M.: The Repairs
description: Less than a month after General Motors announced it would recall 1.6 million cars because of a defective ignition switch, the automaker now faces an arduous task: fixing the cars.

title: 2 Star-Crossed Afghans Cling to Love, Even at Risk of Death
description: BAMIAN, Afghanistan  She is his Juliet and he is her Romeo, and her family has threatened to kill them both.

title: Video Notebook: A Young Man in Love
description: Mohammad Ali, 21, fears for his life after publicly declaring his love for Zakia, 18.

title: China Warns of Risks in Plan to Retire Windows XP
description: Microsofts plans to retire its Windows XP operating system have raised concerns in China, which has been slow to upgrade its computers.

title: Manhattan Community Papers Revamped Under New Editor
description: Kyle Pope once shared in a Pulitzer Prize at The Wall Street Journal and served as the top editor of The New York Observer. So when he recently took a job running five small community newspapers in Manhattan, it raised eyebrows in New Yorks gossipy and insular media world.

title: In the Details of Passengers Lives, Signs of Hope and Prosperity
description: BEIJING  It was one of his first trips abroad, maybe even the first. Wang Moheng was just shy of his second birthday. His parents took him and two of his grandparents to the tropics of Malaysia, with its sunshine and moist air and blue skies.

title: Dreams of a More Streamlined Car-Buying Process, With Technology as Facilitator
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  For generations, the auto dealer has been the primary avenue for carmakers to sell vehicles to consumers.

title: The Intrepid Paralympic Racers on Their Skiing Machines
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  Heath Calhoun was disappointed by how he fared in his ski race at the Paralympic Games on Sunday. He was hoping to win a medal. He was expecting to win a medal. He did not. He came in fourth. He was not satisfied, but in one way he was, because he crossed the finish line.

title: Medals, With Little Guidance
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  It was difficult to determine the greater accomplishment Sunday: that Mark Bathum and Mac Marcoux won silver and bronze in their visually impaired super-G race at the Paralympic Games, or that they made it safely down the course at all.

title: Warm Weather Brings Out Banned Vehicles, and Officers Pounce
description: Legions of dirt bikes and all-terrain vehicles descended on Upper Manhattan over the weekend, their engines howling on bridges to and from the Bronx and echoing through the residential corridors of Harlem.

title: El Salvadors Presidential Election Close at the Wire
description: MEXICO CITY  El Salvadors presidential race ended in a razor-close finish Sunday, a surprising turn after opinion polls had given the governing partys candidate, Salvador Snchez Cern, a double-digit lead.

title: Euro Bank Rules and a Fed Confirmation Hearing
description: CONSIDERING EURO BANK RULES

title: A Secret, Sparkling World
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Herbalife War
description: A look at the war waged by William A. Ackman against Herbalife, and the few hints of the effort by the company to fight back.

title: Chinas Tencent to Buy Stake in JD.com as Part of E-Commerce Push
description: HONG KONG  Last century, it was Microsoft versus Apple. A decade ago, it was Google against Yahoo.

title: House Republicans Balk at Wording in Obama Emergency Aid Package for Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  An emergency aid package for the beleaguered Ukrainian government has become entangled in a partisan dispute over the International Monetary Fund, with House Republicans resisting President Obamas personal pleas to extend the reach of a Ukraine rescue plan by including long-sought changes to the funds structure.

title: McMartin Preschool: Anatomy of a Panic
description: In 1984, news reports that hundreds of children had been abused at a California preschool helped spread panic across the nation. But the case was not all it seemed and its impact continues to be felt.

title: Spaldings Australian Baseball Tour
description: Some 125 years ago, in October 1888, Albert Spalding, a former player and part owner of the Chicago White Stockings arranged for two teams to embark on a round-the-world tour.

title: Ex-President Wins a Seat in Colombia
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Voters in Colombia on Sunday elected former President lvaro Uribe to the Senate, increasing the influence of one of the most vocal critics of peace negotiations between the government and the countrys main guerrilla group.

title: The Trial That Unleashed Hysteria Over Child Abuse
description: Early in the 19th century, two unmarried women who ran a school for girls in Edinburgh found themselves accused by a student of being lesbians. The charge, quite grave in that era, was baseless, and in time the women won a libel suit. But not before they had lost everything, including their school. If this story rings a bell, it may be because Lillian Hellman used it as a starting point for The Childrens Hour, her 1934 play about a couple of schoolteachers whose lives similarly come unraveled after a malicious student falsely accuses them of lesbianism.

title: Australia, Baseballs Diamond in Rough
description: When Albert Spalding arranged a world tour for his Chicago White Stockings and a team of all-stars that included stops in Australia in December 1888, the baseball writer Henry Chadwick hailed it as the great event in the modern history of athletic sports.

title: 6-Foot-8 Pitcher Finds New Role in Comeback
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Headlines do not come looking for Dellin Betances anymore. Not as they did two years ago, when there was so much to like and so much to write about.

title: Girls Recap: Hannah Tries on a  Wig, Lingerie and Campy Dialogue
description: Girls has been touted for mirroring the socio-sexual landscape twenty-somethings navigate these days: porn-influenced liaisons, bleak job prospects, millennial entitlement.

title: Jack Belliveau, Explorer of the Brain Using M.R.I., Dies at 55
description: Jack Belliveau, a Harvard scientist whose quest to capture the quicksilver flare of thought inside a living brain led to the first magnetic resonance image of human brain function, died on Feb. 14 in San Mateo, Calif. He was 55.

title: Little Choice but to Hope Tejada Can Handle Job
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Perhaps no Met has been scrutinized more during this years spring training than Ruben Tejada.

title: A Kiev Question: What Became of the Missing?
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Volodymyr Danyluk was a Soviet Army veteran who joined demonstrations against Ukraines government last year. He was 55 years old, separated from his wife and mostly out of contact with his family, who saw him on live television during a winter of protests.

title: N.C.A.A. Mens Conference Tournament Previews
description: With Selection Sunday right around the corner, here is a look at some of the top story lines at this weeks conference tournaments and who should be moving on to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Fears of Impending Change Darken Normally Lighthearted Odessa
description: ODESSA, Ukraine  In a joke making the rounds in this city famous for its humor, wry and dark at the best of times, two condemned prisoners are talking on death row. One suggests they try to run away, but the other says, No, that will only make things worse.

title: After Big Bet, Hedge Fund Pulls the Levers of Power
description: WASHINGTON  At a Midtown Manhattan steakhouse last June, William A. Ackman, the activist hedge fund manager who had bet a billion dollars on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, offered his latest evidence to a handful of other hedge fund managers about why the companys stock could soon plummet.

title: Orthodox New York City Jews Protest Proposed Israeli Draft
description: Tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews gathered in Lower Manhattan on Sunday to protest Israels proposal to include strictly religious citizens in its military draft.

title: New Movie Studio Is Formed, With China and Self-Distribution in Mind
description: Several years ago, the Hollywood producer Robert Simonds Jr. began thinking about how a movie studio for todays age  with the ascendance of China and a dizzying array of distribution channels  should look.

title: Use of Public Transit in U.S. Reaches Highest Level Since 1956, Advocates Report
description: PHILADELPHIA  More Americans used buses, trains and subways in 2013 than in any year since 1956 as service improved, local economies grew and travelers increasingly sought alternatives to the automobile for trips within metropolitan areas, the American Public Transportation Association said in a report released on Monday.

title: Letter From Linda Snchez
description: Representative Linda T. Snchez, Democrat of California, sent a letter to the F.T.C. asking it to investigate Herbalife. Mr. Ackman obtained a copy of the letter before it was made public.

title: Five Nearly Identical Letters
description: Five people in Connecticut sent letters with very similar language urging the Federal Trade Commission to open an investigation into Herbalife.

title: A Grassroots Video, With Help From a Billionaire
description: Make the Road New York, a nonprofit advocacy group for Latinos, promoted this video showing people who said they were hurt by Herbalife.

title: A Senators Letter, and a Stocks Fall
description: On Jan. 23, Senator Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts sent letters asking the F.T.C. and S.E.C. to look into Herbalife. The letters were based at least in part on research that William A. Ackmans firm provided. Herbalife stock fell by 14 percent.

title: A Ski Race With Horsepower
description: When the tans and browns of the cowboy intermingle with the neon and pastel of the powder hound, it signals the start of the self-proclaimed world skijoring championships in Whitefish, Mont. One finds glory in the dirt, and the other bravery in the snow. For two days in January, they unite as a team of horse, rider and skier to prove who is fastest.

title: Seeking a Killer and a Benign Universe
description: As is so often the case on crime shows, the two partners in True Detective followed a hunch and went straight into the killers lair on their own, without backup. They had each others backs.

title: Photo Replay: March 2-8
description: This weeks criteria: simply beautiful, as in elegant compositions, extraordinary light, singular moments.

title: Popular Demand
description: Facebook usage remained constant at 58 percent from 2013 to 2014, while Instagram grew from 12 to 19 percent overall. Snapchat surged 10 points to 13 percent penetration, and is used by 46 percent of younger users.

title: Nigerians Ask Why Oil Funds Are Missing
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Even in a country where untold oil wealth disappears into the pockets of the elite, the oil corruption scheme he was investigating seemed outsize  and he threatened to lay it bare at a meeting with Nigerias top bankers.

title: Times Minute | Details for Flight MH370
description: Also on the Minute, Edward J. Snowden is set to make an appearance at SXSW, and three relatives dominate in college lacrosse.

title: BlackRock Hires New Head of China Equities
description: HONG KONG  BlackRock, the worlds largest asset-management company, said on Monday that it had hired Helen Zhu as a managing director and head of its China equities business.

title: Corrections: March 10, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: Night of Song, Delivered With Passion and Heart
description: After finishing his recital at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday evening, the tenor Vittorio Grigolo sank to one knee while acknowledging the applause, then tossed his handkerchief into the audience. Im crying inside, he said from the stage, adding, I am trying to give you all of my heart.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 10 P.M. (NBC) BELIEVE Alfonso Cuarn, who just won the Oscar for best director for Gravity, created this faith-based series, which counts J. J. Abrams among its executive producers. The story follows Bo (Johnny Sequoyah, above), a lovely 10-year-old girl with Christlike powers and a cult following of adults, led by Milton Winter (Delroy Lindo) and a wrongfully imprisoned death-row convict named Tate (Jake McLaughlin), intent on protecting her from those  among them, the tycoon Skouras (Kyle MacLachlan)  who would use her talents for evil. Mr. Cuarn directed the pilot, and the opening scene, a car crash shot from the passengers point of view, is genuinely shocking, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. But the characters dont live up to the swirling, often violent action that surrounds them.

title: The Red Faces of the Solar Skeptics
description: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Word of the Day | untenable
description: untenable \n-te-n-bl\ adjective

title: Lifes Guarantees: Death, Taxes and 7.5% Chinese G.D.P. Growth
description: Few things in life are guaranteed, but a researcher at Chinas powerful economic planning agency says one thing is assured: 7.5 percent growth this year.

title: Cleanest Village Questions Its Blessings Amid Influx of Visitors
description: MAWLYNNONG, India  Anshuman Sen was barely a year out of college when, in 2005, he traveled to Meghalaya, a hilly northeastern state distant both in miles and cultural resemblance from what the locals call mainland India.

title: Managing the Discussion of the Missing Malaysian Jet
description: As frustration and anger deepened in China over the unexplained disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 with 239, mostly Chinese, people on board, the Chinese government sought on Monday to balance a swirl of imperatives:

title: 6 Qs About the News | Airplane Goes Missing in Malaysia
description: In Passport Theft Adds to Mystery of Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet, Thomas Fuller and Eric Schmitt write about a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared en-route to Beijing on Saturday morning. In Search for Jet Yielding Only More Mystery, Thomas Fuller writes about the subsequent search efforts.

title: Japan Wont Alter Apology to World War II Sex Slaves
description: TOKYO  Japan will not revise a landmark apology to women forced to work in military brothels during World War II even as it moves ahead with a review of the testimony used to create that apology, a spokesman for the Japanese government said Monday.

title: How Much Time Do You Spend Outdoors?
description: With spring just around the corner, people will soon be spending more time outdoors.

title: Chiquita Buys Irelands Fyffes to Go Global in Banana Business
description: Updated, 8:39 p.m. | The banana is the king of fruit, outselling apples, oranges and all the rest. And now the king of bananas will be Chiquita Brands International.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, March 10, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: Unilever Acquires Majority Stake in Chinese Water-Purification Company
description: LONDON  The British-Dutch consumer goods giant Unilever said Monday that it had acquired a majority stake in the Chinese water purification companyQinyuan Group, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Life and Happiness in Siberias Cold
description: For outsiders, Siberia evokes images of harsh winters, political exile and a lone railway that winds through the mysterious landscape. But as Anton Chekhov once said, Even in Siberia, there is happiness.

title: Ackman vs. Herbalife, a History
description: William A. Ackmans giant financial bet against Herbalife is being played out in the corridors of government, Michael S. Schmidt, Eric Lipton and Alexandra Stevenson report in The New York Times. The reporters found that Mr. Ackmans team had organized protests, news conferences and letter-writing campaigns in California, Nevada, Connecticut, New York and Illinois, and several of the people who signed the letters to state and federal officials say they do not remember sending them.

title: GlaxoSmithKline Increases Stake in Indian Pharmaceutical Unit
description: LONDON  GlaxoSmithKline said on Monday that it had increased its stake in its Indian pharmaceutical subsidiary to 75 percent, in a transaction valued at more than $1 billion.

title: Left Hand Among Bones
description: BUENOS AIRES  In the end it was his fathers left hand, found a couple of years ago in a pile of charred bones outside La Plata, that enabled Gonzalo Reggiardo Tolosa to know for a fact the man he never knew was dead. This was physical knowledge, different from the almost-certain supposition with which he had lived ever since he discovered as a boy in the late 1980s that the couple who raised him and his twin brother Matas were not his parents.

title: 10 Words Entrepreneurs Should Use With Caution
description: Recently, I did a workshop with some young entrepreneurs  mostly, I would say, between 24 and 38  and I soon realized that in this new and enlightened age, every conversation about entrepreneurship seems to include the same 10 words, words that have become a new jargon. At the same time, one very important but old-fashioned word seems to have been all but forgotten.

title: Visualizing the Dynamics of the Labor Market
description: Since the end of the recession in 2009 and through the long stop-and-go recovery, the labor market has emerged as one of the most closely watched, not to mention worrying, parts of the economy.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | March 10, 2014
description: Update: March 11

title: Reckitt Benckiser Buys K-Y Lubricants Brand From Johnson & Johnson
description: LONDON  The British consumer goods company Reckitt Benckiser said on Monday that it had acquired the rights to the K-Y brand of personal lubricants from Johnson & Johnson.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft Pins Hopes for Xbox One on Titanfall
description: A video game that depicts a battle between corporate mercenaries and local brigands in far-off space colonies has already won the hearts and minds of Microsoft executives. Now those Microsoft bosses hope the game, Titanfall, will win over enough consumers to pump up sales of Xbox One, the companys flagship gaming console. Xbox One sales are trailing those of a machine from Sony, Microsofts main rival, Nick Wingfield reports.

title: HGGC to Buy Serena Software From Silver Lake
description: After eight years, Serena Software has found a new home.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Todd Balf on the Coming Changes to the SAT
description: Todd Balf wrote this weeks cover story on the College Boards decision to overhaul the SAT. Balf is the author of several books, including Major, the story of Marshall Taylor, one of the first African-American athletes to become internationally famous.

title: New York Today: Spending Those Daylight Savings
description: Good Monday morning to you.

title: Live Reporting on Autopsy Banned at Pistorius Trial
description: Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, vomited repeatedly in the courtroom on Monday as a pathologist gave graphic evidence about her injuries. News coverage of the testimony was restricted by a sweeping ban on live broadcasting or reporting on Twitter.

title: Ackmans Battle to Bring Down Herbalife
description: After staking $1 billion on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, William A. Ackmans activist hedge fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, has been lobbying aggressively to bring it down, Michael S. Schmidt, Eric Lipton and Alexandra Stevenson write in The New York Times. Others have criticized the business practices of Herbalife, which sells vitamins and other supplements through independent distributors, but Mr. Ackmans attack is unprecedented in its scale, they write. For its part, Herbalife continues to strongly deny his accusations that the company is a pyramid scheme.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Bailey Lauerman, Omaha, was chosen to handle four accounts. The new clients are the Branson/Lakes Area Convention and Visitors Bureau, Branson, Mo.; IMG Academy, Bradenton, Fla.; the Mutual Fund Store, Overland Park, Kan.; and Panda Express, Rosemead, Calif. Billings were not disclosed.

title: FMC to Split Up by Spinning Off Its Minerals Division
description: The FMC Corporation, a chemical maker, said on Monday that it planned to divide itself in two by spinning off its minerals business.

title: Jon Favreau on Chef
description: The actor and director discusses his film about a popular chef who reaches a turning point in his life.

title: Frustration Over Malaysian Flight Turns to Anger
description: BEIJING  It was not an easy meeting. The four Malaysia Airlines employees stood with their hands by their sides at the front of a stuffy room in a Beijing hotel on Monday morning, delivering yet more unwelcome news about the missing Flight MH370, and dodging water bottles hurled by irate listeners.

title: In Latest Metro-North Accident, Worker Is Fatally Struck by Train in East Harlem
description: A Metro-North Railroad worker was struck and killed by a train in East Harlem early Monday morning, officials said, the latest in a string of devastating accidents for the railroad over the past year.

title: Boston Plans to Tighten Security at Marathon
