description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass.  Over the long, cold winter, Boston has been preparing a ceremony to honor those killed and injured in the bombings at last years marathon and to stage a race this year that will be one of the biggest  and, they said Monday, the safest.

title: From Icahn, a Wall Street Billionaires Version of Monopoly
description: The boardroom battles waged by the activist investor Carl C. Icahn have drawn comparisons to poker. But Mr. Icahn apparently prefers to think of his career in terms of a different game: Monopoly.

title: Video: Jon Favreau on Chef at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  With his latest film Chef, the actor and filmmaker Jon Favreau takes a break from directing large-scale Hollywood films to tell the more intimate story of a popular chef at a crossroads in his life. The movie, which includes a segment shot here, opened the South by Southwest film festival on Friday. In this video interview, conducted at QUI restaurant, Mr. Favreau discusses the food-related films that inspired him and the hands-on training he received from the chef Roy Choi. Chef is set to open nationwide May 9.

title: First Charges Filed in $30 Billion Coal Scandal
description: Indias central investigating agency on Monday filed its first formal charges in a $30 billion coal mining scandal in which the government allotted the rights to develop coal blocks to private companies at negotiated prices rather than in an auction.

title: Russias Grip Tightens With Shows of Force at Ukrainian Bases
description: CHORNOMORSKOYE, Ukraine  Russian forces raided a Ukrainian naval missile base here in the darkness of early Monday, scaling its outer walls and outmatching the surprised sailors inside without firing a shot, according to the Ukrainian Ministry of Defense and people familiar with the raid.

title: EBay Rejects Icahns Nominees for Its Board
description: The weekslong battle of words between eBay and Carl C. Icahn has heated up.

title: Rolled Oats With Amaranth Seeds, Maple Syrup and Apple
description: Grated apple adds a fresh, zesty dimension to just about any bowl of hot (or cold) cereal. The little amaranth seeds contribute protein, lysine and calcium to this mix. They will soften overnight, but they retain texture, which is one of the things I like about the combo.

title: Steel-Cut Oats With Amaranth Seeds, Chia Seeds and Blueberries
description: Fresh blueberries are not in season at the moment, so I put my frozen organic wild blueberries to good use in this hearty mix. The chia and the amaranth pump up the nutritional value of this cereal  both are high in calcium, amaranth is high in protein, and chia seeds are a great source of healthful omega-3s. They also contribute texture. For even more great texture, top the cereal with chopped toasted hazelnuts or almonds.

title: Oatmeal and Teff With Cinnamon and Dried Fruit
description: I wanted to make a porridge with teff alone, but I just didnt like the flavor enough. So I added some of those tiny high-protein, high-calcium, gluten-free seeds to oatmeal, along with chopped dried apricots, golden raisins and cinnamon. Chopped toasted hazelnuts are my first choice for topping.

title: Sweet Oven-Baked Grits and Millet With Pecans and Maple Syrup
description: This is one of the two longer-cooking breakfast grain dishes this week. It takes about 1 hour 10 minutes in the oven, so it might be more practical for a weekend breakfast. Grits are much like polenta, and traditionally served as a savory dish, often with cheese added. Here I mixed the grits with the higher-protein millet, and liked the texture of the mix as well as the nuttier flavor. I warmed leftovers in my toaster oven and enjoyed this throughout the week.

title: Breakfast Wheat Berries
description: Wheat berries sweetened with honey and perfumed with rose water and spices make a delicious breakfast on their own or stirred into yogurt (thats the way I prefer to serve this). Whether you use farro, kamut, spelt or wheat berries (and whether you are cooking them for breakfast or for dinner) the trick here is to cook the grains for as long as it takes for them to really soften and to splay (that is, to burst at one end).

title: How Aid to the Poor Is Also an Investment
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: In Our Pages: March 11
description: 1914: Blurred E Sets Slander Charge

title: 4 Accused in Law Firm Fraud
description: Several former leaders of the once-high-flying law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf apparently violated a cardinal rule that lawyers always tell their clients: Dont put anything incriminating into an email.

title: Art Matters | San Juans New Wave
description: If the annual art fairs that zigzag through New York, London, Paris and Hong Kong are now on the verge of being greeted with a collective Champagne-soaked yawn, San Juan has emerged as a breath of fresh tropical air. Despite Puerto Ricos current economic crisis, a handful of boundary-pushing exhibition spaces are thriving, such as Espacio 1414, housed in a former Royal Tire warehouse; Roberto Paradise Gallery, which is showing the work of the painter Jos Lerma through April 5; and Galera Agustina Ferreyra, which operates out of a garage. Art goes beyond geography, Ferreyra says. The minute we start thinking about geography, we close each other off.

title: 24-Hour Rebrand Helps Twin Cities Nonprofits
description: A Minneapolis agency that specializes in health care advertising is offering a new perspective on creating pro bono work for nonprofit organizations with an effort that combines elements of all-nighters, hackathons, sleepovers and team-building exercises.

title: Do Times Journalists Pay Attention to Readers Comments?
description: I was struck recently by a statement from Glenn Greenwald, writing about his new venture, First Look Media, in which he said that reader comments are a vital form of accountability.

title: Inside Wired Well
description: From fitness trackers to pet spy cams to judgmental forks, five reporters from our special gadgets for health issue talk about how they got wired.

title: Minerals Technologies Wins Bidding War for Amcol International
description: LONDON  Minerals Technologies said on Monday that it had won a bidding war for Amcol International, agreeing to pay about $1.7 billion.

title: False Leads Set Back Search for Malaysian Jet
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  The mystery of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 deepened on Monday when a sweeping search failed to find any sign of the jetliner near its last known location, leaving experts to puzzle over how a Boeing 777 with 239 people aboard could have vanished without a trace.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: A Dot on the Map, After Scandal, Could Be Wiped Off
description: HAMPTON, Fla.  Its easy for motorists driving down busy Route 301 to miss this speck of a city in rural north-central Florida: Fiddle with the car radio, unwrap a pack of gum, gaze out the window at the sunset and, whoosh, its gone.

title: Counting Syrias Dead
description: My home in Aleppo is on a quiet cul-de-sac that ends against a large piece of land which, for as long as I can remember, has been a rocky wasteland of patchy yellow shrubs dotted with dirty plastic bags on a ground of dust mixed with broken glass. This triangular plot between residential neighborhoods was zoned to be a park for decades. Like most of Syria, it never reached its promised potential. Last week, I heard that people finally found a use for the wasteland  they have begun to bury Aleppos dead in it.

title: Today in Small Business: The Stars of Vine
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Remembering the Preschool Trial That Launched an Era of Hysteria
description: In 1984, news reports that hundreds of children had been abused at a California preschool helped spread panic across the nation. Despite a lack of convictions and the outlandish nature of some accusations (really now, teachers chopped up animals, clubbed a horse to death with a baseball bat, sacrificed a baby in a church and made children drink the blood, dressed up as witches and flew in the air?), the impact of the case continues to be felt. Read more.

title: In Annual Letter, G.E. Chief Extols Simplification
description: General Electric, a century-old industrial company, is taking its cues from the young technology firms of Silicon Valley.

title: The Challenge of Linking Deweys Leader to Possible Accounting Shenanigans
description: Criminal charges filed by New York prosecutors against Steven H. Davis, former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf, describe actions that sound quite similar to the events that led to the collapse of Enron and WorldCom a decade ago. And, as with those earlier cases, the challenge for the government will be finding enough evidence to link the law firms head to accusations that accounting tricks were used to cover up a deteriorating financial position.

title: Now Boarding: Amtrak Writers Residency
description: The wheels have begun moving on Amtraks plan to offer writers a rolling residency aboard their trains. On Monday the company announced that up to 24 writers, chosen from a pool of applicants, will be given a round-trip ticket on a long-distance train, including a private sleeper-car room with a bed, a desk, and electrical outlets. The trains promise the romance. The writers will have to do the rest.

title: Authorities Give Update on Search
description: At a news conference, Malaysian authorities give an update on possible debris fields.

title: Snowden Tries to Rally Tech Conference to Buttress Privacy Shields
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Edward J. Snowden wants the technology industry to get serious about protecting the privacy of its users and customers.

title: Kerry Orders U.S. Diplomats to Press Case for Climate Action
description: Over the weekend, ahead of a round of low-level climate treaty talks that kicked off today in Bonn, Germany, Secretary of State John Kerry sent a fresh signal that he plans to keep global warming at the top of the State Departments agenda.

title: Times Minute | Searching for MH370
description: Also on the Minute, a generational power divide among Republicans, and the season finale of HBO's "True Detective."

title: Statement From Gary Melius
description: In a video released Monday, Gary Melius thanked his supporters.

title: Snap Sketch | Shala Monroque, Anna Dello Russo and the Faces of Paris Fashion Week
description: The illustrator Damien Florbert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around Paris.

title: Times Minute | Searching for MH370
description: In the Video

title: Long Island Developers Statement on Shooting Is Short on Detail
description: Gary Melius, a prominent real estate developer who was shot in the head outside his opulent Long Island estate last month, said that he had much to say about what happened  but not yet.

title: Image of the Day: March 10
Avoiding Lucky Fool Syndrome
description: Watching the Olympics a few weeks ago, I got pulled in to the drama of short-track skating. It has to be one of the more entertaining Olympic events. The races are fast, and almost anything can happen. If you had a chance to watch the womens 500-meter final, you saw a perfect example of the fine line between skill and luck that drives this sport.

title: At a Luxury Building on the Upper West Side, the Perks Start at the Curb
description: Fifteen Central Park West, home to celebrities and billionaires and an it address of the moment, has a long list of perks. There is the 75-foot sky-lit lap pool, the climate-controlled wine cellar and, for those desiring anything from a four-course custom menu for 80 guests to an at-home romantic dinner for two, the in-house chef.

title: Faulting Army, Judge Puts Off Assault Case
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  The military judge overseeing the court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on sexual assault charges brought the trial to a halt on Monday, suggesting that a senior Army official may have been improperly influenced by political considerations in his handling of the case.

title: The Pi Machine
description: This coming Friday, 3.14 is Pi Day. Lets celebrate maths favorite number with a remarkable puzzle suggested several years ago by Alon Amit of Origami Logic. Dr. Amit and I were sitting on a couch in the old Palo Alto Facebook headquarters (Dr. Amit was working there at the time) surrounded by frenzy (the film The Social Network had just been released) when he told me something amazing: someone had recently figured out a completely original way to calculate pi. It was also a remarkably simple method, requiring just two balls and a wall. With these you have a pi machine.

title: When Local Politics Have Global Consequences
description: Colorful deserts, lush mountains, views that go for 150 miles, star-filled skies and beautiful sunsets are all reasons that I call Arizona home. The politics of my state are the reason I sometimes tell people Im from somewhere else.

title: Smithsonian Names David Skorton as Its New Director
description: The Smithsonian Institution announced on Monday that it had chosen David J. Skorton, a doctor and university president with a reputation as an energetic fund-raiser and forceful advocate of the arts and humanities as its new leader.

title: Gun-Toting David Does Not Amuse Italian Culture Officials
description: ROME  Italian culture officials are furious over a gunmakers unauthorized use of the image of Michelangelos statue of David to promote a bolt-action rifle and are demanding that the company immediately drop its campaign  but it turns out the company already has.

title: A Ski Pass for the States  and Japan
description: Vail Resorts already offers holders of its season Epic Pass access to all 10 resorts it operates primarily in Colorado, Utah and the Lake Tahoe region. Next year the pass will include ski days in a more distant locale: Japan.

title: Apple Releases First Big Software Update for iOS 7
description: Updated | Added background and analysis on iOS 7.

title: Tense Moments in de Blasios TV Interview
description: Bruised by a controversy over New York City charter schools and seeking to regain momentum on a stalled tax proposal, Mayor Bill de Blasio took to national television on Monday to argue his case for his administrations top policy priorities.

title: Boldly Upsetting the Field, and the Establishment
description: DORAL, Fla.  The generation gap in golf has never been more pronounced, and not because the average age of the last three winners on the PGA Tour is 24.3 years. Years from now, we might look at the derring-do shown by 24-year-old Russell Henley at the Honda Classic last week and 23-year-old Patrick Reed at the World Golf Championships event Sunday as the beginning of the brash brothers era on the PGA Tour.

title: Deciding if Inmates Get to Know How Theyll Be Executed
description: WASHINGTON  The capital justice system is in turmoil, with drug shortages leading states to use secret and suspect chemicals to execute condemned inmates.

title: Thai Peanut Sauce Marries Well With Shrimp and Pineapple
Sandy Hook Gunmans Father Says He Wishes His Son Had Never Been Born
description: Peter Lanza had not seen his son Adam for two years before the day Adam walked into Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., and murdered 20 schoolchildren and six adults.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 94
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Jordanian Judge Killed by Israeli Soldiers at Border Crossing
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli soldiers on Monday fatally shot a Jordanian judge of Palestinian origin at the Allenby Bridge after the man tried to seize a soldiers gun and then threatened two soldiers with a metal bar, according to the Israeli military.

title: A New Website Dedicated to Lorraine Hansberry
description: Lorraine Hansberry has never really left the spotlight. Her work is widely taught and her most famous play, A Raisin in the Sun, is back on Broadway for its second revival. Now her estate has created the Lorraine Hansberry Literary Trust, a virtual space that will offer all things Hansberry and showcase her as a writer, public intellectual and civil rights activist. The site, lorrainehansberryliterarytrust.org, is scheduled to go live on April 1, Joi Gresham, the director and co-trustee of Hansberrys literary trust said Monday.

title: The Rate-Hikers Guide to the Economy
description: The big headline on the front page of todays FT  at least in the U.S. edition  goes to this report about the Bank for International Settlements. According to the article, the BIS is warning that forward guidance  the attempt to drive long-term interest rates down by promising to keep short-term rates low for a long time  could endanger the international financial system. So I thought, typical BIS  the gnomes of Basel have been consistently against anything that might restore full employment, have been into punishment all the way. And I got ready to write a BIS-bashing post.

title: British Fret About Anemic Results in Champions League
description: A year ago, there was continual consternation among a large cross-section of English soccer fans. For the first time since 1996, no English teams had advanced past the Round of 16 in the European Champions League, a reality that irritated and embarrassed the countrys passionate followers. Probing questions were asked. Strong opinions were offered.

title: In Store | Cozy Baby Separates Designed by a Rick Owens Alum
description: Among the striking array of nonmodels in Rick Owenss recent fall/winter show  an ode to his extended creative family  was the designer Asha Mines. In the decade since Owens tapped the California Institute of the Arts graduate and prolific seamstress to be his design assistant, Miness career has been closely intertwined with that of her mentor. After seven years of working full-time in his studio, Mines went on to help produce his shows and photography; it was she who tracked down the step teams that famously stomped the brands spring/summer looks down the runway.

title: Titans in Russia Fear New Front in Ukraine Crisis
description: MOSCOW  When Vladimir V. Putin returned to the Russian presidency in 2012, one of the first messages he sent to his political elite, many of them heads of banks and large corporations, was that the times had changed: Owning assets outside Russia makes you too vulnerable to moves by foreign governments, he told them. It is time to bring your wealth home.

title: Rivals Split May Cast a Shadow on Dow
description: Andrew N. Liveris, the head of Dow Chemical, may find it harder to keep his company together now that a smaller rival is planning to break up. Mr. Liveris has resisted the campaign by the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb to split Dow, a $60 billion company, into separate petro- and specialty chemicals groups.

title: Weekly News Quiz | March 4-10, 2014
description: A new SAT, the Paralympics, daylight saving time and more: How many of these 10 questions about recent news can you answer?

title: Discussion About Bright Lights, Big City With Gary Shteyngart
description: 9:35 p.m. | Updated Thanks to all who joined the discussion tonight and special thinks to our co-host Gary Shteyngart. Weve concluded the live conversation but feel free to leave more thoughts and comments here during the week.

title: The Failure of True Detective
description: The fact that the internet is full of defenses(or at least quasi-defenses) of the True Detective finale today is a testament to the shows genuinely extraordinary qualities direction, acting, atmosphere, and (sometimes) writing.But Im afraid itsalso a testament to the human will to believe, often in defiance of the evidence, and reading the various apologia for the way the detective drama finished up Im inclined to channel the shows nihilist-heros harsh words about religion: You gotta get together and tell yourself stories that violate every law of the universe just to get through the [expletive] day? Whats that say about your reality?

title: Behind the Poster: A Small Fire
description: In Adam Bocks play A Small Fire, a womans life unravels after she contracts a mysterious disease that slowly causes her to lose all of her senses except touch. A fire breaks out in her kitchen, but she doesnt realize it, unaware that her sense of smell has disappeared.

title: KJ DellAntonia on Motherlode
description: Motherlode is a destination for information and conversation affecting families. http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/

title: Senate Democrats All-Nighter Flags Climate Change
description: WASHINGTON  In the summer of 2010, it was Harry Reid, the Senates Democratic leader, who squelched his partys efforts to pass a climate change bill, declaring it could never attract enough votes to pass. In the years since, he has rarely spoken publicly about the issue.

title: Monday Motorsports: Keselowskis Excellent Vegas Weekend
description: Brad Keselowski passed leader Dale Earnhardt Jr.  who ran out of fuel on the final lap  and took the checkered flag in the Nascar Sprint Cup race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway on Sunday. The victory completed a perfect weekend for Keselowski, who had also won the Nationwide series preliminary at the Las Vegas track on Saturday.

title: Neil Youngs Digital Music System Coming to Market
description: Neil Young has long been critical of MP3, the popular format that uses digital compression to squeeze music into files small enough to be packed by the hundreds into a portable player. You are getting less than 5 percent of the original recording, he complained in a 2012 interview with The New York Times. He has not been a fan of the digital sound of compact discs, either, and he has been at work for several years on a system he calls PonoMusic as an alternative to both. Mr. Young announced on Monday that Pono is ready to hit the market.

title: As Malaysia Expands Search Area for Missing Jet, Wide Speculation Over Its Fate
description: WASHINGTON  Watching a seat-back display with a plane-shaped icon gliding across the map, it is easy to forget that in true scale, the airplane is very small and the route very large. As the hours and days drag by with no trace of the Malaysia Airlines flight that disappeared over the Gulf of Thailand early Saturday, the world is getting a reminder that if something goes wrong on a jet five miles up in the sky, traveling at 10 miles a minute, it can cover a lot of ground  or water  before it comes down to earth.

title: Whitney Biennial | Darren Bader
description: Scenes from Darren Bader's latest video project, "Things I'm (Probably) Not Going to Get Done for the Biennial."

title: U.S. Sought Port Authority Records Tied to Chairman
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Friday subpoenaed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for records related to potential conflicts of interest involving its chairman, David Samson, a prominent New Jersey lawyer and close political ally of Gov. Chris Christie, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Morgan Stanley Chief Calls Bitcoin Surreal
description: To its devotees, Bitcoin represents the future of transactions. But the financial establishment is still scratching its head over the virtual currency.

title: Dispatches From SXSW: Wearable Tech
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Among the hundreds of interesting start-ups trying to get noticed at the South by Southwest festival, quite a few are entering the relatively new realm of wearable tech  wristbands, watches, rings and the like that identify users and collect data about them.

title: Excerpts From Snowdens SXSW Speech
description: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, discussed government surveillance via video conference at the South by Southwest conference.

title: George Saunders Wins Inaugural Folio Prize
description: Another week, another honor for George Saunders.

title: A Renewed Emphasis on Bag Size at United
description: THERE is a lot of strong opinion about carry-on bags and limited space in overhead bins on airplanes, as I noted when I first reported here about that raging controversy.

title: Kurt Chew-Een Lee, Singular Marine, Dies at 88
description: Maj. Kurt Chew-Een Lee, a Chinese-American who led Marines into battle against the Chinese in the Korean War and was cited for bravery for helping to preserve a crucial evacuation route for 8,000 American troops, was found dead on March 3 at his home in Washington. He was 88.

title: No Comment Necessary: Women Politicians and the Sense of Pedestal
description: Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee treats his wife differently from his pals. He treats women opponents differently, too.

title: After Hours | Sexy Brooklyn Mommy and the Return of Broadways Funniest, Funkiest Storyteller
description: In 2007, a droll, bespectacled black man with fluttery hand gestures named Stew turned the New York theater world on its head with Passing Strange, his big, raucous rock musical about an arty African-American who finds sexual and artistic freedom in the cafes and art collectives of Amsterdam and Berlin.That may sound like an esoteric envelope for a musical, but Stew, alongside a terrific team of writers and performers, pulled it off with a cycle of open-hearted pop-rock showstoppers, as if James Baldwin had partnered with the Who. Since Passing Strange, Stew has mostly played new numbers at small Brooklyn venues like Barbs. But this weekend, he took his New Stew Review, featuring a large and exuberant retinue of musicians and guest singers, to the posh54 Belowin Midtown.The staid settingin no way stopped Stew from serving up his special sauce of astute lyrics, gorgeous melodies and funky grooves that nearly lifted the supper-club audience out of its seats.

title: Esa-Pekka Salonen Wins $100,000 Composition Prize
description: The conductor and composer Esa-Pekka Salonen has been awarded the Michael Ludwig Nemmers Prize in Musical Composition, an award established in 2004 by the Henry and Leigh Bienen School of Music at Northwestern University. The award includes a $100,000 cash prize, a performance by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and a residency of four nonconsecutive weeks over the next two years at the school, in Evanston, Ill.

title: Boston Marathon to Have More Security
description: The Boston Marathon next month will have a number of enhanced safety measures after last year's deadly bombing, including thousands of uniformed and plainclothes officers and bomb-sniffing dogs.

title: Organist Introduces New Partner in Concert
description: Every pipe organ in every concert hall and church in the world is essentially built to order and, of course, immobile. Each is also usually conceived with a specific repertory in mind. Important touring organists must adjust to each instrument and locale, which can be fascinating, frustrating or both.

title: 1937 Horch Wins Best of Show at Amelia Island
description: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla.  A 1937 Horch 853 and a 1958 Scarab racecar took top honors Sunday at the Amelia Island Concours d'lgance. The Horch was given the award for elegance, while the Scarab took the trophy for sport machines.

title: A Mighty Broadway Baritone, Unbound by Stylistic Barriers
description: You are what you sing, declared the Broadway baritone Norm Lewis from the stage of the Appel Room (the recently renamed Allen Room at Jazz at Lincoln Center) on Saturday evening. This handsome 50-year-old singer was explaining the title of his show, Who Am I?, a high point of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series.

title: Idina Menzel Sparks Strong Start for If/Then
description: Amid an unusual burst of publicity for its star, the Tony Award winner Idina Menzel, the new Broadway musical If/Then grossed a very strong $909,159 for its first seven preview performances last week, according to data released Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

title: The Spectator as Playmate and Prop Assistant
description: Thank You for Coming: Attendance, seen on Thursday at Danspace Project, begins the way many participatory performances do: no shoes, no coats, no bags. In dance code, that means youre going to have to move around.

title: Art Matters | Darren Baders Video Contribution to the 2014 Whitney Biennial
description: Nearly three months ago, Darren Bader approached T in the hope that wed host his off-site video contribution to this years Whitney Biennial. The plan, he explained, was to post a series of fake news stories on our website  without attributing them to him or the Whitney, and without even a wink to suggest that something funny was afoot. This idea got shut down. But there were plenty of others. The New York-based artist wanted to produce an editorial that paired celebrities with everyday objects, which echoed a show he staged in Los Angeles last summer at Blum & Poe. Bryan Cranston and sleeping bag, was one suggested match. Patricia Arquette with weather balloon. Another thought was to photograph things that rhyme, such as boule and stool, or the occult Baal and the actor Nick Stahl. In the end, time and budget constraints forced him to shelve (twelve, helve  the game gets inside you) his original slate of ideas, but Bader made the most of a trying situation. What follows is the first video from his new series, Things Im (Probably) Not Going to Get Done for the Biennial. About the videos, which will run here exclusively through the duration of the Biennial, Bader has this to say: I have ideas. You have ideas. Maybe some of them are the same. More likely than not, this last part is untrue.

title: The Jews, a History in So Many, Many Words
description: Simon Schama, the prolific and protean British historian whose topics have included the French Revolution and the history of art, arrives now with a history of the Jewish people, and its a multimedia happening: two books and a five-part television documentary being broadcast on the BBC and PBS.

title: Indelible Arcs, Reverberating in the Air and Memory
description: The pianist Murray Perahia took to the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday for a performance of works by Bach, Beethoven, Schumann and Chopin. Its a big hall for a solo recital, but Mr. Perahia commands a powerful sound and the ability to spin sustained legato lines that bloom in space as if they were produced by a wind instrument. Above all, though, he is a musician in search of big ideas, and throughout the engrossing performance there was a sense that he relishes the opportunity to air them in a large public forum.

title: Albums From Aloe Blacc, Sara Evans and Ambrose Akinmusire
description: ALOE BLACC

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Indonesia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Flashes of Red Break Through in a Brooding Spanish Landscape
description: The most prestigious performer in New Yorks Flamenco Festival 2014 has been Eva Yerbabuena, who presented two programs, Ay! and Lluvia, at City Center this weekend. (The festival continues, but at other New York locations, through March 24.) At the end of Lluvia, as she danced her long, rich and complex Llanto sole, she proved herself one of the worlds great dancers. Not a moment too soon: All of her first program (Ay!, on Saturday evening) had been horrid  and the first sections of Lluvia (on Sunday night) had been worse.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Indonesia, Nepal, Afghanistan and India.

title: Study: Women Who Can Do Math Still Dont Get Hired
description: The economist Larry Summers famously suggested once that so few women become scientists and engineers because of discrimination, preference and even differences in innate ability.

title: Rush Limbaugh Neednt Worry
description: In the great culture war over the so-called birth-control mandate, the most notable extra-legal skirmish to date has been between Sandra Fluke and Rush Limbaugh. In 2012 a speech before House Democrats, Ms. Fluke explained why she thought Georgetown University should be compelled to cover contraception, enraging Mr. Limbaugh, who called her a slut and a prostitute who wanted to be paid to have sex.

title: Event-Free, Sunday Night Still Pulls In Big Ratings
description: Even without a big event, Sunday night remained the main gathering point for television viewers this week, as a host of high-interest shows, led by the finale of True Detective on HBO, the premiere of a new Cosmos series on Fox and the drama Resurrection on ABC, all pulled in impressive audiences.

title: The Sleeker Side of Floral Prints
description: T highlights one seasonal wardrobe staple, worn two ways.

title: Anne Rice Reviving the Vampire Lestat
description: Anne Rice announced to her Facebook fans the publication of her next book, Prince Lestat, a novel that is set for release in October. It was such a relief and such a pleasure, at last, to be able to speak about the up-and-coming novel, which I finished some time ago, Ms. Rice wrote, adding that she had discussed its publication on The Dinner Party Show, a podcast hosted in part by her son, Christopher. The book marks the return of the vampire Lestat de Lioncourt, one of Ms. Rices creations. She is the author of Interview With the Vampire, the first in a series of vampire-theme novels. The book will be released by Knopf.

title: For Some With Flexible Spending Accounts, Time to Act
description: If you have a health care flexible spending account, it may be crunch time: The March 15 deadline to spend any available balance remaining is only days away.

title: The Next Step Is Just Showing Up
description: Oprah Winfrey, mother confessor of the nation, is nothing without her supplicants. Though shes no longer the conscience of afternoon television, her benediction is still sought by the unlucky, the needy and the creatively bankrupt.

title: One Author of a Startling Stem Cell Study Calls for Its Retraction
description: TOKYO  One of the authors of a study that was claimed to have discovered a simple way to make stem cells said on Monday that he was no longer sure of his teams conclusions, and he called for the study to be retracted.

title: Blackstone and TPG Said to Plan $5.5 Billion Bid for Gates Global
description: The Blackstone Group and TPG Capital are teaming up in a planned bid for Gates Global, a maker of industrial and automotive parts, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday.

title: Young Republicans Find Fault With Elders on List of Social Issues
description: OXON HILL, Md.  It was difficult to miss Ian Jacobson at the Conservative Political Action Conference. Known as Rooster, he was 33, with an ample beard, earrings and a towering orange-and-aqua spiked Mohawk haircut. But he also sported a pinstriped suit, French cuffs and a natty contrast collar.

title: Secret Agent, Book Agent, All the Same
description: Thriller writers have a knack for picking settings that are inherently suspenseful. A sinking yacht. The homicide unit of a police department. A secret lair stocked with covert C.I.A. operatives.

title: No Winner Yet in El Salvadors Close Presidential Race
description: MEXICO CITY  With only 6,634 votes separating them, both candidates in El Salvadors presidential race proclaimed victory on Monday, revealing a country equally divided between the political heirs of forces that fought a bloody civil war a quarter of a century ago.

title: Joseph Sax, Who Pioneered Environmental Law, Dies at 78
description: Joseph L. Sax, a legal scholar who helped shape environmental law in the United States and fuel the environmental movement by establishing the doctrine that natural resources are a public trust requiring protection, died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 78.

title: Weekend Gun Report: March 7-9, 2014
description: For some reason, Facebooks recent announcement that it was taking steps to curtail illegal gun sales on its social network has the N.R.A. declaring victory.

title: Jailed Leaders of Egypts 2011 Revolt Describe Beatings
description: Three prominent Egyptian activists who were jailed late last year for violating a new anti-protest law said on Monday that guards had beaten them during their transfer from prison to court for an appeal hearing.

title: Rewriting the Menu in Tulum
description: TULUM, MEXICO  This is not an article about Mexican food.

title: All the Rage | Faux Jewelry Handcrafted From Dried Flowers, Seeds and Pods
description: In the back of the Pennsylvania Convention Center, behind sweeping landscaping displays and salespeople pushing fake paving stones, a group of women swarmed the botanical jewelry exhibition at the Philadelphia Flower Show, a nine-day event that concluded yesterday. Their awe and confusion over the lot of ornate and delicate jewelry Can you wear it? Are they for sale? filled the air.

title: At SXSW Conference, a Mother Presses Her Sons Case
description: Among the tech start-ups pitching their ideas at SXSW this week, there was a mother, advocating not a new company but the cause of her son.

title: Fruitful but Tough Adventures in the Amazon
description: WHEN I was younger we went on a lot of vacations, so traveling isnt new to me. My business partner Tyler Gage and I went to Ecuador and other parts of South America when we were in college, and after taking an entrepreneurship class we started our beverage company, Runa. We work with more than 2,000 guayusa growers who are all members of the Amazonian Kichwa indigenous group. They call themselves Runa, which translates to fully alive human being. Guayusa is a caffeinated tree leaf, and we sell it and use it to make our bottled beverages.

title: Waiting for the Black Box
description: Days after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 shortly after midnight on Saturday, investigators considering a range of possible causes  mechanical failure, pilot error and terrorism  have yet to turn up solid clues. They dont even know where the plane disappeared, which suggests that for grieving families this misfortune could remain a mystery until the recovery of the planes black box.

title: My Brother, Teddy
description: This short film captures a young girls love for her brother, who has cerebral palsy.

title: My Brother, Teddy
description: My daughter Emma was just 3 when Teddy was born, with a viral infection he contracted in utero that caused extensive brain damage. This short film captures her love for Teddy, one not weighted down by disappointment, sadness or a full understanding of all the ways in which he wasnt normal.

title: Moving From the Trenches to Turmoil at Home
description: Theres a lot to watch in The Hero. But the real action is under the surface. This exceptional revival of Gilbert Emerys 1921 play is steeped in subtext and repressed emotions: confusion, regret, desire and despair. Here, the silent moments are among the most moving.

title: Search Area
description: Flight 370 left Kuala Lumpur International Airport just after midnight on Saturday. The Malaysian authorities announced Monday that they were expanding the search zones.

title: Hundreds of Birds and Somewhat Damaged People
description: Asylum of the Birds : Hundreds of Birds and Somewhat Damaged People

title: Obesity and Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Russia Scholars Views
description: To the Editor:

title: For More Online Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Patersons Legacy in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians in London, and the Crisis in Ukraine
description: To the Editor:

title: Limiting Patients Choice of Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: What Were Reading Now
description: The governments new nutrition labels  the first in 20 years  will let families know whether their food has added sugars for the first time, and reflect more realistic portion sizes.

title: Smart Scales in the Kitchen
description: The Prep Pad is a kitchen scale that connects to a smart phone and measures the nutritional content of your food.

title: The Fork Says Slow Down
description: Catherine Saint Louis knows shes a fast eater. She hopes the HapiFork can undo some bad habits.

title: Tilda Swinton: 'Only Lovers Left Alive'
description: The actress discusses her role as a 3000-year-old vampire in Jim Jarmusch's latest film.

title: Walk at Work
description: Is a treadmill desk worth the high cost? A New York Times reporter, Amy Harmon, puts one to the test at work.

title: Parents, Wired to Distraction
description: Every age of parenthood  and parenthood at every age  yields some discouraging metric, some new rating system on which parents can be judged and found wanting. We endlessly jury family dinner rituals, day care and nannies, parents readiness to follow schedules, or to ignore the rules and follow their childs directives. Whatever you are doing is probably wrong. Yes, you, yes, right now. Put down that cellphone and listen to me.

title: Seeking Serenity on a Screen
description: For most of us, smartphones can seem more a constant source of stress than a path to serenity. But more and more people are using their Androids and iPhones to find inner peace.

title: Collecting Data on a Good Nights Sleep
description: Computers and mobile devices are enemies of a good nights sleep, interrupting slumber with text alerts and disrupting natural sleep rhythms with their glowing blue screens. But a new generation of apps and devices may also be the way to improve sleep. Manufacturers are coming out with gadgets like cellphone alarm clocks that wake people at the most opportune point in their sleep cycle and heart rate monitors that people strap on at night, part of a broader movement to improve health by quantifying behavior.

title: Finding the Right Pace on a Treadmill Desk
description: On Day 3 of my long-coveted trial of a treadmill desk, I sat down.

title: Gadgets to Boost Bike Safety
description: In a widely viewed YouTube video, a cyclist named Casey Neistat, deliberately takes tumble after tumble while trying to navigate obstructed bike lanes in New York City. The video is funny  it even includes a crash into a parked police car  but it also has struck a chord with bike commuters around the country facing a seemingly endless array of road hazards.

title: Zombies, Workout Music and Baby Trackers: Health Tech for Everyone
description: Amid a deluge of health apps and devices washing over consumers, there are some quirky, intriguing products that may have escaped your notice. Here are the best of them.

title: Venezuela Goes Mad
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  THE violent demonstrations that have rocked Venezuela for weeks are threatening to wipe out what little democracy is left here after 15 years of systematic erosion by the state. The government of Nicols Maduro has responded with massive military force, raiding offices and houses without judicial orders, imprisoning civilians in military compounds and applauding the killing of protesters by paramilitary groups.

title: Better Eating With Smart Scales and Forks
description: Some people read nutrition labels with the kind of zeal others reserve for tabloids. The pleasure is in the appraisal. Those crackers in the supermarket with no trans fats? Basket-worthy. A cafes peach muffin has one measly gram of fiber? As if.

title: After Online Dating, Online Making Up
description: Here is what Steve S. and Sarah B. do when they fight: They take a breath, go to their smartphones, and click on Couple Counseling & Chatting, a free app created by their real-life therapist, Marigrace Randazzo-Ratliff.

title: Mets Playing It Safe With Return of First Basemen
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets Manager Terry Collins crossed his arms, leaned back in his office chair and sighed. Opening day was about three weeks away, and his first basemen, Ike Davis and Lucas Duda, were hurt. Worse, Collins did not know when they would return.

title: Check Your Head
description: A high-tech tool to combat concussion damage, the Reebok Checklight is a sensor worn under the helmet that lights up upon significant impact.

title: Do Brain Workouts Work? Science Isnt Sure
description: For a $14.95 monthly membership, the website Lumosity promises to train your brain with games designed to stave off mental decline. Users view a quick succession of bird images and numbers to test attention span, for instance, or match increasingly complex tile patterns to challenge memory.

title: Coal to the Rescue, but Maybe Not Next Winter
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  When the temperature here dropped into the teens this winter, ice formed on the inside of Ernestine J. Cundiffs windows in the drafty 50-year-old apartment building where she lives. At 81, with diabetes, poor circulation in her legs and both shoulders damaged in separate falls last year, Ms. Cundiff said wearing leggings and fur-lined slippers was not enough to keep her warm, so she took to using an electric space heater in her bedroom.

title: Israel Displays Arms It Says Were Headed to Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Israels seizure last week of a merchant vessel said to be carrying an Iranian arms shipment had two goals, according to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: to prevent the cargo from reaching Palestinian fighters in Hamas-run Gaza, and to expose what he called the true face of Iran.

title: A Concussion Monitor to Measure Hard Knocks
description: On a frigid night recently in Randolph, N.J., the Jersey Wildcats junior hockey team flew across the home rink during practice at Aspen Ice Arena, sending ice into the air. Hockey is known for its collisions, and concussions arent unusual, but the players didnt seem particularly worried.

title: Share Your Wired Well Story
description: Todays Wired Well special section of Science Times explores how you can now easily track and analyze your every move  from the number of minutes spent in REM sleep to the amount of time your heart rate was above 100 beats per minute to the number of steps you took in the office. You can even do that for your dog.

title: William Pogue, Astronaut Who Staged a Strike in Space, Dies at 84
description: William R. Pogue was the pilot of a record-setting American mission in space, and one of the very few astronauts ever to go on strike  while in orbit  to demand more time for contemplating the universe.

title: Activity Trackers Dont Sense Everything
description: Wearable technology  those wristbands, watches and belt gadgets that track your every move  hold tremendous promise for improving health and physical performance. But as often happens, the technology has outstripped the research, and scientists are still struggling to understand whether the monitors work as promised, how to keep people motivated to use them, and exactly what the devices are supposed to accomplish, anyway.

title: The Monitored Man
description: For years, health advocates have been telling us to move more. But just how much more?

title: West Virginia: Governor Weighs Abortion Bill
description: Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin said he was concerned about the constitutionality of a bill banning abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, which the State Legislature passed over the weekend. Twelve states have passed similar bans, according to the Guttmacher Institute. But West Virginia will be the first with a Democratic governor and Democratic-controlled legislature to embrace the 20-week limit if the governor signs the bill. Supporters contend a fetus that age can feel pain, although the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists says there is no scientific evidence for that view. The Supreme Court in January refused to hear an appeal of a lower courts decision to strike down an Arizona law banning most abortions after 20 weeks. In Roe v. Wade in 1973, the high court said women have a right to an abortion until the point of fetal viability, generally seen as 24 weeks. The abortion bill obviously is one that causes me some concern because even the legislative attorneys and others said they feel this bill is unconstitutional, Governor Tomblin said in a statement.

title: Israel Watches Warily as Hezbollah Gains Battle Skills in Syria
description: TEL AVIV  Hezbollahs distracting and costly engagement in the Syrian civil war has offered some practical benefit to Israelis. It has also been a source of foreboding.

title: An Officer's Alleged Theft
description: Sgt. Scott Greene was arrested after stopping a driver and tucking a $100 bill from an envelope of cash on a car seat into his shirtsleeve. His victim was an undercover detective.

title: Immigrants, Robbed by the Police
description: More than a dozen Latino men on Long Island have reported being robbed by a Suffolk County police officer, saying he pulled them over while they were driving and stole their money. Sgt. Scott Greene was arrested after stopping a driver in late January, riffling through an envelope of cash on a car seat and tucking a $100 bill into his shirt sleeve. His victim was an undercover detective; the incident was caught on camera.

title: Egypt Tycoon Is Released; 3 Detainees Detail Abuse
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court on Monday ordered the release on bail of a right-hand man to former President Hosni Mubarak while another court considered a prison sentence recently handed to three young organizers who led the revolt against him.

title: Harassment of Troubled State Exchanges
description: Now that the badly botched rollout of the federal governments health care website seems to be behind us, Republicans have shifted their criticisms to several states that are experiencing problems enrolling people on their state-run exchanges. Their attacks would be more credible if they showed the slightest desire to help fix the problems. But their main goal is to belittle the efforts of states that are working hard to make their systems better, to scare people away from the state websites and to discredit the health care reform law itself.

title: First Look Media Adds Editor of Gawker
description: First Look Media, the online news venture backed by the technology billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar, is adding John Cook, the editor of Gawker, to its growing stable of journalists, the publication announced on Monday.

title: At Fordham, Gym Has History if Not Allure
description: Among a growing crop of slick new basketball arenas, Fordhams 89-year-old Rose Hill Gym is a venerable throwback, one of the few still in use that were built during the lifetime of basketballs inventor, James Naismith. Its walls, made of sturdy bricks of Manhattan schist, seem destined to withstand all challengers.

title: House to Investigate Slow Response to Fault in G.M. Vehicles
description: WASHINGTON  A House committee has started an investigation into the response by General Motors and federal safety regulators to complaints about faulty ignition switches that have been linked to 13 deaths, officials said on Monday.

title: The Democrats Stand Up to the Kochs
description: Democrats have for too long been passive in the face of the vast amounts of corporate money, most of it secret, that are being spent to evict them from office and dismantle their policies. By far the largest voice in many of this years political races, for example, has been that of the Koch brothers, who have spent tens of millions of dollars peddling phony stories about the impact of health care reform, all in order to put Republicans in control of the Senate after the November elections.

title: Former Rivals Come Together in a Campaign to End Childhood Hunger
description: CONSUMER-PRODUCT giants that were once fierce competitors are joining forces for a good-cause marketing campaign meant to help a nonprofit alleviate childhood hunger.

title: We Need More Tests, Not Fewer
description: DURHAM, N.H.  LAST week, the College Board announced that it was revising the SAT in an effort to make it more acceptable to test-takers, teachers, college admissions officers and the public more generally. Thats a tough objective. The SAT tells us something about how smart we (or our children or students) are. Test-takers who receive lower scores than they had hoped for are likely to be dismayed at the news  and concerned about their academic future. Its no wonder that its hard to discuss the test dispassionately.

title: Methodist Bishop to End Trials for Ministers Who Perform Gay Weddings
description: The head bishop of the United Methodist Church in New York on Monday committed to ending church trials in his region for ministers who perform same sex-marriages, essentially freeing them to conduct a ceremony still prohibited under his denominations laws.

title: Dispute Over Fate of Mysterious Tanker With Oil From Libya
description: HOUSTON  A tanker that had been sitting for three days in a Libyan port controlled by a regional militia has what every refinery in Europe wants: some of the highest quality oil in the world, so sweet it needs little refining to process into high-grade fuel.

title: A Veteran Sticks With the Fastball
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  No starter in baseball throws his fastball as often as the Mets Bartolo Colon. Nobody comes close.

title: Hotels Moving Into Old Buildings
description: Reuse and recycle are taking on new meaning for hotels.

title: A Not-So-Quixotic Search for Cervantes
description: MADRID  He may be one of Spains literary heroes, but during his life four centuries ago, Miguel de Cervantes could have been considered something of a loser, said Fernando de Prado, a Spanish historian. Cervantes, the author of the adventures of the knight-errant Don Quixote, lived in poverty, missed out on a military promotion and was held captive by pirates for five years after his naval ship was intercepted. The recognition and success of his writings came too late to bring him any fortune.

title: Shoe-Bomb Plot Revisited at Trial of Bin Laden Relative
description: In the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, Al Qaeda made plans to have terrorists board airplanes and detonate explosives hidden in their shoes. One operative, Richard C. Reid, tried but failed to blow up a flight from Paris to Miami in December 2001. The other man, Saajid Badat, backed out and was later arrested in Britain.

title: Missing Brooklyn Boy Rode Subway for Five Days
description: The New York City subway is full of people watching people. But even amid the eyes of millions of riders, it is possible to get lost. And as one family learned, it is possible for an 11-year-old boy to drift through the subway system for five days seen by many but noticed by no one.

title: Icahns War of Words With eBay
description: Its a fight that pits Wall Street against Silicon Valley.

title: The Leaderless Doctrine
description: Were in the middle of a remarkable shift in how Americans see the world and their own countrys role in the world. For the first time in half a century, a majority of Americans say that the U.S. should be less engaged in world affairs, according to the most recent Pew Research Center survey. For the first time in recorded history, a majority of Americans believe that their country has a declining influence on whats happening around the globe. A slight majority of Americans now say that their country is doing too much to help solve the worlds problems.

title: Home, at the Other House That Ruth Built
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The woman pressed her eyes shut to see what only she can see. Macular degeneration has left her legally blind. Still, her vision of a bygone era, and of baseballs most famous figure, remains focused.

title: White House Withdraws Plan Allowing Limits to Medicare Coverage for Some Drugs
description: WASHINGTON  Under pressure from patients, pharmaceutical companies and members of Congress from both parties, the Obama administration on Monday withdrew a proposal that would have allowed insurers to limit Medicare coverage for certain classes of drugs, including those used to treat depression and schizophrenia.

title: After Seeing His Family Crumble, Vindicated Whistle-Blower Has Little to Smile About
description: To walk the streets free of the shadow of indictment, to hear a Brooklyn prosecutor last Friday describe the extortion case against him as a tree rotted through, Samuel Kellner might be expected to speak of vindication and hope.

title: Suit Over Inheritance in the Perelman Family Nears Its End in Court
description: A messy family legal brawl involving the daughter of the financier Ronald O. Perelman is entering its final stages in a New Jersey court.

title: Sharply Criticized by Government, Head of the Central Bank of Cyprus Resigns
description: PARIS  The central bank chief of financially plagued Cyprus resigned Monday, following political tensions with the Cypriot government and an investigation into his role in the 10 billion euro international bailout for the island last year.

title: Use of Stolen Passports on Missing Jet Highlights Security Flaw
description: WASHINGTON  As an armada of ships, planes and helicopters combed the waters south of Vietnam on Monday for any sign of a missing Malaysian airliner, aviation safety experts said the discovery that two passengers aboard the plane were traveling on stolen passports has revealed a major gap in airline security procedures developed since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Washington Businessman Pleads Guilty Over Illegal Contributions
description: A wealthy Washington businessman who funneled millions of dollars in illegal campaign contributions to local and federal candidates pleaded guilty to two conspiracy charges on Monday, bringing renewed attention to a longstanding corruption inquiry in the nations capital and to Mayor Vincent C. Grays 2010 election.

title: Puerto Rico Gets a Break With Rates on Its Bonds
description: Puerto Rico is expected to sell roughly $3 billion in bonds on Tuesday at interest rates that are considerably lower than many investors in the municipal market had expected, providing a rare bright spot for the cash-squeezed island.

title: California: Migrants Stage Another Border Protest
description: In a protest against the Obama administrations deportations policy, about 30 foreigners without legal visas who have families in the United States went to the Mexican border near San Diego to ask the authorities to allow them into the United States. The migrants had previously been formally deported or left to avoid deportation, and they asked American border officials to admit them on humanitarian grounds to join close relatives here. It was the third protest since July in which migrants have tried to challenge the administration by attempting to enter without documents through a border station.

title: Roger Hilsman, Adviser to Kennedy on Vietnam, Dies at 94
description: Roger Hilsman, a foreign policy adviser in the Kennedy administration who helped draft a cable giving tacit American support to a coup against President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 94.

title: After Students Hazing-Related Deaths, Fraternity Eliminates Tradition of Pledging
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  After a string of injuries and deaths at its fraternity houses, Sigma Alpha Epsilon, one of the largest fraternities in the country, said it would no longer permit pledging as part of its initiation process for undergraduates seeking to join the organization, and would instead offer new brothers full membership within days of inviting them to join.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 10, 2014
description: March 10, 2014

title: Wendy Hughes, 61, Actress in Australian Film Surge, Dies
description: Wendy Hughes, an Australian actress known internationally for her roles in My Brilliant Career and other movies, died on Saturday in Sydney. She was 61.

title: Yen-Pinching Undercuts Japans Push Against Years of Deflation
description: TOKYO  The loose change in Yusa Nishimuras purse could be undermining Prime Minister Shinzo Abes economic recovery plan for Japan.

title: Release of Syrian Nuns Was Part of a Hostage Swap
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Video of an unusual prisoner swap early Monday between the Syrian government and insurgents appears to confirm what Syrian officials have long denied: that the government has been holding women and children prisoner, including relatives of suspected opposition fighters.

title: An Alter Ego With Attitude
description: All of us play unhappy host to a demon or two roosting in our brains, urging us on to bad behavior now and then: a cutting remark, a catty tweet. But after watching the terrific, scary-funny play Hand to God, by Robert Askins, I am very glad I dont own a hand puppet.

title: A Collaborative Effort
description: When I was a child, my family spent several summers in Amsterdam. My mother, sister and I toured the city, wandered along the canals, visited the great museums and sampled the local chocolates. My father, meanwhile, buried himself in Amsterdams social history library, studying the papers of the anarchists Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman, known as Sasha. Sasha and Emma had been born in czarist Russia, immigrated to New York in the 1880s as teenagers, joined an anarchist group, and formed a lifelong friendship that remained immutable through protest rallies, bombing plots, prison time, love affairs, deportation, separation and war. My father, Paul Avrich, had been fascinated with them for years.

title: About to Bloom
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Its been a while since weve seen Mel Rosen. His last New York Times puzzle was the infamous Question Box grid, but hes back today with a puzzle that hopefully will be more reliable in predicting the arrival of spring than Punxsutawney Phil.

title: Draft Lottery Cant Come Soon Enough for 76ers
description: The Philadelphia 76ers came to Madison Square Garden on Monday night feeling surprisingly optimistic, at least for a team that had lost 16 consecutive games, the longest streak in franchise history since 1973.

title: New York State Reports Steep Rise in Housing Costs
description: Housing costs have risen beyond what New Yorkers can afford in many parts of the state, whether they rent or own, an examination released by the state comptrollers office shows.

title: A Tip of the Goalie Mask to Rangers Greats
description: After Henrik Lundqvist secured a 3-0 victory over the Detroit Red Wings on Sunday, he paid tribute to two great Rangers goalies who came before him: Eddie Giacomin, whose Rangers shutout record he tied, and Mike Richter, whose team victory record is only one win away.

title: Warily, Europes Steel Makers Are Firing Up Their Furnaces Again
description: DUNKIRK, France  Steel mills like ArcelorMittals 1,200-acre complex here on the French coast are forbidding places, full of incandescent metal and groaning machinery. But longtime industry executives like Henri-Pierre Orsoni, who runs the companys operations in northern France, relish being around these dusty behemoths.

title: Daunting Tests Await Admiral Named N.S.A. Chief
description: WASHINGTON  It is not hard to understand why veterans of the National Security Agency argue that 2013 was the worst year since Harry S. Truman got the place running 62 years ago.

title: Steel Mills Endure Hard Times
description: Though demand for steel in Europe waned during the economic downturn, ArcelorMittal and other mills are starting to experience a revival.

title: New Roller Coaster Promises Coney Island a Return of Thrills
description: Fasten your seatbelts. This summer, New York City thrill seekers will be able to experience a 90-degree vertical drop, followed by a 100-foot loop and a zero-gravity roll, along with dives, hills and a corkscrew  all within two minutes.

title: U.S. and Russia Hit Diplomatic Roadblock Trying to Start Ukraine Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations effort to solicit Russias help to defuse the crisis in Ukraine hit a roadblock on Monday when Secretary of State John Kerry delayed an anticipated trip to Russia and the two sides issued dueling accounts of their recent diplomacy.

title: Thieves in Gaza Go Where Money Is, but Hamas Quickly Gets It Back
description: Masked gunmen robbed a post office in Gaza City on Monday, stealing what local news reports said was the equivalent of about $500,000. It was a rare act of criminal violence against a government institution run by Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza. The money was earmarked for about 5,000 beneficiaries of a government unemployment program. But just hours after the robbery, three Palestinian suspects were arrested without resistance and the money was recovered, according to Islam Shahwan, the spokesman for the Hamas-run Interior Ministry.

title: Can Writing Be Assessed?
Indias Supreme Court Orders Speedier Trials for Lawmakers
description: Indias Supreme Court on Monday ordered lower courts to conclude the trials of lawmakers charged with grave crimes within a year of the date of the charges being filed as a way to reduce the number of politicians who are re-elected during drawn-out trials. Criminal cases in India often drag on for several years, allowing lawmakers who are charged with crimes to continue to hold their posts and run for re-election. Mondays ruling is part of a push for electoral overhaul in India. In July, the Supreme Court barred people convicted of crimes carrying prison terms of more than five years from running in elections. On Monday, it ruled that lawmakers who are charged with crimes carrying a punishment of more than two years must have a speedy trial. The Association for Democratic Reforms, a nonprofit group that aims to promote electoral transparency, estimates that 30 percent of sitting lawmakers have criminal charges against them.

title: Nets Defeat Raptors in a Playoff Atmosphere
description: Paul Pierce sank a 3-pointer with 1 minute 14 seconds remaining in the game Monday night and spent the next several seconds skipping deliberately back to the Nets bench  the whole time spinning clockwise with his right hand in the air  as fans at Barclays Center built a wall of noise around him.

title: Despite Fears, Traffic Flows On After Tappan Zee Ramp Is Closed
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  The traffic nightmare did not materialize.

title: Turkish Court Orders Release of 19 More in Plot Case
description: An Istanbul court on Monday ordered the release of 19 men convicted with scores of others of plotting a coup in the controversial Ergenekon case, which the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan used to break the political power of Turkeys military. The court said the men should be released because the Parliament recently reduced the maximum detention period before a conviction to five years, and the prisoners had already been detained longer than that. The court order followed the release of a former army chief last week after the Constitutional Courts ruling critical of the conduct of the recently abolished Special Court that carried out the Ergenekon trial. The trial, which lasted five years, prompted criticism at home and abroad, with several international organizations describing the prosecution of the more than 200 suspects as unfair, with unnecessary arrests, secret witnesses and disputes over evidence. Some Turkish analysts characterized Mondays releases as part of a bid by the government to increase its popularity before local elections in two weeks and gain the upper hand in a power struggle with a pro-Islamic network influential in the judiciary and the police.

title: Patentholder on Breast Cancer Tests Denied Injunction in Lawsuit
description: Myriad Genetics, which lost a closely watched Supreme Court case last year involving the patenting of genes, has suffered another setback in its efforts to protect its main genetic test from competition.

title: Obamas New Approach Takes a Humorous Turn
description: WASHINGTON  In Between Two Ferns, an off-color online parody of celebrity interview shows, the comedian Zach Galifianakis has spanked Justin Bieber with his belt, discussed Charlize Therons thighs and asked Natalie Portman for her phone number.

title: Knicks Win 4th Straight, but Phil Jackson Is Main Character
description: The Knicks and the Philadelphia 76ers, two teams with unfortunate records, convened at Madison Square Garden on Monday night to play a game that was most notable because of one mans absence.

title: For Hateful Comic in France, Muzzle Becomes a Megaphone
description: PARIS  Thirty-eight times in recent years the French authorities have charged the comedian Dieudonn Mbala Mbala with violating anti-hate laws. The government has urged cities and towns to ban his performances, and some have done so, canceling his sold-out shows. Senior officials have condemned him as an anti-Semitic Holocaust denier who is inciting hatred.

title: Post-Fashion-Month Detox Recipes from Downtowns Hippest, Healthiest Chefs
description: Now that fashion month has wrapped, the bi-continental throng is ready to atone for four weeks worth of long days and late nights, champagne and catering. If a spa getaway, juice cleanse or boot camp arent on the iCal, an equally virtuous (and altogether more convivial) course of action is to dine at Dimes, the pint-sized outpost of chic California-style cuisine in New Yorks Chinatown. With their masterfully seasoned produce and inspired juices named after Agnes Martin paintings, the owner-chefs Sabrina De Sousa and Alissa Wagner prove that health and culinary creativity need not be mutually exclusive (at least on the East Coast). An in-house line of organic, aromatherapeutic lip balms and body products  along with decor that feels more Abiquiu than Allen Street  also help to lure a roster of repeat offenders. (Certain stylists, DJs and writers have been known to visit Dimes multiple times per week  even multiple times per day.) Healthy restaurants get a bad rap, says De Sousa. We wanted to bring the idea of wellness into the mainstream with foods that are creative, beautiful and inspiring.

title: Even Before Fort Lee Lane Closings, Port Authority Was a Christie Tool
description: For a state that lost hundreds of lives on Sept. 11, the gifts were emotionally resonant: pieces of steel from the ruins of the World Trade Center. They were presented by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to 20 carefully chosen New Jersey mayors who sat atop a list of 100 whose endorsements Gov. Chris Christie hoped to win.

title: Only 15 Percent of Top Films in 2013 Put Women in Lead Roles, Study Finds
description: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire. Frozen. Gravity. Three of last years top 10 grossing films were led by female protagonists, making 2013 a banner year for women in film, right?

title: Q. and A. on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
description: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has left investigators, aviation experts and the authorities in several countries at a loss to explain what happened. And the few slender clues that have emerged only seem to lead to more questions. As the search broadens and the international inquiries continue, Matthew L. Wald, a correspondent for The New York Times, answers some basic questions:

title: Word of the Day | repeal
description: repeal \ri-pel\ verb and noun

title: Times Minute | Politicizing 9/11 Rubble
description: Also on the Minute, walking on a treadmill at work and rethinking Mexican food in Tulum.

title: Times Minute | Politicizing 9/11 Rubble
description: In the Video

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (El Rey) FROM DUSK TILL DAWN: THE SERIES The director Robert Rodriguez spins off his 1996 supernatural cult western as the first original scripted series on his new English-language cable channel, aimed at Hispanic audiences. D. J. Cotrona, above, and Zane Holtz star as the violently unpredictable Gecko brothers, on the lam from the F.B.I. and a couple of Texas Rangers (Don Johnson and Jesse Garcia) after a deadly bank heist. Fleeing to Mexico, they cross the border in the R.V. of a former pastor (Robert Patrick). But chaos ensues when a detour to a strip club populated by vampires forces them to fight for their lives until sunrise. I thought it would be best to start with a property people knew for a network people didnt know, Mr. Rodriguez said in a recent interview, about adapting the film, which was written by Quentin Tarantino. As a result, he added, we have an identity right off the bat.

title: Joe McGinniss, 71, Dies; Chronicled Politics and Sensational Crime
description: Drawn to the kind of serious subject that had a tabloid sheen, Joe McGinniss, who died on Monday at 71, was a journalist provocateur whose book-length probes into political lives and horrific crimes often triggered controversy, critical debate and mega-sales.

title: How to Help the Working Poor
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Chinese Satellites Redeployed to Search for Malaysia Airlines Plane
description: Updated, 4:12 a.m. ET| China said it had immediately redeployed 10 satellites to help in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared early Saturday with 239 people, mostly Chinese, on board, as frustration mounted among families of the missing over the lack of progress.

title: In Delhi, Hopeful Patients Turn to a Razor Blade for Treatment
description: NEW DELHI  On a brisk winter morning, Dwarka Mistry, 61, sat waiting for a doctor, along with four others, on an iron bench behind Jama Masjid, a Mughal-era mosque in the old part of the capital. Despair covered Mr. Mistrys face as he clutched his knees and thighs from time to time.

title: Corrections: March 11, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Q. & A.: Cmdr. William Marks of the U.S. Navy 7th Fleet on the Search for the Malaysian Jet
description: Two United States Navy guided-missile destroyers, the Pinckney and Kidd, are among the dozens of ships searching for the Malaysia Airlines plane that disappeared while flying from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Beijing. The Pinckney has been searching since Sunday, sending out a helicopter that has been scanning the sea for signs of the missing plane and any survivors. A United States Navy P-3C Orion maritime surveillance aircraft has also been participating in the search, flying out from Subang Jaya, Malaysia. The Kidd joined the hunt on Monday.

title: Test Yourself | History, March 11
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | In a Native American Sport, a Familys Giant Leap
description: In In a Native American Sport, a Familys Giant Leap, Zach Schonbrun writes about a trailblazing family in college lacrosse.

title: What Comes After Rich Baby Boomers? Kids With a Big Inheritance
description: The Waltons might be the closest thing we have to the Carnegies or Rockefellers today. The heirs to the Walmart fortune occupy six slots on the most recent Forbes 400 list, and just those six Waltons  not counting their lucky progeny  are worth $145 billion. But the Waltons are in the distinct minority on the Forbes list. In this new Gilded Age, rich Americans are more likely to have made their own fortunes than to have inherited them.

title: Does a Championship Game Always Need to Have a Winner (and a Loser)?
description: On Saturday night, two Ohio high school ice hockey teams walked away as state champions after seven overtimes and a tie score  and the crowd booed loudly and chanted, Let them play!

title: Inside Roger Ballens Mind: A Place of Refuge and Madness
description: An asylum can be either a refuge or a place of madness. In Roger Ballens new book, Asylum of the Birds, its both.

title: Stolen Passports on Plane Not Seen as Terror Link
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  Two Iranians known to have used stolen passports to board the Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared on Saturday were unlikely to be linked to terrorist groups, international police authorities said, echoing an assessment by the Malaysian police that one of them was a 19-year-old who wanted to migrate to Germany.

title: New York Today: When the Bronx Invaded Manhattan
China Details Plans to Liberalize Interest Rates and Encourage Private Banks
description: HONG KONG  The head of Chinas central bank and other top financial regulators offered new details on Tuesday on the countrys steps toward a more market-driven economy, including plans to liberalize interest rates as early as next year and to allow the establishment of the first privately owned official banks.

title: Daily Report: Icahns Fight Against eBay
description: One of the sharper business battles in recent weeks has been playing out between Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, and Marc Andreessen, the entrepreneur turned technology investor. Its a fight that pits Wall Street against Silicon Valley, Andrew Ross Sorkin reports.

title: Air Links Are Severed as Russia Tightens Its Grip on Crimean Peninsula
description: KIEV, Ukraine  The airport in the regional capital of Simferopol was closed on Tuesday to all flights except those heading to and from Moscow, in the boldest display yet of Russias tightening control over Crimea.

title: North Korea Ably Evades Its Sanctions, Panel Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Recent inspections and seizures of banned cargo have shown that North Korea is using increasingly deceptive techniques to circumvent international sanctions, a panel of experts said in a report to the United Nations Security Council published Tuesday.

title: The Surprisingly Large Cost of Telling Small Lies
description: Recently, I caught up with one of our angel investors for lunch: Peter is a brilliant entrepreneur from England who has lived all over the world. He has built several businesses and now lives a dream life with a house on a harbor, a happy family and a broad smile.

title: Maoist Guerrillas Ambush Police in Chhattisgarh
description: NEW DELHI  At least 15 police officers and a civilian were killed by an estimated 100 Maoist guerrillas in central India on Tuesday as the officers were clearing a road to allow a construction crew to pass through.

title: Protests in Venezuela
description: Demonstrations are continuing around the country.

title: Western Journalist Is Shot and Killed as Kabul Mourns Officials Death
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two men shot a Swedish reporter on a crowded street in Kabul on Tuesday, in a rare assassination-style killing of a Westerner that raised new questions about the safety of the large international presence expected to remain here after American-led combat forces depart this year.

title: With $21 Billion Loss, Italian Bank Signals Wider Vulnerabilities
