description: Italys biggest bank reported a huge loss on Tuesday, foreshadowing the possibility that many financial institutions across Europe could be forced to acknowledge the full extent of their own problems under increased regulatory scrutiny.

title: Icahns Fight Against eBay
description: Marc Andreessen, the entrepreneur turned technology investor, has recently been caught in the verbal cross hairs of the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. The war of words stems from Mr. Icahns campaign to pressure eBay, the online auction company, to spin off its electronic payment unit PayPal. Among other things, he has accused Mr. Andreessen, an eBay board member, of various conflicts of interest that affected eBays sale of Skype in 2009 for $2.75 billion to a group of investors that included Mr. Andreessens venture capital firm.

title: A Less Glossy Take on Teenage Life
description: The most gratifying moment at this years Grammy Awards came just after Lorde was announced as the winner of the best pop solo performance, for Royals. The camera caught her in a calm inhale, leaning forward in her seat, eyes bugging just a bit: Her demeanor was part shock, part shrug. The observer had become the observed, but she was still keeping a watchful eye.

title: In Our Pages: March 12
description: 1889: Arts Minister Asks for Credit

title: From Acne Studios, Wearable Art by an Abstract-Painting Pioneer
description: The Swedish design house AcneStudios has a long history of collaborating with artists and designers, including Lanvin, Liberty of London and the jeweler Husam El Odeh. This season, the lines creative director, Jonny Johansson, enlisted a figure from the past: the artist Hilma af Klint, whose colorful early-20th-century abstract paintings were informed by her studies in mysticism and the occult. Not only did her work provide conceptual and color inspiration for his mens and womens spring collections, but he also designed T-shirts, sweatshirts and scarves  available today exclusively at acnestudios.com  that bear prints scanned directly from the artists canvases.

title: After Scandal, a New Name for SAC: Point72
description: The name of the hedge fund proudly reflected its founder, Steven A. Cohen: SAC Capital Advisors. But eager to put its guilty plea to securities fraud charges behind it, the diminished firm is getting a new name that makes no reference to the billionaire investor: Point72 Asset Management.

title: Subject, Meet Verb
description: Every job has its joyless tasks. Its time again for one of mine: pointing out that singular subjects should go with singular verbs, and plural subjects with plural verbs. A related bit of drudgery is reminding colleagues that singular pronouns should be used to refer to singular antecedents, and plural pronouns to plural antecedents.

title: Not Looking Backwards at Torture, Continued
description: A recent post by the Editorial Page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, criticized the Central Intelligence Agencys effort to keep secret two reports on its post-9/11 detention and interrogation practices.

title: Bangladesh Inspections Find Gaps in Safety
description: Nearly a year after a factory building collapsed in Bangladesh, killing more than 1,100 workers, engineering teams sponsored by Western retailers have been rigorously inspecting that countrys garment industry, resulting in at least two temporary closings because of safety problems.

title: Wheelies: The More Hybrids Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Video: Tilda Swinton at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The actress Tilda Swinton made her first trip to the South by Southwest film festival with the vampire feature she stars in, Only Lovers Left Alive. In that film, the latest from the director Jim Jarmusch, she plays a 3,000-year-old vampire in a very, very long-term relationship. In this video, Ms. Swinton discusses more about the film and how she brought her immortal role to life.

title: Is It Harder to Write About Happiness Than Its Opposite?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Leslie Jamison and Adam Kirsch discuss the difficulties in writing about happiness.

title: The Read Around: Blake Bailey
description: The biographer Blake Bailey tells the story of his own family in The Splendid Things We Planned.

title: Conflict Erupts in Public Rebuke on C.I.A. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  A festering conflict between the Central Intelligence Agency and its congressional overseers broke into the open Tuesday when Senator Dianne Feinstein, chairwoman of the Intelligence Committee and one of the C.I.A.s staunchest defenders, delivered an extraordinary denunciation of the agency, accusing it of withholding information about its treatment of prisoners and trying to intimidate committee staff members investigating the detention program.

title: A Story of Perseverance
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn.  Inside the mixed martial arts studio, Stuart Scott lifted the black T-shirt that read, Everyday I Fight. Beneath was a footlong scar that bisected the ESPN anchors washboard abs.

title: WWS 594, Economics of the Welfare State: The State of the Welfare State
description: Slides here (pdf).

title: Plea Deal Talks Begin After Sexual Assault Trial Against Army General Is Halted
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  In a series of phone calls and emails on Tuesday, military officials and lawyers for Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair began their first full day of negotiations on a plea agreement that would end the sexual assault case against the general, who is accused of bullying a junior officer into sex and threatening her life.

title: A Kindly Detour From the Bronx
description: Dear Diary:

title: Video: Blake Bailey on Writing About His Own Life
description: In The Read Around, a weekly video feature, authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, the biographer Blake Bailey discusses writing about his own life, including his troubled relationship with his brother, in The Splendid Things We Planned.

title: Globe Theater Draws Criticism for Planned North Korea Trip
description: LONDON  The Globe Theaters plan to take its production of Hamlet to North Korea in 2015 has drawn criticism from the human rights group Amnesty International, The Guardian reported. The stop in North Korea is part of the Globes ambitious plan to tour Hamlet to every country in the world over the next two years; the tour begins in England on April 23, the 450th anniversary of the day traditionally observed as Shakespeares birthday, at the companys home theater here.

title: Market Report | Grand Prix
description: Indulge a need for speed with revved-up watches driven by dashboard aesthetics and racing-color combinations.

title: Founder Missing in Mens Wearhouse Deal for Jos. A. Bank
description: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | The man who inadvertently lit the fuse that led to the hottest takeover battle in years was left unmentioned in the announcement of a $1.8 billion merger of two once-warring mens suits chains.

title: Salesman Swimming With Sharks
description: Trying to explain why young people should buy health insurance, President Obama said his health care plan would cost consumers no more than their cellphone bills. His host, Zach Galifianakis, looked bored. Is this what they mean by drones?

title: Authorities ID Passenger
description: Malaysian authorities said one of the two stolen passport holders on the missing flight MH370 is an Iranian who might have been migrating to Germany.

title: Bitcoin Foundation Bolsters Its Ranks
description: The Bitcoin Foundation is adding to its ranks as regulators around the world struggle with how to oversee the evolving world of digital currency.

title: Today in Small Business: #Hashtags
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Times Minute | Washington Today
description: A look at the unconventional political tactics in Washington, including President Obama's appearance on a comedy show, a Senate all-nighter and a confirmation hearing.

title: Times Minute | Washington Today
description: In the Video

title: N.S.A. Nominee Promotes Cyberwar Units
description: WASHINGTON  All of the major combat commands in the United States military will soon have dedicated forces to conduct cyberattacks alongside their air, naval and ground capabilities, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, President Obamas nominee to run the National Security Agency, told the Senate on Tuesday. He said the activation of the long-discussed combat units would help counter the perception around the world that the United States is an easier mark for cyberattacks because it did not have the will to respond.

title: The Foreign Currency Fix
description: Regulators say that a group of London traders, known as the cartel and the mafia, illegally dipped into the $5.3-trillion-a-day currency trade.

title: Choosing a Preschool: Order Amid Chaos, or Structure Above All?
description: The rickety elevator opened into this cluttered loft with hanging papier-mch legumes and what sounded like 200 screeching children. Jon and I barely removed Zees winter layers before she was off to the (what else) doll section, which was mountainous, with a cradle and wooden kitchen. This Bohemian nursery had no formal interview process but instead a wine-and-cheese open house and now, a family meeting, with at least 10 families. The schools curriculum centered on choice: Each day, each child chose whatever activity  music, art, dance  she wanted.

title: Farewell, Latitude
description: On Oct. 31, 2011, The International Herald Tribune started an opinion blog featuring strong views from writers around the world. Over the next two years and two months, each post in this series tried to capture the feel of a place, from a fresh perspective.

title: France Returns Three Paintings Looted by Nazis
description: PARIS  A year after France pledged to search aggressively for the rightful owners of art looted by the Nazis in World War II, the French culture minister returned three oil paintings on Tuesday here to families who had been pressing claims for years.

title: Demand Stronger Than Expected for Puerto Rico Debt
description: Updated, 6:46 p.m. | Faced with strong demand from hedge funds and wealthy individuals, Puerto Rico sold 17 percent more debt on Tuesday than it had originally planned, a sign that the commonwealth still has ample access to the capital markets.

title: Blackstone to Acquire Cybersecurity Firm Accuvant
description: With the prospect of cyberattacks keeping corporations on edge, the Blackstone Group is investing in a company that aims to counteract such threats.

title: Bank of England Governor Pledges More Integrity After Currency Inquiry
description: LONDON  The Bank of Englands reputation is at stake as its independent directors conduct a review into whether bank officials knew of or condoned potential manipulation of the currency markets, Mark J. Carney, the banks governor, told lawmakers on Tuesday.

title: Citing Urgent Need, U.S. Calls on Hospitals to Hone Disaster Plans
description: Federal officials are proposing sweeping new requirements for American health care facilities  from large hospitals to small group homes for the mentally disabled  intended to ensure their readiness to care for patients during disasters.

title: Confusion Over Planes Route Frustrates Families and Search
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  Malaysian authorities now believe that a jetliner missing since Saturday may have radically changed course around the time that it lost contact with ground controllers, news that added to the air of confusion and disarray surrounding the investigation and search operation. But they gave conflicting accounts of the apparent course change and of what may have happened afterward.

title: Victory in Florida Race Bolsters Midterm Hopes for Republicans
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  In a major victory for Republicans in the battle for control of Congress, David Jolly, a former lobbyist, narrowly won a special election for a House seat on Tuesday in a hotly contested swing district, giving the party an expensive triumph in its fight against President Obamas health care plan.

title: Judge Hears Arguments on Subpoenas to Christie Associates
description: TRENTON  The questions for Bridget Anne Kelly from reporters were so relentless  Does she have any regrets? How would it hurt her to surrender her emails? How is she holding up?  that her lawyer finally felt compelled to answer.

title: Freedom From Driving
description: Americans are catching on to the joys of not driving.

title: Good Irish Coffee Starts With the Cow
description: Craft cocktail bartenders can be quite particular about ingredients. To create the perfect drink, theyll go out of their way to secure an obscure brand of whiskey or rum, a hard-to-get foreign liqueur, or a fruit or herb available only on alternate Wednesdays at a farmers market in Queens. But the Dead Rabbit, a financial district bar that evokes 19th-century New York, may be the first in town to hunt down a special cream for its Irish coffee.

title: New Skrillex Album Revealed in Phone App
description: The D.J. and producer Skrillex, long known for his surprising use of timbres, textures and found sounds  and for unusual release strategies, like giving away his 2007 EP, My Name Is Skrillex, on his MySpace page  has found an unexpected way to release his new album, Recess. The set was scheduled for a conventional release, on CD and as a download, on March 18.

title: Image of the Day: March 11
Justice Dept. Is Said to Look at G.M. Actions on Safety Flaws
description: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation into General Motors decade-long failure to address deadly safety problems before announcing a huge vehicle recall last month, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: As Goes Andrew Sullivan, So Goes Pluralism
description: In the interests of further clarity,I want to return to the subject of gay marriage and religious liberty, and respond to some comments from Andrew Sullivan on the subject. Answeringmy original column on the same-sex marriage endgame and its potential aftermath, Sullivan drew a distinction that I think a lot of libertarian-minded Americans would be inclined draw:

title: Farm-to-Table Living Takes Root
description: GILBERT, Ariz.  In many American suburbs, outward signs of life are limited to the blue glow of television screens flickering behind energy-efficient windows. But in a subdivision of this bedroom community outside Phoenix, amid precision-cut lawns and Craftsman-style homes, lambs caper in common green areas, chickens scratch in a citrus grove and residents roam rows of heirloom vegetables to see what might be good for dinner.

title: Cyprus Names Its Top Auditor to Lead Central Bank
description: PARIS  Cyprus on Tuesday appointed Chrystalla Georghadji, an anticorruption watchdog, to replace its central banker, who resigned abruptly a day earlier in the face of tensions with the government.

title: A Camp for Those With Nut Allergies
description: Medomak Family Camp in Washington, Me., always accommodates campers who have nut allergies, but this year its offering a special nut-free week, June 22 to 28.

title: Barack Obama, Between Two Ferns
description: As frustrating as President Obama can be (think drones, wiretapping and refusing to get a full accounting of torture and rendition), he can also be incredibly charming and funny. Its hard to imagine any president (including Bill Clinton) going on Between Two Ferns with Zach Galifianakis and doing far more than just holding his own.

title: Iranian Lawmaker Blames U.S. for Plane Disappearance
description: With the fate and location of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet still unexplained on Tuesday, the police were investigating the possibilities of hijacking, sabotage and possible psychological or personal problems among the crew and passengers, while other agencies in Malaysia continued to investigate noncriminal explanations, as Thomas Fuller, Jane Perlez and Alan Cowell reported.

title: Keith Richards Is Writing a Childrens Book. Yes, a Childrens Book.
description: Its not as if Keith Richards has time on his hands: the Rolling Stones, after all, are in the middle of a Far East tour that will take them to Shanghai on Wednesday, then to Singapore and, next week, to Australia. But Mr. Richards, who wrote Life (2010), his doorstop of an autobiography, when the Stones were between projects, has another book in the works, this time with an audience of children in mind. Little, Brown Books for Young Readers announced on Tuesday that it would publish Mr. Richardss Gus & Me: The Story of My Granddad and My First Guitar, as both a hardcover book with a CD and an ebook on Sept. 9.

title: Inquiries to Change Dynamics of Currency Trading
description: Around the world, investigators are trying to find out if the largely unregulated foreign exchange market was manipulated. Even before the investigations are completed, the pace of change will pick up in the $5 trillion-a-day market, in both what moves currencies and the way business is done.

title: Purim Pastries, a Library Cafe and More
description: To Enjoy: For Purim, Triangles With Savory Fillings

title: Amid Escalating Violence, Israeli Strike Kills 3 Militants in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli airstrike in the southeast Gaza Strip on Tuesday morning killed three Palestinian militants who the Israeli military said had fired a mortar at its soldiers patrolling near the border, hours after a pilotless Israeli surveillance drone crashed nearby.

title: The C.I.A. Torture Cover-Up
description: It was outrageous enough when two successive presidents papered over the Central Intelligence Agencys history of illegal detention, rendition, torture and fruitless harsh interrogation of terrorism suspects. Now the leader of the Senate intelligence committee, Dianne Feinstein, has provided stark and convincing evidence that the C.I.A. may have committed crimes to prevent the exposure of interrogations that she said were far different and far more harsh than anything the agency had described to Congress.

title: Feinstein Questions C.I.A. Search
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein states on the Senate floor that the Central Intelligence Agency has accessed the computers of the Senate intelligence committee.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Board Sides With President, Report Suggests
description: The board of the Minnesota Orchestra is staying silent on its plans to try to recover from a debilitating 16-month lockout, but a report published Tuesday in The Star Tribune suggested it is siding with the orchestras president against the wishes of its former music director.

title: Front and Center in Ukraine Race, a Leader of the Far Right
description: KIEV, Ukraine  During the Independence Square protests, Dmytro Yarosh made a name for himself as an expert with firebombs. Now, just weeks later, Mr. Yarosh, leader of the right-wing coalition known as Right Sector, says he is running for president.

title: Helping Families With Chinese Children
description: Xiaoning Wang, an immigrant from China based in New York, was inspired to start her company after seeing so many American parents adopt Chinese girls. Her company sells Chinese educational products.

title: U.N. Denies Altering Image of Palestinian Refugees in Damascus
description: A spokesman for the United Nations agency that provides assistance to Palestinian refugees rejected claims that an arresting image of thousands of people waiting for food distribution on a ruined street in Damascus recently had been digitally altered.

title: No Questions About I.V.F. in Israel
description: In the 13 years since I had left Jerusalem, souk Mahane Yehuda. which sells fruit, vegetables, spices and household goods, had become a thriving restaurant and night-life scene. A D.J. was spinning in one of the side alleys, 20-somethings were smoking hookahs at a bar, and Solomon and I were meeting some of his friends for some kubbeh in an establishment famous for its bulgar-encrusted meatballs.

title: Ask Me Anything
description: Well, maybe not anything but in imitation of my fellow columnist Nick Kristof, who boldly fielded reader questionsa few months ago, Im inviting your volleys this week. The format will be roughly the same as it was with my colleague, with the slight, not-entirely-flattering-to-me difference that he was writing from Kenya and Ill probably be writing from a coffee shop in Capitol Hill: Readers should post their questions in the comment thread of this post, well sift for a representative selection, and Ill try to wrap as many answers as possible into a post later on this week. (And, hopefully, contain my prolix tendencies along the way.)

title: Owners Compare Notes on Expansion and Software Challenges
description: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about new deals, partnerships and software woes.

title: SXSW Q. and A. | Tilda Swinton
description: Will they bite, Tilda Swinton asks, or not? This is Swintons distillation of the current tweenish vampire formula, offered without a touch of snobbery. I am out of that loop just because Im idle and have other things to do, she says. Im not not interested, I just havent seen Twilight.'

title: Virtual Exchange Plans Are Sought in New York
description: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | At a time when some government agencies are backing away from virtual currency, New Yorks top financial regulator is taking a big step forward.

title: Senators Draft Housing Finance Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  The top Democrat and Republican on the Senate Banking Committee said on Tuesday that they had agreed on a plan to overhaul the nations housing finance system and eliminate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage giants that were bailed out by taxpayers in 2008.

title: The Drug-Fueled Uphill Ride and Headlong Crash of a Secular Saint
description: Early in her compelling account of the downfall of the cyclist Lance Armstrong, Juliet Macur provides us with a glimpse of just how manipulative he remained, even as his world crashed down around him. Cut loose by his sponsors and steeped in legal issues stemming from the lifetime ban he received for doping, Mr. Armstrong, a record seven-time winner of the Tour de France, invited Ms. Macur to visit him at his Texas estate as he prepared to downsize to less pricey accommodations.

title: SXSW 2014: Another Year, Even More Sprawl
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Has it been a year already? Im back in Austin for the South By Southwest Music Festival, the showcase for 2,000-plus bands that just keeps sprawling further: beyond its Texas roots-rock origins, beyond its rapid spread as an indie and alternative and fringe pop showcase, beyond its geographically particular, you-had-to-be-there status to its Internet incarnation as a web stage for events to be streamed and archived, photographed, Tweeted and Tumblred.

title: 'Teenage' Excerpt | Bright Young People
description: A clip from Matt Wolfs documentary Teenage.

title: The Gun Report: March 11, 2014
description: Make no mistake: Peter Lanza knew his son, Adam, the perpetrator of the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary, was a very sick boy.

title: Rogers Appears Before Senate
description: Vice Admiral Michael S. Rogers testifies at a Senate Armed Services Committee on his nomination to run the National Security Agency.

title: Will the Real Satoshi Nakamoto Please Stand Up?
description: TOKYO Satoshi Nakamoto of Fujisawa, Japan, is a shoe repairman.

title: The New Big East: In Spartan Offices, an Ornate Vision
description: On the 24th floor of the Proskauer Rose law firms office in Midtown Manhattan, Val Ackerman greeted a visitor last week for a tour of the temporary headquarters of the new Big East Conference.

title: Health Care Enrollment Falls Short of Goal, With Deadline Approaching
description: WASHINGTON  Almost a million people signed up last month for private health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, federal officials said Tuesday, bringing the total to date to 4.2 million but leaving the Obama administration well short of its original goal, with less than a month to go before the end of the open enrollment period.

title: Text to Text | The Prince and Why Machiavelli Still Matters
description: The political philosopher Niccol Machiavelli wrote The Prince as a manual on leadership and governing during the late Italian Renaissance, a time of feuding family dynasties and warring city-states. But even though 500 years have passed, and the world is a very different place, The Prince somehow feels as relevant as ever in modern culture and politics.

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and More
description: Japan and Elsewhere  Picture of the Day

title: C. J. Chivers on Instagram
description: The senior correspondent for The New York Times has been documenting the crisis in Ukraine on Instagram and Twitter.

title: Au Zaatar, an Arabian-French Bistro, Opens
description: Headliner

title: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Japan, Afghanistan, Istanbul and Israel.

title: Whats In It | Cookie Dough Oreos
description: The makers of Oreo cookies have outdone themselves with their latest attempt to jazz up their icon. But how do they simulate raw cookie dough without using flour or eggs?

title: Theres a Big Difference Between Union Money and Koch Money
description: For dozens of readers, our editorial this morning on the Democratic criticism of the Koch brothers left out something crucial: the big financial muscle of unions in backing liberal politcians.

title: A Place to Park and Cook Up a Storm
description: BEND, Ore.  Residents of this mountain town like doing things outdoors, and dining seems to be no exception.

title: The Cookie Dough Oreo
description: MIMICRY IS AN ART FORM in processed foods, and the makers of Oreo cookies have outdone themselves with their latest attempt to jazz up their icon: the Cookie Dough Oreo. The fun in dissecting this marvel of food engineering begins right on the front of the package, which sports pictures of real-looking cookie dough and chocolate chips, though neither is found inside. Instead, this newest version of the Oreo draws on a mix of extra sugar, precision chemistry and a marketing maneuver that industry insiders call permission to evoke the mere impression of cookie dough. Its success may be measured less in sales than in the buzz it generates for the Oreo line.

title: Scoring a Baseball Bargain at Spring Training
description: Last Tuesday morning at JetBlue Park in Fort Myers, Fla., David Ortiz, the Red Sox designated hitter, finished chatting with a few Tampa Bay Rays and lumbered over to a tour group of fans watching batting practice from behind the third-base line.

title: In 9 Years of Work, Just 3 Public Toilets Go Live
description: For more than a generation, bureaucracy, politics and corruption thwarted three successive New York mayors from modernizing the citys shabby bus shelters, newsstands and public toilets.

title: The Intrepid Explorer, Leaping From Lush to Spiky
description: A recital by a thoughtful young pianist in a basement performance space that seats about 150 people may not seem particularly significant. Yet on Monday night at SubCulture, as I listened to the pianist Benjamin Hochmans sensitive, exciting renditions of four contemporary works that explore the form of theme and variation (including one premiere), I kept thinking that classical music doesnt get better than this.

title: With High Hopes and Deep Pockets, The Times Gambles on NYT Now
description: Updated, 12:15 p.m.

title: Extended-Stay Hotels Climb in Manhattan
description: A fast-growing class of properties in New York is encouraging people not only to visit, but to stay awhile.

title: Turning Coffee Into Water to Expand Business Model
description: What do shoes and coffee have in common?

title: Going Solo Instead of Joining the Chorus
description: The outside makes no grand statements. A glass wall stares out at a not-yet-trendy block of Orchard Street. Its blank except for the small menu posted by the door, offering five courses for the relatively modest sum of $55. Hanging on one inside wall, more art than ad, and almost invisible unless you are walking southbound very close to the window, is the restaurants name in red neon script: Contra.

title: Lips Locked, With Musical Chairs
description: At the Joyce Theater on Saturday, the Brazilian dance company Focus Cia de Dana made its American debut with a work titled As Canes Que Voc Danou Pra Mim. The program did not provide an English translation of that title, The Songs You Danced for Me. Nor did it offer help with the Portuguese lyrics of the many songs to which the company danced. Yet the most significant separation between an American audience and the works meanings was most likely not linguistic.

title: Beethoven in Broad Strokes, and With Mugging
description: There seemed ample reason on Thursday evening to look forward to the English maestro Roger Norringtons performance of Beethovens Missa Solemnis with the Orchestra of St. Lukes and the Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall.

title: Get Out Your Corkscrew
description: Wine School, a monthly column, invites you to drink wine with Eric Asimov. In each installment, Mr. Asimov chooses a type of wine for you to try at home.   At the end of the month, Mr. Asimov will address some of the points in your comments and answer questions in a follow-up column. This months wine selection: Bordeaux.

title: New Roots in Carroll Gardens
description: Nick Donovan chose Carroll Gardens twice. When Mr. Donovan, a lawyer who had just married, first moved to this leafy part of brownstone Brooklyn in 1993, it was very much a front-stoop community, where older neighbors, usually Italian-Americans with deep roots in the area, would gather outside their homes to share pastry and news of the day.

title: Miracles Know No Borders: Upstart Russia Tops Potent U.S.
description: SOCHI, Russia  The men in sleds on the ice gathered and waved their sticks above their heads, swinging them like swords. More, more, more, they motioned, and the partisan fans at Shayba Arena obliged. They waved their flags, stamped their feet and sang in the aisles, surrounding their team in noise and love.

title: Herbalife Shares Fall as Ackman Makes New Accusations
description: Shares in Herbalife fell by more than 2 percent on Tuesday as the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman accused the company, which sells vitamins, shakes and other supplements, of operating illegally in China.

title: Q. and A. | Filmmaker Matt Wolf on the Origins of Teenage Culture
description: A video excerpt from Matt Wolfs documentary, Teenage, features the Bright Young Things of London from the 1920s.

title: Top Disney TV Official to Step Down
description: LOS ANGELES  In a move that stunned Hollywood, the television industrys most powerful woman, Anne M. Sweeney, said on Tuesday that she would step down as president of the Disney-ABC Television Group to become a TV director.

title: Hotel Discounts for Egencia Users
description: An increasing number of travelers are turning to their smart phones and tablets to make travel arrangements on the fly.

title: An Identity He Wont Cede That Easily
description: The line was easy to deliver  maybe Im not that brave  but it rattled the actor Armando Riesco during early performances of The Happiest Song Plays Last last month. His character, a young Iraq war veteran named Elliot Ortiz, had faced up to so many traumas already; burdening him with self-doubt at the climax seemed a cruel twist by the playwright.

title: The Voices of Montserrat
description: Europes oldest boys choir, the Escolania de Montserrat, has eased its residency requirements to raise enrollment. The move was effective and now they are on their first American tour.

title: Park Avenue, the Art Gallery
description: Alice Aycock, the sculptor, was holding her breath.

title: N.S.A. Timeline of Surveillance Law Developments
description: A chart, apparently from an internal National Security Agency presentation, lists milestones in surveillance rules over nearly four decades.

title: Traces of Lives, From Scores to Cigarettes
description: Carnegie Hall, in its Rose Museum, is hosting an exhibition of two dozen priceless musical scores and personal items produced or once owned by composers whose music is being performed in Carnegies festival Vienna: City of Dreams. And one out-and-out fake.

title: Classification Guide for Stellarwind Program
description: A guide to secrecy restrictions for Bush administration surveillance and data collection programs that operated outside FISA rules.

title: Dancing With Doors and Amid Trash Cans
description: Technical difficulties are bound to crop up in work that relies heavily on props and precarious contraptions, like the daredevil vignettes devised by Brian Sanders for his company, Junk. Since 1998, Mr. Sanders, who is based in Philadelphia, has been integrating found objects  doors, trash cans, bicycle parts  into a kind of grungy blend of Cirque du Soleil, Stomp and Momix, the gymnastically inclined company with whom he danced and choreographed for 10 years.

title: Offering Choral Solace for Composers Laments
description: That Ernst Krenek, an Austrian composer of Czech descent, should be moved to write a work based on the biblical Lamentations seems entirely natural, given the personal woes and professional tribulations he faced at the time. A gifted, prolific artist who had mingled with Mahler, Berg and the French upstarts of Les Six, Krenek in 1941 was teaching at Vassar College, exiled by the rise of the Nazis, who had declared his music degenerate, and embattled by jealous rivals who sought his dismissal.

title: Classification Guide for FISA, the Protect America Act and the FISA Amendments Act
description: A guide to secrecy restrictions for various aspects of programs to spy on domestic soil for national security purposes.

title: Ashcroft Memo on Intelligence Sharing Procedures
description: In August 2002, the attorney general issued new procedures that lowered safeguards on providing information about Americans to foreign governments that was deemed relevant to terrorism issues.

title: N.S.A. Memo Expands Access to FISA Information
description: In 2006, the National Security Agency sought to expand access to Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act information to code-breakers around the country.

title: Celebrating the Pianist Ursula Oppens at 70
description: Before playing Frederic Rzewskis The People United Will Never Be Defeated! at Symphony Space on Thursday evening, the pianist Ran Dank spoke about the legacy of Ursula Oppens, his former teacher.

title: A Relentless Widening of Disparity in Wealth
description: What if inequality were to continue growing years or decades into the future? Say the richest 1 percent of the population amassed a quarter of the nations income, up from about a fifth today. What about half?

title: Chobani Said to Seek Investment That Would Value It at $5 Billion
description: Big investors are vying for a piece of Chobani, the fast-growing yogurt maker in upstate New York.

title: Q&A: Thomas Piketty on the Wealth Divide
description: Income inequality moved with astonishing speed from the boring backwaters of economic studies to the defining challenge of our time. It found Thomas Piketty waiting for it.

title: Talking With Readers About Owen, Disney and Autism
description: In last weekends magazine, Ron Suskind wrote about learning to communicate with his son, Owen, who developed regressive autism at age 3, through the language of Disney. Readers were invited to submit questions to Suskind about the article, which is adapted from his coming book, Life, Animated. Here are his responses:

title: In Familiar Scene, Bayern Advances and Arsenal Is Out
description: MUNICH  Inside the shimmering Allianz Arena, there is a sleek and charming museum devoted to all things Bayern Munich. The museum has all types of exhibits, including a new room devoted to the legendary goalkeeper Sepp Maier, a fascinating (if somewhat cringe-inducing) collection of music recorded by Munich players over the years and  of course  a slew of screens showing the best moments from the clubs greatest games.

title: CFDA Award Nominees Are Announced
description: Theyd like to thank the academy  no, make that the council.

title: End the SAT? Discuss. Cite Evidence.
Violence in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Training Russia Specialists
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Web Turns 25, Its Creator Talks About Its Future
description: In 1989, Tim Berners-Lee, a software engineer, sat in his small office at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research near Geneva and started work on a new system called the World Wide Web.

title: A Turnaround for Bitcoin at SXSW
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  At last years South by Southwest gathering, regarded as the place where are the hip technology companies showed up, Bitcoin was still such an underdog that it was not important enough to command a single event or panel.

title: How a Court Secretly Evolved, Extending U.S. Spies Reach
description: WASHINGTON  Ten months after the Sept. 11 attacks, the nations surveillance court delivered a ruling that intelligence officials consider a milestone in the secret history of American spying and privacy law. Called the Raw Take order  classified docket No. 02-431  it weakened restrictions on sharing private information about Americans, according to documents and interviews.

title: Reading Facial Expressions
description: To the Editor:

title: One Singular Sensation for Award Winners
description: THE penchant among people who work in advertising and marketing to recognize their own achievements is evidenced by a seemingly endless skein of awards they bestow at dozens of ceremonies each year. How do they love themselves? Let me count the ways: Ace Awards, ADC Awards, American Advertising Awards, Andys, Cannes Lions, Clios, D&AD Awards, Effies, the New York Festivals, Obie Awards, One Show awards, PromaxBDA awards, Reggie Awards, U.S. Hispanic Idea Awards...

title: Strip Clubs and Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Racism and Irrational Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Kievs Message to Moscow
description: KIEV, Ukraine  AT this very moment, in plain view of the entire world, the final demise of the Soviet empire is unfolding. The plan for its resurrection, long in the works at the Kremlin, has failed: Ukraine has proved that it has matured into an independent state that will determine its own domestic and foreign policy.

title: Stars Peverley Has Tests After Collapsing in Game
description: Dallas Stars center Rich Peverley spent Tuesday at a Dallas-area hospital, undergoing tests to determine what brought on the cardiac event that caused him to collapse during the first period against the Columbus Blue Jackets on Monday night.

title: Set Free in 1995 Killings, 3 Bronx Men File Suits Alleging Police Misconduct
description: Three Bronx men who were set free last year after spending nearly 18 years in prison for two murders they say they did not commit are suing New York City and the two lead police detectives on the case, accusing them of deliberately using tainted or false evidence.

title: Victoria J. Cerami
description: Ms. Cerami, 54, is the chief executive of Cerami & Associates, a company based in New York that provides acoustical, audiovisual andtechnologydesign work for commercial and residential properties. Its recent projects include work at the Hudson Yards development, One World Trade Center and the Barclays Center.

title: The Future of Internet Freedom
description: OVER the next decade, approximately five billion people will become connected to the Internet. The biggest increases will be in societies that, according to the human rights group Freedom House, are severely censored: places where clicking on an objectionable article can get your entire extended family thrown in prison, or worse.

title: Penalties for Mr. Putin
description: It is important at this stage of the confrontation in Ukraine to clarify that the issue is not simply who owns Crimea. There is a difficult question there, and as secession-minded people in Quebec, Scotland or Catalonia have shown, there are legitimate ways to raise it.

title: Fukushimas Continuing Tragedy
description: Tuesday was the third anniversary of the triple disaster that struck the eastern Japanese prefectures of Iwate, Miyagi and Fukushima: the earthquake, tsunami and the nuclear power plant meltdowns in Fukushima. The catastrophe killed 15,884, with 2,636 still missing. The governments reconstruction efforts have been insufficient and painfully slow.

title: Weakness or Realism in Foreign Policy?
Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Removing 9/11 Artifacts From New Jerseys Nest of Political Patronage
description: Still up for grabs from the ruins of the World Trade Center are roughly 90 pieces of steel and 200 other artifacts  things like bits of antenna, a wrecked car, turnstiles  recovered after Sept. 11. Remnants of a dwindling inventory, they have been stored in a hangar at Kennedy International Airport for more than a decade, as pieces have been shipped to 50 states and at least seven countries for memorial sites and museums.

title: A Cardinals Inspiration to Move Ahead
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The image was heartbreaking, no matter your allegiance. The rookie is alone, on his knees in the dirt. He is looking down, and in his right hand he grips his red helmet, about to fire it to the ground. Beside him, stamped with the World Series logo, is the base he had tried in vain to reach before the tag.

title: Exploiting Californias Drought
description: The San Joaquin Valley in California can be stunningly beautiful: On a visit two weeks ago, I saw billions of pink almond blossoms peaking, with the Sierra Nevada towering over all. It can also be a hideous place, the air choked with microparticles of unpleasant origins (dried cow dung, sprayed chemicals, blowing over-fertilized soil), its cities like Fresno and Bakersfield sprawling incoherently and its small towns suffering from poverty, populated by immigrants from places as near as Baja, Mexico, and as far as Punjab, India.

title: Sprint Owners New Appeal for Merger With T-Mobile
description: WASHINGTON  American broadband is slow and expensive. But Masayoshi Son wants to help.

title: Ohio Looks at Whether Fracking Led to 2 Quakes
description: Ohio officials said Tuesday that an oil and gas well near the site of two small earthquakes was undergoing hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, when the quakes occurred.

title: At Trial of Bin Laden Relative, Witness Describes Meeting 9/11 Mastermind
description: A British operative for Al Qaeda testified on Tuesday that, before abandoning a plot to blow up an airplane, he flew from Pakistan to the Netherlands and then on to Britain while concealing a bomb in his shoe.

title: U.N. Denies That Syria Image Was Faked
description: A United Nations photograph showing a sea of hungry Palestinians awaiting emergency food amid the detritus of their bomb-ravaged neighborhood near Damascus has been retweeted more than eight million times in the past few weeks, becoming such an arresting image of the Syrian civil war that some blogosphere skeptics have suggested that it was digitally faked. The suggestion provoked a passionate denial on Tuesday by the official responsible for distributing the photo.

title: Sculptures Vandalized at Bellevue Hospitals Serene Escape
description: The long-awaited sunshine beckoned, and doctors and staff members at Bellevue Hospital Center wandered out on Tuesday to the small garden that has long been a peaceful escape for those struggling with serious issues inside. But the garden was anything but tranquil. The animal sculptures had been smashed and destroyed.

title: The Spies Who Didnt Love Her
description: WASHINGTON  Even Homeland never thought of a plot this wild.

title: Mets Niese Is Rocked, and Is Happy for It
description: JUPITER, Fla.  In his first game action since he felt shoulder discomfort earlier during spring training, Mets starter Jon Niese was shelled by the St. Louis Cardinals on Tuesday, allowing four runs and six hits in two innings of a 9-8 comeback victory. Not only that, his velocity was generally down, which would seem more concerning.

title: Banamex Fraud Exposes Challenges for Citi in Mexico
description: For some top Citigroup executives, it was a kind of little black book: an informal tally of Mexican companies that they feared could imperil the banks crown jewel  a sprawling retail lender called Banamex.

title: Cuomo Hires G.O.P. Adviser as Aides Shift to Re-election Campaign
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has reached into the opposition bench to hire a new adviser, recruiting a well-known Republican strategist to join the governors office as other aides leave to plan his re-election campaign.

title: Sabathia Is Encouraged by an Outing, in Part Because Its Only March
description: VIERA, Fla.  It is not even half past March yet, which means pitching lines and batting averages are written in disappearing ink.

title: As Homeless Shelter Population Rises, Advocates Push Mayor on Policies
description: The number of homeless people staying overnight in New York City shelters reached a dismal record of 53,615 in January, a new study has found, prompting advocates to press Mayor Bill de Blasio to follow through on promises to undo policies that they say drove the citys homeless population to skyrocket in the first place.

title: Fears Spread That Venezuela Is Approaching Bloody Face-Off
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The gunmen descended a street on Monday night toward a park taken over by student demonstrators in the western city of San Cristbal, the crucible of the protests that have shaken Venezuela. They opened fire, and a 23-year-old student leader, Daniel Tinoco, fell. Hit in the upper body, he died before he got to a hospital, fellow protesters said.

title: Clinton Aide Linked to Campaign Scandal
description: A wealthy Washington businessman embroiled in a campaign finance scandal communicated with a longtime adviser to Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton on an illegal canvassing effort to bolster Mrs. Clintons 2008 presidential campaign, according to court documents.

title: Woman Charged in Death Caused by Silicone Injection
description: Plastic surgery is not the first thing that comes to mind when one walks into the Liberty Inn Hotel, the infamous lodge in Manhattans meatpacking district that charges by the hour and is known for romantic trysts.

title: Political Killings Still Plaguing Post-Qaddafi Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  For Judge Jamal Bennour, one of the leaders of the Libyan uprising, the day the revolution turned sour was when his friend and fellow lawyer, Abdul-Salam al-Musmari, was shot dead in front of him.

title: Bill McLaughlin, CBS News Correspondent, Dies at 76
description: Bill McLaughlin, a CBS News correspondent who covered conflicts in Vietnam and the Middle East, the assassination of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games and the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981, died on Friday in Waterbury, Conn. He was 76.

title: Turner Gives the Final Four a Local Flavor
description: Listen up, local voices of college basketball. A chosen few of you might be calling the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Penn Beats Princeton in Showdown for Womens N.C.A.A. Bid
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  A rare finish to an Ivy League womens basketball season turned into an improbable one when Penn stunned Princeton, 80-64, on Tuesday night to clinch its first N.C.A.A. tournament berth since the 2003-4 season.

title: De Blasio Cites Drop in Crime Since Taking Office
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who frequently criticized the Police Department in his previous job as public advocate, highlighted statistics on Tuesday showing a drop in crime during his first two months in office, saying that his approach to policing had already paid dividends.

title: Hunein Maassab, Who Developed FluMist Vaccine, Dies at 87
description: Hunein Maassab witnessed a transformational moment in public health when he was a young doctoral student at the University of Michigan. It happened on April 12, 1955, the day his mentor, Dr. Thomas Francis Jr., announced that he had completed a vast field trial involving nearly two million children to determine the effectiveness of what at the time seemed like a miracle drug: a vaccine for polio.

title: How Democrats Can Compete for the White Working Class
description: On the surface, the Democratic Partys bid to win back the votes of the white working class looks like an impossible task.

title: Death of Boy Caught in Melee Spurs Protests Across Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  In the largest protests since last summer, thousands of people hit the streets in more than 15 Turkish cities on Tuesday to protest the death of a 15-year-old boy who became a symbol of civilian resistance after he was struck in the head by a tear-gas canister fired by the police during antigovernment demonstrations and slipped into a coma.

title: Obama Will Seek Broad Expansion of Overtime Pay
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama this week will seek to force American businesses to pay more overtime to millions of workers, the latest move by his administration to confront corporations that have had soaring profits even as wages have stagnated.

title: Im Buying!
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This is one of those themes where you would be well-advised not to be drinking a beverage when that Aha! moment comes, lest you blow said beverage out your nose. Im just warning you.

title: Newest Edition of Forbidden Broadway Set to Begin Performances
description: Forbidden Broadway: Alive and Still Kicking, the current incarnation of Gerard Alessandrinis  popular revue, in which the theater worlds hits (and the actors who play in them) are gleefully skewered, began previews at the Davenport Theater at the end of February.

title: Libyas Prime Minister Ousted in Chaos Over Tanker
description: CAIRO  Libyas transitional Parliament voted on Tuesday to remove its prime minister as his government conceded that despite days of bluster it was powerless to stop a tanker from sailing away with an illicit shipment of Libyan oil.

title: Universities Try a Cultural Bridge to Lure Foreign Students
description: CORVALLIS, Oregon  As the anthropology instructor engaged her class, a fault line quickly developed. American students answered and asked questions, even offered opinions, but the foreigners  half the class, most from China  sat in silence.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 11, 2014
description: March 11, 2014

title: If Jackson Joins the Knicks, His Options at the Beginning Are Few
description: If he does agree to try to rescue the Knicks, what will Phil Jackson be getting himself into?

title: Obama Team Debates How to Punish Russia
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama searches for a way to contain and ultimately reverse Russias invasion of southern Ukraine without using force, his team finds itself torn over just how far to go using the economic weapons in Americas arsenal.

title: Nice Chatting, Mayor. Now Squeeze In. Press Corps Selfie!
description: After getting pummeled by snowstorms all winter long, Mayor Bill de Blasio emerged from City Hall to bask in Tuesdays warm and sunny weather, briefly moving the business of governing New York City to the great outdoors.

title: China Torn Between Policies and Partnership
description: BEIJING  From the NATO air war in Kosovo to the American invasion of Iraq, Chinas opposition to foreign interference in a countrys internal affairs has been one of the mainstays of its foreign policy, along with a strategic partnership with Russia to counteract the diplomatic and economic might of the West.

title: Queens Councilwoman Confronts Library Leader
description: Last Thursday, trustees of the Queens Library convened inside the Jamaica branch for a regularly scheduled meeting, but with a focus: Tackling the broadening scandal surrounding the library systems president, Thomas W. Galante, who is under federal and city investigation for possible misuse of money meant to improve the librarys 62 branches.

title: Status Quo at Elite New York Schools: Few Blacks and Hispanics
description: Seven black students have been offered a chance to start classes at Stuyvesant High School in September, two fewer than received offers last year. For Hispanics, the number has dropped to 21 from 24.

title: A Sisters Love, Not Tempered by Expectations
description: From the filmmaker, Kelly OBrien: My daughter Emma was just 3 when Teddy was born, with a viral infection he contracted in utero that caused extensive brain damage. This short film captures her love for Teddy, one not weighted down by disappointment, sadness or a full understanding of all the ways in which he wasnt normal. Read more.

title: Fund-Raisers and Shopping Fill Obamas Visit to Manhattan
description: President Obama came to New York on Tuesday to pick up a few sweaters and more than $1.5 million in cash. The sweaters were for his daughters. The cash was for his political allies.

title: The Big Easts Garden Party
description: The Big East mens basketball tournament was held in Madison Square Garden for the first time in 1983, and there it has stayed, even as the conference itself has been transformed.

title: F.D.A. Approves Anti-Migraine Device
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday said it had approved the first medical device to prevent migraine headaches. The device, made by a Belgian company, Cephaly Technology, is small, portable and battery powered, and it looks like a plastic headband. It is worn across the forehead and over the ears, and contains a small electrode that applies an electric current to stimulate the nerve that is associated with migraine headaches. A study of 67 people in Belgium found that those who used the device reported significantly fewer days with migraines per month than those who used a placebo.

title: Obama Adds to National Monument Land
description: President Obama on Tuesday moved to preserve more than 1,600 acres of coastal land in Northern California by declaring them part of a national monument. Point Arena-Stornetta, a 12-mile stretch of coast made up of federal and state public lands, is about 140 miles north of San Francisco. It will now be part of the California Coastal National Monument, a marine boundary that includes islands, rocks and reefs owned by the United States and within 12 miles of Californias 1,100-mile coast. Point Arena-Stornetta is the first shoreline portion of the monument. It is a place where scientists do research; where people who just want to experience the great outdoors can take advantage of it, Mr. Obama said before signing the proclamation. The newly expanded coastal monument is home to a variety of fauna and flora, among them Steller sea lions, Behrens silverspot butterfly, rare bird species like the black oystercatcher, and a bishop pine forest.

title: Wanted by Ecuador, 2 Brothers Make Mark in U.S. Campaigns
description: MIAMI  The donations kept pouring in: hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions to President Obama and more than a dozen members of Congress, carefully routed through the families of two wealthy brothers in Florida.

title: Israelis Split Over Service
description: Ultra-Orthodox Israelis protest plans to include their community in the military draft, arguing that the study of the Torah is as important to defending Israel as carrying a weapon in the Army.

title: The Minimum Wage From a Family Perspective
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: What Running Can Do for the Heart
description: An ingenious new study of marathon runners and their non-running spouses should reassure anyone headed for a spring marathon that prolonged training doesnt damage the heart, a concern that has been raised in previous research. At the same time, becoming fit as a marathoner doesnt seem to protect the heart to the extent you might expect, although it may have unexpected benefits for your spouse.

title: Word of the Day | stanch
description: stanch \stonch, stnch, stanch\ verb

title: Report Says Medication Use Is Rising for Adults With Attention Disorder
description: The number of young American adults taking medications for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder nearly doubled from 2008 to 2012, according to a report to be released Wednesday by the nations largest prescription drug manager.

title: In-Depth Report Details Economics of Sex Trade
description: WASHINGTON  A street prostitute in Dallas may make as little as $5 per sex act. But pimps can take in $33,000 a week in Atlanta, where the sex business brings in an estimated $290 million per year. It is not nearly as lucrative in Denver, where prostitution and other elements of an underground trade are worth about $40 million.

title: Times Minute | Prostitution in the U.S.
description: Also on the Minute, stimulant use in the United States rises and class is in session at the New York Times Wine School.

title: Before Elections, Mumbai Snack Turns Into a Political Hot Potato
description: MUMBAI, India When Arun Garde set out to sell vada pav, the popular street snack of a potato patty in a bun, in south Mumbai in November, the city government closed down his stall before his fourth customer had finished eating. Mr. Garde, 50, watched in horror as his booth, utensils and supplies were thrown into the back of a truck because he was hawking without a license.

title: Fever Trade Guard Phillips to Mercury
description: The Indiana Fever traded guard Erin Phillips to the Phoenix Mercury for forward Lynetta Kizer and a first-round draft pick. The trade gives Indiana two of the top nine selections in Aprils W.N.B.A. draft, with its own pick at No. 5 and the Mercurys slot at nine. (AP)

title: Times Minute | Prostitution in the U.S.
description: In the Video

title: In France, a Quest to Convert a Sea Snail Plague Into a Culinary Pleasure
description: CANCALE, France  On this storm-weathered tip of Mont Saint-Michel Bay, the sweeping tides have washed away the line between land and sea. Fishermen drive their wheeled boats straight into the bay to gather their harvest: an assortment of shellfish prized all over France.

title: Gaza: Explosives in a House Kill 3
description: An explosion on Tuesday at a house in Beit Hanoun, a town in the northern Gaza Strip, killed three people and wounded at least seven others, the Gaza Ministry of Health said. Officials said the blast had apparently been caused by explosives in the house, owned by a family named Hamdeen. A Health Ministry spokesman said most of the survivors were seriously wounded. Officials did not explain the presence of the explosives in the home.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 93
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Suit Filed in Haiti Cholera Epidemic
description: A class-action lawsuit claiming to represent cholera victims in Haiti and their relatives in the United States was filed against the United Nations on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. At issue is the question of accountability for an epidemic that began in 2010 and has since claimed more than 8,000 lives. In response an earlier claim, the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, said that he believed the United Nations Charter rendered the organization absolutely immune from legal process and suit absent an express waiver. Victims groups blame United Nations peacekeepers from Nepal, where cholera is endemic. The United Nations has pledged to help eradicate cholera from Haiti.

title: Nepal: Push to Open Peaks to Climbers
description: The government is considering contracts with climbing companies that would grant exclusive access to many of its highest mountains, a spokesman for Nepals tourism ministry said on Tuesday, as part of an effort to bring more climbers to the Himalayas, the worlds highest mountain range. Nepal has some 3,310 mountains, but only 310 are open to commercial climbing. Since the government determined that it cannot manage all of its peaks, it will soon propose offering 30-year leases on the remaining 3,000 mountains to climbing companies, which would then organize climbs and charge fees. Nepal collects about $2.7 million annually in mountaineering fees, most of which comes from the nearly 35,000 people who visit Mount Everest. Nepal has long been trying to increase and diversify its tourism business, with its extraordinary mountains  60 peaks higher than 26,000 feet  at the center of those efforts. Nepal is one of the worlds poorest countries, and the countrys youths are increasingly leaving for jobs elsewhere.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) PLEASE GIVE (2010) Two Manhattan families collide in this film from Nicole Holofcener, when Kate and Alex (Catherine Keener and Oliver Platt, above), who run a store specializing in furniture acquired from the apartments of the dead, angle to take over the place of their irascible next door neighbor. She is Andra (Ann Guilbert), who comes with two granddaughters: the spiky Mary (Amanda Peet) and repressed Rebecca (Rebecca Hall). Sarah Steele plays Kates teenage daughter, Abby, who wishes her mother would address some of her generosity  she doles out cash to homeless people  toward her. Few American filmmakers create female characters as realistically funny, attractively imperfect and flat-out annoying, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. You may not love them, but you recognize their charms and frailties, their fears and hopes. They may remind you of your friends, your sisters or even yourself, which makes them attractive and sometimes off-putting, an unusual, complicated mix.

title: Corrections: March 12, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Wash Your Car to Keep Rust Away
description: Although it cant be said that were done with winter, the worst appears to be behind us. If you live where there was a lot of snow  which, this year, seems to have been most places in the United States  your car is no doubt coated with a salty film right now.

title: Obama Makes Push for Political Solution to Crisis in Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Ukraines interim prime minister opened the door on Wednesday to a political solution that could lead to more autonomy for Crimea if Russian troops withdraw, as the United States embarked on a last-ditch diplomatic effort to defuse a crisis that reignited tensions between East and West.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 12, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Obamas New Approach Takes a Humorous Turn
description: In Obamas New Approach Takes a Humorous Turn, Michael D. Shear writes about the interview in this video. Watch the video and read the article to answer the questions below.

title: Silicon Valleys Youth Problem
description: The Cisco Meraki office in Mission Bay, San Francisco, is 40 paces from the water, and just as nice as Googles. On a clear winter day in late December, I sat in one of its conference rooms with a company spokeswoman on my right and Sanjit Biswas on my left, peering out through floor-to-ceiling glass. On the other side: brightly patterned furniture, murals and paneled wood, a well-stocked cafeteria, a deck with spectacular views of the bay. Twelve months earlier, in a deal meant to bring fresh edge to Cisco, the networking behemoth bought Meraki from Biswas and two co-founders for $1.2 billion. Now they were making good on their promise  starting with the dcor.

title: Questions About a Popular Heart Procedure
description: Our great-great-grandparents probably didnt have to think much about the way the hearts aortic valve slowly stiffens and narrows over decades, a condition called aortic stenosis. Most of them died before they could experience its distressing symptoms  shortness of breath, chest pain, fatigue, fainting.

title: Tortillas, Almost From Scratch
description: If youre interested in a serious project, you can make the best tortillas youve ever had by soaking and washing dried hominy  corn that has been treated with slaked lime  then grinding it to produce masa, or dough. Then you press out small discs and griddle them. Do that, and youll have my admiration.

title: Is Teenage Voluntourism Wrong?
description: Many teenagers take them  summer or school-vacation trips to other countries to volunteer in some capacity (and, perhaps, build their rsums).

title: Outburst by Prominent Party Official Reverberates Online
description: Online media were abuzz on Tuesday about remarks reportedly made by Wang Qishan, one of Chinas highest-ranked political figures, in which he upbraided the Communist Party secretary of Jilin Province for the fault of formalism.

title: New York Today: Let It Rain
description: Good Wednesday morning. Remember that thing called an umbrella?

title: For First Time in Years, a Raise for Many Japanese Workers
description: TOKYO  Japans bid to revive its economy got much-needed backing Wednesday after a group of major exporters said they would raise wages for the first time in years. Still, union leaders warned that a wider recovery hinged on the fate of low-wage, informal workers who make up a growing part of the countrys labor force.

title: Mixed Results for 2 British Retailers in Trading Debuts
description: LONDON  The British retailers Pets at Home and Poundland had mixed results on their first day of trading on the London Stock Exchange on Wednesday.

title: Shares in a Media Group Soar Well Before Alibaba Makes a Deal
description: Updated, 6:20 p.m. |

title: Wheelies: The V8 Hotel Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Standing by Her Story
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  On the day in 1991 that the Senate confirmed Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, Anita Hill  the little-known law professor who riveted the nation by accusing him of sexual harassment  faced news cameras outside her simple brick home in Norman, Okla., with her mother by her side, and politely declined to comment on the vote.

title: For This Owner, the Recession Has Yet to End
description: Few things are more discouraging than a long steady sales decline  particularly after a business has enjoyed success. Xiaoning Wang knows this a bit too well.

title: Daily Report: Sprints Owner Makes New Case for Merger with T-Mobile
description: American broadband is slow and expensive. But Masayoshi Son wants to help, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Israel to Phase Out Religious Exemptions
description: JERUSALEM  After years of heated public debate and political wrangling, Israels Parliament on Wednesday approved landmark legislation that will eventually eliminate exemptions from compulsory military service for many ultra-Orthodox students enrolled in seminaries.

title: Wages of Fear (Somewhat Wonkish)
description: Conventional wisdom can be a terrible thing. In 2009-10 all the serious people started telling each other that public debt was the number one threat facing advanced economies, and that austerity policies were needed immediately. We know how that turned out. Well, over the past few months Ive been watching a new conventional wisdom take hold  among a narrower and more technical set of people, but still. According to this view, economic slack is vanishing fast; even though we still have huge unemployment, were actually running out of employable workers, and a dangerous acceleration in the pace of wage increases is already underway. Time to raise interest rates!

title: Gone Guy (Personal)
description: Regular readers have surely noticed a certain  thinness .. of blog posting this week. Too many commitments came due at the same time, and Ive been swamped.

title: Maker of Candy Crush Puts Value at $7.6 Billion
description: Updated, 8:41 p.m. | A planned initial public offering of stock by the maker of the wildly popular game Candy Crush Saga will test just how far one hit can take a company.

title: Signals on Radar Puzzle Officials in Hunt for Malaysian Jet
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  After four days of reticence and evasive answers, the Malaysian military acknowledged on Wednesday that it had recorded, but initially ignored, radar signals that could have prompted a mission to intercept and track a missing jetliner  data that vastly expands the area where the plane might have traveled.

title: A Look at Citis Challenges in Mexico
description: In the financial crisis year of 2008, Citigroup severed ties to Mexican companies that it feared could imperil its Mexican affiliate, but it seems that those efforts did not go far enough, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. A $400 million fraud at Citigroups Banamex unit that was discovered last month highlights the limitations of that kind of culling, and underscores the challenges of finding solid lending clients in a country where the line between big business and political cronyism can become blurred.

title: In Our Pages: March 13
description: 1914: Opera Singer Wins Court Case

title: British Opposition Leader Cool to Quick Vote on E.U. Membership
description: LONDON  Ending months of speculation, Ed Miliband, the leader of Britains opposition Labour Party, said on Wednesday that he would almost certainly not hold a quick referendum on the countrys membership in the European Union if his party wins power next year.

title: British Regulator Adds Industry Veteran to Supervise Investment Banks
description: LONDON  The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain is turning to another industry veteran as it looks to bolster its expertise in its supervision division.

title: Ukraine Crisis Limits Merkels Rapport With Putin
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel, a Protestant pastors daughter, grew up in East Germany under a system in which President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia served as a K.G.B. agent stationed in Dresden. Fluent in Russian, she literally speaks his language and, arguably, understands his view of the world better than any other European leader touched by the Ukrainian crisis.

title: An Uncertain Quiet for Crimean Tatars
description: More than 20 years after her family returned from decades of exile, Emine Ziyatdinova wonders if the upheaval in Crimea will again force Tatars from their homeland.

title: Credit Karma, a Credit Score Service, Raises $85 Million
description: Credit Karma, which helps users keep track of their credit scores, has just secured a little financial aid of its own.

title: Shoveling In a Parking Space
description: Dear Diary:

title: Ukraines New Premier, the Rabbit, Seems to Be in His Element
description: KIEV, Ukraine  For three months, throughout the uprising and upheaval in Kiev, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk was one of three political leaders who appeared regularly on stage in Independence Square, but he often seemed out of his element. A former foreign minister, economics minister, speaker of Parliament and acting central bank chief, he is more at home in boardrooms and in the corridors of power than on the barricades.

title: 9 Suspects Arrested in Attack on Hong Kong Journalist
description: The Hong Kong police claimed a breakthrough Wednesday in the investigation of a brutal attack on a prominent newspaper editor that sent chills through the territorys journalists. The two men suspected of carrying out the attack were caught across the border in mainland China, and seven possible accomplices were arrested in Hong Kong, the territorys police commissioner said.

title: Stanley Fischer, Fed Nominee, Has Long History of Policy Leadership
description: WASHINGTON  Stanley Fischer has worked for much of his professional life to improve economic policy in the developing world. Now he is on the verge of a new role in a country with plenty of economic problems of its own: the United States.

title: In His Words | Echoes of Enlightenment
description: As Stephen Shore readies a book of photographs he took in Israel, he reflects on his time in the Holy Land.

title: The I.M.F., Ukraine and President Obama
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a nonresident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. Simon Johnson is a professor at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

title: At Least 3 Killed as Gas Explosion Hits East Harlem
description: The call to Consolidated Edison came at 9:13 a.m. on Wednesday: The smell of gas, detectable the night before, had strengthened around two buildings by 116th Street and Park Avenue in East Harlem.

title: An Uncertain Quiet for Crimean Tatars
description: Emine Ziyatdinovas recent photographs from Crimea sketch the pain that is not far from the tenuous peace. There are images of Russian soldiers and pro-Ukrainian protesters. And just last Sunday, in her familys home, she photographed her mother crying as she stashed some documents into a bag.

title: Yet More G.O.P. Hypocrisy on the Minimum Wage
description: In an earlier post on the minimum wage, I pointed out that Republicans who oppose a raise on the dubious grounds that it will reduce employment in the future have had no compunction about cutting food stamps and blocking the renewal of federal jobless benefits  even though doing so is projected to cost the economy hundreds of thousands of jobs this year alone.

title: For S.E.C., a Much-Needed Win
description: Wall Streets top regulator has taken a number of hard knocks in the courtroom. Now a federal judge has handed the regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, a pat on the back that may embolden it to take more cases to trial.

title: Creightons Ethan Wragge Follows Through on Mothers Lessons
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  The morning before Creightons Ethan Wragge made nine 3-pointers in a win against Villanova in January, his mother, Kari, and father, Brad, joined him on the court after the teams game-day shootaround at Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia. The mood was light, and they grabbed a ball to take some shots.

title: E.P.A.s Proposed Rules on Water Worry Farmers
description: Water rarely flows in one of the streambeds  it really seems to be little more than a small ditch  that Dean Lemke points out to a visitor on his 800-acre farm in Dows, Iowa.

title: Average Wall St. Bonus Increased by 15% in 2013
description: Updated, 12:56 p.m. | On Wall Street, profits are down and the number of workers is shrinking.
