title: After Fatal Crash, Soul-Searching for South by Southwest
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  For nearly 30 years, the irreverent soul of this Texas capital city has been linked with what has been billed as the biggest music festival of its kind in the world  the ever-expanding mash-up of music, culture, technology and buzz known as South by Southwest.

title: Why Do Men Dominate Chinese Politics? Because Theyre Just Too Superb
description: Li Yalan, a delegate to the National Peoples Congress, looked flustered by a question from a foreign journalist at a news conference for female delegates that had, until then, focused on family values, children, the need for better statistics about women and the economic value of womens handicrafts.

title: Danish Outsourcing Firm ISS Surges in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Danish outsourcing company ISS rose 13 percent in its debut on the Nasdaq OMX Copenhagen exchange on Thursday.

title: Germany Urges Russia to Help Solve Ukraine Crisis
description: BERLIN  Emphasizing that the territorial integrity of Ukraine cannot be called into question, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany appealed forcefully to Russia on Thursday to abandon what she called the politics of the 19th and 20th centuries, and to find a peaceful negotiated solution to a crisis in the heart of Europe.

title: Its Growth Targets Elusive, China Focuses on Jobs and Quality of Life
description: HONG KONG  Chinas growth engine continued to show signs of weakness on Thursday, underlining the tricky balancing act that Beijing faces as it tries to reform its economy.

title: Dan Harris, Co-Anchor of Nightline, Discusses Multitasking and Meditation
description: Dan Harris, a co-anchor of ABCs Nightline and the weekend edition of Good Morning America, is the author of a new book, 10% Happier: How I Tamed the Voice in My Head, Reduced Stress Without Losing My Edge, and Found Self-Help That Actually Works  A True Story.

title: What North Dakotas Public Bank Does for Small Businesses
description: Five years ago, Brian Brasch, president of Branick Industries, a maker of specialty automotive tools in Fargo, N.D., took a phone call from a stranger. The caller was an auto mechanic in Florida who had an idea for a new kind of drain plug for an oil pan, one with an O-ring that expands to stop oil leaks.

title: Renaissance Learning Is Sold to Hellman & Friedman for $1.1 Billion
description: Updated, 4:02 p.m. | It was only last month that Renaissance Learning raised $40 million from a new Google investment fund, valuing the education analysis company at $1 billion.

title: This Is the Real Reason Sbarro Is in Bankruptcy
description: Lets get this out of the way first: The food at Sbarro, the pizza-and-pasta chain, isnt very good. The pizza crust manages to be both thick and limp, the tomato sauce bland, the cheese the victim of sitting for too long under heat lamps.

title: Egypts Ancient Snark
description: CAIRO  In 1798, after Napoleon Bonaparte occupied Egypt, some local grandees wanted to get close to him, so they gave him six slave girls. At that time, Egyptians were under the influence of the Turkish taste that considered a fulsome figure a prerequisite of feminine beauty. Napoleon was more fired up by Parisian elegance and refused to sleep with any of the women because they were, in his opinion, fat and reeking of fenugreek.

title: Bouygues and Altice Raise Bids for SFR, Vivendis Mobile Unit
description: Updated, 2:56 p.m. | LONDON  Bouygues and Altice have raised their offers in an escalating bidding war for SFR, the mobile phone unit of the French media conglomerate Vivendi.

title: Daily Report: Europe Moves to Reform Rules Protecting Privacy
description: The European Parliament passed a strong new set of data protection measures on Wednesday prompted in part by the disclosure by Edward J. Snowden, a former contractor at the United States National Security Agency, of Americas vast electronic spying program, David Jolly reports.

title: Buddhist Volunteers Aiding Anxious Families in Beijing
description: At one end of the room, Malaysia Airlines employees delivered the latest briefing to relatives and friends of passengers who were aboard the airlines missing Flight 370. At the other end, volunteers listened from behind tables piled with snacks, waiting to provide counseling, logistical assistance or just hand holding.

title: WGN America Promotes Original Programming With Upfront Presentations
description: Another channel hopes to feed the growing appetite among viewers and advertisers for original programming on cable television.

title: Take a Breath and Thank a Sponge
description: If Tim Lenton is right, we all owe sponges a deep debt of gratitude. It may be hard to give much credit to these simple animals, which spend their uneventful lives on the sea floor trapping floating bits of food. But Dr. Lenton, an earth systems scientist at the University of Exeter, suspects that sponges played a crucial role in the rise of the animal kingdom.

title: G.E. Files to Spin Off Retail Finance Unit
description: Updated, 5:10 p.m. |

title: Lufthansa Results Suggest Overhaul Is Paying Off
description: PARIS  Midway through Lufthansas three-year cost-cutting drive, investors and analysts are looking to the incoming chief executive, Carsten Spohr, to keep focused on paring expenses and boosting profits.

title: Military Repatriates Algerian Detainee From Guantnamo Bay
description: WASHINGTON  The military announced Thursday that it had repatriated an Algerian detainee who had been held without trial for 12 years at the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. The transfer is the first in nearly three months, and it reduces the inmate population there to 154.

title: Herbalife Takes a Tumble
description: For 15 months, the activist investor William A. Ackman has accused Herbalife of being a pyramid scheme, betting $1 billion on its collapse. Since Mr. Ackmans crusade began in December 2012, he has lobbied members of Congress to press state and federal regulators, specifically the Federal Trade Commission, to investigate Herbalife.

title: Remember the Traveling Knish Man
description: Dear Diary:

title: Weak European Auto Market in 2013 Sapped Volkswagen Earnings
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen, Europes biggest carmaker, said Thursday that net profit fell by more than half in 2013, as it earned less from midrange passenger cars and did not have one-time gains that it booked for 2012.

title: In Our Pages: March 14
description: 1889: Baseball at Lords in London

title: The Find | Wish You Were Here
description: Eva Hesse and Sol LeWitt were the closest of friends, their bond informing much of their work. A new book, Converging Lines, chronicles their kinship through personal photos, affectionate letters and, as shown here, postcards from across the globe. Converging Lines is also the catalog for an exhibition of the same name currently at the Blanton Museum of Art at The University of Texas at Austin.

title: Fatal Crash at South by Southwest Festival Was a One-Minute Event
description: Two people were killed and 23 others injured early Thursday morning after a suspected drunken driver, pursued by the police, plowed through groups of revelers attending the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., as my colleagues David Montgomery and Timothy Williams report.

title: An Online Pioneer Leaves His Mark on a Leading Green Blog
description: Scott Rosenberg, a pioneering Web journalist and author of Say Everything, a history of blogging (if that isnt an oxymoron), is stepping down after two and a half years leading the blog flow at the green website Grist. In his farewell post, Rosenberg explains that his weekly commutes from his Bay Area home to Seattle werent sustainable.

title: She Loves Thee, Yeah Yeah Yeah
description: Let me get this straight, Billie Joe Armstrong said to the playwright and screenwriter Rolin Jones over drinks last year. Youre going to rewrite Shakespeare, and Im going to rewrite the Beatles?

title: India Welcomes Dismissal of Visa Fraud Case Against Diplomat
description: NEW DELHI  The Ministry of External Affairs on Thursday welcomed an American courts dismissal of visa fraud charges against the Indian consular official Devyani Khobragade, whose legal troubles had created tensions between India and the United States.

title: Helen Oyeyemi: By the Book
description: The author of Mr. Fox and Boy, Snow, Bird considers Dumass dArtagnan a literary hero: If theres going to be a fray, I cant help but approve of someone who enters it headlong.

title: Vitamin D May Lower Cholesterol
description: Many observational studies have suggested that vitamin D may have benefits for heart health. Now a randomized trial has found that vitamin D appears to reduce levels of LDL, or bad cholesterol.

title: For Foreign Journalists in Beijing, Its All About Asking the Right Question
description: Go ahead, raise your hand and wave it back and forth like an overeager first-grader. If you think youre going to be picked to ask Chinas second most powerful leader a question, you have another thing coming.

title: U.S. Criticized for Lack of Action on Mortgage Fraud
description: Updated, 1:00 p.m. |

title: Russian Troops Mass at Border With Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  With a referendum on secession looming in Crimea, Russia massed troops and armored vehicles in at least three regions along Ukraines eastern border on Thursday, alarming the interim Ukraine government about a possible invasion and significantly escalating tensions in the crisis between the Kremlin and the West.

title: A Getaway Unravels the Ties That Bind
description: You cant not love and hate the same person, Nick says to Meg, the woman he has loved for more than 30 years. They are on an anniversary trip to Paris, celebrating a complicated but enduring and affectionate union. Nicks observation is more wry than anguished, and its implication of melodrama  evoking that famous thin line sung about by the Persuaders and the Pretenders  does not seem to apply to him and Meg. Played by Jim Broadbent and Lindsay Duncan, they look like a modest, decent, likably scruffy couple, British baby boomers entering their sunset years with stoicism and good humor.

title: South by Southwest Car Crash
description: The aftermath of a car crash that killed two at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex.

title: At Request of U.S., Austria Arrests Ukrainian Businessman
description: MOSCOW  The Austrian authorities have arrested a Ukrainian entrepreneur, Dmitry V. Firtash, on bribery and other charges at the request of American law enforcement agencies. Mr. Firtash has strong connections to the ousted Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, and also conducts extensive business in natural gas with Russia.

title: Service Announcement | Wrench Not Required
description: Thanks to a play on proportion and an unexpected accessory or two, stylish jumpsuits step out of the garage.

title: Poetry Pairing | Three Six Five Zero
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features Three Six Five Zero by Conor OCallaghan and the Bits blog post Disruptions: Digital Era Redefining Etiquette by Nick Bilton.

title: 5 Things Teachers Wish Parents Knew: Your Children Can Do More Than You Think
description: This week, Im turning the tables and giving some space to the teacher half of the Parent-Teacher Conference. When I ask teachers, What one thing would you want your students parents to know? the same five points come up over and over again.

title: College Art Museum Hit With Sanction After Sale of Bellows Work
description: The Association of Art Museum Directors, which represents more than 200 museums in North America, has issued a rare sanction against the Maier Museum of Art at Randolph College in Lynchburg, Va., after the museums sale of a George Bellows painting to raise money to shore up the colleges operating budget.

title: NYT Now: South by Southwest Crash
description: The Austin police chief, Art Acevedo, told reporters that two people were killed at the South by Southwest festival after a driver slammed his car into pedestrians walking along crowded streets.

title: High Court Upholds Death Penalty in Delhi Gang Rape Case
description: NEW DELHI  The Delhi High Court on Thursday upheld the death sentences of four men who were convicted of gang-raping and murdering a 23-year-old student in the capital in December 2012.

title: A Blueprint for Ukraine
description: LVIV, Ukraine  Every kind of business in this restless pro-European stronghold near the border with Poland has an idea about how to make Ukraine like its more prosperous neighbor.

title: Gleacher & Co. Plans to Liquidate
description: Gleacher & Company, the troubled investment bank that had tried unsuccessfully to sell itself, announced on Thursday that it planned to liquidate its assets, closing up shop after 24 years.

title: Poignant in Tooth and Claw
description: The tiny gray mouse in the bright red coat scampers as quietly as a whisper. She lives in a land under a city of big if not especially bad bears, in a country where wee houses cling to walls, and itty-bitty mice row boats. On an ordinary day in this little land  as seen early on in Ernest & Celestine  some mice will be out shopping; some will be riding elevators, and still others building muscles as they raise and lower the metal bars of mouse traps with vigor and precision. Tucked into one street, youll find an orphanage that brings to mind Madelines boarding school, but one with little mice like Celestine in straight lines instead of little girls.

title: A Memphis Group Founder Creates Prints for American Apparel
description: A year and a half ago, the French-born, Milan-based artist Nathalie Du Pasquier had never heard of American Apparel. Shes not quite as mature as Jacky OShaughnessy, the 62-year-old star of a recent ad campaign for the downtown-L.A.-based brand, but Du Pasquier does prefer to dress her own age (which is 57). Beginning today, though, Du Pasquiers signature colorful, graphic patterns will grace the 20 newest silhouettes hanging in a select 20 of the labels many retail outposts. The collaboration came about when the brands creative director, Iris Alonzo, approached Du Pasquier about painting prints similar to the iconic ones she produced in the 1980s as an original member of the Memphis Group, the Milan-based collective of designers and architects. I thought, Why not? Du Pasquier remembers. It was the first collaboration with a fashion company in many, many years actually because I am a painter. I have not done that kind of work in a long time. And how does the artist feel about American Apparel now that its emblazoned with work from her own hand? These? she asks about the simple frocks, jumpsuits and skirts, minimalist shapes that complement her bright, unruly designs. I will wear them, yes. There are shirts for men, too, and more cheerful accessories from the capsule will roll out during the summer months to come.

title: 36 Hours in Nassau, the Bahamas
description: Most tourists arriving in the Bahamas capital city head straight across the bridge to the aptly named Paradise Island, where a glitzy resort scene is anchored by the Atlantis megadevelopment, known for its water park rides, casino and celebrity chef restaurants. While the sensory appeal there is undeniable, those looking for a cultural allure thats subtler than, say, a 200-foot water slide, would do well to venture beyond the resorts. In addition to serving as port of call for cruise lines (and as a rowdy hub for spring breakers), at its heart Nassau is a laid-back island town. European influences blend with centuries-old Bahamian traditions here, anchored by an innovative dining scene, unique small hotels and, of course, miles of white sand beaches.

title: The Gun Report: March 13, 2014
description: In Wayne LaPierres America, there is no government, no authority we can trust with our lives. There are only guns.

title: Avinoam Nowogrodski of Clarizen, on the Rewards of Listening
description: This interview with Avinoam Nowogrodski, the chief executive of Clarizen, a work management software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: 6 Trends in Cruising
description: Cruise lines continue to diversify, with itineraries that seem to offer something for everyone, from steeped-in-the-wild adventure cruises to massive floating resorts. But large or small, eco or culinary, most cruises today strive to connect passengers to local cultures.

title: Cruise Quest: Keeping the Entertainment Fresh
description: As the Celebrity Reflection left port in Miami last month for a cruise of the eastern Caribbean, one of the ships activities hosts circulated through the crowd on the pool deck trying to get them excited about the onboard party that was beginning. Despite the pulsating sounds that a pair of D.J.-percussionists on a small poolside stage were pumping into nearby speakers, only a few cruisers were inspired to hit the dance floor. I counted myself among the wallflowers, and it was clear that we nondancers were a majority. It was beginning to feel a bit awkward.

title: Times Minute | G.M.'s Legal Woes
description: The automaker could face damaging lawsuits after a major recall. Also on the Minute, diplomatic efforts ahead of the Crimean referendum vote, and Senator McConnell's re-election fight.

title: Star-Struck by Alibabas Movie Company Deal
description: The e-commerce giant Alibabas latest deal shows the extent of investor frenzy for Chinas Internet. The company announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy 60 percent of the ChinaVision Media Group, which is listed in Hong Kong, for $804 million. The film companys market value promptly soared to almost $5 billion. Star-struck investors are too easily excited.

title: McDonalds Workers File Wage Suits in 3 States
description: McDonalds workers in California, Michigan and New York filed lawsuits this week against the company and several franchise owners, asserting that they illegally underpaid employees by erasing hours from their timecards, not paying overtime and ordering them to work off the clock.

title: Scene | "Jimi: All Is By My Side"
description: Andre 3000, who plays Jimi Hendrix in this biopic, chats with Keith Richardss girlfriend, Linda Keith, who is played by Imogen Poots.

title: Empire Resorts Unveils Plan for $750 Million Casino in Catskills
description: Empire Resorts, the company that operates a small slot machine parlor at the Monticello racetrack in the Catskills, unveiled plans on Thursday for a $750 million casino resort nearby, the first of what may turn out to be a dozen competing proposals for one of four state gambling licenses in upstate New York.

title: Times Minute | G.M.s Legal Woes
description: In the Video

title: She Said, She Said
description: Stuart Blumberg's short film features Marisa Tomei and lodie Bouchez as a lesbian couple going through divorce.

title: Channeling a Breaker of Barriers
description: LONDON  The story is gripping. It is the mid-1820s, and a young black American actor improbably moves to London while still a teenager, tours the provinces and gets his big break a few years later, when he is asked at the last minute to replace Edmund Kean as Othello at Covent Garden in 1833. Can he overcome the innate prejudice of his fellow actors, the public and the critics? Will he succeed?

title: Free Fun: Everything You Wanted to Know About This Is Spinal Tap, Plus the Film Itself
description: To celebrate the 30th anniversary of This Is Spinal Tap, Rob Reiners satirical documentary about a fictional British rock band  and not incidentally, to promote Yeah!,its year-old streaming movie service  AMC Networks is offering a copiously annotated version of the film for free viewing through April 11. The networks edition, called This Is Spinal Tap  The Special Features Version, can be watched either on the web or through the Yeah! iPad app.

title: Anger Can Set Off a Heart Attack
description: Angry enough to have a heart attack? It might actually happen.

title: Questions About News Photographers in Syria Arise After Freelancers Death
description: Late last December, Ahmad Barakat, a tailor turned rebel commander in Aleppo, Syria, buried two sons who died together during a battle with Syrian government troops. The elder son, Mustafa, fought for the Tawhid rebels. The younger son, Molhem, photographed the clash for Reuters.

title: Bank of England Seeks to Expand Clawback Rules
description: LONDON  Bankers who engage in misconduct could have their bonuses clawed back for up to six years after the improper conduct under a new rule proposed by the Bank of England.

title: Today in Small Business: Clueless Sales Representatives
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Delphi Says Autonomous Cars Are Coming, but Only in Bits and Pieces
description: Delphi Automotive, a General Motors spinoff that has become a major independent parts supplier, has a forecast for the future of autonomous driving: partly cloudy, with a drizzle of new technology.

title: Young, Gay and Blaming Myself for Cancer
description: Im scheduling your orchiectomy in two days, my oncologist told me, only minutes after handing me a diagnosis of testicular cancer. With that, he added a new word to my vocabulary: Orchiectomy: Excision of one or both testicles. Castration.

title: Complaints as Amazon Raises Cost of Prime
description: SAN FRANCISCO  People like getting their toys fast. They also like getting them cheap.

title: To Keep Teenagers Alert, Schools Let Them Sleep In
description: COLUMBIA, Mo.  Jilly Dos Santos really did try to get to school on time. She set three successive alarms on her phone. Skipped breakfast. Hastily applied makeup while her fuming father drove. But last year she rarely made it into the frantic scrum at the doors of Rock Bridge High School here by the first bell, at 7:50 a.m.

title: An App to Ditch the Dubious Concert Bootleg
description: The hordes of music fans going to see bands this week at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., can relive the concerts a couple of ways. They can make recordings of dubious quality using their smartphones.

title: Ban on Doctors Group Imperils Muslim Minority in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  Nearly 750,000 people, most of them members of a Muslim minority in one of the poorest parts of Myanmar, have been deprived of most medical services since the government banned the operations of Doctors Without Borders, the international health care organization and the main provider of medical care in the region.

title: NYT Now: Kerrys Options for Ukraine
description: Secretary of State John Kerry explores his options as he goes on a last-ditch mission to stop Russias annexation of Crimea.

title: Labor Market Slack: A Guide for the Perplexed
description: Central bankers like a little unemployment. They want to keep the labor pool reasonably well stocked so that inflation remains under control. They regard a measure of human misery now as the price of avoiding more misery later.

title: Threes a Trend | The Resurgence of Bone China
description: Traditional porcelain tableware has long been a launching point for modern dinnerware design. And recently, three new collections have reinvented nostalgic bone china with fresh styles that feel at once heirloom and avant-garde. The 26-year-old British designer Richard Brendon introduced Reflect, a set of gold-and-platinum teacups from Stoke-on-Trent that he paired with orphan vintage and antique saucers sourced through antique dealers on Londons Portobello Road. The metallic cups reflect the pattern of the saucers, and a new match is made. In the hands of Gucci, Richard Ginoris classic shapes and patterns are given new life and a fresh color palette as seen in the Cartiglio and Oriente Italiano dinnerware, which debuted earlier this year at Maison & Objet in Paris. And the creative team at Seletti blended Eastern and Western design on new asymmetrical cake plates and curiously crafted spoons, which will debut this spring as part of their aptly titled Hybrid Collection.

title: Have a Layover? Hit the Library
description: Theres a new library in Philadelphia  and its in the airport.

title: Another Proposal to Repair Relations Between Boards and Investors
description: Increased shareholder activism, lawsuits filed by investors and continued malfeasance by financial institutions is prompting a renewed bout of introspection by some executives, board members and investors.

title: Mitch McConnells New Spot
description: On Tuesday Mitch McConnells Senate campaign released a content-free ad. I dont say that as a criticism, but as a statement of fact. Theres no talking, and no text  just a car-commercial-type soundtrack played over footage of the senator smiling, walking, shaking hands, signing papers, posing for snapshots, and gesturing pointedly.

title: Image of the Day: March 13
SXSW 2014: Scenes From Wednesday
description: Photos from Wednesday nights performances at the music festival in Austin, Tex.

title: Dragon Mother Emily Rapp: A New Baby Doesnt, and Shouldnt, Replace Whats Lost
description: On a cold night in February 2013, my son Ronan died of Tay-Sachs disease. He was nearly 3 years old. During the course of his life he experienced seizures, lost his sight and volitional movement, and finally, his ability to eat. From the time of his diagnosis at 9 months old  the worst day of my life; the day that drew a line between the person I was before I knew he was sick and the person I am now after his death  my ideas about parenting shifted irreversibly. I cast off all notions of what the future might hold for Ronan. I accepted, however reluctantly, that my task was not to prepare my son for his future, but to make each day and each moment count until the day of his death.

title: Mobile Security Specialist Lookout to Announce New Chief Executive
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Lookout, the mobile security company, will announce on Thursday that it is bringing in a new chief executive.

title: Good Morning America Hits Ratings Milestone
description: Good Morning America has ridden spillover from ABCs Oscar coverage to a new milestone  its biggest weekly audience average since Nielsen began keeping electronic ratings records in 1991.

title: Draghi Praises European Banks That Are Cleaning Up Their Books
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank said on Thursday that euro zone banks faced a period of creative destruction that would be healthy for the economy, and he praised the banks that were moving more aggressively to deal with their problems.

title: Chinese Police Detain Activist Who Runs Website
description: BEIJING  Huang Qi, a well-known human-rights advocate and blogger, was taken from his home by police officers on Thursday, according to Mr. Huangs assistant, who had spoken to Mr. Huangs mother at 3 p.m.

title: Locking Up Amazon Deliveries
description: Q. Im usually not home when U.P.S. tries to deliver packages from Amazon. If I use Amazon Locker for a delivery, how long do I have to pick up my order?

title: Theyd Rather Stay for a While
description: Il Salumaio was not supposed to be a restaurant. It opened last June in Yorkville, on the Upper East Side, as an old-world salumeria with hocks of prosciutto and mesh sacks of soppressata clustered like chimes over monumental cheeses.

title: Where Russian Troops Are Massing
description: Map showing where the recent military operations were.

title: At Hearing, Fed Board Nominees Endorse Current Path
description: WASHINGTON  Three nominees to the Federal Reserves board sailed through a brief confirmation hearing on Thursday, assuring senators of their commitment to strengthen financial regulation and stimulate the economy.

title: Merkel Assails Russia's Actions
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany criticized the Kremlins actions as Russia announced new military operations in several regions near the Ukrainian border.

title: Flight 370 and the Terror of Being Off the Grid
description: How can a commercial airliner go missing? How, in this hyperconnected age, could it vanish from the earth, apparently without trace, eluding a nearly weeklong search involving more than a dozen governments and some of the worlds most advanced surveillance technology?

title: Robert Rickel, a Founder of Hardware Supermarkets, Dies at 90
description: Robert Rickel, who along with two brothers founded a chain of home improvement stores that were precursors to retail giants like Home Depot and Lowes, died on Sunday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 90.

title: Fashion Month Fast-Forward
description: Scenes from New York, London, Milan and Paris.

title: Colorado Appeals Court Says Marijuana Law Can Be Used to Challenge Convictions
description: DENVER  A Colorado law that allows adults to legally possess and use marijuana may now allow some people found guilty of minor marijuana crimes to challenge their convictions in court, a state appeals court ruled on Thursday.

title: Hitmakers Tunes Lead to Jukebox Musical
description: A new jukebox musical about the 1960s-era songwriter and record producer Bert Berns, featuring hits including Twist and Shout, I Want Candy and Hang On, Sloopy, will begin a commercial Off Broadway run at Signature Center on June 25 and open on July 21, the producers announced on Thursday.

title: De Blasios Update on Blast in Harlem
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio held a news conference on Thursday about the rescue effort after the collapse of two buildings in East Harlem on Wednesday morning.

title: Russian Troops Hold Drills Near Ukraine
description: Russian troops held military exercises in several regions near the Ukrainian border early on Thursday amid heightened tension between Kiev and Moscow.

title: A Second Embrace, With Hearts and Eyes Open (Updated With Podcast)
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by Cheryl Strayed, followed by a conversation with the writer, Mary Elizabeth Williams, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below.

title: Obama Orders Rule Changes to Expand Overtime Pay
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, declaring that Americans have spent too long working more and getting less in return, ordered the Labor Department on Thursday to revise federal rules on overtime pay to make millions more workers eligible for extra pay when they work more than 40 hours a week.

title: Imagine if Companies Had to Ask Before Using Your Data
description: If youre worried about Internet companies using-and-abusing your data, you might want to consider moving to Europe, where privacy legislation is much further along than in the United States.

title: The Man, Not the Myth
description: The Museum of Modern Arts groundbreaking Gauguin exhibition may be the last of its kind. After decades of unstinting curatorial attention to artists from Manet to Seurat, how many more exhibitions can radically reshape our understanding of a major 19th-century French painter?

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: in the news: concussions, fitness trackers and sleep. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Confirmation Hearing for Fed Nominees
description: Stanley Fischer and other Federal Reserve nominees appeared for a confirmation hearing held by the Senate Banking Committee.

title: Emmet Gowin: Loving the Problem
description: In a career of reinvention, Emmet Gowin has pondered the unanswerable and worked the margins of understanding. A new monograph shows how.

title: From No Points the Night Before to the 2 Biggest in a Stunner
description: In a banquet hall in the New York Marriott East Side, Seton Hall gathered for a walk-through at 8 a.m. Thursday, less than 12 hours after leaving Madison Square Garden the night before.

title: A Mixed Week for Ackman
description: From one perspective, the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman had a good day on Wednesday. The Federal Trade Commission announced an investigation into Herbalife, a company that he is betting against, sending its shares tumbling.

title: Jets Will Need Their Big Catch to Grab His Opportunity
description: John Idzik, the Jets general manager, has finally dipped his toe into the free-agency waters, and even if his first big splash turns out to be an overpriced belly-flop, it is unlikely that anyone will ever view it as his fault.

title: Led Zeppelin Album Reissues Will Offer Previously Unreleased Song
description: The Led Zeppelin catalog has been reissued on CD several times, but the band has always been parsimonious with extras and bonus tracks: a 1990 four-CD compilation of its studio recordings included only one, a stray 1970 B-side. But lately, Jimmy Page, the bands guitarist and producer, has been rethinking that policy, and when Atlantic/Swan Song kicks off the next round of Zeppelin album reissues on June 3 with remastered versions of Led Zeppelin, Led Zeppelin II and Led Zeppelin III, fans who already own the albums will have reason to considered shelling out once again.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Need for Speed'
description: The director Scott Waugh narrates a scene from his film.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Need for Speed
description: In this video, the director Scott Waugh narrates a stunt sequence from the racing film Need for Speed, starring Aaron Paul and based on the video game of the same name. The scene includes two major vehicle stunts, a double 360-degree-spin at 80 miles an hour, and a 175-foot jump over 4 lanes of traffic. Here, Mr. Waugh offers some insight into how the scene was put together.

title: Q. and A. | Diane Pernet, the Original Style Blogger, on Fashion and Film
description: The woman behind A Shaded View on Fashion, whose 2005 launch marks it as one of the first fashion blogs, is Diane Pernet, a former New York designer who defected to Paris in 1990 and never looked back. Since then, shes become a street icon in Paris for her black mantilla, beehive hairdo and voluminous black-and-white-shirts and skirts  a look from which she never deviates, even when running out for a baguette. Schoolchildren in her neighborhood of the Seventh Arrondissement sometimes call her La Sorcire (The Witch).

title: Text to Text | A Raisin in the Sun and Discrimination in Housing Against Nonwhites Persists Quietly
description: Updated: April 4

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Germany, Malaysia and India

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, Germany, Malaysia and India.

title: Moodys Downgrades Royal Bank of Scotland Ratings
description: LONDON  The credit rating agency Moodys Investors Service downgraded the Royal Bank of Scotlands long-term debt ratings on Thursday.

title: Bill Cunninghams Facades
description: From 1968 to 1976, the photographer Bill Cunningham shot vintage clothes, modeled by a friend and paired with period architecture.

title: After Stay in Gramercy Park, Calder Sculpture Pops Up in Maastricht
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  New Yorkers arriving at the invitation-only preview to the European Fine Art Fair on Thursday afternoon were greeted by a 26-foot-tall Alexander Calder sculpture that might look a bit familiar to some. Before being installed at the fairs entrance here, the bright-red 1969 standing mobile had been on view in Gramercy Park for the past three years.

title: Landmarks of Fashion
description: Bill Cunningham calls himself a street photographer, and in a way he is the innovator and prototype of that calling. Mr. Cunningham is modest and reserved, and street photographer doesnt fully explain his practice. He isnt a street photographer in the same sense as Elliott Erwitt or Gary Winogrand. He is not looking for extraordinary happenstance to make a remarkable picture; he is on the street to document the passing parade of fashion where it really lives  and as the public wears it, not as it is presented by editors, stylists and fashion photographers. As Mr. Cunningham has put it, The fashion show has always just been on the street.

title: Juggling, an Unexpected Workout
description: I RECENTLY added juggling to the list of physical feats I can perform, along with standing on my head and hula-hooping. I had never fully appreciated how hard  and how much of a workout  it could be until attending a beginners workshop on a wintry Saturday afternoon at a studio in Chelsea. Nevertheless, the instructor, Heather Wolf, was confident that by the end of the session everyone would be able to perform this ancient circus art.

title: Cleaning Tips Mama Never Told You
description: My wife and I arent much on housecleaning. We dont let things get foul. But we mostly agree with Phyllis Diller, who said that cleaning your house while your kids are still growing is like shoveling your walk before the snow stops. Plus we have enough animals to outfit a petting zoo.

title: Joel Brinkley, a Times Washington and Mideast Reporter, Dies at 61
description: Joel Brinkley, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter who spent more than two decades at The New York Times, where he displayed range, rigor and lucid writing as a White House correspondent, as Jerusalem bureau chief and as an editor, died on Tuesday in Washington. He was 61.

title: Harriet the Spy at 50
description: In her review of Harriet the Spy in The New York Times in 1964, Gloria Vanderbilt described the young heroine of the title as delicious, but thats probably because she hasnt included us in her spy route  yet. The 11-year-old Harriet, after all, had announced, When I grow up, Im going to find out everything about everybody and put it all in a book.

title: Showtime Orders Hedge Fund Pilot Called Billions
description: Showtime announced its first drama pilot order of the season Thursday, a project co-created by Andrew Ross Sorkin, the author and financial reporter for The New York Times.

title: Keeping the Recipes Within the Family
description: At one table were two police detectives (the holsters and handcuffs were a tip-off), having plates of pasta early on a Saturday night. In the back corner, one of the children at a family-sized table was still in her Our Lady of Perpetual Help basketball uniform. There was a guy in a Yankees cap and jeans on one side of the room; a few tables away, the fashion call was a suit, no tie.

title: Operators Are Standing By
description: Has this ever happened to you? Youre lingering by the canaps at a cocktail party when a stranger comes up and asks, And what do you do?

title: Judging the World
description: Hart and Schaffner are dead; Marx, ringed round with laurels, has notoriously retired. But the firm itself was dissolved long ago, and it was Saul Bellow who, with a sartorial quip, snipped the stitches that had sewn three acclaimed and determinedly distinct American writers into the same suit of clothes, with its single label: Jewish Writer. In Bellows parody, Bellow, Malamud and Roth were the literary equivalent of the much advertised mens wear company  but lighthearted as it was, the joke cut two ways: it was a declaration of imaginations independence of collective tailoring, and it laughingly struck out at the disgruntlement of those who, having themselves applied the label in pique, felt displaced by it.

title: Lions Gate Is Fined for Fending Off Carl Icahns Attentions
description: Pledging to go after companies that deceive shareholders in the course of fighting off a hostile tender offer, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that Lions Gate Entertainment had agreed to admit wrongdoing and pay a $7.5 million penalty for its actions in fending off a takeover by Carl C. Icahn.

title: A Wow of a Water Slide
description: Hold on to your bikini straps. Schlitterbahn, the Texas water park company, is opening its newest location in Kansas City, Kan., this spring, featuring what it claims will be the tallest and fastest water slide in the world.

title: Ken Okiishi: Reena Spaulings Fine Art
description: 165 East Broadway, at Rutgers Street,

title: Eric Doeringer: Paintings & Sculpture and Megan Whitmarsh: Fabricated Revisions
description: Mulherin & Pollard

title: Deducting Your Home Office, Made Simpler This Year
description: If you work at a home-based business, you may want to consider a new, simpler option for taking a deduction for your home office on your federal income tax return this year.

title: Fallout From Refinancing
description: Homeowners who refinanced when fixed mortgage rates dropped below 4 percent will be less inclined to put their homes on the market as interest rates climb. And as a result, the limited property supply already impeding sales in many markets may not ease anytime soon.

title: Brian Wood: Enceinte
description: Church of St. Paul the Apostle

title: David Goldes: Electro-graphs
description: Yossi Milo Gallery

title: Rudolf Stingel
description: Gagosian

title: Emilia Azcrate: Liminal
description: Henrique Faria Fine Art

title: Classy Burgers in Relaxed Settings
description: Ralph Perrazzo, 34, trained at the Culinary Institute of America and worked at celebrated restaurants like Jean-Georges in Manhattan, Bradley Ogden in Las Vegas (since closed) and Clio in Boston. Then, six months ago, the Long Island native returned to the North Shore  to heed a new culinary calling: Burgers.

title: Contemporary Photos Given to National Gallery
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington came later to photography than most big institutions. Though its holdings date to 1949, when Georgia OKeeffe donated 1,270 photographs made by her husband, Alfred Stieglitz, it didnt set up a separate photograph department until 1990. (The Museum of Modern Art in New York, by comparison, began assembling its photo collection in 1930 and a decade later formed a separate department.)

title: Fifty-Five Years of Reading Roth
description: Reviewing Philip Roths Goodbye, Columbus for the Book Review in 1959, William Peden called it perceptive, often witty and frequently moving. But first he introduced the author: An English instructor at the University of Chicago, 26-year-old Mr. Roth has published fiction in Harpers, The Paris Review, The New Yorker and other periodicals. Fifty-five years later, Roth has retired after writing 31 books. He talks about his career in this weeks issue.

title: Letters: Why Pick on M.F.A. Programs?
description: Get With the Program

title: U.S. Agrees to Allow BP Back Into Gulf Waters to Seek Oil
description: HOUSTON  Four years after the Deepwater Horizon rig explosion, BP is being welcomed back to seek new oil leases in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Charter Still Hanging Around Time Warner Cable
description: In early February, Comcast struck a deal to acquire Time Warner Cable for more than $45 billion, a move that will unite the two largest cable operators in the country if approved.

title: St. Johns Falls to Providence, Dimming N.C.A.A. Hopes
description: In a somber moment outside the St. Johns locker room after a tough loss at Madison Square Garden on Thursday, Coach Steve Lavin quietly made plans for Sunday.

title: Making Sushi and Friends
description: At a sushi-making class last month at Chef Central, a retail store with a cooking studio in Paramus, an informal survey of students revealed a spectrum of motivations: Evan Strassberg, 15, of Glen Rock, came because he is an aspiring cook. Sergio Minervini, 54, of River Vale, said he signed up with his wife and daughter as a family bonding thing. And Steve Fleischer, 50, of Suffern, N.Y., reserved two spots at the 90-minute class because he thought it was an inventive place to bring a first date.

title: Facebooks Zuckerberg Complains to Obama Over Government Spying
description: Updated | Added a response from a White House spokeswoman.

title: Degenerate Art Exhibit of 1937
description: Silent footage of the Degenerate Art exhibition in Munich, taken in 1937 by the American filmmaker Julien Bryan. The excerpt, part of a longer film, is featured in a new show at the Neue Galerie.

title: Bookshelf: Pets
description: New picture books include Megan McDonalds Shoe Dog and Jenny Offills Sparky!

title: Degenerate Art
description: A new exhibit at the Neue Galerie is devoted to modernist art seized by the Nazis.

title: Let Me Show You to Our Worst Table, Madame.
description: My friend Herb had a birthday recently, so I decided to take him to one of the nicer places in the neighborhood. We set out in a picturesque Sunday night snowstorm, happy in the warmth and comfort of 40 years of friendship, and a charming young hostess told us she had a lovely table for us and led us to the worst table in New York, in a narrow mezzanine between a service door and a waiters station.

title: Fast Cars, and Racing for Revenge
description: Based on a popular series of racing-themed video games, Need for Speed sums up its appeal in the title. An energetic, unpretentious B movie  the kind best seen at a drive-in like the one in an early scene  it is devoted, above all, to the delivery of visceral, kinetic excitement. In the game, you are at the wheel. Watching other people drive is never as much fun, so the movie, directed by Scott Waugh from a script by George Gatins, supplies a few passenger seat distractions. In addition to velocity, you may need some emotion.

title: Your Mother Is Grand
description: When my husband and I go out of town for long weekends, my mother takes care of our three sons (ages 8, 5 and 3). We appreciate this immensely: its free, we trust her, the boys adore her and she seems to enjoy it. The problem is, she leaves our house a mess. It takes me a full day to clean up the toys, half-washed clothing and dirty dishes. Plus, she lets the boys eat ice cream in my car, which creates a sticky mess. Complicating matters, she likes lots of praise and is sensitive to criticism. Next time, may I suggest the children stay at her place and offer to pay for maid service after they leave?

title: Confident CBS Renews 18 Shows at Once
description: CBS, which has the most consistent roster of prime-time shows, demonstrated its fundamental stability again Thursday, announcing the renewals of 18 shows at once.

title: Working With the Teenagers Internal Clock
description: Are teenagers developmentally driven to be late to bed, late to rise? A school board in Columbia, Mo., decided to find out, Jan Hoffman writes, by realigning its first bell with what many parents know as a biological reality. A nearly 20-year movement to start high schools later has recently gained momentum. In just the last two years, high schools in Long Beach, Calif.; Stillwater, Okla.; Decatur, Ga.;, and Glens Falls, N.Y., have pushed back their first bells, joining early adopters in Connecticut, North Carolina, Kentucky and Minnesota, she found.

title: No Pretenses, but Lots of Personality
description: IN his hilarious 1987 bar guide, The View From Nowhere, Jim Atkinson writes about the pleasures of what he calls bar bars, defined as real bars, bars and nothing else, institutions that exist as a sanctuary for those of us who just didnt want to be anyplace in particular at the moment.

title: First, They Came for the Art
description: Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937, at the Neue Galerie, opens with a quietly devastating compare-and-contrast. The walls of the narrow hallway leading onto the first gallery are covered with facing photomurals.

title: Ancient Prescriptions From Tibet
description: TIBETS LONG HISTORY OF ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE

title: Barbecue With Roots in Several States
description: New Englanders tend to feel abashed about their barbecue  geographically disadvantaged, perhaps  yet Connecticut in recent years has seen a proliferation of worthy barbecue venues. The smoky Southern breeze blows especially hard in Windsor, which hosts not one, not two, but three barbecue joints.

title: The Hamilton Theaters Changing Act
description: Broadway above West 135th Street is a tepid stretch of modest five- and six-story apartment houses, but one bright spot, at 146th Street, is the 1913 Hamilton Theater, one of the theater architect Thomas Lambs trademark gleaming terra-cotta designs. Its been bedraggled for years, the cornice sheared off, the window frames rusting, the auditorium a crumbling time warp. Now some of the excitement may be coming back, as a developer seems to be moving toward a fix-up, perhaps a full-blown restoration.

title: Wheelies: The Governators Tank Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Prospect-Lefferts Gardens Is On the Map
description: In a city where neighborhoods can transform in the blink of an eye, cranes and glass towers have come to signify areas that developers refer to as on the map, and Prospect-Lefferts Gardens and its environs are next in their sights.

title: S.E.C. Unveils Case Against 10th Former Employee of SAC Capital
description: Updated, 7:59 p.m. | Federal regulators on Thursday announced the latest case to stem from the decade-long insider trading investigation into SAC Capital Advisors, taking aim at a former employee for prompting a number of illegal trades.

title: Doors That Open to the Art of a Continent
description: LAST weeks contemporary art fairs gathered more or less like-minded galleries in concentrated spaces in several New York locations, but the annual Asia Week New York takes a different approach. Spread across 47 galleries, 19 museums and five auction houses, the featured art ranges over millenniums and vast regions. One common thread this year is the fluidity between periods, with traditional works alongside contemporary ones. The focus on traditional Asian forms remains, however, and you will see plenty of ceramics, bronzes, textiles and ink.

title: A Local Girl Who Made It Returns
description: The current cultural directive to give the people what they want explains the existence of the Veronica Mars movie, a likable, unmemorable, feature-length footnote to the admired television series that became a cause when it was canceled in 2007. A sleuth from the fictional, filthy rich town of Neptune, Veronica traversed high school and college for three seasons, solving mysteries while cracking wise about the privileged locals. She looked like a Southern California cheerleader and alternately talked like Sam Spade and Noam Chomsky, a combo that made her televisions very own Little Miss Sunshine and Noir.

title: A History of New York Fashion and Architecture, Through Bill Cunninghams Lens
description: Before Bill Cunningham became a regular presence on the sidewalks of New York  in his trim blue French workmans jacket, camera slung around his neck, perennially and furiously chronicling the comings and goings of the citys fashion elite for this newspaper  he embarked on a very different type of street-style assignment. Starting in 1968 and continuing through the mid-1970s, Cunningham undertook a particularly involved project to document Manhattans architectural and fashion history.

title: Clip: 'Ernest & Celestine'
description: A scene from the movie.

title: Amid Bitter Rift, Senate Approves Pick for Top C.I.A. Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday voted overwhelmingly to confirm President Obamas nominee to become the C.I.A.s top lawyer, as senior lawmakers escalated pressure on the agencys director to make public a voluminous report on the C.I.A.s defunct detention and interrogation program.

title: Obama Seeks Expansion of Overtime Pay
description: The president said he directed the Department of Labor to revise federal rules to make more workers eligible for overtime pay.

title: His Swans Are Primal, Yet Very Precise
description: MONACO  JEAN-CHRISTOPHE MAILLOT was in full swing. Prcis! Prcis! Hold! Stay! Feel where your body is! he cried in a mix of French and English. Phalanxes of dancers ran and leapt and balanced as Tchaikovskys Swan Lake music surged through the air. The desire to please was palpable. Mr. Maillot sighed. I dont know why I feel tender towards you today, he said.

title: U.S., Rebuffing U.N., Maintains Stance That Rights Treaty Does Not Apply Abroad
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration declared Thursday that a global Bill of Rights-style treaty imposes no human rights obligations on American military and intelligence forces when they operate abroad, rejecting an interpretation by the United Nations and the top State Department lawyer during President Obamas first term.

title: An Intimate Entree, Escorted by Beethoven
description: Egocentric Americans might assume that no gifted young performer from overseas can have a budding career in classical music without making significant appearances in the United States, especially, lets admit it, New York. But the success of the remarkable Russian-German pianist Igor Levit proves otherwise.

title: In Lunging Cowrie Shells, Gods Speak
description: DanceBrazil, a longtime staple at the Joyce Theater, is wrapping up a festival of Brazilian dance there through Sunday with its primal fusion of Afro-Brazilian movement and contemporary dance. At its core is capoeira, the martial-arts form from which much of the groups brash power derives. Performers contrast a weighted, rocking connection to the floor with bursts of upward energy: out of nowhere, a whipping fan kick spins into a cartwheel.

title: The Wisdom in the Middle
description: In recent days, as the debate over education has produced so many glowering expressions on so many faces all over the city, I have heard people say, in a spirit of both bafflement and confession, that they dont know what to think about charters. In one sense, the befuddlement itself is a part of the problem, a suggestion that charter schools, like graphic wallpaper or adventurous restaurants in Brooklyn, constitute a matter about which one should have an opinion.

title: Close Enough to See the Scriabins Colors
description: It has become common for venues to set up extra chairs onstage whenever the prodigiously talented Russian pianist Evgeny Kissin gives a solo recital. On Monday evening, too, the capacity audience at Carnegie Hall spilled over onto the stage, where it offered Mr. Kissin a welcoming embrace during his mesmerizing performance of works by Schubert and Scriabin.

title: Senate Deal Is Reached on Restoring Jobless Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday reached an agreement to pay for an extension of an unemployment assistance program that expired in December, leaving more than a million Americans who have been out of work for a half-year or longer without support from the federal government.

title: Comedy Listings for March 14-20
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for March 14-20
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Grandeur, Delicacy and Duels in Nielsen Symphonies
description: In a much-quoted 1907 exchange, the two most important and influential symphonists of the 20th century expressed opposing views about the nature of that musical form. Sibelius spoke of deep logic, which requires that all its motifs must be linked to each other. No, Mahler replied: The symphony must be like the world. It must encompass everything.

title: A Spelling Bee Bully With Decades on His Rivals
description: For a guy who often plays nice, Jason Bateman sure knows how to wrap his lips around invective. He doesnt have an especially rubbery mouth, the kind that Jerry Lewis could stretch until it almost snapped, nor does it curl with the puckered elasticity displayed in the poster for Bad Words, a comedy about a guy who crashes childrens spelling bees. Sometimes, he just opens wide, and out pops an expletive. At other times, he turns his nice-guy face toward the target, pauses for a beat or two while he sizes up the opposition  maybe sends out a decoy, like a faint smile or a deceptively inviting word  and then he slashes and burns. The kids take it hard.

title: Press Wars in Ukraine
description: As Russian troops moved into Crimea, one of their targets was the army of journalists from around the world trying to tell the story.

title: Movie Listings for March 14-20
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: In Snub to Loeb, Sothebys Board Nominates 2 Independent Directors
description: Sothebys, the auction house fending off attacks by the activist billionaire Daniel S. Loeb, dug in its heels on Thursday by rejecting his proposal for new board members and instead selected two others.

title: Jumping Off the Screen
description: Several weeks ago, 30 young professionals crowded into a bare-bones Manhattan office space. It was frigid outside and the workday was long over, but this group was devoted. For nearly two hours, they debated the particulars of time travel, Chuck Berry songs, poodle skirts and the most pressing issue of all: Would they be able to track down a DeLorean?

title: Jazz Listings for March 14-20
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for March 14-20
description: Pop

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for March 14-20
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for March 14-20
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for March 14-20
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: For Dewhurst, a Familiar Spot Out on a Ledge
description: It would be interesting to know whether the film Groundhog Day is on the recently viewed list on David Dewhursts Netflix account.

title: Spare Times for March 14-20
description: SEPHARDIC JEWISH FILM FESTIVAL (Saturday through Thursday) Films of personal triumph and historical significance will be featured at this years festival  the 17th  presented by the American Sephardi Federation, with most screenings at the Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, Flatiron district. (Other locations include the JCC in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, and the Museum of Jewish Heritage, 36 Battery Place, Lower Manhattan.)

title: Where Performance Enhancers Are Legal
description: Inside every milquetoast beats the heart of a tiger waiting to be released. All it takes to liberate the beast is a beautiful, seductive woman whose wiles can turn a mouse into a man. So goes the hoary, misogynist pop myth that drives Better Living Through Chemistry, a tepid but pleasant comic satire given a shot of contemporaneity by its writing and directing team, Geoff Moore and David Posamentier, and its star Sam Rockwell.

title: In Laredo, a Quiet Symbol of Closer Ties With Mexico
description: LAREDO, Tex.  A little-known customs agreement between the United States and Mexico removes a major hurdle in how goods move across the border and could be an economic boon to South Texas, trade experts and elected officials say.

title: When Your Twin Is Far More Interesting
description: The double is an ancient and irresistible literary theme, especially beloved by philosophically minded scaremongers like Edgar Allan Poe, whose tale William Wilson is a concise classic on the matter. The idea of a second self  who might be the manifestation of madness, an allegory come to life or the result of a supernatural glitch in the order of things  is both frightening and fascinating. Movies make the conceit literal with the simple trick of using the same actor in two roles. Who can forget the two Kim Novaks driving James Stewart around the bend in Vertigo?

title: Weakened by Mobile, Desktop Search Advertising Is Declining
description: In the latest example of mobile phones upending of the tech industry, desktop search advertising, perhaps the most lucrative online business, is shrinking.

title: Being a Catholic in the Time of Francis
description: To the Editor:

title: This Week's Movies: March 14, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics on "Need for Speed," "Veronica Mars" and "Le Week-End."

title: Economists Hit Back in the Minimum-Wage Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: A Practical Guide to Buying and Selling Smartphones That Last
description: In my column today, I wrote about buying smartphones with an eye to longevity  not just using them for two years and then leaving them forgotten in the desk drawer.

title: Disabled Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Prisoners and Health Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Innovation in the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Spare Times for Children for March 14-20
description: AN AFTERNOON WITH KEVIN HENKES

title: Events in New Jersey for March 16-22
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Chronicler of Presidents Is Bringing Four Together
description: Few occasions are notable enough to bring together former and sitting presidents  inaugurations, funerals, the opening of a presidential library. But next month, four presidents will participate in an Austin, Texas, event that goes beyond ceremonial roles. And one man is largely responsible for putting the event together.

title: Center for Auto Safety Letter to N.H.T.S.A.
description: The Center for Auto Safety on Thursday sent a letter to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration regarding safety issues concerning G.M. vehicles.

title: Why Black Women Die of Cancer
description: SINCE the early 1970s, studies have shown that black Americans have a higher death rate from cancer than any other racial or ethnic group. This is especially true when it comes to breast cancer. A study published last week in the journal Cancer Epidemiology found that, in a survey of 41 of Americas largest cities, black women with breast cancer are on average 40 percent more likely to die than their white counterparts.

title: 303 Deaths Seen in G.M. Cars With Failed Air Bags
description: As lawmakers press General Motors and regulators over their decade-long failure to correct a defective ignition switch, a new review of federal crash data shows that 303 people died after the air bags failed to deploy on two of the models that were recalled last month.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Fear of Wages
description: Four years ago, some of us watched with a mixture of incredulity and horror as elite discussion of economic policy went completely off the rails. Over the course of just a few months, influential people all over the Western world convinced themselves and each other that budget deficits were an existential threat, trumping any and all concern about mass unemployment. The result was a turn to fiscal austerity that deepened and prolonged the economic crisis, inflicting immense suffering.

title: Liberty Abandons Plan to Buy Rest of Sirius
description: Liberty Media, the company controlled by John C. Malone, announced late Thursday that it had abandoned its plan to buy the shares of SiriusXM that it did not already own as part of a move to set up two tracking stocks to house the companys assets.

title: Bayern Munichs Hoeness Sentenced to Prison for Tax Evasion
description: Uli Hoeness, the president of the European champion soccer club Bayern Munich, was convicted Thursday of tax evasion and sentenced to three and a half years in prison after a four-day trial that had consumed the country.

title: Events on Long Island for March 16-22
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Crimean Tatars Face Uncertain Future
description: Seventy years after Stalin brutally deported thousands of Crimean Tatars to Central Asia, the descendants of those who returned fear repression as Russia tightens its grip on the peninsula.

title: Mindful of Past, Many Tatars Fear a Russian Future
description: BAKHCHYSARAY, Ukraine  Outside the ornate auburn gates of the Khans Palace here in the historical capital of the Crimean Tatars, the streets are empty. Many stores are shuttered, their doors padlocked.

title: Events in Connecticut for March 16-22
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Bob Crow, Firebrand at Helm of British Union, Dies at 52
description: LONDON  He called his dog Castro and quit the Communist Party because it was too moderate.

title: A Theory Behind Surge in Xbox One Sales
description: In January, Sonys PlayStation 4 walloped Microsofts Xbox One console in sales, outselling it in the United States nearly two-to-one.

title: Eater Hires Three Restaurant Critics
description: Eater, the food blog that started in 2005 as a self-proclaimed restaurant rumor mill, has hired three experienced restaurant critics, an ambitious expansion under its new owner, Vox Media, which acquired Eater.com and its siblings Curbed.com and Racked.com in November.

title: Oil Money, and Where It Flows
description: Not for nothing does Big Men, Rachel Boyntons astonishing documentary about the 2007 discovery of oil off the coast of Ghana, open with a quotation on greed from the economist Milton Friedman. Dropping us into a perfect storm of avarice, this cool and incisive snapshot of global capitalism at work is as remarkable for its access as for its refusal to judge.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 91
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Events in Westchester for March 16-22
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: New Name and Mission for Taylor Dance Troupe
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company announced Thursday that it had commitments of $10 million to reinvent itself next year as Paul Taylors American Modern Dance, a center that will perform dances by Mr. Taylor, other modern dance pioneers and contemporary choreographers.

title: Mae Keane, Whose Job Brought Radium to Her Lips, Dies at 107
description: Like other young women working at the Waterbury Clock Company in Connecticut the 1920s, Mae Keane was taught a specific technique for applying paint to the numbers on wristwatch dials: Put the tip of the tiny brush between your lips to shape the bristles into the finest of points.

title: A Devils Anomaly: Porous Defense, Potent Offense
description: NEWARK  Tuomo Ruutu almost did not recognize the team for which he was playing.

title: Former Egyptian General Calls Promise of Free Elections a Farce
description: CAIRO  Critics of the military takeover here often say the generals promise of free elections is little more than a bad joke. Now a prominent former military man who cheered the takeover seems to agree: Ahmed Shafik, a former general and prime minister and the runner-up in the last presidential election, has called it a farce.

title: The Black Press During the Civil War
description: Although the Civil War began as a conflict over secession, from the start most blacks saw it as an opportunity to free the enslaved with a Union victory  a theme reflected in the robust black press that prospered across the North.

title: For-Profit Schools Face New Default Rules
description: For-profit colleges would lose all federal student aid, a fatal blow, if their students fail tests of earnings and debt default, the Obama administration will propose Friday. The rule would replace one struck down last year by a court. The proposed rule covers about 8,000 professional programs, each rated separately, and currently about 20 percent would fail, Education Secretary Arne Duncan said. Among other measures, a program would fail if 30 percent of former students defaulted on loans. The programs include those that grant certificates in trades, mostly at for-profit schools, and most degree-granting programs at for-profits.

title: At Spring Training With the Mets, the Good, the Bad and the Apology
description: VIERA, Fla.  The first batter Daisuke Matsuzaka faced on Thursday, Denard Span of the Washington Nationals, doubled, stole third base and scored on a groundout. It was the only blemish in an otherwise sharp outing for Matsuzaka, who is trying to win a job in the Mets rotation.

title: A Quiet Village in the Catskills Braces for an Influx of Hasidim
description: BLOOMINGBURG, N.Y.  Clifford M. Teich came to this rustic village in the foothills of the Catskills 30 years ago to be a country doctor, an internist who would treat his fellow villagers aches and pains, and get to know them as neighbors. He occasionally accepts payment in the form of homegrown onions and tomatoes.

title: Wendys Turns Up Volume on Adoption Drive
description: DAVE THOMAS, the founder of the Wendys Company, was adopted at six weeks old, so it was fitting when the hamburger magnate started the Dave Thomas Foundation for Adoption in 1992.

title: Soaring Prices Fuel Frustrations Among Weary Argentines
description: BUENOS AIRES  Diego Gmez scurried around the food market, a labyrinth of bustling stalls in a gritty neighborhood far from the elegant avenues of central Buenos Aires. He did not stay long.

title: Iraq: Members of Wedding Party Are Killed in Blast
description: A car bomber detonated his explosives at an army checkpoint on a bridge in Anbar Province on Thursday, killing at least 16 people, including security officers and members of a wedding party. The groom and his family were on their way to the brides house near the town of Rawa when they were struck by the explosion, relatives said. The groom survived but was hospitalized with a head wound, said Ahmed al-Rawi, a relative. We wanted a wedding so we can party and smile, but instead the wedding turned into a funeral, Mr. Rawi said.

title: A Tough Day Being French (She Needs a Cigarette)
description: The word that best describes Catherine Deneuve in Emmanuelle Bercots likable French road movie, On My Way, is unflappable. Her character, Bettie, who runs a failing bistro in Brittany, is a former regional beauty queen in her 60s who lives with her controlling mother, Annie (Claude Gensac).

title: Scott Brown May Seek Office Again, but in New Hampshire
description: BOSTON  After a year of mulling his political future, Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, has told people on Capitol Hill that he intends to open an exploratory committee and run this year for the Senate from New Hampshire, according to people with firsthand knowledge of those discussions.

title: At South Jersey Forum, Hecklers Test Christies Paramount Rule
description: MOUNT LAUREL, N.J.  The foremost rule at a Chris Christie Town Hall is inviolate and oft-repeated: Do not, under any circumstances, shout out questions unless called upon.

title: The Deepest Self
description: There is, by now, a large literature on the chemistry and biology of love and sex. If you dive into that literature, you learn pretty quickly that our love lives are biased by all sorts of deep unconscious processes. When men become fathers, their testosterone levels drop, thus reducing their sex drive. Theres some evidence that its the smell of their own infants (but not other peoples infants) that sets this off.

title: Saving a Future for Those With Disabilities
description: Back in the old days, when Congress did crazy things like pass legislation, a sensible bill like the ABLE Act might have sailed to the presidents desk. But today, even with a long list of positives  its a good idea, solves a pressing problem and has lots of bipartisan support  its not a slam dunk, because theres always a way in Washington to squelch good ideas, especially those that involve tweaking the tax code and spending a little money.

title: Giants Justin Tuck Takes Two-Year Deal With Raiders
description: Justin Tuck, a defensive end whose pass-rushing skills and leadership helped the Giants to two N.F.L. championships during his nine-year career, spoke of winning more Super Bowls after signing on Thursday with the lowly Oakland Raiders.

title: Can New York Lead on Campaign Finance Reform?
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and lawmakers in New York State are tantalizingly close to making political history by enacting a campaign-finance reform law that not only would weaken the power of special interests and make elections more competitive, but also could set an example for the rest of the country.

title: El Salvador: Officials Confirm Ex-Guerrillas Victory
description: El Salvadors electoral tribunal on Thursday confirmed that Salvador Snchez Cern, a former guerrilla commander during the countrys civil war, emerged from Sundays presidential election with the most votes, by a margin of 6,364. But his opponents party, the right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance, or Arena, said it would not accept the results without a manual recount. The party said it submitted evidence of fraud to the attorney generals office. International election monitors and Attorney General Luis Martnez Gonzlez have said there was no sign of wrongdoing during the election.

title: U.S. Takes Back Seat in Malaysian Jet Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The best information about Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 is probably in the hands of American officials sent to assist in the investigation. But they will say nothing.

title: Happy Meals, Unhappy Workers
description: McDonalds and several franchise owners were hit this week with seven lawsuits brought by workers in California, Michigan and New York. The details differ, but all the cases charge wage theft  the violation of federal labor laws, including failure to pay the minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime, denial of meal periods and rest breaks, and mandatory unpaid work.

title: De Blasio Closes In on Pre-K Funding, but Not From a Higher Tax
description: ALBANY  Even as he came under escalating attacks from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the Legislature for his stance toward charter schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday stepped closer to securing state financing to expand prekindergarten in New York City.

title: Ukraine Premier Makes Plea at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  Ukraines interim prime minister, seeking to rally support for a Security Council resolution criticizing the Russian takeover of Crimea, took pains on Thursday to say that his country wanted a peaceful resolution to the crisis.

title: Trying to Take What Isnt Theirs
description: Matt Dillon and Kurt Russell may not make the most convincing half-brothers, but The Art of the Steal is a fairly amusing heist film with some sibling tension helping the story along.

title: Fixing Ukraines Economy
description: International efforts to provide financial aid to Ukraine offer a chance to fix a troubled economy. But those efforts will help only if the countrys new leaders are willing to end bad policies like wasteful energy subsidies and take steps to increase exports.

title: No Easy Task in Bid to Find Seats for Pre-K
description: Let us leave Albany to its machinations, and for todays discussion of universal prekindergarten, turn to the principles of the hydraulic power of toddlers.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 13, 2014
description: March 13, 2014

title: Are Infrastructure Needs Truly Urgent?
Absence of U.S. Envoy in Dublin Looms Over White House St. Patricks Day
description: WASHINGTON  When Prime Minister Enda Kenny of Ireland presented President Obama with a traditional bowl of shamrocks at the White House on Friday to celebrate St. Patricks Day, there was a rare snake lurking at this convivial garden party.

title: Obama, Citing a Concern for Families, Orders a Review of Deportations
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Thursday that deportations of illegal immigrants should be more humane, and to make that happen, he has ordered a review of his administrations enforcement efforts.

title: G.O.P. Moving to Ease Its Stance on Sentencing
description: WASHINGTON  Not that long ago, criminal justice reform in a conservative place like Texas meant executing prisoners with lethal injection instead of the electric chair.

title: Turkish Leader Deplores Unrest, Calling Demonstrators Fakers
description: ISTANBUL  Breaking his silence, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Thursday condemned as fakers protesters who have been demonstrating across Turkey since Tuesday night, when a 15-year-old boy who had become a symbol of civilian resistance died after months in a coma.

title: A Kiss Is Just a Kiss, Unless Its an Ad for a Clothing Company
description: The email Tatia Pilieva sent to 21 people Monday morning started off the way such notes usually do when someone wants to get a link on Facebook.

title: Two Coaches Born Into Fame Earn Respect Themselves
description: When Dan Hurley was the coach at Wagner and his brother, Bobby, was an assistant, their father, the Hall of Fame coach Bob Hurley Sr., would often drive from Jersey City to Staten Island to watch the Seahawks morning practices. He saw them steadily improve, from a team that had gone 5-26 before Dans arrival to a squad that won a program-record 25 games only two seasons later.

title: Murder, Mentoring and Masochism in Japan
description: Guilty of Romance is a garish-colored noir by the Japanese filmmaker Sion Sono. Black shadows and bright green and pink lights set the tone of this sickening, lush mystery about two female corpses, each partly a severed human and partly a mannequin.(This is seemingly a nod to the real-life 1940s Black Dahlia case.)

title: In Cambodia, Voicing the Struggle
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  As freedom fighters go, Mam Sonando stands out as somewhat eccentric. The entrance to his radio station, which is described by his loyal supporters as Cambodias only truly independent broadcaster, is decorated like a nightclub, complete with colored lights and a disco ball. It also has at least four Buddhist shrines.

title: Former U.S. Ambassador Confronts Russian Networks Editors Over Reporting on Crimea
