description: Michael McFaul returned to academic life at Stanford last month after two years in Moscow as the United States ambassador to Russia, but he has continued to engage with Russian critics of American foreign policy on Twitter in lively exchanges across 12 time zones, despite the attendant frustrations.

title: In Japan, Two Teenagers Bond in a Chaotic, Violent World
description: Himizu is a futuristic, dystopian film set in the present. It was made by Sion Sono in 2011, soon after the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan.

title: Mutual Self-Interest May Help Advance Deal Allowing Aid to Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  Republican leaders have proposed giving the Obama administration the changes it badly wants for the International Monetary Fund in exchange for delaying regulations on tax-exempt political organizations, enraging some members of both parties who say they are holding urgent aid to Ukraine hostage for conservative donors like the Koch brothers.

title: Big East Tournament at the Garden Lacks New York Flavor
description: Behind the St. Johns bench, three rows up, Lou Carnesecca rose in protest, along with those around him. From across the floor, you could read his lips.

title: Russia Blocks Web Content Amid Tension Over Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  The Russian authorities on Thursday blocked three websites and a blog, including platforms used by the opposition figures Aleksei A. Navalny and Garry K. Kasparov, saying that Russias general prosecutor had ordered the sites closed because they had encouraged illegal activities and participation in public events held in violation of the established order.

title: In 2 East Harlem Buildings Leveled by Explosion, Lives Entwined as in Bygone Era
description: In the three floors above the Spanish Christian Church lived a 44-year-old security guard and a 67-year-old dental hygienist. There was a 22-year-old line cook at a four-star Midtown Manhattan hotel and her mother, who immigrated from Mexico. All were members of the 80-year-old church downstairs.

title: A Review of Banks in Europe Gets Results
description: What is an asset worth? How much capital does a bank really have?

title: The Killer Online
description: While the horror film The Den indulges in the hoary found-footage conceit and traffics in shopworn genre staples (dank hallways, claustrophobic subterranean lairs), it brings a new player to the party: the online video chat. And the movie, the feature debut of the director, Zach Donohue (who wrote the script with Lauren Thompson), does so with flair.

title: Swinging at Fighters and Serenading Turtles
description: The official curtain time for Rocky, the new musical at the Winter Garden Theater, is 8 on most nights. But at the risk of promoting tardiness among theatergoers, I feel obliged to point out that the show doesnt really get started until 10:10 or thereabouts.

title: The Shorter You Are
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Im of two minds about this puzzle. Your mileage may vary. All I can tell you is that this wasnt my most enjoyable solve.

title: Young Drifter
description: Raised off the grid and orphaned at 11, Atticus lives through more than one rough patch over the course of Tom Gilroys The Cold Lands. This becalmed film, which was partly shot in a woodsy part of New York State, fails to crystallize until Atticus attaches himself to a dude who sells homemade trinkets.

title: New York City Bar Association Urges Steps to Improve Ethics Panel
description: ALBANY  The New York State commission charged with investigating the shenanigans of public officials is being urged to take major steps to shore up its image.

title: Target Missed Signs of a Data Breach
description: Target acknowledged on Thursday that its computer security system had alerted it to suspicious activity after hackers infiltrated its network last year, but the company ultimately decided to ignore it, allowing what would become one of the largest data breaches ever recorded to proceed without a hitch.

title: With Gas Explosion in Her District, City Councils New Speaker Is at Center Stage
description: By midafternoon on Thursday, Melissa Mark-Viveritos eyes were smarting, her clothes rank with the smell of smoke. But her day was not over. There were more grim conversations to have with the medical examiners office, and a prayer circle organized by local pastors to attend.

title: Interrogation of Bin Laden Relative Is Recounted
description: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a close associate of Osama bin Ladens, told the authorities after his arrest last year that the Sept. 11 terror attacks were a surprise to him, but that he had heard around Qaeda training camps in Afghanistan that something big was going to happen, a federal agent testified on Thursday.

title: A Female Trailblazers Next Notch
description: COLUMBUS, Ga.  At the Columbus Cottonmouths morning skate on Thursday, Brad Prefontaine, the assistant coach, opened the door to the practice rink for Shannon Szabados, who squeezed through in her goaltending gear. This is the last time Im going to do that for you, he said, jokingly.

title: Federal Judge Went Too Far in Lawsuits, a Court Says
description: Something about the cases seemed wrong. The lawsuits, scores of them, accused businesses of failing to provide proper access for disabled customers. Defendants who lost had to pay the plaintiffs legal fees, and they piled up in case after case. Last year, a federal judge in Brooklyn, citing troubling litigation tactics, denied legal fees, based in part on an unusual step by his chambers. His staff members investigated the matter outside the courtroom.

title: Preserving Culture in the Amazon
description: A gripping account of a collision of cultures, Xingu tells the inspiring true story of the three Villas Bas brothers, who became the leading advocates for Brazils Amazonian Indians, an effort that culminated in the founding of a mammoth tribal preserve.

title: Artistic Director of New York Live Arts Leaving for Post in Florida
description: Carla Peterson stayed in the same building when she changed jobs in 2006, from executive director of Movement Research to artistic director of Dance Theater Workshop, now known as New York Live Arts. Now she is going to need some interstate transport. The Maggie Allesee National Center for Choreography at Florida State University has announced that Ms. Peterson will be its next director, following Jennifer Calienes, who has held the position since the centers inception in 2004.

title: Two Stars Longing for Jackson to Return to the Lakers
description: LOS ANGELES  The coach-as-imperialist figure is increasingly a relic in the N.B.A., as more teams turn toward low-profile game managers who dutifully carry out the analytics-driven, playing-for-tomorrow plan set out by well-educated executives.

title: Yankees Head to Panama and a Reunion With Rivera
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joe Girardi had barely heard a comment concerning the weather in Panama when he blurted: Ninety-eight, every day. Friday, Saturday, Sunday. Ninety-eight. The low is 75, and if you look during the middle of the day its not humid, but it gets humid at night. Believe me, I checked it out. Its 98, 98, 98.

title: Singapore Government Firm Pursues Buyout of Olam International
description: HONG KONG  Olam International, a Singapore agricultural commodities company that has been targeted by the short seller Carson C. Block, said on Friday that it had received a cash buyout offer led by a Singapore government investment firm valuing it at more than $4 billion.

title: Not Quite Grown-Ups
description: A lot of intriguing ideas are floated in Teenage, a frenetic documentary by Matt Wolf about the creation of the Western concept of the teenager. But the film takes a point of view that leaves all of them underdeveloped.

title: A Good-Will Trip to Las Vegas for the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It is a more or less unwritten rule of spring training: Established veterans are not asked to make too many two-hour bus rides across Florida to play in spring training games. There will be plenty of travel once the regular season begins.

title: Some Things Go Bump in the Daytime, Too
description: Mere minutes into Dark House, it becomes depressingly clear that the deficit of imagination displayed by the title will not be made up for by the content. (One wonders why the makers even bothered to replace the original name, Haunted.) Grabbing off-the-rack ideas  the creepy-crumbly mansion in the woods, the Deliverance-style locals, the troubled young man with the weird psychic power  the director, Victor Salva, stuffs them into a plot of resounding silliness.

title: Yankees Pineda Makes Impression Against Orioles
description: After another strong performance, the Yankees continued to be optimistic about Michael Pineda.

title: L.A.s Thai Wunderkind Serves Up a Second Course
description: The peppercorns come back from near the Burmese border in Kris Yenbamroongs suitcase, wrapped in newsprint. The waterbugs, however, are a little trickier. He buys them frozen in packs of four from a market in the San Fernando Valley, steams them, and grinds them into nam prik, a relish he serves with long beans, cabbage and house-made fermented sausage.

title: Looking for Love? This New Fragrance Could Help You Find It
description: The artists Carole Beaupr and Pauline Rochas started their still-life and beauty photography studio Coolife in 2000, and since then the pair has been conceptualizing bold imagery for clients like Ralph Lauren and Este Lauder. Now, Beaupr and Rochas  the latter a granddaughter of Marcel Rochas, the founder of theRochas fashion and fragrance house  have broadened their creative portfolio by creating an intriguing new scent, Le Premier Parfum.

title: How to Shave $1 Trillion Out of Health Care
description: Victor R. Fuchs is Professor Emeritus of Economics and Health Research and Policy at Stanford University, and author of Who Shall Live? Health, Economics and Social Choice.

title: U.N. Envoy Warns Against Syria Elections
description: Lakhdar Brahimi, the United Nations special envoy to Syria, warned that holding elections would doom prospects for any future talks between the warring parties.

title: Ask Well: Laser Treatments for Nail Fungus
description: Question:

title: Amid Preparations, Mediator Says Syria Vote Would Doom Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations mediator who has sought to coax the warring parties in Syria to negotiate an end to the three-year-old conflict said on Thursday that holding elections would doom prospects for any future talks, even as lawmakers in Damascus appeared to inch closer to scheduling national polls.

title: Word of the Day | parable
description: parable \pa-r-bl\ noun

title: South Korean School for Scandal
description: In Tabloid Truth, the director Kim Kwang-sik explores the underbelly of a world that may sound familiar to fans of House of Cards or Scandal. Here, journalists, political figures and businessmen (yes, all men) collude to shape public opinion and further their agendas. At meetings, they hatch up news (accuracy is not a guiding principle) that is disseminated via an exclusive stock market tip sheet, whipping the tabloids into a frenzy.

title: Emails Link Duke Energy and North Carolina
description: Environmental regulators in North Carolina consulted Duke Energy last year before seeking to exclude citizen activists from talks to settle charges that the utilitys coal ash ponds had polluted the states groundwater, newly released email exchanges among the regulators indicated on Thursday.

title: Matthew Power, Wide-Roving Journalist, Dies at 39
description: Matthew Power, a wide-roving journalist whose writing took readers from a journey down the Mississippi with modern-day hobos to the scenes of international disasters and inside the Lower East Side apartment where Allen Ginsberg spent his last days, died on Monday in Uganda. He was 39.

title: Times Minute | Flight 370's Pings
description: More information on the search for the Malaysian jetliner on the Minute including the United States' silent role in the investigation and withering criticism of Malaysia's political elite.

title: Times Minute | Flight 370s Pings
description: In the Video

title: Peter Callander, Lyricist of Pop Hits in 60s and 70s, Dies at 74
description: Peter Callander, a British songwriter who provided lyrics for hits of the 1960s and 70s like The Night Chicago Died and Billy, Dont Be a Hero, died on Feb. 25 in Haresfield, Middlesex, England. He was 74.

title: Their Life Is a Cabaret, With Freedom in Vulgarity
description: Dancing on the wilder shores of burlesque, the eight performers profiled in Exposed practice the kind of subversive cabaret that few non-city-dwellers are likely to have seen. Thats too bad, because these confrontational comedians  however serious the message, its always imparted with liberal dollops of humor  are experts at merging shock and showmanship.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 8:15 A.M. (TMC) THE COLOR OF MONEY (1986) Paul Newman reprises his role as the pool player Fast Eddie Felson from The Hustler (1961) in this Martin Scorsese film, set 25 years after the original. Felson now serves as the manager and mentor of Vincent Lauria (Tom Cruise), a talented but nave, young pool shark. When a disagreement leads Felson and Lauria to part ways, the stage is set for teacher-student showdown on the green felt. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby described Mr. Newmans Oscar-winning portrayal as a wonderfully funny, canny performance, set off by the actors intelligence that shines through the character without upstaging it.

title: Writing a New Romance
description: Dull filmmaking and spiritless dialogue can together feel like a curse that hangs over actors, stifling their every other scene. Nominally a romantic comedy in the ethnic-family subgenre, Shirin in Love is a case in point, plodding along with the young Iranian-American writer of the title as she gets cold feet about marrying her fianc, a surgeon, and pursues the son of an interview subject.

title: A Marketplace Dispute in Central China Turns Deadly
description: An argument between two vendors in a marketplace in Changsha Friday morning escalated into a fight that left five people stabbed to death and one man shot and killed by the police, a police statement said.

title: A Documentary on Battling Addictions Powerful Pull
description: Joining the stunned conversation surrounding Philip Seymour Hoffmans recent overdose, The Anonymous People could not have appeared at a more opportune moment. But however good the intentions, this sluggish documentary about the stigma of substance abuse and the barriers to recovery never comes close to catching fire.

title: Compromising Moral Positions
description: The writer and director of more than 40 feature films, Woody Allen is one of the most driven artists in Hollywood history. Im not sufficiently driven to have seen every one of his movies, but of the three dozen or so I have taken in, one stands alone: Crimes and Misdemeanors, newly out in a limited edition Blu-ray from Twilight Time.

title: Corrections: March 14, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Report Finds Punctuality Trumps Safety at Metro-North
description: The Metro-North Railroad has fallen prey to a deficient safety culture that prizes on-time performance at the expense of protecting riders and workers, according to a blistering federal review that was ordered after a spate of rail disasters.

title: Jet Skids Off Philadelphia Runway After Takeoff Is Aborted
description: A US Airways jet en route from Pennsylvania to Florida skidded off the runway during an aborted takeoff on Thursday after the planes nose gear collapsed, forcing an emergency evacuation of the disabled plane, officials said.

title: Social Media App Blocks Prominent Chinese Accounts
description: Several prominent Chinese-language accounts on the social media app WeChat were suspended on Thursday in what users called the broadest clampdown on the service so far.

title: U.S.-Russia Talks on Ukraine Fail to Ease Tension
description: LONDON  An 11th-hour bid by Secretary of State John Kerry to ease the escalating crisis over the Kremlins intervention in Crimea ended in failure on Friday, raising the likelihood of sanctions against Russia and deepening the most serious East-West rift since the end of the Cold War.

title: Tony Benn, Who Preferred Politics to an Aristocrats Title, Dies at 88
description: LONDON  Tony Benn, a passionate orator, prolific diarist and provocative leader of the British left who became the first peer to surrender an aristocratic title to remain in the House of Commons, died on Friday at his home in West London. He was 88.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, March 14, 2014
description: Use the following question for practice or just for fun.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Celebrating Pi Day
description: In celebration of Pi Day, we pose questions that link to Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about pi and Pi Day.

title: What Qualities Would You Look For in a College Roommate?
description: Recent studies show that the roommate you are paired with in college can affect everything from academic performance to freshman weight gain. While you may not have as much say in the matter as you would like if you attend a college away from home, what qualities would you look for in a college roommate?

title: Emmet Gowin: Loving the Problem
description: The telephone rang in a Pennsylvania home last month and was answered by Edith Gowin, known to many as the subject of her husbands most striking photographs.

title: Investment Bank Chief is UBSs Top-Paid Executive
description: LONDON  The head of UBSs investment bank was the companys highest-paid executive in 2013, earning more than Sergio P. Ermotti, the Swiss lenders chief executive, according to its annual report released on Friday.

title: New York Today: After the Frost
description: Good Friday morning to you.

title: Uber Expands Insurance Program for Community Drivers
description: Uber, the maker of a smartphone app for summoning cars for rides, has been under intense scrutiny since an Uber driver struck and killed a 6-year-old girl late last year, when he was between fares  raising questions about when Uber should be held responsible for an accident.

title: India Expands Its Efforts in Search for Missing Jet
description: NEW DELHI  Indian military forces searched hundreds of uninhabited islands in the Andaman Sea on Friday for any signs of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 as efforts to find the wreckage turned westward from the aircrafts origin in Kuala Lumpur.

title: UBS Tried to Rig Interest Rate, Hong Kong Regulator Finds
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kongs main banking regulator on Friday released the results of an investigation that found that traders at the Swiss bank UBS tried to rig a local benchmark interest rate over a four-year period.

title: Bayern Munich President Accepts Jail Term for Tax Evasion
description: BERLIN  When all of his cards were played and Uli Hoeness, the Bayern Munich president and German soccer legend, faced the prospect of a protracted and high-profile appeal of his conviction on charges of tax evasion, he chose to take his punishment.

title: China Puts a Stop to Plans for Virtual Credit Cards
description: HONG KONG  Chinas central bank has ordered the Internet giants Alibaba and Tencent to halt plans to issue virtual credit cards in partnership with a large Chinese bank, citing concern over safety risks.

title: Whos More Famous Than Jesus?
description: There are many varieties of fame. Jesus Christ was the first person to achieve it globally, Clive James wrote, without conquering the world by violence. The best kind for a poet to earn, W. H. Auden said, is like some valley cheese  local, but prized elsewhere. Yet if all fame, like all politics, is to some degree local, how thoroughly it has been transmitted across the planet and through the centuries has been difficult, if not impossible, to quantify.

title: The I.R.S.s Final Mandate Reporting Rules? Still Complicated
description: Last summer, the Obama administration delayed implementing the employer mandate in the Affordable Care Act because, it said, it needed time to figure out how it might simplify the laws complicated reporting requirements for businesses with 50 or more employees. We dont necessarily need to load up the vast majority of companies that are already doing the right thing with a bunch of additional paperwork, President Obama told The Times in an interview in July, asking, Are there simpler ways for us to allow them to certify that theyre providing health insurance?

title: 15 Power Couples of the Last 6,000 Years
description: Of the many categories you can use to sort the giant database of fame that M.I.T.s media lab put online today  artist, lawyer, philosopher, pirate  one of the most captivating is companion. It makes sense that in any rankings of cultural production (Dwight Garner has more on how exactly they were produced), some people make the list not for what theyve done but whom they know. Most of the famous companions are women married to distinguished men, but not all. Theres Joseph Bonaparte, elder brother of Napoleon, who comes in at No. 1,683 (his brother is No. 21), and Al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib (No. 4,519), the uncle of Muhammad (No. 13).

title: Spring Cleaning Who Has Access to Your Data
description: Its almost that time of year again. Wash off the car. Take the cover off the grill. And figure out who has access to your social accounts.

title: Time to Adjust Overtime Pay
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Daily Report: Target Missed Warning Signs of Data Breach
description: Target acknowledged on Thursday that its computer security system had alerted it to suspicious activity after hackers infiltrated its network last year, but the company decided to ignore it, allowing what would become one of the largest data breaches ever recorded to proceed without a hitch, Elizabeth A. Harris and Nicole Perlroth report.

title: America Exports Democracy, Just Not the Way You Think
description: Those seeking evidence that the United States retains an ability to export democracy in the 21st century should turn their attention away from city squares in Kiev and Cairo to more peaceful terrain where a major global devolution of control from political elites is underway.

title: Chilean Architect to Design Serpentine Gallerys Summer Pavilion in London
description: London Daniel Libeskind designed a set of steel panels folded like origami, Frank Gehry piled up a stack of timber beams and glass panels,Rem Koolhaas built an inflatable canopy that was described as a cosmic egg. Those architects are just three of the famous names who have designed the Serpentine Gallerys summer pavilion, a temporary structure that has been constructed in Kensington Gardens in London each year since 2000, and which has become a major tourist attraction here.

title: Notes on Piketty (Wonkish)
description: Im working on a long-form review (for the New York Review of Books) of Thomas Pikettys epic Capital in the 21st Century; I dont want to steal my own thunder, so a broader reaction will have to wait. But for my own edification I wanted to write up a clarification of a couple of technical points.

title: Consumers Not Powerless in the Face of Credit Card Fraud
description: When you think about the security of your credit and debit cards, consider the facts on the ground.

title: S.E.C. Takes Aim at Another Former SAC Employee
description: S.E.C. TAKES AIM AT 10TH FORMER SAC EMPLOYEE | The Securities and Exchange Commissions investigation into Steven A. Cohens hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, isnt done just yet. Federal regulators announced on Thursday a civil case against Ronald N. Dennis, who worked for SAC for less than two years, for prompting a number of illegal trades stemming from confidential tips he received about two technology companies, Dell and Foundry Networks, Ben Protess and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Dennis, the 10th former employee of SAC to face civil or criminal insider trading charges, settled with the S.E.C., agreeing to be banned from the securities industry and to pay $200,000.

title: Obama Has Made America Look Weak
description: Should Russias invasion and looming annexation of Crimea be blamed on President Barack Obama? Of course not, just as it should not be blamed on NATO expansion, the Iraq war or Western interventions to stop mass atrocities in the Balkans and Libya. The blame lies squarely with Vladimir V. Putin, an unreconstructed Russian imperialist and K.G.B. apparatchik.

title: The Blame Game in Venezuela
description: In the month since mass demonstrations began in Venezuela, at least 25 people have died in the protests. No end to the crisis is in sight, and each day the grievances grow, the arrests multiply, positions harden and moderates retreat.

title: Chinese Debt Worries
description: Atif Mian and Amir Sufi, our leading experts on the macroeconomic effects of private debt, have a new blog  and it has instantly become must reading. Their latest post is about China, which is looking a whole lot like an overleveraged economy at great risk of a Minsky moment. The key figure is this one:

title: De Blasio Pushes a 9-Year Contract for Teachers
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios administration, seeking to be generous to its allies in labor without jeopardizing New Yorks finances, is pushing for what would be the longest-ever contract with the teachers union: a nine-year deal that would let the city stretch out potentially huge retroactive pay increases.

title: Senate Investigates C.I.A.
description: But has the C.I.A. also been investigating the Senate?

title: Several Feared Trapped in Mumbai Building Collapse
description: Updated, 6:15 p.m. | MUMBAI, India  A decrepit seven-story building collapsed in a western suburb of Mumbai on Friday, killing at least six people and injuring five more, with rescue officials searching for others trapped under the rubble.

title: Former G.M. Chief Returns to Carlyle
description: Daniel F. Akerson, the former chief executive of General Motors, has returned to the Carlyle Group, the private equity giant where he worked before running the automaker.

title: In the Snow With Two Canes
description: Dear Diary:

title: Satellite Firm Says Its Data Could Offer Location of Missing Flight
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  As the hunt for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet expanded into the vastness of the Indian Ocean, a satellite communications company confirmed on Friday that it had recorded electronic keep alive ping signals from the plane after it disappeared, and said those signals could be analyzed to help estimate its location.

title: Governor of Jakarta Receives His Partys Nod for President
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Joko Widodo, the wildly popular governor of Indonesias capital, Jakarta, on Friday received what his supporters had been hoping to see: his partys blessing to run for president in July.

title: Lifting of Ban Should Return BP to Competition, Analysts Say
description: LONDON  The agreement to allow BP to bid on new oil leases in the Gulf of Mexico and elsewhere in the United States is an important milestone in the companys efforts to return to normal after the Deepwater Horizon rig explosion nearly four years ago, analysts said Friday.

title: Away She Goes
description: Caroline Polachek of the band Chairlift spent a year on the road recording songs for her debut solo album. Here, she looks back on the places that colored her electronic, soulful sound.

title: Your Questions, My Answers (I)
description: Earlier this week I invited reader questions, and Id like to thank everyone who submitted one. Below are my responses to a selection, which have been edited slightly for length (the full versions are available from the link on each questioners name). Since my answers are predictably on the long side, Im breaking this up into two posts of five questions each; the second will run on Monday. (I might do a third set, but other forms of punditry may end up taking precedence.)

title: Private Employment Slowly Reclaims Pre-Downturn Peak
description: TWO presidential elections have taken place since employment by United States businesses hit a peak of almost 116 million workers. This seems likely to be the month when a new high is finally reached, ending a period that featured the largest drop in employment and the slowest recovery of any period since the Great Depression.

title: UBS Discloses It Is Reviewing Its Precious Metals Business
description: LONDON  The Swiss bank UBS said on Friday that it was conducting an internal review of its precious metals business amid expanding regulatory investigations into potential manipulation of interest rates and the price of commodities and currencies.

title: A Film to Change the World
description: The Chilean filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky explains his ambitions for Dune.

title: Pakistani Court Issues Arrest Warrant Without Bail for Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A special court on Friday issued a warrant for the arrest of Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler of Pakistan, after he failed to appear in court for the proceedings in a treason case against him, lawyers said.

title: Art World Places Its Bet
description: LONDON  Before a standing-room crowd at Christies here last month, the bidding opened on an abstract painting filled with black scratching, Burrito scrawled across the top in bright yellow. The auctioneer announced that there were already 17 telephone and absentee buyers vying for the canvas, made three years ago by Oscar Murillo, who just turned 28.

title: Citigroups Proxy Details Link of Pay to Performance
description: The public is at something of a loss when it comes to judging whether big banks are following new rules that are meant to make them less risky.

title: People Think Were in a Recession. Dont Blame Them.
description: The United States economy emerged from recession in June 2009 and has been growing for nearly five years. Yet this week, an NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll of American adults found that 57 percent still think the economy is in recession.

title: Vivendi Agrees to Exclusive Talks With Altice for Mobile Phone Unit
description: The French media conglomerate Vivendi said Friday that it would enter into exclusive negotiations with Altice for three weeks over the possible sale of SFR, Vivendis mobile phone unit.

title: More Hope Than Headway So Far in U.S.-Europe Trade Talks
description: BRUSSELS  European and American officials had hoped they could highlight progress on negotiations for a wide-ranging trade agreement when President Obama visits Brussels on March 26. But in talks here this week, they made little headway.

title: Japan Stands by Apology to Its Wartime Sex Slaves
description: TOKYO  Moving to defuse a heated diplomatic dispute over World War II-era history, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Friday that his government would not revise a landmark 1993 apology to women forced to work in Japanese military brothels.

title: Basic Training With the New York City Ballet
description: Dancers in the New York City Ballet spend their days rehearsing in a large theater that, as legend goes, was designed to be blocked off from natural light for a reason: because it suited the wishes of George Balanchine, one of the companys founders, who died in 1983. Apparently Mr. Balanchine wanted it that way so he would have this whole group of girls locked away, out of sunlight, only seen when the curtain rises, Devin Alberda, one of the dancers, says. Alberda, who joined the corps de ballet in 2006, has been providing a rare glimpse inside this cloistered world, posting pictures of his fellow dancers to Instagram all winter. This is the most punishing time of year, when they work 12-hour days for 14 weeks without a break. Alberda says they struggle with the long stretches of rehearsal indoors, under artificial light. We really dont see the sun, he says. But theres also something really spectacular about it. Julie Bosman

title: Even Aliens Love California
description: Disappearing hares; nachos by any other name.

title: Who Made That Corkscrew?
description: For as long as wine was stored in jugs and stoppered with oil cloth and bits of wood, there was no need for a specialized opener. But in the 17th century, as bottles sealed with cork became more common, corkscrews did too. Collectors say that very early versions of the tool were derived from military kits: Soldiers used screw-shaped gun worms to pull misfired musket balls from the barrels of their guns. They would drill into the lead and drag the ammunition up and out. The first corkscrews were small and portable, often nothing more than the worm (the screw itself) and a small ring for pulling with your finger. But in the 18th century, people came to understand the benefits of aging wine, and bottles were standardized in a long-necked cylindrical shape suitable for long-term storage. The new emphasis on shelf life necessitated a better cork  and thus a better corkscrew.

title: The Secret Life of Our Trash Can
description: Recently there was a snowstorm. When you tried to step outside, it was as if youd just opened the winning door in The Price Is Right and were being barraged by confetti and blowing horns. There were snow plows everywhere, and one ran into our plastic garbage can, cracking it right down its side. When I tried to put a big garbage bag in it, the bag fell out. The garbage can was 15 years old. It was time for it to become garbage itself.

title: The Death of the Bargain Bin
description: Most adolescents reach a point when they realize that they owe their parents something. Many of these young people, including me, will realize that what they owe is essentially boundless and that theyll spend the rest of their lives trying to pay off this debt. And most start in a way that makes sense financially and lines up nicely with major holidays  because gift-giving is a good way to start chipping away at that whole they-gave-you-life deficit.

title: The Psychomagical Realism of Alejandro Jodorowsky
description: In September, on the day of the Paris premiere of The Dance of Reality, his first movie in 23 years, Alejandro Jodorowsky, the Chilean-born filmmaker, learned that he was now an asteroid  261690 Jodorowsky  as the International Astronomical Union had named a three-mile-wide chunk of rock orbiting between Mars and Jupiter. For a man whose life has been defined by cosmic ambitions, the honor seemed almost expected.

title: Clip: 'Muppets Most Wanted'
description: A scene featuring the character Constantine, the evil Kermit look-a-like.

title: One of These Frogs Is Extremely Dangerous
description: When Disney revitalized the Muppets movie franchise in 2011, it added  a new member to the family, a somewhat clueless puppet named Walter. Now Muppets Most Wanted, scheduled for release on March 21, also introduces a fresh character.

title: NYT Now: Erlanger on Crimea Vote
description: Steven Erlanger, the London chief bureau for The New York Times,  discusses the prospects for Sunday's vote in Crimea.

title: Families of Indians on Missing Flight Plead for Information
description: NEW DELHI  The families of the Indian passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner on Friday expressed frustration that the news about the search for the plane, like the Indian Navys expanded efforts in the Andaman Sea, was coming from the media, not the government or the airline.

title: The Voiceless
description: The French writer Daniel Anselme (1927-89) started out as a poet and journalist. He fought with the Communist underground during World War II, and when the Algerian conflict started in the mid-1950s, he turned from journalism to what he called a mode of action, by which he meant, of all things, the novel. This was in Paris in the decade of Waiting for Godot, when being a man of action could mean writing a novel that contains almost no action at all.

title: Today in Small Business: Was a Viral Video a Fraud?
description: Editors Note: Gene Marks will be on vacation next week. His posts will resume on March 24.

title: Quiet Desperation
description: Whats most improbable about The Wherewithal, Philip Schultzs novel-shaped poem, is that its at once a weak instance of each of its genres and a stunning instance of both. Little develops, little resolves. You know less in the end than after the first chapter. Its characters are stock types or caricatures, and its descriptions, sketchy for prose, are almost mock-poetry (the pitiless turbine / of his thoughts). There is little rhythm, less meter, less closure that makes sense. There is no catharsis.

title: Hello, My Lovely
description: About two-thirds of the way through The Black-Eyed Blonde, Philip Marlowe  that name might ring a bell  tells us he lit up another cancer stick. For a novel set in the early 1950s, this sounded anachronistic, so I went online to investigate. While a connection between tobacco and cancer was suggested in the 1930s in Germany, the Oxford Dictionary of Modern Slang places the earliest use of cancer stick at 1959  which is not to say that it wasnt used before then.

title: Control Group
description: Parents: You know that dad at the park, the nice guy who sidles up to talk at the swings? Hes laid back, not one of those intense helicopter parents, and soon youre shooting the breeze, talking idly about when your kid started to walk, or how many words he has. Cool Dad is nodding, and then suddenly hes telling you about this weird thing he and his partner did that involved green tea and cloth diapers, and now their little guy is getting his postdoc at M.I.T., but hey, thats awesome that your little Lysander can roll over already!

title: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Sheri Fink Win Book Awards
description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Sheri Fink were among the winners of the National Book Critics Circle Awards, named Thursday night in New York City. The awards, given annually to books published in the United States in English, are chosen by a group of nearly 600 critics and editors from major publications that cover books.

title: SXSW Q. and A. | British Starlet Imogen Poots on Acting Opposite (and Dressing Like) Andr 3000
description: There are two principal thrills in the first act of Jimi: All Is by My Side, the Jimi Hendrix biopic written and directed by John Ridley, who just won an Oscar for his 12 Years a Slave screenplay. The first is the way Andr 3000 portrays Hendrix, with a mix of looseness and intensity. The second is the 24-year-old British actress Imogen Poots, who plays Linda Keith, the London scenester, Vogue model and daughter of posh parents who disdained both music and the fashion world. Im not sure what a good English girl is supposed to do, Poots says in the film, but apparently shacking up with the Rolling Stones isnt it.

title: Life Intervened
description: Any novelist whos ever stood in a bookstore, watching as someone picks up a copy of her book and pauses before returning it to the shelf, knows theres no logical explanation for why particular books appeal to particular people. Over time, though, readers do tend to make intuitive decisions. Someone who wants a fast-moving story may seek out what she imagines is a plot-driven novel. Someone who wants to spend time in close quarters, getting to know a person like herself, or perhaps like no one shes ever met, may choose what appears to be a character-driven novel. And someone who tends to pepper margins with exclamation points, who calls a friend to shout, Listen to this line!, may gravitate toward a book preoccupied with language.

title: In Our Pages: March 15
description: 1889: Pope Condemns Annexation

title: Techs Favorite Cartoonist Enters Mainstream Publishing
description: At 29, Randall Munroe still revels in a recent honor that can resemble a lifetime achievement award  an asteroid in orbit between Jupiter and Mars and once known simply as 4942 was renamed last year by the International Astronomical Union as 4942 Munroe.

title: New York State of Mind
description: Wow . . . New York! Just like I pictured it. Skyscrapers and everything. So murmurs a presumably wide-eyed newcomer during a spoken-word break in Stevie Wonders Living for the City, and who among us outlanders and former rubes did not feel that same sense of mingled recognition and awe when we first set foot here? Thanks to movies and TV, magazines, the news, books  iconography in general  all of us, even natives, carry a mental suitcase stuffed with received images of the Big Apple. Thats true of children, too, for whom the citys superlatives (biggest, loudest, tallest) hold a special fascination. You might even say that New York is to other American cities what dinosaurs are to other animals  minus, one hopes, the extinction event. And if we are  or were  lucky children, picture books play a huge role in how we picture the city, from Eloise and The Snowy Day to Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile, In the Night Kitchen, You Cant Take a Balloon Into the Metropolitan Museum and The Man Who Walked Between the Towers.

title: Keys to the Kingdom
description: Emily Vole, the heroine of Operation Bunny, the first book in Sally Gardners Wings & Co. series, has had, by the age of 9, the kind of transformative experiences that are possible only in fairy tales. Found in a hatbox in Stansted Airport (the modern-day equivalent of being lifted from bulrushes), Emily is adopted by Daisy and Ronald Dashwood. Dark-eyed and solemn while the Dashwoods are blond and shrill, she is found wanting. There was no getting away from it. The child just didnt fit in with the Dashwoods ancestral color scheme.

title: Come Together
description: What must anyone born this century make of the Beatles? They didnt command attention by swinging naked on demolition balls. They wrote songs called I Want to Hold Your Hand and All You Need Is Love, sentiments so quaint theyd trigger thousands of snarky tweets if the tunes were released today. They wore matching suits. Without an accompanying CD, download or hyperlink, how can a book convey the revolutionary impact of their music? How can you present the case, as the husband-and-wife team Mick Manning and Brita Granstrom do in The Beatles, that from boy bands to punk rockers and rap singers, you could say it all began with those fresh-faced, cheeky lads from Liverpool?

title: Boy Meets Girl
description: For most of us, high school posed logistical challenges. How, for example, should we behave in order to be perceived as cool by kids who are successfully masquerading as cool? And could anyone cool somehow be hoodwinked into hanging out with us? But it seems we had it easy.

title: Inside the List
description: Top Cat: The great independent publisher New Directions has been around since 1936, offering a home to authors including William Carlos Williams, Muriel Spark and Roberto Bolao. But it didnt land its first New York Times best seller until last month, when Takashi Hiraides novel The Guest Cat  a sweet philosophical story (translated from Japanese) about a jaded couple who embrace life again after a neighbors cat adopts them  briefly surfaced on the trade paperback list. It took everyone fantastically by surprise here, Michael Barron, the publicity director for New Directions, said via email. We didnt think it would do this well. . . . Only a few people seemed interested in reviewing it, but one of those was Juan Vidal, a reviewer for NPR Books. His rave review is a testament to the power of social media  it was posted by NPR Books, and then reposted by the main NPR site, which has over a million followers. It got thousands of likes on Facebook, and was heavily retweeted. That same day it was picked up by NPR, we watched as The Guest Cat climbed up and up the Amazon sales list to the top 20 sellers. But the big news was when it hit the New York Times best-seller list, our first book ever to do so, and all because of a single review.

title: N.Y.C. History
description: MACHINE MADE  Tammany Hall and the Creation of Modern American Politics  By Terry Golway  Liveright, $27.95.

title: Jamaican Dancehall Star Is Convicted of Murder
description: The Jamaican dancehall reggae star Vybz Kartel and three of his associates were found guilty of murder on Thursday evening, the Jamaica Observer reported. He is to be sentenced on March 27.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE STILL POINT OF THE TURNING WORLD,  by Emily Rapp. (Penguin, $16.) When Rapps son Ronan was 9 months old, it was discovered that he had Tay-Sachs disease, an untreatable genetic condition. This grief-filled memoir recounts the months that followed, as Rapp tries to make sense of it all and comes to the gradual realization that writing would not save Ronan. But, I thought, it might save me.

title: Editors Choice
description: REDEPLOYMENT,  by Phil Klay. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) Twelve stories by a former Marine who served in Iraq capture on an intimate scale the ways in which the war there evoked a unique array of emotion, predicament and heartbreak.

title: 220 Are Detained in Raid on a Thai Jungle Camp
description: BEIJING  Thai police officers raiding a jungle camp in the hills of southern Thailand have detained about 220 people suspected of being ethnic Uighurs fleeing China, two-thirds of them women and children, according to a Thai police officer and reports in the Thai news media on Friday.

title: A Family Bond From Court to Pulpit
description: When Jim Crews coached at the University of Evansville  where he spent 17 years  in the early 1990s, he often picked up his son, Todd, at the nearby Holy Rosary Catholic School.

title: Venture Aboard the Steampunk Cruise
description: Join Victorian gentlemen, mad scientists and others on a journey to the Bahamas.

title: Video Notebook: Jim and Todd Crews
description: The St. Louis coach Jim Crews and his son Todd Crews, an associate pastor at the Brooklyn Tabernacle, speak about their relationship and how it ties to their chosen professions.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Parentology
description: This week, Rebecca Traister talks about Dalton Conleys Parentology; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Amy Finnerty discusses four new books about New York City history; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Federal Railroad Administration Review of the Metro-North Railroad
description: An inquiry into Metro-North, known as Operation Deep Dive, was prompted by the fatal derailment on Dec. 1 of a Hudson line train in the Bronx that killed four passengers and injured more than 70 others.

title: Steampunks at Sea
description: On the first full evening of last months second annual Steampunk cruise to the Bahamas, I found myself  in tuxedo and a World War I-era aviators cap  marching in a strange parade past the Deck 5 duty-free shops on the Royal Caribbean cruise ship  Explorer of the Seas. Strolling with me were 62 elaborately costumed Victorian re-enactors, including but not restricted to: a Gypsy minstrel playing the accordion, a princess in authentic Turkoman beads, a Russian submarine commander, an African explorer in safari gear, some mustached gentlemen in John Bull top hats and, in her tiara, a 60-year-old woman dressed up as Her Majesty the Queen.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Parentology
description: This week, Rebecca Traister and Amy Finnerty.

title: Video Reviews of Need for Speed, Veronica Mars and Le Week-End
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Need for Speed, Veronica Mars and Le Week-End. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Who Owns Your Taste in Music?
description: Ben Ratliff and Ben Sisario discuss the increasing sophistication of internet data-mining in the music business.

title: Castlight Health Soars in Stock Market Debut
description: Updated, 2:21 p.m. | Stock market investors are lining up for a piece of Castlight Health, a young company that provides software to track health care costs.

title: When Bedbugs Bite
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: A Presidents Struggles in Clinton-Era Memos
description: WASHINGTON  In the darkest days of Bill Clintons presidency, just after voters repudiated him by handing control of Congress to Republicans in the 1994 midterm elections, the politically wounded chief executive and his team prepared a speech in hopes of getting back on his feet and salvaging his administration. His aides were not impressed with what they came up with.

title: Popcast: Who Owns Your Taste in Music?
description: Next time you listen to something on Spotify or Beats or Pandora or Rdio, ask yourself: whos streaming whom?

title: For Myanmar Muslim Minority, No Escape From Brutality
description: HAT YAI, Thailand  He had already endured a treacherous journey down the Bay of Bengal, squeezed in the belly of a fishing trawler, then squashed in a pickup truck as it hurtled down Thailands southern coast. Malaysia, his final destination, was tantalizingly close.

title: Times Minute | High Tension in Crimea
description: Crimea prepares for Sundays referendum. The mood on the ground, last-minute diplomacy, and the question of Putins next move.

title: Times Minute | High Tension in Crimea
description: In the Video

title: Toxic Toking
description: An unexpected side effect of trying to give up drugs.

title: Roasted Rabbit
description: Rabbit is no harder to cook at home than chicken. Melissa Clark shows how to enhance this lean meat with olives, lemon and feta cheese.

title: Hop, Skip and a Jump: Rabbit the Easy Way
description: Of all the things that supposedly taste like chicken, rabbit is the most convincing.

title: Reply All: The 3.2.14 Issue
description: THE MAMMOTH COMETH

title: On Boycotting Woody Allens Films
description: I was discussing with a friend whether it is permissible to boycott Woody Allens films in the wake of the sexual-abuse allegations. We both thought it would be wrong to further empower someone who may have sexually abused a child. But our legal system is built on the principle that the accused are innocent until proved guilty, and preserving that value is important whether or not you believe the allegations. Is it permissible in this case to boycott, or should we presume innocence? J.K., NEW YORK

title: Settlement Reached in Cy Twombly Foundation Lawsuit
description: The foundation of the artist Cy Twombly, who died in 2011, has reached a settlement in a bitter legal battle against two of its directors, who were accused in civil court of taking unauthorized fees and of engineering inflated appraisals for artwork to pad their commissions.

title: High Levels of Pollution Spur Paris to Action
description: PARIS  Parisians taking public transportation to work on Friday were surprised and delighted to find free subways and buses for the next three days, but the reason was a bit less cheerful: Air pollution had reached an unusually high level and was expected to continue unabated through the weekend.

title: Reminder to Politicians: That Microphone May Still Be Live
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Lindsey Graham has witnessed enough congressional hearings to know: If you want to have a side conversation, cover that microphone.

title: A New Brand for Red Roof
description: Marriott has the Ritz-Carlton. Hilton has the Waldorf Astoria. And now Red Roof Inn has Red Roof Plus+.

title: The Rock Boat: Booze, Battles and 32 Bands
description: On a music cruise, could there be anything better than discovering a great band you hadnt heard before? Yes, helping that band annihilate a rival rock group in a shipboard soccer game in front of a cheering crowd.

title: Crocodiles and Culture on a Cruise in West Africa
description: The radiant sun was starting its late-afternoon descent, leaving behind pleasantly warm air, and I was gliding on glassy water through a Gambian archipelago of tropical rain-forest islands in a brightly painted boat, a converted ferry with an upper deck and even a soft-drink bar. Propped against pillows with my feet up, I was as comfortable as Cleopatra on her royal barge. Suddenly, Assan, our guide, spotted our goal: a big, black chimpanzee sitting on the wet, brown shoreline, eating fruit. And then there was another one, with a baby chimp swinging from its belly, high up in the trees.

title: Choose Your Own Cruise
description: Follow our flow chart to see which type of cruise might suit your tastes and needs.

title: Skills Practice | Socratic Seminars Using Informational Text
description: Look at the front page of any days New York Times  and youll find plenty for teenagers to discuss, whether meaty matters of global geopolitics, or lifestyle topics that hit closer to home.

title: Image of the Day: March 14
A City of Madness, Bypassed by the N.C.A.A.
description: LAS VEGAS  In three arenas strung along a three-mile stretch of Tropicana Avenue, 19 postseason mens college basketball games were played on Wednesday and Thursday. The games attracted tens of thousands of fans, with many more watching on television. They were played under rules set by the N.C.A.A., college basketballs governing body.

title: Movie Review: 'Veronica Mars'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Veronica Mars."

title: Why Kids Love a (Minor) Crisis
description: It snowed a little bit here in New Hampshire. A little bit, as in we stopped counting after the first foot and a half, and the children had two days off from school, and the wind blew and the snow piled up and we lost the driveway. One of my 9-year-old daughters friends was with us for the duration, but after it was all over, her familys au pair set off to pick her up on the evening of the second day (both of her parents are doctors with call responsibilities).

title: USEC Bankruptcy Shakes Up Creditor Line
description: There is theory and then there is actual practice. The Chapter 11 bankruptcy case of USEC, which processes uranium for power plants, provides a nice reminder.

title: Movie Review: 'Need for Speed'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Need for Speed."

title: As Living Standards Fall for Seniors, Some See Signs of Silver Revolution
description: BEFORE Boston police detained Ann A. Stewart last August, she had a clean record. But she vows not to wait long, certainly not another 89 years, to become a repeat offender.

title: Minnesota Orchestras Principal Clarinetist Extends Stay in Los Angeles
description: The Minnesota Orchestra has been working hard to rebuild after a polarizing 16-month lockout that has left it without its renowned music director, Osmo Vanska, as well as several players who have taken leaves of absence, some to try out positions with other orchestras.

title: For Starters, the Upper East Side
description: Julie Murray shares an apartment with a friend on 95th Street near First Avenue. The building is respectably maintained, its true, and the bathroom is a reasonable size. Theres an elevator, and Ms. Murray, 22, a college senior hoping to work in the fashion industry, has her own room.

title: Instant Replay in Baseball? Stranger Things Have Happened
description: Just like the serendipitous collision of peanut butter and chocolate in the Reeses Peanut Butter Cup ads of the 1980s, two of my favorite things  the magazines Who Made That? column and baseball  have met to form a more perfect union. While waiting for the baseball season to begin, I have been thoroughly enjoying Steve Rushins The 34-Ton Bat: The Story of Baseball as Told Through Bobbleheads, Cracker Jacks, Jock Straps, Eye Black and 375 Other Strange and Unforgettable Objects.

title: Graham's Hot Mic Offer to 'Help' Kerry
description: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina was caught on an open microphone offering to help Secretary of State John Kerry following his testimony at a Senate hearing on Ukraine assistance.

title: Trying to Drive Sales by Giving Away Diamond Rings
description: Josh Opperman was a 27-year-old in love, living in New York City, when he realized his pending nuptials were not going to happen. He tried selling his $10,000 engagement ring on eBay and Craigslist but the best offer he got was just 35 percent of the price he had paid.

title: Movie Review: 'Le Week-End'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Le Week-End."

title: California Sued Over Diversion of Money From National Mortgage Settlement
description: Three nonprofit groups offering homeowner counseling sued Gov. Jerry Brown of California on Friday, demanding the state replace $369 million that had been earmarked to help troubled borrowers but was used instead to pay down the states debt.

title: Book Review Podcast: Parentology
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Rebecca Traister reviews Dalton Conleys Parentology: Everything You Wanted to Know About the Science of Raising Children but Were Too Exhausted to Ask. Ms. Traister writes:

title: Chinese Activist Dies in Custody
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  A Chinese activist who fell gravely ill after being detained last fall died Friday of a lung infection, her brother said.

title: Chinas Online Goliaths Prepare Public Offerings in U.S.
description: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | The Chinese Internet industry is coming of age, as some of its biggest players prepare to start new chapters as publicly traded companies  in the United States.

title: A.C.C. Tournament Said to Be Heading to Brooklyn in 2017
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference will hold its mens basketball tournament at Barclays Center in Brooklyn in 2017 and 2018, a person with knowledge of the deal said Friday.

title: Big Ticket | Rupert Murdoch Pays $43 Million for Bachelor Pad
description: Rupert Murdoch, the newly single media tycoon, has acquired the triplex penthouse that crowns One Madison, the 60-story sliver of bronze glass designed by CetraRuddy, for $43,010,000. A 6,850-square-foot sponsor unit, it was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Together Forever, Hypothetically
description: The round-robin style of mating dance known as speed dating is the premise for Date of a Lifetime, a modest, appealing, two-actor musical that is currently being given a lively production by the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

title: For Boarding Schools, an Evolving Financial Aid Philosophy
description: ERIC LONG dreaded answering his phone this week at Tabor Academy in Marion, Mass., while across the country at the Webb Schools in Claremont, Calif., Leo Marshall let the switchboard screen his calls.

title: In Rare Case, Woman With H.I.V. Infects Female Sex Partner, C.D.C. Says
description: The first confirmed case of lesbian transmission of H.I.V. was reported on Thursday by federal health officials, who said the event was exceedingly rare but nonetheless advised lesbian couples in which one partner is infected to take precautions.

title: Restoration Rings From the Rafters of the Hudson Opera House
description: Gary Schiro, the executive director of the Hudson Opera House, is a confirmed workaholic, often loath to delegate even loathsome tasks. So until the holes in the roof of that Hudson landmark were repaired six years ago, he regularly found himself, net in hand, chasing down pigeons that had made their way into the disused auditorium on the second floor.

title: Remembering Always to Say What Matters Most
description: In the early days of their relationship, in Washington, a place where no three words seem ever to be spoken without having been carefully considered beforehand, Lauren Jiloty and Steve Slupski found how easy it can be to fail to communicate simply by neglecting to say what matters most.

title: A Dragnet at Dewey & LeBoeuf Snares a Minnow
description: Youve been indicted, an assistant Manhattan district attorney, Peirce Moser, told Zachary Warren, a 29-year-old magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown Law School with a prestigious clerkship on the Federal Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Memphis.

title: Witness Accounts and Video of a Deadly Attack by Russian Separatists in Ukraine Undercut Kremlin Claims
description: Updated, 2:49 p.m. | The morning after journalists, including my colleague Andrew Roth, watched a pro-Russia mob attack peaceful protesters in the eastern Ukrainian city of Donetsk, leaving at least one young demonstrator dead, Russias foreign ministry released a statement on Friday claiming that the exact opposite had occurred, and warning ominously that Russia reserves the right to protect ethnic Russians in Ukraine.

title: Actors Who Know Cute Is Not Enough
description: With all of the fine grown-up acting on television these days, its easy to overlook the excellent work being done by the younger set and, in some cases, the considerably younger set.

title: Despite a Senate Deal, the Jobless Still Wait for Aid
description: For three months, more than 2 million jobless people who lost their unemployment benefits have been watching their wallets shrink as they wait for Republicans to decide whether they are worthy of getting the benefits back. It used to be that extensions of this aid were routinely approved by both parties when unemployment is high, but todays Republicans have to demonstrate the necessary callousness to the party base before a few eventually do the right thing.

title: Prewar Apartments from Scratch
description: Developers have long profited from renovating out-of-date prewar apartment buildings to create interiors pleasing to todays buyers. But many are now building entirely from the ground up, in a style harking back to the era before World War II; the trend is particularly evident on the limestone-clad Upper East Side.

title: How to Get to Spontaneity? Practice
description: To borrow a term from the Olympics, the technical element of playing classical music demands formidable skills and continual work. The ultimate goal is for an artist to be so assured that a performance exudes spontaneity.

title: Saved by Martha Graham
description: No offense to one of the mothers of modern dance, but most aspiring dancers dont dream of joining the Martha Graham Dance Company. For one, she died in 1991; much of the repertory  some of it timeless, some of it outmoded  dates to the last century. But Lloyd Mayor, born in Geneva to a British mother and Swiss father, is not your typical 20-year-old. It had to do with the mind, he said. The work was really talking about shame and empathy and vulnerability, and they are not to be romanticized.

title: Ancient Grains for Breakfast
description: I had already decided that this week I would play around with breakfast grains when I noticed that food manufacturers are also coming up with new ideas. I rarely look at the breakfast cereals on the shelves in the supermarket or at Trader Joes, as its easier and cheaper for me to put together my own combos. But this week, as I reached for a container of steel-cut oats, I noticed several prepared mixes of grains and seeds like oats, quinoa and flax, mostly for hot cereal, that I hadnt seen before.

title: Two Exhibitions, From Cover to Cover
description: Perusing her copy of The Complete Book of Covers From The New Yorker 1925-1989, Eve Potts of the Westport Historical Society recognized scene after familiar scene.

title: Kerry Speaks After Talks With Lavrov
description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference after his meeting with the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, about the Ukrainian crisis ahead of a referendum on Crimea.

title: NYT Now: Kerry Reviews Talks With Lavrov
description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference after his meeting with the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, about the Ukrainian crisis before a referendum on Crimea.

title: Wheelies: The Ford Legacy Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Russia Moves Swiftly to Stifle Dissent Ahead of Secession Vote
description: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine  Early this month, Russian soldiers took up positions at the television transmission center here in the capital of the Ukrainian region of Crimea. Their arrival was part of a broad effort to muffle dissent over the Kremlin-backed project to guide Crimea through a swift secession from Ukraine.

title: Review: 2014 Ford Flex
description: Unapologetically original, the Ford Flex is for families that want a vacation from ordinary vans and crossovers.

title: Mammographys Limits, Seldom Understood
description: A sad fact: None of the eight major clinical trials looking at whether regular mammograms reduce a womans risk of dying from breast cancer has included women over age 75.

title: 2 Choices in Crimea Referendum, but Neither Is No
description: Crimea will vote on Sunday in a ballot referendum that leaders of the regional Parliament expect will ratify their decision to break away from Ukraine and become part of Russia. The referendum will offer two choices, neither one of them no:

title: The Struggles Cant Dim the Sparks
description: Mike Riezenman had been making frequent stays in hospitals and nursing homes, sometimes for months at a time, for the last four and a half years. But that did not make his death in January at age 73 any easier to bear for his wife, Paula Riezenman.

title: A Timeless California Enclave Fears a Citys Sway
description: MODESTO, Calif.  Farmers and other residents of the rural district known as Wood Colony refer to the 110-year-old arboreal landmark in their midst  a gigantic walnut tree of Grimms fairy-tale proportions  as, simply, the Tree. To many people in this unincorporated community, settled more than a century ago by a religious group called the Old German Baptist Brethren, the mighty tree is a kind of tabernacle, a living testament to the districts deep roots, fertile soil and unshakable resolve.

title: The Journalist and the Public Editor: On Joe McGinniss in the Mix
description: Often admired, often criticized  but seldom ignored  the distinctive journalistic figure and author Joe McGinniss died this week at age 71.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Board Recommends Shareholders Vote Against Dividend
description: Warren E. Buffett prefers to use Berkshire Hathaways huge cash pile to buy up companies, rather than return it to shareholders.

title: Eric Decker Says What He Values Most Is Jets Respect
description: After catching 172 passes, 24 for touchdowns, from Peyton Manning in the past two seasons, receiver Eric Decker was a bit baffled that the Denver Broncos did not value his contributions enough to offer him a contract as a free agent this off-season. That is why Decker said he was so won over by the Jets pitch for his services. In offering a five-year, $36.25 million contract and penciling him in as the No. 1 receiver, the Jets made him feel valued.

title: ISS Debut Gives Less-Than-Stellar Return for Goldman and EQT
description: Lego has trumped Goldman Sachs in the $1.5 billion flotation of ISS, a cleaning and catering group based in Denmark.

title: J. K. Rowling Publishes First Part of History of the Quidditch World Cup
description: If you were unable to get enough of Harry Potter and his magical world, J. K. Rowling has added just a bit more to the legend  a footnote  on the web page Pottermore.com, which she introduced in 2011. On Friday, Mrs. Rowling posted the first part of her History of the Quidditch World Cup, an expansive description of the game that Harry and his Hogwarts colleagues play, using flying broomsticks, throughout the series.

title: Making It Last
description: Paula Riezenman offers some lessons learned about marriage from her more than 14 years with Mike Riezenman, who died in January.

title: The Gun Report: March 14, 2014
description: Shyanne Roberts stood up at a New Jersey Assembly hearing yesterday and asserted her right to bear arms. I am not a gangbanger or domestic terrorist, she told the Law and Public Safety Committee, speaking against a bill that would limit the magazine capacity of firearms to 10 rounds from the current 15-round maximum. The bill passed the committee 5 to 3.

title: The Science of Paying It Forward
description: ONE morning in December of 2012, at the drive-through window of a Tim Hortons coffee shop in Winnipeg, Manitoba, a customer paid for her order and then picked up the tab for the stranger in the car behind her in line. Then that customer paid the bill for the following customer in line  and so on, for the next 226 customers, in a three-hour sequence of spontaneous generosity.

title: Refurbishing a Museum Wing and Its Trophies
description: To hear George Dante describe them, you would think the animals whose stuffed heads he carted away in October from the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum had been in a rowdy bar fight. The mule deer, he said, had a bashed-in skull and an antler hanging by a thread. The black bears teeth were broken. And lets not even talk about the poor moose with their mangled ears and split lips.

title: Video: What Is a Ford Flex, Anyway?
description: Escape, Fusion, Focus, F-150 and Explorer are Ford vehicles with instant name recognition. Flex? No, Im not asking you to a yoga class. Flex is a family crossover that needs a new agent.

title: Please Dont Call Me Mom
description: Not to be disrespectful (although Ive started explaining to my children that a statement beginning this way usually is), but it drives me crazy when someone other than my kids addresses me as Mom.

title: Apartment Hunting With a Mobile App
description: Movement, an app introduced in May, is the best platform Ive found for apartment searching on a mobile phone, something that might eventually help to curb the misery of the apartment search experience. I say eventually because even as the app has experienced impressive growth since its most recent update, it lacks the kind of comprehensive listings that would make it truly invaluable.

title: BRIC Arts Center Starts a Cable Channel Focused on Brooklyn
description: Forget about those hours of badly lit, single-camera chat shows set in drab studios, to say nothing of Wayne and Garth partying on in the basement: BRIC, the contemporary arts center in Brooklyn, is introducing Brooklyn Independent Media, a round-the-clock cable channel, on Monday, and its directors promise that it wont be your grandfathers public-access station.

title: Shock as Militants Attack Nigerian Military Prison
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Militants suspected of being members of the group Boko Haram carried out a daring daylight raid early Friday on a heavily guarded military prison in northern Nigeria, freeing some of their comrades but also suffering heavy losses, witnesses and officials said.

title: Hunting Honey, and Trying to Hide
description: An ancient tradition of hunting honey on Nepalese cliffsides is in danger of vanishing from excessive tourism  and even photographers.

title: Austria Holds Ukrainian Pending Extradition Decision
description: BERLIN  An Austrian court ruled on Friday that it would continue to hold a Ukrainian businessman, identified as Dmitry V. Firtash, a billionaire with close ties to his countrys ousted president, and set bail at 125 million euros, or $174 million, after his arrest this week on an American warrant.

title: Whats Real Gets More Creative
description: The very first movies were, in their way, documentaries: snippets that showed the trot of a horse, a smoke-belching train pulling into a station or Queen Victorias Diamond Jubilee procession. But the paths of fiction and nonfiction film soon diverged, and they remain distinct today, each with separate standards and expectations and consigned to separate categories at festivals and the Oscars.

title: A Bandleader and His Repertoire of Songs
description: Minutes into his first set on Monday night, Tommy Mulvihill looked down the long bar and announced, You can ask us to play anything you want.

title: Its Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes first open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Greenwich Village: No Dowel Left Unturned
description: A fancifully renovated Greek Revival-style Greenwich Village townhouse, part of a historic enclave of eight brick homes built on a serene stretch of Waverly Place in 1839 by Lambert Suydam, a former president of the Manhattan Gas Light Company and later the New York Fire Insurance Company, is about to enter the market at $14.95 million.

title: By Any Name, a Doughnut Destination
description: There are three types of customers at Shaikhs Place, a 24-hour coffee shop on Avenue U near the southern end of Brooklyn: those who come for the company, those who come for the tacos and those who come for the doughnuts.

title: Face to Face With Blog Contributors: Can Familiarity Breed Conviviality?
description: [Production note |Im taking eight Pace University students to Brazil for 10 days starting tonight (to make a film on tourism and the environment) so comment moderation and posting may be sporadic.]

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Start-Up Seeks to Capitalize on Security Concerns for Bitcoins
description: After living with hyperinflation, currency fluctuations and minimal access to credit in his country, Wences Casares, an Argentine raised on a sheep farm, says he has the vision and team to make Bitcoin more widespread and accepted worldwide.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, London, France and New York.

title: SXSW 2014: The Music Plays On After a Somber Scene
description: Theres not much a music critic can say about the car crash that killed two people at SXSW and injured at least 23. A few blocks of Red River Street, where the Mohawk is, hold a long strip of clubs. At 12:30 p.m. on Wednesday night, many of them were busy if not spilling out onto the street, which was as usual blocked off for pedestrians who expected nothing more hazardous than an encounter with a clumsy drunk on foot, when the car crashed through. It could have been any crowded city street with a car out of control, but it was SXSW.

title: Pharrells Phragrance, Karls Custom Emojis and Obamas Shopping Trip
description: Scent of a multihyphenateComme des Garons announced Wednesday that this fall they will release a unisex scent called Girl in collaboration with the ubiquitous, giant-hat-wearing, perfect-skin-having superstar Pharrell Williams. What will it smell like? Billionaires? Boys? Clubs?

title: The Celebrity in the Apron at Gato
description: With vaulted brick ceilings and big bold lighting fixtures, Gato reveals two notable reincarnations. Bobby Flay, the celebrity chef and brand, has opened a new restaurant in New York for the first time in nine years, and it is in a 100-year-old NoHo space at 324 Lafayette Street that previously housed a Bowery Residents Committee treatment center. Now the well-heeled, the early adopters, the neighborhood families and the restaurant industry types mingle at the center bar and on leather banquettes. Mr. Flay, apron-clad, is visible to diners through the kitchens glass window. His business partner, Laurence Kretchmer, roamed the brightly tiled floor on Tuesday after a weeks soft opening. The room was humming, at a manageable level. Mr. Kretchmer said they had kept some tables empty so the restaurant could have time to settle. Zesty Mediterranean dishes arrived on plates of various shapes, as the solicitous staff watched Flay fans and old friends digest the novelty.

title: Search for Bodies Yields to Hunt for a Cause of East Harlem Explosion
description: After an eighth body was extricated from the rubble of two buildings in East Harlem that were leveled by an explosion, fire and safety officials began on Friday narrowing in on what caused the blast.

title: A Fistful of Movie Scores
description: Much has been made of the prodigious musical output of Ennio Morricone, the Italian film composer whose scores have accompanied six decades worth of films, from spaghetti westerns like A Fistful of Dollars and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly to several pictures starring Robert De Niro, like The Untouchables and The Mission. When asked to pick a favorite among the bunch, he refused, falling back on that old chestnut about them all being his children, so how could he pick just one?

title: Links to the Past
description: The Amelia Island Concours dlgance featured antique and collectible vehicles and high-powered racing machines feted over three idyllic days in the Florida sunshine.

title: A Beating Heart, a Social Conscience and a Deluge of Ideas
description: Ana Tijoux

title: Mikaela Shiffrin Begins to Look Beyond the Slalom
description: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland  In the weeks after the Olympic slalom champion Mikaela Shiffrin caps the best season of her young career Sunday, she plans to have her wisdom teeth removed and to visit her grandmother  regular teenager stuff.

title: Mark Zuckerbergs Call to Obama Was Not About Privacy
description: Mark Zuckerberg is not happy with the way the American government conducts surveillance on the Internet, so much so that he called President Obama to complain about it and then wrote a post Thursday on Facebook to vent his frustration. The U.S. government should be the champion for the internet, not a threat, he said.

title: An Athlete With a Nervous Condition
description: AMG, the in-house tuner shop for Mercedes-Benz, has consistently found ways to push the performance abilities of production vehicles without betraying their luxurious nature. The AMG machines can be ridiculously powerful, but theyve also been as fully useful and indomitable as any other Mercedes.

title: Music-and-Wine Formula, Multiplied
description: As the crowd settled in for a Steve Earle concert at City Winery one night last month, Michael Dorf, the clubs founder, was busy hunting for candles.

title: Questionable Breeding
description: The new CLA250 compact sedan looks like a member of the Benz family, but its a mix of royal bloodlines and peasant genes.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Designers of a Williamsburg Look
description: When Ral Arvalo and Bradley Schmidt bought an apartment in north Williamsburg in 2007, they had no aspirations to become emblems of Brooklyn style. They were economic refugees from Manhattan who had discovered they could afford to buy a three-bedroom duplex with a rooftop deck that was a major step up from their previous home in Chelsea.

title: Under Cover: Illustrating Silicon Valleys Discontents
