description: This Sundays cover story about the rift between the generations in Silicon Valleys tech industry was illustrated by Tim Enthoven.I interviewed Enthoven, who is based in the Netherlands and whose previous work for the magazine includes the cover illustration for the Nov. 13, 2011, issue, about his inspiration for the face-off between the middle-aged engineer and the hipster techie.

title: Scott Brown Moves One Step Closer to a Senate Bid
description: NASHUA, N.H.  After a year of flirtations, coy poses and even a shirtless plunge into frigid waters for a charitable cause, Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, took his biggest step yet on Friday toward a campaign for the Senate from New Hampshire.

title: Sushi Restaurant Owner Reconnects With His Italian Roots
description: Alessandro Borgognone, 33, comes from a family that runs Italian restaurants, but he took a detour to found Sushi Nakazawa, named for its chef, Daisuke Nakazawa. The restaurant, which opened in August in the West Village, was awarded four stars in The New York Times.Sundays, when Sushi Nakazawa is closed, are devoted to family and the Italian-style feast, which can include roasted peppers, salumi, braciola and pasta, Mr. Borgognones favorite. He lives in the Grymes Hill section of Staten Island with his wife, Anna, 33, and their three girls: Patrizia, 8, Olivia, 6, and Stella, who was born in May.

title: Radar Suggests Jet Shifted Path More Than Once
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 experienced significant changes in altitude after it lost contact with ground control, and altered its course more than once as if still under the command of a pilot, American officials and others familiar with the investigation said Friday.

title: Orient-Express Hotels Gets a New Name
description: Orient-Express Hotels, more than decade old, and with 45 luxury hotels, as well as trains, safari camps and river cruises in its collection, got a new name this week: The London-based brand is now called Belmond.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 14
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: Sensors Could Put Cars a Step Ahead of Their Drivers
description: If a car already knows where you like your seat positioned, what radio stations you favor and how you want the air-conditioning set, would you be more likely to buy it?

title: Benz on a Budget, Angling for Youngsters
description: If Leonardo Da Vinci had painted dogs playing poker on black velvet, would it necessarily be a masterpiece? It would be a genuine Da Vinci, but not every Da Vinci is the Mona Lisa.

title: To Change Tunes, a Nod Will Be as Good as a Wink
description: Hand gestures from other drivers are a lot like trash talk at playground basketball games: provocative distractions from an otherwise engaging activity.

title: In Florida, New Stars on Block
description: AMELIA ISLAND, FLA.  The 19th annual Amelia Island Concours dlgance went off largely according to script last weekend, with antique and collectible vehicles, high-powered racing machines and famous personalities feted over three idyllic days in the Florida sunshine.

title: Vibrations, but Not Good Ones
description: Cadillacs with lights that seem to have a mind of their own and Jeep Wranglers that overheat are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Knicks Turn to Jackson to Resuscitate the Team
description: A huge rebuilding project will soon begin in Midtown Manhattan, where the Knicks have turned to Phil Jackson, a former coach with unrivaled credentials, to run the front office and restore order to the shambles at Madison Square Garden.

title: Scenes From the Streets of Venezuela
description: Venezuela is a country divided between Chavistas, supporters of President Nicols Maduro, and anti-government protesters who have taken their political differences to the streets.

title: SXSW 2014: Lady Gagas Keynote Message  Dont Sell Out
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  When Lady Gaga made her entrance on Friday for her keynote appearance at SXSW  a conversation with John Norris of Fuse News at the Hilton Grand Ballroom here  she looked at first glance like a bride in white platform heels and cascades of fabric. On second glance, the flounces were plastic: dropcloths, perhaps.

title: Finding Beauty in the Sludge
description: Despite the beckoning townhouses and the waterfront arrival of Whole Foods, the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn remains a haunting place. At any given moment, iridescent bubbles ominously float along its murky green waters, past discarded trash and scattershot debris. Gas plants, tanneries, chemical plants and other industry once lined its banks, and their remnants trouble the water like ghosts. Lurking contaminants include heavy metals, PCBs and coal tar. And for decades, untreated sewage was carried into the canal by city drains.

title: Devilishly Slashing Narrow Notions of Flamenco
description: With good reason, flamenco is most commonly thought of as an art of suffering. But there are other sides to the tradition. The form known as the bulera, for example, is fast and playful. Its name comes from the Spanish for to mock. And mockery of some kind is what courses through La Curva, a remarkable show by the experimental flamenco dancer Israel Galvn that had its American debut on Thursday at Pace Universitys Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts.

title: Fast-Forwarding Through Fashion Month
description: Ts intrepid fashion editors Kate Lanphear and Malina Joseph Gilchrist recently completed a nonstop month in the fashion trenches of New York, London, Milan and Paris, and returned to the office armed with video footage of what they saw from the front row and in the surrounding city streets. The video design team of Rosanna Webster and Charlie Sheppard compiled their material into this impressionistic montage that lets you experience the glamour, excitement and absurdity of a full month of fashion shows, all in two short minutes.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Was There a Gangster Called Oscar the Poet?
description: Q. Wasnt there an old-time gangster named Oscar the Poet? What can you tell me about him?

title: Frank Relle
description: Frank Relle

title: Sign of a New Spring in Rockettes Steps
description: If Linda Habermans new Walk the Walk were a dress, it would be a statement piece: classic, strong, powerful.

title: Phil Jackson, by the Numbers
description: The most N.B.A. championships, the highest regular-season winning percentage and more stats about Phil Jackson, who returns to where his career began, with the Knicks.

title: Anxiety Builds as New York City Parks Await a Leader
description: One by one, officials have been announced for top jobs in Mayor Bill de Blasios administration: to oversee the police, schools, housing, criminal justice, aging, environmental protection.

title: Fighting Over Wood Colony
description: The city of Modesto, Calif., plans to bring about 1,800 acres of Wood Colony, a rural district, under city jurisdiction.

title: GoDaddy Is Said to Be Exploring I.P.O.
description: GoDaddy, the online domain registrar known for its racy television commercials, is preparing to file for an initial public offering, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

title: Fed Transferred $79.6 Billion in Earnings to the Treasury Last Year
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve paid $79.6 billion to the Treasury Department in 2013 as the Feds enormous investment campaign to stimulate economic growth continued to generate windfall profits for taxpayers.

title: Recovered Enough to Play Hobbled
description: After missing the first two performances in the Metropolitan Operas revival of Bergs Wozzeck because of bronchitis, the baritone Thomas Hampson sang on Thursday night, his debut in the title role. As he had made clear in interviews and in posts on his Facebook page, Mr. Hampson is excited to be taking on this challenging genius opera, as he called it.

title: A Double Dribble: 2 Long Looks at the Hoop
description: The sports documentary is not the purest genre. For every Hoop Dreams or When We Were Kings there are dozens of films whose primary goals are commercial, promotional, jingoistic or tritely celebratory and sentimental.

title: Lines Meet Atmospheres, and a Visiting Drummer
description: At the center of Brad Lindes jazz group Underwater Ghost, which played on Wednesday night at Seeds, the storefront performance space in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is a pair of opposites. Its the sound of Mr. Lindes slowly and evenly phrased, swinging and nearly vibrato-less tenor saxophone playing; and then theres the sound of the guitarist Anthony Pirogs electric guitar, which involves careful chords and explicit, jazz-related harmonies but also and more often a freaky action-painting of effects and textures by means of a dozen or so digital pedals. While Mr. Linde focused on lines  one of the tunes he played was called Lines Mr. Pirog made atmospheres.

title: A Medicine of Oneness, Body, Soul and Stars
description: Its doubtful that the American Medical Association would choose the beings we see in the Rubin Museum of Arts remarkable new exhibition, Bodies in Balance: The Art of Tibetan Medicine, as guardians. One protectress of the healing arts in a 19th-century painting rides a nine-headed bird through the sky. She has the head of a wolf, the label explains, with three large, round eyes and matted, disheveled hair. She holds a curved knife, a hook and a freshly severed head with a lasso of intestines.

title: Leading Militant Killed in Mali, Military Officials Say
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A leading jihadist militant close to top figures in the West African affiliate of Al Qaeda has been killed in Malis desert north, two senior Malian military officials said Friday.

title: Egypt Asks U.S. to Impose Sharp Curbs on Importing of Antiquities
description: WASHINGTON  Egypts antiquities minister is asking the Obama administration to impose emergency restrictions on the importing of ancient artifacts from his country, saying that the looting and smuggling of such treasures has been catastrophic since the Arab Spring revolt of 2011.

title: Hot Baton Takes Turn at Festival
description: Lovers of great orchestral playing in New York are getting a second bite of a very big apple this weekend. After the Vienna Philharmonic opened Carnegie Halls three-week festival Vienna: City of Dreams with two concerts at Carnegie last month  and took part in concert performances of Bergs Wozzeck and Strausss Salome there with its parent company, the Vienna State Opera  the orchestra fled to sunnier climes in California.

title: These Kidnappers Hit the Mother Lode
description: Kidnappings are risky, and not just for the victims.

title: Oaklands Surprise: Grammy-Winning Caribbean Sound
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Of all the surprises when Grammys were handed out in January, perhaps the biggest came in the tropical music category for salsa, merengue and related styles. Up against stars like Marc Anthony and Carlos Vives, the winner was the virtually unknown Pacific Mambo Orchestra, based here, a continent away from the Caribbean, geographically and culturally.

title: Blondie on Blondie
description: At a festival where Blondie imitators (conscious or unconscious) are everywhere, the founders of the genuine article sit in the basement of the Four Seasons Austin, trying to avoid the spotlight. I dont have any anonymity, says Deborah Harry, who removes her massive sunglasses only when there are no civilians in the room. Im either in the hotel or Im at the gig. I cant go anywhere. Its kind of awkward. She and Chris Stein have brought their band to town for a talk and a couple of shows, part of a series of events celebrating Blondies 40th anniversary this year. Up next is a Smithsonian Channel documentary on the group, which premieres March 21. The groups 10th album, Ghosts of Download, comes out in May, packaged with a new greatest-hits release, as Blondie 4(0) Ever. The duo chatted with T about the new record, Lou Reeds memorial and what it means to be hip these days.

title: Embracing the Recital, With Arms Wide Open
description: In recent interviews the 48-year-old soprano Natalie Dessay has spoken of her desire to take a sabbatical from opera, citing her discomfort with portraying teenage heroines. Originally trained as an actress, Ms. Dessay hopes to pursue acting again as well as focus on recitals. She is currently midway through a recital tour with the pianist Philippe Cassard.

title: U.S. to Cede Its Oversight of Addresses on Internet
description: WASHINGTON  The United States will give up its role overseeing the system of Web addresses and domain names that form the basic plumbing of the Internet, turning it over in 2015 to an international group whose structure and administration will be determined over the next year, government officials said on Friday.

title: Synagogue, Rebooted
description: At a rock club on the edge of SoHo on a recent Saturday, Amichai Lau-Lavie stood in front of two musicians and a set of video screens, bringing a message about counterculture. Mr. Lau-Lavie, 44, descends from at least 37 generations of Orthodox Jewish rabbis. He is also a gay man who lives in the East Village  a fan of the Smiths and Emily Dickinson, a father of three, the creator of a drag character named Hadassah Gross. On the screens was an image of a sacrificial lamb, taken from a Dutch painting.

title: A Cranky Bonding Agent for Societys Oil and Water
description: A movie-length act of affirmation, Tyler Perrys The Single Moms Club saunters through the struggles, hopes, and reconciliations among five mothers making do. Mr. Perrys latest film touches upon some recognizable and realistic challenges with efficient compassion, but theres probably more dramatic tension in a car pool than in this films collection of predicaments.

title: If a Book Annoys You, Ridicule It in Song
description: When it comes to potential for satire, E. L. Jamess she-porn best seller 50 Shades of Grey seems as easy a target as you could shake a sex toy at. That said, 50 Shades! The Musical  The Original Parody, an exuberant takeoff now at the Elektra Theater, handily delivers the goods.

title: Map of Malaysian Air Flight 370
description: Latest details on what officials have said is known about the flight path.

title: Now, the Shut Up Your Mouse, Obama Dance Remix
description: As The Lede reported earlier this week, many Egyptians have embraced a conspiracy theory, borrowed from the American right, which holds that President Obama is a supporter of the Muslim Brotherhood and helped install and prop up the countrys first Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, at least until he was forced from power by the military last year.

title: A Method That Has Revolutionized Defense
description: What is the best improvement in bridge technique in the last 25 years?

title: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Supersymmetry
description: This is from the soundtrack for Her, also on the album. AF havent done many (any? Cant recall) straight Win-Regine duets; given how lovely and moving this one is, heres hoping they do more.

title: Music and Motion as Sliding Screens, Intuitively Calibrated
description: When Andr Gide was once asked to name Frances greatest poet, he said, Hugo  hlas. Though the line has been both misquoted and misattributed, its central point should be unmistakable: an amalgam of admiration and regret. Those mixed feelings returned to mind this week at Diamond Anniversary season performances by the Paul Taylor Dance Company at the David H. Koch Theater. Mr. Taylor is our greatest living choreographer  alas. You cant admire his excellences without observing his lapses. And this has been true for decades.

title: Video Notebook: St. Bonaventure Wins
description: St. Bonaventure Coach Mark Schmidt and the guard Jordan Gathers talk about Gathers's game-winning shot.

title: Excerpt: 'Crisis'
description: Rachael Taylor and Gillian Anderson star in "Crisis," a new hostage thriller on NBC.

title: U.S. Attitudes Toward Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Extradition Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ethics of Eating Meat
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Refuses to Alter Pandoras Payments to Songwriters
description: A federal judge on Friday left unchanged the royalty rate that the streaming service Pandora pays songwriters, a move that may fuel efforts by music groups to change the decades-old government regulation over licensing.

title: Working (or Not) at 65
description: To the Editor:

title: The Debate Over Wolf Restoration and Ecosystems
description: To the Editor:

title: Contaminated Beaches
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pros Who Help You Move to the Music
description: On a frigid Saturday morning on the Upper East Side, Evren Dogancay, 36, and about 15 other women clad in stretchy pants, sports bras and shoulder-baring loose tops like those on So You Think You Can Dance, stood under a giant disco ball at AKT In Motion, a workout studio that opened in November. Led by Anna Kaiser, the owner, a Lilliputian but muscular blonde who wore gold hoop earrings and a lime green bandanna with her athletic gear, they ground their hips and flailed their arms like Britney Spears. Youve got an audience! Ms. Kaiser shouted into her headpiece mike as Rihanna blared. Feel the music!

title: A Los Angeles Gay Landmark Buttons Up
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  The infamous San Vicente Inn here, long operated as a clothing-optional, men-only motel with a just-smoke-it drug policy, in many ways epitomizes this citys past as a live-and-let-live gay ghetto.

title: Work Like a German
description: SOME of our workplace programs, like Unemployment Insurance and Disability Insurance, parts of which date from the 1930s, desperately need updating. The original designers did not envisage such large numbers of people unemployed for long periods of time or living on disability benefits. If we could convert these programs into ladders of upward mobility, they would disproportionately benefit the disadvantaged, as well as strengthen the economy. We need to focus on enabling workers to stay in work  rather than having to compensate them after they have lost their jobs.

title: Walking the Walk to Increase Diversity
description: Bethann Hardison, the fashion industry gadfly, has adopted a slogan: Activism needs to remain active.

title: The West Wing Cast Draws Chatter
description: WASHINGTON  On March 8, President Obama urged the French president, Franois Hollande, the British prime minister, David Cameron, and the Italian premier, Matteo Renzi, to keep a united front during the crisis in Ukraine. He assured nervous leaders of the Baltic States that he had an unwavering commitment to their security.

title: Reduce Gun Penalties
description: CHICAGO  IN May of 2002, a 23-year-old man named Michael Brandon Shuler was sentenced in federal court to 15 years in prison for illegally possessing a gun  something that even the prosecutor acknowledged was a rather benign act.

title: Growing From Song to Spectacle
description: Theres no hiding a rock star. So when David Byrne, the former frontman of Talking Heads, walked into Il Cantinori in Greenwich Village recently, wearing a navy twill jumpsuit and a snow-white puffer coat (and having just arrived on bicycle), the only person who held a candle to his bold chic was Cyndi Lauper, the flame-haired singer who arrived in slim black leggings and top, her hands sprinkled with silver jewelry. They came to talk about their musical pasts in 1970s and 80s New York, and their shared theatrical presents  she as the Tony-winning composer and lyricist of the Broadway hit Kinky Boots, and he as the Obie-winning creator of the musical spectacle Here Lies Love, about the former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos, which will resume its run at the Public Theater next month. Over calamari and mushroom salad (for Mr. Byrne) and pasta and arugula salad (for Ms. Lauper), they spoke with The New York Times about artistic growth, recovering from career setbacks and how music can save your life.

title: Network? Lets Party!
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a Monday night, but Bar Marmont was packed. Women milled about in high heels and cropped fur coats (it was 50 degrees outside, this citys version of a polar vortex). Hair had been meticulously coaxed into face-flattering waves, makeup freshly applied. Im going to get a massage on my lunch break tomorrow, a woman at the bar told her friend, as she fiddled with a large gold necklace.

title: Saudis Lonely, Costly Bid for Sunni-Shiite Equality
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Mikhlif Al-Shammari has been jailed repeatedly, declared an infidel, ruined financially and shot four times  by his own son  all for this: He believes his fellow Sunni Muslims should treat Shiites as equals.

title: Official Targets Russophobia
description: MOSCOW  With the Russian authorities on edge amid fears of conflict in Ukraine, a member of Parliament on Friday submitted a draft bill that would penalize the spreading of Russophobic propaganda in Russia, imposing maximum penalties of 15 days in prison or a fine of 50,000 rubles, or about $1,370.

title: In Land of Elvis, UConn Still Yearns for Broadway
description: MEMPHIS  At an omelet station in the breakfast buffet of the Crowne Plaza hotel in Memphis, the Big East tournament lives on. Here, some 1,097 miles from 4 Pennsylvania Plaza, is a renowned coach in an unfamiliar place, ruminating over games gone by.

title: Pacifica Radio Fires Its Executive Director
description: The Pacifica Foundation, a community radio network that includes WBAI-FM in New York, has dismissed its executive director, the latest tumultuous step for an organization that has been plagued by financial problems and acrimonious turnover among its management.

title: A Store With Media in Mind
description: At a Manhattan boutique called Story, shoppers can buy delicate lingerie or intricately decorated chocolate, scented candles or underwear made by a Swedish company called Bread & Boxers.

title: Mayors Pre-K Tax Drive: Views Vary on Its Success as Widely as on Its Merits
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio rose to power with a promise to increase taxes on wealthy New Yorkers to pay for prekindergarten classes, an idea, rich with symbolism, that many hoped would galvanize liberal causes across the country.

title: Senate Balks at Obama Pick for Surgeon General
description: WASHINGTON  Facing a possible defeat in the Senate, the White House is considering delaying a vote on President Obamas choice for surgeon general or withdrawing the nomination altogether, an acknowledgment of its fraying relationship with Senate Democrats.

title: Study Called an Advance in Stem Cells Had Faults
description: TOKYO  A study billed as a breakthrough in stem cell research contained a spliced image, material recycled from the lead authors doctoral thesis and other mistakes, a Japanese research institute acknowledged on Friday.

title: Massachusetts College Town Seeks Answers as Festivities Spin Out of Control
description: AMHERST, Mass.  This neat college town, home to the University of Massachusettss flagship campus, is accustomed to a certain level of rowdiness. In the last decade alone, the local police and university officials have dispersed unruly crowds celebrating New England sports championships or railing against home-team losses, sometimes making between one and two dozen arrests.

title: N.B.A. Looks to Asia for Next Growth Spurt
description: HONG KONG  When the National Basketball Association commissioner David Stern spent a week in Beijing in the winter of 1987, he had to plead with China Central Television to broadcast N.B.A. games  and he eventually offered to provide content free.

title: Doherty Exiting as New York Sanitation Chief
description: There are no snow plows in Aruba.

title: End of Gulf Ban Allows BP to Expand in Familiar, Lucrative Territory
description: HOUSTON  Even as drilling for new oil in the Gulf of Mexico has made a robust return since the Deepwater Horizon rig disaster in 2010, BP has been in the unusual position of spectator.

title: Legislature Rejects Cuomos Plan to Use Rebates to Freeze Property Taxes
description: ALBANY  In a rare bipartisan rebuke, the New York State Legislature is resisting Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos plan to effectively freeze property taxes for two years, one of the centerpieces of the budget he proposed in January.

title: Clinton Archives Collection, Part 2: Foreign Intelligence
description: Papers related to intelligence and terrorism from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

title: Clinton Archives Collection, Part 1: Speechwriting
description: Speechwriters papers from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

title: Clinton Archives Collection, Part 4: Domestic Issues
description: Papers related to domestic policy and history from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

title: A Mystery, a Murder Case and an Injustice
description: Much of the news this past week seemed to come from the pages of best-selling thrillers. The creepy disappearance of a jetliner over Southeast Asia, with the possibility that it may have kept flying for hours after it broke electronic contact, was the mystery of the week, inflicting agonizing suspense on relatives of the lost passengers.

title: Clinton Archives Collection, Part 5: 2000 Election
description: Papers related to the 2000 presidential election from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

title: Clinton Archives Collection, Part 3: International Relations
description: Papers related to foreign policy from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

title: BMW to Introduce X4 Sports Activity Coupe at New York Auto Show
description: BMW will showcase several new-to-America models at the New York International Auto Show next month, but the vehicle making its first appearance on the world stage will be the X4 Sports Activity Coupe.

title: Florida: Sentencing Is Delayed in Case of Shooting Over Loud Music
description: The sentencing of Michael Dunn, who was convicted last month of attempted murder for shooting at three teenagers after a confrontation over loud music, will be delayed until after his new trial on the remaining first-degree murder charge. A judge on Friday in Jacksonville set a trial date of May 5 for Mr. Dunn, 47. A jury was unable to reach a verdict on whether Mr. Dunn fatally shot Jordan Davis, 17, in self-defense or did so intentionally. A retrial will be held on that charge. But it is possible that the trial date could be postponed. Mr. Dunn, who could no longer afford to pay his lawyer, is being represented by someone new. He could waive his right to a speedy trial to give his new lawyer more time to prepare, a move that would delay the trial until later this year.

title: Metro-North to Study Whether Surge in Riders Affected Railroads Safety
description: Last year, the Metro-North Railroads three main lines achieved their highest ridership ever, carrying nearly 82 million passengers as suburban growth and a stronger regional economy helped fuel unprecedented demand.

title: Phil Jackson Lands a No-Lose Proposition
description: When he was coaching in Chicago, Phil Jackson was watching a baseball game one spring afternoon with Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Bulls and the White Sox, who volunteered what Reinsdorf considered an important tenet of proprietary success.

title: Tennessee: Ruling Favors 3 Gay Couples Seeking Recognition of Marriages
description: In the latest challenge to same-sex marriage restrictions, a federal judge in Nashville said Friday that Tennessee must recognize the status of three couples who were married in other states. The ruling is preliminary and applies only to these couples, said Judge Aleta A. Trauger of Federal District Court, pending a broader decision on whether Tennessee must recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. But all signs indicate, the judge wrote, that same-sex marriage bans will soon become a footnote in the annals of American history. The state did not say whether it would appeal the temporary ruling.

title: In Venezuela, Conciliatory Talk but Combative Tactics
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Acting on the orders of President Nicols Maduro, riot police officers and soldiers this week blocked a march of thousands of student protesters, doused them with pepper spray, blasted them with water cannons and bombarded them with tear gas.

title: Evening Hours | Dodging the Cold
description: Supporting the arts and fighting hunger and AIDS.

title: A Defective Auto Safety System
description: It is too early to say whether General Motors failure to identify and fix an ignition defect linked to at least 12 deaths but possibly many more was a case of negligence or a deliberate cover-up or something else. That will be determined by a criminal investigation being conducted by the Department of Justice and inquiries by Congress.

title: Mr. Obama Feels the Heat
description: An escalating campaign by immigration advocates against President Obamas get-tough policies (nearly two million deportations and counting) is having an effect on the deporter in chief.

title: In A.C.C. Tournament, Syracuse Cannot Find Allies or the Basket
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  If Madison Square Garden offered a warm, cozy, home-away-from-home-court advantage for Syracuse in the Big East tournament, the comparative backwoods of Greensboro Coliseum turned out to be far less hospitable.

title: As Owners of Roadside Institution Enter Political Fray, Texans Weigh Their Loyalties
description: NEW BRAUNFELS, Tex.  Dan Patrick, a Texas state senator running for lieutenant governor, has been endorsed by the former presidential candidate Mike Huckabee and the Young Conservatives of Texas. The trouble started when he won an endorsement from a man named Beaver.

title: Craven Statehouse Behavior
description: Despite all the lethal mayhem caused by the Stand Your Ground laws now on the books in nearly two dozen states, the gun lobby is inviting more trouble.

title: Bill Cunningham | No Coupons at Chanel
description: At Chanel, the real fun began after more than 2,000 guests got up from their carton seats and thought they had the right to shop.

title: Hoarder Facing Deadline to Clear Out Says Hes About Done
description: A New York City marshal showed up at Kevin McCrarys Upper East Side apartment on Friday around 10 a.m. to evict him.

title: For Land of Hoops, No Shot in N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: With every missed shot, there was a collective groan. With every turnover, a loud sigh. It was as if the college basketball fans inside 33 Brick Street, a sports bar in Larry Birds hometown, French Lick, were speaking for the entire basketball-crazed state of Indiana.

title: We Cant Grow the Gap Away
description: The shocking level of income inequality in this country has set off alarms that grow louder by the day, but little seems to be underway to reverse the trend.

title: U.S.-Europe Trade Talks Continue
description: European and American officials had hoped they could highlight progress on negotiations for a wide-ranging trade agreement, but talks in Brussels have yielded more frustration than headway.

title: Bill Cunningham | No Coupons at Chanel
description: The unforgettable show in Paris two weeks ago was Chanels gigantic supermarket that filled the Grand Palais, right. The collection was shown with models shopping the maze of aisles, everything labeled with a connection to Chanel. The real fun began after Karl Lagerfeld took his stroll through the market, left, when the more than 2,000 guests got up from their carton seats and thought they had the right to shop, filling their arms with goods. But at the checkout counters, security guards confiscated everything. One woman was so angered she struck out at the security workers.

title: Deportation Policy Shift Is Signaled by Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and his top aides have for months rejected demands from Hispanic activists that Mr. Obama wave a magic wand to end deportations, an action the White House saw as so antagonistic to Republicans that it would destroy any hope for a bipartisan immigration overhaul and even open the door to impeachment.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 14, 2014
description: March 14, 2014

title: Bloomberg Says He Wont, but Still Criticizes de Blasio
description: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had said he would not criticize his successor. He even said it again during an interview with Katie Couric for Yahoo News that was released Friday. But still, his remarks, at least in part, were critical.

title: Spreading the Word on the Power of Atheism
description: SEATTLE  The atheist writer S. T. Joshi, 55, born in India, raised in Indiana and now living in Seattle, has written or edited more than 200 books, including a novel of detective fiction, a bibliography of writings about Gore Vidal and numerous works about H. L. Mencken.

title: Rumors Mushroom in Eastern Ukraine, Fueling Expectations of War
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  In confident and knowing tones, people here say they have heard that Russian spies have infiltrated the city, or that pro-Ukrainian fighters are hoarding weapons for an attack, or that thousands of Russian citizens have been bused in from across the border to foment riots.

title: Judge Rules Terror Case Should Go Before Jury
description: A federal judge said on Friday that the evidence that Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a top adviser to Osama bin Laden, conspired to kill Americans was dramatically more than merely sufficient to allow the case to go a jury.

title: Medical Marijuana Bill Dies in Washington State
description: SEATTLE  Legislation aimed at bringing Washington States largely unregulated medical marijuana system under state control, which state officials have said is crucial to maintaining order as the legalized sale of recreational marijuana begins this year, died late Thursday night without a vote as the House and Senate adjourned.

title: Song of Exultation
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Ladles and gentlemints, we have a winner. Ed Sessa has actually included a pop culture/social media reference in his puzzle that I didnt know.

title: Amid Rubble, a Bloody Face Spied in Time
description: He was a few blocks away, at the 25th Precinct station in East Harlem, getting his day going, when he heard the jarring explosion. Officer Paul Pastorini immediately knew something was terribly wrong. Noise like that, well, it shouldnt happen.

title: To Learn How His Pitchers Tick, McCann Leans on Technology
description: TAMPA, Fla.  After giving catcher Brian McCann a five-year, $85 million contract, the Yankees gave him something else  an iPad.

title: Harlem Blast Victims to Get Housing
description: New York City officials announced efforts on Friday to house dozens of families who were displaced after an explosion destroyed two buildings in East Harlem.

title: White House Tightens Health Plans Standards After Consumers Complain
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued stringent new standards on Friday for health insurance to address a flood of complaints from consumers who said that costs were too high and that the choice of doctors, hospitals and prescription drugs was too limited in many health plans offered this year under the Affordable Care Act.

title: France Convicts Rwandan Ex-Officer of Genocide
description: PARIS  By his account, Pascal Simbikangwa did not see a single dead body. While thousands of members of the Tutsi ethnic group were slaughtered in the streets of Kigali, the Rwandan capital, in 1994, Mr. Simbikangwa, a former intelligence officer who uses a wheelchair, testified that he rarely left home.

title: As Syria Prepares for Election, U.N. Envoy Plans Trip to Its Ally Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS  Syria plans to hold national elections in June or July, its ambassador to the United Nations said Friday, as Secretary General Ban Ki-moon announced that he would send his seasoned Syria mediator, Lakhdar Brahimi, to Iran, the Syrian governments most vital backer in the Middle East.

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 90
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Jack Kinzler, Whose Ingenuity Saved Skylab, Dies at 94
description: Had Jack A. Kinzler not built model planes as a boy, had he not visited the post office as a youth and had he not, as a grown man, purchased four fishing rods at $12.95 apiece, Skylab  the United States $2.5 billion space station  would very likely have been forfeit.

title: Diplomat From India Is Indicted Again Over Housekeeper
description: A grand jury in New York has reindicted an Indian diplomat whose arrest and strip-search last year in the United States created tensions between the United States and India.

title: Iola Brubeck, Collaborator and Wife of Jazz Pianist, Dies at 90
description: Iola Brubeck, who played an important behind-the-scenes role in the success of her husband, the jazz pianist and composer Dave Brubeck, died on March 12 at her home in Wilton, Conn. She was 90.

title: Israel: Military Fires Into Lebanon After Border Blast
description: A large explosive device was detonated against an Israeli Army vehicle patrolling the Israel-Lebanon border on Friday, and the Israeli military responded with tank and artillery fire against positions held by the Lebanese group Hezbollah near the border, Israeli military officials said. The blast, which damaged the armored vehicle, caused no apparent injuries to the soldiers inside. But the Israelis described it as a serious violation of the cease-fire that ended the 2006 war between Israel and Hezbollah. Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, an Israeli spokesman, said Israel suspected a Hezbollah connection, adding that it was reinforcing troops on the border. Israel Radio reported lateFridaythat an Islamic group affiliated with Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attack via Twitter. The reliability of the claim could not be verified.

title: U.S. Navy Strategists Have a Long History of Finding the Lost
description: The uncertainties surrounding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370s disappearance are enormous, but naval strategists have been unraveling lost-at-sea mysteries as far back as the U-boat battles of World War II, and perhaps most dramatically in 1968, when an intelligence team found the submarine Scorpion, which sank in the North Atlantic after losing contact under equally baffling circumstances.

title: Providence Continues Physical Run
description: Providence runs a drill that LaDontae Henton would challenge any team in the country to try for five minutes. It is a box-out drill featuring four players. And it is physical.

title: Obama Welcomes Prime Minister of Ireland
description: The president met with Prime Minister Enda Kenny to kick off the St. Patricks Day holiday.

title: Video Notebook: Providence Hangs On
description: The Providence coach Ed Cooley talks about the Friars' ability to hold off Seton Hall in the second half of the Big East semifinals.

title: Corrections: March 15, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE GREAT GATSBY (2013) Leonardo DiCaprio, above, stars as the enigmatic millionaire Jay Gatsby; Carey Mulligan portrays Daisy Buchanan, the object of his obsession; and Tobey Maguire is Nick Carraway, the Midwestern Yale graduate  and, conveniently, Daisys cousin  renting the cottage next door to Gatsbys colossal Long Island mansion in Baz Luhrmanns stylized musical take on F. Scott Fitzgeralds novel. Despite what you may have heard, it is an eminently enjoyable movie, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar winner for best costume and production design. Still, he asked, is the tale a credible love story? Fitzgerald himself was not sure, but Mr. Luhrmann, Mr. DiCaprio and Ms. Mulligan make it an effective one. At a crucial, climactic moment  a scene in a suite at the Plaza Hotel  the director mutes his irrepressible circus ringmaster showmanship and plunges into undiluted melodrama. The music stops, and the camera cuts among the assembled faces as the emotional core of the film is laid bare. That scene, Mr. Scott added, stands out in a movie that is otherwise gaudily and grossly inauthentic, like Gatsby himself. As a character in Nicks ruminations, in Fitzgeralds sentences and in our national mythology, he is a complete mess. This movie is worthy of him.

title: Video Notebook: Creighton Advances
description: The Creighton forwards Doug McDermott and Ethan Wragge talk about playing for a Big East tournament title in their first year in the conference.

title: Malaysia Officials Open Criminal Inquiry Into Missing Jet
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The search for Flight 370 turned into a criminal investigation on Saturday, after Malaysia declared that the plane had been deliberately diverted and then flown for as long as seven hours toward an unknown point far from its scheduled route of Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.

title: Malaysian Prime Ministers Statement on Flight 370 Investigation
description: Following is the text of Prime Minister Najib Razaks statement Saturday on the investigation into the missing Malaysia Airlines plane, as provided by Mr. Najibs office.

title: Analytics: To Revive or Not to Revive
description: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All letters page in the March 16 issue of the magazine.

title: Remembering A.C.P.T. 2014
description: SPECIAL POST  The big boards are put away for another year and Dan Feyer is at home polishing his latest first place trophy. Will there be anyone who is solver enough to defeat him?

title: As Scandal Unfolds, G.M. Calls In the Lawyers
description: Late last summer, a lawyer named Lance Cooper sensed that his long battle with General Motors was coming to an end.

title: Brand Placement Moves to the High Seas
description: If your cruise ship makes you feel more at home than ever, its not just the comfortable cabins. The expansion of familiar brands on the high seas is showcasing American pop culture.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, March 16
description: I didnt want Bobs job.

title: Fed Challenge: Pull Back Without Pulling the Rug Out
description: March has been an up-and-down stretch for the stock market, but it is turning into a month of milestones nonetheless. The bull market reached its fifth anniversary last weekend, and if the trend continues this week, on Saturday it will become the fifth-longest bull market since 1928.

title: Crimea Through a Game-Theory Lens
description: A Russian occupation of Crimea raises the specter of the Cold War, in which the nuclear stalemate between the United States and the Soviet Union devolved into regional disputes around the world.

title: Preserving Family History, One Memory at a Time
description: Until recently, Jessie Leiken, 27, a union organizer in Brooklyn, was confident that she knew about the major adventures of her mothers life: a hot-air balloon ride in Egypt, a snowshoeing excursion in Montana, a camel-meat meal in Morocco. But two weeks ago, an email appeared in Ms. Leikens inbox from her mother, Nancy Mills, 64, that told an entirely new tale:

title: A Demonstration of Enigma
description: Hicham Oudghiri, a co-founder of Enigma, demonstrated an application of his companys service during the TechCrunch Disrupt conference in 2013.

title: Shawn Jenkins of Benefitfocus: A C.E.O. Is Like a Flight Instructor
description: This interview with  Shawn Jenkins, chief executive of Benefitfocus, a benefits technology company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: A Harvest of Company Details, All in One Basket
description: Trolling government records for juicy details about companies and their executives can be a ponderous task. I often find myself querying the websites of multiple federal agencies, each using its own particular terminology and data forms, just for a glimpse of one companys business.

title: A Man, a Truck and a Load of Stuffed Shrimp
description: In 1981, after my first year of college, I decided to spend the summer in San Francisco. Id grown up on the East Coast and had never been to that city before, and I wanted an adventure. Part of the adventure would be figuring out how to pay for food and the room I was renting in an old Victorian house in the Haight  so, when I arrived, I scoured the help-wanted ads and made some phone calls.

title: A Loan Fraud War Thats Short on Combat
description: In the years since the financial crisis of 2008, the Justice Department has been regularly questioned about a lack of criminal prosecutions related to the mortgage mess.

title: For Crimea, Secession Is Only as Good as Recognition
description: PARIS  When Kosovo declared independence from Serbia in 2008, with the strong support of the United States, Russia, a staunch ally of the Serbs, insisted that the declaration was a reckless breach of international law.

title: Executions Delayed for Two in India Gang Rape Case
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian Supreme Court on Saturday temporarily stayed the executions of two of the four men sentenced to death in the gang rape and murder of a 23-year-old woman in Delhi in 2012, an attack that set off a public outcry and mass protests in India over violence against women in the country.

title: Foes of America in Russia Crave Rupture in Ties
description: MOSCOW  As Russia and the United States drift toward a rupture over Crimea, the Stalinist writer Aleksandr A. Prokhanov feels that his moment has finally arrived.

title: Variety: Two for One
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  So. How did we do? I am not a genius, I can tell you that much, but I definitely had fun with this one. Maybe not by normal, puzzle-solving standards, but I had fun.

title: Capital Crimes, Re-Examined
description: Miscarriage-of-justice stories drawn from real life are television slam-dunks, but a new CNN series, Death Row Stories, tells them especially well. The series, whose second installment will be broadcast on Sunday night at 9, looks at capital murder cases in which questionable evidence or investigative tactics led to convictions of dubious merit. Its a sure formula for building suspense and outrage as the story goes along.

title: Becoming French, as Well as ...
description: Filmed at the Granges-aux-Belles school in Pariss 10th Arrondissement, Julie Bertucellis documentary School of Babel observes a reception class of immigrant children, ages 11 to 15, who speak little or no French. Ms. Bertucelli, best known for her features Since Otar Left and The Tree, observes parent-teacher meetings in which family backgrounds and reasons of immigration are revealed. The teacher, Brigitte Cervoni, is patient and gentle with her students, who make their own film about themselves for a student festival. You see firsthand the students dealing with the anxiety about cultural integration. The children come from all over the globe: Ireland, Brazil, China. Rama, the most resistant student, is a Senegalese girl from a troubled family. In some ways, this smart, clear, upbeat movie, which has its final screening Sunday in Lincoln Centers Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series, is a documentary equivalent of Laurent Cantets The Class (2008). (1:30 p.m., rendezvouswithfrenchcinema.com.)

title: Working Stiffs and Just Folks
description: Revisited as memory and myth or seen in warts-and-all close-up, the South looms in concerts this week by Rosanne Cash, on Tuesday, and by Drive-By Truckers, on Thursday. Although she is a longtime New Yorker, Ms. Cashs new album, The River & the Thread, grew out of sojourns in Tennessee, Louisiana and Arkansas, where she helped to restore the boyhood house of her father, Johnny Cash. The songs are folksy, lean and aphoristic; they conjure characters real and imagined, all the way back to the Civil War, with laconic grace. (8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, 212-840-2824, thetownhall.org.)

title: Of a Feather: Audubons Birds
description: After John James Audubon died in 1851, his widow sold the 435 watercolors he created for his opus, The Birds of America, tothe New-York Historical Society. Last year, the society presented 200 of those masterpieces of ornithological observation in the first of a three-partexhibition series called Audubons Aviary: The Complete Flock. The second installment, subtitled Parts Unknown, opens Friday. It will display132 more watercolors, most of water birds or waders. They represent some of Audubons biggest subjects, including the great blue heron and the whooping crane. Other species include the Atlantic puffin, which Audubon saw in Labrador; the snowy egret, which he studied in South Carolina; and the golden eagle, in particular a live but injured specimen that he bought in Boston and euthanized so he could paint it. The show will be enhanced by audio of bird calls and songs of each species from the Cornell Lab of Ornithology. (Through May 26, 170 Central Park West, at West 77thStreet, 212-873-3400, nyhistory.org.)

title: Left Coast, Meet Right Coast
description: At 33, Gustavo Dudamel, the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and perhaps the most charismatic conductor of the new generation, brings that adventurous West Coast orchestra to Avery Fisher Hall for a pair of enticing programs. On Sunday afternoon, he conducts John Coriglianos Symphony No. 1 (1989), a work of rage and remembrance for friends who died of AIDS, in Mr. Coriglianos words; and Tchaikovskys Fifth Symphony. Monday evenings program offers the New York premiere of a work by the Icelandic composer Daniel Bjarnason; Rachmaninoffs Third Piano Concerto, with the young virtuoso Yuja Wang; and Brahmss Second Symphony. (3 p.m. Sunday and 8 p.m. Monday, Lincoln Center, 212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org.)

title: Choreographers New Landscape
description: The last time Beth Gill created a new work, people noticed. Her 2011 Electric Midwife earned three Bessie awards, including one for outstanding emerging choreographer. There arent many dance makers of Ms. Gills generation (she is 33) working with the kind of clear, penetrating focus that made Midwife  a pair of perfectly symmetrical trios  such a transporting meditation on the body, its intricate physics and intrinsic poetry.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: During the height of the financial crisis, mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were bailed out by taxpayers to the tune of $187 billion. Now, more than five years later, theyre on track to pay all that back and more. But then what?

title: Even With Top N.B.A. Draft Picks, Saviors Prove Rare
description: As the N.B.A. regular season winds down, losing teams turn hopeful eyes toward the N.C.A.A. tournament and the draft, whose class this season is so packed with talent that it has drawn comparisons to 2003, the year LeBron James, Carmelo Anthony and Dwyane Wade came out.

title: Obama Factor Adds to Fears of Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats are becoming increasingly alarmed about their midterm election fortunes amid President Obamas sinking approval ratings, a loss in a special House election in Florida last week, and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law.

title: Jackson the Iconoclast, Coolly Collecting Rings
description: The Los Angeles Lakers had just suffered a lackluster loss in Chicago. It was Phil Jacksons final season with them, but not even his presumed last game coaching in a city that held so many memories for him could stir the Lakers from the malaise that afflicts teams, particularly back-to-back champions, during the regular-season grind.

title: Malaysian Premiers News Conference
description: Prime Minister Najib Razak said on Saturday that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been deliberately diverted from its planned flight path.

title: Where Income Is Higher, Life Spans Are Longer
description: As incomes have diverged between the countrys richest counties, like Fairfax County, Va., and its poorest ones, like McDowell County, W.Va., so have the life expectancies of their residents.

title: The Threats That Help PayPal
description: The best thing that happened to PayPal in years may also be why it has turned into a Wall Street football: a big upswing in innovation, fed by the prospect of irrelevance.

title: Shining Examples for Marlins Team Seeking Its Way Back
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The Miami Marlins franchise started with a knuckleball and has basically behaved like one ever since. From the moment Charlie Hough delivered that first fluttery offering, in 1993, the Marlins have dipped and darted, from the highs of two championships to the lows of cost-cutting trades.

title: Out of Office, Sarkozy Is Still Front and Center
description: PARIS  The scandal, intrigue and occasional vaudeville of Nicolas Sarkozys five years in the presidency made for great headlines, and French journalists once fretted that politics under his successor, Franois Hollande, who pledged to be a normal president, might prove unbearably dull.

title: Mathematicians Are Hoping Their Calculations Add Up to the Perfect Bracket
description: Typically, when the worlds of math and sports collide, name calling, noogies and maybe even a wedgie follow.

title: Chinas Central Bank Allows Its Currency More Volatility
description: SHANGHAI  In the latest sign that China is loosening its tight grip over the economy, the government said on Saturday that the value of its currency would now be allowed to fluctuate more widely against the United States dollar.

title: The Pride of Wichita State, Whatever It May Actually Be
description: ST. LOUIS  The Wichita State mascot stands around 7 feet tall with a prominent highlighter-yellow head sticking out of a black sweatshirt. The head is streaked with black, the face sports a pronounced nose and angry eyebrows, and atop it all sits what looks like a mop of blond hair in a bowl cut gone awry.

title: Evolution of WuShock
description: WuShock, the mascot for Wichita State, has a long history, and it is one of the more distinctive and odd members of the mascot kingdom.

title: Rebuilt Big East Sees Room for a Rival Conferences Tournament
description: When Val Ackerman, the commissioner of the Big East Conference, learned Friday that the Atlantic Coast Conference was planning to move its postseason tournament to Barclays Center in Brooklyn in 2017 and 2018, she reacted with quiet confidence.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 89
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Map of Planes Last Contact With Satellite
description: The missing Malaysia Airlines plane may have been over China or west of Australia when it last made contact with a satellite.

title: Melba Hernndez, a Confidante of Castro From First Volley, Is Dead at 92
description: When Melba Hernndez met Fidel Castro in the early 1950s, she likened it to a religious experience. I felt secure, she said. I felt I had found the way.

title: Industry Behind Anti-Wage-Hike Letter
description: WASHINGTON  The National Restaurant Association did not disclose upfront its role in helping draft and circulate a statement signed by more than 500 prominent economists, including four winners of the Nobel Prize, urging the federal government to reject the proposal by the Obama administration to increase the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour, interviews with signers of the letter showed.

title: Israel Reaches Out to the Diaspora
description: OVER the past two weeks, Jewish leaders outside Israel quietly gathered in seminar groups to grapple with a thorny question: how to ensure that Israel is both a Jewish and a democratic state.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 16
description: The mystery surrounding the fate of Malaysian Airlines Flight 370 continues to capture the worlds attention. While nobody knows exactly what happened, that wont stop the chattering classes more than 9,000 miles away in Washington from weighing in.

title: Letters to the Sports Editor: Is a Career Extender a Performance Enhancer?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution on Crimea
description: UNITED NATIONS  Russia on Saturday vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution that declared a planned Sunday referendum on secession in Crimea illegal, casting the sole vote against it.

title: Lucrezia Reichlin
description: The Italian economist Lucrezia Reichlin is a professor at the London Business School and was the first female head of research at the European Central Bank. She is best known for developing a system for making real-time assessments and near-term economic forecasts using mind-numbingly large data sets.

title: How Much Should Hepatitis C Treatment Cost?
description: A new pill to treat hepatitis C raises difficult questions about fair pricing, not only in the United States and other affluent nations but in developing countries around the world. Hepatitis C, which afflicts some 150 million people globally, often without symptoms for years, can cause fatigue and fever, cirrhosis or liver cancer.

title: Erin Go Drinking
description: MONDAY is St. Patricks Day, a holiday that seems to last longer than the 40 days of Lent. This provides more than enough time for Irish-Americans to fulfill all that our proud, guilt-ridden tradition requires.

title: Ohio Mistrusts Democracy
description: Ohio Republicans must not think their political candidates can win a fair fight against Democrats. Theyve decided to rig the states election system in their favor, deliberately making voting harder for people who tend to vote Democratic, particularly minorities and the poor.

title: Go West, Young People! And East!
description: IM delighted to announce that the winner of my 2014 win-a-trip contest is ...

title: Dems in Distress
description: WASHINGTON  Scott Brown, the Republican who admitted he wore pink leather shorts on his first date with his wife-to-be, is back.

title: The Three Faces of President Obama
description: BARACK OBAMA is surely the first president to be accused of acting in foreign policy like Pollyanna, John Wayne and Henry Kissinger in the same month.

title: The Age of Individualism
description: IN the future, it seems, there will be only one ism  Individualism  and its rule will never end. As for religion, it shall decline; as for marriage, it shall be postponed; as for ideologies, they shall be rejected; as for patriotism, it shall be abandoned; as for strangers, they shall be distrusted. Only pot, selfies and Facebook will abide  and the greatest of these will probably be Facebook.

title: Domestic Violence
description: Readers react to Nicholas Kristofs call for more attention and resources to fight this scourge.

title: The Incessant Selling of the Self
description: YOUNG people have been educated to believe that self-promotion is essential. Being excellent is only part of the scenario, and quick personal advancement is mandatory. Otherwise, all will be lost. All the talent, all the hope, all the achievement. Those things are not meant to speak for themselves: Theyre kindling for the fire, and the fire must be breathed out of the mouths of young dragons that have no fear (with tongue piercings removed for job interviews).

title: Learning From Legos
description: WHEN I was a boy, my father, an architect, attempted a no-toy policy, with the significant exception that hed buy my brother and me almost anything  any birthday, holiday or restless rainy Saturday  as long as it was Lego.

title: The Apartheid of Childrens Literature
description: Of 3,200 childrens books published in 2013, just 93 were about black people, according to a study by the Cooperative Childrens Book Center at the University of Wisconsin.

title: The Rise of Anti-Capitalism
description: WE are beginning to witness a paradox at the heart of capitalism, one that has propelled it to greatness but is now threatening its future: The inherent dynamism of competitive markets is bringing costs so far down that many goods and services are becoming nearly free, abundant, and no longer subject to market forces. While economists have always welcomed a reduction in marginal cost, they never anticipated the possibility of a technological revolution that might bring those costs to near zero.

title: Where Are the People of Color in Childrens Books?
description: Of 3,200 childrens books published in 2013, just 93 were about black people, according to a study by the Cooperative Childrens Book Center at the University of Wisconsin.

title: Paul Ryans Irish Amnesia
description: IN advance of St. Patricks Day, I went time traveling, back to the 1840s and Irelands great famine. On one side of the Irish Sea was Victorian England, flush with the pomp and prosperity of the worlds mightiest empire. On the other side were skeletal people, dying en masse, the hollow-bellied children scrounging for nettles and blackberries.

title: A Rare Opportunity on Criminal Justice
description: The current Congress is the place where virtually all legislation, however urgent or reasonable, goes to die. Yet out of this stew of partisan mistrust and dysfunction there may come one promising and unexpected achievement: the first major reforms to Americas broken criminal justice system in a generation.

title: Paralympics, at Peace as Wars Wind Down
description: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia  A dozen years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan, years of grenades and land mines and roadside bombs, left thousands of American soldiers and their allies without limbs. Many of them regained a sense of self after being introduced to adaptive sports, enjoying life outside the constraints of wheelchairs or prosthetic legs.

title: Planet Pasta
description: A field trip to the worlds largest pasta maker.

title: Behind the Bulls Surge, a Center Playing Like Chamberlain
description: Accused of attempting to tank the season when they traded Luol Deng to the Cleveland Cavaliers for Andrew Bynum, who was immediately waived, and three draft picks, the Chicago Bulls have instead moved steadily up the standings. One major factor in the teams surge despite a depleted roster has been the play of Joakim Noah. Always a defensive ace, Noah has turned himself into one of the N.B.A.s great passing centers.

title: Disdaining Shootouts, General Managers Push an Overtime Turnabout
description: The Period of the Long Change sounds like an epoch of upheaval in Cromwells England or 20th-century China. But it is the trendy way of referring to the second period of hockey games, when teams defend the end of the ice farther from their benches.

title: SXSW 2014: Music Three Ways
description: Samsaya was born in India and raised in Norway, where she has been releasing albums for a decade. Shes applies a full pop arsenal  short catchy melodies, singalong-ready wordless hooks (woh-oh-oh-oh-oh!) and big beats out of hip-hop, punk-pop and Bollywood  to messages of self-empowerment and tolerance. She hit the small indoor stage at Stubbs as if she were working an arena, with cheerleader energy somewhere between peak No Doubt and Lady Gaga. Dont ever fear your difference! Dont ever let them change you! she exhorted. Our strength is our uniqueness! She was introducing the single Stereotype, which insists, Ill just dance to whatever I like.

title: Russia Seizes Gas Plant Near Crimea Border, Ukraine Says
description: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine  Tensions mounted on the eve of a secession referendum here in Crimea as helicopter-borne Russian forces made a provocative incursion just outside the peninsulas regional border to seize a natural gas terminal, while American and European officials prepared sanctions to impose on Moscow as early as Monday.

title: Unions Hockey Team Turns Adversity to Advantage
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.  Two years ago, the Union mens team was college hockeys Cinderella story when the Dutchmen advanced to the Frozen Four in only their second N.C.A.A. Division I tournament appearance.

title: Evidence Mounts That Mens Top Four Tennis Players Are No Longer on Pedestal
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  A vision of what the future might hold for mens tennis appeared in the desert last week.

title: Congrats to my Win-a-Trip Winner! Now, Where Should We Go?
description: As my Sunday column notes, I have a win-a-trip winner! Congratulations to Nicole Sganga of University of Notre Dame, winner of my 2014 contest. Nicole, 20, is from Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, and is majoring in political science and film, television and theatre. She is a talented video journalist who has worked for CBS News in Washington and London and received rave reviews from people she has worked for and interned for. After graduating, she wants to cover the worldand Im sure well hear plenty more from her in years to come. For now, Im looking forward to seeing her blog posts and videos from our reporting trip together.

title: Mets Pitchers Mechanics Are Perfect; His Pluperfect Is Not
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On a recent morning, Ronny Reyes sat behind his desk at the Mets minor league complex, folded his hands and furrowed his brow. He was concerned about one of his players, the top pitching prospect Rafael Montero.

title: Waiting for Jackson but Still Winning, Knicks Stay in Race
description: It was still three days before Phil Jacksons scheduled introduction as Knicks president, but already his presence was tangible at Madison Square Garden.

title: Funding the Future
description: As government financing of basic science research has plunged, private donors have filled the void, raising questions about the future of research for the public good.

title: Billionaires With Big Ideas Are Privatizing American Science
description: Last April, President Obama assembled some of the nations most august scientific dignitaries in the East Room of the White House. Joking that his grades in physics made him a dubious candidate for scientist in chief, he spoke of using technological innovation to grow our economy and unveiled the next great American project: a $100 million initiative to probe the mysteries of the human brain.

title: Investigators in Jet Search Rely on an Imperfect Tool
description: WASHINGTON  The main tool available in the search for the missing jet operating as Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 is imprecise and awkward, and unfamiliar to the investigators using it, but it is all they have.

title: After 3 Days of Prayers in East Harlem, a Treasure Is Found in the Ashes
description: Over three grim and grueling days of digging through the rubble of two East Harlem buildings annihilated in a gas explosion, rescue workers uncovered eight bodies and a catalog of ruined lives. On Saturday, though, they also discovered a small, but precious treasure.

title: Passengers and Crew of Missing Plane Scrutinized for Aviation Skills
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The investigation into the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has shifted to include anyone on board with a navigation or aircraft background in response to evidence that the plane was deliberately diverted from its route and, after communication was lost, navigated by someone with deep experience at the controls.

title: After Wars Agony, a Will to Win
description: The Paralympics in Sochi, Russia, included a number of athletes who had been grievously wounded while serving in the armed forces.

title: In Dream Game for Senegalese Players, St. Josephs Reaches A-10 Final
description: On Thursday night, hours after St. Bonaventure had defeated La Salle in a second-round game at the Atlantic 10 tournament, the Bonnies Youssou Ndoye and Jean Yves Toupane had dinner with an old friend from Senegal, Papa Ndao, a junior forward for St. Josephs.

title: On the Wrong Side of Globalization
description: Trade agreements are a subject that can cause the eyes to glaze over, but we should all be paying attention. Right now, there are trade proposals in the works that threaten to put most Americans on the wrong side of globalization.

title: De Blasio Picks Sanitation Commissioner
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York named Kathryn Garcia, an official of the Environmental Protection Department, to replace John J. Doherty as the citys sanitation commissioner.

title: Jackson Offers a Glimmer of Hope at Dolans Palace
description: Perhaps James L. Dolan has a slyly nasty sense of humor.

title: Sentence Cut for Bin Laden Figure
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani official reduced by 10 years the 33-year sentence of a Pakistani medical doctor who had helped the C.I.A. track down Osama bin Laden, local news media reported Saturday.

title: Two Counties, Separated by Fortune
description: Perhaps the greatest distance between the two places is this: Fairfax County is a place of the haves, and McDowell County of the have-nots.

title: Income Gap, Meet the Longevity Gap
description: Fairfax County, Va., and McDowell County, W.Va., are separated by 350 miles, about a half-days drive. Traveling west from Fairfax County, the gated communities and bland architecture of military contractors give way to exurbs, then to farmland and eventually to McDowells coal mines and the forested slopes of the Appalachians. Perhaps the greatest distance between the two counties is this: Fairfax is a place of the haves, and McDowell of the have-nots. Just outside of Washington, fat government contracts and a growing technology sector buoy the median household income in Fairfax County up to $107,000, one of the highest in the nation. McDowell, with the decline of coal, has little in the way of industry. Unemployment is high. Drug abuse is rampant. Median household income is about one-fifth that of Fairfax.

title: Teixeira Hopes Recovery Is All a Matter of Routine
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Yankees first baseman Mark Teixeira picked at the tape wrapped tightly around his right wrist. It was black, much like his mood most of last season.

title: Charlie Porter, an Adventurer Scaling Rock and Sailing Seas, Is Dead at 63
description: When Charlie Porter showed up in the Yosemite Valley in the early 1970s and started forging new climbing routes up the famously imposing monolithic rock wall known as El Capitan, he was something of a mystery man, a stranger to the clubby group of mostly Californians who had made Yosemite the center of the climbing world.

title: Two European Events Could Scramble Rankings
description: Two competitions this month  the Candidates tournament and the European Individual Chess Championship  have the potential to shake up the world chess order.

title: Celebrity Guest Solver Suzanne Whang: Its Better This Way
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Well, I dont have to say very much today, because Suzanne Whang, stand-up comedian, actress and host of HGTVs House Hunters for 10 years, is going to tell you about her experience solving todays crossword puzzle.

title: Perrys Exit Leaves a Void for Republicans
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Video Notebook: Papa Ndao
description: The junior forward Papa Ndao for St. Joseph's talks about hanging out and competing against the St. Bonaventure junior center Youssou Ndoye.

title: Alamos First Lady Calls and History Buffs Gather
description: The fall of the Alamo on March 6, 1836, is observed each year by a candlelit remembrance in downtown San Antonio. But another, more festive event commemorates the battles anniversary: an annual private party in Terrell Hills for the community that has developed around the Alamo mystique.

title: Honda Recalls 900,000 Minivans
description: Honda is recalling almost 900,000 Odyssey minivans because of a potential fire hazard, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said in a report posted on its website on Saturday.

title: Endangered School Says State Standards Hurt Troubled Youths
description: As a wide-reaching law intended to encourage the growth of high-quality Texas charter schools and shutter underperforming ones takes effect, the state is facing questions over the guidelines used to decide which schools to close.

title: Syrian Forces Close to Taking Over Long-Held Rebel Town
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As Syrian government forces on Saturday pushed into Yabrud, a town long held by rebels near the Lebanese border, opposition activists said that one of many fighters who fell in battle was a leader of the insurgent group the Nusra Front who had helped negotiate an unusual prisoner exchange last week.

title: In Husbands Campaign, a Chance to Make History
description: Gov. Rick Perry made history with an unprecedented three terms in office. The next administration could make history by just taking office.

title: Denominations Downsizing and Selling Assets in More Secular Era
description: BOSTON  The American Unitarian Association, peopled and powered by this citys Brahmin elite, announced its presence here in 1886 with a grand and stately headquarters at the very top of Beacon Hill, right next door to the Statehouse.

title: A Brazilian Models Transformative Role
description: Carol Marra is leading a new group of transgender models who are stepping into Brazils mainstream fashion industry.

title: Thats Not My Daughter
description: Carol Marra says she did not grow up thinking she would be a model.

title: More Acceptance for Transgender Models
description: Carol Marra is leading a new class of transgender models who are stepping out of the alternative scene and into the mainstream of Brazil's fashion industry.

title: After 20 Hours in Solitary, Colorados Prisons Chief Wins Praise
description: CAON CITY, Colo.  The cells where inmates are kept in solitary confinement at the state penitentiary here are 7-by-13-foot boxes arranged in semicircular tiers. When the warden, Travis Trani, heard that Rick Raemisch, Colorados new chief of corrections, intended to spend a night in one of them, he had two reactions.

title: Tensions Flare Over Loyalty to Russia in Eastern Ukraine
description: Nationalist and pro-secessions groups clashed in Kharkiv, a major city in eastern Ukraine.

title: Transgender Models Prosper in Brazil, Where Carnival and Faith Reign
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  As a young boy in Brazils heartland, Carol Marra watched her parents politely correct strangers who said what a pretty daughter they had. In her teenage years, she coveted the boyfriends of her female classmates and tried out androgynous outfits, dutifully changing back into a young mans clothes in her car before returning home.

title: A Star Was (Recently) Born: A Play Boldly Casts Babies
description: Hattie Morahan, who stars as Nora in the acclaimed production of A Dolls House now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has won the kind of rave reviews any actor would envy.

title: Questions as More Wastewater Flows in North Carolina
description: Duke Energy, the giant utility whose spill of toxic waste into a North Carolina river last month is under federal investigation, released wastewater last week from a second site near Raleigh that state regulators said could be illegal.

title: As Putins Popularity Soars, Voices of Opposition Are Being Drowned Out
description: MOSCOW  There were two large rallies on Saturday in Moscow. One was a pro-government rally in support of Crimea and against fascism, led by a phalanx of husky men in identical crimson jackets, marching military-style in a sea of red. Some held signs reading No Maidan in Moscow and Glory to Berkut, references to Independence Square, the site of the Ukrainian protests in Kiev, and to the riot police who cracked down on the protesters.

title: Newfound Assertiveness Sends Romanian Toward Top of Rankings
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  With light, springy footwork and a combination of defensive speed and offensive power, Simona Halep has been moving through courts and draws on the womens tennis tour with considerable ease in recent months.

title: David Brenner, Stand-up Comic of the Little Things in Life, Dies at 78
description: David Brenner, whose wry brand of observational humor made him a stand-up comedy star in the early 1970s and kept him in the public eye for more than four decades, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: In Colombia, Two Warring Officials Provide a Portrait of a Nations Political Divide
description: BOGOT, Colombia  The political battle royale playing out between the mayor of Bogot and the countrys powerful inspector general, who ordered him removed from office, has been compared to a Latin soap opera. But as it drags on, it more closely resembles an absurdist drama in which two actors alternately fascinate and irritate their audience with squabbling, philosophizing and the occasional kick in the pants.

title: Kentucky Adds Snarl to Its Skills
description: ATLANTA  With its collection of heralded freshmen, Kentucky is playing not like an entitled team but like an embattled one. The Wildcats, under harsh criticism for the programs style of recruiting, have been ridiculed most of the season for not reaching preseason expectations of being No. 1, so now they look desperate, even determined, not to be remembered as underachievers.

title: Series of Errors by Malaysia Mounts, Complicating the Task of Finding Flight 370
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  The radar blip that was Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 did a wide U-turn over the Gulf of Thailand and then began moving inexorably past at least three military radar arrays as it traversed northern Malaysia, even flying high over one of the countrys biggest cities before heading out over the Strait of Malacca.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 15, 2014
description: March 15, 2014

title: Technical Problem Silences Ending of Mets Live Simulcast of Werther
description: Updated, 11:59 a.m. | It is one of the most wrenching endings in opera: the lingering death of the title character in Massenets Werther. But it was an accidentally, and frustratingly, silent ending for opera fans who went to movie theaters across the country on Saturday afternoon to see the celebrated tenor Jonas Kaufmann perform the title role in the Metropolitan Operas live high-definition simulcast.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Purim, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Amid Officials Lockout, a Call Costs the Red Bulls
