Nevertheless, he spent two years and millions of dollars on his 14-hour passion project, enlisting the special-effects wizard (and future Alien screenwriter) Dan OBannon and the artist Moebius to oversee the production design; recruiting Orson Welles, Mick Jagger and Salvador Dal to play monstrous roles; and Pink Floyd to compose the score. But not a single frame was ever shot.

title: Schizophrenics and Home Care
description: Home treatment for schizophrenics overseen by local health workers is more effective than institutionalization, a recent large study in India has found.

title: Out of Control
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN mass murderers took over the cockpits of four American airliners on Sept. 11, 2001, one of the first things they did was turn off the transponders, so the planes would not register properly on civilian radar.

title: All Together Now, No Leader Needed
description: There is a warm glow to the sound of the East Coast Chamber Orchestra, a conductorless ensemble made up of members of a variety of American orchestras and quartets.

title: Study Questions Fat and Heart Disease Link
description: Many of us have long been told that saturated fat, the type found in meat, butter and cheese, causes heart disease. But a large and exhaustive new analysis by a team of international scientists found no evidence that eating saturated fat increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.

title: Questions Over Absence of Cellphone Calls From Missing Flights Passengers
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  When hijackers took control of four airplanes on Sept. 11, 2001, and sent them hurtling low across the countryside toward New York and Washington, frantic passengers and flight attendants turned on cellphones and air phones and began making calls to loved ones, airline managers and the authorities.

title: LWren Scotts Designs on the Red Carpet
description: With powerful and body-conscious silhouettes, Ms. Scotts dresses were popular among Hollywood starlets.

title: A Frozen Suite at an Ice Hotel
description: A suite at Quebec Citys Htel de Glace brings aspects of Disneys animated movie Frozen to life.

title: Science Times Podcast
description: A look at how far nuclear fusion has come; contemplating the frightful parallels between an embryo and a tumor; what is the science behind side-splitting humor?

title: A Wintry Mix at the Broadway Box Office
description: March is shaping up as a very mixed month for several new Broadway musicals.

title: A Tribute to a California Pension Funds Guiding Hand
description: They were the power couple of Californias pension assets. But their romance was largely a secret, even at the time of their wedding more than a year ago.

title: Machinery of an Energy Dream
description: LIVERMORE, Calif.  Fusion, the process that powers the sun, is the forever dream of energy scientists  safe, nonpolluting and almost boundless. Even here at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, where the primary focus of fusion work involves nuclear weapons, many scientists talk poetically about how it could end the worlds addiction to fossil fuels.

title: Myanmars Deadly Medicine
description: A cynical decision by Myanmar to ban Doctors Without Borders from the state of Rakhine has left some 750,000 people without medical care since Feb. 28. About 150 people, including women with difficult pregnancies, are estimated to have died since the ban was imposed.

title: In Performance: Steven Boyer
description: Steven Boyer and the puppet Tyrone perform a scene from Robert Askinss dark comedy Hand to God, at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: A Long-Haul Traveler
description: For the first time, researchers have detailed information about the movements and habitats of young loggerhead turtles in the Atlantic Ocean. Tracked by satellite in the open ocean, the turtles traveled 124 to 2,672 miles and stayed mainly near the surface.

title: American Express to Sell Half of Its Business Travel Arm for $900 Million
description: American Express said on Monday that it had sold half of its business travel unit to a group of investors that includes the government of Qatar and the money management giant BlackRock for $900 million.

title: Seeking Truth in a Counterfeit
description: Walter Kirns Blood Will Out has a subtitle that bills it as The True Story of a Murder, a Mystery, and a Masquerade. Its got all those things, but it is primarily a tale of seduction. For 15 years, Mr. Kirn allowed himself to fall for the con man then calling himself Clark Rockefeller, certain that if he let their friendship persist, hed find something valuable at the end of the rainbow. There would surely be a book in it, if not a pot of gold.

title: On View | Charting the Real Roots of Minimalist Art
description: Minimalism is generally thought of as one of the apogees of 20th-century Western high culture. In fact, the movement known for its pure forms and vibrant colors did not originate solely in the United States and Western Europe, but simultaneously in countries throughout the world, especially the southern hemisphere. The new exhibition Other Primary Structures at the Jewish Museum gathers Minimalist 1960s sculpture by artists from Asia, Africa, the Middle East, Eastern Europe and especially Latin America, all of which were made before or at the same time as similar work in the Western art world.

title: A Beauty and a Beast, but This Ones for Adults
description: Grown-ups of New York, are you ready to be told the best bedtime story youve heard since you were a credulous tyke? Its called Beauty and the Beast. And yeah, I know what youre thinking: Youve heard that one before; your daughter made you watch the Disney movie with her like 28 times; and if you wanted something more sophisticated, youd just slip on your digitally enhanced edition of Jean Cocteaus La Belle et La Bte from 1946.

title: Flamenco Proves Contagious for the Ear and for the Eye
description: If you put any faith in the notion of mirror neurons with regard to listening  the theory that an empathic region of your brain can make you experience the neural impulse to play the notes that you are hearing someone else play  then you may have been very interested in Tomatitos performance at Rose Theater on Saturday night.

title: Returning to the Roots of His Roots
description: Three and a half years ago, Skrillex released Scary Monsters and Nice Sprites (mau5trap/Big Beat), the EP that would transform him from a onetime post-hardcore singer who dabbled in producing electronic music to the savior of dance music in this country. He did it with a particularly mean stripe of dubstep  dirty, aggressive and sometimes grating  that ignored subtlety and demanded dancing with pneumatic intensity, sometimes in complete ignorance of the beat.

title: Acquiring Status as Big as Their Robots
description: Video game designers may be the worlds most anonymous creative professionals, at least among the makers of mass entertainment. Thats because game players tend to extend their loyalty to favorite franchises or proven studios rather than to individual designers.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and More
description: Ukraine and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: The Ukraine Crisis and U.S. Policy
His Fertility Advance Draws Ire
description: BEAVERTON, ORE.  To most people, the word mitochondria is only dimly familiar, the answer to a test question in some bygone high-school biology class. But to Shoukhrat Mitalipov, the mysterious power producers inside every human cell are a lifelong obsession.

title: Vienna Love Fest Comes to Sober and Sassy End
description: By now, you might have heard already about the momentous conductor substitution that transpired over the weekend at Carnegie Hall, when the Vienna Philharmonic returned for the last two events of the Vienna: City of Dreams festival. No, not the one Saturday night, when Christoph Eschenbach memorably filled in for an injured Daniele Gatti. Im talking about Sunday, when, at the end of a long program, Zubin Mehta ceded his baton to the soprano Diana Damrau.

title: The Pianist Teaches, Too
description: I will tell you the story of the piano, said Olivier Cav before his recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon. His engaging commentary highlighted the connections among works by Lodovico Giustini, Bach, Scarlatti and Clementi featured on the thoughtful program, called Il Pianoforte Italiano.

title: A Growth Spurt at 1,500 Years Old
description: Signy Island, which lies 375 miles off Antarctica, has too harsh an environment to support a single tree. Its mountains are girdled instead by banks of moss.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Ukraine, China, Afghanistan and Israel.

title: Sleepwalker With Love Trouble Avoids a Rude Awakening
description: The German soprano Diana Damrau balanced on the window ledge of a building high above the streets of Manhattan in the Act II sleepwalking scene of Bellinis Sonnambula, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening in Mary Zimmermans modern-dress production.

title: Tuning in to an Earlier Time, When Moving Was Easy
description: It helps that the seven dancers who were performing this weekend with Kyle Abraham/Abraham.In.Motion at the 92nd Street Y were all good-looking, well dressed, well lighted and very good movers. The work in which they appeared, Mr. Abrahams Radio Show, featured deliberate ambiguities and tensions that, with other performers, could have easily turned it into a quite different piece. These dancers are so appealing that youre on their side from the first.

title: Comment
description: WIRED WELL

title: Murdoch Urges Irish to Boycott Guinness Over Its Embrace of Gay Rights
description: Responding to the news that Guinness had withdrawn its sponsorship of the St. Patricks Day Parade in New York over the continued exclusion of gay groups from the festivities, Rupert Murdoch called on the people of Ireland and their cousins in the diaspora to retaliate by boycotting the beer.

title: A Conversation With Steve Jurvetson, Space Investor and Rocket Maker
description: Steve Jurvetson is a partner at Draper Fisher Jurvetson, a Menlo Park, Calif., venture capital firm that has invested in SpaceX, Tesla Motors and Planet Labs, a satellite company we profiled in Mondays newspaper.

title: State Senate Rejects Bill Granting Tuition Aid to Illegal Immigrants
description: ALBANY  In a surprise vote, the New York State Senate on Monday rejected legislation that would have granted state tuition aid to undocumented immigrants, dealing a blow to immigrants advocates who had made it their top priority in the capital.

title: Enough Wine to Last
description: To the Editor:

title: A Single June Primary
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Money in London
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgeon General Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: More Diversity in School
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chicken Miracle
description: To the Editor:

title: An Inside View of Arab Photography
description: Samer Mohdad was once told that Arab photography did not exist. This week he is part of an ambitious showcase of contemporary Arab photography at Houston FotoFest.

title: The Razors Edge
description: A trip to the local barbershop, from Beijing to Beirut, gives one man an entree into the customs and people of each country he visits  as well as a smooth shave.

title: Cardinal Dolan to Lobby for Tax Credit That Rewards Donations to Education
description: A proposal to create a state tax credit for donations to public schools and nonprofit scholarship funds is gathering steam in Albany and turning the archbishop of New York, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, into something of a lobbyist.

title: A Classical Composer in a Contemporary World
description: ENJOYING business travel has been the most delightful surprise. Im a contemporary classical music composer, dividing my time between New York City and Cambridge, England, and am currently working on projects with the Dutch National Ballet, Washington Chorus and Sydney Dance Company, among others.

title: How to Profit Modestly by Moving to a Nonprofit
description: WHEN he was 5 years old, Steven Elson built pretend skyscrapers out of blocks. It was the start of a love affair with buildings.

title: What Color Is Your Online Adult Course?
description: AS part of the latest wave of online learning platforms, Massive Online Open Courses (Moocs) have gone viral. They can be useful for certain students, although those interested in changing or enhancing their careers should consider their more intensive sister, distance learning.

title: A Degree Where Techie Meets Business Smarts
description: DANIEL BRISKER, who graduated in 2009 with an undergraduate degree in biology, likes his job at MedImmune, a Maryland biotechnology company, where he grows and harvests cell cultures, but he also wanted to enhance his professional credentials. So he went back to school for a professional science masters degree  what some are calling a science M.B.A., a degree combining science knowledge with business skills.

title: New Health Law Is Sending Many Back to School
description: PROFESSIONAL development classes constantly need to adapt to new realities, and that is especially true now in health care management, with the Affordable Care Act changing the rules for patients, managers, doctors and other health workers.

title: Culinary Schools Speed the Rise of Hopeful Chefs
description: WHEN Rob Anderson decided last year to pursue a longtime passion for food and open a restaurant in Provincetown, Mass., he left behind a job as an opinion page editor at The Boston Globe and enrolled in the six-month culinary arts program at the International Culinary Center in New Yorks SoHo neighborhood.

title: Many Adults Falling Short of Degrees
description: TWO and a half years ago, Kristine Rose enrolled full time at Mount Holyoke College and crammed her belongings into a 12-foot-square room.

title: Earning Their Stripes as Umpires and Referees
description: In 2012, when David Martinez left a job teaching math at a high school in Bayonne, N.J., to try to become a professional baseball umpire, he understood that the numbers might not add up.

title: For Aztecs Leader, Court Is No Place to Run Scared
description: SAN DIEGO  The story had to be pulled out of Xavier Thames.

title: More Information for Women Looking to Get Back in the Work Force
description: How can women prepare for returning to work after taking a career break to care for children or aging parents? As we reported in the article, New Programs Help Women Get Back In The Game, a growing number of re-entry programs are now being offered to professional women on Wall Street and at big law firms. Explaining a career gap on a rsum is not the only challenge women face. We asked Michelle Friedman, Ann Blinkhorn, Carol Fishman Cohen and Vivian Steir Rabin, who specialize in career development, to share their best job search tips and resources. In addition, Ms. Cohen and Ms. Rabin answered questions from New York Times readers on The Motherlode blog. They are the authors of Back on the Career Track and founders of iRelaunch.com, which provides extensive resources for women looking to navigate their way back to work.

title: Helping Women Get Back in the Game
description: Andrea Chermayeff planned to go back to work when the youngest of her four children enrolled in school last fall. With a Harvard M.B.A. and experience at a private equity firm, she had the credentials to return to Wall Street. The only problem was explaining a 15-year gap on her rsum.

title: In Eastern Ukraine, the Curtain Goes Up, and the Clash Begins
description: KHARKIV, Ukraine  The opponents arrived in the citys center and prepared for the coming scuffle with ritualized familiarity.

title: Triangle Offense Has Its Defenders and Skeptics
description: People tend to listen when Phil Jackson talks, or tweets, even in August, traditionally the N.B.A.s tune-out season.

title: Rescued Puppies in Gambling Haven Steal Hearts
description: LAS VEGAS  Las Vegas enjoys its reputation as a Sybaritic town, with its heady blend of sparkle, sex and money. It celebrates its history of organized crime with a Mob Museum championed by a former mayor.

title: German Firms Sale to Russians Draws Fire
description: BERLIN  The announcement of a preliminary German-Russian energy deal sparked criticism on Monday from at least one leading conservative in Germany, who suggested it sent the wrong message as the West was imposing sanctions on Russia for its occupation of Crimea.

title: Reader Comments and Questions: Helping the Stay-at-Home Parent (and More) Get Back in the Game
description: Were looking for questions from people looking to rejoin the work force after taking a family-related break, and stories from women and men who have successfully returned to the game. Ask and share here, in the comments, and well come back with expert answers later in the week. Ask todaywell close questions by the end of the day Wednesday, March 19, 2014 in order to give our experts time to respond.

title: Like That Vase on the TV? Click Your Phone to Buy It
description: ABOUT 87 percent of Americans watch television while using devices like smartphones and tablets, but most of that second-screen usage is unrelated to the show or movie, according to the NPD Group, a market research company.

title: The Rangers Scoring Slump Includes the Player Acquired to Lift the Offense
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Martin St. Louis won the N.H.L. scoring title last season with Tampa Bay and had 61 points in 62 games for the Lightning this season. But he has no goals and two assists in seven games since coming to the Rangers in a blockbuster trade March 5, and he is trying not to be weighed down by his lack of production.

title: Deterioration in U.S.-Russian Relations May Disrupt Coming Talks With Iran
description: PARIS  Tensions between the West and Russia over events in Ukraine have cast a shadow over the second round of talks set to begin on Tuesday in Vienna on a permanent nuclear agreement with Iran.

title: Letter From Nakamoto on Bitcoin Claim
description: I did not create, invent or otherwise work on Bitcoin, Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto said. I unconditionally deny the Newsweek report.

title: CNNs Coverage of Malaysia Flight 370
description: A selection of clips from CNNs nonstop coverage of the mystery surrounding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: CNNs Ratings Surge Covering the Mystery of the Missing Airliner
description: On CNN, the plane rises from misty clouds accompanied by an eerie background score while anchors offer intriguing details  some new, some days old  of the disappearance of Flight 370. The reports, broadcast continually, often are augmented by speculation  sometimes fevered, sometimes tempered  about where the flight might have come to rest. And viewers are eating it up.

title: Tesla Fights for a Place to Park
description: Tesla Motors, the maker of high-end all-electric cars, has made no secret of its ambitions to transform the auto industry, through methods ranging from the radical design of its cars to its free network of charging stations to repairing its sedans remotely by computer. But now, Teslas lofty goals have run into a more ordinary roadblock: the ubiquitous local auto dealer.

title: A Culture Change Is Coming to the Garden
description: Phil Jackson played his final game for the Knicks on April 23, 1978, going scoreless off the bench as the Philadelphia 76ers closed out a four-game sweep in the Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: Hedge Fund Spars With a Nameless Blogger
description: Who was the leaker?

title: How Missing Jets Debris Could Have Floated to Runion
description: This animation shows where floating debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 could have drifted if experts are correct about where the plane went down.

title: The Unlikely Road to War
description: A 19-year-old Ukrainian nationalist from a remote farming village, raised on stories of his familys suffering during Stalins great engineered famine, embittered by Moscows long imperialist dominion, enraged by the slaying of a fellow student in Kiev during the uprising of 2014, convinced any price is worth paying to stop the Russian annexation of Crimea, takes the long road to Sevastopol.

title: Clarissa Dickson Wright, Rebel TV Chef in Two Fat Ladies, Dies at 66
description: Clarissa Dickson Wright, who rose to middle-aged fame as the co-star and co-chef of Two Fat Ladies, a popular British television show known as much for the hosts irreverence and eccentricity as for their indulgent and sometimes confounding recipes, died on Saturday in Edinburgh. She was 66.

title: G.M. Saw Cobalt as Its Entry Into a Better Small-Car Market
description: When the Chevrolet Cobalt, now at the center of a recall of 1.6 million cars, was being engineered more than a decade ago, executives at General Motors saw it as the beginning of a new era at the automaker.

title: Bond Insurer Files Suit Against Detroit in Setback for Bankruptcy Plan
description: A bond insurer on Monday struck a blow against Detroits proposal to exit bankruptcy, arguing in a new lawsuit that Detroits approach would illegally discriminate against the citys third-biggest group of creditors  the investors who provided $1.4 billion for its workers pensions nearly a decade ago.

title: Italy Divided Over Rail Line Meant to Unite
description: CHIOMONTE, Italy  To get to the site of an exploratory tunnel now being bored into Italys northwestern Alps, visitors must first pass through a police checkpoint, then a military one. Tall fences topped with barbed wire roll along the mountainside. Armored vehicles cross paths with jeeps on winding roads lined by vineyards.

title: Weighing My Words
description: As a child, I had a relatively unusual speech impediment: I couldnt form the sounds sh, j or ch properly, and this made a large swath of words difficult to pronounce. The word just would come out sounding like chust or shust; double-whammy words like church never emerged cleanly even if I squared myself and took a good run at them; if I said that I was a Jew someone in earshot might call out gesundheit! (everybodys a comedian), and I dreaded having to speak my own name. An adults uncomprehending Can you say that again? was a staple of my life.

title: How Cities Change
description: Shavar Jeffries was born in Newark in 1975, the son of a 19-year-old mother who was unprepared to take care of him. He spent the first nine years of his life shuttling between different relatives. Then his mother came back into his life and moved him to California.

title: In Armys Second N.C.A.A. Bid, a Bittersweet Connection to the First
description: Before the N.C.A.A. womens tournament bracket was revealed Monday night, Army Coach Dave Magarity could not predict the Black Knights seed. He did not seem to care, either. All that mattered was that they were in the tournament.

title: Foreign Investors in Russia Vital to Sanctions Debate
description: As the United States and Europe move to punish Russia for its conduct in Ukraine and Crimea with official sanctions, a subtle approach could prove more powerful: pressuring large global investors to reduce their sizable holdings in Russia.

title: Prosecutors Argue Against Allowing 9/11 Masterminds Testimony
description: Federal prosecutors asked a judge on Monday to deny a request by defense lawyers to allow a jury to hear testimony from Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed organizer of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: A Broken Military Justice System
description: On Monday, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey Sinclair avoided prosecution on sexual assault charges that could have brought him a life sentence. In an agreement with the prosecutor, General Sinclair pleaded guilty to lesser charges, including mistreating his accuser, an Army captain and his former mistress.

title: Fitting the New Managerial Mold
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  The desk sits in the same spot as ever, on a blue carpet decorated with orange paw prints, facing the Ty Cobb portrait. But while Jim Leyland wielded Marlboros in his morning session with reporters at spring training, Brad Ausmus, his successor as the manager of the Detroit Tigers, does not.

title: The Women's Bracket
description: TK

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 18, 2014
description: This is a signal from the very earliest universe, sending a telegram encoded in gravitational waves.

title: Plan for Affordable Housing in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  As many cities look for ways to house their neediest residents, officials here on Monday announced a plan to increase this citys stock of affordable housing by using tax incentives and bond proceeds to redevelop 1,500 vacant, city-owned properties over the next two to three years.

title: Lowering the Deadly Cost of Drug Abuse
Three Years of Strife and Cruelty Puts Syria in Free Fall
description: BEIRUT  Day after day, the Syrian civil war has ground down a cultural and political center of the Middle East, turning it into a stage for disaster and cruelty on a nearly incomprehensible scale. Families are brutalized by their government and by jihadists claiming to be their saviors as nearly half of Syrians  many of them children  have been driven from their homes.

title: G.O.P. House Members Plan Tour to Test Alternatives on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Senior House Republicans  struggling to find consensus for health care legislation to replace the Affordable Care Act  are planning to test ideas in April at town-hall-style meetings that could provide a path toward a long-promised alternative to President Obamas signature legislative achievement.

title: Beltran Fights Off Slumps With a Bat at His Bedside
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  There are people who keep a baseball bat next to their beds to fend off potential intruders. Carlos Beltran does so to fend off bad thoughts that have invaded his mind. The thoughts that will follow him home from the ballpark, lying dormant while he is with his family.

title: A Parade Goes On Without the Mayor
Government Sends Soldiers to a Protest Site in Caracas
description: The government on Monday deployed hundreds of soldiers in a part of Caracas where weeks of often violent protests have taken place, and a top official boasted that the area had been liberated.

title: Corrections: March 18, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: World War I Novel
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  David Kwong is two people: he is both magician and puzzle constructor. At his very best, he combines the two, and today is a very nice example of that.

title: Evicted, a Hoarder Clears Out
description: It was only after he was given notice of eviction that Kevin McCrary, a hoarder on the Upper East Side, took on the challenge of emptying his apartment.

title: New York City F.C. Coach Learning Manchester Way
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Jason Kreis is a coach by trade, but for now, he has enrolled in a kind of soccer boot camp in Manchester, England.

title: Suit Alleges Developer Violated Civil Rights
description: Manhattans top federal prosecutor filed a civil rights lawsuit Monday against Related Companies, one of New York Citys most prolific builders, charging that the developer had violated the Fair Housing Act by discriminating against disabled tenants in the design of two apartment buildings.

title: The Rescued Puppies
description: Video of puppies who were rescued from a Las Vegas pet store fire.

title: The Gun Lobbys Latest Bizarre Crusade
description: The National Rifle Association has mounted an outrageous campaign to torpedo President Obamas nomination of an outstanding young doctor to be the next surgeon general of the United States because of his attitudes on gun control. The sad part is, the campaign is causing some nervous Democrats whose votes may be needed for Senate confirmation to consider breaking with the president to bolster their own chances for re-election in states where the gun lobby is powerful.

title: Final Victim of Blast Is Identified
description: The police on Monday identified the final victim who was killed in a gas explosion that leveled two buildings in East Harlem last week.

title: Geometry Lesson
description: The triangle offense, which relies on precise spacing to spread out the defense, was at the core of numerous N.B.A. championships won by the Chicago Bulls and the Los Angeles Lakers under Phil Jackson, who will now try to straighten out the Knicks. So the triangle may be coming to New York, and here is a sampling of how it works.

title: After a Final Challenge, Election Officials Declare a Winner in El Salvador
description: After election officials turned aside complaints of fraud in the March 9 presidential election, Salvador Snchez Cern, 69, a former leftist guerrilla commander in the countrys 12-year civil war, was officially declared the victor on Sunday night. Mr. Snchez Cern, of the Farabundo Mart National Liberation Front, will take office on June 1, becoming the first former rebel commander to rise to the presidency. He defeated Norman Quijano, the candidate of the National Republican Alliance, by 6,364 votes, winning 50.1 percent of the three million votes that were cast. Late Sunday, election officials rejected a petition by the National Republican Alliance, or Arena, to annul the results of the election. Mr. Snchez Cern has promised to govern as a moderate and help reconcile a nation heavily divided since the end of the civil war in 1992.

title: Nets Miss Garnett but Keep Winning Without Him
description: Life these days without Kevin Garnett has seemed remarkably easy for the Nets and their fans to tolerate. It has been an unexpected but hugely welcome surprise because he may not be returning any time soon.

title: Malaysia Backtracks on When Airliners Communications Were Disabled
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  As the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 stretched into a 10th day, the Malaysian authorities on Monday identified the planes first officer as the last person in the cockpit to speak to ground control. But the government added to the confusion about what happened during those key minutes by withdrawing its assertion that the radio signoff had come after a crucial communications system was disabled.

title: Hoarder Meets Clean-Out Deadline, Exchanging Key for Check
description: At 11 a.m. on Monday, Jeffrey Weber, the managing agent for 344 East 65th Street, walked into Apt. 4D and looked around in amazement.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 17
description: March 17, 2014

title: Pilots Possible Role in Flight 370 Vanishing Unthinkable to Friends
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  One was only a few years out of flight school and still living at home with his family, but he was getting serious about a girlfriend, another pilot, and talking about getting married.

title: Ex-Official Tells of Cash and Refrigerators as Bribes
description: There were the trips to Jamaica, Paris and Greece, and a townhouse in Strivers Row in Harlem  not to mention the cash.

title: Tension Is Growing as Families of Flight 370 Passengers Hold Vigil
description: BEIJING  The families gathered in the ballroom at the Lido Hotel wanted answers. Over a week ago, a jet carrying their loved ones vanished, and for a week the airline executives who appeared before them told different, sometimes contradictory, stories.

title: In the New York Senate, Playing a Game of Legislative Fantasy
description: The State Senate leadership, that happy band of Republicans and sort-of Democrats, pushed through its proposed budget resolution early Friday morning and could not help clapping at its cleverness.

title: Times Minute | Is Saturated Fat So Bad?
description: Also on the Minute, General Motors issues a recall for 1.7 million vehicles and rethinking the American public school.

title: Times Minute | Is Saturated Fat So Bad?
description: In the Video

title: Where to Find Nuggets of Data in the Budget
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Word of the Day | cascade
description: cascade\()kas-kad\ noun and verb

title: Samuel W. Lewis, Shuttling Diplomat in Mideast Peace Pact, Dies at 83
description: Samuel W. Lewis, a former American ambassador to Israel, whose tenure spanned the administrations of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan and the delicate negotiations between Israel and Egypt that led to the Camp David accords, died on March 10 at his home in McLean, Va. He was 83.

title: Scientists Sound Alarm on Climate
description: Early in his career, a scientist named Mario J. Molina was pulled into seemingly obscure research about strange chemicals being spewed into the atmosphere. Within a year, he had helped discover a global environmental emergency, work that would ultimately win a Nobel Prize.

title: Walmart to Offer Customers Credit for Used Video Games
description: Walmart Stores has a proposition for anyone with copies of Call of Duty and other old video games lying around the house: Trade them in for store credit to spend on other items.

title: Joseph Fan Zhongliang, Underground Bishop of Shanghai, Dies at 95
description: Bishop Joseph Fan Zhongliang, who was imprisoned for more than two decades for resisting a Chinese crackdown on religion and spent his final years under house arrest after Pope John Paul II named him bishop of Shanghai, died on Sunday at his home in Shanghai. He was 95.

title: A Campaign Inquiry in Utah Is the Watchdogs Worst Case
description: It is the nightmare scenario for those who worry that the modern campaign finance system has opened up new frontiers of political corruption: A candidate colludes with wealthy corporate backers and promises to defend their interests if elected. The companies spend heavily to elect the candidate, but hide the money by funneling it through a nonprofit group. And the main purpose of the nonprofit appears to be getting the candidate elected.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (FOX) GLEE Gleeks, rejoice  the seriess 100th episode will unite current and former New Directions members to perform remixes of the top 10 songs from the past five seasons. Popular guests also reprise their roles, including Kristin Chenoweth as April Rhodes and Gwyneth Paltrow as Holly Holliday; Chace Crawford makes an appearance as a new character, Biff McIntosh. In New Girl, at 9, Jess (Zooey Deschanel) and Cece (Hannah Simone) are invited to a party given by the musician Prince. And in Brooklyn Nine-Nine, at 9:30, Jake (Andy Samberg) uses his weekend off to try to crack a cold case.

title: 5 Million Have Enrolled for Coverage Under Health Law, White House Says
description: The White House said Monday that more than five million people had signed up for private health insurance under President Obamas health care law, an increase of about 800,000 in the last two weeks. Marilyn B. Tavenner, the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said that some consumers were obtaining insurance for just $22 a month. The six-month open enrollment period ends on March 31, and Philip M. Schiliro, a health care adviser at the White House, said the final enrollment numbers would be better than many people anticipate.

title: March Randomness: The Bracket Picks
description: The Times turned to a math professor, a random coin toss, and the four stars of the Broadway musical Matilda for help filling out brackets for the 2014 N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: China Rules Out Terror Ties Among Citizens on Jet
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner spread out across an expanded area nearly the size of the continental United States, the Chinese government said on Tuesday that it had ruled out the possibility that any of the Chinese citizens on the plane  about two-thirds of the 227 passengers  were terrorists, separatists or malcontents who might have tried to hijack or destroy it.

title: Reading, Writing and Renewal (the Urban Kind)
description: BALTIMORE  In many ways, public schools are gated communities, dead zones. Theyre shuttered after dark and during the summer, open to parents and students while in session but not to the larger community.

title: Pet Store Surveillance Video
description: Security video showed a woman letting a man in through the back door, who then splashed a liquid from two gas cans around the shop, even into the cages.

title: The Mathematician vs. the Matildas
description: A math professor from Davidson College and four young girls from the Broadway show Matilda the Musical share how they chose their brackets for the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Plenty of Ways to Try for a Billion-Dollar Prize
description: It is a rite of spring  a pencil, a bracket, a few bucks invested in a pool in the pursuit of picking the Final Four teams and, eventually, the last one standing in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament. None of us have dreamed of filling out the perfect bracket, mostly because obsessing over that feat would be weird, and the odds of actually doing so are essentially impossible: 9,223,372,036,854,775,808 (thats 9.223 quintillion) to 1.

title: Trying Their Luck
description: A floating casino now takes visitors to the island of Bimini, which developers are trying to turn into a new gambling and marina destination.

title: School Inspections Ordered After New Reports of Drugging Children
description: Updated, 4:30 a.m. ET| The Education Ministry and the National Health and Family Planning Commission have ordered thorough, one-by-one inspections of all kindergartens and schools in China to determine if they have been administering antiviral drugs to children, Peoples Daily online and other major news media reported on Wednesday.

title: Test Yourself | History, March 18
description: Take the Quiz

title: European Car Sales Extend Fragile Recovery
description: PARIS  Sales of European passenger cars continued their feeble recovery in February for the sixth straight month, according to an industry report on Tuesday.

title: South Korea Prepares to Return Chinese Soldiers Remains
description: South Korea plans to repatriate the remains of more than 400 Chinese soldiers killed during the Korean War, a sign of warming ties between the two countries and Chinas increasing focus on remembering its war dead.

title: Putin Reclaims Crimea for Russia and Bitterly Denounces the West
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin reclaimed Crimea as a part of Russia on Tuesday, reversing what he described as a historic injustice inflicted by the Soviet Union 60 years ago and brushing aside international condemnation that could leave Russia isolated for years to come.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Undercover Reports on School Security Raise Ethical Questions
description: In Undercover TV Reports on School Security Raise Ethical Questions, John Eligon writes about recent attempts by news organizations to test school security measures. In Seeking Expos, Students End Up in Handcuffs, a June 2013 article, Al Baker writes about a similar undercover attempt by student journalists.

title: An Inside View of Arab Photography
description: Samer Mohdad was a 10-year-old boy living in the mountain village of his Druse ancestors when Lebanons civil war broke out in 1975. His life changed overnight: His childhood playmates were now his sworn enemies. The traumatic experience of the war, which lasted until 1990, stayed with him and, Mr. Mohdad believes, eventually led him to photography.

title: Should the School Day Start Later?
description: Could letting teenagers sleep later in the morning do more than just make them happy? New evidence suggests that a later start to the school day could have all sorts of benefits, like better grades and fewer car crashes. But some worry that pushing the school day back might get in the way of after-school sports and jobs, and wouldnt leave students enough time to finish homework.

title: Devin Alberda of the New York City Ballet: Behind the Curtain
description: Last weekends magazine features photographs from the New York City Ballet dancer Devin Alberdas Instagram account, @dalberda, which gives his followers an intimate, behind-the-scenes look at the ballet. Alberda started his ballet training at age 4 and has performed with the New York City Ballet for nine years. Gabrielle Plucknette, the magazines photography assistant, interviewed him about the strains and joys of dancing professionally while capturing images backstage.

title: New York Today: Play (Brrr!) Ball
description: Good Tuesday morning to you. It is 32 degrees.

title: Scania Panel Recommends Rejecting Volkswagen Offer
description: Updated, 8:45 a.m. | LONDON  A committee of Scanias independent directors said Tuesday that shareholders should reject Volkswagens offer to take full control of the Swedish truck maker because the offer undervalues the company.

title: West Sees Unity on Iran Despite Crisis in Ukraine
description: VIENNA  Talks on a permanent nuclear agreement with Iran resumed in Vienna on Tuesday, heavily shadowed by the Ukraine crisis between the West and Russia. But European and American officials said their differences with the Kremlin had no effect on the unified position they all take aimed at ensuring the Iranians can never make atomic bombs.

title: Pakistans Culture Wars
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  On the banks of the luminous China Creek, overlooking old mangrove swamps and the shipping cranes at the port, more than 50,000 people flocked to this years Karachi Literature Festival, held annually in February when the flowers bloom, the weather is temperate and the city feels alive with possibility.

title: A Safe Place for Unwanted Babies Is Overwhelmed
description: So many babies poured into a government-run baby hatch in the southern city of Guangzhou after it opened in January that the overwhelmed institution has had to stop taking in any more.

title: Edinburgh International Festival Announces Lineup
description: LONDONTo help commemorate the centenary of the First World War, the relationship between culture and conflict is the broad theme of this years Edinburgh International Festival, the director Jonathan Mills announced on Tuesday.

title: Crimea Challenges U.S. Foreign Policy
description: It might be time for another change in direction.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 16 in Northern Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber in northern Afghanistan detonated explosives packed into a rickshaw Tuesday morning, killing at least 16 people at a bazaar in the latest major attack ahead of presidential elections early next month.

title: Hertz to Spin Off Rental Equipment Business
description: Updated, 8:00 a.m. | The Hertz Corporation said on Tuesday that it would spin off its equipment rental corporation, a move that would give the remaining company net proceeds of $2.5 billion.

title: Bidder for Long Island College Hospital Has Checkered Record in Role of Rescuer
description: Seven years before its emergence as a possible savior for Long Island College Hospital, which has been on the verge of closing for almost a year, a Brooklyn development group was expected to play a similar role for a hospital in New Jersey.

title: A Conversation With Yukari Kane, Author of Haunted Empire: Apple After Steve Jobs
description: More than two years after the death of Steven P. Jobs, Apple has continued to rake in huge profits with record sales of iPhones and iPads. But despite Apples ever-growing mountain of cash, some doubt the companys success will continue without its visionary leader, whose unwavering obsession with quality helped make its products great and innovative.

title: Starting Up Is Hard to Do
description: Twelve months ago, we introduced Posse, a social search engine that helps users get recommendations for products, places and services from their friends. I prepared for this by attending every start-up conference I could, by reading books and learning concepts. But nothing prepared me for the challenges I have faced in the past year.

title: Intersection: Delhis Indo-Western Style
description: Hauz Khas Village is where monuments dating to the 13th century meet fashion boutiques. In this happening neighborhood in New Delhi, Indians embrace a mix of traditional and Western styles.

title: German Court Validates Participation in Euro Zone Bailout Fund
description: FRANKFURT  Germanys highest court ruled on Tuesday that the countrys government may participate in a fund set up to help financially stricken countries in the euro zone.

title: New U.S. Ambassador to China Gets a Fast Start
description: The new American ambassador to China, Max Baucus, got off to a fast start on his first day on the job in Beijing. Early Tuesday, he visited the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to present a copy of his credentials, a formality that allowed him to meet with journalists at the United States Embassy in the afternoon.

title: Many Cars Are Green, but Only a Few Can Be Called Irish
description: Irelands most significant contribution to automotive history may have been genealogical: Henry Fords father was an Irish immigrant, and in 1917 the automaker, already wildly successful, reconnected with his roots by opening a factory in Cork. Although the plant closed in 1984, Henry Ford & Sons still operates there as a sales enterprise for Ford Motor.

title: Chinas Rapid Growth Hits the Brakes
description: HONG KONG  New pockets of economic weakness in China emerged on Tuesday, as the collapse of a highly indebted real estate developer and weak home sales pointed to a slowdown in the sprawling property sector.

title: Afghan Leader Picks Ex-Resistance Figure as Deputy
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Moving to preserve the political and ethnic balance at the top of his government, President Hamid Karzai on Tuesday nominated a prominent former Northern Alliance figure to fill the vice-presidential post left vacant by the death of Muhammad Qasim Fahim last week.

title: Taking Aim at an Anonymous Blogger
description: It may seem as though David Einhorn, the outspoken hedge fund manager, wants to have his cake and eat it, too. After an anonymous blogger on the website Seeking Alpha leaked one of his firms investments  a stake in Micron Technology  Mr. Einhorns firm, Greenlight Capital, asked a court to force the website to identify the writer by name. If Mr. Einhorn  a longtime champion of transparency when he singles out companies and other market participants  were to win, the result could limit the free flow of information to traditional news outlets and require sites like Seeking Alpha to not publish anonymous contributions, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

title: In Poland, Biden Promises Allies Protection
description: WARSAW  Citing the need for friends to stand with one another, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. reassured Poland and the Baltic states on Tuesday that the United States would protect them from any Russian aggression like the actions the Kremlin has taken in Crimea.

title: Sergeant Friday Was Not A Fox
description: The new FiveThirtyEight is up, and Tyler Cowen is not impressed. Im sorry to say that I had the same reaction. Heres hoping that Nate Silver and company up their game, soon.

title: In Performance: Steven Boyer (and Tyrone) of Hand to God
description: This weeks video features the actor Steven Boyer  with the puppet Tyrone  in a scene from Robert Askinss dark comedy Hand to God. Mr. Boyer plays Jason, a troubled Texas teenager who discovers that his hand puppet is possessed by evil. In this scene, Jason and Tyrone discuss what it means to have devilish thoughts. The show, which Charles Isherwood called a terrific, scary-funny play, continues through March 30 at the Lucille Lortel Theater, in an MCC production.

title: Close but Not Quite
description: In careful writing, its not enough to know the general meaning of a word. Precise usage requires knowing exactly how a word should fit into a sentence. Is it typically used with a preposition, and if so, which one? Is a verb transitive  used with a direct object  or intransitive?

title: Daily Report: Airlines Use Wearables to Get More Personal
description: At a time when many airline innovations  like charging extra for an aisle seat or cutting back on frequent flier benefits  might anger more than amaze, carriers like Virgin Atlantic and Qantas are using wearable devices and other technology to get closer to their customers, Nicola Clark reports.

title: Dependence on Russia Is Likely to Leave Regions Economy in a Precarious State
description: YALTA, Crimea  Many A.T.M.s in this sun-dappled seaside resort city in Crimea, and across the region, have been empty in recent days, with little white transaction denied slips piling up around them. Banks that do have cash have been imposing severe restrictions on withdrawals.

title: Paris Opera Ballet Wins Jerome Robbins Award
description: The Jerome Robbins Award, an annual acknowledgement of excellence in the arts, will go this year to the Paris Opera Ballet, the Jerome Robbins Foundation announced on Tuesday. The award, worth $50,000, has previously gone to Mikhail Baryshnikov, Robert Wilson, Jennifer Tipton, Stephen Sondheim and the New York City Ballet, among others. It will be presented to Brigitte Lefvre, the director of the Paris Opera Ballet, on June 19 at the Palais Garnier in Paris.

title: I.M.F. Official to Fill New Oversight Post at Bank of England
description: LONDON  As part of an effort to improve its oversight, the Bank of England said on Tuesday that a senior member of the International Monetary Fund would join the central bank later this year in a newly created position to supervise markets and banking.

title: India to Appeal Milan Ruling in Canceled Helicopter Deal
description: NEW DELHI  India said Tuesday that it would appeal a Milan courts ruling that denied the country 278 million euros, or $387 million, in bank guarantees in a helicopter deal that was canceled after top officials at AgustaWestland and its Italian parent,Finmeccanica, were arrested on bribery charges last year.

description: The New York Observer rose to prominence as a salmon pink, broadsheet newspaper. Starting Wednesday, when a wholesale redesign begins, it will be white, tabloid-size and stapled like a magazine.

description: The notion of a world class striker using a move to Major League Soccer as a path to the World Cup might seem far-fetched to some, but it made perfect sense to Jermain Defoe.

title: 45 Years After Woodstock, New Hudson River Festival Is Announced
description: Nearly 45 years after Woodstock, a new festival is going up the country  or, at least, up the Hudson River  to bring a three-day weekends worth of music to the New York area. The Hudson Project, a new music and arts festival promising more than 85 musical acts, will make its debut this year from July 11 through 13, and will be held at the Winston Farm in Saugerties, N.Y., its organizers said on Tuesday. The Hudson Project promises four stages worth of performances  musicians were not immediately disclosed but are expected to be announced next week  as well as an emphasis on local arts and crafts; gourmet food, wine and beer; and a wide range of camping choices from top-level luxury accommodations, according to a news release.

title: What Would Scott Brown Do?
description: In case you werent keeping track  dont worry, that was a joke!  Scott Brown, the short-time Massachusetts senator and shorter-time political celebrity, has relocated to New Hampshire, where he might run for the Senate again. This speculation has been especially rampant among media types who have been tracking such nitty-gritty as: 1) Browns tweeting about his performance with the band Cheap Trick last month; 2) the former Cosmopolitan centerfolds appearing at a midwinter polar-plunge-type event and having his bare torso reimmortalized, this time on the front page of The New Hampshire Union Leader; and 3) his planning to make a trip to Iowa next month, which would be his third in a year.

title: Beastie Boys and Toy Company Settle Lawsuit Over Ads Use of Girls
description: A San Francisco-area toy company that found itself in a public dispute with the Beastie Boys said on Tuesday that it had reached a settlement with that hip-hop group over its use of the bands song Girls in a popular viral video. In November, the toy company, GoldieBlox, gained widespread attention for a video which showed girls building an elaborate Rube Goldberg device and singing a version of that song with alternate lyrics celebrating their scientific achievements. GoldieBlox filed a lawsuit against the Beastie Boys, asserting its right to use the song in its video; the band countered that the video was an advertisement that is designed to sell a product, and that it does not allow its songs to be used for such purposes. The band filed a copyright infringement suit in December. On Tuesday, a press representative for GoldieBlox said that suit had been settled, adding in a statement: That settlement includes (a) the issuance of an apology by GoldieBlox, which will be posted on GoldieBloxs website, and (b) a payment by GoldieBlox, based on a percentage of its revenues, to one or more charities selected by Beastie Boys that support science, technology, engineering and mathematics education for girls. A press representative for the Beastie Boys confirmed these details of the settlement.

title: Inquiry Into High-Speed Trading Widens
description: Updated, 9:34 p.m. | The New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is expanding his crackdown on the high-frequency traders that dominate financial markets.

title: Barclays Grants $53 Million in Shares to Top Executives
description: LONDON  Barclays has granted nearly 32 million pounds, or about $53 million, in share awards to its top executives this year, the British bank disclosed on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Orders Syrian Embassy and Consulates to Suspend Operations
description: WASHINGTON  The United States formally notified the Syrian government on Tuesday that it must suspend operations at its embassy here and at its consulates in Michigan and Texas, the State Department said.

description: The Knicks introduced Phil Jackson as their new president at a news conference Tuesday morning at Madison Square Garden, where he pledged to be fully committed to the organization and to the tenets of team basketball. He also said that the team had been hindered by a lack of solidarity in recent seasons and that he would work to build better relationships.

The agreement comes just before the two companies were to return to court next week and reflects the changed landscape concerning allegations of copyright violations on the web.

title: 350 Rose Petals Packed Into a Single Jar of Moisturizing Balm
description: Time and time again, multi-use beauty products  a single liquid, stick or powder that can be used on almost any part of the body, travels well and functions as an objet dart on the shelf  attain must-have status. And the new hero in the latest collection from Aerin, the eponymous beauty line from Este Lauders impossibly chic granddaughter, is the superhydrating Rose Balm that seems all but certain to become a cult classic. The extract of over 350 rose petals fills each 0.8-ounce jar of the silky stuff, which nourishes everything from eyes and lips to face and hands without a greasy residue. Aerin used the product as a base for 10 colors of lipsticks in the new Essentials collection so that they feel more like a restorative lip balm  slicking it on smooths the surface of the mouth, leaving the pout soft and dewy-looking  than a traditional pucker paint. If anything, stocking up on these gold-cased gems is motivation to kick into spring cleaning and toss any near-empty tubes of gunk from last season. Aerin Essentials Rose Balm, $58, and Lipstick, $30; aerin.com.

title: Phil Jackson on New Role With Knicks
description: Phil Jackson, the new president of basketball operations for the New York Knicks, spoke about his new job at Madison Square Garden.

title: New Yorks Dream Act Dies
description: The New York State Senate on Monday rejected the Dream Act, which would allow undocumented immigrants to receive state tuition aid. The narrow vote  the bill fell two votes short of passage  was a bitter disappointment to immigrant advocates who had hoped the state would help make college more affordable for Dreamers, young immigrants brought here illegally as children, many of whom are unable to continue their educations once they leave high school.

title: Measles Outbreak May Have Spread in Medical Facilities, a New York City Official Says

title: Pentagon Finds Washington Navy Yard Killings Could Have Been Prevented
description: WASHINGTON  A Defense Department review of the mass shooting that killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard in September has concluded that the deaths could have been prevented if the Navy had properly evaluated and reported alarming behavior by the gunman, Aaron Alexis, a former Navy reservist.

title: High Fallutin Nazis
description: Here comes another billionaire who thinks that anyone who talks about income inequality is a Nazi; this time its Ken Langone, co-founder of Home Depot. I dont have anything useful to say about this, other than the observation that there must be a lot of these guys. I mean, there arent that many billionaires, so that coming up with multiple examples of the genus who not only believe that progressives are just like Hitler but are willing to say so in public must indicate that a substantial proportion of our billionaires share this belief, but more privately. Luckily, great wealth doesnt bring great political influence in modern America  does it?

title: Remembering LWren Scott
description: Like so many, the staff of T was devastated to learn yesterday about the passing of LWren Scott. We celebrate her remarkable life by reaching into our archive for this 2008 Profile in Style, a tribute to the one-of-a-kind designer written by Alex Hawgood, accompanied by this playful high-octane video by the New York design firm Adolescent. She will be deeply missed.

title: If History Is a Guide, Crimeans Celebration May Be Short-Lived
description: ATOTSI, Georgia  As Crimeans danced in the streets this week, giddy at the prospect of being gathered into Russia, few were watching as closely as the residents of the tiny mountainous enclave of South Ossetia, who, five and a half years ago, were similarly ecstatic.

title: Another Cars Movie Is on the Way
description: LOS ANGELES  Robert A. Iger, Disneys chief executive and chairman, offered a few cinematic news nuggets in the early part of the companys annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday. Pixar, which is owned by Disney, is working on a third Cars movie, he said, and Brad Bird, who directed The Incredibles, is working on a story for a sequel to that animated superhero film. (But Mr. Iger notably did not say that Mr. Bird would direct it.)

title: Confirmation of Shake-Up in Chinas Film Industry
description: LOS ANGELES  Even more mysterious than the subterranean power struggles in Hollywood are the hidden currents in Chinas growing film business. But one mystery clarified itself, at least a little, when Asia Film Business on Monday confirmed what had been widely reported for months: Han Sanping has stepped down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company with duties that include the supervision of film imports to China.

title: Inquiry Seeks Port Authority Records That Involve Christie Ally
description: Federal prosecutors in New Jersey issued a subpoena last week to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey seeking records relating to its chairman, David Samson, and contracts on two bridge projects worth $2.8 billion that he voted to award to construction companies with some ties to his law firm, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Blast in Golan Heights Wounds 4 Israeli Soldiers

title: Major Balkan Drug Trafficker Arrested in Serbia, Authorities Say
description: PARIS  Darko Saric, described as being among the most feared and wanted drug traffickers in the Balkans, was arrested in Serbia on Tuesday and charged with smuggling more than five tons of cocaine and laundering at least $30 million as leader of an elaborate drug ring that stretched from South America to western Europe, the Serbian authorities said.

title: Obamas Test: Can Penalties Change Russias Course?

More than two weeks later, Moscow has given no sign that it feels any pain, and the challenge for President Obama is whether he is willing or able to inflict enough to change the Kremlins calculus.
