title: Criminals, All Young, Let Loose Upon Earth
description: The science-fiction series The 100, beginning Wednesday night on CW, is an imagine-the-pitch kind of show. Its Lord of the Flies meets Lost in Space! Or, to put it in terms its target audience might recognize, its The Hunger Games meets Battlestar Galactica, with bits of Terra Nova and Lost thrown in.

title: The White House Pastry Chef Is Moving to a New Kitchen
description: Bill Yosses, the man who made the Hawaiian chocolate-malted ganache for the White House state dinner for France, is now headed to New York with an aim to teach children and adults about eating better, Marian Burros writes in The Times.

title: Dirck the Norseman Opens in Greenpoint
description: Headliner

title: Tales From Tel Aviv and Upper West Side
description: Molly Antopols first book, a collection of stories called The UnAmericans, has poise and gravity. It sometimes put me in mind of Allegra Goodmans work; both writers are adept at auditing the emotional lives of frazzled Jewish intellectuals. At other times, the Old World lefty politics in Ms. Antopols stories summoned the memory of Grace Paley, for whom every joke came wrapped around a bony fist of meaning.

title: Cheese Curds, a Riff on Cronuts, a Paris Ham and More
description: To Munch: Any New Yorker Can Be a Cheesehead

title: Nuzzel Finds the Top Stories in Your Personal Twitterverse
description: Twitter is large and contains multitudes (hat tip to Walt Whitman). Business moguls like Carl Icahn menace corporate bosses on it. Comedians like Jerry Seinfeld crack jokes. Eyewitnesses to riots, invasions and Super Bowl games post live updates as they happen. All told, there are half a billion Twitter messages published every day.

title: Robert Clergerie Steps Out With A.L.C.
description: Those of us who stockpile and eBay-stalk the eccentric, refreshingly comfortable footwear of Robert Clergerie consider ourselves an anti-stiletto sisterhood of sorts. (Call it the Clergerie Club, or simply the Clergy.) One card-carrying member, it turns out, is Andrea Lieberman of A.L.C.The Los Angeles-based designer and stylist has been collecting the brands platforms, oxfords and crepe-soled creepers since she first discovered them in their heyday during the 1990s. That decades favored status in fashion, along with the appointment in 2011 of Roland Mouret as Clergeries artistic director, means that the 33-year-old company is lately having something of a moment. For spring, Lieberman created a special limited-edition version of the brands Danvin sandal, fabricated with pale-gray suede and black patent-leather straps, and a color- and texture-blocked platform sole. The result is a sturdy but sleek, outfit-making shoe that harmonizes nicely with A.L.C.s laid-back Left Coast sportswear. Theres a certain integrity that resonates with a pair of Robert Clergerie shoes, Lieberman says. Theyreluxurious but cool, edgy but refined.

title: Top Technology Officer at Pandora Steps Down
description: The top technology officer of Pandora Media will resign and move into a part-time advisory role, the biggest management change at the Internet radio giant since the arrival of its new chief executive last year.

title: A Bottle of Bandol Begs for Lamb
description: Provence is not all ros and ratatouille. Its mistral winds can send you inside to sit by the fire and inspire you to open a bottle of Bandol rouge, an intense wine with dark red fruit and echoes of smoke and herbs that begs for lamb.

title: Original Review: Of Mice and Men (1937)
description: Brooks Atkinsons review of John Steinbecks play, which opened on Broadway in 1937 at the Music Box Theater.

title: Taming of the Bestial Bandol
description: Wine is so often typecast. Ros belongs to the summer, and zinfandel, the all-American wine, to Thanksgiving. We drink white wine with fish.

title: Further Thoughts on Hedgehogs and Foxes
description: A few more thoughts on Nate Silver and his attempt to be a fox among hedgehogs.

title: A Culinary Pilgrimage to Punjab
description: Within five minutes of ordering three deluxe thalis at the large and bustling Bharawan da Dhaba in Amritsar, India, a waiter brought us round steel trays filled with our $3 lunch. There were a half-dozen bowls on each, which included spicy chickpeas with a hint of pomegranate powder, the black lentils known as daal and the Punjabi comfort food equivalents of macaroni and cheese  the creamy mustard greens called sarso ka saag and kadhi, a yellow chickpea flour and yogurt curry swimming with fried onion fritters. Lachedar parantha, whole wheat butter-layered bread, fresh from the tandoor clay oven, was our accompaniment.

title: In Panama City, Mixing Global and Local Flavors
description: One hundred years after the opening of the Panama Canal  which continues to bring in immigrants of different ethnicities whose foods dominate Panama Citys culinary scene  a new Panamanian cuisine is emerging, one that looks inward while embracing its diversity. Panama City, admittedly, has very few original dishes. You are more likely to dine on spanakopita or chow mein than saus, pickled pigs feet or the chicken stew called sancocho. Thats changing. Everywhere you look, ambitious young chefs and entrepreneurs are adapting local ingredients to global trends, ranging from Southern barbecue to Japanese-Peruvian fusion.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel La Jolla in San Diego
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Linea Caffe in San Francisco
description: The premise of Linea Caffe, which opened last September, sounds as if it came straight out of a late-night brainstorming session without a next-morning reality check. A coffee bar (Linea Caffe) shares a tiny storefront with a waffle counter (Lt. Waffle), which also functions as a salad bar. Click on the salad bars website, and youll find a statement of purpose that reads like a manifesto: avocado is the zeitgeist, and kale is not a passing fad.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Greece Reaches Deal to Release Foreign Rescue Funds
description: ATHENS  After seven months of faltering negotiations, Prime Minister Antonis Samaras said on Tuesday that Greece had reached a deal with its foreign lenders on economic reforms necessary to unlock billions of euros in crucial rescue funding. He also pledged to distribute 500 million euros to one million Greeks hit hardest by the countrys economic crisis.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Ukraine, Malaysia and Afghanistan.

title: M Pches Focus Turns to Four Wheels
description: As soon as I heard about State Bird Provisions, the San Francisco restaurant where the food comes around on dim-sum trolleys, I hoped a New York chef would steal the idea. Now David Chang has.

title: West Coast Visitors Arrive, Then Look Back
description: While many American orchestras are grappling with financial challenges and discontent among players, the Los Angeles Philharmonic looks to be a solid success story. Relations between management and musicians seem very positive. A four-year contract signed last fall included slight annual raises in the salaries of the players. Walt Disney Concert Hall, the coolest symphonic performance space in America, remains a big draw. Most important, the charismatic conductor Gustavo Dudamel, 33, now in his fifth season as music director, continues to galvanize audiences in the Los Angeles area while heading the orchestras impressive community outreach and education efforts.

title: Its Official, Secret Money Corrupts
description: Lawmakers of both parties are desperately trying to stop the Internal Revenue Service from interfering with the most powerful political invention that ever fell into their laps: the use of non-profit groups as a source of unlimited and anonymous campaign money. If you want to understand why, consider an investigation now unfolding in Utah, which exposes in remarkable detailhow profoundly the non-profit system can be corrupted for the benefit of a single industry and a single politician.

title: Women Lawyers Climb Top Rungs of Corporate America
description: Some 21 percent of the top lawyers at the nations Fortune 500 companies are women, an increase from 17 percent five years ago, according to a new tally of corporate counsel ranks.

title: Ofer Cohen
description: Mr. Cohen, 43, is the president and a partner in TerraCRG, a commercial brokerage and advisory company focused solely on Brooklyn. Before starting TerraCRG in early 2008, Mr. Cohen was a senior broker at Massey Knakal Realtys Brooklyn office.

title: Balancing Act: Building the Village
description: A profile of the Jeremiah Program, which tries to help single mothers and their children escape the poverty trap by providing subsidized housing and early childhood education.

title: Spinning a Classic French Tale
description: Earlier this year Rtisserie Georgette put a new chef in charge of its spit-roasted chickens and fish, its fries flecked with tarragon and its baby potatoes heavy with meat drippings, and I couldnt tell the difference. This is meant as praise, and not the damning-with-faint kind.

title: Program Works to Lift Single Mothers Out of Poverty
description: Low-income single mothers, a growing demographic group, face a challenging set of responsibilities, with unusually tight resources. They must juggle erratic work hours, inconsistent child care and often (at least if they want to move up the socioeconomic ladder) school programs that are not built to accommodate their work and family lives. With so much economic insecurity, their children also have the decks stacked against them.

title: Time to Make Up for a Missed Measles Vaccine
description: WIth 20 confirmed cases of measles in New York City, now is a good time to check your childrens vaccination records, make up for any shots missed because of illness or travel and reconsider any stance your family might have taken on delaying or refusing vaccinations. Writing for The Times, Anemona Hartocollis reports that of the 20 confirmed cases, 9 were children. Of those, 7 were too young to be vaccinated or within the window of 12 to 15 months old when the vaccination is recommended. The other 2 were from families in which the parents refused to allow the vaccination.

title: Just a Little Bit of Yonkers Goes a Long Way at Iowa State
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The first snip of scissors sliced cleanly through the net at the Sprint Center. But the second? Dustin Hogue of Iowa State, standing on a ladder, needed several tries to finish the job after the Cyclones won the Big 12 tournament championship here, at one point making a face as if somebody had slipped him rubber scissors as a gag.

title: Rebuilding Detroit, One House at a Time
description: The message implicit in the prizewinning documentaries Detropia and Searching for Sugar Man, in Detroits declaration of bankruptcy in 2013  in even a casual drive along Gratiot Avenue, past mile after mile of burned-out or boarded-up houses and stores  is that Detroit is in a pitiable state.

title: Leak Found in Main Near East Harlem Explosion Site
description: Investigators examining the scene of the deadly gas explosion in East Harlem said on Tuesday that they had identified a leak in an eight-inch cast-iron and plastic gas main under Park Avenue between 116th and 117th Streets.

title: Dream Homes in Kings Point, L.I.
description: Last November, when the youngest of their three children was ready for his own room, Bobby Zargari and his wife, Melissa, moved from a compact home with a postage-stamp-size backyard in Saddle Rock Estates, an unincorporated area, to a sprawling, twice-expanded five-bedroom three-bath ranch on a flat, rectangular 1.25-acre plot in Kings Point, the verdant, affluent village at the northern tip of the Great Neck peninsula in Nassau County.

title: A Troubled Neighborhoods Revival in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Three residential towers in the notoriously crime-ridden, impoverished Bayview Hunters Point neighborhood opened earlier this year, the first signs of efforts to overhaul the area.

title: Update on Our Student Editorial-Writing Contest
description: Update | April 23: We have announced the winners of the Student Editorial Contest here.

title: Jemima Kirkes Paintings of Girls
description: Jemima Kirke is methodical and serious as a painter, but if Jessa had a show, she might not have shown up, says Holly Fouladi, the owner of Fouladi Projects in San Francisco, where the British-American Girls star will unveil her second solo exhibition of oil portraiture, Platforms. Comparisons are easy to make. The 28-year-old shares a number of commonalities with her character Jessa Johansson on the HBO series: a best friend in Lena Dunham (or Hannah Horvath); the flung-on, bohemian insouciance; that penchant for an American Spirit after dinner.

title: Do Friends Let Friends Sign Their Paychecks?
description: Its hard to imagine a worse premise than an actress and her best friend writing and starring together in a film about their friendship.

title: Pushing Buttons and Boundaries on Movie Screens
description: Every spring, New Directors/New Films  a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art  offers a sampler of recent work from around the globe by filmmakers you may not know but should. Last years edition included Sarah Polleys documentary Stories We Tell and Shane Carruths Upstream Color, titles that pushed film form and some filmgoer buttons. This years edition features 27 diverse features and two programs of short works that are certain to keep the conversation going long after the festival ends. Here are highlights from the first week.

title: Video of Putins Complete Speech on Crimea
description: As my colleagues Steven Lee Myers and Ellen Barry report from Moscow, President Vladimir V. Putin reclaimed Crimea and the port city of Sevastopol as a part of Russia on Tuesday, in an emotional address before the countrys political elite in the Grand Kremlin Palace.

title: De Blasios Approval Slips, a Poll Shows
description: The bumps and bruises afflicting his young administration have lowered Mayor Bill de Blasios stature among New Yorkers over the past two months, and there is a sharp racial divide in voters optimism about the citys future, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

title: North Carolina Beer Month Is Near
description: North Carolina Beer Month, celebrating the states 100 breweries and scheduled for April, is going to get an early start.

title: Reviews: Smash Hit, Castlevania, Calculords and Threes!
description: SMASH HIT

title: Wooing the Public to Recover Art
description: LA CHAUX-DE-FONDS, Switzerland  Alain Monteagle unfolded his blue chair and set up a white table at a vegetable market last weekend, covering it with brochures titled The Looting of Art in War. As a baker nearby peddled croissants that morning, Mr. Monteagle tried to sell his version of justice.

title: Unpacking a Familys Musical Legacy
description: As a boy growing up in the Berkshires, Yevgeny Kutik paid little attention to the stack of yellowing sheet music that sat on a shelf in his familys music studio, where he practiced the violin. He had arrived as a 5-year-old in 1990 from the crumbling Soviet Union with his parents, maternal grandparents and two suitcases that were as tall as he was. In those first years, he said during a recent interview over tea, I was more concerned with making friends, learning English, fitting in.

title: Activists Prevail in Campaign to Oust REITs Board
description: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | For more than a year, an activist hedge fund and a prominent real estate developer have pressed for change at a real estate investment trust.

title: Richard Prince Settles Copyright Suit With Patrick Cariou Over Photographs
description: In the final, quiet act of a copyright case that riveted the art world for five years, the artist Richard Prince has reached a settlement with Patrick Cariou, a photographer who accused Mr. Prince of violating his copyright protections by using Mr. Carious pictures of Rastafarians as the basis for a series of paintings that sold for millions of dollars.

title: Returning, in His Own Way, to the Killing Fields
description: The audacity of The Missing Picture  a brilliant documentary about a child who held on to life in Cambodias killing fields  is equaled only by its soulfulness. On April 17, 1975, the day the Khmer Rouge seized the capital, Phnom Penh, the 13-year-old Rithy Panh, his family and millions more were driven from that city and other towns and villages and straight into hell. Four years later, many of his relatives, including his father, mother, sisters and a niece and nephew were dead; decades later, Mr. Panh, now a filmmaker, has told his story in a movie in which the act of remembrance serves as a form of resistance.

title: Free-for-All on the Final Friday of Tribeca Film Festival
description: AT&T has been offering free Wi-Fi in New York City parks since 2011 but now, as part of its sponsorship of the coming Tribeca Film Festival, it will be offering park users a reason to switch off their devices: free movies.

title: Forget the Triangle: Dolan and Jackson Play a Two-Man Game
description: The introductory news conference for Phil Jackson at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday did not exactly feature the democratic share-the-ball principles of his beloved triangle offense. In a late-morning session with the Knicks owner, James L. Dolan, and the holdover executive Steve Mills, Jackson spoke extensively, Dolan waxed triumphantly and Mills never once got a chance to speak.

title: A Global Boom, but Only for Some
description: Remember when Al Gore took on H. Ross Perot? It was November 1993. Mr. Gore deployed his smoothest scorn to swat down the cantankerous billionaires argument that the North American Free Trade Agreement would produce a great sucking sound of jobs flowing to Mexico. The agreement, Mr. Gore said, would become an engine of American prosperity.

title: A Mideast Deal Breaker
description: To the Editor:

title: New Life for Old Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: Let High School Students Sleep Later?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hijacking by Hackers
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Acts, and the West Reacts
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvards Latest Basketball Success: Winning Over Its Campus
description: BOSTON  Shortly before leaving for Spokane, Wash., and their N.C.A.A. tournament matchup against Cincinnati, the members of Harvard mens basketball team gathered in the universitys Murr Center to meet the news media.

title: Ruling Highlights Unequal Treatment in Penalizing Corporate Wrongdoers
description: Bankers are not exactly popular these days, but is it right to let directors escape scot-free when they do wrong and an investment bank pays the bill?

title: Russias Most-Wanted Rebel Is Dead, Website Says
description: MOSCOW  The death of Doku Umarov, Russias most wanted terrorist leader, was announced Tuesday on a website representing Islamist militant groups in southern Russia.

title: Memories of a Friend, a Teacher and a Fighter
description: LWren Scott was beguiling to her friends, so I cant imagine what strangers thought of her. There was her height: 6-foot-7 in heels, which made me (5-foot-7) feel like a shrimp.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Q. and A.: A Development Expert on Narrowing Inequality
description: Branko Milanovic has been studying income inequality around the world for a long time.

title: Trial Judge Will Not Allow 9/11 Architects Testimony
description: A judge in Manhattan ruledon Tuesdaythat Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of theSept. 11attacks, will not be permitted to provide testimony in the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a former top adviser to Osama bin Laden.

title: Radar on Mainland Too Robust to Miss a Jet, Experts Say
description: HONG KONG  If the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner flew north over the Asian mainland after it lost contact with ground controllers on March 8, it would have had a difficult time avoiding detection by Chinese, Indian or American radar, current and former military officers say.

title: Diner Musical to Open at Signature Theater in Virginia
description: The bumpy road for the Sheryl Crow-Barry Levinson musical Diner, based on Mr. Levinsons 1982 film, is not leading to San Francisco or New York first (as originally planned) but rather to Arlington, Va., where Signature Theater will stage a world premiere production in December, the theater announced on Tuesday night.

title: Republican Primary
description: Live results from the Republican primary for Illinois governor.

title: Salvation Army Settles Lawsuit on Religious Discrimination
description: The Salvation Army on Tuesday settled a decade-old lawsuit that charged it with engaging in religious discrimination by requiring its government-funded social service employees to reveal their beliefs and to agree to act in accordance with the Christian gospel.

title: Report Issued on War Crimes in Syria
description: Both those fighting for and against the Syrian government are terrorizing the countrys civilian population in defiance of a recent Security Council resolution, a panel of investigators told the United Nations Human Rights Council on Tuesday.

title: Subway Alarm
description: A New Yorker questions whether the alarms on emergency exit doors in the New York subway system are necessary safety measures  or harmful annoyances.

title: Subway Alarm
description: For a very long time, the blaring alarms at the exits of the New York subway system have driven me crazy. On my daily commute, I ride in the last train car, and at my stop I wait about a minute before heading to the turnstiles. By the time I arrive, the crowd has hopefully gone and the alarm is hopefully silent. But if that approach fails and an alarm is blaring, Ill stubbornly exit through the revolving doors instead of joining the rest of the crowd in an easy passage through the open emergency door. Call me irrational if you want. But I really hate those alarms.

title: Egyptian Police Officer Gets 10 Years for Detainees Deaths
description: CAIRO  A criminal court in Cairo on Tuesday sentenced a police officer to 10 years in jail for manslaughter in the deaths of 37 detainees last August after their arrest for protesting against the military takeover. An official investigation concluded that the detainees had died of asphyxiation in a badly overcrowded police van after officers fired tear gas inside it. A total of 45 detainees had been packed into a van with a capacity for 24, Egyptian state news media reported Tuesday, and investigators discredited initial statements by the police that they were killed while trying to escape.

title: The Graves of Forgotten New Yorkers
description: ON New York City maps, Hart Island drifts off the edge of the Bronx like an amputated leg. Among overgrown vegetation and ramshackle buildings spread out over 101 acres, about a million bodies are buried  the homeless, the poor, the stillborn, the unidentified and the unclaimed. The island is said to be home to the largest active potters field in America. Until recently, it was off limits to all but the most persistent.

title: Big Banks Fulfill Part of Mortgage Deal
description: The nations four largest banks  Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo  have more than fulfilled their financial obligations toward homeowners under a $25 billion nationwide mortgage settlement reached in 2012, the settlement monitor said on Tuesday in a final report.

title: A Blunder From Beginning to End
description: From the moment Ulysses S. Grant took control of the Union Army in March 1864, he went on the offensive. Offensives, in fact: With his forces already pressing down into Virginia and Tennessee, he planned to open a new front by attacking Mobile, Ala.

title: Green, Bayern Munich Striker, to Play for the U.S.
description: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann received a gift on Tuesday only months before the start of the World Cup in Brazil when striker Julian Green, 18, chose to represent the United States mens national team instead of Germany.

title: Bad Back Forces Woods From Palmer Event
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Tiger Woodss balky back forced him to withdraw Tuesday from the Arnold Palmer Invitational, imperiling his bid for a fifth green jacket at the Masters in less than a month. On his website Woods said, Unfortunately, my back spasms and the pain havent subsided.

title: From Putin, a Blessing in Disguise
description: There are a lot of people who seem intent on restarting the Cold War  in both Moscow and Washington. I am not one of them. But if were going to have a new Cold War, then I have one condition: I want a new moonshot.

title: A Divide Among Palestinians on a Two-State Solution
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  When President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority visited the White House this week, he again heard dire warnings that the current moment could be the last chance for a two-state solution through negotiations with Israel.

title: Russian Aggression Puts NATO in Spotlight
description: LONDON  Russias annexation of Crimea has suddenly revived the North Atlantic Treaty Organizations central role as a counterweight to Moscow, and with it questions about the alliances options and ability to act.

title: New Social App Has Juicy Posts, All Anonymous
description: From Facebook to Twitter to Instagram and Google, many big Internet successes depend on coaxing people into sharing every last bit of information about themselves and their lives.

title: When Minimum Wage Rises, Many Are Left Looking Up at It
description: On Tuesday, Edgar Juarez, 36, awoke in the two-bedroom apartment that he shares with five other men on 136th Street in Manhattan. His shift in a restaurant on the Upper West Side would begin at 4 p.m., and he would stay until nearly 1 a.m. The job is dishwasher.

title: Student Deaths Spark Debate Over Hazing at Portugals Universities
description: LISBON  By almost any measure, Portugals universities have had a turbulent time. After the end of the countrys dictatorship in the 1970s, public education found itself overwhelmed by soaring numbers of young people seeking degrees. The unmet demand opened a market for private universities, generally regarded as being of lesser quality.

title: Leucadia Raises Stake in Harbinger
description: More than half a year after a landmark settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the embattled hedge fund billionaire Philip A. Falcone, who also heads the publicly traded Harbinger Group, has struck a deal with the Leucadia National Corporation.

title: Costly Loans Are Drawing Attention From States
description: Loralty Harden, a 62-year-old retiree, was distressed when the balance on a short-term loan she had obtained to supplement her Social Security income did not budge even though she diligently followed the payment plan that came with it.

title: Medals of Honor Go to 24 Army Veterans Who Had Been Denied
description: WASHINGTON  Mitch Libman was surprised when his childhood friend, Pfc. Leonard Kravitz, was not selected for the Medal of Honor  the militarys top honor  after his service in the Korean War. Mr. Libman, back in Denver, had received regular updates from Private Kravitz about the fighting. But then Private Kravitz died a hero, with his actions saving his entire platoon in Yangpyong on March 6-7, 1951.

title: Los Angeles Museums Board Elects New and Returning Artist-Trustees
description: Three of the artists who left the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles in 2012 to protest the leadership of Jeffrey Deitch, then the museums director, have been re-elected to their positions at the artist-centered museum.The artists Catherine Opie, John Baldessari and Barbara Kruger left the board, along with a fourth artist-member, Ed Ruscha, complaining that Mr. Deitch was steering the museums program too much in the direction of pop culture. Mr. Deitch, who had previously been a New York gallery owner, stepped down from the museum post last year, three years into a five-year contract, and the museum recently chose Philippe Vergne, a longtime curator and the director of the Dia Art Foundation in New York, to replace him.While Mr. Ruscha is not returning, the painter Mark Grotjahn has been elected to take a fourth artist seat on the board, the museum said.The museum, which has one of the most important collections of postwar art in the country but has struggled financially for years and considered merging with other institutions, announced recently that it had secured a combination of commitments and donations to raise its endowment to $100 million, by far the highest in the museums history.Im very excited about the prospects for MOCA with Philippe leading us and I want to be supportive, Mr. Baldessari said in a statement.

title: Republicans Versus an Informed Public
description: At regular intervals, congressional Republicans take aim at government surveys, vowing to end or curtail them for being too intrusive. The latest target is the Census Bureaus American Community Survey.

title: If Not a Cold War, a Return to a Chilly Rivalry
description: WASHINGTON  A month ago, most Americans could not have found Crimea on a map. But its lightning-quick takeover by Moscow has abruptly redrawn the geopolitical atlas and may have decisively ended a 25-year period of often tumultuous yet also constructive relations between the United States and Russia.

title: Shortchanging New York Citys Commuters
description: Many subway riders in the New York City area sense a certain decay settling in as the system continues to suffer from age, budget limitations and problems related to Hurricane Sandy. The Straphangers Campaign  activists who have been assessing mass transit for 35 years  confirm that unease. The group estimates that the subways have shown a significant decline in cleanliness; fares have gone up steadily; crowding is getting worse.

title: Recalling Success for the Knicks, After Years of Losing
description: Phil Jackson made the task of turning around a moribund franchise sound so easy.

title: Updating Internet Governance
description: The technical business of managing Internet addresses and domain names has often taken on geopolitical overtones. About a year ago, some countries including Russia and China tried to pressure the United States into relinquishing management and coordination of web addresses to the telecommunications arm of the United Nations.

title: Obama Awards Medals of Honor to Veterans
description: The president awarded 24 Medals of Honor, 21 of them posthumously, to Army veterans at a White House ceremony.

title: Leaked File Details U.S. Phone Monitoring Abroad
description: The National Security Agency is recording all telephone calls and their routing data in one foreign country and retaining that information for a month so that it can be analyzed later, according to a report based on a top secret intelligence document.

title: Families From Diverse Lands Mourn Victims of East Harlem Explosion
description: They lived just steps from one another in two buildings in East Harlem. They were a mother and a daughter, neighbors and friends, whose day-to-day routines intersected for weeks, or even years, in a corner of the city that for some of them was far from their homeland.

title: Guatemala: Ex-President Admits Taking Taiwan Bribes
description: Former President Alfonso Portillo pleaded guilty Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to a charge that he accepted bribes in exchange for diplomatic recognition of Taiwan. In a plea bargain with federal prosecutors, Mr. Portillo, 62, who served from 2000 to 2004, was extradited to the United States almost a year ago on corruption charges, pleading guilty to conspiracy. He read a statement admitting to taking $2.5 million in bribes, with the proceeds funneled through American banks. Sentencing is scheduled for June 23.

title: Post-Crimea Relations With the West
description: Vladimir Putins annexation of Crimea on Tuesday was accompanied by a grand piece of theater in the gilded St. Georges Hall of the Kremlin and disdain for the West and its sanctions and threats. The United States and the European Union are likely to impose added sanctions beyond the measures ordered against a few senior Kremlin officials, but there is virtually no chance that Mr. Putin could be coerced into reversing what the overwhelming majority of Russians and Crimeans seemed to regard as the righting of a historical anomaly. It may also prove to be a watershed in post-Soviet East-West relations, with a lot less for the Russians to celebrate.

title: When a Hospital Stay Is Not a Stay
description: If you go to the emergency room and end up staying in the hospital, you may assume that you have been officially admitted. But it turns out that even though you are receiving treatment in a hospital bed, you may simply be under observation, and technically are still an outpatient. That can cost you money if you are covered under Medicare, the federal health plan for older Americans.

title: Los Angeles Mayor on Airport Report
description: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles commented on a report released about the emergency response to last years shooting at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Report on Los Angeles Airport Shooting Cites Poor Communication
description: LOS ANGELES  When a gunman opened fire at the Los Angeles International Airport in November, poor communication and coordination among emergency officials led to a chaotic response that left victims waiting for responders and passengers stranded without information, according to a report released Tuesday reviewing the emergency response to the episode.

title: New Alliances in Battle for Corporate Control
description: For ages, institutional investors like mutual funds and pension funds were content to take stakes in public companies, trust their managements and bet on long-term gains. Companies trusted that these investors would be passive shareholders and not rock the boat.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 18, 2014
description: March 18, 2014

title: Another Tale of Two Cities
description: LOS ANGELES  The tremors may have had morning TV anchors diving under the desk, but it takes more than a 4.4 quiver to rattle Eric Garcetti.

title: In Defense of Anonymous Political Giving
description: The explosion in secret financing of political advertising has turned tax-exempt nonprofit organizations into the weapon of choice for those who want to influence elections without leaving fingerprints.

title: Full-Court Press Wooed Jackson to Knicks
description: James L. Dolan, the owner of the New York Knicks, was riding an all-terrain vehicle near Palm Springs, Calif. It was March 2, and the Knicks were in Chicago for another blowout loss in a season full of them  on national television, no less.

title: Ukraine's Effect on a Deal for Syria
Rikers Island Struggles With a Surge in Violence and Mental Illness

title: Noble Widow Needs Cash
description: Though it is packed with fashionably dressed sentences and high-calorie bons mots, David Grimms Tales From Red Vienna achieves its greatest eloquence in an opening scene in which scarcely a word is spoken. There are only a few strangled monosyllables, like please, no and so.

title: Go Away
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  By all accounts, Samuel A. Not The Newscaster Donaldson is a very nice guy. So why is he telling us to Go away?

title: Sam Lacey, Top Center in N.B.A. and the 1970 Final Four, Dies at 66
description: Sam Lacey, a leading N.B.A. center of the 1970s who could do just about anything on the court but was often overlooked, playing for mostly lackluster teams, died on Friday at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 66.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 19, 2014
description: They cheated us again and again, made decisions behind our back, presenting us with completed facts. Thats the way it was with the expansion of NATO in the East, with the deployment of military infrastructure at our borders.

title: Morning Joe Host Says He Wont Run in 2016, but He Leaves Door Ajar
description: WASHINGTON  Joe Scarborough is running a campaign. It may be a campaign to change the Republican Party, to sell a book or perhaps to enhance his reputation.

title: A Growing Fraternity: Tommy John Patients
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Together, they could form a strong starting rotation: Matt Harvey, Kris Medlen, Patrick Corbin, Jarrod Parker and Brandon Beachy. Instead, they will probably be the phantom five this season, some of the latest victims of Tommy John elbow surgery.

title: Politics Wont Be on First Ladys China Itinerary, Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obamas trip to China starting on Wednesday will be nonpolitical, the White House says, a people-to-people exchange emphasizing the importance that both nations place on education. As if to underscore the point, no reporters are traveling with the first lady, and she does not plan to give interviews while there.

title: LWren Scotts Death Still Under Investigation
description: The medical examiners office worked on Tuesday to determine the cause of death for LWren Scott, the fashion designer, who was found dead in her Manhattan apartment on Monday.

title: Randolph Thrower, I.R.S. Chief Who Resisted Nixon, Dies at 100
description: Randolph W. Thrower, a Republican lawyer who headed the Internal Revenue Service under President Richard M. Nixon from 1969 to 1971 before losing his job for resisting White House efforts to punish its enemies through tax audits, died March 8 at his home in Atlanta. He was 100.

title: Growing as a Player, Beaming as a Father
description: CINCINNATI  Every night, whether he is at home or in a hotel room, the Cincinnati guard Sean Kilpatrick makes time to video chat with his 3-year old daughter, Bailey.

title: Ellsburys Replacement Is Struggling, but Hes Playing
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Jackie Bradley Jr.s phone was insistent, chirping and buzzing, demanding his attention.

title: Mets Send Syndergaard, a Top Prospect, to the Minors
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets are rich with pitching, which is why they appear to be taking their time with Noah Syndergaard, one of their best prospects.

description: Two days after being passed over for the N.C.A.A. tournament, St. Johns hosted a first-round game in the National Invitation Tournament on Tuesday night as a No. 1 seed. The Red Storm (20-13) did not play much like a team deserving of that honor, either.

title: Scott Asheton, Drummer in the Stooges, Is Dead at 64
description: Scott Asheton, the original drummer and a founder of the influential rock band the Stooges, died on Saturday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 64.

description: A large fire at a recycling plant in Greenpoint sent smoke moving across the city on Tuesday night, but there were no reported injuries, fire officials said.

title: Warby Parkers New Uptown Outpost
description: This Saturday, the socially conscious eyeglass retailer Warby Parker will open the doors to its third New York retail space in what was, for more than a century, the iconic Lascoff Drugs on the Upper East Side. Though the massive two-story store on Lexington Avenue boasts 21-foot cathedral ceilings, the abundant books and stylish frames lining the walls will feel familiar to anyone who has received an eye exam at the companys bustling SoHo location on Greene Street or shopped for frames at its cozy Washington Street store in the Meatpacking District. Art by Maira Kalman hung alongside the gothic windows that line the perimeter adds a lightness to the space. There are even pneumatic tubes to send glasses through the store, at a speed of 24 feet per second. Shoppers can browse all of the brands styles  including the new Spectrum Sun collection of glasses, which made its debut yesterday  and pick up new prescriptions in one of the two exam rooms. Here, a brief look at the do-good companys new location and its growing product line.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Danny McBride and Judy Blume
description: Judy Blume and Danny McBride get hopped up on hefeweizen while contemplating pillowcases and backpacks.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 10:30 P.M. (IFC) BOILER ROOM (2000) Before Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio adapted the life of Jordan Belfort for the screen in The Wolf of Wall Street, Mr. Belfort inspired this fictional tale about a group of young, ruthless stockbrokers who work miles from the trading floor and use nothing but cold calls to relieve unsuspecting clients of their life savings. Giovanni Ribisi (above right, with Ben Affleck) plays Seth, a college dropout who joins the small firm of J. T. Marlin, rising quickly through its ranks, thanks to the no-nonsense tutelage of his possibly corrupt bosses and colleagues (portrayed by Mr. Affleck, Vin Diesel and Nicky Katt, among others). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film, written and directed by Ben Younger, reflects the sensibility of the generation it holds up to critical scrutiny, and its a cunningly ambiguous act of self-portraiture. He added that Mr. Younger presents a world ruled by a gang of lawless, soulless children, like the island of lost boys in Peter Pan. But his film also shows us a group of actors, and a filmmaker, with soul to spare and talent to burn.

title: Toyota Expected to Settle Justice Dept. Investigation
description: Toyota is poised to pay more than $1 billion to settle a criminal investigation into disclosures around the sudden acceleration of its vehicles, a steep fine that caps a multiyear inquiry and provides a template for the authorities pursuing a similar case against General Motors.

title: Obama Turns to Web to Illustrate the Effects of a Changing Climate
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama wants Americans to see how climate change could deluge or destroy their own backyards  and to make it as easy as opening a web-based app.

title: Dont Worry, the Calendar Will Catch Up
Insurers Seek to Capitalize on Chinas Smog
description: Updated, 5:28 a.m. ET| Wars can present many opportunities to make money, and Chinas recently announced war against pollution looks to be no exception.

title: Opponents of China Trade Deal Occupy Taiwans Legislature
description: Hundreds of people have occupied Taiwans legislature to protest a trade deal with China that they fear will give Beijing too much influence over the islands economy.

title: A Village Brings Down Its Hills as Lure of Mining Grows
description: NONGTALANG, India  Bomb, bomb, bomb! shouted the miner, and his warning echoed off the walls of the decapitated hillock. Seconds later, an explosion sliced off yet another chunk of limestone, which crumbled into a pile somewhere near where the center of the hill used to be.

title: Israeli Strikes on Syrian Army Sites Raise Concern About Entanglement
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli airstrikes against several Syrian Army positions across the decades-old cease-fire line in the Golan Heights on Wednesday came as a specific response to a bomb attack against Israeli forces along the frontier a day earlier, according to Israeli officials. But for many here, the unusually sharp exchange signaled the possibility of a broader Israeli slide into regional turmoil.

title: Test Yourself | Math, March 19, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: Notable Absences in Congress Partys Latest Slate of Candidates
description: NEW DELHI The Indian National Congress, the governing party in New Delhi, has released its third list of its nominees for the lower house of Parliament, or Lok Sabha, a slate that is notable for what it omitted as much as for what it included.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Space Ripples Reveal Big Bangs Smoking Gun
description: In Space Ripples Reveal Big Bangs Smoking Gun, Dennis Overbye writes about new evidence that helps to prove what happened immediately after the universe rapidly expanded 13.8 billion years ago.

title: Activists Death Questioned as U.N. Considers Chinese Rights Report
description: The United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva was expected to adopt a Chinese government human rights report on Wednesday, five days after the death in custody of a prominent rights advocate who had pushed, unsuccessfully, for citizen input in the report.

title: Chicken With Shallots, Chef-Style
description: The recipe, which came in a Twitter update from the chef and television personality Andrew Zimmern, was succinct, as the form requires: Brown 8 thighs, 3 C shallots. Add wine, tarragon, Dijon, sim 30 min covered. Remove lid, reduce. Add 2 C cut cherry toms.

title: What Pakistan Knew About Bin Laden
description: Shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks, I went to live and report for The New York Times in Afghanistan. I would spend most of the next 12 years there, following the overthrow of the Taliban, feeling the excitement of the freedom and prosperity that was promised in its wake and then watching the gradual dissolution of that hope. A new Constitution and two rounds of elections did not improve the lives of ordinary Afghans; the Taliban regrouped and found increasing numbers of supporters for their guerrilla actions; by 2006, as they mounted an ambitious offensive to retake southern Afghanistan and unleashed more than a hundred suicide bombers, it was clear that a deadly and determined opponent was growing in strength, not losing it. As I toured the bomb sites and battlegrounds of the Taliban resurgence, Afghans kept telling me the same thing: The organizers of the insurgency were in Pakistan, specifically in the western district of Quetta. Police investigators were finding that many of the bombers, too, were coming from Pakistan.

title: New Orleans by Streetlight
description: A girl broke Frank Relles heart, but a city captured it.

title: Have You Ever Paid It Forward?
description: Have you heard the term paying it forward, in which a person who has been the recipient of a generous act does a similar kindness for someone else, often a stranger? When have you been the recipient of kindness from a stranger? When have you done something generous for someone you didnt know?

title: Swiss Confront the Costs of Curbing Foreign Labor
description: THAYNGEN, Switzerland  Werner Bernhard, who was selling roasted chicken from a cart across from the train station in this prosperous village north of Zurich, is eager to see Switzerland close its borders to some of the thousands of European Union citizens who come here every year.

title: Newly Detected Objects Draw Searchers for Malaysian Plane
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian prime minister, Tony Abbott, announced on Thursday that satellite imagery had detected objects that might be connected to the missing Malaysia Airlines jet that vanished on a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on March 8.

title: New York Today: The MetroCards Future
description: Good Wednesday morning. Its been a rough one on roads and subways.

title: More Fed Officials Say 2016 Is Year for Rate Increase
description: The Federal Reserve isnt going to tell us when it expects to start raising interest rates. It isnt going to draw a line in the sands of economic data  a minimum unemployment rate, a minimum rate of inflation. Its done with all of that.

title: Daily Report: Anonymous Social App Offers a Hotbed of Silicon Valley Gossip
description: From Facebook to Twitter to Instagram to Google, many big Internet successes depend on coaxing people into sharing every last bit of information about themselves and their lives. But a five-week old social app, Secret, is testing the limits of just how much sharing Silicon Valley thinks is a good thing, because the sharing is done anonymously, Jenna Wortham reports.

title: Ukraine Plans to Withdraw Troops From Russia-Occupied Crimea
description: SEVASTOPOL, Crimea  Bowing to the reality of the Russian military occupation of Crimea a day after Russia announced it was annexing the disputed peninsula, the Ukrainian government saidon Wednesdaythat it had drawn up plans to evacuate all of its military personnel and their families and was prepared to relocate as many as 25,000 of them to mainland Ukraine.

title: On Hiring and Autism
description: In a previous post, I wrote about mentoring David Geslak, who owns Exercise Connection, a company in Chicago that works with children who have autism. Dave has discovered that the structure and routine that his students learn from exercise build confidence, which can be a gateway to getting a job. He called me about the job search for one of his students  he calls them champions  whose name is Anthony.

title: One Year Later, Dead Pigs Discovered in Another Chinese River
description: One year after thousands of dead pigs were found floating in a river that flows through Shanghai, another city in eastern China says it has discovered dead swine in a major waterway. On Wednesday, officials in Nanchang, the capital of Jiangxi Province, said that more than 100 dead pigs had been pulled from the Gan River.

title: Sony Unveils Virtual Reality Headset
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sony is joining the chase for virtual reality, one of the most elusive dreams of the technology industry.

title: More Scrutiny for Payday Lenders
description: The battle is heating up against payday lenders and their practice of offering fast money to borrowers so desperate for cash that they are often willing to accept it at almost any terms, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

title: Broadway Bromance
description: On a recent weekday morning, the Of Mice and Men cast was rehearsing a scene set in the ramshackle California bunk house where much of the play, opening on Broadway next month, takes place. James Franco, portraying George, was explaining his complicated symbiotic friendship with Lennie (Chris ODowd, offstage just then), when the director, Anna D. Shapiro, began musing aloud: What should Mr. Franco do during the speech, so as not to be simply standing around?

title: After Derivatives, a Bet on Crispy Seaweed
description: Until last year, Robert Mock sold financial derivatives at Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Today, he sells something completely different: seaweed chips.

description: Kit Eaton delves into three apps that can help you get your comic book fix.

title: Need a Towel? No Need to Buy One
description: Dear Diary:

title: Document | The Long Way Round
description: When it comes to souvenirs, passport stamps can be as effective as photographs. Such is the case, at least, for Charles Veley, 48, who took an extended break from the tech world in 2000 to become king of the niche pastime known as competitive travel. Heligoland? The Johnston Atoll? The island of Diego Garcia? Veley, one of the worlds most extreme travelers, has been to these places, as well as 826 other countries, territories, autonomous regions, enclaves, geographically separated island groups and major states and provinces. Here, the voracious wanderer  and owner of nine passports  shares a few of the pages from his never-ending pilgrimage.

title: JPMorgan Commodities Unit to Be Sold for $3.5 Billion
description: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | Wall Street banks, facing tighter scrutiny from regulators, are moving to get out of the business of physical commodities trading.

title: Toyota Is Fined $1.2 Billion for Concealing Safety Defects
description: Eric H. Holder Jr., the United States attorney general, talked in impassioned tones on Wednesday about Toyotas behavior in hiding safety defects from the public, calling it shameful and a blatant disregard for the law. A $1.2 billion criminal penalty, the largest ever for a carmaker in the United States, was imposed.

title: Japan Display Slides 15% in Market Debut
description: TOKYO  A high-stakes bid by Japan to breathe life back into its electronics sector got a tepid response from investors on Wednesday after Japan Display, fused from the struggling display units of Sony, Toshiba and Hitachi two years ago, slid 15 percent in its debut on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: Your Questions, My Answers (III)
description: Im going to do a final round here, since answering reader questions turns out to be easier than figuring out where Malaysia Flight 370 ended up or how to evict Vladimir Putin from the Crimea. As before,these been edited slightly for length, and the full versions are available from the link on each questioners name. And as before, my thanks to everyone who offered questions, and my apologies for only answering a selection of the many that were posed.

title: Report Faults South African Leader for State-Funded Work on Home
description: LONDON  Less than two months before national elections, South Africas public protector issued a report on Wednesday finding that President Jacob G. Zuma benefited unduly, in a manner inconsistent with his office, from state-funded improvements worth around $23 million to his rural estate that were supposed to enhance presidential security.

title: British Budget Outlines Higher Growth and Help for Savers and Retirees
description: LONDON  Arguing that austerity budgets had delivered a recovery sooner than expected, Britains chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, laid out new financial plans Wednesday that included help for savers and retirees, as well as measures meant to spur business investment.

title: Odd Birds
description: What could be more retrograde than a story about a prince choosing his bride among a batch of eager princesses? In The ABC of Fabulous Princesses the Austrian artist Willy Puchner upends expectations in a surprising and delightful way. Even the appearance of the princesses  there are 26  is probably not what readers will anticipate, for each is an exotic bird, painted by Puchner as a full-page, full-length portrait and wearing a regal gown. And  feminists rejoice!  there are no Disneyish wasp-waists here; these dresses are almost dumpily triangular, to accommodate the bird-shaped bodies. In the tradition of royal portraiture, Puchner paints the princesses accompanied by objects and animals that illustrate their attributes: a peculiar array of walking sticks, Venetian masks, snowy owls and casserole dishes.

title: Parodist of Goldman Finds a New Publisher
description: Two weeks ago, John LeFevre, the author of the Twitter account @GSElevator that parodied Wall Street bankers, was dumped by Simon & Schuster, the publisher that had promised him a six-figure book deal.

title: Pet Food Good Enough to Eat  Literally
description: Lucy Postins sells human-grade pet food, meaning you could grab a spoon and eat it with your pooch.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Danny McBride and Judy Blume
description: Danny McBride, actor and foulmouthed comedian who will appear in Cameron Crowes next film, and is now writing a new HBO series with the co-creators of his hit show, Eastbound & Down, takes on Judy Blume, beloved American writer and tween-whisperer who has sold more than 82 million books. Her 29th, which she is currently working on, involves love and loss in 1950s New Jersey.

title: Start-Ups Try for a Piece of the Lucrative Industry of Catering to Pets
description: Alex Stone and his wife, Marissa McDaniel, both work full time. They have two dogs that they miss during the day, and often have trouble getting home to feed them. Pets are like children and need to be on a schedule, Mr. Stone said.

title: Flies That Do Calculus With Their Wings
description: There are lots of reasons scientists love fruit flies, but a big one is their flying ability. These almost microscopic creatures, with minimalist nervous systems and prey to every puff of wind, must often execute millisecond aerial ballets to stay aloft.

description: The amazing fruit flys millisecond maneuvers.

title: Shouldnt Your Dog Be Gluten-Free, Too?
description: Midwestern beef mixed with papaya and dandelion greens. Line-caught whitefish with sweet potatoes and parsley. These are the meals that Taro and Willow, two Rhodesian Ridgebacks owned by Lucy Postins of San Diego, wolf down on a regular basis.

description: The envelope came on a Friday in March  the last day of the last week of a college acceptance season that had been dragging on since early admissions began in October.

description: Two decades ago, Stephen Friedman navigated challenging markets as the head of Goldman Sachs.

title: Distraught Relatives of Missing Flight 370 Passengers Dragged Away From TV Cameras by Malaysian Officials
description: As my colleague Chris Buckley reported, distraught family members of passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 were forcibly dragged away from reporters on Wednesday after they unfurled a banner accusing the Malaysian government of concealing the truth and spoke of their grief.

title: Obamas Bracket: Michigan State vs. Louisville in Final
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama and Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo met in February, the president impressed the coach with his knowledge of the team, its injury woes and style of play. Turns out, he might have just been scouting for his bracket.

title: Classical Playlist: George Antheil, Haydn, Sibelius and More
Teaching Children to Calm Themselves
description: When Luke gets angry, he tries to remember to look at his bracelet. It reminds him of what he can do to calm himself: stop, take a deep breath, count to four, give yourself a hug and, if necessary, ask an adult for help.

title: Questions Over Goldman Deal as Investors Sit in the Dark
description: The revolt of the Muppets is heating up.

title: Swiss Ingenuity Will Be Focus of Festival in New York
description: Historians have conflicting opinions about precisely when and where Dadaism got its start  and that is as it should be, given the spirit of the movement, which prized nonconformity. Still, the consulate general of Switzerland in New York is taking the view that it all began in Zurich in 1916, when poets, artists, musicians and novelists fleeing the First World War gathered at the Cabaret Voltaire and debated Dadaism into existence.

title: Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin to Star in a Netflix Comedy Series
description: You dont need a calendar to remind you that its been a minute or two since Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin were last working nine to five together. But these two actresses are about to get back on the clock for a new Netflix comedy series that was announced by that streaming video service Wednesday.

title: Ivan Lendl Will No Longer Coach Andy Murray
description: Andy Murray and Ivan Lendl, the partnership that began the former champ tutoring the current superstar trend in tennis, ended rather abruptly Wednesday, with Murray announcing on his website that Lendl would no longer be coaching him.

title: Being Smart About Phone Fees Overseas
description: YOU WANT TO USE your smartphone while traveling abroad. But choosing an affordable method can seem mind-numbingly complicated. Should you buy an international roaming plan? And if you do, what does 100 megabytes of data get you anyway? Perhaps you need a hot spot pass? Or a SIM card? If you dont want an eye-popping phone bill, its essential to decide before youre on the plane.

title: In Rome, an Enclave of Cool
description: Pigneto feels a world away from Romes tourist herds and ancient ruins, with a soundtrack of electronic pop music that spills out over sienna-hued courtyards, and nary a souvenir shop in sight. By day, locals shop for produce and sip cappuccinos on tree-filled terraces. At night, crowds of tattooed and stylishly top-knotted 20- and 30-somethings flock to open-air bars and upscale restaurants. Street art, like a metal store gate emblazoned with a Beyonc-esque superhero and a spaceship, seems like a religion. Hotel chains have yet to venture here. A 10-minute bus ride from the arterial Termini station, Pigneto, Romes answer to Bushwick, Brooklyn, is an enclave of cool in the eternal city.

title: On the Final Day of Winter, a Morning of Mayhem
description: Tomorrow: Spring.

title: Can You Trust Secure Messaging Apps?
description: Its officially a post-Snowden and post-WhatsApp world, and my inbox is filled with pitches from companies promoting their secure messaging apps. But can you trust them?

description: CENTREVILLE, Miss.  Finding an alligator in your back yard can ruin your day.

title: I.M.F. Chief Testifies Again About Role in Payout
description: PARIS  Christine Lagarde, the International Monetary Fund chief, was appearing before a French court in a closed session on Wednesday to explain her role in a murky affair involving a government payout to a prominent businessman while she was finance minister of France.

title: Judge Rebukes Justice Dept. for Requesting Overly Broad Email Searches
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge has admonished the Justice Department for repeatedly requesting overly broad searches of peoples email accounts, a practice that he called repugnant to the Constitution.

title: She Called Her What? Uh-Oh.
description: The annals of literature contain many a memorable put-down, but few can match the slaying simplicity of the words Mary McCarthy once used in discussing, or rather dismissing, Lillian Hellman. All together now: Every word she writes is a lie, including and and the. Although she had used the phrase before in an interview, this withering bit of pith became the dis heard round the world only in 1980, when McCarthy trotted it out during an appearance on The Dick Cavett Show. A lawsuit from Hellman followed, and soon the literary world was in a fine old uproar.

title: Wheelies: The Hertz for the People Edition
description: After its fleet grew 22 percent  to 472,200 vehicles  last year, Hertz Global Holdings decided to reduce the number of cars it owned. Mark Frissora, chief executive of the company, said Hertz would sell many of those vehicles to consumers as the cars were retired from service. Mr. Frissora said the company would make about $1,400 a vehicle in retail sales. (Automotive News, subscription required)

title: With Russia, as With China, Unnerved U.S. Allies Seek Reassurances
description: VILNIUS, Lithuania  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. found himself in a fraught but familiar place this week: holding the hands of American allies fearful of being bullied by a larger, aggressive neighbor.

title: Porsche to Replace 911 GT3 Engines Over Fire Hazard
description: Citing a concern over fires, Porsche is replacing the 475-horsepower 3.8-liter 6-cylinder engines in all 785 of its 2014 911 GT3 models worldwide, the automaker said in a news release late Tuesday. The replacement includes about 400 vehicles in the United States with about half unsold and still at dealerships, Nick Twork, a spokesman for Porsche, said in a telephone interview.

title: Rand Paul, Warning About Spying, Faults Obama
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said Wednesday that President Obama should be particularly wary of domestic spying, given the governments history of eavesdropping on civil rights leaders like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., injecting the issue of race into the contentious debate over surveillance.

description: A selection of clips of President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, urging Americans to sign up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act before the March 31 deadline.

description: LONDON  The marbled floors, luxury stores and corporate skyscrapers of Londons Canary Wharf financial district arent the typical surroundings for high-growing technology start-ups.

title: Administration Plays to Young in Health Push
description: WASHINGTON  Russian troops were rolling through Crimea when Denis R. McDonough, the White House chief of staff and a foreign policy expert, was deployed on a mission to do media outreach. But the focus of Mr. McDonoughs calls to local talk radio stations was not geopolitical tensions in Eastern Europe, it was health care.

title: Traders of Tips Meet at Grand Central, and Eat the Evidence
description: Updated, 8:40 p.m. | Secret stock tips scribbled on Post-it notes and paper napkins. Illicit meetings held in broad daylight at Grand Central Terminal. Cover-up efforts that involved chewing, and even eating, damaging evidence.

title: The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes
description: A traveling exhibition is an ambitious and multifaceted presentation of the most famous detective in English literary fiction.

description: BOULDER, COLO.

title: At the Garden, Meet the New Boss (Not the Same as the Old Boss)
description: Phil Jackson, corporate savior, towered over his new boss, James L. Dolan, as Jackson, a former Knicks reserve, was introduced as the teams new president Tuesday in the lobby of Madison Square Garden.

title: Theyre Real and Dont Care What You Think
description: Fueled by a hefty dose of liberal guilt and propelled by an earnest desire to understand his fellow citizens a young white playwright-performer leaves the comfort of his native San Francisco on a cross-country road trip.

title: Only Perfect
description: If Wichita States players have been a bit dismissive of their 34-0 record, it is not because they have not accomplished much. An undefeated regular season for a mens college basketball team is nothing to sniff at. But the Shockers also know the record will fall into the dustbin of history if they do not follow up with an N.C.A.A. title, a midmajor team that could not shake the mid. But if the Shockers win the N.C.A.A. championship, they will join rarefied air occupied by the likes of Bill Russell, John Wooden, Lew Alcindor, Bill Walton, Frank McGuire and Indianas most Hoosier-like set of Hoosiers.

title: Only Perfect
description: Seven Division I mens basketball teams have finished undefeated seasons with an N.C.A.A. championship, starting with San Francisco in 1956 and ending with Indiana in 1976.

title: A New Cruise on the Loire
description: Europes booming river cruise industry has set its sights on the Loire in France, where the M.S. Loire Princesse, the first riverboat with overnight cabins to cruise this river, will launch next year.

title: Data Deleted From Flight 370 Simulator
description: Malaysias defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said the investigating teams were trying to recover data deleted from a flight simulator built by the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.

title: If These Walls Could Talk
description: The restoration of a storied French neo-Classical salon reveals as much about polite society as it does about high design.

title: New York Courts Cut Time Between Arrest and Arraignment
description: For two decades, court officials in New York City have struggled to solve a vexing problem: reducing the arrest-to-arraignment time in its criminal courts.

title: Labyrinth Announces Readings of Pulitzer-Winning Plays
description: The Academy Award winner Ellen Burstyn, the Obie winner Eric Bogosian, and other members of Labyrinth Theater Company will take part in a weeklong series of readings of Pulitzer Prize-winning plays in April, the company announced on Wednesday.

title: Judge Sides with F.T.C. in Payday Lending Case
description: A United States District Court judge has reinforced the Federal Trade Commissions authority to go after payday lenders that claim their ties to Native American tribes make them immune to laws restricting high-cost loans.

title: Hey, Hey, Hey! Animated Touchstones
description: Growing up in the 1970s at opposite ends of New York State, two girls were immersed in all things cool, black and funky.

title: Two Officers Killed by Militants, Egypt Says
description: CAIRO  Islamist militants killed an Egyptian brigadier general and a colonel in an early-morning gun battle in the Nile Delta province of Qalyubeya, the Interior Ministry said Wednesday.

title: Live Blog: Yellen and the Fed
description: Janet Yellen met the media Wednesday for the first time as Federal Reserve chairwoman, after the conclusion of her first meeting leading the central banks policy committee. Here is an account of the events as they unfolded.

title: French Court Upholds Prison Term for Rogue Socit Gnrale Trader
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel, the former trader convicted of rogue dealings at Socit Gnrale, was walking through the Italian countryside on Wednesday on his 900-mile trek to Paris when he received a text from his lawyer that a court had upheld his three-year prison sentence for fraud against the French bank.

title: Discovering Two Screens Arent Better Than One
description: For years, techies have argued that getting an extra monitor or two for your desktop computer is an especially effective way to increase personal productivity. The logic seemed airtight: Two (or more) computer monitors means more room on your virtual desktop, which means more room to do your work. And more room to work would seem to mean faster work.

title: Scene City: A Dragon Holds Court in Lincoln Center
description: Cast of HBOs Game of Thrones premieres fourth season with a flaming museum party.

title: The Billion Dollar Bracket Challenge Is Really a Hundred Thousand Dollar Lottery
description: Technically its true that if you register online for the Quicken Loans Billion Dollar Bracket Challenge by March 20, and fill out a perfect N.C.A.A. mens tournament bracket, you could win a billion dollarscourtesy of Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway, which is insuring the prize. But even though its sort of free to enter (more on the sort of later) its not worth your time.

title: Please Tell Me You Didnt Cut That Part
description: Theres a scene in the 2010 film The Twilight Saga: Eclipse in which Bella (Kristen Stewart), the movies teenage heroine, gets on the back of a motorcycle owned by Jacob, a werewolf. She does so unprompted, at least in part to get under the skin of her beau, Edward, who is a vampire. In the book, however, Jacob has to persuade Bella to get on his motorcycle, which she does. See the difference? If youre a young or even not-so-young fan of the wildly popular Twilight series, you sure do.

title: The Pleasures of Plain Rap
description: The virtues of simplicity are many, and also too easily dismissed. In hip-hop especially, where complexity is too often equated with progress, the straightforward can get a bad rap. And yet its music like this, distilled down to first principles, that moves the genre, and gives it many of its signature moments.

title: Q. and A. With Fiorentinas Giuseppe Rossi
description: Giuseppe Rossi grew up in Clifton, N.J., but never played soccer in high school or college in the United States (or for the United States national team). Instead, he joined the youth academy of Parma of Italys Serie A as a 12-year-old. His professional career has taken him to Manchester United (England); Newcastle (England) and Parma on loan; Villarreal (Spain); and back to Italy with his current club, Fiorentina. Before an ankle injury in January, Rossi was leading Serie A in goals. He was back in the United States recently to treat and rehabilitate his right knee and to visit family. He returned to Italy on Wednesday ahead of Fiorentinas Europa League game against Juventus on Thursday, but not before an interview with The Times.

title: Protein May Hold the Key to Who Gets Alzheimers
description: It is one of the big scientific mysteries of Alzheimers disease: Why do some people whose brains accumulate the plaques and tangles so strongly associated with Alzheimers not develop the disease?

title: Mood Enhancers That Recharge
description: Hauz Khas Village in New Delhi is a cultural hub filled with 13th-century monuments, bars with local bands playing U2 covers and trendy boutiques. Rahul Kumar was strolling through the neighborhood wearing a red vest inspired by Jawaharlal Nehru, the former prime minister, plus purple pants and lace-up boots. Mr. Kumar said he frequents the neighborhood, which he considers the most stylish in the city, to draw inspiration from locals who mix traditional and modern styles.

title: Fed Cuts Bond Buying by Another $10 Billion
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve further curtailed its economic stimulus campaign on Wednesday, even as it said the effort would continue for the foreseeable future given the enduring consequences of the Great Recession.

title: Decoding the Feds Statement
description: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.

title: At Trial, Son-in-Law Recalls a Cave Meeting With Bin Laden on 9/11
description: It was some hours after the World Trade Center towers had been toppled when Sulaiman Abu Ghaith was summoned to a meeting with Osama bin Laden. He recalled a three-hour-or-so drive into the night, finding the leader of Al Qaeda in a cave amid the mountains in Afghanistan.

title: Sundance Institute to Look at the Little Picture
description: LOS ANGELES  As the creative heart of Hollywood beats ever closer to television, one of the film industrys most important training grounds  the Sundance Institutes workshops  is adding a small-screen spinoff.

title: Two States Win Court Approval on Voter Rules
description: PHOENIX  A federal judge in Kansas on Wednesday ordered federal election authorities to help Kansas and Arizona require proof of citizenship of registering voters, in a decision that could well set a trend for other Republican-dominated states.

title: Frozen Back to No. 1; Happy Is Top Single
description: The effect was not instantaneous, but the Oscars that Disneys Frozen won for both best animated feature and best original song (Let It Go) seems to have helped push the soundtrack recording back to the top of the Billboard album chart for a sixth nonconsecutive week. (The Oscars were awarded on March 2. The new Billboard chart measures sales for the week ending on March 16.)

title: The Gun Report: March 19, 2014
description: According to a new report by the Center for American Progress, gun violence is devastating millennials. Those born after 1980 are four times more likely to die by gunfire than their counterparts in Canada, seven times more likely than those in Israel, and 65 times more likely than those in the United Kingdom. This, despite the fact that violent crime has declined in recent years.

title: Flappy Gameplay Beyond the Fourth Wall
description: The most obvious problem with Flappy Bird was that players couldnt flap their arms along with the titular character. Fortunately, NYT developer Alistair Coote is here to help, with his amazing, WebRTC-backed Flappy Arms. Read about how he did it on his blog  and have a go. (Mobile phone not included.)

title: News Release Distributor to Stop Selling to High-Speed Traders
description: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, can count another victory in his quest to curb some of the advantages enjoyed by the fastest traders on Wall Street.

title: Letters: Peyton Place Revisited
description: Peyton Place Revisited

title: A Pet-Friendly Place in Stamford, Conn.
description: For Kathie Nurena and Mike Taylor, the decision to move was 100 percent canine-driven.

title: Suitcase Full of Cash Gives a Youth Program New Life
description: More than 200 students from Cardinal Newman Catholic School, in Brampton, Ontario, filed into the Canadian Broadcasting Centre to cheer on the popular eighth-grade teacher from Room 26. It was January 2007, and Mike George was about to be on television.

title: Mining the Past and Sharing the Plenty
description: Cassandra Wilson, a singer who is not known for indelicate music, put on a bright red electric guitar on Sunday night and played a loud, dissonant solo  gestural, atmospheric, raw, tentative and interestingly brave. It was during an original, riff-driven, North Mississippi kind of electric blues called Black Sun, and she was performing in a band called Black Sun.

title: Baked to Death on Rikers Island
description: The American corrections system is teeming with mentally ill people who have been arrested for misbehaviors related to their illnesses. Those who present little or no danger to the public  and there are many  belong in psychiatric care instead of jails, where they are at greater risk of suicide and other forms of harm, primarily because the corrections staff is ill-equipped to care for them.

title: Alter Ego Rattles Authors Ego
description: LIVINGSTON, Mont.  Standing over an open suitcase inside his office here, the journalist and novelist Walter Kirn is preparing for a six-week book tour, trying to squeeze his life inside a carry-on. The trick is to wear the nicer, costlier items  the ones that need ironing if they get wrinkled  and pack the rest, he says, rolling up a pair of cotton briefs into a tight, cigarlike cylinder. He sets the undergarment, which is zebra striped, into the case beside three other pairs that range from polka dot to paisley. I like to wear strong patterns against my skin, he says, pitching his voice low, as though to share a tip that I dont recall soliciting. It gives me a wonderful feeling of inner confidence.

title: The Berber Decorative Tradition, an Inspiration to Yves Saint Laurent
description: During the decades they spent holidaying in Morocco, Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berg became captivated by the culture of the native Berber, or Amazigh, tribe, which has inhabited North Africa for 9,000 years. The extensive collection of Berber art and artifacts the couple acquired from the 60s until Saint Laurents death in 2008 is now housed at the Muse Berbre at the duos Jardin Majorelle studio villa in Marrakesh. Beginning Friday, the pieces will appear for the first time in the West  alongside a trove of art and objects from private collectors and the Muse du Quai Branly  in the show Berber Women of Morocco at Pariss Fondation Pierre Berg  Yves Saint Laurent. More than 600 intricately detailed decorative objects, including headpieces, jewelry, carpets, textiles, furniture, pottery and one spectacular set of handcarved kohl eyeliner pots, will share space with drawings by the French artist Titouan Lamazou and archival photographs of Berber women sporting the tribes traditional dress. Those familiar with YSLs oeuvre will no doubt spot the influence on the designers work. But whats especially uncanny is how on-point the womens look  layers, volume, insouciant accessorizing  feels today.

title: Gleaned From eBay, the Artifacts of an Era
description: A new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society sheds light on the Black Five basketball franchises from the first half of the 20th century.

title: Every Dog Has Its Daybed
description: ORLANDO, FLA.  The takeaway from the Global Pet Expo, at which 985 exhibitors of pet products were spread out over 13 football fields worth of real estate in the Orange County Convention Center here, is that Americans really love their dogs. And yet, perhaps as a result of so much love, those dogs are increasingly anxious, bored, overweight, messy and have terrible breath. They suffer from separation anxiety and they worry about thunderstorms, traffic noises, visitors and vacuum cleaners.
