Their joints ache, and they eat too fast; they chew the furniture and bedevil the neighbors with their barking. Also, drool happens.

title: In a Show of Early-Music Vigor, a Lofty Commitment Is Confirmed
description: The tremendous improvement in early-music performance in New York over the last decade has tended to come in flashes and bursts. Unevenness has typically remained a part of the package.

title: Gains Reported in Removing Syrian Chemical Supplies
description: Nearly half of Syrias chemical stockpile for weapons use has now been removed from the war-ravaged country, the organization helping to oversee the elimination of the deadly arsenal reported on Wednesday.

title: Holder Discusses Toyotas Settlement
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that Toyota had reached a $1.2 billion deal with the Justice Department to settle a four-year criminal investigation.

title: A reading of Icebergs, Ilulissat by Jean Valentine
description: The American poet reads her ode to Greenland.

title: Russia Takes Crimean Naval Base
description: Ukrainian and Russian officials spoke in Sevastopol after militiamen, backed by Russian forces, seized the headquarters of the Ukrainian Navy and raised a Russian flag.

title: Does Texting at a Stop Sign Count?
description: Most drivers, teenage and adult, have received the message loud and clear: Dont text and drive.

title: A Chance to Hear the Music That Louis XIV Used to Eat Breakfast To
description: When the Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra, from Toronto, came to Zankel Hall in 2011, it offered as an encore a teaser drawn from the score of Marin Maraiss 1706 opera, Alcyone: a frisky Tambourins dance. On Monday evening in the same hall, that tease became an embrace, as the orchestra closed its concert with a full suite of sumptuous music from Alcyone, including a honeyed solo in the noble Sarabande from the violinist Jeanne Lamon, the groups music director since 1981.

title: Families of Missing Passengers Speak Out
description: Relatives of Chinese passengers onboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 demanded answers about the missing plane.

title: Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
description: HONG KONG  By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kongs growing Bitcoin scene.

title: Icahn Calls on eBay to Sell 20% of PayPal Unit to the Public
description: Carl C. Icahn hasnt let up his attack on eBay. But he has modified what he is demanding from the online commerce giant.

title: An Invisible Boy Keeps His Promise
description: When I was 8 years old, I watched my trial-lawyer father play Horace Vandergelder in the Livingston, N.J., community-theater production of Hello, Dolly! He entered wearing an enormous marching-band bass drum (the character is in a parade), and he roared to his sobbing niece, Dammit! How am I supposed to play Yonkers My Yonkers with all that bellowing in my ears! It was the most exciting thing I had ever seen.

title: Works of Varied Eras Set Side by Side Onstage
description: The repertoire of the Paul Taylor Dance Company currently includes 140 works. During its 60th anniversary season, the troupe is presenting 23 of them, mostly three at a time. Each combination exhibits Mr. Taylors vaunted range of subject matter, tone and approach, but too many also show a range in quality, setting the unforgettable next to the best forgotten. The two new pieces that Mr. Taylor adds each year are understandably hit and miss, but the misses are recycled along with the hits, mixed in with the misfires and masterpieces. The choices can make for a jolting theatrical experience.

title: Army General Apologizes to Victims of Misconduct Before Being Sentenced
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  On the eve of a decision about his sentence on sexual misconduct and other charges, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on Wednesday tearfully apologized to the women he had wronged, and to the Army where he had spent 27 years, saying that he felt a deep and abiding sense of shame and remorse.

title: Doctors Push Scrutiny for Smog Masks
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When smog descends on Beijing or other Asian cities, people rush to buy face masks.

title: Biden and Lithuanian President on Russia
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Dalia Grybauskaite of Lithuania gave joint statements at the presidential palace in Vilnius to address Russias intervention in Crimea.

title: Mobile Platforms
description: Trailer parks are Frank Rolfes world. And when you hear about some of the economics lessons being taught at Mobile Home University, the three-day seminars he puts on, you can see why. He and a partner own a hundred such parks in 16 states, and by placing what he calls a contrarian bet on a poorer America, they are making $30 million in yearly revenue, half of it profit.

title: Aretha Franklin to Headline the Blue Note Jazz Festival
description: The prize headliner in this years Blue Note Jazz Festival lineup is Aretha Franklin, who has had her share of dalliances with jazz, though her core and purpose lie elsewhere. Shell be far from the only artist fitting that description in the festivals fourth annual edition, running throughout June in more than a dozen spaces around New York.

title: Billy Crystal Returns to TV With New FX Comedy
description: In one more affirmation of the growing appeal of series television, Billy Crystal, who last starred in a sitcom in Soap in the late 1970s, will headline a new comedy series on the cable channel FX, the network announced Wednesday.

title: Busting the Brackets! Mathematics and the N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Overview | What are the odds of picking a perfect bracket? How can students put large numbers and small probabilities in context? In this lesson, students apply concepts of probability and explore the scale of extremely large and extremely small numbers by diving into March Madness and bracketology.

title: Warming Up to the Culture of Wikipedia
description: IF ever there was the antithesis of the crowd-sourced Wikipedia, it would be a museum, where an expert picks what is seen and not seen, then carefully prepares captions explaining what each piece of art means.

title: Breaking From Donor Dependence
description: ONE doesnt typically think of drawing visitors to a cultural institution with a sheepshearing festival. But that is part of the strategy of Gore Place, a historic house in Waltham, Mass., that also has a working farm.

title: Exhibition Traces a Career Dedicated to Mutability
description: ELIMINATING lead poisoning from the lives of children is not a typical goal of art. But for Mel Chin, the borders of art have long extended past the crafting of discrete objects.

title: The Mets Director Looks Ahead
description: IN the five years since Thomas P. Campbell became director and chief executive of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the museum world has had to grapple with declining philanthropic dollars, mushrooming entertainment options and a rapidly developing digital world. But in an interview, Mr. Campbell said he was optimistic about the publics appetite for museums in general and the Mets prospects in particular. This interview has been edited and condensed.

title: If You Cant Make It to the Lecture
description: JANIS LOEWENGART YERINGTON, an artist from Bolinas, Calif., became a fan of online museum lectures after seeing the touring Vermeer painting, Girl with a Pearl Earring, at the de Young Museum in San Francisco.

title: In Washington, 100 Examples of the Epitome of Cool
description: AMERICAN COOL is the kind of exhibition many people will find irresistible. This exploration of 100 cultural figures at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington first takes a persona that inspires emulation, and then offers up the avatars in classic celebrity photographs, some by master portraitists like Richard Avedon, Diane Arbus and Henri-Cartier Bresson. And it is the exhibit that keeps on giving. By the time you leave, youll have enough material for hours of earnest cocktail party debates over the selection.

title: Minnesota Makes Do Without a Civil War Battlefield
description: ST. PAUL  THE Civil War seems a long way from St. Paul: 1,100 miles to Manassas; 1,000 miles to Gettysburg. Even the nearest battlefields, in Missouri, are hundreds of miles away.

title: Entering World of Literatures Great Sleuth
description: SINISTER blood splatters, concealed clues and murder most foul are just part of the fun at The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes, now at the Center of Science and Industry in Columbus, Ohio. The 10,000-square-foot traveling exhibition is an ambitious and multifaceted presentation of the most famous detective of English literary fiction, his creator, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, and more than 125 years of Sherlockian lore.

title: Monuments Man in War, Conservator in Peace
description: BY now, much of the moviegoing world is familiar with The Monuments Men, an art-historical film that sees George Clooney, Matt Damon and other stars swashbuckling around Europe during World War II, trying to save masterpieces like the Ghent Altarpiece and a Rembrandt self-portrait from bombs and the clutches of German and Russian troops. As the film opens, Mr. Clooneys character is seen addressing President Roosevelt, trying to persuade him to help safeguard Europes cultural patrimony.

title: Making Devices Child-Friendly
description: Molly Wood offers tips for parents to make their tablets and smartphones more child-friendly before handing them over.

title: Is There a Doctor in the Exhibition?
description: A POISON of choice since antiquity, belladonna has been linked to witches, sorcerers, kings and queens  all with murder on their minds. Also known as deadly nightshade, it is part of the Medicinal and Poison Plants Tour at the United States Botanic Garden, said Beth Burrous, the tours creator.

title: What Comes Next, After the Troops Are Dismissed
description: THE furor over the possible sale of the collection at the Detroit Institute of Arts  a prospect that seems in abeyance for now  reminds the art world of the flip side of its relentless focus on expansions, additions and growth: Sometimes museums close.

title: Shedding a Light on Islamic Arts Great Treasure
description: SABIHA AL KHEMIR was visiting a solar energy plant in Spain about four years ago when inspiration struck. Her host, the foundation of a Spanish company with interests in alternative energy, wanted her to conceive an Islamic art exhibition for Seville to recognize Spains 800-year history under Moorish rule and ideally to tie her concept into the Seville-based companys work. Touring the solar plant, the Tunisian-born curator found her organizing principle.

title: Motowns Link to Civil Rights Movement on Display
description: THE story of Motown Records can be told in many ways. It can be presented as a tale of musical revolution, the creation of a sound steeped in gospel and blues but packed with endlessly inventive pop hooks. There is also the business story of the founder, Berry Gordy Jr.; for a time in the 1960s, Motown was the largest black-owned company in America.

title: Soliciting Funds From the Crowd? Results Will Vary
description: ESTABLISHED museums like the Smithsonian Institution are increasingly turning to crowdfunding appeals to help pay for exhibits and programs that tight budgets might otherwise preclude.

title: Remembering the Black Fives of Pro Basketball
description: ROSENA DISERY, a teenager at the New York African Free School in 1820, surely knew nothing about basketball when she stitched a silk-on-wool sampler with words from the poem Self-Love and Truth Incompatible.

title: After the Exhibition, Finding New Uses for Displays
description: MAKING what is old new again with fresh displays has long been the province of museums. But what happens to all the stuff left over when shows end? Many museums are going beyond traditional recycling efforts and giving second lives to exhibit materials.

title: Start-Up Success Isnt Enough to Found a Museum
description: WHEN the idea for the Museum of Science Fiction struck Greg Viggiano last April, he shot into warp speed. He wrote a business plan, picked Washington as a prospective location, recruited volunteers and produced a video featuring befuddled Imperial storm troopers, armed with maps, searching for the phantom museum near the United States Capitol. Mr. Viggiano used the video as part of a crowdfunding campaign that has raised almost $48,000, an amount he described as a rounding error in terms of how much were going to need.

title: In Boston, Altering the Artist-in-Residence Concept
description: COLLABORATIONS among museums and artists-in-residence typically culminate in a single artwork or event. More unusual is the one between Matthew Ritchie and the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston. During his 18-month residency, he is producing a series of related artworks and performances in and near the museum that weave Boston and the institute into an abstract narrative of past, present and future.

title: At Play in Skies of Cretaceous Era
description: When viewed from Central Park West, where it straddles four blocks like a castle, the American Museum of Natural History can seem like a fusty place  the neo-Classical idea of the museum, as David Harvey, its senior vice president for exhibition, put it. In the popular imagination, or perhaps just Ben Stillers imagination, its a retro-cool place filled with dioramas that are put together by curators who are part-time taxidermists.

title: Golden Age of Discovery ... Down in the Basements
description: GALLERIES usually get all the publicity, but at many museums the biggest news is happening in the basement.

title: Wooing a New Generation of Museum Patrons
description: Several hundred millennials mingled under the soaring atrium of the Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue one recent frigid February night. Weaving around them were black-clad servers bearing silver trays piled high with doughnuts, while a pixieish D.J. spun Daft Punk remixes.

title: Only on Reality TV: Old Vaults That Keep on Giving
description: Apparently all the abandoned storage lockers have finally been opened.

title: New Insights Into History May Skew the Big Picture
description: Museums are born to wrestle with history. What else, after all, is a museum but a collection of objects gathered to shape a narrative, to assert an interpretation, to evoke memory and reaction  in other words, to make a history? So when I complain, as I often do in making my critical rounds, about the way history is treated in museums, how could it be otherwise? History  particularly in nonart museums  is the point. And it is bound to be an issue of debate.

title: Door to Art of the World, Barely Ajar
description: On a pay-what-you-wish Saturday evening in late February, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum rotunda was dense with visitors to a new show, Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe.

title: For LWren Scott, Her Identity Was by Design
description: It was a crowded cocktail party at the Cafe Royal in London on a balmy February night. As hundreds of people mingled in the ornate, recently renovated space, one of the attendees, an editor who had gone to LWren Scotts fall 2013 fashion show that day, stood in a corner making small talk with Bobbi Brown, the cosmetics entrepreneur, and John Demsey, the president of Este Lauder.

title: David Frum to Join The Atlantic
description: The conservative commentator and author David Frum is joining The Atlantic at the end of the month as a senior editor with a focus on politics and national affairs, the publication announced Wednesday afternoon.

title: Turning a Tablet Into a Childs Interactive TV
description: MY son has been having conversations with imaginary characters. I know, because I can listen to some of them, and even see pictures.

title: NATO Weighs Assistance for Ukraine to Dissuade Further Moves by Moscow
description: WASHINGTON  The secretary general of NATO, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, said on Wednesday that the alliance was considering providing assistance to Ukraine to help deter Russia from another military intervention there.

title: Measuring Americas Shakespearean Devotion
description: New York has been handed a surplus of Shakespeare over the last six months. To celebrate the 450th anniversary of his birth, there were eight Broadway and Off Broadway productions on offer  enough, surely, for even the most ravenous Shakespearean appetite. But to a 19th-century American, this stuffed schedule might well look like slim pickings.

title: Toyota Settlement Blazes Path for G.M.
description: Toyotas settlement with the Justice Department on vehicle defects is yet another example of how covering up misconduct results in far greater penalties than the underlying violation. For General Motors, the settlement provides a template for resolving a growing investigation into faulty ignition switches that caused a number of deaths.

title: German Energy Push Runs Into Problems
description: BERLIN  It is Germanys national goal: to have the bulk of its energy supplied by renewable power sources by 2050, without endangering the countrys powerful industrial sector or an export-based economy that is the envy of other Europeans.

title: In Hong Kong, Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
description: HONG KONG  By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kongs growing Bitcoin scene.

title: If He Says Its Funny, Its Funny
description: If anyone is entitled to pepper his memoir with New Yorker cartoons, its the cartoon editor of The New Yorker. So Bob Mankoffs new book is half prose, half illustrations and tirelessly playful. But the artwork and text work together to tell a fizzy, jokey story about a long and busy career. Its title, How About Never  Is Never Good for You? comes from a famous Mankoff cartoon that depicts a businessman on the telephone, dodging a lunch date. Now around 70, Mr. Mankoff depicts himself with a big grin and a lipstick mark on his forehead, saying those words to the Grim Reaper.

title: Some Cold Medicines May Have Higher-Than-Expected Levels of a Decongestant
description: Some widely used over-the-counter cold and flu medicines may be exposing patients to unexpectedly high amounts of one ingredient, revealing a lapse in regulations and perhaps raising safety concerns, a company that develops such drugs reported on Wednesday.

title: In Words and Photos, Cramming in Life
description: On a recent visit to the International Center of Photography, the Nigerian-American author and photographer Teju Cole leaned forward to study an image by Robert Capa. It offered an aerial view of the Place de la Concorde in Paris, bustling with traffic, sunlight filtering through a blanket of clouds. Mr. Cole admiringly listed its elements and expressed a preference for expansive photos like this one.

title: Malaysias Deep Political Rifts Exposed Amid Mystery of Missing Flight
description: GEORGE TOWN, Malaysia  Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, missing since March 8, is rapidly becoming a hot political issue in this country, with opposition politicians caustically criticizing the governments handling of the search for the jet even as the government has focused public attention on the flights pilot, a supporter of the opposition.

title: Art Around the Country
description: A sampling of works from current and coming exhibitions at museums in the United States.

title: In the Eye of a Superstorm, Their Close-Ups
description: Photographers with work in the Rising Waters: Photographs of Sandy exhibition share the stories behind their images.

title: Nobody Could Have Predicted, Monetary Edition
description: Brad DeLong and Josh Bivens send us to a House hearing on monetary policy, in which three conservatives explain why it was totally forgivable for everyone on their side to predict runaway inflation from the Feds expansion of the monetary base, and why the failure of that inflation to appear says nothing at all about possible flaws in their approach.

title: Hurricane Sandy Revisited and Unleashed Through a Photographic Vision
description: Chris Ozer was watching television and web coverage of the approaching Hurricane Sandy. He did not like the looks of it.

title: Yellen on Feds Stimulus Campaign
description: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, spoke at a news conference after the Fed announced it would reduce its monthly bond purchases because of the economic recoverys progress.

title: Exploring Modern Ruins in Southern California
description: California has always been linked with the idea of American possibility. Its the sun-drenched place where you go to leave the stuffy, decaying old world for a new life. But not everything here is shiny, new and full of potential. Drive deep into the deserted corners of Southern California and youll find dreams that flickered to life briefly and then faded away. Places once destined for greatness that have disintegrated into modern ruins. These arent Wild West ghost towns but more recent vestiges of the 20th century.

title: Judges Order on Voter Proof of Citizenship
description: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered the U.S. Election Assistance Commission to help Kansas and Arizona enforce laws requiring new voters to provide proof of their U.S. citizenship.

title: Pictures of the Day  Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine, the West Bank, Afghanistan and More: Pictures of the Day

title: Want to Vote? Show Us Your Papers
description: There isnt a state in the country that allows non-citizens to vote. And there is no evidence that people who are in the country illegally want to vote, or have tried in any significant number. But that hasnt stopped Arizona and Kansas from insisting on proof of citizenship in order to register, knowing full well that the legitimate voters who will have the most trouble coming up with that proof tend to lean Democratic.

title: The Embodiment of American Cool
description: An exploration of 100 cultural figures at the National Portrait Gallery takes a persona that inspires emulation and offers up the avatars in classic celebrity photographs.

title: The Challenge of Pluralism
description: In a defense of religious liberty thats basically written to reassure liberals that they can support something called religious freedom without conceding an inch to actual-existing dissenters from liberalisms preferred legal and regulatory regime, Emily Bazelon offers a formulation that hints at why religious and ideological pluralism, so honored in theory, is often hard for people to get behind in practice:

title: Ways to Apply Fuchsia, the Hot Makeup Color
description: Not quite red and not quite pink, vivid fuchsia is a good (and suddenly ubiquitous) makeup shade for the transition from winter to spring.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine, the West Bank, Afghanistan and Taiwan.

title: An Unrewarded Leap of Faith
description: I SHOULD STATE up front that Im wearing Air Jordans as I write this: black-and-cement retro 3s. Mostly I wear 3s and 4s, though lately Ive been tempted by 6s, 10s and 12s. I gave up on 1s a few years ago, though that feels foolish to admit. Ill only end up reclaiming them a few years from now. I firmly believe you can tell someones age (and taste level) by which generation of Jordan is the holy grail. (Would a grown-up really entertain, say, 24s?) I have formal occasion Jordans, day-to-day Jordans, Jordans that go with exactly one item of clothing in my closet, dirty outdoor festival Jordans, rain Jordans and house Jordans.

title: Dustin Yellin: Opening Doors, Opening Eyes
description: There are so many keys attached to Dustin Yellins jeans, its a wonder he is not a locksmith.

title: Riding the Wave of Girls
description: We definitely have to go dancing tonight. AndrewAndrew is D.J.ing at Greenhouse.  Elijah, to Hannah, Girls Episode 3, Season 2.

title: Spring North American Championships Start in Dallas
description: The 11-day Spring North American Championships, organized by the American Contract Bridge League, start on Wednesday in Dallas.

title: Beneath Their Feet, a Foundation of Ideas
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Its too bad the dance detail in Wayne McGregors choreography is seldom of any interest because so many surrounding features of his wordless theater are admirable and arresting. He uses new music (live), new lighting, new designs and video technology in combinations that make you want to acclaim him as an heir to Diaghilev. The way he has employed computers makes him sound like the successor to Merce Cunningham. And his collaborations with science and medicine (in experimental psychology, heart-imaging work, creative cognition study, all at university level) could not be more commendable. Also, he is English-born, and his family name implies Celtic stock  so I feel we chaps ought to stick together. But most of his dances, alas, go in one eye and out the other.

title: Makeup That Addresses the Many Shades of Women
description: In 1994, when the Somali supermodel Iman started her cosmetics line based on foundations in a broad range of colors, she said she wasnt interested in ethnicity or race. The mission statement has not changed, she said one morning not long ago. It was for women of skin of color and addressing skin tone.

title: Music Has Southern Roots, but Lyrics May Travel
description: An eight-member band, with as many as four guitars upfront, rarely sounds as serenely contained as Rosanne Cashs concert did on Tuesday night at Town Hall. Ms. Cash started the concert performing all 11 songs from her superb new album, The River & the Thread (Blue Note), her first collection of new material since Black Cadillac in 2006. The music is understated; the ideas are large.

title: At the Game of Thrones Premiere, Even the Dragons Behaved
description: As far as events go, you cant get much worse than the Red Wedding, the infamous climax of last seasons Game of Thrones, the HBO fantasy series. Fortunately, the premiere of its fourth season, shown Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, was cheerier: for one, there were no visible impalings (at least in real life).

title: Political Views Test the Harmony
description: Like most seasoned conductors, Zubin Mehta has built his reputation on interpretations of a core repertory, in his case the music of Romantic-era giants like Bruckner, Tchaikovsky and Mahler. But on tour with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, an ensemble that named him music director for life in 1981, he is increasingly in demand for his exegesis of a long-winded drama fueled by high passions of a different kind: Middle East politics.

title: Two Bands Chances to Show Growth
description: Modern mainstream rock is thankless work, an ouroboros of familiar ideas that is notable mainly for managing not to atrophy into total disappearance. It is a space of diminished influence and relevance, a haven for the dull and complacent.

title: Spring Fashion That Makes a Statement
description: Think of it as power dressing with a sense of humor. Pinstripes were taken for a playful spin at the round of fashion shows just ended. The young woman on the left calls to mind a Blond Ambition"-era Madonna in her double-breasted bustier top and matching pants, which she wore with cold-weather layers and lighthearted accessories. The model and blogger Zanita Morgan wore wide-leg Acne pinstripe pants, with a dark coat and sneakers; the front-row fixture Miroslava Duma was coolly chic in a Salvatore Ferragamo pinstripe suit and a bustier top; and the stylist Ece Skan wore a pinstripe suit with a turtleneck, the skirt slit up to there. This is a trend just about any woman can embrace. Dig into your wardrobe or invest in new pinstripes, like the smart Acne suit at right  and have a little fun. You can always style your pinstripes more soberly for business hours.

title: Art Matters | The Thing About Noah and the Ark
description: Darren Aronofsky explains why he decided to take on the fantastical Bible story in his new film and curate an art show about it.

title: What Lies Beneath
description: I came cold to the Supreme Courts most recent decision, by which I mean that I hadnt read the briefs or the argument transcript, let alone attended the argument itself. In fact, I confess to having known nothing about the case, Marvin M. Brandt Revocable Trust v. United States, before I downloaded the opinion from the courts website.

title: What Does $1.8 Billion Get You in Mens Wear?
description: A MAN IN NEED OF A SUIT AND TIE has an ample resource just west of Grand Central Terminal. There along Madison Avenue, a mens wear corridor has taken shape over the years. It is less sexy than stretches of Madison farther north, where Prada squares off against Gucci; more fit for a salaryman than a rou. Down in the East 40s, a more orderly air pervades. The options are many for the traditionally minded gent. Paul Stuart and the Brooks Brothers are the grand old men.

title: On Mobile Devices, Narrowing Choices for Your Child
description: TABLETS and phones are increasingly the new television and entertainment devices for our children. But they dont have to be a free-for-all of screen time, app downloading or inappropriate content discovery.

title: Suppliers of Jet Parts Require Greater Oversight, Report Says
description: The major systems on Boeings 787 Dreamliner jets are safe and well designed, but federal regulators need to provide more oversight of the far-flung supply networks that are building these and other new planes today, according to a report released on Wednesday.

title: More Than 2,000 Migrants Rescued Off Italian Coast
description: ROME  Italian Navy and Coast Guard vessels rescued about 2,400 migrants coming from North Africa over the past two days, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: Cultural Exchange
description: All three of Dinaw Mengestus novels are about people who, for various reasons, come to this country and fashion new lives. But it would be a huge mistake  it would be an insult, in fact  to call him a novelist of the immigrant experience or a chronicler of life on the hyphen or any of the other shabby, summary clichs deployed to characterize (and too often diminish and even dismiss) authors whose birth certificates identify them as foreign-born. For while questions of race, ethnicity and point of origin do crop up repeatedly in Mengestus fiction, they are merely his raw materials, the fuel with which he so artfully  but never didactically  kindles disruptive, disturbing stories exploring the puzzles of identity, place and human connection.

title: An Asian Pioneer of Free Games Aims for a Bigger Profile in the West
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It could be argued that Nexon has changed how games are experienced more than almost any other company. Yet relatively few people in the United States even know it exists.

title: A Benefit for All Tastes
description: Who will create the most evocative dinnertime aura inside the yawning hangarlike space of Pier 94? This weekend, more than 30 designers and their sponsors display inventive dining room installations for the 17th annual Diffa Dining by Design benefit exhibition and dinner.

title: Sales at Lumens, Property, Roubini Rugs and Others
description: Some lighting and furniture are up to 40 percent off at Lumens, through March 27 (the AJ table lamp by Arne Jacobsen for Louis Poulsen, regularly $1,018, now starts at about $865); 877-445-4486, lumens.com.

title: Not Big-City Types But Still Sophisticated
description: The 100 antique rugs and textiles collected for Art in Bloom, an exhibition and sale at the Kentshire Galleries in Manhattan and on 1stdibs.com, are village rugs as opposed to the city rug, said Peter Pap, the San Francisco-based dealer who curated the sale.

title: A History of Bath Fixtures, by Appointment
description: The DXV by American Standard showroom, which opened last week in the Flatiron district, is a bit of a tease. The storefront at 15 West 20th Street offers window displays by local interior designers that change monthly. But you will have to make an effort to view the bath and kitchen fixtures inside  examples of the companys new DXV collection inspired by the styles of four epochs in American Standards 150-year history. The space is not staffed and is accessible by appointment only (send requests to dxvappt@dxv.com). Once granted entrance, should you fall in love with, say, the Fitzgerald Two-Piece Elongated Toilet ($760), from the Golden Era Movement section, you can order it from a distributor. We want to democratize luxury by making it part of a conversation and engaging the community with this space, said Jay Gould, the companys chief executive. Information: 732-980-3040 or dxv.com.

title: Hand-Dyed Pillows With Reversible Detail
description: Rebecca Atwood is a pragmatist. I studied painting at Rhode Island School of Design and realized that textiles were the closest thing to painting that I could do as a job, said Ms. Atwood, a 29-year-old Brooklyn designer.

title: Yankees Who Speak Cantonese
description: Thousands of Chinese immigrants working at southeastern Connecticut casinos have adapted mid-20th-century ranch houses to their native traditions and the demands of communal living. Stephen Fan, 31, an architectural designer who grew up in Norwich, Conn., and runs a firm with projects from New York to Boston, has studied front-yard melon patches, garages turned into sociable sitting porches, and narrow, repartitioned bedrooms for Sub Urbanisms: Casino Company-town, China-town, an exhibition at the Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London through May 12. (The museum is publishing a book based on the show, and a related symposium will be held March 29.)

title: How Can I Update My Kitchen Pass-Through?
description: Q. My kitchen has a pass-through that looks out of date. How can I improve it?

title: Sectional Sofas: Legos You Can Sit On
description: Unlike ordinary sofas, sectionals have a special ability. They make a space within a space, always, Adam Rolston said. Theyre the most architectural of interior furnishings.

title: The 28-Year Plan
description: When Jonathan and Wendy Segal moved to San Diego, it was 1984 and they were both 22, newly graduated from the University of Idaho. They arrived with just $350 between them, in a beat-up 1968 Rambler, one of its doors roped shut. Yet as they drove the winding streets of the citys affluent La Jolla section, gazing at the grand ocean-view homes, Ms. Segal sang out, This is it: our dream neighborhood!

title: Meet Me in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  It seemed like such a simple question.

title: Former Prime Minister Indicted During Raucous Hearing in Bangladesh
description: KOLKATA, India  A former Bangladeshi prime minister and other opposition leaders were indicted on Wednesday during a raucous court hearing in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The indictments, stemming from two long-delayed corruption cases, could further inflame the countrys already tense political situation.

title: Muscle Head
description: Feel the burn! That was Jane Fonda in 1982, exhorting the viewers of her first-of-its-kind workout video to engage in an exotic pursuit called exercise. In her striped leotard and legwarmers, Fonda led the charge against the generally held opinion that exercise was a weird waste of time. (In those days, lifting weights was for Charles Atlas aspirants, and jogging was for quirky health nuts.) The tireless exertions of Fonda  and of tiny-shorted Richard Simmons and toothy Judi Sheppard Missett, the founder of Jazzercise  were ultimately wildly successful, making what was then an eccentric choice into what is now practically an obligation. Today we all exercise, or at least know we should.

title: After the Protests
description: LAST Wednesday, more than 100,000 people showed up in Istanbul for a funeral that turned into a mass demonstration. No formal organization made the call. The news had come from Twitter: Berkin Elvan, 15, had died. He had been hit in the head by a tear-gas canister on his way to buy bread during the Gezi protests last June. During the 269 days he spent in a coma, Berkins face had become a symbol of civic resistance shared on social media from Facebook to Instagram, and the response, when his family tweeted we lost our son and then a funeral date, was spontaneous.

title: How to Punish Putin
description: MOSCOW  AS I write this, I am under house arrest. I was detained at a rally in support of anti-Putin protesters who were jailed last month.

title: Shopping Openings and Events for the Week of March 19
description: Hitting the Racks

title: Pilot of Missing Jet Expressed Interest in Democracy and Atheism on Social Networks
description: Updated, Thursday, 2:06 p.m. | As my colleagues Chris Buckley and Michael Schmidt report, in the absence of any solid information about what happened to the Malaysia Airlines flight that went missing March 8, Malaysian authorities are looking for clues in the deleted memory of the flight simulator that the planes pilot, Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah, kept in his home.

title: Pakistan Vows to Improve Journalists Freedom and Safety
description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan promised on Wednesday to improve journalists safety and freedom to work, saying his government would investigate targeted violence, ease visa and travel restrictions, and immediately review the blacklisting of The New York Timess Pakistan bureau chief, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists advocacy group.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 85
description: Josip Simunic, a defender for Croatia, will almost certainly miss the World Cup after FIFA upheld a 10-game international ban for leading fans in Zagreb in a pro-Nazi chant.

title: Wizard of Westwood
description: To be a college basketball fan today is to be an initiate in the cult of the coach. With the games best players staying in school only one or two years before taking their talents to the N.B.A., its the men wearing the sharp suits and pacing the sidelines who are the sports constants. They are the faces of their teams, the true stars of March Madness.

title: U.N. Stymied in Efforts to Take Aid to Syrians
description: UNITED NATIONS  In the three weeks since the United Nations Security Council ordered Syrias warring parties to let aid workers deliver food and medicine, the world bodys relief agencies have suspended their efforts to cross one land border, are waiting to cross another and are facing severe difficulties getting food into a Damascus neighborhood where children are starving.

title: David Sive, a Father of Environmental Law and Advocacy, Dies at 91
description: David Sive, considered one of the founders of environmental law, who argued precedent-setting cases and helped establish a string of advocacy groups when such issues had barely penetrated public consciousness, died on March 12 in West Orange, N.J. He was 91.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Hurleys Smarter
description: This week, Dan Hurley talks about his new book, Smarter: The New Science of Building Brain Power; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jason Zengerle discusses Seth Daviss new biography of John Wooden; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. John Williams is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Hurleys Smarter
description: This week, Dan Hurley and Jason Zengerle.

title: Young Golfers Enter Game Outside of Woodss Shadow
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Patrick Reed, 23, a two-time winner on the PGA Tour in 2014, is part of the latest wave of young golfers to crash ashore and churn the rankings. The worlds top 50 players include eight under the age of 25, with Reed among them at No. 20.

title: Ban Lifted, BP Bids $42 Million to Win Gulf Oil Leases in U.S. Auction
description: LONDON  Just days after the United States lifted a ban on new oil and gas leases for BP, the company took full advantage of the opportunity. In an auction held in New Orleans on Wednesday, BP was the high bidder on 24 exploration blocks in the Gulf of Mexico for about $42 million, according to the Interior Department.

title: A Website Asks Readers to Finance Independent Journalists
description: With news publications increasingly charging for their once-free websites and apps, they face a critical question: Will readers pay for digital content? Now, one Internet start-up has put a twist on that question: Will readers pay for a journalist?

title: Plane Debris Would Be Modest Clue Two Weeks After a Crash, Experts Say
description: WASHINGTON  Even if searchers are fortunate enough to spot floating debris in the ocean west of Australia from the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, it would be only a modest step in locating the rest of the Boeing 777, according to oceanographers and recovery experts. And only then could they dig into the question of why it crashed.

title: Westin Creates Six Pillars of Well-Being in a Program for Guests and Employees
description: WESTIN HOTELS, a brand of Starwood Hotels and Resorts, is starting a new well-being initiative on Thursday, for employees and guests.

title: Jesse Jackson Confronts Silicon Valley
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr., the civil rights leader and political activist, appeared at a shareholder meeting of Hewlett-Packard Wednesday afternoon, in what appeared to be the start of a comprehensive campaign to bring greater minority representation to the technology world.

title: TV Lowers Birthrate (Seriously)
description: In the struggle to break cycles of poverty, experts have been searching for decades for ways to lower Americas astronomical birthrate among teenagers.

title: The Orioles Are Wired for Winning
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Every 10 years, a team built largely by Dan Duquette becomes a powerhouse. The 1994 Montreal Expos had the best record in the major leagues. The 2004 Boston Red Sox won the World Series. Maybe it will be a special season for the 2014 Baltimore Orioles.

title: Studying Abroad, in a Linked World
Working in Pennsylvania
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Crimea Crisis Affects U.S.-Russia Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Leaders Gird for Battle Against Republican Running for Governor of Illinois
description: CHICAGO  With the selection of a multimillionaire businessman to be the Republican candidate for governor in Illinois, union leaders have begun bracing for one of their starkest campaign battles of the year over the fate of public sector labor unions, pensions and pay.

title: Syria: Rebels Seize Southern Prison
description: Rebels in southern Syria took over a government prison in Daraa Province on Wednesday, expanding their control near the border with Jordan and freeing hundreds of prisoners, antigovernment activists said. The prison, near the provincial capital of Daraa, fell after a siege by rebel forces that lasted weeks. A video posted online showed a fighter telling a large group of prisoners that they would be taken to a rebel court. Another video showed rebels leading what appear to be more than 100 prisoners from a prison building. It was unclear whether the prisoners were political detainees. The Syrian government did not comment.

title: Revisiting Gandhi, on the Banks of the Sabarmati
description: AHMEDABAD, India  As a teenager in the 1920s, my grandfather Prabhudas Kamdar was enthralled with Mahatma Gandhi. He devoured every issue of Gandhis magazine, Young India, as soon as it came out and was deeply drawn to Gandhis satyagraha movement.

title: Hurricane Sandy and New Jerseys Poor
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is required by law to ensure that states spend federal disaster aid in a fair, nondiscriminatory manner that furthers the goals of the federal fair housing law. But history shows that states sometimes need a push, and the evidence suggests that Gov. Chris Christies administration in New Jersey needs one right now.

title: PETA Investigation: Nehro's Feet
description: The trainer Scott Blasi discussed the poor state of the race horse Nehros feet. Despite the horses condition, it continued to train.

title: After East Harlem Explosion, Mourning a Japanese Daughter Who Loved New York
description: The last time that Keiko Nakamura saw her daughter, Mayumi, was last March when she was leaving their home in Japan to move to New York City to study art.

title: PETA Accuses Two Trainers of Cruelty to Horses
description: Over a 26-year career, the trainer Steve Asmussen has built one of horse racings largest and most successful operations. He ranks second in career victories, with more than 6,700; has earned more than $214 million in purses, the fifth most in thoroughbred racing; and was recently included on the National Museum of Racings Hall of Fame ballot.

title: Russia and the Group of 8
description: Expelling Russia from the Group of 8  as demanded by hawks on the Hill and mooted in conflicting signals from Europe  is the wrong way to punish President Vladimir Putin for annexing Crimea from Ukraine.

title: A Wedding in Intensive Care
description: BOSTON  There wasnt going to be a happy ending. The patient had metastatic cancer and had just gone through her third unsuccessful regimen of chemotherapy. Now it seemed that everywhere we looked, we found disease. An X-ray of her belly revealed an obstruction in her intestines. A CT scan of her chest uncovered a pulmonary embolism. Her labs demonstrated that she had almost no white blood cells left with which to defend herself.

title: Tempered Cheers in Ukraine for Ex-Premier, Tied to Political Past
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Released from prison last month by the rebellious Ukrainian Parliament, Yulia V. Tymoshenko raced to Independence Square in Kiev to join the celebrations. But the appearance of Ms. Tymoshenko, a former prime minister, was curiously subdued, and not just because she was in a wheelchair.

title: Gang-Related Shootings Decline in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  Gang-related shootings here are steadily declining, officials said on Wednesday, citing violence-reduction efforts that prevent gang retaliation and that are prompting the interest of other cities.

title: Drywall Drama
A Mystery: Who Are the Dewey Secret Seven?
description: They are the mysterious seven: former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf who pleaded guilty to taking part in a four-year plan to manipulate the financial statements of the once prominent law firm, but whose identities and plea agreements are being kept under wraps by New York prosecutors.

title: Paying Price, 16 Years Later, for an Illegal Entry
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The cellblock intercom awoke Josue Noe Sandoval-Perez at 1 oclock on a frigid January morning at a detention center in northwest Missouri: Get your things, get ready to go. Immigration officials were preparing to whisk him away.

title: Turkey: Corruption Probes Details Will Not Be Disclosed
description: Parliament voted Wednesday against the public disclosure of accusations against four former government ministers who have been implicated in a major corruption investigation. The governing party contended that the disclosure would violate the secrecy of the inquiry, which was initiated in December. Opposition members of Parliament argued, however, that the former ministers had the right to hear in full detail the allegations against them. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has criticized the corruption investigation as a judicial coup, and he has asserted that it was initiated by a rival pro-Islamic network, led by Fethullah Gulen, a preacher based in the United States whose sympathizers are believed to be influential in Turkeys police force and the judiciary.

title: Second Round of Iran Nuclear Talks Ends With Optimism
description: VIENNA  The second round of talks between Iran and six world powers over Irans nuclear program ended Wednesday with all parties expressing satisfaction with the discussions, which were the most detailed so far on each of the main issues dividing them.

title: Everywhere Pitino Looks at N.C.A.A. Tournament, Theres Another Protg
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Rick Pitino is not happy that his Louisville team is playing Manhattan on Thursday in its opening game in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Its not hard to guess why.

title: Robert S. Strauss, Presidential Confidant and Deal Maker, Dies at 95
description: Robert S. Strauss, who rose from the Texas Plains to become an influential Washington insider, leading the Democratic Party and hopscotching among White House posts when not making millions as a lobbyist and deal maker, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 95.

title: Corrections: March 20, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Sixty-Five Minutes
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Sixty-five minutes. Thats how long it took me to figure this puzzle out. I did this mainly by staring at the grid, occasionally frowning deeply at it in order to scare it into submission. I worked the clues one at a time, not really sure why some had only dashes (in the print version, these clues are combined), and crawled my way through a Thursday puzzle. Thursday puzzles are supposed to bring light and joy. This puzzle, for me, highlights the observation that some puzzles are experimental, more than anything. Maybe you had better luck.

title: Justice Dept. Is Cautious on Joining C.I.A. Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Both the Central Intelligence Agency and the Senate Intelligence Committee believe that laws may have been broken in their bitter dispute over top secret documents relating to the C.I.A.s detention program and who has the right to read them.

title: Correction Dept. Investigating Death of Inmate at Rikers Island
description: The New York City Correction Department is investigating the death of a mentally ill inmate who was found in an overheated cell last month at Rikers Island after being left unattended for hours, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: Coach Gets a New View of a Notorious Seeding
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The shock and fear of what happened in March 1994 remain a fresh reminder for Mark Gottfried, a link to the past that now defines a journey through the bracketology of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Ukraine Troops to Leave Crimea
description: In an admission of defeat, Ukraines leaders began plans for a military pullback after the Russian takeover.

title: For Knicks Jackson, Lakers Buss Is Companion and Competition
description: While the sports world stopped Tuesday to size up Phil Jackson in his latest incarnation, as Knicks president and savior, Jeanie Buss was nowhere near him.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 19, 2014
description: March 19, 2014

title: Many Seek Spanish Citizenship Offered to Sephardic Jews
description: The Spanish government has been flooded with thousands of inquiries about legislation it approved last month that will grant dual citizenship to descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled from Spain more than 500 years ago, the countrys justice minister said on Wednesday.

title: Vote Put Off on Trade Center Loan
description: The fate of the developer Larry A. Silversteins second tower at the World Trade Center site remains undecided.

title: San Diego Opera to Shut Down
description: The San Diego Opera, which once attracted Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti and Beverly Sills to sing in Southern California, announced Wednesday that an insurmountable financial hurdle would force it to shut down after this season ends in April.

title: Relatives of Ghanaian Who Died During Deportation Win Ruling in Japan
description: TOKYO  A Tokyo court on Wednesday ordered the Justice Ministry to pay some $50,000 to the family of a Ghanaian man who in 2010 was forcibly deported from Japan and suffocated in a plane seat.

title: Delaware Coach Laments Missed Call (Luckily, Biden Called Back)
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The call came from a number that Delaware Coach Monte Ross did not recognize, its 202 area code revealing only that it was from Washington, D.C. He did not answer it. It was a game day, after all, and Ross was eating breakfast.

title: Tales of Sorrow and Threats of Eviction in the Bronx
description: She strode out of a third-floor room in Bronx Housing Court as if propelled by a gust, spinning through the door, clenching her mail-order receipts, bank account statements and her dispossess notice tight as pearls to her chest. Can we talk?

title: Jets Consider Michael Vick for Role as a Backup
description: The Jets are searching for a quarterback to push Geno Smith. Michael Vick is the best free agent available. Could there be a fit?

title: Knicks Begin Jackson Era With Impressive Victory
description: Phil Jacksons arrival as Knicks president has generated a variety of emotions within the organization. There is excitement. There is optimism. But there is also uncertainty about which players and coaches figure into Jacksons plans.

title: A Step Toward More Pay for Airport Workers
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey took a significant step on Wednesday toward increasing wages and benefits for workers across all its facilities, beginning with its airports.

title: Vote Fails to End Fight Over Growth in Catskills
description: The last time there was an election for the Village Board of Bloomingburg, N.Y., 24 residents came out to vote. On Tuesday, more than 330 did, roughly two-thirds of the population of the small rustic spot in Sullivan County.

title: Port Authority Moves Toward Transparency With Public Roll Call
description: At a full board meeting of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Wednesday, the agenda turned at one point to lease agreements at Teterboro Airport.

title: Familiar Consultants Hired by de Blasios Pre-K Drive
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios privately financed campaign to offer prekindergarten to all 4-year-olds in New York City spent nearly $236,000 in January and February, spreading much of the money among the same core group of political consultants behind his winning campaign last year, according to records released on Wednesday.

title: With Williams in Form, Nets Hold Off Bobcats
description: The Nets spent the preseason saying Deron Williams would be their engine, but injuries sent him sputtering on a detour of self-doubt. His season has progressed in fits and starts and with open frustration, but he finally seems to be shifting into his highest gear.

title: Small Museums
description: In the age of mega-institutions and competitive building, the Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk pays homage to the more personal places, like his own Museum of Innocence, whose character and content evoke a deeper experience.

title: Pomp, No Circumstance
description: The fantastical drama of Victoriana comes down to earth with a simple pair of weathered mens blue jeans.

title: Adrift in Solace
description: The abstract painter Julie Mehretu captures the maelstrom of emotion inside the American poet Jean Valentine as she recollects a recent voyage to Greenland.

title: Times Minute | March Madness Trivia
description: Trivia for the N.C.A.A. tournament. The role of Deal or No Deal Canada; Warren Buffetts billion-dollar prize; and favorites on the men and the womens sides.

title: Tango Messaging App Dances With Alibaba
description: Tango, a Silicon Valley start-up that makes a popular messaging app by the same name, is going to the senior prom  and its date is one of the hottest tech companies on the planet.

title: Times Minute | March Madness Trivia
description: In the Video

title: The Bugs in Your Home Quiz
description: How familiar are you with the creepy, crawly critters that live under your roof?

title: The Economics of Limiting Russias Expansion
description: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a nonresident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. Simon Johnson is a professor at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

title: The Bugs in Our Homes
description: We swat flies on our windowsills. Watch ants scramble for the crumbs on our kitchen counters. Bathe our pets to rid them of fleas. And all of us have crossed paths with the nasty cockroach.

title: New York Fed Chief Expresses Concern on New Leverage Rule
description: An influential New York bank regulator has privately raised concerns in recent weeks about a proposed rule that seeks to make the nations largest banks safer, frustrating other regulators who see it as a centerpiece of a financial system overhaul and want it to take effect swiftly.

title: IBMs Big Hope for Fraud
description: IBM is changing with the crimes. So are other companies, and their collective efforts could affect more than catching tax cheats.

title: Obama Promotes Womens Economic Prospects
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  President Obama has vowed to make 2014 a year of action, using his executive authority to bypass a Congress where his agenda is so stalled that even the confirmation of his surgeon general nominee is held up. But at a Thursday speech at a community college here in Central Florida, the limitations of that so-called pen and phone strategy were clear.

title: Walmarts New Push for Outdoor Sales
description: Retailers often say that the shopping season before Christmas is their Super Bowl. But for big home improvement chains like Home Depot and Lowes, spring is the busiest time.

title: After Serving Six Years, Mobster Receives His Sentence
description: The mob boss had been at the federal jail in Brooklyn longer than any other inmate: four years awaiting trial and, after his conviction in 2012 on racketeering charges, nearly two more waiting to be sentenced. By the time his sentencing date arrived on Wednesday, the mobster, Thomas Gioeli, had been considered for the death penalty, convicted of conspiring to murder three mobsters and acquitted of killing a police officer; he had multiple angioplasties and, with the help of his family, even became an avid blogger and user of Twitter who taunted prosecutors and two mayors.

title: Word of the Day | sophistry
description: sophistry\s-f-stre\ noun

title: Assault on Hong Kong Media Executives Adds to Press Freedom Concerns
description: Updated, 11:09 p.m.ET | An assault on two executives of a Hong Kong newspaper by men with iron bars has heightened concerns about press freedom and the safety of journalists in the semiautonomous Chinese city.

title: Louisvilles Rick Pitino and Russ Smith Make Odd Couple
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  About four years ago, two Louisville assistant coaches, Steve Masiello and Ralph Willard, were scouting J. J. Moore of South Kent (Conn.) Prep, when another player, a wire-thin guard, caught Willards eye. His hands. His ability to control the ball. His knack for scoring. His anticipation defensively.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 10:05 A.M. (Starz) HIGH FIDELITY (2000) Rob (John Cusack, above) is the manager of a vinyl record store in Chicago. Along with his fellow employees (Jack Black and Todd Louiso), he spends most of his days spouting thematic Top 5 music lists while viewing himself as one of the last great curators of pop music. After his girlfriend, Laura (Iben Hjejle), dumps him, Rob creates a ranking of all his exes (a group that includes women played by Catherine Zeta-Jones, Lili Taylor and Joelle Carter), based on the amount of emotional turmoil they caused and decides to go on a mission to find out what went wrong. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that the relationships depicted in this romantic comedy, directed by Stephen Frears and based on the novel by Nick Hornby, have a pulsing flesh-and-blood reality. He also wrote, Even more sharply than the book, the movie evokes the turmoil of urban single life with a quirky mixture of confessional poignancy and dry, self-deflating humor.

title: Australian Premiers Statement
description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia announced the discovery of two objects in the southern Indian Ocean that could possibly be from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: Yankees Kelly Johnson Focuses on Playing Third, Not Replacing Alex Rodriguez
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  There are two holes to fill in the Yankees infield, and two questions are always asked about them.

title: Delhis Indo-Western Style
description: Hauz Khas Village in New Delhi is a cultural hub filled with 13th-century monuments, bars with local bands playing U2 covers and trendy boutiques. In this happening neighborhood, Indians embrace a mix of traditional and Western styles.

title: Where the Objects Were Spotted
description: Satellite imagery captured near the Australian search areas shows objects which officials say could be related to the missing plane.

title: U.N. Delays Action on Chinas Rights Report
description: In what one Western diplomat called a very unusual development, the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva has postponed the adoption of Chinas human rights report amid protests over the death in custody of a rights activist in Beijing and reports of delaying tactics by China.

title: Satellite Photos Send Jet Hunt to Southern Indian Ocean
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Aircraft and ships rushed to scour a remote stretch of the southern Indian Ocean on Thursday after satellite photographs showed tantalizing glimpses of two large floating objects that might be pieces of the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner. But the first searchers on the scene could not find the objects.

title: A Temporary End to a Tour of the Indian Womens Movement
description: The womens rights activistsRuchira GuptaandGloria Steinem kept a diary of their travels throughout India as they met the countrys young feminists, writers and thought leaders (their most recent post is here). In the final installation for India Ink, the two wind up their tour of India in Kerala.

title: Herms, Holding Steady in Luxury Market, Posts Strong Growth for 2013
description: PARIS  The French luxury group Herms International on Thursday reported a rise in profit of nearly 7 percent last year, bolstered by strong sales growth in the United States and in China, where many of its larger competitors have struggled to adapt their product lines in response to a government-led clampdown on lavish spending.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 20, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | A New Cold War?
description: In the News Analysis If Not a Cold War, a Return to a Chilly Rivalry, Peter Baker writes about how tensions over Crimea may bring about a long period of confrontation and alienation.

title: 5 Indian Men Are Convicted in Gang Rapes at Abandoned Mill in Mumbai
description: MUMBAI, India  A court in Mumbai found five men guilty on Thursday on charges related to the gang rapes of a photojournalist and a call-center operator in an abandoned mill building last year. The case has shaken a city that has long prided itself on being relatively progressive and cosmopolitan.

title: From Chaos and Drought, Commerce and Art
description: Americas second most-productive agricultural county receives less rain than the Gobi Desert.

title: The Scientific Quest to Prove Bisexuality Exists
description: The traffic was bad, even by the warped standards of a Southern California commute. We were headed south from Los Angeles to San Diego on an overcast morning last spring, but we hadnt moved in 10 minutes.

title: C.C.R.C. Residents Ask, Wheres the Money?
description: The way Burton Richter tells it, the house he and his wife had lived in for 40 years needed a fence repaired, and the repairman damaged the pool plumbing. Fixing that messed up the gardens irrigation system. Soon afterward Dr. Richter had to climb onto the roof to repair a solar panel.

title: How Concerned Are You About Climate Change?
description: This week the worlds largest general scientific society released a stark report on global warming that shows how dire, and how urgent, the problem is.

title: Russian Forces Release Ukraine Naval Commander, Reports Say
description: SEVASTOPOL, Crimea  Russian forces and their Crimean militia allies were reported on Thursday to have released the commander of the Ukrainian Navy, seized in his own headquarters here as Moscows annexation of the strategic Black Sea peninsula forced the authorities in Kiev to begin planning for the evacuation of their forces to mainland Ukraine.

title: Gunmen Attack Luxury Hotel in Kabul Weeks Before Afghanistan Elections
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four men with pistols opened fire inside the luxurious Serena Hotel complex in central Kabul on Thursday night, killing nine people before being gunned down and sowing panic in an exclusive enclave frequented by foreign officials, prominent Afghans and an array of development workers, officials and witnesses said.

title: New York Today: Dawn of Spring
description: Updated 10:08 a.m.

title: Running as Therapy
description: I started distance running in 2007 because, in the short space of six months, the person I was dating left me for another woman, I bought a house (a rash decision) and my grandfather died.

title: Samsonite Takes the Pulse of Chinese Consumers
description: HONG KONG  There are plenty of things to worry about in the Chinese economy  shadow banking, pain in the property sector, flagging growth in industrial output  but the willingness of the Chinese consumer to spend, at least on some things, seems to be holding up.

title: JPMorgan Commodities Sale Shows Tradings Opacity
description: JPMorgan Chases $3.5 billion sale of its physical commodities business is a perfect example of just how opaque trading is.

title: Michelle Obama Stays Connected During Her Visit to China
description: As Michelle Obama kicks off her weeklong trip to China, her first ever, her team is harnessing the power of technology to ensure that every step, every impression is documented. Accompanied by her daughters, Malia and Sasha, as well as her mother, Marian Robinson, the first lady will be blogging, tweeting and Instagramming her way through the country.

title: Newtown Helps Map Out a New Path to Healing
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  The school will be in the woods, away from the parking lot. It will feature a long, curving corridor that the architect likens to arms embracing students as they enter. All classrooms will have natural light and will share treehouse-like spaces where students can work in groups or just reflect.

title: Why an Atlanta Institution Cant Seem to Expand
description: Here is the thought that flashed through my mind as I washed down my Red Dog (hot dog with ketchup) with an F.O. (frosty orange) and a side of Strings (fries): If the Varsity can sell a thousand Naked Walking Dogs (hot dog to go on a plain bun)every day of the week from a restaurant that has become an Atlanta institution, why cant it stamp out locations all over the state, region or even country?

title: Why San Francisco Is Not  New York
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For some time, people have been saying that San Francisco is transforming into another, different kind of big city.

title: Intimate Ritual in a Ghostly Abyss
description: A pressurized hush in a cavernous space: That was the sensory impression left by the xx toward the end of its mesmerizing performance at the Park Avenue Armory on Wednesday night. Considering the setting and the bands trademark sound  its drowsy clarity and terse interiority  the feeling itself wasnt a stretch. What gave it depth was a larger context that often seemed as much an art installation as a concert, and at every moment like a dynamic, self-aware commentary on the issue of scale.

title: European Officials Reach Deal on Failed-Bank System
description: BRUSSELS  European Union lawmakers and finance officials reached a political agreement early Thursday on the structure of a system meant to prevent failing banks from unleashing the kind of havoc that has periodically threatened the survival of the euro in recent years.

title: Strauss-Kahn Seeks to Start $2 Billion Hedge Fund
description: Updated, 11:41 a.m. | PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking to translate his extensive experience at the top levels of global policy-making into a lucrative career as an investment manager, hoping to raise $2 billion for a hedge fund, one of his partners in the venture said on Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Entrepreneurs in Hong Kong Place Their Bets on Bitcoin
description: By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kongs growing Bitcoin scene, Alan Wong reports.

title: Questioning the Leverage Ratio
description: Since the financial crisis, William C. Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has made significant changes to bolster the banks supervision efforts. But now, some regulators are blaming him for holding up a proposed rule to make banks safer, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. Mr. Dudley is said to have privately expressed his concerns to senior Fed officials in Washington about the rule, known as the supplementary leverage ratio, frustrating other regulators who see it as a centerpiece of a financial system overhaul.

title: The Draw of a Mail-Order Art School
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.  For more than two decades, the promise of art shined forth from advertisements in the back pages of comic books and magazines. But the ads had nothing to do with beauty or form or eternal verities. They were clip-out visions of arts more tangible rewards: a paycheck, an escape from the blue-collar grind, maybe even a glamorous career perched at an easel.

title: Forward Thinking, Backward Mind
description: The conceptual photographer Robert Heinecken, who died in 2006 at 74, was ahead of his time in some ways  and hopelessly retrograde in others. The technically experimental, media-savvy work he made in the 1960s and 70s paved the way for appropriation artists like Richard Prince and Sherrie Levine, and for the digital-image samplers who dominate photo exhibitions today. Yet much of it looked, and still looks, oblivious to the advent of feminism.

title: Confucian Purity, Glacially Formal Yet Glowering
description: PHILADELPHIA  If you dont know much about traditional Korean art, you might be perplexed, as I was, by Treasures From Korea: Arts and Culture of the Joseon Dynasty, 1392-1910, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. With the promise of treasures in mind, I was looking forward to works of spectacular opulence, craftsmanship and imagination among the approximately 150 paintings, sculptures, ceramics, furnishings, robes and more on view. Much to my puzzlement, what I found was an aesthetic and an ethos of sober, even oppressive restraint.

title: One Man, Two Wheels, 4,122 Miles
description: A man in the grip of a midlife crisis often gets himself a new set of wheels: a Porsche or a Jaguar or a Mustang convertible. But at 57, Bruce Weber, the author of the memoir and travelogue Life Is a Wheel, opted for a different vehicle, a shiny red custom-made titanium bicycle, which he resolved to ride from the Pacific Coast to the Atlantic.

title: Remembering a Young Ukrainian Student
description: Dear Diary:

title: Bharatiya Janata Party Announces Second Race For Modi
description: NEW DELHI  The Bharatiya Janata Partys fifth list of candidates for the general elections confirmed that Narendra Modi, the partys prime ministerial nominee, would be contesting for a parliamentary seat in his home state of Gujarat, in addition to one in Varanasi. The party also assigned a senior leader, Lal Krishna Advani, to Gandhinagar, in Gujarat.

title: In Our Pages: March 21
description: The final scene of Richard Strausss last opera, Capriccio, performed by the Orchestre National de lORTF in France, in 1974.

title: Britain Fines Former Credit Suisse Trader Over Bond Manipulation
description: LONDON  Another day, another iteration of financial fraud innovation.

title: Harlan Coben: By the Book
description: The author of Missing You and Tell No One says most of his classmates probably remember him more for the basketball I was dribbling than the book I may have been carrying.

title: President of Apollo Global to Step Down
description: Updated, 12:56 p.m. | Marc Spilker, the president of Apollo Global Management, plans to leave the giant private equity firm, according to an announcement on Thursday.

title: Bloomberg Hints at Curb on Articles About China
description: HONG KONG  The chairman of Bloomberg L.P. said in a speech here on Thursday that the company should have reconsidered articles that deviated from its core of coverage of business news, because they jeopardized the huge sales potential for its products in the Chinese market.

title: Can Sing and Smolder and Play Leading Man
description: When that hunky guy in jeans and cowboy boots sends his bari-tenor soaring at the Schoenfeld Theater, one cant help wondering: Why hasnt he been in a Broadway musical before?

title: Obama Rules Out Military Force Over Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said on Wednesday that he had ruled out the use of United States military force in the Ukraine crisis, and that the international response to Russias seizure of Crimea will be limited to diplomacy.

title: Art Is the Theme at a Cape Town Hotel
description: With its year as World Design Capital 2014 underway, Cape Towns designers, artists and architects are having a moment in the spotlight.

title: Sexual Misconduct Case Ends With No Jail Time for General
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.  Bringing an end to a closely watched military sexual misconduct trial, a judge on Thursday reprimanded Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair for, among other offenses, mistreating an Army captain who was his mistress, but did not sentence him to jail time and allowed him to remain in the military.

title: Review: In Divergent, Jolted Awake by Fear and Romance
description: Women warriors are on the rise again in American movies, and so, too, are hopes that theyll be able to strike where it counts: in the industrys executive suites.

title: Rare Glimpses of Irans Lost Underworld
description: PARIS  Kaveh Golestan was 52 on the bright spring day he died. He was killed in a minefield in northern Iraq in 2003 while working as a cameraman with the BBC.

title: Book on Gettysburg Wins $50,000 Military History Prize
description: A book about the battle of Gettysburg triumphed over some 100 other nominees to win the first Guggenheim-Lehrman Prize in Military History, which was founded last year to bolster the status of military history and is to be awarded annually.

title: Corporate Lies Are Increasingly Immune to Investor Complaints
description: Companies do not have a right to lie to their shareholders, a German judge ruled this week. But sometimes, she added, lies are necessary.

title: Agreement Ends Lockout of M.L.S. Referees
description: The union representing Major League Soccers game officials ratified a new collective bargaining agreement Wednesday, ending a lockout that had led the league to use replacement referees and assistant referees for the first two weeks of the season.

title: Douglas Merrill of ZestFinance: Steer Clear of What You Cant Measure
description: This interview with Douglas Merrill, chief executive of ZestFinance, a big-data company that focuses on underwriting, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: NYT Now: Australian Premier on Lost Jet
description: Tony Abbott held a news conference after the announcement of the discovery of two objects in the Indian Ocean that may be related to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: The Last of Us Claims a Top Video Game Prize
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Last of Us, the somber story of a man and a teenage girls trek across a post-apocalyptic American landscape, won three awards here on Wednesday at the Game Developers Choice Awards, including game of the year. Other games that won multiple awards were BioShock Infinite, which won for best visual art and best audio, and Papers, Please, which won the innovation award and the award for best downloadable game.

title: Poetry Pairing | Mama Said
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features Mama Said by Mary Moore Easter and the article Oldest Woman in New York Celebrates Birthday No. 114 by Michaelle Bond.

title: New Capital Could Raise Airbnb Value To $10 Billion
description: Airbnb is poised to join the 11-digit club.

title: Port Agency Investigates Boys Ascent of World Trade Center
description: Authorities are trying to determine how a 16-year-old New Jersey boy sneaked past security at 1 World Trade Center and spent two hours early Sunday making his way to the top of the 1,776-foot tower, which is still under construction.

title: Australian Premier Discusses Search
description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia spoke at a news conference and said his government would do all it could to help find the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: American Dance Festival Announces Lineup
description: Shall We Dance is not a question; its the theme of the American Dance Festivals 2014 season, taking place June 12 to July 26 in Durham, N.C., on the campus of Duke University.

title: Obama Steps Up Russia Sanctions in Ukraine Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama expanded sanctions against Russia on Thursday, blacklisting a bank and several wealthy businessmen with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin, as the United States struggled to forestall further Russian incursions into Ukraine.

title: German Panel Says Medieval Treasure Should Not Be Returned to Heirs of Jewish Owners
description: BERLIN  A medieval ecclesiastical treasure acquired by the Prussian state in 1935 and later presented by Hermann Gring to Hitler as a surprise gift was legally purchased from a consortium of Jewish art dealers, whose heirs have no rightful claim at restitution, a panel convened by the German government said Thursday.

title: In Iran, Hopes Fade for Surge in the Economy
description: TEHRAN  Suffering in an economy dragged down by years of mismanagement and the effects of international sanctions, Irans increasingly impoverished middle class voted in huge numbers last summer for President Hassan Rouhani, who promised to reignite growth by restoring ties with the rest of the world.

title: U.N. Warns of Anti-Muslim Violence in Central African Republic
description: GENEVA  Thousands of Muslims in the Central African Republic remain in danger of being slaughtered despite the presence of international peacekeepers, Navi Pillay, the United Nations human rights chief, warned on Thursday, criticizing the international community for a slow and inadequate response to the countrys humanitarian catastrophe.

title: Ukraine Upheaval Highlights E.U.s Past Miscalculations and Future Dangers
