description: Scenes of police officers standing guard near a luxury hotel that was attacked by gunmen in Kabul, Afghanistan.

title: Life Sentences for Four Men Convicted of Gang Rape in Mumbai
description: MUMBAI Inside a courtroom on Friday, as a crowd parted to allow four men barefoot and blank-faced to walk to a witness box, their defense attorneys prepared their arguments for leniency, ready to blame poverty as one of the main reasons these men gang-raped a call-center worker.

title: Democrats Plan Ads in Challenge to Koch Brothers
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Majority PAC, a group that supports Democratic Senate candidates, is preparing a $3 million advertising campaign against Charles G. Koch and David H. Koch, the libertarian-minded billionaire brothers who support conservative causes and have already poured millions of dollars into the 2014 midterm elections.

title: After 58 Years in a Couple, a Spouse Fights for Benefits
description: On Dec. 13, 1953, Lawrence Schacht walked into the Cork Club on West 72nd Street in Manhattan and spotted Russell Frink Jr. at the bar. From that moment forward, the two were inseparable.

title: A Shot of Religion
description: Alcohols effects on the pious; March Madness itself draws a challenger.

title: How Did Sleep Become So Nightmarish?
description: My experience with insomnia began when I was 6 or 7, though I didnt recognize it as such. In those days, I thought of it as a gift. I had a window that faced east, and in the mornings, a sweet, clear light would pour over my bed, rousing me from the middle of my dreams. I went to bed late and woke up early, and when I did sleep, I slept lightly, waking many times in the night to register the clocklike clicking of a raccoons claws on the roof, an especially noisy frog or the breathing and muttering of the house as it rolled and shifted position with the temperature, my fellow restless sleeper.

title: Life in the Group Room
description: Everyone was always trying to escape the stroke ward, and who could blame them?

title: Should We Protect Wild Horses?
description: Despite their romantic appeal, horses are an invasive species on this continent with few natural predators. In the United States, its illegal to kill a wild horse on public lands. Yet wild horses can have destructive grazing behavior, and indigenous grazers and browsers (deer, for example) presumably have to compete with them for land. Advocates for wild horses like to compare the ecological impact of horses with that of cattle, but thats sort of like saying we should protect the Asian long-horned beetle because it kills fewer trees than lumber mills do. Is it unethical to protect wild horses? T.G., NEW YORK

title: Reply All: The 3.9.14 Issue
description: SAT OVERHAUL

title: Tracy Letts Is Still Haunted by His Past
description: In 2008, Tracy Letts won the Pulitzer Prize and the Tony Award for his play August: Osage County, a multigenerational drama presided over by a mother whose cancer of the mouth is both literal and figurative. It is ONeill for Okies, based on a seminal event in Lettss own Durant, Okla., family: His maternal grandfathers suicide (Letts was 10 at the time) and his grandmothers ensuing drug addiction. Although Letts, 48, has written other successful plays  the violent and misogynistic Killer Joe and the paranoid and bloody Bug  August, three acts that last more than three hours, was epic in every way: its sweep, its humor and its sorrow. (The movie version, released last year, lost plenty in translation, but then again, most movie versions do.)

title: Whats on Friday
description: 5 P.M. (AMC) FACE/OFF (1997) John Woo directed this action extravaganza in which the F.B.I. agent Sean Archer (John Travolta, right) must undergo an experimental facial procedure to assume the identity of his comatose nemesis, an international terrorist named Castor Troy (Nicolas Cage, left), to prevent a bomb from going off. But the bullets start flying after Troy awakes and uses the same method to steal Archers face and identity. Mr. Woo is such an action wizard that he can make planes or speedboats kick box, but his surprising strength this time is on a more human level, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. She added that Mr. Woo accomplishes something near-impossible. He makes the viewer buy this films loony premise, and buy it with a smile.

title: Video: Reviews of Divergent, The Missing Picture and Nymphomaniac: Volume I
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on the action drama Divergent, the documentary The Missing Picture and Lars von Triers drama Nymphomaniac: Volume I.

title: Updates on Search for Flight 370
description: Royal Australian Air Force members, Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia and the Malaysian defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, gave updates on the search for Flight 370 in the Indian Ocean.

title: Inspired by Irish Soda Bread
description: In honor of St. Patricks Day, I spent the week working on whole-grain soda breads and scones. Not all Irish soda bread is made with whole-grain flour, but the ones I like the best are. They are one of the reasons I love going to Ireland. I especially love the moist brown pan-baked loaves served with smoked salmon, butter and cheese.

title: Revelations of N.S.A. Spying Cost U.S. Tech Companies
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft has lost customers, including the government of Brazil.

title: Students See Many Slights as Racial Microaggressions
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  A tone-deaf inquiry into an Asian-Americans ethnic origin. Cringe-inducing praise for how articulate a black student is. An unwanted conversation about a Latinos ability to speak English without an accent.

title: Paperback Row
description: COMANDANTE: Hugo Chvezs Venezuela,  by Rory Carroll. (Penguin, $17.) Carroll spent six years covering Venezuela and Hugo Chvez (1954-2013) for The Guardian of London. He frames this sharp-eyed biography as a study of how the democratically elected strongman rose from poverty and prison to unrivaled influence as president, thumbing his nose at Washington while wielding his countrys oil reserves as a tool for Socialist-inspired change.

title: The View From Afar
description: Where did it all go wrong? This is the ide fixe of depression, the question that haunts anyone who has ever felt the color drain out of life. This question also underlies much of literature  it can drive writers. And the difference between good writing and a writing exercise is in fact very much like the difference between life itself and its depressive moments: It is in the complexity, the texture, the expansiveness, the lack of desire to fixate on the moment when it all went off the rails.

title: Above and Below
description: Outside the Royal Air Force Chapel in central London stands a statue of Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Harris, better known as Bomber Harris, the British officer most closely associated with the policy of area bombing German cities in the latter stage of World War II. On the pedestal, in honor of the bomber crews and their commander, is the legend: The nation owes them all an immense debt.

title: Good Sport
description: San Benedetto, the fictional Ligurian hub of Brigid Pasulkas second novel, The Sun and Other Stars, was a cloistered fishing village before an Italian-American Hollywood director fell for a local Venus, posed for the paparazzi and provided the photos caption: San Benedetto, a hundred kilometers from Genoa, is the last spot on earth that is simple and pure. Here the light is brought down from on high by angels, and those Italian fishermen, well, they really know how to, you know, live. Benvenuti, turisti!

title: Absolute Power
description: The problem posed by nuclear weapons  that they work by holding their possessors hostage, with the threat of catastrophic retaliation if used  has confounded thinking about them since the beginning of the nuclear age. One of its earliest analysts, the American physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, the first director of the Manhattan Projects Los Alamos laboratory, which developed the atomic bomb, once compared the two dominant nuclear powers of his day and ours, the United States and Russia, to scorpions in a bottle, each capable of killing the other, but only at the risk of his own life. Oppenheimer chose not to note that scorpions, a species almost as well known for belligerence as Homo sapiens, would sooner or later take that risk. We humans have not done so, at least not so far. But while circling each other warily during the Cold War, the United States and the Soviet Union occupied themselves with stockpiling enough weapons to freeze out food production with nuclear winter and destroy the human world.

title: Spyfall
description: Spy novels function with our complicity. We know bad things happen in the world; in some ways, they have to happen in order for us to enjoy ice cream sundaes and ham sandwiches and spring mornings in Palm Beach. Thats the unspoken deal we make with ourselves when we accept their premise.

title: Editors Choice
description: BERNARD MALAMUD:Novels and Stories of the 1940s and 50s andBERNARD MALAMUD: Novels and Stories of the 1960s, both edited by Philip Davis. (Library of America, $35 each.) Malamuds voice was unlike any other, haunted by whispers of Hawthorne, Babel, Isak Dinesen and even Poe.

title: Historical Fiction
description: WAKE  By Anna Hope  Random House, $26.

title: Coach Woodens Bookshelf
description: As Jason Zengerle notes in his review of Seth Daviss new biography of John Wooden, the U.C.L.A. basketball coach originally planned to be an English teacher.

title: Evolution of an Activist
description: In the iconography of black American history, Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. have long been understood as dueling poles of identity, one an apostle of contempt, urging a downtrodden race to renounce a nation that had rejected it, the other an exemplar of Christian idealism, committed to the redemptive power of forgiveness and common humanity. The America we inhabit now is both more socially integrated and segregated than it was in the tumultuous days in which the two men lived. A black president coexists with residential and educational patterns that are in some instances more racially separated than they were on the morning of the 1963 March on Washington. This circumstance is not entirely indicative of a failure of will. Its partly a reflection of the fact that black aspirations for equality were far more complicated than the simple Martin versus Malcolm formulation, just as each man was far more complicated than his public depiction. If those years can be understood as a sort of test, black America looked at the multiple-choice question of identity and answered yes.

title: Deathly Quiet
description: In Jesse Balls absorbing, finely wrought fourth novel, Silence Once Begun, a journalist also named Jesse Ball tells the story of a thread salesman who makes a wager with two people in a bar. Upon losing that wager, he signs an extremely detailed confession to a crime he didnt commit  the kidnapping of eight people from a Japanese town called Narito over the course of four months. The kidnappings, known to the populace as the Narito Disappearances, have spurred a moral panic that demands a scapegoat. A man who would offer himself up as that scapegoat is taking the most desperate of chances, asking all his fellow men for some proof that he should continue to live.

title: Daughters of Revolution
description: In her 2007 memoir Infidel, the activist and former politician Ayaan Hirsi Ali related the advice once given to her by her own grandmother in Somalia: A woman alone is like a piece of sheep fat in the sun, she wrote. Everything will come and feed on that fat. Before you know it, the ants and insects are crawling all over it, until there is nothing left but a smear of grease.

title: Was It Any Use?
description: In Donal Ryans compact debut novel, The Spinning Heart, effects of the economic downturn ripple through an Irish village whose laborers, flush during the boom, have been left in the lurch now that the local developer, Pokey Burke, has skipped town.

title: The Walls Are Closing In
description: Fiction depicting the lives of working-class Americans has a long tradition. Its practitioners  John Steinbeck, Raymond Carver, Tillie Olsen and Stewart ONan, to name a few  aim for a frank portrayal of men and women whose freedom is limited by economic and social realities, and whose American dream is elusive at best. These works often bypass overt lyricism in favor of unadorned prose, to create a kind of literary cinma vrit.

title: Points of Departure
description: W. G. Sebald was born in 1944 in Wertach im Allgu in the Bavarian Alps, educated in Germany and Switzerland, taught literature in England for three decades, and between 1990 and 2001 became world famous for Vertigo, The Emigrants, The Rings of Saturn and Austerlitz  four novels about Jews, set variously in Vienna, Venice, Verona, Riva, Antwerp, Prague, Paris, Suffolk, Manchester and Long Island. He wrote in German, but was a German writer in the same way that Alfred Dblin, Hermann Broch and Stefan Zweig were Jewish writers: tragically and by accident. As for what he called himself, he hated the name Winfried Georg, and responded only to Max. Shortly after Austerlitz was published in English, Sebald died in a car crash. Mortal: the universal identity.

title: Missionaries Kid
description: Early in More Than Conquerors, a memoir of her familys life as Christian missionaries, Megan Hustad anticipates her readers expectations. With a wry frankness typical of the book, she writes: This is not a story of judgmental zealots thumping pulpits. . . . This is not a story about pious blowhards whose unbending conviction alienated their children forever.

title: The Wolf of Fifth Avenue
description: Sooner or later, a historical crime novel is bound to drag you down some dark alley and into the nastiest, most lawless precincts of the period. Jean Zimmerman followed this tradition in her first novel, The Orphanmaster, a descent into the hellish criminal haunts of 17th-century New Amsterdam. In SAVAGE GIRL (Viking, $27.95), this canny author puts all that aside and turns to the Gilded Age for a sweeping narrative, set within the cloistered ranks of high society in 19th-century Manhattan, that raises touchy questions about what it means to be civilized.

title: The Cutting Edge
description: It is easy to forget how amazing modern medicine is.

title: Skills Practice | Alternative History as Narrative
description: What if the British won the Revolutionary War? What if the Cuban Missile Crisis had started World War III? What if John Lennon had not died when he was shot?

title: Advice on How to Have a Good Paternity Leave
description: When you ask for advice about paternity leave, you learn that a lot of really nice people are out there. Strangers, friends and acquaintances popped up on the Internet and in person to wish me well and share their experiences. There may be a persistent social stigma that discourages many fathers from taking more time at home with their babies, paid or unpaid. But there are also a lot of people who will tell you that youre doing the right thing, and I hope youll hear those voices of encouragement echoed here if you are preparing for parental leave.

title: Digitizing Those Customer Loyalty Cards
description: Q. How do I convert my drugstore rewards card into a digital version I can store on my phone?

title: Microaggressions: Comments That Sting
description: Across college campuses and social media, younger generations have started to challenge those fleeting comments that seem innocent but leave uneasy feelings behind.

title: A Doyens Rebellion
description: NEW DELHI  On Wednesday, the central election committee of Indias opposition Bharatiya Janata Party met to announce the partys fifth list of candidates for the national elections in April and May. The meeting had one notable absence: Lal Krishna Advani, the partys doyen and one of its founders.

title: Movie Review: Nymphomaniac: Volume I
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Nymphomaniac: Volume I.

title: Frustrating Black Hair Remark at Harvard
description: Kimiko Matsuda-Lawrence, a student who wrote and directed I, Too, Am Harvard, a play about feeling marginalized at the university, explains why a compliment can be offensive.

title: Looking for Ways to Keep Money From Dividing a Family
description: MARVIN BLUM, a lawyer from Fort Worth, flew to New York last week to visit his daughter, son-in-law and young granddaughter. Staying close to his family is crucial to him. The same goes for seeing his son, who lives in Austin.

title: Movie Review: Divergent
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Divergent.

title: Australias Search for the Missing Plane
description: Lt. Russell Adams of the Royal Australian Airforce gave a brief news conference after completing a search mission for Malaysia Airlines flight 370.

title: Students and Readers Share Their Experiences of Race on Campus
description: As I report in The Big Topic on Campus: Racial Microaggressions, microaggressions is a term that has long been used by race theorists and sociologists, and is now increasingly popping up in blogs, social media campaigns, art and academic papers. Young people are using the term to describe the subtle ways that racial, ethnic, gender and other stereotypes can play out painfully in an increasingly diverse culture.

title: Third-Party Hotel Booking Sites Can Mislead Consumers
description: THIS is the situation: Customers search for a particular hotel and click on a link. They think theyve landed on the official hotel website, but unknowingly they really have arrived at an unrelated site of a hotel booking company.

title: Daily Report: Fallout From Snowden Hurts Tech Company Bottom Lines
description: Microsoft has lost customers, including the government of Brazil. IBM is spending more than a billion dollars to build data centers overseas to reassure foreign customers that their information is safe from prying eyes in the United States government. And tech companies abroad, from Europe to South America, say they are gaining customers that are shunning United States providers, suspicious because of the revelations by Edward J. Snowden that tied these providers to the National Security Agencys vast surveillance program.

title: Cumin Lamb Stir-Fry
description: Melissa Clark makes a restaurant-worthy stir-fry using toasted cumin and Sichuan peppercorns for bigger, spicier flavors.

title: Lamb at Play in a Field of Cumin
description: When it comes to cooking lamb, I lean European. I dream of a Provencal-style roasted leg scented with herbs, or the seared little Italian lamb chops that scorch your fingers when you pick them up.

title: Obama and Tech Executives to Meet Again on Privacy Issues
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will meet with technology executives on Friday afternoon to discuss issues of privacy, technology and intelligence, a senior White House official said, amid growing concerns in Silicon Valley that intelligence agencies cyber snooping is steering customers away from buying American technology.

title: Boardwalk Empire
description: The HBO series is shot on the sound stages of Steiner Studios. Video courtesy of HBO.

title: In the Heights
description: Peter Fines investment helped bring the show to Broadway. The original Broadway cast performs 96,000. Video courtesy of Usnavi Broadway LLC.

title: The Last of the Unjust
description: The Cohen Media Group distributed Claude Lanzmanns Holocaust documentary, released last month. Video courtesy of Cohen Media Group.

title: The Reluctant General Grant
description: After his strategically critical victories at Vicksburg and Chattanooga, Ulysses S. Grant was indisputably the Unions most successful general. By early 1864, it was clear to many observers that the commander of Northern forces in the Western theater would, and should, rise even further in acclaim and power  and they began to plan accordingly, without bothering to ask the brilliant, mercurial leader whether he was even interested.

title: Mercedes-Benz Simulator Shows Off Safety Technology
description: MONTVALE, N.J.  There is little doubt that Mercedes-Benz is has advanced safety technology, and the automaker prides itself on its ability to offer semiautonomous safety features even on its entry-level models.

title: Biltmore, in Bloom
description: Biltmore, Americas largest privately owned home, will celebrate spring ceremoniously with more than 100,000 blooms coloring the estate gardens in Asheville, N.C..

title: They Kept a Lower East Side Lot Vacant for Decades
description: Nearly four decades ago, a new assemblyman named Sheldon Silver and his young protg escorted Edward I. Koch, then a mayoral candidate, through the Orthodox Jewish enclave on Manhattans Lower East Side where the two had both grown up.

title: Most Advanced Gaza-Israel Tunnel Is Found
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military announced on Friday that it had uncovered a sophisticated tunnel that stretched hundreds of yards into its territory from the Gaza Strip and could have been used to attack or kidnap Israelis.

title: Charm School for Real Estate Brokers
description: Sometimes it seems as if New York brokers cant catch a break. The stereotype is that members of the species are rude, arrogant, aggressive, and more apt to talk than to listen. While the image may be just that  a stereotype  it clings to the people who help clients buy, sell and rent houses and apartments in this sharp-elbowed metropolis.

title: Movie Review: The Missing Picture
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Missing Picture.

title: 36 Hours in Mexico City
description: Built from the rubble of violent conquest, Mexico City has endured both the torment of Pacific Rim fault lines and the explosive force of its own expansion. Now with a greater metropolitan area of 21 million, Mexicos nearly 500-year-old capital is made of ancient stone and gleaming glass, Old World architecture and indigenous tradition. With its plazas and palm trees, its murals by Mexican masters and its contemporary street art, it is a beautiful city  and one that has been spared from much of the countrys drug war violence. In recent years, the Distrito Federal has been treated to the opening of one art institution after the next, from the Carlos Slim-funded Soumaya Museum, which moved into a $70 million building in 2011, to the new David Chipperfield-designed Jumex Museum, which focuses on contemporary work and opened last November.

title: In Search of Oxford
description: When I took off in late October to join my husband, a law professor on sabbatical in Oxford, I thought I knew what to expect, thanks to all the books and movies that have been set in this ridiculously pretty, medieval town in south central England. Evelyn Waughs Brideshead Revisited  the 1945 novel that grapples with the allure of aristocracy and privilege  had prepared me for the sight of elegant undergrads romping about, perhaps carrying bottles of Champagne, on the vast green meadows of Christ Church college. Colin Dexters Inspector Morse series (both the books and the television show) had warned me about the dangers of tripping over dead bodies. And that very last bit of the recent film An Education prepared me for flocks of students riding bicycles on their way to conquer DNA analysis on the one hand and the liturgical language of Theravada Buddhism on the other.

title: Real Estate Developers in Movieland
description: When it comes to a second career, many people daydream about breaking into show business, including some well accustomed to white-knuckle drama and skin-of-the-teeth ventures: real estate tycoons.

title: Turks Evade Twitter Ban to Mock Twitter Ban, on Twitter
description: Updated, 1:36 p.m. | As my colleagues Sebnem Arsu and Alan Cowell report, Turkeys court-ordered ban on Twitter was widely subverted on Friday by many of the 12 million Turkish users of the social network, who found ways to gain access to the platform and posted defiant messages of protest.

title: The Tweets of Melissa Mark-Viverito
description: Little has been known publicly about Melissa Mark-Viverito, but as Kate Taylor reports, the City Council speaker provides glimpses into her life and personality through frequent posts on Twitter.

title: Portals to the Past
description: In the early 1930s, when the writer Paul Bowles first visited Tangier, Morocco, where he would end up living for more than a half-century, he described its medina, or old city, as ancient, its passageways were full of people in bright outlandish costumes, and each street leading to the outskirts was bordered by walls of cane, prickly pear and high-growing geranium. Today Moroccos medinas are much the same. The photographer Ambroise Tzenas visited medinas in the Moroccan cities of Tangier, Tetouan and Chefchaouen, which is known for its striking buildings painted bright blue. They arent just tourist playgrounds like you have in downtown Paris, Tzenas says. What I was interested in is the fact that its not just nice and pretty. You still have people working in little shops. Its like stepping back in time, and nothing has changed.Julie Bosman

title: Reflecting on a Writers Walk Through Europe
description: From the time he was a boy, acclaimed travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor wanted to live like a character in a novel. Somehow, he found out how. During his lifetime, he was stabbed in Bulgaria, car-bombed in Greece, targeted in a blood vendetta, and hunted by German soldiers after kidnapping their commander on the island of Crete and handing him off to a waiting British submarine during World War II. But his story started in 1933, when at 18 he was focused on the single goal of walking across Europe, From the hook of Holland to Constantinople.

title: 4 Dead as Fire Destroys Motel on Jersey Shore Used for Storm Victims
description: A fire swept through a motel at Point Pleasant Beach on the Jersey Shore just before dawn on Friday, killing four people and injuring eight others.

title: A Lens Catches; a Painter Converts
description: What do you do if youre a busy museum, and an eminent and famously enigmatic artist in late career tells you hes prepared to go public with new work? You shake up your schedule, clear out some space and move the stuff in, pronto.

title: Times Minute | Behind the Flight Search
description: On the Minute, more information on the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, including the progress, the geopolitics at play and the limits of the planes black box if it is found.

title: Times Minute | Behind the Search for Flight 370
description: In the Video

title: Instead of the Poker-Playing Dogs
description: Gifts for art lovers.

title: Pay Higher Wages, Earn More Profit
description: How often do you walk into a retail establishment and interact with a salesperson, stock clerk or cashier? How often do you stop and think about what that persons life is like?

title: Lauren Ambrose and Chris Pine to Star in Fool for Love at Williamstown
description: Chris Pine (Kirk in the recent Star Trek movies) and Lauren Ambrose (Six Feet Under) will face off as the battling lovers in Sam Shepards Fool for Love in a production this summer at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, the company announced Friday. The 1983 play will be directed by Daniel Aukin (4000 Miles) and run July 24-Aug. 3 at Williamstowns Nikos Stage.

title: Kronos Quartets 40-Year Adventure
description: That sounded massively unmassive, the violinist David Harrington said during a recent rehearsal of Nico Muhlys Diacritical Marks with the Pannonia Quartet, gesturing energetically to encourage a ponytailed teenager in pink sneakers to create a more dramatic sound on her violin.

title: Rhyming Wit, Plaintive Sorrow and a Rising Diva
description: Marian Hill

title: The Historical Becomes Personal
description: The five-hour PBS series The Story of the Jews With Simon Schama sweeps across some 3,000 years of Jewish history. But late last month, when the Center for Jewish History in Manhattan showed excerpts from the documentary, the post-screening questions for Mr. Schama didnt gravitate toward history, but toward current affairs: the status of todays Israel and what should the response be to the rise in ultra-Orthodoxy there.

title: Ha Jin and Wendell Berry Among New Members of American Academy of Arts and Letters
description: The novelist Ha Jin, the farmer-writer Wendell Berry and the artist Ann Hamilton are among the nine new members elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, commonly described as one of the highest honors in the arts.

title: Chicken Piccata With Chard or Beet Greens
description: This recipe, adapted from a Mark Peel recipe for veal piccata, produces pungent, lemony chicken breasts that are among the top 10 dinners in my house. I pound chicken breasts thin, to about 1/4 inch. This way, you can get a good two servings, if not more, out of each boneless, skinless breast. They take minutes to cook, and you can pound the chicken breasts ahead of time and keep them between sheets of plastic in the refrigerator until youre ready to make dinner.

title: A Southern Stew of the Self-Taught
description: Outsider art  the catchall term for the work of self-trained artists and a lot of folk art  has always raised more questions than it answers: Outside what? Says who? Why is the distinction necessary? Those questions have been particularly fraught when it comes to the history of work by African-American artists, a tension that will be explored in When the Stars Begin to Fall: Imagination and the American South, a show at the Studio Museum in Harlem of 35 artists who share an interest in the South and who often scramble the insider-outsider equation. Setting out to inject a gutbucket-funky aesthetic into classical, sometimes overwrought, tropes of African Americana  the folk, the down-home, the hailed, the show, opening on Thursday, will examine the history of self-taught artists in influencing and defining what black art can be, the museum says. It will include work by Kara Walker, David Hammons, Theaster Gates and other established stars alongside that of emerging artists and others never before exhibited at the museum, like Frank Albert Jones, who made ecstatic drawings over many years in Texas prisons. (144 West 125th Street, 212-864-4500, studiomuseum.org.

title: Lemon and Garlic Chicken With Cherry Tomatoes
description: This is a summery dish to make in the middle of a cold winter (or early spring), but you can find decent cherry tomatoes even now, from Florida or from Mexico. I marinate the breasts in lemon juice, olive oil, garlic and rosemary before I pound them. This makes them very flavorful, a great savory contrast to the sweet tomato topping.

title: Lemon and Garlic Chicken With Spiced Spinach
description: This is a heavenly combination; Im not sure what I like best, the subtly spiced spinach or the chicken, but they make a great combo. When you add the rinsed spinach to the pan after cooking the chicken it will wilt in the liquid left on the leaves after washing, and it will deglaze the pan at the same time.

title: Hungarian Strains and Moonlight
description: The British pianist Paul Lewis has proved an elegant and probing interpreter of Beethoven, whose complete sonatas he has recorded for Harmonia Mundi. On Wednesday night at 7:30, he offers the Moonlight Sonata alongside the less frequently performed Sonata in E flat (Op. 27, No. 1) or Quasi una Fantasia." His program at Zankel Hall also includes two Bach-Busoni chorale preludes, three late works by Liszt and Mussorgskys Pictures at an Exhibition.

title: Soy-Ginger Chicken With Asian Greens or Arugula
description: I serve these spicy pan-cooked pounded chicken breasts over a mound of pungent wild arugula or Asian salad greens. Some of the Asian salad dressing serves as a marinade for the chicken.

title: 2 Prisms for Bach, Classic and Modern
description: For imaginative choreographers like the rising talent Emery LeCrone, a challenge is something to relish. In Bach Interpreted, Ms. LeCrone shows how there can be two sides to one piece of music by creating a pair of dances, each set to Bachs Partita No. 2 in C minor, for the Works & Process series at the Guggenheim Museum. One will be based on classical vocabulary, the other on contemporary movement. Fittingly, the designer Yigal Azroul has created costumes that respond directly to the choreography and performers  an impressive bunch  in each work.

title: Lemon and Garlic Chicken With Mushrooms
description: In this Provenal rendition of pan-cooked chicken breasts, the mushrooms take on an added dimension of flavor as they deglaze the pan with the help of one of their favorite partners, dry white wine.

title: What Made Me | Edward Droste
description: The founder of the band Grizzly Bear reflects on his musical education, songwriting and the bands history.

title: Whos the Oddest of Them All?
description: Jim Hensons Creature Shop Challenge is the stuff dreams are made of  if your reveries star Yoda, Kermit the Frog and flying purple people eaters. This competition series, which begins Tuesday night at 10 on Syfy, follows 10 contestants eager to demonstrate their expertise in sculpting, animatronics, full-body design and generally out-imagining their rivals for $100,000 and a contract with Jim Hensons Creature Shop.

title: Goodbye, Roseland: Gaga Blows a Kiss
description: Lady Gaga is certainly the pop star with the most Twitter followers  over 41 million  who may not even really be a pop star anymore. Her 2013 album Artpop (Streamlive/Interscope)  only her third full-length  had maybe one and a half hits on it. Thats not a wholly fair metric  the album also included some of her more accomplished songwriting and some successful oddball songs  but it landed with a thud, and disappeared in silence. Being known by as many people as she is means that someday all of those people will forget you.

title: Whats a Logical Drone Strikes Policy? Hint: Not the Current One.
description: The Obama administrations targeted killing policy has been the subject of furious debate that has not nearly been put to rest by the governments equivocations.

title: Casual Remarks That Hurt: Microaggression and Adoptive Families
description: Adoptive families, and children who were adopted into them, often talk among ourselves about the dumb things people say to and about us. Where is her real family? Do you know her parents? It bothers some people more than others, and it bothered Kim Kelley Wagner to the point that she created a photo series about it, of the kind thats rapidly becoming ubiquitous: images of those spoken about (in this case, her daughters), holding hand-lettered signs with the offensive words that have been directed at them.

title: Iraq Hit by Wave of Bombings and Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  Thirty-seven people were killed on Friday in a wave of bombings and attacks across Iraq, and eight soldiers were kidnapped, security officials said.

title: Zimmer Breaks His Silence on Mens Wearhouse Deal
description: George Zimmer, the man who was missing in the merger of Mens Wearhouse and its chief rival, Jos. A. Bank, has finally broken his silence.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Divergent
description: Neil Burger narrates a scene from his film starring Shailene Woodley.

title: Did You Go to the Worlds Fair?
description: As the 50th anniversary of the opening of the 1964 Worlds Fair approaches, The New York Times is looking for stories and memories from the fair.

title: Boy, 14, Is Charged With Murder in Stray Shooting on Brooklyn Bus
description: He sat toward the front of the bus, facing forward, immersed in a cellphone conversation, unaware that his life was about to end.

title: Justice Department Names New Leader for Criminal Division
description: The Justice Departments criminal division, which oversees some of the biggest investigations into Wall Street and corporate misdeeds, has a new leader.

title: A Threat to Male Fertility
description: To study the impact of everyday chemicals on fertility, federal researchers recently spent four years tracking 501 couples as they tried to have children. One of the findings stood out: while both men and women were exposed to known toxic chemicals, men seemed much more likely to suffer fertility problems as a result.

title: What Made Me | Edward Droste, Musician
description: More than a decade ago, Edward Droste started Grizzly Bear as a bedroom recording project after college. Today, Grizzly Bear is a four-piece act renowned for its shimmering brand of harmonic, experimental pop, with an international fan-base and four albums to its name (the most recent, Shields, came out in 2012). In the second installment of the What Made Me video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, Droste reflects on his childhood musical education on Cape Cod, how he began writing songs as an adult and what its like for a band to grow up together.

title: Books on the New Deal and an Indian Massacre Win Bancroft Prize
description: Books on racial politics during the New Deal and on an 1864 massacre of American Indians in Colorado have won the Bancroft Prize, considered one of the most prestigious honors in the field of American history.

title: A Pension Fund Invests Against the Rules, and Wins
description: Are the trustees of the Tampa firefighters and police officers pension fund out of their minds?

title: Timid Analysis (Wonkish)
description: I referred to this briefly in todays column, but heres more.

title: That Nuisance in the Sky
description: Last week, a Quinnipiac poll on Bill de Blasios tenure so far revealed, among other judgments, that 64 percent of respondents feel the mayor should not ban horse-drawn carriages, something he has vowed to do, despite disapproval from union leaders and Liam Neeson. It is hard not to admire the ease with which the mayor, standing for the rights of animals, is obviously willing to forfeit any chance of an invitation to the premiere of Taken 3, and at the same time it is hard not to wonder whether his passion for ending a particularly self-indulgent mode of sightseeing might extend to curtailing or eliminating other dubious methods of experiencing the citys landmarks.

title: Big Ticket | Upper East Side Townhouse for $15.77 Million
description: A neo-Classical townhouse on East 64th Street that received its first face-lift in 1910 from John W. Cross, the architect of the Tiffany & Company flagship store on Fifth Avenue, sold for $15,775,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The annual property taxes on the 14-room home are $61,246; the initial 2012 asking price was $19.5 million.

title: In a Squall of Mayhem, Lines Not Crossed
description: Recently, the action-movie genre has evolved into a magpie mash-up of international styles: a no-holds-barred cinema where seemingly anything goes. Its not just that action films range from the pyrotechnic spectacle of Michael Bay to the ugly realism of indie fight tales, or from the jittery documentary-style realism of Kathryn Bigelow to the superhuman hyperbole of Bryan Singer. Now a single film will often deploy every device at once: hyperfast editing and bullet-time slow motion, fanciful kung fu wire work and gritty mixed martial arts, apocalyptic Imax 3-D destruction and acrobatic parkour. The action-movie director has never had so many tools, a development that has yielded some thrilling spectacles and some incoherent messes.

title: A Mystery Womans Eye on the World
description: In her self-portraits, the photographer Vivian Maier could be the actress playing herself in the movie of her life. She confronts the camera with utter self-possession. She affects an austere, distancing look. Her medium-format Rolleiflex is ever-present, slung around her neck, cradled at her sternum, capturing the image reflected off a store window or car mirror. Her clothes  broad hats and big coats, calculated to conceal  suggest a secret agent in a postwar film noir.

title: Kate Bush to Return to the Stage After 35 Years
description: Kate Bush, the British singer-songwriter known for her invitingly eccentric melodies and lyrics with a flexible vocal style to match, announced on her website on Friday that she would play 15 concerts in London in August and September, her first extensive run of shows since 1979, at the beginning of her career, when she toured with an elaborately staged and choreographed production.

title: As Malaysia Goes Its Own Way Over Missing Jet, China Finds Limits to Power
description: BEIJING  China has not held back in forcing the pace of the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. It has deployed 21 satellites and a flotilla of naval ships. It has dispatched investigators to Malaysia, run background checks on the Chinese passengers, and scoured radar images of its vast western regions. Every day it has cajoled, chided and criticized Malaysian officials.

title: Taking More Than Mitts to Australia for Opener
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  Grant Balfours father, David, played rugby for the Balmain Tigers in Australia. Grant would play rugby, too, but he changed the course of his life with one simple question: What are you guys doing?

title: Image of the Day: March 21
Caribbean Flavors, Southern Harmonies
description: Alvin & Friends, a darling of downtown New Rochelle, has moved from its tight quarters on Lawton Street to spacious new digs on Memorial Highway. The place looks like a million bucks, with high ceilings, yards and yards of banquette seating and plenty of elbow room, which comes in handy when you have to fend off companions as they reach for your last morsel of firecracker shrimp or that last lick of ginger crme brle.

title: F.B.I. Agent Is Cleared in Fatal Shooting of Man Tied to Boston Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. agent who fatally shot a Chechen man in Orlando, Fla., during an interrogation in May about the Boston Marathon bombing suspects has been cleared of wrongdoing by a prosecutor in Florida and by an F.B.I. internal review, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Battle for SFR Puts Vivendi in Drivers Seat
description: The latest pitch by Bouygues for SFR, Vivendis mobile phone unit, may still fall short. The French building, TV and telecommunications group has sweetened its offer with 1.85 billion euros more cash and heavyweight backers. That puts extra pressure on the preferred bidder, Patrick Drahi, soon after he began three weeks of exclusive talks to buy Frances No. 2 wireless carrier. But Bouygues still poses greater antitrust risks. It may need to offer more equity in the combined company  and a big breakup fee.

title: Border Patrol Seeks to Add Digital Eyes to Its Ranks
description: PHOENIX  Among the federal officials who gathered here this week for a conclave on border security, there was little talk of building a fence along the 2,000-mile Mexican border. Instead, the chatter was all about technology: about concentrating Border Patrol agents, equipped with late-model surveillance tools, in areas of frequent illegal traffic, while using aerial drones to monitor remote, lightly trafficked spots.

title: New American Amid the Salt Hay
description: In a tiny kitchen in Carlstadt, a town in southern Bergen County better known for its proximity to the Meadowlands than for farm-to-table restaurants, Todd Villani prepares some of the best locally sourced New American dishes in New Jersey.

title: Michelle Obama in China
description: The first lady began her visit to Beijing, accompanied by Chinas first lady, Peng Liyuan.

title: Behind a Simple Storefront, a Standout
description: In recent years, new Asian restaurants on Long Island have resembled palaces, each more dramatic than the last. Thai Coconut is a different story: a modest storefront, set across the street from the Wantagh station of the Long Island Rail Road. The vibrant flavors, tender meats and sparkling seafood, not the setting, are what make Thai Coconut stand out.

title: Book Review Podcast: Dan Hurleys Smarter
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Annie Murphy Paul reviews Dan Hurleys Smarter: The New Science of Building Brain Power. Ms. Paul writes:

title: Wanderlust | Madurai, India, Where Time Stands Still
description: Though its home to more than a million people, Madurai, the second-largest city in the South Indian state of Tamil Nadu, remains a paradigmatic temple town. Around its ragged edges, Madurai looks much like any other medium-sized Indian city, with its clusters of concrete buildings and traffic-choked streets. But at its center  an elegant arrangement of concentric ring roads surrounding the labyrinthine, 17-acre compound of the Meenakshi Temple, among the holiest in South India  the city feels timeless. You come here not to experience the much-touted New India but the India that has endured for centuries.

title: Stunned by Dukes Exit? Mercer Isnt
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Four national championships, a Hall of Fame coach, five-star recruits each year and national exposure second to none. That is the Duke mens basketball program, the envy of most and the measure of just about every team in the N.C.A.A.

title: Artistic Problems Delay Rockettes Heart and Lights Until 2015
description: Heart and Lights, a new dance-oriented show featuring the Rockettes, has been canceled less than a week before it was supposed to open at Radio City Music Hall, its producer announced on Friday, saying that it has become clear that additional work is needed before the production is ready for audiences.

title: Home as Scene Stealer
description: This particular ode to American exceptionalism came wrapped as a lengthy Cadillac commercial looping throughout the Olympics and the Academy Awards. In it, the actor Neal McDonough portrays a brash, fast-talking cheerleader for capitalism who gets in digs at other countries for taking August off. Off!

title: Once a Hit, Its Ratings Make Idol An Also-Ran
description: The fall of the house of Idol continues unabated this season, despite the introduction of improved production values on the show and an appealing new lineup of judges.

title: Russias Shifting of Border Force Stirs U.S. Worry
description: WASHINGTON  The White House cast doubt Friday on the Kremlins claims that thousands of troops massing on the border of southeastern Ukraine are merely involved in training exercises, deepening fears that Russian aggression will not end in Crimea.

title: Dont Worry, Get Botox
description: FEELING down? Smile. Cheer up. Put on a happy face. No doubt youve dismissed these bromides from friends and loved ones because everyone knows that you cant feel better just by aping a happy look.

title: Another Price Cut for the Xbox One
description: SEATTLE  Sonys pricing advantage over Microsoft for the latest generation of game consoles didnt last long.

title: A Long Way From Down-Home
description: For a restaurant as stylishly handsome as Eleven14 Kitchen in Riverside, the name seems curiously ill-fitting.

title: Video: Neil Burger Narrates a Scene From Divergent
description: In this video, the director Neil Burger discusses a scene from Divergent, the film adaptation of Veronica Roths novel, featuring Shailene Woodley.

title: Reader Questions, Answered: Returning to Work After a Career Break
description: After we reported this week on new efforts to help professional women find their way back into the work force after taking a break to care for their family, we invited readers on Motherlode, Twitter and Facebook to ask questions about their own efforts to return to work. Here are some answers from Carol Fishman Cohen and Vivian Steir Rabin, co-authors of Back on the Career Track, and co-founders of iRelaunch, which provides resources for people looking to return to work after staying home to care for children or aging parents.

title: Baylor Continues Its Late Run as Nebraska Goes Cold
description: SAN ANTONIO  Baylor Coach Scott Drew sat in front of an N.C.A.A. banner and acknowledged, with a laugh, how fortunate he was to be doing so. This had all seemed so distant, so improbable, in January, when his Bears were languishing at the bottom of the Big 12, having lost 8 of their first 10 conference games.

title: The Gun Report: March 21, 2014
description: During its latest gun buyback in Newark, N.J., last month, Jewelry for a Causewhich shreds firearms and melts them down into jewelrycollected 185 guns ranging from sniper rifles to assault weapons. Some photos from the resulting shred are above.

title: Finding Each Other, Midlife
description: Though Stephanie Rosenbaum had led more than 100 food tours of San Francisco, she rarely saw a single man older than 40 take part. Mainly women and couples wanted her insiders take on the citys food scene.

title: New York Owes No Damages in Childs Death in 2007, a Jury Decides
description: Sometimes in a verdict, a tiny legal point can make all the difference.

title: Sentimental Journey
description: My mother-in-law hates to travel. As a consolation, shes turned family trips into shopping trips that over the years yielded a staggering collection of quirky egg cups and flower frogs (those things that go inside vases to hold stems in place). The search for these oddities gave her a way to enter strange places on her own terms. They led her into local shops and outdoor markets, introduced her to interesting people and gave purpose to her wanderings when her husband and children decided to hit the second or third major museum of the day.

title: Skadden to Pay $4.25 Million in Fletcher Bankruptcy Case
description: The trustee overseeing the bankruptcy of the investment firm once led by the flashy money manager Alphonse Fletcher Jr. has reached a $4.25 million settlement with the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: In Paris, Pictures at an Airport Exhibition
description: The wait before boarding a plane can feel interminable, but those passing through Pariss Roissy-Charles de Gaulle Airport have a stimulating alternative to idle perfume-testing in the tax-free zone.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Tantalizing Matchups in Champions League Quarterfinals
description: The draw in Zurich on Friday for the quarterfinals of the Champions League yielded four tantalizing matchups.

title: Weekend Reading: March Madness, Wall St. Edition
description: A number of sides are facing off in our financial coverage of the past week. Since weve already blown our NCAA college basketball brackets, lets try out the concept with the news from Wall Street.

title: Legends of the Clipboard
description: There is a long line of colorful characters who have given a thumbs up or thumbs down on an evenings entertainment.

title: Playing Poker With the Devil
description: Maybe this is what an Irish holiday house party looks like outside of the lace-curtain neighborhoods.

title: Premiums Rise for Long-Term Care Insurance. Keep It or Drop It?
description: Every day, Jesse Slome says, about a half-dozen people contact his office at the American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance, a group for industry professionals, to complain about premium increases on their policies.

title: Spring Travel Issue
description: This spring, T is all over the map. Our travel issue visits the sun-soaked Greek island of Hydra, a place of unspoiled and beauty and automobile-free cobblestone streets that seduced Henry Miller and Leonard Cohen, and thatremains a refuge for artists and intellectuals. We head to the sleepy Uruguayan fishing village of Jos Ignacio, where a small group of locals and expats are preserving the areas small-town vibe despite its growing reputation as a beach-lovers paradise. Out of the sun, we share the charms of one-room hotels in four different cities and the Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk extols the virtues of small museums, like his own Museum of Innocence, that offer an inventiveness and personality not found in mega-institutions. Plus, a writer visits barbershops from Beijing to Beirut searching for both the perfect shave and an unforgettable experience; a 18th-century French salon gets resurrected in San Francisco; and one extreme traveler shares pages from his ink-stained passports. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Brooklyns Dance Fever
description: A group of artists contort their bodies while performing flex, a Brooklyn dance featured in the film Flex Is Kings.

title: Silk Road Case Began With Hunt for a John Doe
description: The criminal case against Ross W. Ulbricht, the man who federal prosecutors contend is the mastermind behind the notorious Silk Road online marketplace for illegal drugs and hacked credit card numbers, began quietly with an indictment filed in a Maryland courthouse against an unidentified individual five months before the authorities made an arrest.

title: Theyve Got Moves
description: Flex is the dance. Its practitioners tell stories  cinematic slices of street life  gliding, pausing, dropping, shivering, contorting. One moment their movements are smooth and airy, then suddenly theyre violent, sharp like broken glass. Dancers slow time and speed it up. They use props, costumes and illusion. And their faces twist, transmitting fear, fury, love, mockery.

title: Small Roles Make Big Impressions
description: The Method creator Konstantin Stanislavski supposedly said, There are no small parts, only small actors. Then again, maybe it was just an agent trying to cheer up an underemployed client. In any case, a number of performers are currently making big impressions with relatively minuscule amounts of screen time.

title: If Your Chauffeur Needs a Snowplow
description: DETROIT  It started with a few innocent flakes. (Doesnt it always?) And then a snowstorm barreled into town the night after Christmas, frosting rows of parked cars and smothering the Walter P. Reuther Freeway, an unofficial autobahn where traffic tends to stream at 80 to 85 miles per hour. But not tonight. Confidence plummeted in direct proportion to the snowfall. Drivers picked their way along the freeways eerie, white-glowing moonscape like nervous skiers on a powder run.

title: Wolf for Wall Street
description: Bentleys Flying Spur ultraluxury sedan prevails in bad weather, but not all of its technology is cutting-edge.

title: The (Door) Man of the Hour
description: Its hard to miss Markus Kelle, 24, at the door of Westgay, the scruffy Tuesday night party at Westway on Clarkson Street in the West Village. At midnight on a recent Tuesday, he wore a black snood, clip-on earrings made of old celluloid, blood-red lipstick and a pavement-length silver fox coat.

title: Hall of Fame Removes Trainer From Ballot
description: Steve Asmussen was removed Friday as one of the finalists for the Racing Hall of Fame while three states investigate allegations that he and an assistant mistreated thoroughbred racehorses in their care.

title: A Cross Between Risotto and Paella, the Catalan Way
description: One of the best meals I ever had was on a strip of beach near Barcelonas port, in a seafood restaurant built on stilts. Barceloneta, as the area is called, housed a collection of such places, each with a barker outside and breezy nautical dining rooms looking out to sea. Most had tables set in the sand below, too. (This vanished when the city later remodeled for the Olympics and it became a boardwalk.) All fish, all day was the motto, and indeed it was the very freshest.

title: Oops, Sorry for Being So Creepy
description: Have you ever been unintentionally cybercreepy? I have. A few weeks ago, after stashing my bathing suit and towel in my locker at my gym, I reached for my cellphone to check my email. You cant have a cellphone in here! an older gym-goer rebuked me. Thinking he feared I was about to conduct a lengthy phone call about how I like enough mustard on a sandwich such that the salami comes alive but not so much that it becomes a mustard sandwich, I explained to the man that I was only checking my email. No, its not that, he rightly explained to me. There are naked people in here. I apologized and skittered off.

title: N.C.A.A. Round of 64: The Day in Pictures
description: Day 2 of the round of 64 was full of more excitement, including Duke losing to Mercer and Stanford toppling New Mexico.

title: Costume Drama on the Cheap
description: Man your battle stations! Around 3 p.m. on a recent Friday, the announcement came over the P.A. system deep inside the basement of the Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens. A jolt of expectation shot through a line of nearly 50 people, who had been patiently waiting in a hallway outside a set of locked doors.

title: The xx Makes Over the Armory
description: The British pop band the xx play on themes of exposure and intimacy in the immensity of the Park Avenue Armory drill hall, inverting almost all of what is expected in rock.

title: Bill Cunningham | Wearing It Forward
description: Guests dressed for the fall Dior show on Feb. 28, at the Rodin Museum in Paris, made a loud statement about the diversity of the women.

title: Credit Suisse Reaches $885 Million Mortgage Settlement
description: Credit Suisse said on Friday that it had reached an$885 million settlement to resolve claims that it soldquestionable loans to the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in the lead-up to the financial crisis.

title: Bill Cunningham | Wear it Forward
description: Guests dressed for the fall Dior show on Feb. 28, at the Rodin Museum in Paris, made a loud statement about the diversity of the women. A highlight: seeing what they had on from the previous Dior show, held last September for the spring line; back then, it seemed like two shows, the first one with all the dressmaker details that customers admire, and the second featuring silver flecked brocades (top left). If the clients in February were a gauge, brocades (top) won out over details (the three women at left). My first Paris Dior show was in 1951, Only couture was presented; ready-to-wear did not exist. Highly styled women went privately, days after the show. Another item from September worn a few weeks ago: a swatch of fabric around the waist (far right), which Raf Simons created by lifting a sash built into a 1949 Dior dress (far right, bottom) and making it an accessory. Will the stoles worn on the arm on the runway a few weeks ago (bottom) end up on clients in September?

title: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 83
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Remembering LWren Scott, Kim and Kanyes Cover Story and Phoebe Philos Crowning Moment
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Stanford Sends New Mexico to Another Early Exit
description: ST. LOUIS  Some teams want to avoid top seeds in the opening game of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Other teams want to sidestep opponents with contrasting playing styles to ensure the best matchup of skills.

title: The xxs Armory Show: Step by Step
description: The British electro-pop trio the xx is no stranger to vast concert spaces, having headlined the Governors Ball Music Festival and Radio City Music Hall. But the shows the group is staging in the 55,000-square-foot Drill Hall at the Park Avenue Armory are more ambitious and more intimate than anything it has attempted before.

title: LWren Scott: A Legacy of Elegance
description: IN THE AFTERMATH of LWren Scotts death, media coverage, which was in no short supply, tended to focus on the questions of why and who. Why a woman who seemed to have it all would choose to end her life, and who among her friends, beginning with her partner, Mick Jagger, could explain it. Less attention was paid to what she had created: her fashion collections.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 21
description: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes second official weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Im Not Getting Better, Im Getting Older
description: No more prostitutes, Annabelle Gurwitch says as we swill our pinot grigio in the lobby bar of the Shutters hotel in Santa Monica, Calif. Its tragic. Playing prostitutes used to be my specialty. The actress/author and I are gleefully debating everything in life we must leave behind now that were over 50, and everything we must embrace.

title: An Online Generation Redefines Mourning
description: In 2010, when Rebecca Soffers father died of a heart attack on a cruise to the Bahamas, the condolence notes came pouring in, many in the form of text messages. I got so many from very good friends, Ms. Soffer, 37, said from the couch of her Upper West Side apartment not long ago. They said they were sorry or how r u?

title: Fresh From a Kentucky Sinkhole, Recovered Vettes Draw Crowds
description: Corvettes are built to go fast and stop fast, but they were never designed to free-fall 40 or 50 feet. Yet that is what happened to eight of the Chevrolet sports cars in the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., when a sinkhole opened in the facilitys Skydome area in the predawn hours of Feb. 12.

title: Taking Bids for the Next Beast
description: The Secret Service is shopping for a new car  something durable and roomy, and unlike anything else on the road.

title: Sticker Shock From the Options Sheet
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF.  Up a flight of stairs from the Porsche Design boutique on Rodeo Drive, in a room of modernist sofas and chairs, low white coffee tables and oversize video monitors, is the Porsche Exclusive-Personal Design suite. Prospective car buyers come to this luxury lounge to optimize their accessories: Here, they can choose precisely the right optional extras to maximize their vehicular happiness.

title: Evening Hours | Cultural Swirl
description: Art, music and dance were the focus of many benefits as winter came to a close.

title: Earthy, With a Hint of Fiberglass
description: Collectors groaned when $1 million worth of Corvettes plunged into a sinkhole at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky.

title: Under Cover: Ian Lawrence on Becoming One of the Faces of Bisexuality
description: Ian Lawrence, who has been an activist in the bisexual community for 14 years, didnt hesitate to be interviewed and photographed for Benoit Denizet-Lewiss article about the quest to prove scientifically that bisexuality exists. Still, Lawrence was surprised when he landed on the cover of this Sundays magazine. Heres what he had to say about his familys reaction and what he plans to do with this newfound visibility.

title: The Decline and Fall of the H Word
description: To most ears, it probably sounds inoffensive. A little outdated and clinical, perhaps, but innocuous enough: homosexual.

title: Institutional Memory Onstage
description: A choreographer needs a dancer the way a dancer needs a choreographer. Its an even swap.

title: In Many States, Few Legal Rights for C.C.R.C. Residents
description: Im not nave about the corporate world, Burton Richter told me when we spoke about the class action lawsuit he and other residents are bringing against Vi at Palo Alto, a very upscale continuing care retirement community.

title: In the Air | Space Age Style
description: This season, fashion looks to the heavens, taking inspiration from both space-age design and the wondrous immensity of the night sky.

title: The Government Is No Drunken Sailor
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Top-Seeded Arizonas Road So Far Has Been a Struggle
description: SAN DIEGO  When Arizona was delayed by nearly four hours when it traveled here Wednesday night, it might have been a sign that the road to the Final Four would not be as easily traversed as the Wildcats imagined.

title: The Sinkhole Doubters Emerge
description: Was it an inside job?

title: A Dance Spreads Joy for Mercer
description: In Mercers 78-71 upset victory over Duke on Friday in the N.C.A.A. tournament, the senior guard Kevin Canevari had zero points, one assist and one spontaneous outburst of joy gone viral.

title: The Tentative, the Vibrant and Then the Impassioned
description: In its official biography, the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra is described as the countrys premier cultural ambassador. The ensembles international tours are also good-will missions. Its current 14-city American tour brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night for a concert presented by the American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: How and Why They Are Raising the Bayonne Bridge Roadway
description: Diagrams showing the current and planned roadways on the bridge.

title: Going Up! A Bridge Makes Way for Bigger Ships
description: When it opened in 1931, the Bayonne Bridge  with its parabolic arch connecting Staten Island and Bayonne, N.J.  was an engineering marvel, boasting the longest unsupported span of any steel arch bridge in the world. But the height of its roadway, at 151 feet above the Kill Van Kull waterway, is increasingly insufficient for the large container ships now calling at the container ports of Staten Island and New Jersey.

title: After Playing In, Tennessee Plays On
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Those First Four play-in games might be an insult to teams that are forced to compete in an extra contest even after making the tournament field. But maybe theyre not such a bad deal.

title: The Book of Mormon Is to Sell Tickets via StubHub
description: StubHub, the online ticket marketplace, has long listed scalped seats for Broadway shows at high prices, to the chagrin of both theater fans and the producers missing lucrative markups. But now those producers are trying to get in on the action.

title: A Galaxy of Orbs and Novas
description: Alonzo Kings Constellation features a grid of LED lights designed by the electronic artist Jim Campbell and strung up like a beaded curtain at the rear of the stage. Illumination and color pass across the grid like a pixelated aurora borealis, sometimes outlining what seem to be shadows of birds in flight. But mostly the light is as incomprehensible as a solar flare. Mr. Kings dance, which his Lines Ballet opened  on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, is itself like a string of lights, with 19 shiny sections presented in 75 minutes. Mr. King leaves it to the viewer to connect the dots.

title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Michigans Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
description: A federal judge in Detroit struck down Michigans ban on same-sex marriage on Friday, the latest in a string of court decisions across the country to rule that denying marriage to gay and lesbian couples is a violation of the Constitution.

title: Brazilian Yearning and Imminent Loss
description: The Girl From Ipanema has been embedded in the worlds consciousness for so long (half a century) that nowadays this seductive Antnio Carlos Jobim melody tends to register as cozy, even annoying background music. Do listeners even look beyond its travel poster image of a tall and tan and young and lovely dream girl on a beach, sketched in Norman Gimbels English-language translation of Vinicius de Moraess Portuguese lyrics?

title: A Sunrise in the American Southwest Helps Inspire Another Dawning
description: Among the many wonders of Beth Gills New Work for the Desert is that the dance lasts an hour but seems much shorter or possibly much longer: It alters your sense of time. In this way, it successfully suggests one of its inspirations, a sunrise in the American Southwest. Thomas Dunns lighting, gradually brightening, eventually suffuses the white space with lemon and blood orange. But the greatest wonders emerge from Ms. Gills choreography and her six dancers.

title: It Aint Over Till the Fat Man Spits: Recalling a Colorful Coach
description: Luv Ya Blue, an electronic sign reads as you enter the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa for its current show, referring to the defunct Houston Oilers of the National Football League through the color of their home jerseys. The word Blue flashes at times, seeming to short out, then morphs into Bum.

title: Detroit Symphony Dives Headlong Into Streaming
description: DETROIT  Orchestras and opera companies in the United States and Europe, facing uncertain futures and rapid changes in how people listen to music, are increasingly making forays into web streaming, taking one of Western cultures most traditional live art forms out of theaters and concert halls and putting it onto small screens.

title: Holding a Mirror to Race
description: A new website uses vintage photos  presented at first without context  to get viewers to confront everyday assumptions about race.

title: McDermott Scores 30 as Creighton Advances
description: SAN ANTONIO  In assessing its showings at the N.C.A.A. tournament the last two years, Creighton did not feel that it had underachieved so much as failed to maximize its potential. There is a difference. Both times the Bluejays were bounced by a higher seed, the better team.

title: Outside the U.S., Steps to Track Planes Better
description: PARIS  Some foreign regulators and airlines have moved much faster than their American counterparts to adopt more advanced airplane tracking technology.

title: Melodies Steeped in Memories
description: Sometimes an outsider is best at showing an institution its own history, and on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Jeffrey Kahane held a striking mirror up to the New York Philharmonic of the 1920s and 30s.

title: The Spring North American Championships
description: DALLAS  The first national title decided at the Spring North American Championships began last year in bridge clubs across the continent.

title: Pictures of the Day  Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Afghanistan and More: Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Ukraine, Brazil and India.

title: Malaysian Opposition Leader Calls Speculation About Pilot of Missing Jet Absurd
description: Malaysias opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, dismissed speculation that the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, a supporter of his movement for democratic change, might have hijacked the plane for political reasons, in an interview with Britains Channel 4 News on Friday.

title: U.S. Pushes for Wider Recall of Graco Car Seats
description: Graco Childrens Products, which resisted recalling about 1.8 million child restraints earlier this year, has responded to a special order from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration demanding more information about incidents or injuries involving the rear-facing infant restraints. But despite continued pressure from the safety agency, Graco is not saying whether it will remain steadfast in its refusal.

title: Turkey and Twitter
Cooking for Her Men, and Serving the Audience
description: Well, its no Long Days Journey Into Night.

title: One Foot in Each of Two Worlds, and a Pen at Home in Both
description: SHARJAH, United Arab Emirates  WHEN Leila Aboulela arrived at the international book fair here recently, the conference room was packed to capacity with dozens of eager listeners. After she finished reading a passage from her award-winning novel, Lyrics Alley, the torrent of questions  some in English, others in Arabic  began.

title: Walking the Dog to Awaken the Muse
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda has lived in Greenwich Village, Inwood, Upper West Hell (as he calls a dreary block between the Upper West Side and Hells Kitchen) and now Harlem with his wife, Vanessa Nadal, a lawyer, though they are about to move  at long last  to Washington Heights, where Mr. Miranda, 34, set his hit Broadway musical, In the Heights. Yet no matter the neighborhood, his Sundays have always been about art. Lately, besides working on Hamilton, a rap-infused bio-musical about Alexander Hamilton that will open early next year at the Public Theater, he has been curating a monthly film series at the United Palace of Cultural Arts in the Heights, where Ghostbusters is screening on March 23.

title: Jets Release Mark Sanchez to Make Room for Michael Vick
description: Jets Coach Rex Ryan once felt so certain of quarterback Mark Sanchez that he repeatedly referred to him as Sanchize and had a tattoo of his wife wearing a Sanchez jersey added to his right arm.

title: Kansas Closes Out Eastern Kentucky
description: ST. LOUIS  The Kansas players were aware of what had happened to Duke earlier Friday. The Blue Devils loss to Mercer in the Round of 64 was another reminder of the long history of upsets in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and its impact resonated on the Jayhawks bench before their South Region opener.

title: Flowers, Yes, but Figures, Too, at Garden Party
description: Though the curators of Garden Party, the new exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, could not have foreseen the brutal winter that has preceded their celebration of luscious flora, they nevertheless feel fortunate about the timing.

title: Should We Welcome Private Science?
Stores With Pharmacies That Sell Tobacco Products
description: To the Editor:

title: The Betrayals of Paul Ryan
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Disarmament
description: To the Editor:

title: Countering the Gun Lobby
description: To the Editor:

title: Friday Night Music: The Advantages of Floating
description: Not, as it turns out, about currency regimes; but theres a pretty good exposition of physiocratic economics in there. Inspired, of course, by this mornings Japan session at Brookings.

title: Jack Fleck, Who Stole Hogans Moment at 1955 U.S. Open, Dies at 92
description: When Jack Fleck drove from his native Iowa to Olympic Club in San Francisco for the 1955 United States Open, he was in the midst of a two-year trial run to see if he could make it on the PGA Tour. If not, he would return to Davenport and the life of a professional at two municipal courses.

title: Beware of Cold-Blooded Americans
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  AMERICANS are predatory. They invade other countries, prey on native populations and exploit their resources. They are typically voracious, opportunistic and highly adaptive. It is said they are filthy; they can tolerate living in polluted areas and can carry diseases to which locals have no immunity. As we speak, they are causing global ecological damage.

title: Eyes Alighting Between the Canals
description: Ah, Venice. Can anyone go there without wanting to bring home a picture? In the 18th century, travelers bought paintings by Canaletto; today, tourists point and shoot with cellphones and digital cameras, capturing the same grand churches, peeling palaces and shimmering canals.

title: If Only for a Night
description: St. Patricks Day, that annual excuse for overindulgence, would seem  like alcohol itself  to heighten the desire for love while lessening the chance of achieving it. But at least according to the Internet, several revelers managed on Monday to find romance in spite of their intoxication. The following poems about attraction on St. Patricks Day were found this week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.Connollys St. Patricks DayYou told me Im nice.You stroked my beardand told methat Im handsomebut you werent into facial hair.You told me your nameand you left. Mm, I hope youfind me.4 or 5 Between Wall St & GCSWe shared a few glances,possibly a million miles apartbut I thoughtthere was a spark ofconnection.I was the guy in the greenjacketin a sea of green jackets.Luckily you askedare you famous?and we chatted for secondsbefore both getting off at GrandCentral Stationand going separate ways.Youre studying on the 17thas life goes onaround the St Patricks dayparade on 5th.Your brown eyes were hypnoticbut I did catch a glimpseof jet black hairand fair/pale complexionbefore having to look awayout of politenessI Told You You Were HandsomeI was waitressing St. Paddys....You were a firefighter. Youcame in after the paradeand was surprised Iremembered youand told you were handsome.We live very far apartbut you saidwe could make it work.Maybefor a least a night.Holly at Dermotts Today

title: Unwilling to Allow His Wife a Divorce, He Marries Another
description: LAS VEGAS  The wedding was a modest affair, held in a reception hall overlooking an artificial lake tucked behind a suburban strip. But just minutes after it ended, the bride and groom hurriedly scurried past dozens of protesters here who were chanting Bigamist! and Shame on you!

title: Coping When Not Entering Retirement Together
description: FOR Daniel Ryan, turning 40 and 50 came and went. But sometime around his 61st birthday last July, he said he had an old man crisis.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Current Fees on Debit Card Purchases
description: In the latest chapter of the debit card fee wars, the banks and Federal Reserve were dealt a victory on Friday when a federal appeals court overturned a lower courts decision. The ruling means that the amount banks collect from retailers when consumers swipe debit cards can remain as is, and not be reduced further.

title: Creativity vs. Quants
description: Heres how John Lennon wrote Nowhere Man, as he recalled it in an interview that ran just before he was murdered in 1980: After working five hours trying to craft a song, he had nothing to show for it. Then, Nowhere Man came, words and music, the whole damn thing as I lay down.

title: Highly Enriched Danger
description: NEXT week President Obama will join 57 world leaders in The Hague for the third biannual Nuclear Security Summit. The first two summits played a critical role in phasing out the use of highly enriched uranium as fuel in research reactors to prevent its misuse by states or terrorists to make nuclear weapons.

title: A Record for Tomic, but One to Quickly Forget
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Many who saw the potential in the young star Bernard Tomic believed he would one day enter the record books in a far different fashion than the way he did Thursday.

title: A Burst of Spring Blossoms
description: The red maple (Acer rubrum) is an attention-grabber in its brilliant autumn guise, but the tree also produces a dazzling spring show for the observant urban naturalist. The trees delicate blossoms are as red as its autumn leaves, but they last only a few days.

title: Lawmakers Attack Cost of New Hepatitis Drug
