description: A new drug to treat hepatitis C that costs $1,000 a pill has caused rising concern among insurers and state Medicaid programs. It has now also spurred interest from Democratic congressmen whose queries about the drug prompted a sell-off in biotechnology stocks on Friday.

title: In Paris Campaign, Left and Right Have One Thing in Common
description: PARIS  If cities had genders, Paris would almost surely be a woman. So much about it seems feminine: the sensuous curves of the Seine around which it is built, the ubiquitous concern for the cut of a coat, the elegance of its cityscape. And now, Paris is on the eve of electing its first female mayor.

title: Sergeant Missing Since 1964 Is Given Funeral
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Nearly 50 years after Staff Sgt. Lawrence Woods of the United States Army disappeared while fighting in the Vietnam War, a funeral service was held for him at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Russian Defiance Is Seen as a Confidence Builder for Syrias Government
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Russias growing rift with the West over the crisis in Ukraine has bolstered the confidence of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, pro-government analysts here say, emboldening him to press ahead with plans for re-election despite a three-year insurgency and making Syrian officials doubt that Russia will pressure him to compromise anytime soon.

title: Mercer Sees Value in Mastering a Simple Task That Foils Many
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Mercer Bears and their unassuming, previously unappreciated band of underdogs  admit it, most of us had no idea where Mercer was even located, much less that great basketball was played there  had the precise ingredients for an upset.

title: As Listener and Saleswoman, E.P.A. Chief Takes to the Road for Climate Rules
description: BEULAH, N.D.  Gina McCarthy was deep in enemy territory.

title: In Reprieve for Restaurant Industry, New York Proposes Changes to Grading System
description: They are one of the most visible legacies of the Bloomberg administration and a ubiquitous presence in the culinary life of New York: the blue A, green B and orange C letter grades that trumpet the sanitary conditions of the restaurant within.

title: E.P.A. Agrees to Join North Carolina in Reviewing Spill
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency will join North Carolina regulators in addressing potential violations of the Clean Water Act at Duke Energy power plants, including a massive spill of toxic coal ash last month in the Dan River, state officials said on Friday.

title: Blue Devils Parker Feels Incomplete After Upset
description: CHICAGO  Eight hundred miles from Raleigh, N.C., where the Duke freshman Jabari Parker played on the biggest stage of his young life on Friday, friends, former teammates and teachers gathered in his high school lunchroom at Simeon Career Academy to watch his latest star turn.

title: Rhode Island: Raids Target Speaker of State House, but Reason Is Unclear
description: Federal and state law enforcement agents raided the office and home of Gordon D. Fox, the speaker of the Rhode Island House, on Friday, but did not disclose what they were looking for. As news media gathered outside, agents filed out of both locations with boxes and bags. Mr. Fox returned home in the afternoon and said nothing to reporters who were waiting outside. Conducting the searches were agents from the F.B.I., the Internal Revenue Service, the United States attorneys office and the state police. The surprise searches stunned Providence, sending politicians and reporters scurrying for answers that did not immediately materialize. The information vacuum did not stop some politicians from calling for the speakers resignation or others from suggesting they might run for speaker themselves. Mr. Fox, 52, a Democrat, was first elected to the state House of Representatives in 1992 and has been speaker since February 2010. He had planned to run again for his seat this fall and hoped to keep his position as speaker.

title: Blue-Collar Renaissance: Texas Recalls How to Win
description: MILWAUKEE  Smiles abounded in the Texas locker room on Friday, not quite 24 hours after the Longhorns won their first N.C.A.A. tournament game in three years. Players who were not interviewed pulled chairs near one another to chat, joke and laugh. And no one signaled disengagement by strapping on headphones or ear buds.

title: Wheelies: The 20 Million Hondas Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Paul Ryan, Culture and Poverty
description: Paul Ryan continues to be flogged for disturbing comments he made last week about men in our inner cities and their culture of not working.

title: U.S. and California Officials Enter Battle Over Facebook Privacy Settlement
description: A couple of government wingmen have joined privacy groups in their legal dogfight with Facebook over the companys use of teenagers likes and comments in advertising.

title: After Ruling, Alabama Joins 2 States in Moving to Alter Voting Rules
description: Alabama says it plans to move ahead with a requirement for potential voters to show concrete proof of citizenship, in the first sign of a wider impact from a court decision on Wednesday ordering a federal elections agency to help Arizona and Kansas enforce their own such requirement.

title: Trip Upstate Takes Coach Back to Roots
description: BUFFALO  In 1984, Mike Neer, then the coach at the University of Rochester, needed a full-time assistant, somebody to get out on the road and recruit, but the 23-year-old sitting in the interview had experience with neither.

title: Health Care Caricature
description: Republican leaders are making preposterous assertions that President Obama has abandoned a centerpiece of his health care reforms  the requirement that most people obtain comprehensive insurance or pay a penalty. In a cartoonish misrepresentation of how so-called hardship exemptions will be determined, the leaders, egged on by their allies in the conservative media, contend that recent steps by the administration undermine the individual mandate by giving virtually everyone who wants one a free pass to escape the penalty.

title: Gonzaga Is Good Enough
description: SAN DIEGO  For a good portion of the last three months, Gonzaga guard Kevin Pangos has been troubled by turf toe and a sore ankle. His toe and ankle do not feel perfectly healthy, but at this point in the season he has no complaints.

title: Turkeys Move to Silence Twitter
description: The Turkish governments assault on free speech reached a self-defeating low this week with its order to silence Twitter  an authoritarian move that quickly backfired in the tech-savvy world of social media.

title: Following Great Score With Good One, Scott Extends Lead
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  In the first round of the Arnold Palmer Invitational, Adam Scott posted the 11th score of 62 or better on the PGA Tour this season. Two of the other 62s  by Tim Clark at Sea Island, Ga., and Zach Johnson outside Palm Springs, Calif.  were recorded in the final round.

title: Court Orders Rehiring of 2 Brooklyn Teachers in Misconduct Case
description: It was a November night in 2009 when Alina Brito, a Spanish teacher at James Madison High School in Brooklyn, and Cindy Mauro, a French teacher there, went out with a colleague to a neighborhood restaurant for dinner, and a cocktail or two.

title: As Sanctions Start, Russia Feels a Sting
description: MOSCOW  American and European sanctions rattled Russias economy on Friday, with Moscows stock indexes opening sharply lower, rating agencies threatening to reduce the countrys creditworthiness, and hints of trepidation coming from Russias tycoons as they concluded an annual conference here.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 21, 2014
description: March 21, 2014

title: Dying Churches, Revived in a Flash
description: The idea behind Buffalo Mass Mob is simple. Pick an old Roman Catholic church, in one of Buffalos hollowed-out immigrant neighborhoods, where the congregation has dwindled to a white-haired few, where the spaces beneath the great stone arches ring with the echo of abandonment. Send the word by Facebook and Twitter to Catholics across western New York: O.K., everybody, lets all show up there one Sunday.

title: North Dakota State Thinks Big, Has Fun, Earns Attention
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The fun began long before North Dakota State Coach Saul Phillips, in the middle of a news conference Friday (the man has turned scripted drudgery into performance art), asked his boss for a raise. Phillips joked that he got the job in the first place because he had pictures of his boss, the athletic director, who just laughed.

title: Two Cases, One Conclusion on Military Justice
description: WASHINGTON  Two highly publicized military sexual assault cases this week appear to strengthen the argument of those who want to take such cases out of the hands of military commanders  but not only for the reason that has been widely debated in Congress, which is that the hierarchy is unfair to women.

title: Memphis Struggles Past George Washington
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Memphis arrived at PNC Arena with a rsum featuring a pair of wins over No.-5 ranked Louisville among a handful of head-turning victories this season. Performances like that could give top seeds in the tournament reason to worry.

title: A Womens History Museum, at Last?
description: It took seven decades before the rudely banished monument to three historic suffragists  Susan B. Anthony, Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Lucretia Mott  was hauled up from the basement of the United States Capitol in 1997 and restored to its rightful place by the rotunda.

title: After Leaving Victim in the Cold, the Police Work to Make It Right
description: When the detectives arrived at Fredrick Brennans apartment in Brooklyn in January, it was not to question him about the theft or show him pictures of suspects or return the money stolen from him. That had all been taken care of already.

title: Signs of Things to Come
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Well, this was a zippy outing. With entries like FLEW BY and RAN ALONG, how could you not solve this puzzle by Greg Johnson at a relatively fast clip?

title: G.M.s Bankruptcy Drawn Into Defect Inquiry
description: Federal authorities nascent investigation into General Motors is looking in part into whether the automaker committed bankruptcy fraud by not disclosing defects that could lead to expensive future liabilities, a person briefed on the inquiry said on Friday.

title: Wichita State Is Still Unbeaten
description: ST. LOUIS  Joe Callero, the Cal Poly basketball coach, said he dreamed of his team becoming a 16th seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament so it could make history with an unprecedented upset.

title: North Korea: Rockets Fired in a Test Land in the Sea
description: North Korea test-fired 30 short-range rockets off its east coast on Saturday, the latest in a series of military actions condemned by South Korea. The rockets flew about 37 miles before landing in the sea between North Korea and Japan, the South Korean military said. North Korea has conducted a series of tests of short-range ballistic missiles and rockets since late February. On Sunday, the North launched 25 short-range rockets off its east coast. South Korea urged North Korea to stop its provocative acts, saying they had raised military tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula. The tests have coincided with the joint military exercises that South Korea and the United States began last month.

title: Decades Later, the Clave Beat Goes on for Latin Jazz and Jewish Musicians
description: Sometime in the late 1940s, two young Latin musicians in New York, Joe Loco and Tito Puente, sat down to compose songs for a new album by the bandleader Pupi Campo. Mostly, they wrote in a language and style intended for the citys postwar wave of Cuban and Puerto Rican newcomers, the obvious audience.

title: An Autobiography, Written in Bodies
description: Ian Spencer Bell likes to divide his dances into two categories, quiet and talking: those danced in silence and those accompanied by text that he writes and recites. Accompanied, though, is not quite the right word. At its best, his movement itself seems to do the talking, physical sentences inseparable from verbal ones  neither upstaging the other  so that what results is not dance and not poetry but some third medium.

title: Works Seldom Heard, From Haunting to Jubilant
description: The motto of the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, which gave a semi-staged concert of Handel rarities at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening under the direction of Thomas Crawford, is music as the masters heard it. But Alceste, a Handel adaptation of Euripides conceived as a masque combining music, dance and spoken theater that was intended to be performed at Covent Garden in 1750, never made it to the stage in his time. Beyond a few rehearsals with the singers, the master never did hear the music.

title: The Sorrows of Hades and the Glories of Spring
description: The Boston Early Music Festival presented a double bill of short operas by Marc-Antoine Charpentier at the Morgan Library & Museum on Monday evening, led from within the continuo section by Paul ODette and Stephen Stubbs, two lutenists who are the festivals joint musical directors. The innovative production by Gilbert Blin largely made up for an uneven performance by the vocalists, and an often indifferent one by the instrumentalists. As early-music brands go, the Boston festival has long enjoyed a reputation for combining high musical standards with rigorous scholarship, and there was a solid dose of scholarship in the program notes, which had the length and intellectual heft of two academic papers.

title: North Carolina Edges Providence in Final Seconds
description: SAN ANTONIO  James Michael McAdoos most important contribution for North Carolina was not his go-ahead free throw with 3.5 seconds left Friday night. It was the rebound of his next foul shot.

title: A Senator on the Stump With a Frank Message: Give Me More Stature
description: WASHINGTON  The red-and-white campaign signs are on lampposts across the capital, urging voters to re-elect Paul Strauss as the United States senator from the District of Columbia.

title: Yankees Insurance Policy at Shortstop Has a Physical Problem of His Own
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeter walked past Brendan Ryan in the Yankees clubhouse Friday afternoon, jokingly turning his entire body toward his teammate to say hello, moving as deliberately as a robot. Other teammates have called Ryan Robo Cop because his injured back prevents him from moving with any fluidity, and one teammate referred to Carl Pavano, a former Yankees pitcher known for being frequently injured.

title: Murray L. Weidenbaum, Reagan Economist, Dies at 87
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, who as President Ronald Reagans first chief economic adviser elevated government regulation of business to the forefront of public policy debate, but resigned unhappy about the administrations budget-making, died on Thursday in St. Louis. He was 87.

title: Knicks Survive Late Run by Sixers
description: PHILADELPHIA  If the Knicks lost Friday night, there would have been major explaining to do.

title: Howard H. Callaway, Strategist Who Helped G.O.P. Rise in South, Dies at 86
description: Howard H. Callaway, a Republican politician and strategist from the South who played leading roles in the presidential campaigns of Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford and served as secretary of the Army under both, died on March 15 in Columbus, Ga. He was 86.

title: Lopez Still in Plans; Nets Stay on Roll
description: Brook Lopez has not been able to do much the past three months but sit around his apartment and heal his ailing body. Lopez, the Nets 25-year-old center, has not shaved much, General Manager Billy King joked, and he has allowed his hair to become rather unkempt.

title: Bridges Neighbors Fight Bike Path on Tappan Zee
description: SOUTH NYACK, N.Y.  It seems like a generous gift to the people of New York State: a three-mile path for bicyclists and pedestrians stretching across the silvery waters of the Hudson River on a new Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: New Parks Dept. Leader Shares de Blasios Goal of Addressing Inequities
description: When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the new commissioner of the citys Department of Parks and Recreation on Friday, it was not on the well-tended greenswards of Central Park or at Prospect Parks recently completed high-design skating complex. Instead, he introduced Mitchell J. Silver, a planning official in Raleigh, N.C., and a Brooklyn native, at Seward Park on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, a small patch of green surrounded by tenements and public housing.

title: Fall Down SoHo Elevator Shaft Injures Girl
description: A 12-year-old girl was seriously injured on Friday when she fell about 35 feet down an elevator shaft at a Manhattan co-op, setting in motion a rescue that drew 20 emergency workers, the authorities said.

title: Staggered by 4-Point Play, V.C.U. Is Sunk in Overtime
description: SAN DIEGO  Havoc is what Virginia Commonwealth does. The word is emblazoned across the backs of the teams warm-up outfits. It is on the cover of the media guide. And it is liberally dropped into conversation.

title: Ex-Christie Aides Seek Immunity in Deal for Bridge Scandal Documents
description: Lawyers for the two aides dismissed by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey in the scandal over the closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge struck back on Friday at the legislative committee investigating the closings, arguing in court filings that if the panel wanted them to turn over documents, it would have to grant the aides broad immunity against prosecution.

title: How Much Europe Depends on Russian Energy
description: Map of European energy imports that come from Russia.

title: Coach Faces Renewed Questions About the N.B.A.
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The news media interview area at Amway Center here is at the Magics practice court, and Florida Coach Billy Donovans presence has led to several questions about whether he would consider taking an N.B.A. job.

title: No. 1 Seed Virginia Survives Scare
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  It took the Virginia Cavaliers 31 years to earn a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament. In 40 minutes, they very nearly blew it.

title: In Dominating Win, Iowa State Is Dealt a Blow: Niang Is Hurt
description: SAN ANTONIO  When his teams matchup was revealed last week, Iowa State Coach Fred Hoiberg had but one reaction, he said: I got a little worried.

title: Those Who Stayed With UConn Helped Save It
description: When the University of Connecticut was hit with a postseason ban before the 2012-2013 season, the mens basketball team became a house divided.

title: Next Up for Kentucky: Wichita State
description: ST. LOUIS  The eighth-seeded Kentucky Wildcats set up aSundayshowdown with top-seeded Wichita State, cruising past Kansas State, 56-49, onFridayat Scottrade Center.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Encore) L.A. CONFIDENTIAL (1997) Kevin Spacey, Russell Crowe and Guy Pearce (above right, with Mr. Crowe) are detectives in 1950s Los Angeles who become embroiled in a scandal encompassing three murder cases. Kim Basinger plays a call girl who becomes involved in the investigation. Janet Maslin, in her review for The New York Times, called this film, directed by Curtis Hanson and adapted from a James Ellroy novel, a tough, gorgeous, vastly entertaining throwback to the Hollywood that did things right. She added that the Los Angeles depicted is a film noir paradise of smoldering evil and knee-weakening glamour with a dirty little secret behind every palm tree. The film won two Oscars: best adapted screenplay for Brian Helgeland and Mr. Hanson, and best supporting actress for Ms. Basinger.

title: Corrections: March 22, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: 20 Years Later, U.C.L.A. Knocks Off Tulsa
description: SAN DIEGO  Geography has never been a strong suit of U.C.L.A. basketball players. Before one N.C.A.A. tournament game against Penn State, a Bruin said he thought the Nittany Lions played in the Ivy League. Before U.C.L.A. opened the 1994 tournament against Tulsa  with a 112-102 loss  another Bruin said he did not know the university was in Oklahoma.

title: Analytics: Grading the Test
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the March 23 issue of the magazine.

title: As Numbers Swell, Students Pledge to Continue Occupying Taiwans Legislature
description: Students who have occupied Taiwans Legislature to oppose the governing partys efforts to approve a trade deal with China said Saturday that they would escalate their protests after President Ma Ying-jeou declined to meet with them.

title: A Conversation With Danah Boyd, Author of Its Complicated, About Teenagers Online
description: Danah Boyd is a principal researcher at Microsoft Research, a research assistant professor in Media, Culture and Communication at New York University, and a fellow at Harvards Berkman Center.

title: Chinese Satellite Spots Object in Search Area for Missing Jetliner
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  A Chinese satellite has spotted an object in the southern Indian Ocean in an area that is the focus of a multinational effort to find the Malaysia Airlines airliner that disappeared on March 8, the Chinese authorities said Saturday.

title: In Beijing Talk, Michelle Obama Extols Free Speech
description: BEIJING  On a visit that was supposed to be nonpolitical, Michelle Obama delivered an unmistakable message to the Chinese on Saturday, saying in an address here that freedom of speech, particularly on the Internet and in the news media, provided the foundation for a vibrant society.

title: Working for the Owners
description: Ive just finished a draft of a long review of Thomas Pikettys Capital in the 21st Century, which argues that were on the road back to patrimonial capitalism, dominated by inherited wealth. Its an amazing book; among other things, it does an awesome job of integrating economic growth, the factor distribution of income (between capital and labor), and the individual distribution of income into a common framework. (Its all about r-g). One slight weakness of the book, however, is that Pikettys grand framework doesnt do too good a job of explaining the explosion of income inequality in the United States, which so far has been driven mainly by wage income rather than capital. Piketty does take this on; but its kind of a side journey from the central story.

title: Sit Back and Soak Awhile in Natural Springs
description: Instead of pushing traditional spa services, several hotels around the world are focusing on expanding natural hot springs on-site as a way for guests to unwind. A recent renovation at Calistoga Spa Hot Springs in Napa Valley, Calif., for example, added four mineral pools with temperatures ranging from 80 to 106 degrees.

title: For Antigay Church, Losing Its Cause Before Its Founder
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  On the final night of Fred Phelpss life, as he lay dying in hospice care here, two of his daughters and several of his grandchildren lined a sidewalk in front of an upscale grocery store in Kansas City, Mo., 60 miles to the east, and sang.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, March 23
description: Other car companies should not repeat Toyotas mistake.

title: Life Expectancy and Income
description: Life Expectancy and Income

title: In His Office, a Wide World of Experience
description: Computing and thinking

title: W-2s, 1040s and Long Hours
description: Charlotte Ogorek, 66, is a tax preparer in Park Ridge, Ill.

title: She Didnt Mean to Be Bossy
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Just Dont Call Them Hearing Aids
description: People who strain to hear conversations in noisy places sometimes shun hearing appliances as telltale signs of aging. But what if those devices looked like wireless phone receivers? Some companies are betting that the high-tech look of a new generation of sound amplifiers will tempt people to try them.

title: When the Scientist Is Also a Philosopher
description: Do you want to know a dirty little secret of economists who give policy advice? When we do so, we are often speaking not just as economic scientists, but also as political philosophers. Our recommendations are based not only on our understanding of how the world works, but also on our judgments about what makes a good society.

title: Tremors in the Palace of the Bond-Fund King
description: Pimco, the giant asset manager, has been attracting attention for all the wrong reasons.

title: Don Knauss of Clorox, on Putting Your Followers First
description: This interview with   Don Knauss, chief executive of the Clorox Company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: The Stone Unturned: Credit Ratings
description: Its the one question about the 2008 financial crisis that people still ask me more than any other: Why have regulators done so little to rein in the credit rating agencies? Other institutions that contributed to the mortgage debacle have submitted to new rules and compliance requirements, but Moodys Investors Service and Standard & Poors and their peers remained relatively untouched.

title: Not the Best Way to Sell a Smartphone
description: As HTC readied a new version of its flagship smartphone, it planned for many challenges. It didnt know that one of them would be Roshan Jamkatel, a teenager from Schaumburg, Ill.

title: Israeli Raid Leaves 3 Dead in West Bank Refugee Area
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces killed three Palestinians and wounded at least seven others early Saturday when their attempt to arrest a person suspected of being a militant in the restive Jenin refugee camp erupted into a violent clash.

title: Variety: A Worldly Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I like to think of myself as a citizen of the world, not just the United States, so I really liked this quote. If you live in a big city or any other place that has a heterogeneous population, you know what I mean. I grew up in the Melting Pot of all Melting Pots, New York City, and it never occurred to me that people lived in an area that didnt have residents from all walks of life.

title: If Fairways Were Roadways, Gridlock Alert Would Be On
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  With his starched shirt and his nose for bottlenecks, Mark Russell could pass for a traffic engineer. Instead of watching a bank of monitors in a windowless room, Russell, a PGA Tour rules official, is gazing at the green expanse of Bay Hill Golf Club.

title: Russian Forces Take Over One of the Last Ukrainian Bases in Crimea
description: BELBEK, Crimea  Russian forces pushed Saturday to complete their expulsion of the Ukrainian military from the disputed Crimean Peninsula, smashing through the gates of a base here with armored vehicles, firing weapons into the air and demanding that the cornered Ukrainian soldiers surrender.

title: Jacksons Arrival Overshadows Nets Selflessness
description: Behold Jason Kidd, the rookie Nets coach whose stoic game face remains unchanged but has somehow evolved from the look of being lost to one of being learned.

title: For Phoenix, Record Guarantees Nothing
description: Nothing shows the disparity between the N.B.A.s Western and Eastern conferences more than the quality of the teams fighting for the last few playoff spots. As three sub-.500 teams vie for two spots in the East, it is all but certain that one team with an impeccable record in the West will not make the postseason.

title: Au Revoir, Entrepreneurs
description: Guillaume Santacruz, an aspiring French entrepreneur, brushed the rain from his black sweater and skinny jeans and headed down to a cavernous basement inside Campus London, a seven-story hive run by Google in the citys East End.

title: From Hawaii to End of Pitt Bench to 56 Seconds in Spotlight
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Pittsburgh led Colorado by 30 points in the final minute Thursday in their N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament opener. The fans waiting to see No. 1-seeded Florida seemed to have fallen asleep when Pitt Coach Jamie Dixon called a timeout with 56 seconds left and sent in Joshua Ko, a slender walk-on freshman guard. The crowd cheered, and the Panthers bench perked up.

title: Really? Youre Not in a Book Club?
description: WHATS your book group reading? I say to a friend encountered on the street. Not: Are you in a book group? I have no idea whether Clara is in a book group. Weve never talked about it. All the same, I just know. Why? Because its a safe assumption to make these days.

title: Slides Describe Mission Involving Huawei
description: Powerpoint slides from 2010 lay out the National Security Agencys goals in an effort to break into networks of Huawei, the telecommunications giant.

title: N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat
description: WASHINGTON  American officials have long considered Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, a security threat, blocking it from business deals in the United States for fear that the company would create back doors in its equipment that could allow the Chinese military or Beijing-backed hackers to steal corporate and government secrets.

title: Toy Guns for Girls
description: Toy manufacturers are selling new lines of toy guns and toy archery sets specifically aimed at girls. Does this make play time more equal?

title: Face of the Twins Surrenders His Mask
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  The end of a decorated catching career came without warning, on a Monday afternoon last August, in a makeup game against the Mets at Target Field. Joe Mauer took one foul ball off his mask, and then another the next inning, nothing unusual for his position. He played the rest of the game and flew with his Minnesota Twins teammates to Detroit.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 82
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jets Disappearance Puzzles a World Under Constant Electronic Watch
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  A satellite image of an indistinct, pale object floating in the ocean far off the west coast of Australia, published on Saturday by the Chinese authorities, is the latest of a succession of elusive clues in what has already become one of aviations greatest mysteries.

title: Born in the U.S., Playing for Iran
description: TORRANCE, Calif.  Steven Beitashour was 11 during the 1998 World Cup in France, where the United States, the country of his birth, faced Iran, where his parents were born.

title: Spreadsheets and Global Mayhem
description: UNITED NATIONS

title: Diversity in Kids Books
description: Readers reflect on how we see ourselves and learn about others through what we read.

title: Pay for Play and Title IX
description: What if college athletes were paid? A few years ago, it seemed impossible that the National Collegiate Athletic Associations longstanding amateur system could collapse, but recent high-profile legal actions have taken the possibility of professionalization out of fantasy territory.

title: The Sequester and the Homeless
description: The across-the-board cuts to federal programs that took effect last spring receded from the headlines after Republicans were shamed into allowing the government to pay its bills. But the cuts, known as the sequester, continue to take a toll on crucial housing programs that are intended to shield the elderly, the disabled and impoverished families with children from homelessness.

title: Russia Without Illusions
description: SINCE the end of the Cold War, Americas policy toward Russia has been shaped by two dangerous illusions.

title: Trend-Spotting, With Wink at Mr. Peanut
description: IF only I were gifted at satire, or even its goofy little brother, parody. Those skills would sometimes make commenting on The Timess journalism so much more fun.

title: What Id Say to My Fat Son
description: I WAS 7 when I first sprouted a belly. What can I say? I liked food and ate whatever I wanted because it tasted good. I was helped along by an elderly neighbor up the street who thought my little pouch was the most adorable thing she had ever seen. When her grandson stayed with her Id be invited over to play. Every now and then shed marvel at my midsection, sometimes giving it a pat, and shed feed me treats.

title: This Is What 80 Looks Like
description: ON Tuesday, Gloria Steinem turns 80.

title: You Sanction Me? No, I Sanction You!
description: The week brought more snow to the Mid-Atlantic region, along with a blast of the Cold War, replete with an exchange of sanctions by Washington and the Kremlin, followed by displays of bravado by the sanctioned. Big honor for me, declared Vladislav Surkov, a top Kremlin strategist. Badge of honor, came the echo from Senator Mary L. Landrieu, head of the Senate energy committee.

title: Ghosts of the Displaced
description: MY grandmother lived in three countries without ever moving. The Bengali village where she was born, married, had five children and became a widow saw its political boundaries change from British India to Pakistan to Bangladesh between 1947 and 1971. My grandmother was a storyteller, and when I was growing up in that village, her imagination recreated for me altered allegiances and divided houses.

title: A Common Core for All of Us
description: I COULDNT get a cab. A sketchy-looking guy hunkering around the entrance of the Grand Hyatt in San Diego showed me his bicycle. Climb on, lady, he said. Ill take ya.

title: The Pilots in the Basement
description: MUCH has been made of the flight simulator found in the home of Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah, the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet. Why would a guy who spends so much time flying real airplanes want to pretend hes flying a fake one in his off hours?

title: Palmy Days for Jerry
description: SACRAMENTO  I ASK Jerry if hes ready for Hillary.

title: All Economics Is Local
description: In the face of congressional inaction, the debate on raising the minimum wage is moving to the local level. As more cities and counties consider setting their own wage standards, they can learn from the policy experiments already underway.

title: The Geography of Fame
description: WHERE do the most successful Americans come from? I was curious. So I downloaded Wikipedia. (You can do that sort of thing nowadays.)

title: Notable Boomers and Where They Came From
description: There are 36,625 Americans born between 1946 and 1964 who warrant their own entry in Wikipedia.

title: Pope Names Members of Anti-Abuse Group
description: Pope Francis on Saturday made his first appointments to a special commission intended to signal the Vaticans new resolve in tackling the clerical sexual abuse problem, a group that includes an equal number of women and men, more laypeople than clergy and an outspoken Irish activist who was abused by a priest as a child.

title: Lessons From the Little Ice Age
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  CLIMATOLOGISTS call it the Little Ice Age; historians, the General Crisis.

title: Top Team Finds That Four Hands Are Better Than Two (on Forehands, Too)
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  In doubles tennis, which treasures technique and tradition, Peng Shuai of China and Hsieh Su-wei of Taiwan became the first doubly double-handed pair to win a Grand Slam tournament when they captured the womens title at Wimbledon last July.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 23
description: Russias military occupation of Crimea left Ukraine little choice but to withdraw from the disputed peninsula, officials said Wednesday. President Obama responded to the annexation of Crimea with heavier economic sanctions, including against some of President Vladimir V. Putins closest supporters, but some in the White House remain concerned that Russias aggression will not stop in Crimea.

title: Ovechkins Value, the Plus and the Minus
description: It is hard to picture an N.H.L. player being the best over an entire season in one category while also being the worst in another. But we may be witnessing that in Alex Ovechkin.

title: For Gay Couples in Michigan, a Day of Joy Ends in Legal Uncertainty
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  A day after a federal judge struck down Michigans voter-approved ban on same-sex marriages, hundreds of gay couples raced to clerks offices across the state on Saturday morning to exchange wedding vows before an appeals court challenge that could reinstate the ban.

title: Wave of Appeals Expected to Turn the Tide on Same-Sex Marriage Bans
description: With a slew of cases barreling toward federal appeals courts, almost certainly including the decision Friday that overturned Michigans restrictive marriage amendment, the legal battle over same-sex marriage is entering a new and climactic phase. Decisions in the coming months will resonate beyond individual states across entire regions and may impel the Supreme Court to revisit the issue sooner than it wished.

title: The Lost Art of the Unsent Angry Letter
description: WHENEVER Abraham Lincoln felt the urge to tell someone off, he would compose what he called a hot letter. Hed pile all of his anger into a note, put it aside until his emotions cooled down, Doris Kearns Goodwin once explained on NPR, and then write: Never sent. Never signed. Which meant that Gen. George G. Meade, for one, would never hear from his commander in chief that Lincoln blamed him for letting Robert E. Lee escape after Gettysburg.

title: He Was Supposed to Take a Photo
description: ONE of Raven Kalianas first, hazy memories is of her parents taking her to a professional photo studio, telling her to be good, and then leaving her with a child pornographer. In front of a camera, a man raped her.

title: Crying Wolf on Religious Liberty
description: This week, the owners of two secular, for-profit corporations will ask the Supreme Court to take a radical turn and allow them to impose their religious views on their employees  by refusing to permit them contraceptive coverage as required under the Affordable Care Act.

title: Confronting the Netherworld of Child Pornography
description: My Sunday column looks at one facet of child trafficking, the child pornography industry. This was largely eliminated by the early 1990s and then exploded with the Internet, but its mostly hidden in peer-to-peer networks and the dark web so that few people are aware just how odious it is.

title: Russian Troops Storm Ukrainian Base
description: Russian troops broke an overhead camera as they forced their way into a Ukrainian base in Crimea.

title: Gambling on Postponing Rockettes Show Rather Than Risking Poor Reviews
description: With one problem out of the way, James L. Dolan quickly turned to another. On Thursday night, just two days after introducing Phil Jackson as the new president of his beleaguered New York Knicks, Mr. Dolan, executive chairman of the Madison Square Garden Company, found himself assessing the performance of another troubled property: the musical extravaganza Heart and Lights.

title: Wilbekin Drives, and Florida Cruises Past Pittsburgh
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Scottie Wilbekin limped slightly as he headed toward the Florida bench. He sat down and was given an ice bag for his bruised left knee, a symbol of sorts for his gritty play and timely leadership that lifted the Gators to a 61-45 victory Saturday over Pittsburgh.

title: Lee Armstrong
description: Lee Armstrong is a British computer programmer who co-founded Planefinder, a website and mobile app that allows its five million users to track air traffic worldwide in real time. User activity has surged 300 percent since the Malaysia Airlines jet vanished on March 8. Planefinder gets much of its data from a global network of volunteers who have placed specialized aviation-tracking receivers on their rooftops.

title: The Whole Year, Nothing Went Our Way
description: SAN DIEGO  The business of redemption, like the art of image reconstruction, is rarely neat or uncomplicated.

title: Favoring Wealth Over Work
description: In my last post I tried to document the extent to which modern Republican rhetoric has already adopted the values of patrimonial capitalism, even though Americas top one percent still owes its high incomes largely to compensation rather than wealth. On reflection, I thought I should also document the extent to which the GOP has put its money  or, actually, taxpayers money  where its mouth is, with concrete policies that favor wealth over work.

title: Times Report on Al Qaeda Is Censored in Pakistan
description: An article about Pakistans relationship to Al Qaeda, and its knowledge of Osama bin Ladens last hiding place within its borders, was censored from the front page of about 9,000 copies of the International New York Times in Pakistan on Saturday, apparently removed by a local paper that has a partnership to distribute The Times.

title: At Wichita State, Son Quietly Savors the Sideline
description: ST. LOUIS  Kellen Marshall was a 6-foot-3 junior on his high school basketball team in Wichita, Kan., a forward for a squad that won its league the previous season. At 17, he had been steadily climbing the basketball ladder for years, dribbling and shooting in dusty little gyms since before he could read.

title: Garden Buys Stake in Indie Film Bastion
description: LOS ANGELES  Tribeca Enterprises, the Manhattan-based independent film concern co-founded by Robert De Niro, has agreed to sell a 50 percent stake to the Madison Square Garden Company in a deal that values Tribeca at $45 million.

title: N.C.A.A. Round of 32: The Day in Pictures
description: Florida opened the first day of the round of 32 with a convincing win over Pittsburgh.

title: Defending Champs Have a Pulse, but Its Not Strong
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Louisville Coach Rick Pitino has lived through enough of these games to understand there are no style points in the N.C.A.A. tournament. So as the Cardinals gathered in their locker room at Amway Center, Pitino looked to the television for part of his pregame motivation.

title: Vanquished, but Still Eyeing Winners Circle
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: What an Electric Current Does Not Flow Through
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Todays puzzle by Ian Livengood contains one of my favorite quotations, yet I am going to predict that we will have at least a few people who take issue with the fact that THOMAS EDISON is presented as the sole inventor of the INCANDESCENT LIGHT BULB. He patented it, of course, but there are many people who feel that, had EDISON not been a particularly good businessman, Nikola Tesla would have had a much more important place in the light bulb invention section of the history books.

title: A Prison Alliance: Dog Trainers and Veterans
description: GATESVILLE  Lark Goode, wearing a stark white prison jumpsuit, set a prosthetic leg down on the glazed concrete floor and calmly walked to the other side of the gymnasium. At her signal, Rocky, a black lab mix with a naturally bobbed tail, retrieved the leg and brought it to Ms. Goode.

title: For Ukraine Military in Crimea, Glum Capitulation and an Uncertain Future
description: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea  The Ukrainian marines emerged Friday from their barracks juggling awkward armfuls of personal effects: wet-weather overcoats, suitcases, potted plants, even a model ship.

title: After Gains and Discord, U.T. Chancellor Moves On
description: Barbara Cigarroa was not surprised when her eldest son, Francisco, announced in February that he would step down as chancellor of the University of Texas System after five years on the job.

title: Paul Has Ideas, but His Backers Want 2016 Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a ballroom at the Olympic Club, a grand, early-20th-century building at the foot of Nob Hill, Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, pitched a gathering of venture capitalists last week in an effort to show them that he may be the next big thing.

title: The Push to Label Genetically Modified Products
description: When Eric Herm heard in 2005 that genetically modified cottonseeds were the latest innovation on the market, he thought he should plant the crop on his family farm near Lubbock, Tex.

title: Todays Girls Love Pink Bows as Playthings, but These Shoot
description: Once upon a time, Grace Maher twirled around the house in Disney princess costumes, a vision of sequins, tiaras and pink.

title: Computer Play Emboldens World Title Contenders
description: Computer programs have changed the pace of this years tournament that will select the next title challenger for the world champion, Magnus Carlsen.

title: A Routine Flight, Till Both Routine and Flight Vanish
description: The night sky was clear above the clouds, and the last glimmer of a setting half-moon had faded when Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, cruising at 35,000 feet over the Gulf of Thailand, approached the border between Malaysian and Vietnamese airspace on its usual route to Beijing. What happened next should have been routine for a twice-daily milk run between two of Asias most important cities. Air traffic controllers outside Kuala Lumpur usually hand the jet off to their counterparts in Ho Chi Minh City as the flight turns northeast toward the Chinese capital.

title: An Embattled Trainer Fires His Assistant
description: Steve Asmussen fired his longtime assistant Scott Blasi on Saturday as horse racing authorities and federal agencies investigated allegations that the two had mistreated thoroughbred racehorses in their care.

title: Gene Feist, Founder of Roundabout Theater Company, Dies at 91
description: Gene Feist, who brought regular productions of classic theater to New York when he founded what is now the Roundabout Theater Company, a multistage Goliath that is one of the nations most important nonprofit companies, died on Monday in Englewood, N.J. He was 91.

title: With Experiment, Mets Hope to Have Potent Offense Down to a Science
description: JUPITER, Fla.  The Mets signed outfielders Curtis Granderson and Chris Young in the off-season partly to address their lack of power. But a year after the Mets hit .237 as a team, Manager Terry Collins is still looking for ways to lift the offense.

title: For Columbia, a Milestone Seems to Be Worth the Fee
description: A video featured last week on the home page for the CollegeInsider.com tournament showed the jump shot by Columbia guard Maodo Lo that carried the Lions to a 58-56 victory over Valparaiso in a first-round game on Tuesday.

title: Montana Ex-Guardsman Now Must Fight to Keep Senate Seat Given to Him
description: PABLO, Mont.  After three decades in the Montana National Guard, including a combat tour in Iraq, John Walsh, the states newly appointed Democratic senator, still has a brush cut and military bearing and occasionally slips into soldier-speak, referring to the civilian world when discussing life inside and outside the political arena.

title: Pro-Russian and Pro-Kiev Camps Dig In Amid Uneasy Calm in Eastern Ukraine
description: KHARKIV, Ukraine  The funeral procession for Artyom Zhudov, 19, was led by a Zhiguli subcompact car bearing the orange-and-black standard of St. George, the distinctive and now ubiquitous symbol of support for Russia here in Kharkiv, the second-largest city in Ukraine.

title: Point Guard Turns His Life Around, With an Assist From His Coach
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Just before the halftime buzzer, Florida point guard Scottie Wilbekin shot a running 3-pointer, leaping high above two Pittsburgh defenders. The ball floated, and then slipped through the net just as the light on the backboard turned red. The thousands of Gators fans in the stands during the N.C.A.A. tournaments Round of 32 on Saturday went into a frenzy.

title: Multivehicle Accident in Pakistan Kills More Than 30
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 33 people were killed on Saturday in a crash involving two tanker trucks and two passenger buses on a coastal highway in southern Pakistan, officials said. At least 20 others were injured, many with severe burns.

title: The Catholic Roots of Obamas Activism
description: CHICAGO  In a meeting room under Holy Name Cathedral, a rapt group of black Roman Catholics listened as Barack Obama, a 25-year-old community organizer, trained them to lobby their fellow delegates to a national congress in Washington on issues like empowering lay leaders and attracting more believers.

title: After Slow Start, the Aztecs Pull Away
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Xavier Thames was the best player in the Mountain West Conference, a silky guard who led his team in scoring and made the leagues all-defense team.

title: Iraqi Journalist Shot Dead by Officer
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi journalist was shot dead on Saturday by a Kurdish officer in the presidential guard brigade in Baghdad, security officials said.

title: Names of Health Plans Sow Customer Confusion
description: WASHINGTON  As Americans race to sign up for health insurance in the final days of open enrollment, many consumers and consumer advocates say the names of plans are unhelpful, confusing and in some cases misleading.

title: Michigans 3-Point Shooters Strike Early and Often Against Texas
description: MILWAUKEE  Coming from the Big 12 Conference, Texas had twice played Iowa State this season and was familiar, then, with having to defend four or even five 3-point threats at once.

title: Scotts Lead Becomes Slightly Less Comfortable
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Adam Scott enjoys playing from ahead. Keegan Bradley prefers being the pursuer. Both will be in their comfort zones Sunday when Scott carries a three-stroke lead over Bradley into the final round of the Arnold Palmer Invitational at Bay Hill Golf Club.

title: Rhode Island House Speaker Resigns Amid Investigation
description: Gordon D. Fox, speaker of the Rhode Island House of Representatives, resigned his leadership post on Saturday and said that he would not seek re-election in the fall, a decision that came a day after federal and state law enforcement authorities raided his office and home.

title: $5 Million for Vick? If Smith Thrives, Its a Steal
description: At one time the Jets were criticized for profligate spending, for overvaluing some of their players and awarding generous contracts to those whose production did not quite seem to merit the reward. On Friday they invested $5 million in a player they hope never takes a snap for them.

title: Palestinians Criticize Abbas for Public Fatah Feud at Delicate Time Diplomatically
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  When Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, returned to his headquarters here late last week after a quick trip for talks in Washington, the welcome-home reception featuring waving flags, a marching band and posters with his portrait seemed like a forced attempt to boost the spirits of an embattled leader.

title: Girardi Makes His 1st Successful Replay Challenge
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi successfully appealed an umpires call through television replay for the first time Saturday.

title: Mercer Coach Says Rankings Are Flawed
description: Upsets have been somewhat commonplace in this N.C.A.A. tournament: Of the 32 games Thursday and Friday, eight were won by a lower seed. Maybe the seedings were wrong in the first place.

title: Complexity of Conflict Leaves Donors Wary of Aiding Syrians
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  When an earthquake killed 150,000 people in Haiti in 2010, private individuals donated $20 million to the international aid group Mercy Corps to help victims, most of it within weeks of the disaster. During three years of turmoil in Syria that have produced a similar death toll, the organization has collected just $2 million for Syrians.

title: Rally Falls Short and Syracuse Is Eliminated
description: BUFFALO  The night before the first game of the season, Dayton Coach Archie Miller gave his team an order: It would forgo the standard routine during starting-lineup introductions. The team would instead huddle in a circle near the foul line, lock arms and sway.

title: Reconstructing a Routine Flight
description: Tracing the Malaysia Airlines route, from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, that Flight 370 never completed.

title: Vera Chytilova Dies at 85; Made Daring Films in Czech New Wave
description: Vera Chytilova, a filmmaker often called the first lady of Czech cinema, whose work  subversive, experimental and strongly feminist  was long banned in her homeland, died on March 12 in Prague. She was 85.

title: U.S. Emerges as Central Stage in Asian Rivalry
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The political and historical war of words between Japan and South Korea has found another battleground: the United States.

title: No Bail for Former I.R.A. Member Charged in 72 Killing
description: DUBLIN  A man accused of being a former Irish Republican Army commander was denied bail on Saturday after being charged in connection with one of the most notorious crimes of the conflict in Northern Ireland: the murder of a mother of 10 in 1972.

title: Countries Divided on Future of Ancient Buddhas
description: BAMIAN, Afghanistan  They were the picture-postcard view of a rural and mostly untouched Afghanistan: ancient, towering Buddhas that became a symbol of the Talibans religious fanaticism and intolerance.

title: Bird Strike Shatters Malaysia Jets Windshields
description: NEW DELHI  A Malaysia Airlines plane ran into a flock of ducks late Friday night just as it landed at Tribhuvan International Airport in Nepal, shattering its two right windshields, officials said.

title: Wisconsin Tops Oregon With Surge in 2nd Half
description: MILWAUKEE  The booing started as soon as Oregon took the court for warm-ups before its N.C.A.A. Tournament game with Wisconsin. Not that the players expected anything else. Bradley Center is about an hours drive from Madison, and anyone not wearing Badger scarlet and white on Saturday stood out like an extra from a 1930s gangster film.

title: Lundqvist Breaks Another Record in a Key Win
description: NEWARK  Two great goalies based on each side of the Hudson River, Martin Brodeur and Henrik Lundqvist, met for probably the last time Saturday night, and once again Lundqvist skated away the winner.

title: Spartans Survive Crimsons Comeback
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  Michigan State was coasting eastward, toward the N.C.A.A. tournaments East Regional at Madison Square Garden, when Harvard ambushed the bandwagon.

title: The Geopolitics of Name-Dropping
description: Moldova to Micronesia. Bombay to Burma. East Timor to South Sudan. For well-traveled sophisticates, the world is an ever-shifting big geography lesson.

title: Patricia Byrne, Lee Jablow
description: Patricia Grace Byrne, the daughter of Mimi Byrne and Michael J. Byrne of Media, Pa., was married Saturday afternoon to Dr. Lee Michael Jablow, the son of David A. Jablow of Somerset, N.J., and the late Anne Sehring Jablow. James F. McKay III, the chief judge of the Louisiana Fourth Circuit Court of Appeal, officiated at the Peristyle, an open-air pavilion at City Park in New Orleans.

title: Mara Cvejic, Nitesh Paryani
description: Dr. Mara Cvejic and Dr. Nitesh Nandlal Paryani were married Saturday at the Players Championship at Sawgrass Clubhouse in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. Pandit Kadambi Srinathji performed the Hindu wedding ceremony.

title: Christina Stavridis and James Wong III
description: Christina Anne Stavridis, a daughter of Laura Hall Stavridis and Adm. James G. Stavridis of Bedford, Mass., is to be married Sunday to James Wong III, the son of Dr. Lucy A. Wong and Mr. Wong Jr. of Warren, N.J. The Rev. Milan R. Kralik, a minister of the United Church of Christ, will perform the ceremony at the Coral Gables Congregational Church in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Jana Lewis, Joshua Deitch
description: Dr. Jana Lori Lewis and Joshua Reuven Deitch were married Saturday evening at Cold Spring Country Club in Huntington, N.Y. Rabbi Jaimee Shalhevet officiated.

title: Beth FitzPatrick, Brian Mulherin
description: Beth Alexandra FitzPatrick and Brian George Mulherin were married Saturday at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington. Msgr. W. Ronald Jameson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Meredith Montgomery, Joseph Khawam
description: Meredith Day Montgomery and Joseph Norman Khawam were married Saturday at the Oaks Waterfront Inn in Royal Oak, Md. Mary A. Tankersley, who was ordained by St. Lukes Evangelical Church Ministries in Dearing, Ga., officiated.

title: Yael Kushner and Eliot Heher
description: Dr. Yael Batia Kushner and Dr. Eliot Charles Heher were married Saturday evening at the State Room, an event space in Boston. Adrian Robbins-Cole, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with Rabbi David B. Kudan taking part.

title: Carol Romney, Fernando Leiva Bertrn
description: Carol Jane Romney, a daughter of Susan C. Romney and Larry R. Romney of Chino Valley, Ariz., was married Saturday evening to Fernando Jos Leiva Bertrn, a son of Ricardo A. Leiva of Mendoza, Argentina, and the late Maria Silvia Bertrn. The brides father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Nathaniel Hill II and Cliff Wynne III
description: Nathaniel Lamar Hill II and Dr. Ernest Clifford Wynne III are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Dr. Jorge Delgado, a Community Church minister, at the Park Hyatt in Washington.

title: Christie Cunningham and Jonathan McNeill
description: Christie Lauren Cunningham and Jonathan David McNeill were married Friday at their home in Philadelphia in a ceremony held under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute.

title: Catherine Sear and Scott Cantor
description: Catherine Kilbourn Sear and Scott Michael Cantor were married Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York. Denise L. Cote, a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated.

title: Amy Bennett, Richard DeFrank Jr.
description: Amy Robin Bennett and Richard Alan DeFrank Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Elizabeth M. Phaire, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

title: Mary Chapman, Jason Benoit
description: Mary Jordan Chapman and Jason Matthew Benoit were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Brant S. Copeland at First Presbyterian Church in Tallahassee, Fla.

title: Megan Chan and Jarrod Stuard
description: Megan Hojing Chan and Capt. Jarrod Hunter Stuard were married Saturday evening at St. Pauls Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. Jeffrey White, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Erin Barbach, Scott Silver
description: Erin Nicole Barbach and Scott Kyle Silver are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Joy Han, Daniel Jones
description: Joy Nova Han, a daughter of Hyuk Koon Han and a stepdaughter Dr. Simon Peter Cho of New York, was married Saturday to Daniel Allison Jones, a son of Margaret M. Kotlewski of Newton, N.C., and Allison Van Lopik Jones of Sarasota, Fla. Mark Giller, an associate pastor of the Sanctuary of the Beloved, officiated in New York at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: A Mystery Writers Ulterior Motive
description: Samantha Anne Spindel and Justin Ryan Musaffi were married Saturday evening at the DoubleTree by Hilton hotel in Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Noah Fabricant officiated.

title: Intervening Before Their Friends Could
description: Rachel Liane Slaff, the daughter of Howard B. Slaff and Rene W. Slaff of Wilmington, Del., is to be married Sunday to Dr. David Jay Berman, the son of Debbie H. Berman and Dr. Mark S. Berman of Oradell, N.J. Rabbi Bradley Hercman will officiate at the Helen and Martin Kimmel Center for University Life at New York University.

title: Napier Takes Center Stage as UConn Upsets Villanova
description: BUFFALO  Connecticut led second-seeded Villanova by 5 with less than four minutes remaining Saturday, but Shabazz Napier  the Huskies best player and the teams indisputable heart and soul  sat crumpled in a heap on the bench, his face buried in a towel.

title: Biden Notes Progress in Gay Rights, but Says There Is Much Left to Do
description: LOS ANGELES  As hundreds of gay couples in Michigan flocked to clerks offices on Saturday  only to have a federal appeals court again halt same-sex marriages in the state hours later  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. made a forceful case for gay rights, both in the United States and worldwide.

description: NEW YORK

title: More Possible Sightings in Hunt for Missing Plane
description: PEARCE AIR FORCE BASE, Australia  The search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet entered its third week on Sunday, as data from a French satellite buttressed the theory that the plane might have fallen into the southern Indian Ocean, far off the west coast of Australia. But the day ended without any possible wreckage being found.

title: At Airports, a Misplaced Faith in Body Language
description: Like the rest of us, airport security screeners like to think they can read body language. The Transportation Security Administration has spent some $1 billion training thousands of behavior detection officers to look for facial expressions and other nonverbal clues that would identify terrorists.

title: Tarnished Silver
description: Timothy Egan joins the chorus of those dismayed by Nate Silvers new FiveThirtyEight. Im sorry, but I have to agree: so far it looks like something between a disappointment and a disaster.

title: Name-Calling in the Virtual Playground
description: Silicon Valley sometimes feels like high school. It has its alpha types and its outcasts, its bullies and its bullied.

title: The Crime of 2010
description: The most important paper at the Brookings Panel was probably Krueger et al on the long-term unemployed, which basically confirmed what were learning from a number of sources: its really hard to get employers to look at people who have been out of work for an extended period, so any sustained increase in long-term unemployment tends to become permanent.

title: Vows: A Mutual Connection
description: Live music superfans Amy Bennett and Richard DeFrank danced around each other at concerts for years before unfortunate circumstances brought them together as a couple.

title: Turkey Downs Warplane From Syria After Warning
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Turkish fighter jets shot down a Syrian warplane on Sunday after it violated Turkish airspace, Turkeys prime minister said, part of the longstanding hostilities between the two nations over the conflict in Syria.

title: Crews Work to Contain Oil Barges Leak
description: Emergency crews in Texas worked on Sunday to contain 168,000 gallons of oil that leaked into Galveston Bay on Saturday from a barge that collided with a ship, officials said.

title: Banks Urge Young Analysts to Do the Unthinkable: Take Weekends Off
description: The hard-charging investment banker rolled out of bed at 11 a.m. First on the to-do list? A leisurely cup of coffee and some Greek yogurt while checking out the sports highlights on ESPN. Next up: a two-hour run along Manhattans waterfront with a pit stop at Chopt for a double chicken salad to go.

title: Its Really Not That Tough to Backdate Unemployment Benefits
description: We criticized Speaker John Boehner on Thursday for refusing to bring an extension of unemployment benefits to a vote. Mr. Boehner cited as his excuse a letter from state unemployment agencies that said backdating the benefits to December (when they expired) would be difficult and costly to administer. The letter was signed by Mark Henry, director of the Mississippi Department of Employment Security, who is chairman of the national group of unemployment agencies.

title: Adolfo Surez Dies at 81; Led Spain Back to Democracy
description: MADRID  Adolfo Surez, Spains first elected prime minister after the Franco dictatorship and a key figure in the countrys transition back to democracy, died here on Sunday. He was 81.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICAN DREAM BUILDERS This competition-style reality show hosted by the interior designer Nate Berkus pits a dozen designers and home builders against one another to see who can pull off the best renovation each week. In the series premiere, the contestants are divided into teams to complete projects in two Tudor-style homes. Judging their work will be Mr. Berkus; Eddie George, the professional football player turned landscape architect; and the interior designer Monica Pedersen (second from left above, with Mr. Berkus at center and Mr. George, second from right). Each week the losing team will vote off a member, with the remaining two contestants facing off in a final home makeover.

title: Can You Spot the Liar?
description: Subjects in a study on body language and lying were asked several general questions  and then told off camera to lie or tell the truth when answering. Can you tell truth from falsehood?

title: Stanford Stymies Kansas and Its Star Freshman
description: ST. LOUIS  Stanfords plan to stop Andrew Wiggins, the star Kansas freshman, was straightforward: It was the responsibility of every Cardinal player on the court.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 22, 2014
description: March 22, 2014

title: U.S. Intelligence Officials Believe Snowden Is Working With Russia, Lawmaker Says
description: WASHINGTON  A top congressional intelligence official said on Sunday that American counterintelligence officials are virtually unanimous in believing that Edward J. Snowden is under the influence of Russian intelligence services.

title: Danger Lingers After Landslide Kills 8 in Washington State
description: ARLINGTON, Wash.  A huge landslide that roared down from a rain-saturated mountain slope near here, leaving eight people dead and at least 18 others missing, remained a site of both devastation and continued extreme danger on Sunday, state and local officials said.

title: A Rocker Never Sure of His Step
description: In October 1966, a Memphis pop group known as the Devilles lost its lead singer and had to find a new one in a hurry. An acquaintance of the band recommended a singer who had impressed him at a talent show. This singer was eager to audition, but he asked for a ride, because he was only 15 and didnt have a drivers license. No matter: By the time he was 16, the Devilles had become the Box Tops and the kid, Alex Chilton, had sung the lead vocal on The Letter, which went on to sell four million copies.

title: Putting Science What-Ifs to the Demonstration Test
description: The slick Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey, with Neil deGrasse Tyson surveying millions of years in dulcet tones, is one way to use television for science education. Or, you could just dress a guy in a chain-mail suit, hit him with a million volts of electricity and see how charbroiled he gets.

title: Whats On Monday
description: 11:15 A.M. (Cinemax) TRUE LIES (1994) Helen (Jamie Lee Curtis) thinks her husband, Harry (Arnold Schwarzenegger, above, with Ms. Curtis), is a mild-mannered computer salesman, but no one is what he or she seems in this romantic action comedy written and directed by James Cameron. When she learns that Harry is actually an international spy, Helen gets pulled into a globe-saving mission to stop terrorists with nuclear bombs. The most engaging part of the film is the long middle section, which toys with marital types, Caryn James wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Schwarzenegger, she added, is no Cary Grant, but along with Ms. Curtis, he makes True Lies the first successful romantic comedy in which trucks, as well as heartstrings, are blown to bits. (The movie is repeated at 10 p.m.) On Showtime 2, at 1:35 p.m., Mr. Schwarzenegger stars as John Kimble, an undercover officer in Ivan Reitmans Kindergarten Cop (1990). The search for a drug dealer leads Kimble and his partner (Pamela Reed) to an Oregon school where their suspects son is a student. Kimble ends up teaching the class of kindergartners, and though the film relies on obvious jokes, Ms. James wrote in The Times, Mr. Schwarzenegger is so appealing, relaxed and genial in this role that his fans are not likely to ask for more, and even his detractors are likely to be happily surprised. And theres one more chance for a dose of Mr. Schwarzenegger before the day ends: On The Tonight Show, at 11:34 p.m. on NBC, he will be a guest, along with the television host Carson Daly and the band Vampire Weekend.

title: James Rebhorn, an Actor Often Playing a Man in a Suit, Dies at 65
description: James Rebhorn, a character actor who appeared in dozens of popular movies and television shows and recently starred on the Showtime hit Homeland, died on Friday at his home in South Orange, N.J. He was 65.

title: Gentler Words About Charter Schools From de Blasio
description: It was perhaps fitting that Mayor Bill de Blasio found himself Sunday at Riverside Church, the neo-Gothic landmark in Morningside Heights: The church was long a cathedral of antiwar sentiment, and the mayor was looking to make peace.

title: Brass Band of Brothers, a Dads Gift
description: Probably the biggest influence on the group in Brothers Hypnotic comes from very close to home. In Reuben Atlass relaxed documentary about the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, the bands proudly independent musicians still grapple with the ideals of the Chicago trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran, father to seven of the groups eight members, their teacher in their formative years and an advocate of black consciousness for alternatives to the establishment.

title: Extending the Reach of a Long Run, Twists Included
description: In Private Domain  the autobiography, not the dance  the choreographer Paul Taylor divulges that most of his works begin as a swamp. The only firm ground seems to be a certain craft that Ive learned by trial and error, handy to fall back on  a roller to help squish the path dry, he writes. But craft is never the heart of the matter. No craft, however finely honed, can disguise a passionless base.

title: Lobbyists Set to Fight Royalty Bill for Artists
description: Lawyers for Sothebys auction house paid an unusual visit to a few lawmakers on Capitol Hill this month and brought along some high-powered lobbying muscle. They had come to complain about a new bill that even some supporters acknowledge faces a difficult road in this divided Congress: a proposal to give visual artists  or their estates  a cut of the profits when their work is resold at public auction.

title: Virtual Reality Is Here. Can We Play With It?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The notion of virtual reality has been tantalizing since at least the 1980s, when William Gibsons novel Neuromancer and the holodeck on Star Trek: The Next Generation popularized the idea of transporting people into a three-dimensional computerized environment. And until recently, its been science fiction.

title: Baby M and the Question of Surrogacy
description: The custody battle over Baby M was the first time a court considered surrogacy. Todays families are created in many different ways. But have we resolved the question of surrogacy?

title: Illness Sidelines Gregg Allman
description: Gregg Allman, the lead singer and keyboardist of the Allman Brothers Band, sat out the groups last two performances over the weekend because of bronchitis. Only four shows remain in the bands sold-out run at the Beacon Theater before it is scheduled to end on Saturday. Mr. Allman, 66, hopes to recover in time to participate in the remaining shows, although a message on the groups Facebook page said there were no guarantees. Mr. Allman has dealt with health issues in the past, including a liver transplant in 2010 and back problems that caused a Beacon performance to be cut short in 2012. The guitarists Warren Haynes and Derek Trucks both announced in January that they would leave the band at the end of the year.

title: Curses
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Its really too bad this puzzle didnt come with one of those wet wipes. Or had WET WIPES in the puzzle, as a kind of anti-reveal. That would have been neat. (See what I did there?)

title: Baby M and the Question of Surrogate Motherhood
description: You could say that the surrogate mother of all surrogate mothers was Hagar, servant to Sarai in the Old Testament. Sarai, later known as Sarah, had fertility woes. So she pleaded with her husband  Abram, before he became Abraham  to lie with Hagar and do what needed to be done. It may be that I may obtain children by her, she said, as rendered in the King James Version of Genesis 16:2. Her plan worked splendidly. Hagar conceived a son. Call him Ishmael.

title: Malaysias Mystery
description: The struggle to piece together the puzzle of the missing airliner.

title: Divergent Ticket Sales Justify a Franchise
description: LOS ANGELES  Summit Entertainments high-profile Divergent arrived to solid if not spectacular ticket sales at North American theaters.

title: Singing and Playing, With Emotions in Play
description: How many of us have found ourselves in the position that the West Coast singer-songwriter Matt Alber describes in his anguished folk-pop ballad, End of the World? Buckled into a roller coaster alongside a lover with whom he is breaking up, he worries they are climbing to their death. Just before it makes a steep drop, he cries out, I dont want to be dangled over the edge of a dying romance. Then he recognizes that his partner feels the same terror and asks, Can you tell me why youre holding on to me like its the end of the world?

title: I Didnt Build That
description: Update: According to Sutch, the term liquidity trap comes from a 1940 book by Dennis Robertson, and it was popularized by Alvin Hansen in the 1950s. What with secular stagnation and all that, Hansen seems to be having a comeback!

title: Ideas for the Criminal Justice System
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Uses Social Media to Manage Customers and Its Reputation
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If you glance at the Facebook page of General Motors, it seems like business as usual at the Detroit automaker, even though the company is struggling to cope with the recalls of 1.6 million cars that it has linked to 12 deaths.

title: For Wildcats, Win Over Shockers Is Perfectly Thrilling
description: ST. LOUIS  With about four minutes remaining in the game and a timeout called, Wichita State and Kentucky slowly began walking off the court like weary heavyweight fighters returning to their corners.

title: Odes to the Season of Rebirth Surround an Episode of Trauma
description: The members of the Martha Graham Dance Company are impressive individually and collectively, but they have two main and dissimilar ways of moving. In modern pieces by living choreographers, they look released, motivated, free. In Grahams own choreography, they look tense, stiff-backed, self-conscious, showy.

title: For Those Hoping to Lose, a Hard Look in the Mirror
description: Fat people arent very visible on American television, and when they appear, it tends to be in one of a few approved roles: comic props in blue-collar reality series, cautionary figures in exploitative medical shows, huffing and puffing contestants in weight-loss competitions.
