description: The second day of the Round of 32 included a stunner as Wichita State suffered its first defeat of the season at the hands of eighth-seeded Kentucky.

title: At the Lebhar Imp Pairs, a Declarer in Control
description: DALLAS  The second national championship decided at the Spring North American Championships here was the Lebhar Imp Pairs.

title: Confronting Putins Russia
description: The decision by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to annex Crimea ended the post-Cold War era in Europe. Since the late Gorbachev-Reagan years, the era was defined by zigzags of cooperation and disputes between Russia and the West, but always with an underlying sense that Russia was gradually joining the international order. No more.

title: Washington Officials Discuss Mudslide
description: Washington State officials discussed the mudslide that has killed at least three people.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 81
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Standoff Over Prisoner Release Threatens Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli-Palestinian peace talks revived by Washington last summer are scheduled to continue until April 29, but a showdown  and possible breakdown  is likely this week over the anticipated release of a fourth batch of Palestinian prisoners.

title: Queen Victoria, Another Maligned Mother
description: SYDNEY, Australia  IS anyone else bored with the seemingly endless tomes on modern motherhood?

title: A Pay Strike in Israel Stalls Premiers Trip to Mexico
description: JERUSALEM  Employees of Israels Foreign Ministry announced an open-ended general strike on Sunday over pay and working conditions, an unprecedented step involving a complete shutdown of the ministrys office here and the countrys 103 diplomatic missions abroad.

title: Childrens TV Aims to Profit From Award Shows
description: LOS ANGELES  Awards shows are sprouting like mushrooms across the television landscape as networks try to create event programming. Now even the childrens channels are introducing additional trophy telecasts.

title: Anger Grows in Taiwan Against Deal With China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Demonstrators who have occupied Taiwans legislature since last week expanded their protest of a trade deal with China on Sunday evening by invading the government building nearby that houses the offices of the prime minister.

title: Jeters Meager Average in Spring Training Does Not Worry Him or Girardi
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Games are nine innings in spring training just as they are in the regular season. Three strikes still make an out, and teams still charge dearly for tickets and parking. But for many veteran hitters, like Derek Jeter, much about spring training has nothing to do with the regular season.

title: Birchbox, Seller of Beauty Products, Steps Out From Web With a Store
description: A banner for the hair salon that once occupied these quarters still hangs outside an abandoned West Broadway storefront in the heart of SoHos main shopping area in Manhattan. Inside, the 4,500-square-foot duplex space is utterly empty, with no hint of what  if anything  will fill it next.

title: In Hollywood News Wars, TheWrap Rebounds
description: LOS ANGELES  Talk about going from fizzle to sizzle.

title: Rwanda Reaches for New Economic Model
description: KIGALI, Rwanda  On the 12th floor of the Kigali City Tower, a modern blue-glass office building on the side of one of this capitals famous hills, the latest endeavor in the effort to transform a tiny rural economy into a financial and high-tech hub is trying to find its footing.

title: His Future Bright, Daytons Coach Focuses on the Now
description: In the time it took to win his first two N.C.A.A. tournament games, Archie Miller went from relative obscurity to next in line as the prince of mens Division I basketball. On Thursday, Miller, 35, and his 11th-seeded Dayton Flyers disposed of No. 6 Ohio State, whose coach, Thad Matta, had been a mentor and friend to Miller.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of March 24
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Obama and Allies Seek Firm, United Response as Russia Grips Crimea
description: THE HAGUE  As Russia consolidated its hold on Crimea, raising its flag over seized military bases and detaining ousted Ukrainian commanders on Sunday, President Obama and his international allies prepared to meet here in an effort to develop a strong, united response despite their diverging interests in dealing with the Kremlin.

title: Wealth Over Work
description: It seems safe to say that Capital in the Twenty-First Century, the magnum opus of the French economist Thomas Piketty, will be the most important economics book of the year  and maybe of the decade. Mr. Piketty, arguably the worlds leading expert on income and wealth inequality, does more than document the growing concentration of income in the hands of a small economic elite. He also makes a powerful case that were on the way back to patrimonial capitalism, in which the commanding heights of the economy are dominated not just by wealth, but also by inherited wealth, in which birth matters more than effort and talent.

title: 3 Presidents and a Riddle Named Putin
description: WASHINGTON  Bill Clinton found him to be cold and worrisome, but predicted he would be a tough and able leader. George W. Bush wanted to make him a friend and partner in the war on terror, but grew disillusioned over time.

title: Americas Underappreciated Entrepreneur: The Federal Government
description: Imagine a world in which the United States government  not the private sector  is the economys indispensable entrepreneur, innovating at the frontiers of science and technology, able and willing to take risks and to persevere through uncertainty.

title: When Nature Looks Unnatural
description: Nothing makes scientists happier than an experimental result that completely contradicts a widely accepted theory. The scientists who first invented the theory might not be tickled, but their colleagues will be overjoyed. Science progresses when a good theory is superseded by an even better theory, and the most direct route to building a better theory is to be confronted by data that simply dont fit the old one.

title: City That Squandered Baseball Relishes Brief Return
description: For the Mets and the Toronto Blue Jays, they are just games at the end of the long spring training schedule, the final chance for the players to work out the kinks and the managers to trim their rosters.

title: Dispute on Sri Lanka War Crimes Escalates
description: NEW DELHI  About 100 government supporters marched to the American Embassy in Colombo, Sri Lanka, last week and smashed coconuts on the embassys doorstep in a Hindu ritual meant to curse an enemy. We will not let them take our president to the electric chair! the protesters shouted.

title: Risks Abound as Reporters Play in Traffic
description: It is a dirty secret of the journalism profession that many reporters are bad at math. Many of us ended up typing our way to a living because we had an easier time making words dance than numbers.

title: Iowa States Do-It-All Kane Leads a Rally Over North Carolina
description: SAN ANTONIO  Iowa State was undermanned. And undersize. But hardly overwhelmed. Playing without one of their top scorers, the Cyclones still had the do-everything point guard DeAndre Kane, who, again, did everything to propel Iowa State into the Round of 16.

title: Rhode Island Legislators Vie to Fill Speaker Post After Hasty Resignation
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  The political world in Rhode Island remained in turmoil on Sunday as two members of the State House scrambled for support to become the next speaker after the sudden resignation of Gordon D. Fox, a Democrat who had held the job since 2010.

title: Rejuvenated Harlem Building Becomes a Business Incubator for Biotechnology
description: It is no secret that Harlem is changing. There is a new Red Lobster, a Joes Crab Shack, a DSW shoe store, and soon there will be a Whole Foods on 125th Street. But some of the most interesting changes are not so obvious.

title: Far-Right Party Stirs Municipal Elections in France
description: PARIS  The far right National Front party was poised to make a strong showing in the first round of French municipal elections held on Sunday, showing that the party is thriving on Frances moribund economy and broad dissatisfaction with the two main parties.

title: Tennessee, With Story of Its Own, Tops Mercer
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Ten busloads of fans from Macon, Ga., came to PNC Arena to watch 14th-seeded Mercer in another performance of its role as Cinderella in this N.C.A.A. tournament, a victory against Duke already in the books and a berth in the Round of 16 on the line for the first time in the programs history.

title: Urbanizing China
description: The plan announced by Chinas leaders last week to move more people from the countryside to cities could help raise the standard of living for millions of people. But it does not go far enough to protect migrants and farmers.

title: Willfully Endangering Drivers
description: The delayed recalls of millions of defective cars by Toyota and General Motors put the American public at risk and shows glaring deficiencies in enforcement of auto safety regulations.

title: Virginia Governor Finds Jollity Is No Guarantee Against Gridlock
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Terry McAuliffes memoir of raising oodles of money for Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, What a Party!, offered ample evidence of its authors celebrated talents for sociability and salesmanship.

title: Japan to Let U.S. Assume Control of Nuclear Cache
description: THE HAGUE  Japan will announce Monday that it will turn over to Washington more than 700 pounds of weapons-grade plutonium and a large quantity of highly enriched uranium, a decades-old research stockpile that is large enough to build dozens of nuclear weapons, according to American and Japanese officials.

title: Making Vaccination Mandatory for All Children
Another Victim of Global Financial Crisis: Pro Soccer Players
description: SANTANDER, Spain  Christmas was the last straw. Agustn Fernndez, a powerful defender for the Spanish soccer club Racing Santander, had gone four months without seeing a paycheck, so while corporate mismanagement had left his team on the brink of insolvency, Fernndez was the one going broke.

title: Start-Up Data Storage Firm Actifio Hits $1 Billion Mark
description: Updated, 2:39 p.m. | Social networking companies, online game developers and other consumer-focused tech start-ups have attracted huge investor attention, and lofty valuations to boot.

title: Breaking With the West, Afghan Leader Supports Russias Annexation of Crimea
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan this weekend joined Syria and Venezuela and became the newest member of a select club of nations: those that have publicly backed the Russian annexation of Crimea.

title: Washington Group Sees a Cutting-Edge Museum in a Vacant School Building
description: WASHINGTON  The Franklin School stands vacant and crumbling on a corner of 13th and K Streets, near a stretch of glass-fronted office buildings. The Reconstruction-era public high school was the first of its kind in Washington in 1869, and it could soon make a new mark as a kunsthalle, one of just a handful of noncollecting art museums on the East Coast.

title: Upgrades for L Train, but Not More Praise
description: The embrace comes in stages for the people of the L train, if it comes at all.

title: Russia Steps Up Economic Pressure on Kiev
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Russia and Russian state companies have increased the economic pressure on the new pro-Western government in Kiev over the past week, closing the border to most trucks, shutting a Ukrainian factory in Russia and yet again raising the price of natural gas.

title: U.N. Report Faults Syria and Rebels for Blocking Relief Supplies
description: A month after the Security Council ordered warring parties in Syria to let aid workers into besieged areas and stop indiscriminate attacks on civilians, the office of the United Nations secretary general says that the Syrian government continues to delay or ignore requests for access and that relentless fighting among opposition groups has also kept many areas of the country inaccessible.

title: Matt Everys First Win Comes at Event That Was a Boyhood Ritual
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  For a few years starting when he was in grade school, Matt Every and his father made the one-hour drive from their home in Daytona Beach every spring to attend Arnold Palmers tournament at Bay Hill. While his father planted himself at one hole, Every preferred to follow Mark Calcavecchia, a Florida high school golf standout who went on to win 13 PGA Tour events, including a British Open.

title: Going Coast to Coast
description: The itinerary of one of the 10 to 15 planes that the N.C.A.A. has chartered to take mens and womens basketball teams to and from games around the country. In some cases, the destination is unknown because the plane is taking home the loser. Times are local.

title: U.N. Report on Blocked Relief Supplies in Syria
description: A month after the Security Council ordered warring parties in Syria to let aid workers into besieged areas and stop indiscriminate attacks on civilians, the office of the United Nations secretary general says that the Syrian government continues to delay or ignore requests for access and that relentless fighting among opposition groups has also kept many areas of the country inaccessible.

title: New York, Keeper of Secrets
description: Dear Diary:

title: Bringing Him Home, Yet Again
description: While I was watching the new revival of Les Misrables, it occurred to me that this beloved stage adaptation of Victor Hugos novel may have helped pave the way for the pop singing contests that have proliferated across the globe in this century.

title: After Filling the Brackets, Finding the Charters
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  About the time that San Diego State Coach Steve Fisher was railing against the N.C.A.A.s travel preparations late Thursday night, New Mexico States dispirited basketball team was quietly boarding a bus to go back to its hotel to pack.

title: Foreign Monitors Enter Ukraine to Observe Political Situation
description: THE HAGUE  The first foreign observers permitted by governments in Moscow and Kiev to monitor the political situation and human rights are assembling in the Ukrainian capital and will start fanning out across the troubled region on Tuesday, a spokeswoman said Sunday.

title: Hurricane-Damaged Boilers Will Be Replaced in New York Public Housing
description: Thousands of New York City public housing residents faced an agonizing wait for heat and hot water to return after Hurricane Sandy flooded their buildings boilers in 2012. Even after officials rushed temporary boilers to New York in the weeks after the storm, service has remained unreliable through two winters.

title: Scintillating Clsico Sets Up Compelling Race for the Spanish Title
description: MADRID  Lionel Messi put on a dazzling display Sunday to lead Barcelona to a thrilling 4-3 victory over its archrival Real Madrid, leaving the race for Spains La Liga title wide open.

title: Girls Recap: Can You Imagine Hannah in Iowa?
description: Bravo! So satisfying, right?

title: Young Leads the Gators by Lurking on Defense
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Pittsburgh guard James Robinson dribbled quickly to his left and into the lane, around a cluster of bodies that shielded him from his Florida defender. No one stood between Robinson and the hoop. But Patric Young was lurking behind.

title: After Dream Acts Narrow Defeat, Focus Is on Timing of the Vote
description: ALBANY  Amid the generally festive energy at this weekends Somos El Futuro conference in Albany, there was another emotion coursing through many of the events Latino participants: fury over the fate of the Dream Act, which would allow undocumented college students who meet certain criteria access to state financial aid.

With each of his loping strides, his upper body sways back and forth, the carriage of an old man. The long, languid release on his shot is, like most everything about Anderson, done on his own time.

title: Peter Marino Works His Magic on Bulgaris Rome Flagship
description: To celebrate its 130-year anniversary, the Italian luxury goods titan Bulgari turned to a familiar figure in fashion circles: Peter Marino  the architect known for his luxurious retail environments for clients like Chanel and Louis Vuitton  brought his transformative techniques to the brands Rome flagship. Sotirio Bulgari, the companys founder, oversaw the shops first ribbon cutting on Via dei Condotti in 1905. At the reopening ceremony last Thursday, which was attended by Bulgaris grandsons, Paolo and Nicola, it was clear that Marino had sought to recapture the spirit of the original. He has restored the stores travertine stone slabs, the green African marble cornices and the bronze letters above the entrance doors. It took all my skills to get a new concept that was as eternal as Rome, as sexy as Bulgaris clientele, says Marino, who looked to the boutiques first architect, Florestano Di Fausto, for inspiration. His goal, he says, was to capture the Roman-ness of the brand in the neoclassical-baroque marriage  the sun-filled yellow walls, the extraordinary mix of ancient and new.

Here in the provincial capital just a few miles away, schools shut down early, and many stayed indoors fearing a riot, residents said.

title: Story of the Century
description: Good morning, this is Brian Bowman of CNN on Day X with breaking news on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370: The zombie plane theory still has legs! Some aviation experts say it is gaining steam as the search in the South Indian Ocean, one of the most remote and windy places on the planet, continues in an area somewhere between the size of West Virginia and the United States. Now, what is the zombie scenario? Well, its a spooky possibility. That this Triple Seven, after making its famous left turn, flew on autopilot for hours with its crew and passengers incapacitated before crashing into the sea or, if you happen to think the Northern Corridor option is still open, in Central Asia. Of course, there are many theories floating around and vertical gyrations are not an autopilot maneuver and no theory at this point connects all the dots and that is why we have an investigation and why we intend to stay on top of this story.

The detention of the two groups brings to 409 the number of people thought to be Uighurs who have been stopped by Thai officials this month.

title: Search List Expands in Washington State Mudslide
description: ARLINGTON, Wash.  Estimates about the number of people who may have been in the vicinity when a huge mudslide smashed through the tiny community of Oso continued to grow on Monday, as Snohomish County officials said they had compiled 176 reports of people unaccounted for since the disaster, which killed at least 14 people and wounded at least eight more.

title: Storm Damaged Their Art, and Now It May Take Their Studio Space

For about half that time, she worked out of the buildings sculpture studio, a yawning space with whitewashed brick walls and a soaring ceiling that sits just off a large interior courtyard. There, Ms. Maile and a dozen other sculptors used table saws to slice wood and pipe benders to manipulate metal, creating large-scale pieces for galleries and museums.

title: Baby M Grew Up, but Surrogacy Remains Controversial

For $10,000 (equivalent to about $22,000 today), Ms. Whitehead agreed to be inseminated with Mr. Sterns sperm, carry the pregnancy to term and then yield parental rights to the more affluent Sterns.

Mr. Iwasawa is a mathematics writer and lecturer in Japan whose puzzles have won Puzzle Design Competition awards including Puzzle of the Year (2008), First Prize (2009) and the Puzzlers Award (2012); I had the good fortune to meet Mr. Iwasawa at last weeks 11th Gathering for Gardner, a biennial celebration of the many interests including puzzles, magic and philosophy of the late math and science writer Martin Gardner.

title: Ailing Dudamel to Miss Concerts With New York Philharmonic

title: Image of the Day: March 24
Fruit of the Bartered Vine
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Broc Cellars fits hardly anybodys idea of a California winery. You wont see any cellars, for one thing, or anything remotely pastoral, like a vineyard. The cellars are a warehouse, on a corner in an industrial district here in Berkeley. Across one street is a cement plant. Across another is a motorcycle-repair shop. The melody of passing freight trains plays every once in a while.

description: Cairo residents discussed a court decision sentencing 529 members of the Muslim Brotherhood to death on charges of murder and other offenses.

title: Weekly News Quiz | March 18-24, 2014
description: A hit movie, a scientific discovery and more details about a missing airplane: How many of the 10 questions in this weeks news quiz can you answer correctly?

title: Jury Says 5 Madoff Employees Knowingly Aided Swindle of Clients Billions
description: Updated, 9:13 p.m. | A federal jury on Monday found five associates of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff guilty of 31 counts of aiding one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.

title: Guidelines May Double Statin Use
description: New treatment guidelines for lowering cholesterol could result in nearly 13 million more adults being put on statins, researchers reported last week in The New England Journal of Medicine. Nearly half of people older than age 40 may end up taking the drugs, roughly doubling current usage.

title: Oil Spill Delays Cruise Departures
description: Several cruises departing ports in Houston and Galveston have been delayed after a barge carrying almost one million gallons of bunker fuel oil collided with a bulk carrier ship in Galveston Bay, near Texas City, Tex., on Saturday.

title: Easel Turns Tablet Into a Workstation
description: Upgrading a gadget can be frustrating because it often means replacing all the accessories you bought for it, too. The creators of Nimblstand share your pain. They say that their accessory, a tablet easel, is future-proof.

title: Mother Is Charged With Abandoning Infant
description: A woman was arrested and charged with abandoning her 6-month-old son in an Upper Manhattan playground Sunday night, the police said on Monday.

title: A Study of Twins, Separated by Orbit
description: When Scott Kelly returns to space next year, he will be taking part in what may be the most far-flung twin study of all time.

title: Layoffs in Maine
description: Ive written in the past about the damage being done by sharp cuts in funding for public education, which among other things have led to sharply rising tuition, making college unaffordable for poor and even working-class students. It was inevitable that there would also be a degradation in quality  and some friends have asked me to draw attention to an ugly example at the University of Southern Maine, which is laying off a number of faculty, including tenured professors, and in the process effectively gutting several departments, including economics.

title: In Egypt, One Step Up and 529 Steps Back
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, a court in the Egyptian city of Minya sentenced 529 people to death on Monday after a hasty mass trial that included no defense, convicting them of murder for the killing of a police officer during rioting by Islamists last summer after the military deposed President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Facts & Figures: The Koch Brothers
description: Slates David Weigel looked at fundraising emails from a Democratic campaign and, based on a non-scientific sample, found that criticizing the Koch brothers can triple the haul.

title: An Implant to Prevent Seizures
description: NeuroPaces RNS system is an implantable device that prevents seizures in patients plagued by epilepsy.

title: Patient Voices: Epilepsy
description: Frequent seizures, difficult treatment decisions and social stigma -- what is it like to live with epilepsy? Eight men, women and children speak about their experiences.

title: Easing Epilepsy With Battery Power
description: ALEXANDRIA, N.H.  For most of his life, Kevin Ramsey has lived with epileptic seizures that drugs cannot control.

title: China Reports Gains in Fighting Tuberculosis
description: China has cut its rate of tuberculosis by more than half over the last 20 years, according to health officials there.

title: Taiwan Uses Force Against Protesters
description: Taiwanese riot police used water cannons on protesters in Taipei as demonstrations continued against a controversial trade pact with mainland China.

title: Cisco Bets a Billion on the Cloud
description: Even for the world of globe-spanning computer systems, Cisco is going big.

title: Ex-Yale President to Join Online Education Venture
description: Richard C. Levin, who stepped down as president of Yale University in June, will next month become the chief executive of Coursera, a California-based provider of online academic courses.

title: Bookshelf | Wordbirds, a Fine-Feathered Compendium of Modern-Day Neologisms
description: The writer Liesl Schillinger shares the process that produced Wordbirds: An Irreverent Lexicon for the 21st Century, her illustrated volume of newly coined expressions for describing contemporary life (cancellelation, occuplaytion), and lists 10 personal favorites.

title: Obama and Britains Leader on Ukraine
description: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain discussed Russias actions in Ukraine and the steps they would be taking.

title: Smoking Proves Hard to Shake Among the Poor
description: MANCHESTER, Ky.  When smoking first swept the United States in the early decades of the 20th century, it took hold among the well-to-do. Cigarettes were high-society symbols of elegance and class, puffed by doctors and movie stars. By the 1960s, smoking had exploded, helped by the distribution of cigarettes to soldiers in World War II. Half of all men and a third of women smoked.

title: Ex-Presidents Party Concedes Defeat in Maldives Parliamentary Elections
description: NEW DELHI  The party of Mohamed Nasheed, a former president of the Maldives, on Monday conceded defeat in weekend parliamentary elections, making way for a political coalition led by the countrys new president, Abdulla Yameen.

title: The Man in the Middle
description: After he begins his morning by reading 75 emails, Irving Azoff makes five phone calls to the same five friends. Azoff, a music industry executive, has a reputation as a slick negotiator, but he is also a man of routine. So he picks up the phone and dials.

title: Weekend Gun Report: March 21-23, 2014
description: Sales of the Armatix iP1, a .22-caliber pistol that only fires when a passcode is typed into the users wristwatch, were suspended in California two weeks ago after the states first vendor, the Oak Tree Gun Club outside Los Angeles, experienced an online backlash from gun rights advocates. Why are the N.R.A. and its allies so scared of smart guns?

title: Having Identified Blogger, Hedge Fund Drops  Lawsuit
description: David Einhorn, the hedge fund manager, dropped a lawsuit aimed at unmasking an anonymous blogger on the Seeking Alpha financial website, who had discussed one of his funds stock positions before it was publicly announced.

title: American Patrimony
description: One problem the Piketty work I discuss in todays column may have  at least in America  is the widespread perception, even among those who take inequality seriously, that its all about compensation, that wealth inequality isnt that big an issue, and that inheritance is also not that big an issue. We think hedge fund managers, not Kochs and Waltons.

title: Teaching as a Second Act, or Maybe Even a Third
description: GAIL R. RUSCETTA changed careers for the first time when she had children. A theater major who bounced between acting gigs in her 20s, Ms. Ruscetta took the kind of leap that overachieving city dwellers often fantasize about: She and her then husband moved to Montana and opened a horse farm and riding school.

title: In Crimea, Russia Moved to Throw Off the Cloak of Defeat
description: SEVASTOPOL, Crimea  With a single diesel-electric submarine and a hodgepodge of other aging vessels, Russias rickety Black Sea Fleet would be no match for the United States Sixth Fleet, based in Italy, which boasts the latest in seaborne military technology and has been running drills nearby.

title: Insurers Push to Enroll People as Health Care Deadline Nears
description: Its last call for health insurance.

title: House Ethics Panel Releases Details of Charges Against 2 Republican Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, Republican of Washington, the highest-ranking woman in the House leadership and a rising star in the party, may have improperly used her House office staff and financial resources to help bolster her political career, the Office of Congressional Ethics has concluded.

title: Chiefs Update on Washington Mudslide
description: Travis Hots, the Snohomish County fire chief, gave a news briefing on the search and rescue operation after a mudslide in the area.

title: Pritzker Architecture Prize Goes to Shigeru Ban
description: Architecture generally involves creating monuments to permanence from substantial materials like steel and concrete. Yet this year, the disciplines top award is going to a man who is best known for making temporary housing out of transient materials like paper tubes and plastic beer crates.

title: Seeking Autisms Biochemical Roots
description: The biochemist Ricardo E. Dolmetsch has pioneered a major shift in autism research, largely putting aside behavioral questions to focus on cell biology and biochemistry.

title: With Paper Tubes, Building Social Change
description: The jury for this years Pritzker Prize sent a clear message by choosing Shigeru Ban, the Japanese architect. That the jury did not choose a woman  after much justified protest about its historic indifference to women (only two have been acknowledged), and despite the extraordinary work of so many female designers  suggests that change in architecture remains glacial and needs a shove. But it is happening.

title: Allman Brothers Postpone Remaining Beacon Shows
description: It has to have been a tough decision: The Allman Brothers Band has spent the last couple of weeks playing what it said would be the last of its annual residencies at the Beacon Theater, and fans unable to get tickets to the sold-out run have paid scalpers high prices for the opportunity to say farewell. But Gregg Allman, the bands keyboardist and lead singer, was sidelined by bronchitis this weekend, and did not appear on Friday or Saturday. At first, he seemed inclined to take his chances on recovering by the end of the run, and the bands Facebook page offered no guarantees that Mr. Allman, 66, would return for the remaining shows.

title: Of Mice and Men Starts Well at Broadway Box Office
description: James Franco may have a new title to add to his multi-faceted, hyper-hyphenated resume: Broadway box-office draw.

title: What Were Reading Now
description: Health: An exhaustive analysisfound no evidence that eating saturated fat increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.

title: Senate Debates Ukraine Aid Bill
description: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, called for bipartisan support to pass a bill providing financial aid to Ukraine.

title: Under the Streets, a Lurking Danger
description: Investigators have not yet pinpointed the cause of the gas explosion that destroyed two buildings in East Harlem and killed eight people on March 12. Whether it was the age and decrepitude of gas and water mains, or something else, has not yet been explained. But even without all the answers, there is more that can be done to make New York and other cities safer, starting now.

title: Restaurants for Robins
description: Q. Ive noticed a lot more robins staying in my area during the winter in recent years. Why do some stay and some fly south?

title: Video of Witness to Landslide in Washington State
description: Paulo Falcao de Olivera was driving on State Route 530 north of Seattle to pick up his children two days ago when he watched as a huge landslide buried the road right in front of him.

title: Which Jazz Greats Were Left Off the Blue Note 100?
description: Blue Note Records holds a special place in the hearts of jazz fans. Since its founding in 1939, the label has recorded many of the most important names in jazz  a list limited just to saxophonists would include Ornette Coleman, John Coltrane, Dexter Gordon, Joe Henderson, Joe Lovano, Jackie McLean, Sonny Rollins and Wayne Shorter  and chronicled the development of influential movements like hard bop, 1960s avant-garde and, more recently, jazz incorporating hip-hop textures.

title: A Porpoise With a Big Chin
description: A newly identified species of ancient porpoise had an unusually long lower jaw, analogous to the human chin. The extinct porpoise, known as Semirostrum ceruttii, lived 1.5 million to 5.3 million years ago along the California coast; its closest living relative is the crown porpoise. Researchers say the porpoise used its chin to probe the seabed for food.

title: These Vultures Get First Dibs on the Good Parts
description: The early bird gets the best cut of meat.

title: No Monkeying Around for These Partners
description: Monogamy is rare in animals. Even among species that pair off, there is often philandering. But a new genetic analysis adds to the evidence that the South American primates called Azaras owl monkeys are remarkably faithful to their partners.

title: Pictures of the Day: The Netherlands and Elsewhere
description: Photos from The Netherlands, Malaysia, China and Spain.

title: Pictures of the Day: The Netherlands and Elsewhere
description: Photos from The Netherlands, Malaysia, China and Spain.

title: Reactions
description: GENETICS

title: Leaving the Comfort Zone to Learn Computer Code
description: AFTER eight years, Patsy Price had grown bored of working as a program manager at Google.

title: Birds Extinction Is Tied to the Arrival of Humans
description: When Maori settlers arrived in New Zealand in the 13th century, they were greeted by some formidable inhabitants: the moa, nine species of flightless birds up to 12 feet tall.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 1:35 A.M. (Encore) SNATCH (2001) A diamond heist by a thief who also happens to be a gambling addict named Franky Four Fingers (Benicio Del Toro) sets off a chain of events in both the organized and the not-so-organized crime worlds of London, with two small-time boxing promoters (Jason Statham and Stephen Graham) and a Gypsy bare-knuckle boxer (Brad Pitt, above) caught in the middle. In his review in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell said that the films writer and director, Guy Ritchie, seizes the bespoke machismo of British gangster movies and gives it an action pictures ferocity. He added: The effort is hyper-real, and he plays it for comic potential. Everything clicks into place by the end, though, in what is literally a shaggy dog story, with a cast of characters with florid names.

title: Bohemians in Chaos, With Flair and Drama
description: In his book Opera as Drama, the musicologist Joseph Kerman, who died last week, defended opera against what he described as the frankest assault from certain dramatic critics of particular literary bent, who tend to question the dramatic efficacy of any nonverbal artistic medium.

title: BBC Classical Music Chief Is Leaving the Studio
description: Roger Wright, the director of the BBCs classical music station, Radio 3 and of the the BBC Proms, will become the chief executive of Aldeburgh Music, the foundation that runs the Aldeburgh Festival, as well as several other programs, including a young artists program and residencies for musicians and composers. The organization was started in 1947 by Benjamin Britten, the tenor Peter Pears and the librettist Eric Crozier. The first Aldeburgh Festival was held the following year.

title: He Acted Like the Man You Wanted to Be
description: He was the strong, forthright hero: authentic, stubborn, sometimes pigheaded but dedicated to justice and capable of tenderness and sacrifice; a solitary figure, called upon to defend the homestead or rescue the girl, but often exiled, in the end, from the post-frontier civilization that no longer needed his hard mans brand of competence and courage. Whether he was a gunfighter, a cowboy or a cavalry officer, he became, for many moviegoers, the very avatar of the American frontier: the embodiment of James Fenimore Coopers Deerslayer, Emersons American Adam or what Garry Wills called fans sense of what was disappearing or had disappeared from American life.

title: Ripples From the Big Bang
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS.  When scientists jubilantly announced last week that a telescope at the South Pole had detected ripples in space from the very beginning of time, the reverberations went far beyond the potential validation of astronomers most cherished model of the Big Bang.

title: Editor Leaves Bloomberg, Citing China Coverage
description: Ben Richardson, an editor at large in Asia at Bloomberg News, announced his resignation on Monday, citing the companys handling of an investigative report in China late last year.

title: The Work of Shigeru Ban
description: Images of the architects designs.

title: Smaller Airports Are Being Left Behind
description: MY son Chris is on a business trip in India this week, and his choice of how he got there from his home in Tucson underscores a reality in air service. More often these days, business travelers will choose to drive a few hours to a bigger airport because airline service is not as convenient at their local airport.

title: Festival Focus Is on Quality, Not Diversity
description: The second half of New Directors/New Films, the annual spring showcase from the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, comes on strong with a slate that helps make this years event one of the best in a while. Its a nice change for the 43-year-old festival, which in recent years has had a tough time pulling in enough memorable work to justify its two and a half weeks, making memories of emergent masters like Spike Lee and Wong Kar-wai seem very distant. These days, the programmers  Jytte Jensen, Dennis Lim, Marian Masone, Gavin Smith, Rajendra Roy and Joshua Siegel  are selecting titles that may not be to all tastes (a good thing) and that dont seem to have been primarily chosen for some mechanistic criteria, like national diversity. Here, the work is the thing.

title: In Photography, Cool Rules
description: What good is being cool if nobody knows it? An exhibit at the National Portrait Gallery shows how cool and photography need each other.

title: Interpretations Looking Back and to the Future
description: Think of Colin Stetson as the Neil deGrasse Tyson of the avant-garde saxophone world: a brilliant adept in a rigorous, esoteric science, but also an adroit communicator with an uncommon knack for making the arcana of his field accessible to the layman. In a concert presented by the Ecstatic Music Festival on Saturday night at Merkin Concert Hall, Mr. Stetson wasted no time in demonstrating his enviable skill as the prime mover in two unorthodox collaborations.

title: Scare Tactics Over Foreign Drugs
description: ABOUT five million Americans buy medication internationally each year because of high costs in the United States. These drugs are considered foreign unapproved drugs by the Food and Drug Administration, and federal law makes it illegal to buy them. Generally, though, purchases go through without a hitch. Only rarely do customs agents seize an order.

title: Violin Sonatas Suffuse Lent
description: The Sonata No. 10 The Crucifixion, by the 17th-century virtuoso violinist Heinrich Ignaz Franz von Biber, unfolds in a blaze of effects, beginning with slashing chords perhaps intended to depict the nailing of Jesus to the cross.

title: A Risqu Romp in Any Century
description: The Queens Company, the all-female downtown ensemble led by Rebecca Patterson, taps its inner swashbuckler (and farceur) with Sir Patient Fancy, a work by one of the rare female professional playwrights of the 17th century, Aphra Behn (1640-89). Little is known about Behn except that she was a spy for King Charles II at one point, and that her plays often possess a ribald flair. This one, presented at Wild Project in the East Village, certainly does.

title: Families React to News About Crash
description: Relatives of Chinese passengers aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 reacted with anger after learning that the jet had ended its journey in the remote southern Indian Ocean.

title: New Music by the Hold Steady, Future Islands, Caetano Veloso
description: THE HOLD STEADY

title: A Side Business as a Way to Gain Financial Security
description: IN the height of the recession, as new rounds of layoffs were announced on what seemed like a daily basis, I was grappling with motherhood. Staring at my newborn daughters face, I felt overwhelmed with the responsibility. The job market only worsened my anxiety. What would we do if I were to suddenly lose my job, or if my husband were to lose his? How would we care for our child?

title: Millennials at Work: Young and Callow, Like Their Parents
description: THE generation now entering the work force, people in their late teens and early 20s, are consistently panned by many employers as not ready for the workplace. But while there are real differences, their behavior on the job might not be so different from that of previous generations.

title: Freelancers Piece Together a Living in the Temp Economy
description: LAS VEGAS  The photos spread out on a coffee table tell the story of a career. In one, a woman wears a fairy costume and rides a flying horse. In another, the woman lounges on a desert rock at sunrise, in a gold bikini draped with red silk. In a third, she wears an Uncle Sam outfit and poses on three-foot stilts.

title: Sweet Smell of Money for Plumbers
description: While working underneath a house, Joseph Rosenblum, a plumber in training in northwest Arkansas, confronted a skunk and discovered a talent that he previously hadnt been aware of: crawling very quickly.

title: Older, They Turn a Phone Into a Job
description: OLGA HOWARD has had a varied career. She worked for Pacific Bell, the California telephone company; reviewed credit card applications for Citigroup; and most recently, taught special education students in Arizona.

title: Playing With Boundaries
description: Flamenco dancers rarely perform without live music. A solo dancer surrounded by singers, guitarists and percussionists  flirtatious interchanges flaring up, various members of the clan staking out or ceding the spotlight  is a familiar image. That dancer-musician banter is a pleasure of the form.

title: A Freebie That Proved Quite Costly
description: The life of a freelance journalist is not a pretty one: As described by Mike Albo in his often amusing but slight solo show, The Junket, its filled with anxiety, insecurity and professional perils.

title: Discriminate Against the Old? Even the Old Do It
description: I AM sitting at my desk, clicking keys on my keyboard as faces with words cross my computer screen rapidly. In my midday slump, Im more than a bit annoyed. What useful information can anyone glean from how quickly or slowly I decide whether words are happy or sad, even as I am also answering whether a pictured face belongs to a younger or older person?

title: A Degree in Hand, but a Slow Start Up the Career Ladder
description: THERE were so many low points, its hard for Kyle Whittaker to say which was the lowest. Ditching his girlfriends broken-down Lincoln at a gas station, because they couldnt afford the tow? Month No. 3 of living on nothing but angel hair pasta? Or maybe it was the day he realized he might have to move back in with one of his parents.

title: Experts Offer Their Guidance for Dealing With Online Bullying
description: #bits-blockie { color: #444; padding: 20px 40px 10px 40px; box-shadow: inset 0 0 5px 1px rgba(0,0,0,0.07); margin: 20px 0 20px 0; position: relative; font-size: 17px; line-height: 35px; background-color: #fffffe; } #bits-blockie p { font-size: 16px; line-height: 23px; font-family: nyt-franklin, arial, helvetica, sans-serif; font-weight: 200; }

title: Fluid Moves, Just Like Pros
description: You might go into a program of the Juilliard Dance Division prepared to see a group of competent dancers in training. The latest edition of Juilliard Dances Repertory, performed by the current crop of sophomore, junior and senior dancers, is a reminder that, at their finest, these students are much more: one of the most vibrant dance companies in the city.

title: With Start-Ups, Greeks Make Recovery Their Own Business
description: ATHENS  For Natalie Kontou, 32, Greeces economic crisis may be a blessing in disguise.

title: Tips for Women Asking for a Raise
description: Experts say women need to take a more calibrated approach when they ask for a raise, or they can risk being perceived as overly demanding and unlikable, and their requests can backfire.

title: Faith and Rights: A Test for the Justices
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama and the Pope
description: To the Editor:

title: How the I.R.S. Created a Campaign-Spending Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: Gloria Steinem at 80
description: To the Editor:

title: Botox for Depression?
description: To the Editor:

title: Money for the Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Allow Pre-K at Charters
description: To the Editor:

title: The Threat to the Palisades
description: THE Palisades, a treasured American landmark, are under threat. The consumer electronics maker LG Electronics USA is preparing to construct a towering headquarters building along the Hudson River north of the George Washington Bridge, breaking the natural sweep of parkland and scenic vistas.

title: Torn Between Two Lands, and Two Suitors
description: Woe to the surly, cheaply dressed teenagers of American arts and letters: One after another, these broadly drawn characters are shipped off to remote relatives, the better to find themselves anew.

title: In N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket, Mathematician Outdoes Matildas
description: Mastering anN.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament bracket is a tough racket. Ask anyone who had Duke, Kansas and Wichita State making it to the Round of 16 or beyond.

title: Belgian Paper Apologizes Over Racist Images of Obama Used in Satire
description: Last Updated, Tuesday, 10:34 a.m. | One of Belgiums leading newspapers, De Morgen, apologized on Monday to readers offended by a satirical feature published two days earlier that used racist images of President Obama to mock his strained relationship with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.

title: After the Death of Their Daughter, a Verdict Looms
description: DOHA, Qatar  Matthew and Grace Huang spend five hours a day on Skype home-schooling their two adopted sons, now living with Mrs. Huangs mother back home in the United States. The Huangs are also using the Internet to connect with an American counselor, who is helping them attempt to repair their psyches after nearly a year of separate incarcerations in Qatars penal system.

title: Left Fares Poorly in First Round of Frances Municipal Elections
description: PARIS  The lowest turnout in 50 years in the first round of municipal elections appeared to help the far right to a strong showing and hurt the governing Socialist Party in the countrys first major balloting since the election of President Franois Hollande in 2012.

title: Loyalty Programs for One-of-a-Kind Hotels
description: Its a decision many business travelers would rather not have to make: stick with the big, predictable hotel chain and accumulate rewards points, or stay at the offbeat independent hotel but give up any rewards.

title: Closing on Short Notice, Brooklyn Assisted-Living Home Angers Families
description: Outside the elevator doors where residents congregate with their walkers, in the big white dining room and in the floral-carpeted hallways where aides push wheelchairs along, it has been all anyone can talk about.

title: Encounters With Celebrities and Wild Dogs
description: AFTER college, my first job was working for my fraternity. It was a dream job and gave me my first taste of business travel. I enjoy the physical sensation of taking off and the freedom to read, rest, watch a movie or just stare out the window.

title: A Fighters Training Pays Off
description: The mixed martial artist Johny Hendricks spent months in the gym to prepare for his welterweight championship fight at U.F.C. 171 against Robbie Lawler.

title: U.F.C.s Big Daddy
description: Most Saturdays, you can find Johny Hendricks spending time with his wife and three young daughters, playing golf or hunting. But once every few months, he steps into a steel cage with an unlucky opponent and becomes Bigg Rigg Hendricks, one of the top fighters in the world.

title: Case Spurs Fan Debate Over Boston Announcer
description: BOSTON  Jerry Remy, the longtime color announcer and former second baseman for the Boston Red Sox, has been a superstar in New England for decades. He owns several restaurants bearing his name and reigns as president of Red Sox Nation, the teams crazed, irreverent, die-hard fans.

title: Box, a Cloud Storage Firm, Plans I.P.O.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Box, an online storage service that aims to become an essential part of the cloud computing-based business, on Monday released financial data before a public offering.

title: Monday Motorsports: Busch Wins Kyle vs. Kyle Showdown
description: Kyle Busch held on for a narrow victory on Sunday in the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup race in Fontana, Calif. Busch beat Kyle Larson  the rookie who won the Nationwide Series race on Saturday  on the final green-white-checkered dash to the finish. Larson was trailed by Kurt Busch, Matt Kenseth and Tony Stewart.

title: Fish Embryos Exposed to Oil From BP Spill Develop Deformities, a Study Finds
description: Embryos of tuna and amberjack that were exposed to crude oil collected from the Deepwater Horizon spill developed heart and other deformities that would probably kill some of the developing fish and shorten the lives of others, a new study by a team of marine scientists reported on Monday.

title: Ugandas Anti-Gay Law Complicates U.S. Aid in Rebel Hunt
description: WASHINGTON  On the February day that President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda signed a law making homosexuality a crime punishable by life in prison, the White House sharply criticized the measure as more than an affront and warned that the administration would review the American relationship with Uganda in light of the law.

title: College Basketball Data Aplenty for Those Who Can Afford It
description: SAN DIEGO  When Butler fell a precious few inches short of winning a national championship in 2010, its players took the court during that season believing they were the most prepared team in the country. That faith rested in the coaching staffs embrace of new statistical formulas that augmented what showed up on film and offered up ideas on the most efficient path toward victory.

title: Hurt in Crisis, TPG Pursues Smaller Deals
description: When the financial crisis erupted in 2008, TPG suffered more than most private equity firms, having invested in three of that eras most troubled deals.

title: Venezuela Takes Steps to Ease Curbs on Currency
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Seeking to confront the deep economic problems that have helped fuel weeks of protests here, Venezuelas socialist-inspired government took a step on Monday toward easing strict currency controls and opened what it says will be a free market for the sale of dollars to Venezuelans.

title: Lethal Liquid Nicotine
description: As little as a teaspoon of liquid nicotine  the key ingredient in electronic cigarettes  can kill a small child and less than a tablespoon, at high concentrations, can kill an adult. Yet some vendors are offering to sell the lethal product over the Internet by the gallon or barrel, with little control over how it is handled, as reported by Matt Richtel in The Times on Monday.

title: A Question of Whats a Reasonable Reward
description: Earlier this month, Coca-Cola sent out its annual report and proxy statement to shareholders.

title: Egypts Miscarriage of Justice
description: Egypt has been on an alarming downward spiral ever since the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak in 2011. Even so, the court verdict on Monday that condemned 529 Islamists to death for the killing of a single police officer last summer was a uniquely shocking example of a judicial system run amok.

title: Keep It Short
description: In my first daily newspaper job some 25 years ago, I learned a few lessons about brevity that Im still using today. Back then, among other editorial chores, I contributed to a weekly feature called Books in Brief. Each review could be no longer than 200 words  less than a fourth the length of a usual article. Imagine a slender column of type slightly taller than your middle finger, and youll get some idea of the word limit.

title: Obama Juggles Itinerary in Bid to Ease Tensions Between Two Asian Allies
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama brings together the estranged leaders of Japan and South Korea for a peacemaking session in The Hague on Tuesday evening, it will be the culmination of three months of intense behind-the-scenes American diplomacy.

title: Lawyers Sum Up Cases at Bin Laden Relatives Trial
description: The video, which showed Sulaiman Abu Ghaith seated beside Osama bin Laden the day after the Sept. 11 attacks, practically spoke for itself, prosecutors argued on Monday  evidence of Mr. Abu Ghaiths participation in a terrorist conspiracy to kill Americans.

title: Obama to Call for End to N.S.A.s Bulk Data Collection
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is preparing to unveil a legislative proposal for a far-reaching overhaul of the National Security Agencys once-secret bulk phone records program in a way that  if approved by Congress  would end the aspect that has most alarmed privacy advocates since its existence was leaked last year, according to senior administration officials.

title: Teixeiras Roundabout Trip to First Proves Right Path
description: TAMPA, Fla.  At the end of the 2014 season, or perhaps even before that, the Yankees will have to find a new shortstop to replace Derek Jeter, who has already announced that this will be his final season. If the Yankees seek an internal option to replace Jeter and want someone with the potential to hit for power, one outside-the-box choice  all right, way outside the box  would to be put Mark Teixeira back at his original position.

title: Disney Buys Maker Studios, Video Supplier for YouTube
description: LOS ANGELES  Mickey Mouse became a YouTube giant on Monday.

title: Angry Judge Says Sheriff Defied Order on Latinos
description: PHOENIX  A federal judge strongly rebuked Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County and one of his chief deputies on Monday, saying that they had defied and even mocked the judges order last year to stop singling out Latinos during routine patrols, traffic stops and workplace raids.

title: The Smoking Divide
description: A new analysis of federal smoking data reveals that although the national smoking rate has been falling, there is a clear geographic divide.

title: Matsuzaka Looks Strong in Bid for a Rotation Spot
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It was perhaps Daisuke Matsuzakas last chance to win the fifth spot in the Mets rotation, and against the St. Louis Cardinals on Monday, he pitched as well as he had all spring. He struck out the side  Matt Carpenter, Mark Ellis and Allen Craig  in the first inning and allowed only one run over six innings.

title: Order Signed by Judge G. Murray Snow
description: Judge G. Murray Snow strongly rebuked Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., and one of his chief deputies.

title: Murray Faces Crossroads After Lendl
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  For Andy Murray, a major change was not immediately visible on the surface.

title: The Republic of Fear
description: If youre reading this, you are probably not buffeted by daily waves of physical terror. You may fear job loss or emotional loss, but you probably dont fear that somebody is going to slash your throat, or that a gang will invade your house come dinnertime, carrying away your kin and property. We take a basic level of order for granted.

title: G.M.s Own Findings vs. Drivers Experiences
description: A timeline maps internal findings by General Motors and driver experiences.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 25, 2014
description: This is a remote location, far from any possible landing sites. It is therefore with deep sadness and regret that I must inform you that, according to this new data, Flight MH370 ended in the southern Indian Ocean.

title: If Gays Can Marry, and Be Fired for Doing So
Parachutists Admit Jumping From Trade Center Tower
description: With concern about security at the World Trade Center tower growing, a group of daredevils who parachuted off the skyscraper last year turned themselves in to the police on Monday afternoon, with one saying that the stunt had exposed the need for more vigilance at the citys tallest tower.

title: N.B.A. Denies Clearing Nets to Become Russian
description: The Nets owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov spoke Monday in Moscow about transferring the team to a Russian-based company and his desire to turn the Nets into the legal equivalent of a Russian team.

title: Absence of Contention at Council Hearing Seems to Shore Up the de Blasio Effect
description: It may not feel like spring yet, but the atmosphere in the New York City Council chambers, where members are discussing Mayor Bill de Blasios preliminary budget, is warmer than it has been in years.

title: General Motors Misled Grieving Families on a Lethal Flaw
description: It was nearly five years ago that any doubts were laid to rest among engineers at General Motors about a dangerous and faulty ignition switch. At a meeting on May 15, 2009, they learned that data in the black boxes of Chevrolet Cobalts confirmed a potentially fatal defect existed in hundreds of thousands of cars.

title: Paths That Crossed Cross Again
description: The curtain rises on two people frozen in what feels like a thaw-proof silence. Their eyes are fixed straight ahead, and the possibility of even their gazes intersecting seems remote; forget about a meeting of minds. With these figures implacably embodied by Tyne Daly and Frederick Weller in Terrence McNallys Mothers and Sons, any dialogue that might occur seems destined to be nasty, brutish and short.

title: Corrections: March 25, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Goodell Holds Off on Discipline for Irsay and Dolphins Players
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Commissioner Roger Goodell said he had not decided whether to penalize the Colts owner, Jim Irsay, who could face felony charges of possession of controlled substances.

title: CBO Secrets
description: A bit of a utility post. A few people have asked where they can find some of the CBO numbers I cited in todays column. A general heads-up: when CBO releases a report, you always want to check for the supplemental material. If you look at the big report on income inequality, look off to the right  youll see data underlying select figures, which has lots of additional numbers  and which is where I got the changing share of business income going to the one percent.

title: In a Mischievous Manner
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This is New York Times puzzle number 2 for David Woolf, although he tells me that it was the first one Will Shortz accepted from him. That can happen sometimes; a constructor submits a number of puzzles in a row and some are accepted, but they might not necessarily run in the order in which they were received.

title: Biggest Eyewear Company Signs On With Google Glass
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google on Monday announced a partnership with the Luxottica Group, the largest eyeglass company in the world, to design, manufacture and distribute frames for Google Glass, the Internet-connected eyewear.

title: Amid Wave of Pro-Gun Legislation, Georgia Proposes Sweeping Law
description: ATLANTA  Pro- and anti-gun forces do not agree on much, but they do agree on the breathtaking sweep of the Georgia legislation allowing guns in bars, schools, restaurants, churches and airports that is now awaiting the signature of Gov. Nathan Deal.

title: A Film Premiere Cesar Chavez Would Appreciate
description: LOS ANGELES  The billboards, with images of labor struggle, are rousing. And the online campaign, aimed at getting support for an official Cesar Chavez national day of service, rings some bells. But Participant Media and its partners on Monday announced the sort of promotional move that the labor activist Cesar Chavez might have planned for his namesake biopic.

title: 17 Months After Hurricane, Recovery Effort Plods Along
description: To walk east into Far Rockaway, or west along the south shore of Staten Island, is to reach storm-raked lands half healed.

title: Israel: Reporter Denied Saudi Visa
description: The Washington bureau chief of The Jerusalem Post has been denied a visa to Saudi Arabia to report on President Obamas visit to that country, the newspaper reported on Monday. The reporter, Michael Wilner, had submitted forms to the White House requesting a visa, the newspaper said. He was scheduled to arrive in Riyadh, the capital, on a commercial flight on Wednesday and to leave with the president on Saturday. On Monday, Mr. Wilner, an American citizen, said he thought his visa request had been denied because of his media affiliation or his Jewish faith.The State Department referred inquiries to the Saudi Embassy in Washington, which did not respond to requests for comment.

title: 5 Bidders Face Hurdle to Save Long Island College Hospital
description: Five bidders have come forward with proposals to keep the distressed Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn running as a hospital, but none of them have licenses to run hospitals in New York, which could prove a significant hurdle, hospital experts said Monday.

title: Crash Kills Boy, 11; Stepfather Charged
description: An 11-year-old boy who was critically injured on Sunday in what the police say was a drunken-driving accident that his stepfather caused has died, the authorities said on Monday.

title: After Honoring Lundqvist, Sluggish Rangers Rally for a Stirring Victory
description: Alain Vigneault exudes a stately calm, and in that calm, his team is thriving. Vigneaults Rangers displayed exactly that quality Monday in a wild, stirring and important 4-3 overtime victory over the Phoenix Coyotes at Madison Square Garden.

title: After 5 Years, Nets Have a Player of the Week
description: For 264 weeks, no Nets player was worthy of the player of the week award.

title: Ebola, Killing Scores in Guinea, Threatens Nearby Nations
description: The first outbreak of Ebola fever in the West African nation of Guinea has killed at least 59 people and may be spreading into nearby countries, international health agencies warned on Monday.

title: In Working Extra Time Again, Nets Break Down
description: NEW ORLEANS  The Nets collective battery lasted a bit less than three quarters Monday night. After that, the previous nights game, the overnight flight, the depleted roster and the persistent New Orleans Pelicans seemed to drain it all at once.

description: DAVIS, Calif.  As more homeowners generate their own electricity from solar panels, they still need power from a utility after the sun goes down.

title: Wu Tianming, Who Shaped Chinese Cinema in 1980s, Dies at 74
description: Wu Tianming, a movie director and former studio head known as the godfather of contemporary Chinese cinema for the generation of filmmakers  including Zhang Yimou and Chen Kaige  he shepherded to international acclaim, died on March 4 in Beijing. He was 74.

title: Joseph Kerman, Colorful Critic of Musicology, Dies at 89
description: Joseph Kerman, an eminent musicologist and critic who modernized a field he had found insular and stagnant, challenging conventional wisdom with colorful, pungent prose, died on March 17 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 89.

title: Why I Wont Run for Office in India This Time
description: MUMBAI, India  Taking the kids to school, I pass a bridge in Dharavi that collapsed nearly three years ago. Traffic there is always a dreadful snarl. No attempt has been made to fix the bridge.

title: Ex-Bloomberg Editor Tells Why He Left
description: Below is the on-the-record text of an email message that Ben Richardson, a former senior Bloomberg News editor based in Hong Kong, sent to Jim Romenesko, an American journalist who writes about the news media on his popular blog, jimromenesko.com. Mr. Romenesko reported on Monday on Mr. Richardsons recent departure from Bloomberg. Mr. Richardson was involved in the editing of a story last year on Chinas wealthiest man, Wang Jianlin, the founder of the Dalian Wanda Group, and Mr. Wangs financial ties to the families of Communist Party leaders.

title: Malaysia Says Missing Plane Sent One Last Partial Signal
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Malaysian authorities released new details on Tuesday to buttress their conclusion that Flight 370 must have ended in a crash in a remote part of the Indian Ocean.

title: A Chinese-Style Suit for Xi Jinpings European Trip
description: President Xi Jinping wore a modified Mao suit to a state dinner hosted by the Dutch royal family in Amsterdam on Saturday, eliciting surprise from Chinese citizens who are used to their leaders sartorial decisions being a model of suit-and-tie uniformity.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Virtual Reality Is Here. Can We Play With It?
description: In Virtual Reality Is Here. Can We Play With It?, Chris Suellentrop writes about his experience trying out virtual reality gaming.

title: Who Needs a Boss?
description: If you happen to be looking for your morning coffee near Golden Gate Park and the bright red storefront of the Arizmendi Bakery attracts your attention, congratulations. You have found what the readers of The San Francisco Bay Guardian, a local alt-weekly, deem the citys best bakery. But it has another, less obvious, distinction. Of the $3.50 you hand over for a latte (plus $2.75 for the signature sourdough croissant), not one penny ends up in the hands of a faraway investor. Nothing goes to anyone who might be tempted to sell out to a larger bakery chain or shutter the business if its quarterly sales lag.

title: A Quiet Sea Change in Medicare
description: Ever since Cindy Hasz opened her geriatric care management business in San Diego 13 years ago, she has been fighting a losing battle for clients unable to get Medicare coverage for physical therapy because they plateaued and were not getting better.

title: In Photography, Cool Rules
description: The thing about cool is that it shows itself equally in moments of distress or pleasure, driving people indifferently to greatness or stupidity. It comes from gritty streets and prices out the people who live there; it pulls couples together or cleaves them apart. And even as its meaning dissipates from overuse, you still cant talk about Miles Davis without mentioning it.

title: What Do You Want to Be Doing When Youre 80?
description: When you get to be a certain age, growing older isnt something you necessarily want to happen  it just happens. But 80 today for many people isnt the same 80 as it used to be. Some 80-year-olds are still traveling around the world and riding elephants.

title: Once an Enemy of Bill, Now a Friend of Hillary
description: WASHINGTON  In a cozy corner of loftlike offices near Union Station, 16 young researchers sit almost shoulder to shoulder, monitoring rows of computer screens.

title: New York Today: A Little More Snow

title: Centrica and 2 Investment Firms to Buy Irish Energy Assets
description: LONDON  The British energy company Centrica and two investment partners said on Tuesday that they had agreed to acquire the natural gas and electricity supply business and other assets from Bord Gais Eireann, which is owned by Ireland, for 1.1 billion euros, or about $1.5 billion.

title: A War Horse Revived, With No Stars Riding
description: The Metropolitan Opera puts it plainly in a program note: Star power has been the driving force behind productions of Andrea Chnier since the works Met premiere in 1921. The text goes on to cite a Whos Who of the opera pantheon that includes Gigli, Ponselle, Milanov and Corelli.

title: British Insurer RSA Aims to Raise $1.27 Billion in Rights Issue
description: LONDON  The British insurer RSA Group said on Tuesday that it had begun a rights issue to raise 773 million pounds, or about $1.27 billion, looking to bolster its balance sheet after capital problems in its Irish business.

title: CVC Capital Acquires Nordic Eyewear Retailer
description: LONDON  The private equity firm CVC Capital Partners said on Tuesday that it had acquired Synsam Nordic, an optical retailer in the Nordic region, from an investment group controlled by the family behind the Swedish furniture retailer Ikea.

title: Supreme Court Hears Cases on Contraception Rule
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday will hear arguments in a pair of challenges to a part of President Obamas health care law that requires many employers to provide insurance coverage for contraceptives. Here is a look at the parties, the lawyers and the issues in the case.

title: Daily Report: Box, an Online Storage Company, Files for Public Stock Offering
description: Box, an online storage service that aims to become an essential part of the cloud computing-based business, on Monday released financial data before a public offering, Quentin Hardy reports.

title: TPGs New Investment Approach
description: TPG Capital, the 22-year-old private equity firm, suffered more than other firms when the financial crisis took hold in 2008. But now, as it contemplates a future initial public offering, TPG is coming back  this time with smaller deals and a recalibrated approach to private equity, William Alden and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook.

title: Power Is Restored Across Crimean Peninsula
description: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea  Electricity was restored on Tuesday to cities across the disputed Crimean Peninsula following power failures a day earlier, and both Russian and regional officials said they were taking steps to limit Crimeas vulnerability to any cutoff in services by the Ukrainian government.

description: LiveSafe, a start-up aiming to create a next-generation safety network for mobile phones, has found a powerful new backer.

title: Climate Change Art: That Sinking Feeling
description: I apologize for 10 days of blog silence while I co-led our Pace University documentary production class on a filmmaking trip in Brazil. Now comes crunch time as we shift to editing mode. The film will describe efforts in three places  Ilha Grande, Paraty and Rio de Janeiro  to make sure the benefits of tourism arent exceeded by the environmental and social costs.

title: What It Would Have Taken
description: Brad DeLong is wrong. He thinks we have a disagreement, but hes misinterpreting what I said when I argued that the Feds 2008 inflation phobia wasnt responsible for the Great Recession and the Lesser Depression that have followed and continue to this day.

title: A 4 A.M. Encounter With New Yorks Finest
description: Dear Diary:

title: Listen Up | The Dreamlike Sounds of S. Carey, Bon Ivers Secret Weapon
description: I love California, and I get jealous when other people are there, says the musician Sean Carey, whose forthcoming solo album, Range of Light (out April 1, Jagjaguwar), under the name S. Carey, pays tribute to the American West. Carey, a 28-year-old from Wisconsin who is also the drummer and backing vocalist for the indie folk band Bon Iver, says that yearly trips to California as a child left a lasting impression, later reinforced by playing gigs out west. We would go hiking and backpacking, and have big family reunions in Yosemite, Carey says. On tour, those feelings kind of rekindle. The trips provided a jumping-off point for the sound of the new album, as well as its title, a term the 19th-century naturalist John Muir used to describe the Sierra Nevada.

title: Cant Play by the Rules? Its Fine by Mr. Monopoly
description: Maybe you and your friends have made Free Parking more like a winning lottery ticket by adding the proceeds from taxes and fees. Or youve started your own stimulus program by jacking up the take for landing on Go  or amended those pesky regulations limiting houses and hotels.

title: In Ocean of Mud, a Plea: Leave Me and Find My Wife
description: OSO, Wash.  This was how last Saturday morning began for Linda McPherson, 68, and her husband, Gary, 78, better known as Mac: They were in their twinned reclining chairs in the living room easing into the day when, without warning, at a few minutes before 11 a.m., their world and everything around them was shattered.

title: 2 Killed in Shooting Aboard Destroyer at Norfolk Naval Base
description: WASHINGTON  Navy officials on Tuesday were investigating a shooting on a guided-missile destroyer docked in Norfolk, Va., that left a sailor dead along with a civilian believed to be the gunman.

description: Niesha Hogan, a visual operations manager, moved to Harlem from Oakland, Calif. She says the neighborhood feels like home to her, because everyone there understands and loves getting dressed.

description: TLAJOMULCO, Mexico  The United States calls Hugo Cullar Hurtado a longtime trafficker of the cocaine coming from South America, working with one of the men believed to command Mexicos biggest drug cartel now that its leader, Joaqun Guzmn Loera, has been captured.

title: For Carlyle, Recruiting an Outsider Is Not Unusual
description: Many financial firms, from Goldman Sachs to Bain Capital, like to groom their senior talent from within. But the Carlyle Group, a private equity giant based in Washington, has shown time and again that it is willing to look elsewhere for its leaders.

title: U.N. Expresses Alarm Over Egyptian Death Sentences
description: GENEVA  The United Nations human rights office expressed deep alarm Tuesday after an Egyptian court sentenced 529 people to death, condemning the judgment as a violation of international law.

title: Prepare Before Negotiating
description: Dolly Chugh, a professor at the New York University Stern School of Business, discusses the need for women to prepare before asking for a raise.

description: A patient in a Canadian hospital who was feared to have been infected by the Ebola virus while in West Africa does not have the virus, health officials said Tuesday.

description: Top Australian officials discussed the continuing search effort for any crash debris of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which was halted because of bad weather.

description: WASHINGTON  After being interrogated for four and a half hours, a 27-year-old Chechen man who had just admitted to committing a grisly triple homicide in 2011 with the help of one of the Boston Marathon bombers was starting to show signs of anxiety.

description: THE HAGUE  Amid the chest-thumping between President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in recent weeks, one question has lingered: How big a threat is Russia, anyway?

description: Robert Louis Stevenson married Fanny Van de Grift Osbourne in 1880. When author Nancy Horan saw how adventuresome their lives were, she had the material for Under the Wide and Starry Sky.
