description: In the Video

title: Search for Missing Jet Is Moved Nearly 700 Miles, Based on Radar Analysis
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Australia announced on Friday that it had moved the search area for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 nearly 700 miles to the northeast, the latest in a long series of changes by the authorities on where they think the plane might have disappeared.

title: Test Yourself | English, March 27, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Obama Deplores Russias Brute Force in Ukraine
description: In Obama Deplores Russias Brute Force in Ukraine, Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker write about President Obamas speech in Europe outlining for Americans back home and for allies around the world why it is crucial to confront President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after his takeover of Crimea.

title: Have You Ever Posted, Emailed or Texted Something You Wish You Could Take Back?
description: Have you ever posted something you shouldnt have on an impulse, or texted somebody by mistake?

title: A Look Back at Burt Glinn
description: One of my most treasured possessions is a creased and well-handled black-and-white photograph. It lives in my living room in a floating, double-sided frame so that I can view its front and back, both of which I find mesmerizing. The photograph was made in 1957 by the Magnum photographer Burt Glinn and shows the Little Rock Nine, surrounded by armed and helmeted troops, ascending the steps of Little Rock Central High School on its first day of integration. The schools brick facade fills the frame, evoking a prison, rather than an opportunity. The back of the print features stamps and instructions Magnum used to identify and track its images when there was no other option than to transport physical photographs.

title: High and Low Views From the Bay Area
description: The Bay Area has a lot of million-dollar views, but even the cheaper ones are pretty nice.

title: Objects That Make a House a Home
description: As part of Key, our mini-magazine on real estate and design, we asked seven designers to tell us about the most comfortable things they own.

title: The San Francisco Envy Chain
description: When I first walked into Mark Donaldson and Dawn Judds loft in San Franciscos Dogpatch neighborhood, their two daughters were swinging on climbing ropes hung from the rafters, and Mark was weaving between them on a skateboard. All the kinetic energy looked a bit dangerous, but also exhilarating. A pink bicycle perched on its kickstand near a door that led to the patio, and everywhere, about to topple, were stacks of books. The building once served as the Esprit headquarters, where Mark and Dawn both worked in the late 80s. Some 20 years later, while at a childrens birthday party across the street, they noticed the place was for sale. Now a bust of a girl with braided hair, sculpted by Dawns grandmother, sits in the entryway, and wooden birds float from the ceiling.

title: Social Gains for Women Linked to Domestic Violence
description: NEW DELHI  Indian women who experience economic and social gains in the form of employment and education are often at a greater risk for domestic violence, according to a study released on Tuesday.

title: Qatar Finds U.S. Couple Guilty in Daughters Death
description: DOHA, Qatar  Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple accused of killing their 8-year-old adopted African daughter last year by depriving her of sustenance for four days, were unexpectedly found guilty on Thursday and were each sentenced to three years in prison followed by deportation, in a case that has drawn close attention in Qatar and in the United States.

title: Pretax Profit Slumps 40%  at Raiffeisen
description: FRANKFURT  Raiffeisen Bank International, an Austrian lender closely watched because of its extensive operations in Ukraine and Russia, reported fourth-quarter results on Thursday that reflected its mounting number of problem loans in the region.

title: New York Today: De Blasios Diversity
description: Good Thursday morning. Its 25 degrees.

title: Yahoo Japan to Buy eAccess From SoftBank
description: HONG KONG  Yahoo Japan said Thursday that it would acquire eAccess, a mobile Internet service provider, from the Japanese telecommunications giant SoftBank for 324 billion yen, or $3.2 billion.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Babcock International to Pay $1.53 Billion For Spanish Aviation Firm
description: LONDON  The Babcock International Group said Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the Spanish aviation services company Avincis for 920 million pounds from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Investindustrial Group.

title: Enlisting a Computer to Battle Cancers, One by One
description: When Robert B. Darnell was a graduate student in the early 1980s, he spent a year sequencing a tiny fragment of DNA. Now Dr. Darnell is an oncologist and the president of the New York Genome Center, where the DNA-sequencing machines can decode his grad-school fragment in less than a ten-thousandth of a second.

title: UBS Said to Suspend Six Traders in Currency Review
description: LONDON  UBS has suspended six additional traders on three continents as an investigation into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day currency markets widens, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Criticism, and Rare Words of Support, as China Watches Taiwan Protests
description: The occupation of Taiwans legislature by students protesting the handling of a trade pact with China has been condemned by Chinese state media and in many comments online, but some democracy advocates on the Chinese mainland have endorsed the movement, calling it an inspiration to their efforts.

title: I.M.F. Prepares $18 Billion in Loans for Ukraine
description: LONDON  After three weeks of urgent negotiations with the interim government of Ukraine and in an atmosphere of great power competition, the International Monetary Fund announced on Thursday an agreement to provide up to $18 billion in loans over two years to prevent the countrys default.

title: Daily Report: Inventor Behind Oculus Rift, a Virtual Reality Sensation
description: Palmer Luckey, a baby-faced 21-year-old college dropout, figured out how to build a virtual reality headset so exciting that it became a sensation on Kickstarter, the crowdfunding site, raising a staggering $2.4 million in 30 days, Jenna Wortham reports.

title: Quiet Formula One Cars Spark a Noisy Debate
description: As Formula One prepares for its second race of the season on Sunday, the Malaysian Grand Prix in Sepang, it feels like business as usual despite the radical new set of technical regulations introduced by the series.

title: What I Have Learned About Pitching for Investment Capital
description: When I started Posse in 2010, I knew Id have to raise money, which meant pitching to investors. I attended a few start-up events and watched YouTube videos showing other people pitching ideas. Id never used PowerPoint, and the night before my first pitch, I called up a friend to find out how it worked. I designed a simple deck and stayed up all night rehearsing.

title: An Exchange of Views, Some in Accord
description: VATICAN CITY  President Obama and Pope Francis on Thursday skirted social issues that have generated tension between some Roman Catholic leaders and the American president, opting instead for a nearly hourlong discussion that touched on income inequality, the conflict raging in Syria, the persecution of Christians around the world and the elusiveness of global peace.

title: 529 Reasons to Doubt Egyptian Justice
description: CAIRO  It was the kind of mass death sentence that seems to come from another time and place. But the news on Monday that an Egyptian judge had handed down a verdict condemning 529 people to execution was all too real, even as the particulars of the case, the trial and the public reaction all conjured a sense of what could be called Egypts current brand of magical realism. In the end, Judge Saeed Elgazars gesture was at once brutal, tragic, absurd  and most likely futile.

title: Confrontation Rumors, Easily Debunked, Touch a Nerve
description: It was just after Michelle Obama, the American first lady, had extolled the glories of free speech, during a talk last Saturday at the prestigious Peking University, that the student allegedly blurted out her sarcastic retort to the guest of honor.

title: A Failure for Citigroup
description: CITIGROUP FAILS FED STRESS TEST | For the second time in three years, the Federal Reserve rejected Citigroups plans to manage its capital, an embarrassing blow that could derail the plans of Michael Corbat, the banks chief executive, to rehabilitate the bank, Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. Citigroup was the only one of the nations top five banks that failed to persuade the Fed to bless its plans for shareholder payouts.

title: Microsoft to Offer Office for iPad, Maybe a Bit Late
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One of the most lucrative software franchises in history, Microsoft Office, has finally come to the most influential computing device of the last few years, the iPad.

title: Poetry Pairing | Lenten Song
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing features Lenten Song by Phillis Levin and the article An Online Generation Redefines Mourning by Hannah Seligson.

title: Hodinkee, Watch Cheerleader
description: Benjamin Clymer introduced the watch website Hodinkee in 2008, at age 25. It has grown into a hub for fans and advertisers.

title: Dealing With Unwanted Windows Updates
description: Q. In Windows 7, the Windows Update service keeps trying to install an important security update for Microsoft Office 2007 and then tells me it failed to install the fix. I dont even use Office 2007 anymore, so how can I stop these failed efforts?

title: U.S. to Shrink Stake in Ally Financial
description: The Treasury Department is preparing to reduce its stake in Ally Financial by more than half, through an initial public offering of stock.

title: Biking to Dollar Beer Night
description: Dear Diary:

title: Baxter to Split Into 2 Health Care Companies
description: Splitsville has been a popular destination for big United States corporations of late.

title: In Our Pages: March 28
description: 1914: Wall Street Has a Dull Day

title: Nafta Still Bedevils Unions
description: Two decades after its enactment, the North American Free Trade Agreement  better known as Nafta  remains a source of deep disagreement among economists.

title: Consortium Wants Standards for Internet of Things
description: Attention: Internet of Things. For better or worse, big boys are in the room.

title: Growth in the Fourth Quarter Is Revised Up a Shade, to 2.6%
description: The American economy grew by 2.6 percent in the final months of 2013, the Commerce Department said on Thursday, a slight uptick from its previous estimate but still well below the pace of growth recorded in the third quarter.

title: 3 Things Parents Wish Teachers Knew: We Can Handle the Truth
description: After I wrote 5 Things Teachers Wish Parents Knew, parents started filling my inbox with the things they wish teachers knew  and why not? The ideal parent-teacher conference is an opportunity to give and take, a time and place for both teachers and parents to share their observations. Heres what the parents who got in touch wish their childrens teachers knew:

title: Former Prime Minister Announces Candidacy for President of Ukraine
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former prime minister, said Thursday that she would run for president in elections to be held in May.

title: Tweets About Music to Get Their Own Billboard Chart
description: Chatter about music is everywhere on Twitter. Soon there will be a Billboard chart to rank all of it.

title: Life Is an Audition
description: As shed be the first to tell you, Michelle Williams, a movie star with practically no experience as a singer and dancer, was not an obvious choice to play the nightclub entertainer Sally Bowles in Cabaret. She is making her Broadway debut in the role, at Studio 54, in the Roundabout Theater Companys resuscitation of its legendary 1998 production, which brings back Alan Cumming in his Tony-winning turn as the Emcee. But she got the job only after Emma Stone (who does have a modest background in musical theater and, because of The Amazing Spider-Man, is more recognizable as well) dropped out.

title: Rain, Heavy at Times
description: The information supplied about Noah in the Book of Genesis is scant  barely enough for a Hollywood pitch meeting, much less a feature film  but his story is among the strangest and scariest in the Hebrew Bible. At its center is what appears to be an unnerving example of divine self-doubt. Disgusted with his creation, God decides to wipe the slate clean and start again, only to relent and allow Noah, a 500-something-year-old father of three, to save his family and a boatload of animals.

title: Obama Meets Pope Francis
description: President Obama and Pope Francis met for the first time on Thursday at the Vatican.

title: Michelle Obama in China
description: Solo trips to foreign countries by first ladies always draw scrutiny and sometimes controversy. Although Michelle Obama has not escaped some domestic carping for visiting China, she seems to have hit most of the right notes during a week of travel, including emphasizing the importance of human rights and free speech.

title: U.N. Approves Investigation of Civil War in Sri Lanka
description: GENEVA  Overriding fierce objections from Sri Lanka, the United Nations Human Rights Council voted on Thursday to open an international investigation into possible war crimes by both the Sri Lankan government and the Tamil Tiger rebels in the final stages of a 26-year civil war that ended in 2009.

title: Emma Donoghue: By the Book
description: The author of Frog Music was happy to hear that President Obama bought her novel Room, but admits: Im tormented by the notion that its still in a groaning pile of books by his bed.

title: 36 Hours in Jamaica
description: Sun, sand and sea: a timeless recipe, readily available throughout the Caribbean. But sun, sand, sea  and city? Visit Jamaica to indulge in that one. Sure, the resplendent island has a range of resort areas where one can merrily get ones beach-bum on. But its also got Kingston, a woefully underrated, misunderstood metropolis. Yes, there are slums and there is crime. But there is also cosmopolitan culture, pulsating night life, a booming local music scene and a host of other urban delights. With a new airline (Fly Jamaica), a 130-room Marriott under construction in the islands capital, modish-yet-playful new lounges in both international airports (Club Kingston and Club Mobay, decked out in sprightly Jamaican colors) and restaurant openings across the island, its an ideal time to take a side of city with your sand, and heed the tourism boards Bob Marley-inspired mantra, trite yet spot on: Come to Jamaica and feel all right.

title: A Taste of a Denver Art District
description: Warmly embraced by youthful art enthusiasts in Denver, the River North Art District, known as RiNO, is in a former industrial area northeast of downtown. RiNO is the still-gritty home to dozens of galleries and artists studios, but the area now has cafes, restaurants, bars, music and a profusion of craft breweries. RiNO landed on the map in 2005, when a group of local artists trademarked the name for their cooperative, and it caught on as a moniker for the neighborhood. A highlight: the first Friday of each month, dozens of galleries open late for patrons (information: rivernorthart.com).

title: David Chase Will Discuss Sopranos at Museum Screening
description: If youre a dedicated Sopranos fan who wont stop believing in the possibility of getting closure on that influential HBO drama, this may be as near as youll come to it. On April 30, the shows creator, David Chase, will make a rare public appearance at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, where he will present the only two episodes of the series that he directed: the pilot, which introduced James Gandolfini as the emotionally conflicted mob boss Tony Soprano; and the finale, Made in America, in which Tonys story came to an ambiguous ending in a New Jersey restaurant. The museumsaid in a news release that its screening of these two episodes would be followed by a conversation between Mr. Chase and David Schwartz, the museums chief curator, which, with any luck, might fill in a few further details about televisions most talked-about smash-cut to black. Tickets for the event are expected to go on sale Tuesday. For more information, go to movingimage.us.

title: History Gives Other Cases of G.M.s Behavior
description: Four decades ago, Edward Heath, then the prime minister of Britain, rose in Parliament to denounce the unpleasant and unacceptable face of capitalism.

title: Call to Artists on Crimea Echoes Soviet Ways
description: MOSCOW  Russias Ministry of Culture recently called leading artists and intellectuals to suggest that they endorse a petition hailing President Vladimir V. Putins annexation of Crimea, setting off impassioned accusations from the literati that the Kremlin was resurrecting repugnant Soviet methods.

title: Thai Satellite Detects Floating Objects
description: The executive director of the Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency, Anond Snidvongs, said that Thai satellites had detected about 300 floating objects in the southern Indian Ocean.

title: With Banking, What Happens in Europe Does Not Stay in Europe
description: Mayra Rodrguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a New York-based capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World.

title: Adviser on Dell Buyout Questions a Tumultuous Process
description: NEW ORLEANS  By the time the sale of Dell Inc. to its namesake founder was completed last October, the computer companys board felt like it had been through hell.

title: Report Details Claim by Ally: Christie Knew of Bridge Lane Closings
description: The Port Authority official who directed the shutdown of lanes to the George Washington Bridge said that he informed Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey about it at a Sept. 11 memorial ceremony while the lanes were closed, according to an internal review that lawyers for the governor released on Thursday.

title: Navin Nagiah of DNN: Intellectual Honesty Is the Best Policy
description: This interview with Navin Nagiah, chief executive of DNN, a web content software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Internal Review of Bridge Scandal
description: The report, commissioned by Gov. Chris Christies office after the George Washington Bridge scandal erupted, was made available on Thursday morning.

title: A Festive Moment When Time Pauses
description: Ceremonies, public and private, are one way that people mark the passage of time.

title: Jobs and Health Bills Make for Busy Day at Capitol
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday voted to move forward with a long-stalled proposal to extend aid to more than two million people whose unemployment assistance ran out late last year.

title: Today in Small Business: Can Bookstores Survive?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Local-Guide Requirement Considered for Nepal Peaks
description: NEW DELHI  Struggling to cope with a crush of climbers and garbage on Mount Everest, Nepal is also considering a proposal that would require every foreign climber to hire a local guide to ascend the countrys highest peaks.

title: Tate Pledges to Return Looted Constable Painting to Family
description: The Tate gallery in Britain pledged on Thursday to return a painting by John Constable to the heirs of a Jewish Hungarian art collector after a government panel concluded that the institution had failed to properly vet the ownership of the 1824 work, Beaching a Boat, Brighton.

title: The Secret History of Homoerotic Illustration
description: Before Abercrombie & Fitch catalogs and Lady Gaga videos mainstreamed homoerotic imagery, some of fashions most talented illustrators had shadow careers from the 1950s through the 1990s drawing for underground gay magazines such as Physique Pictorial and, later, more overt porn glossies such as Mandate, Honcho and Torso. The Internet, with its abundance of porn, killed those titles, but a diverse trove of illustrations from their pages will be on display beginning Friday at the Leslie Lohman Museum of Gay and Lesbian Art in SoHo, in the winkingly titled show Stroke: From Under the Mattress to the Museum Walls. Curated by Robert Richards, himself a longtime illustrator of fashion and homoerotic imagery, the show aims to exhibit quality artwork that had to be hidden away for many years, says Hunter OHanian, the museums director.

title: Intel Exits a Data Analysis Business and Invests in Another One
description: For a company getting out of the data analysis business, Intel is spending a lot of money on a data analysis business.

title: Wu-Tang Clan Plans to Sell Just One Copy of a New Album
description: As any record collector can tell you, rarities  particularly one-of-a-kind pieces like Elvis Presleys 1954 acetate pressing of Thats Alright Mama, or the single-copy 1958 disc containing Thatll Be the Day and In Spite of All the Danger by the Quarrymen, who became the Beatles  are holy grails, discs that could command fortunes. But those discs acquired their value long after they were made, once the musicians who recorded them became hot properties, with history giving them a special patina.

title: Vote by U.N. General Assembly Isolates Russia
description: UNITED NATIONS  In the first barometer of global condemnation of Russias annexation of Crimea, Ukraine and its Western backers persuaded a large majority of countries in the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday to dismiss the annexation as illegal, even as Russia sought to rally world support for the idea of self-determination.

title: Washington Slope Had a History of Slides
description: Aerial photography of the area destroyed by Saturdays landslide shows how the land has eroded over the years.

title: Image of the Day: March 27
New Mexico Is Reaping a Bounty in Pecans as Other States Struggle
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M.  On the edge of this parched southern New Mexico city, Phillip Arnold surveyed his rows of neatly pruned pecan trees with a satisfied smile.

title: Walk-On Earns His Spot With Virginia
description: At four days old, Jeff Jones had brain surgery to relieve a blood clot. While he was in high school, complications from an appendectomy led to multiple follow-up operations and lengthy hospitalizations.

title: Getting Poetry to the People in Miami
description: If you live in Miami and you do not read, recite or listen to a poem in April, something has gone seriously wrong. For the third year, the O, Miami Poetry Festival will flood the city with words, using any pretext to accomplish its mission of putting all 2.6 million residents of Miami-Dade County in contact with at least one poem.

title: Congress Approves Aid of $1 Billion for Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  The House and the Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to approve a $1 billion aid package for Ukraine, but Congresss near unanimity on its modest package of aid and sanctions on Russia masked deep divisions on what the government should do next to confront President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: TPG Said to Be in Talks to Invest in Chobani
description: The private equity giant TPG is in advanced talks to invest in Chobani, the fast-growing yogurt maker in upstate New York, two people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Wheelies: The Empire State Mustang Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Seeking to Ban Online Betting, G.O.P. Donor Tests Influence
description: A push by the billionaire casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson to outlaw online gambling has ignited a bitter civil war in the gambling industry, dividing one of Washingtons most powerful interest groups and posing a major test of the Republican donors political clout.

title: Most Chinese Cities Fail Minimum Air Quality Standards, Study Says
description: BEIJING  Only three of the 74 Chinese cities monitored by the central government managed to meet official minimum standards for air quality last year, the Ministry of Environmental Protection announced this week, underscoring the countrys severe pollution problems.

title: Its All About the Amor
description: March suddenly turned into Latin pop blockbuster season. By some coincidence, arena-filling stars who tend to take years between releases emerged almost simultaneously with new albums: Shakira and Juanes, who are both from Colombia, Enrique Iglesias from Spain and the reggaeton rapper Wisin from Puerto Rico. Romeo Santos, the Dominican bachata singer who was born in the Bronx and was Aventuras lead singer for 17 years, beat the rush by releasing his second solo studio album in February.

title: Times Minute | The Papal Visit
description: On the Minute, The Timess White House Photographer Doug Mills reports on the first meeting of President Obama and Pope Francis in Vatican.

title: Times Minute | The Papal Visit
description: In the Video

title: Indonesians in Queens Are Beginning to Learn About Film on Genocide
description: Every Friday afternoon, Mas Pratomo, 83, sips tea at Fay Da Bakery on Justice Avenue, in Elmhurst, Queens, and catches up with fellow Indonesians. He never forgets to list the days attendees in his journal.

title: I.M.F. Announces Bailout for Ukraine
description: The International Monetary Fund announced an agreement to provide up to $18 billion in assistance over two years to Ukraine.

title: CitizenM Hotel to Open in New York
description: CitizenM, the five-unit Amsterdam-based chain of stylish and affordable hotels, will make its debut in the United States when its Times Square outpost opens this week in New York.

title: Seamy Side of a Sport: Prodding Horses With Shocks
description: It is called a buzzer, a battery or a machine: It is a device the size of a lighter that conducts electrical current and shocks a racehorse into running faster. It is prohibited at American racetracks but has long been a part of the sports seamier lore.

title: Loggers Join in Search for Washington Landslide Victims
description: DARRINGTON, Wash.  Two days after a giant landslide engulfed the small community of Oso and rescue workers struggled to find either survivors or victims amid the sea of muck, a group of volunteers  many of them loggers  drove along back roads and trails on Monday to reach the site. They immediately began to dig, looking for their neighbors and, in some cases, friends and relatives.

title: The Bird, and Everything That Comes With It
description: The first time I ordered cockscomb  that fleshy crest on a roosters head whose red flush telegraphs virility  it arrived on my plate at Mountain Bird looking like a tiny deep-fried valentine, with two plump lobes where I had expected a spiky stegosauran frill.

title: New York Citys Jobless Rate Rises for First Time in Nearly 2 Years
description: New York Citys unemployment rate rose slightly in February to 7.9 percent, the first monthly increase in nearly two years, according to figures released Thursday by the State Labor Department.

title: Soccer Tourism: World Comes Out for Clsico
description: MADRID  Hours before Sundays Clsico, the match between Real Madrid and Barcelona, Juan Manuel Alfaro strode into the business lounge of a hotel near Santiago Bernabu Stadium.

title: Too Much Faith In Models, Capital Taxation Edition
description: Yesterday I offered a rousing defense of the use of simplified models in economics. So maybe its appropriate that today I offer a caution: you should use models, but you should always remember that theyre models, and always beware of conclusions that depend too much on the simplifying assumptions. And I have a case in point, which ties into one of my other big concerns: the appropriate taxation of capital income.

title: James R. Schlesinger, Willful Aide to Three Presidents, Is Dead at 85
description: James R. Schlesinger, a tough Cold War strategist who served as secretary of defense under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford and became the nations first secretary of energy under President Jimmy Carter, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 85.

title: A Nasty Corporate Divorce, With Insults Traded on Twitter
description: Like divorces by couples, corporate separations are rarely pretty.

title: Obamacare Fails to Fail
description: Update: And exchange-based enrollments pass 6 million. Gaba now projects 6.5 million by 3/31, and with the extensions it will go higher. The original CBO projection of 7 million now looks basically right, despite the website woes.

title: Its Crow-Killing Time in Upstate New York, and Elsewhere
description: Its crow-killing time in upstate New York this weekend, and in many places around the country this spring. My friend Suzie Gilbert, a bird rehabilitator and writer (read Flyaway), has written a blog post criticizing this form of recreation. [Update, March 28 | Shes added a followup piece that has valuable new elements.]

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: bone-building exercises, smoking rates and norovirus. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: As Rescues Push On, Video of Landslide Survivors
description: A 78-year-old man who survived the landslide in Washington described how he called out to his wife, Linda, when they were both buried in the mud and debris, encouraging her to dig. But she never replied to his entreaties.

title: Doctor Priorities vs. Patient Priorities
description: Not so long ago, a middle-aged patient came to my office for a checkup. He cheerfully admitted that he hadnt been paying attention to his diabetes for the last few years. Hed stopped taking his medicine, stopped seeing his doctors, stopped thinking about the disease altogether. When I checked his blood sugar in the office, it wasnt just a little elevated  it was four times the normal level.

title: A Shoe-In for Spring
description: Couture sneakers, monster platforms, luxury locker-room slides: its all too much sometimes. The right everyday shoe  not too basic, not too crazy  is hard to find in todays overheated footwear market, but the spring offerings from the 23-year-old designer Dora Teymur of Dorateymur stand out for their sculptural quality and ease of wear. The Turkish-born, London-based designer, a recent graduate of Cordwainers at London College of Fashion, calls them slightly nostalgic shoes that dont tire your eyes. He claims not to be influenced by his heritage: I suppose the only Orientalist element in my work, he says dryly, is myself. And he makes sure to emphasize comfort in his designs for women  especially, he notes, now that Ive started to wear them.

title: All Nippon Airways Splits $16.6 Billion Aircraft Order
description: Boeing and Airbus each won something to brag about in their latest face-off, as All Nippon Airways of Japan said on Thursday that it would split a $16.6 billion order between the two plane makers.

title: Letters: Ozick on Malamud
description: Ozick on Malamud

title: Our Fifth Annual New York Times Found Poetry Student Contest
description: Update: June 3 | Winners have been announced!

title: James Bond Cars Take Up Residence at London Film Museum
description: Beginning last week, the London Film Museum began displaying a number of the cars and other machines featured in James Bond films over the last 50 years. Called Bond in Motion, the exhibition had been housed last year in Britains National Motor Museum, but now the collection of movie cars, props and memorabilia will be displayed in London.

title: Conscious Uncoupling for Drug Makers
description: Baxter International has put conscious uncoupling on pharmas radar.

title: Falcone Accused of Using Company Assets in Cash Crunch
description: An investor has accused the hedge fund billionaire Philip A. Falcone of using his publicly listed company to bail himself out after a reaching an $18 million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: American Couple on Qatar Sentencing
description: Matthew Huang, an American sentenced to jail in a case involving his adopted daughters death, and his adviser, Eric Volz, spoke after the courts decision in Doha.

title: U.N. Calls Annexation of Crimea Illegal
description: Ukraines foreign minister, Andriy Deshchytsia, decried Russias actions, as Thomas Mayr-Harting, the E.U. ambassador to the U.N., and Samantha Power, the American ambassador, supported the U.N. vote.

title: Updates on Washington Landslide
description: Washington State authorities spoke about the current number of deaths and said that crews were still working to recover bodies after a deadly landslide in Oso.

title: An Exaltation of Birds and He Who Adored Them
description: Ive never met an animal I didnt like. And birds? Bring them on, which is what the New-York Historical Society is doing with a whoosh of wings and cries in Audubons Aviary: Parts Unknown (Part II of the Complete Flock), the second of three sequential exhibitions of the museums complete set of more than 400 paintings by John James Audubon, all models for his grand book The Birds of America. It is widely regarded as the most ambitious example of color engraving with aquatint ever made.

title: Report Says Mother Warned Queens School to Watch Autistic Boy
description: The mother of a teenager with autism who disappeared from his school in Queens last fall and whose remains were found in January had warned a teacher that he needed to be watched at all times because he likes to run and would leave the building.

title: Project to Improve Poor Childrens Intellect Led to Better Health, Data Show
description: In 1972, researchers in North Carolina started following two groups of babies from poor families. In the first group, the children were given full-time day care up to age 5 that included most of their daily meals, talking, games and other stimulating activities. The other group, aside from baby formula, got nothing. The scientists were testing whether the special treatment would lead to better cognitive abilities in the long run.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: The Raid 2
description: Gareth Evans narrates a sequence from his film.

title: White House Says Health Care Rolls Top Goal: 6 Million
description: WASHINGTON  The White House said on Thursday that more than six million people had signed up for medical insurance plans under President Obamas health care law, exceeding the administrations revised goal for enrollment by the Monday deadline.

title: The Gun Report: March 27, 2014
description: The Supreme Court, which frequently splits 5-to-4, issued a unanimous ruling yesterday regarding guns and domestic abuse: People convicted of misdemeanor domestic violence offenses, however minor, are barred under federal law from possessing a gun.

title: The Avoiding Tough Financing Decisions Act of 2014
description: In a strong show of timidity, using a voice vote that cloaked the identity of those voting for and against, the House of Representatives passed a bill today that would stave off for another year a drastic reduction in Medicare payments to doctors. The bill now goes to the Senate. It must take action before April 1, or a 24-percent cut in payments will take effect and greatly diminish the willingness of doctors to treat Medicare patients.

title: At Upfronts, E! Network Again Promises Its First Scripted Series
description: If the E! cable channel were to be graded on keeping its promises to introduce original scripted programming, the verdict would have to be F. Or, to be charitable, I for incomplete, as discussions of adding such series to the channels lineup of reality and talk shows date to its 2012-13 upfront presentation.

title: Where Are the Sony Open Cameras? Mostly Trained on the Men
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  At the sun-soaked Sony Open held on this island east of Miami, the women have not been able to shine quite as brightly as the men  at least to those watching on television.

title: Ex-Finance Director of Dewey & LeBoeuf Says Its Chairman Feared Audit
description: Francis J. Canellas, the former finance director of the bankrupt law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, who pleaded guilty this year to taking part in a scheme to manipulate the firms financial statements, told New York prosecutors that the firms former chairman, Steven Davis, had been nervous before meeting with an auditor to discuss the firms 2010 finances.

title: Anti-Anxiety Drugs Tied to Higher Mortality
description: A large study has linked several common anti-anxiety drugs and sleeping pills to an increased risk of death, although its not certain the drugs were the cause.

title: Investigation Report on Avonte Oquendo
description: A report by the special commissioner of investigation for New York Citys school system showed a series of errors and oversights on how a 14-year-old boy with autism could leave his school undetected.

title: Yoga Classes, Even With a Fused Spine
description: I WENT to yoga classes fairly often before I had a spinal fusion at 17. The poses helped with flexibility and relaxation, even if they didnt have a straightening effect on my S-shaped scoliosis. But yoga didnt have the same charm after surgery: The long rods and screws in my back kept me from curling like a cat or bending into a cobra pose.

title: The Colorful Man Behind the Carved Eagles
description: The 19th-century New England woodcarver John Haley Bellamy, best known for creating aggressive eagles out of pine blocks, has always been subject to conflicting tales. He has been depicted alternately as a disciplined laborer and a helpless drunkard, a manic inventor and an aloof poet, an irresponsible pleasure-seeker and a devoted kinsman, the historian James A. Craig writes in a new book, American Eagle: The Bold Art & Brash Life of John Haley Bellamy (Portsmouth Marine Society Press).

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of The Raid 2
description: In this video, the director Gareth Evans discusses his ideas behind a scene from The Raid 2, a sequel to his 2012 action thriller. This sequence involves a seasoned hitman (Yayan Ruhian) who is ambushed in a nightclub.

title: A Tune as Parisian as Tin Pan Alley
description: YEARNING for the charm of spring? For a warm embrace? Do you hear the sirens singing April in Paris, that old romantic chestnut in blossom?

title: Appeals Court in Gupta Case Chooses Not to Admonish Bad Behavior
description: It was never going to be easy for Rajat K. Gupta, the former managing director of McKinsey & Company and board member of Goldman Sachs, to overturn his criminal conviction for insider trading. But the opinion of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was muted, suggesting that the judges did not seem to want to use the case to make a statement about the conduct they expect from businesspeople.

title: Rules of Style | Ins de la Fressange on Dressing for Yourself and Why Bad Fashion Is a Good Thing
description: While many might consider Ins de la Fressange a style icon, she insists, Im like every woman on earth when I wake up in the morning. I have the feeling that I dont have the right things and I dont know what to wear. And I feel terrible in everything I try! Still, the French model, author and onetime muse to Karl Lagerfeld emerges most days with an effortless chic-meets-street look, which is one reason she is so uniquely suited for such varied roles as the brand ambassador for the French accessories house Roger Vivier and a collaborator with the Japanese fast-fashion brand Uniqlo (her collection of charming prints and easy knits arrived in stores last week).

title: Contemplating Other Peoples Pain
description: Leslie Jamison has a balky heart. The medical name for her condition is SVT, or supraventricular tachycardia. There was an extra electrical node, her doctor explains, sending out extra signals  beat, beat, beat  when it wasnt supposed to. She calls this her tiny rogue beat box.

title: NBC News Hires Away Cynthia McFadden From Nightline
description: NBC News on Thursday plucked a long-serving anchor from ABC News, hiring Cynthia McFadden to be the networks senior legal and investigative correspondent. She will leave ABCs Nightline, where she has been an anchor for nine years.

title: Soaking Up Ukrainian Culture in the East Village
description: As the news from Ukraine has gone from bad to worse, the Miser has had to scramble, not just to keep up with breaking events, but also to familiarize himself with the broader historical and cultural forces at play.

title: Molly Lowe: Sorry, Excuse Me, Thank You
description: The Suzanne Geiss Company

title: Brian ODoherty: Connecting the...
description: P!

title: William Beckman
description: Forum

title: For Marian
description: FiveMyles

title: Norbert Prangenberg: The Last Works
description: Garth Greenan Gallery

title: Mika Tajima: Negative Entropy
description: Eleven Rivington

title: Despite Loss, SFX Draws Corporations as Sponsors
description: Fans of electronic dance music, get ready for a lot more corporate sponsorship.

title: Grinding Beans Long Before the Baristas Came
description: PETER LONGO was sitting in his office making a long story short, or at least he kept promising to. I figured that his sense of time was different from mine because his office, on the ground floor of 201 Bleecker Street, which houses his store, Porto Rico Importing Company, is downstairs from where he was born 62 years ago. I think if you grow up in the building where you were born and work there your whole life, you develop a sense of place the rest of us dont have. You never have to hurry. Youre already home.

title: S.E.C. Official Criticizes Proxy Proposals on Social Issues
description: NEW ORLEANS  Much of the Tulane Corporate Law Institute this year has focused on outspoken hedge fund managers like Carl C. Icahn and Daniel S. Loeb. But one of the Securities and Exchange Commissions top officials took aim at a different sort of shareholder activism.

title: Air Force Fires 9 Officers in Scandal Over Cheating on Proficiency Tests
description: WASHINGTON  The Air Force said Thursday that it had fired nine officers and accepted the resignation of the commander at Malmstrom Air Force Base in Montana as it continued to deal with a widespread cheating scandal among the men and women entrusted with the launching of intercontinental ballistic missiles.

title: Government Data Requests Fall at Yahoo But Rise at Google
description: Yahoo saw a significant drop in the number of government requests for data about its users in the second half of 2013, compared with the first half, according to the semiannual transparency report that the Internet company published on Thursday.

title: Social Analysis From the Edge
description: A species of contemporary art embraced particularly by the young and intellectually ambitious combines avant-garde style and social science. Those who do this sort of thing operate like sociologists or anthropologists, investigating and documenting certain real-world human situations. But rather than present their discoveries in clear, straightforward terms, theyll typically interpret their findings obliquely, often by means of multiple mediums including video, sculptural assemblage and architectural construction.

title: Works From Scotland Set to Tour America
description: Four years ago, the National Galleries of Scotland sent their prized Titian with other paintings from their collection on a tour that started at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. The exhibition was a way to raise the National Galleries profile in the United States and, for the High, to allow its audience to see rare works from abroad without having to travel overseas.

title: Players Reach Biggest Stage in Their Second Act
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  In 1992, Steve Fisher started five freshmen on his Michigan team, which advanced to the N.C.A.A. tournament championship game. Twenty-two years later, Fisher is running what amounts to a deprogramming center at San Diego State for players who grew up dreaming of instant college stardom.

title: An Assertive Pasta With Nebbiolos
description: With their gentle tannins and earthiness, the delicious nebbiolos we tasted could handle a wide array of dishes. Pasta is a fine choice; I selected an assertive, wheaty variety to combine with sausage. Some of the wines delivered hints of mushroom, so those went into the dish, as did carrots to pick up sweetness.

title: In India, a New Wellness Resort
description: Ayurvedic treatments are staple options on the menus of resort and destination spas.

title: Finding Neverland to Have U.S. Premiere at American Repertory Theater
description: The new musical Finding Neverland will have its United States premiere in July at the American Repertory Theater, kicking off a 2014-15 season there that will also include a new play by Eve Ensler (The Vagina Monologues) and a theatrical work starring Mandy Patinkin and Taylor Mac, the theater announced Thursday.

title: House Payments a Priority Again
description: The recession turned the typical consumer debt hierarchy upside down: Faced with unemployment and plummeting home values, consumers began paying down their credit cards ahead of their mortgages.

title: Why a Symbolic Democratic Agenda Is Better Than None
description: A surprising number of Senate Republicans  10 out of 45!  supported an extension of unemployment benefits in a procedural vote this afternoon. Many of them live in states with large numbers of jobless people, and would have a hard time explaining their opposition to a bill that provides five months of extra aid.

title: Turkey Blocks YouTube as Audio of High-Level Meeting on Syria Leaks
description: Updated, 5:55 p.m. | The Turkish government blocked access to YouTube on Thursday, after an audio recording was uploaded to the platform in which the foreign minister and senior military and intelligence officials could be heard discussing the security situation in Syria.

title: Cynthia Rowleys Spring Break in the Other Magical Kingdom
description: Few schoolchildren have gotten to experience as big an adventure on their March vacation as the one the fashion designer Cynthia Rowley took her daughters on earlier this month. Gigi, 9, and Kit, 14, who have already visited 35 countries and three of the seven wonders of the world, just returned with their mom and dad, the gallery owner and writer Bill Powers, from a 10-day trip to the Kingdom of Bhutan. Rowley says the journey was inspired by a life-changing trip she took to Tibet many years ago, and the familiar itch to find that place again that was untouched and unspoiled and where the cultures preserved.

title: Playing College Football Is a Job
description: Before college is even in session, Northwestern football players spend up to 60 hours a week practicing at a one-month training camp. During the three- or four-month football season, they put in up to 50 hours a week preparing for games. Thats more time than many full-time employees devote to their jobs.

title: A Painter, Well Aware, Takes Twists and Turns
description: Maria Lassnigs show at MoMA PS1 begins with a standoff. In a large self-portrait from 2005, the artist brandishes two guns: one is pointed at her own head, the other at the viewer. The title of this anxiety-inducing work is You, or Me?

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 77
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Broken, Not Bound, by an Intimate Tie (Updated With Podcast)
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by America Ferrera, followed by a conversation with the writer, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below.

title: Traipsing the Terroir of Nebbiolo
description: Few places offer so intriguing a concentration of wonderful, indigenous red-wine grapes as the Piedmont region of northwestern Italy. Yet, nobody would dispute the primacy of nebbiolo, the great grape of Barolo and Barbaresco.

title: Making Much Ado About a Fab 4
description: NEW HAVEN  All the mod markers have been spruced up and put in place in the freely swinging Shakespeare-inspired romp These Paper Bullets! at Yale Repertory Theater here. Cheekily described as a modish ripoff of Much Ado About Nothing, the production evokes with tangy authority the sights, sounds and styles of London rumbling through the youthquake years. The Vidal Sassoon bobs are spot on; the bowl cuts for the boys raise a smile; A-line miniskirts expose milky thighs above go-go boots snugly hugging calves.

title: G.M. Sent Letter but Didnt Issue Recall for Faulty Air Bags
description: The 2005 Chevrolet Cobalt is already involved in a high-profile recall that has become a major embarrassment for General Motors. The recall, which G.M. delayed for years, involves a faulty ignition switch that has been blamed for at least a dozen deaths.

title: English King, Pacific Profile
description: If you believe, as I do, that the core of Shakespeares greatness is his language, then any production of one of his plays in translation begins with a serious handicap.

title: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Spain, Taiwan, Crimea and Italy.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Hello from The Timess newsroom.

title: Amid Chants of Huelga!, an Embodiment of Hope
description: Cesar Chavez, directed by Diego Luna, is a well-cast, well-intentioned movie that falls into the trap that often awaits film biographies of brave and widely admired individuals. The movie is so intent on reminding viewers of its subjects heroism that it struggles to make him an interesting, three-dimensional person, and it tells his story as a series of dramatic bullet points, punctuated by black-and-white footage, some real, some simulated, of historical events.

title: Duck Dynasty Ends Season With a Sharp Decline in Viewership
description: The duck flock is thinning: The latest season of the A&E hit reality series Duck Dynasty showed a sharp falloff in ratings, with the finale Wednesday night coming in at six million viewers, down from 8.4 million for the finale in the fall cycle of the show, and 9.6 million for the finale for the most-watched edition a year ago.

title: Taxi Dancers to Gaga: Roselands Life and Death
description: For decades, patrons of Roseland Ballroom have walked in past the Wall of Fame, which holds the shoes of famous dancers  Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, Betty Grable, James Cagney  and a plaque with names of couples who met dancing at Roseland and went on to marry. They are relics from the many incarnations of Roseland, a name that has been part of New York City night life since 1919. Roseland, which moved to its current location in 1956 with a vaunted deluxe dance floor  maple over cork padding  is to close on April 7 at the end of a string of shows by Lady Gaga, which begin on Friday.

title: Comedy Listings for March 28-April 3
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for March 28-April 3
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for March 28-April 3
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for March 28-April 3
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Chinas Criticism Over Handling of Missing Flight Stirs Malaysian Backlash
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Chinese governments unrelenting criticism of Malaysias handling of the disappearance of Flight 370 and an angry protest outside the Malaysian Embassy in Beijing this week have produced a nationalistic backlash here.

title: Jazz Listings for March 28-April 3
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Nanny as Sphinx, Weaving Enigmatic Magic on the Sly
description: An exciting electric current of discovery runs through Finding Vivian Maier, a documentary about a street photographer who never exhibited her work. She scarcely shared it even with those who knew her. Then again, many of her acquaintances when she was taking some of her remarkable images, particularly in and around Chicago in the 1950s and 60s, were the children she cared for while working as a nanny. Later in her life, some of those children took care of her in turn, first by moving her into an apartment and then the nursing home where she died in 2009. What rotten timing: She was on the verge of being discovered, first as a curiosity and then as a social-media sensation and a mystery.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for March 28-April 3
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for March 28-April 3
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for March 28-April 3
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Tortured Soul, Golden Touch
description: Note the savvy come-hither title of The Passions of Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux, the Metropolitan Museum of Arts latest, unusually swashbuckling foray into 19th-century French art. What better way to attract attention to a sculptor prominent in his own time but not widely known in ours than to promise not just one but multiple passions? And what better way to make this artist memorable than to deliver on almost every front?

title: Spare Times for Children for March 28-April 3
description: PEACE, LOVE AND CUPCAKES: THE MUSICAL

title: Seas of Anger and Innocence
description: In the classical music sphere, as in many genres, a nostalgia-fueled golden age is sometimes referenced  an era of superlative artists whose gifts are implied to overshadow those of the present generation. But whatever the undoubted glories of the past, the remarkable pianists who perform regularly in New York prove that the golden age is the one we live in.

title: Spare Times for March 28-April 3
description: THE ORCHID SHOW: KEY WEST CONTEMPORARY (through April 21) A modernist garden from Key West, Fla., was the inspiration for this years show  which features floral displays and the verses of writers who spent time there  at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx River Parkway (Exit 7W) and Fordham Road, the Bronx.

title: Russian Businessmans Death Remains Mystery, Coroner Says
description: LONDON  A British coroner said Thursday that he could not establish whether the mysterious death of Boris A. Berezovsky, a businessman and power broker from Russia, was suicide or homicide.

title: A Boyhood Summer of Darkness
description: Daniel Patrick Carbones haunting debut feature, Hide Your Smiling Faces, evokes a semi-rural 1950s America in which packs of neighborhood boys pass the time riding bikes, exploring the woods and engaging in ritualistic roughhouse games. The mood of the film, shot in areas of Sussex County, N.J., suggests a darker reflection of the same vision of boyhood adventure depicted in Terrence Malicks The Tree of Life. Although the time feels like the 1950s, the appearance of a portable DVD player signals that it is set more or less in the present.

title: Carnage and Chaos, Heavy on the Gore
description: Lovers of camp and cannabis are the most plausible audience for Sabotage, given the giggle-to-bullet ratio in this extravagantly silly movie about a gang of marauding Drug Enforcement Administration undercover thugs. Scholars of Arnold Schwarzenegger, its big-ticket attraction, may also want to check in, just to see what the governator has been up to in his postpolitical golden years. Let me spare you the change and the suspense: He can still bench-press serious weight, as a narratively superfluous visit to a gym makes clear, and hes still not an actor, as is evident by the confusingly indistinguishable grimaces, smiles and vacant looks that hes put into rotation here.

title: Christies Lawyer on Bridge Report
description: Randy M. Mastro, the lawyer hired by Gov. Chris Christie to lead an internal investigation into the closing of George Washington Bridge access lanes in Fort Lee, N.J., defended the findings.

title: Temptation in Suburbia, Amid a Midlife Crisis
description: The warning notes in the tense marital drama Breathe In are sounded during a casual conversation at a suburban outdoor gathering whose hostess breezily remarks that she has been to six divorce parties in the past few months.

title: Recordings, Posted Online, Rattle Officials in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  If any meeting was meant to be private, it was this one: the top spy chief, the foreign minister and his deputy, and a top military official discussing secret plans for possible military action in Syria.

title: Guns and Alcohol
description: To the Editor:

title: Visas for Afghan Allies
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Womens Book Clubs
description: To the Editor:

title: Suicide in Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving a Dying Woman a Brief Moment of Joy
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring the Unnamed Dead of AIDS on Hart Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Limiting Ivory, Saving Elephants
Beekeeping and the Neighbors
description: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: A Rock Star and a Roadie, Brothers After All
description: A tale of two brothers, one band and a boatload of psychological baggage, Mistaken for Strangers is, like its maker, scruffy, undisciplined and eager to be loved. The big surprise is how easy it is to comply.

title: He Died Laughing (Isnt That Sweet?)
description: Blumenthal, a chilly Jewish comedy that wraps old jokes in a distinctively young voice, has a brisk cleverness that can cause you to overlook its more unpalatable characteristics. Before those take hold, though, there is much to enjoy in this prickly observation of the familial fallout when Harold Blumenthal (Brian Cox), a bloviating playwright, dies while relishing one of his own jokes.

title: I.P.O. to Cut Ill-Fitting Ad Business From CBS
description: When CBS Outdoor begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, it will represent not only the dawn of a new publicly traded advertising company in a hot market for initial public offerings, but also the latest step in the evolution of its parent company, CBS.

title: Its No Substitute for the Sun
description: CLEVELAND  MY psychiatrist is a fan of happy lamps, lamps that use full-spectrum bulbs to treat wintertime seasonal depression. A really big fan. Opening his office door is like entering a scene inPoltergeist: Im blinded by a powerful glow that emanates from every direction. I must rely on his voice in the distance calling out to me in order to orient myself. This is how our appointments begin: I go toward the light.

title: Remembering How to Fight Measles
description: THE measles vaccine is a victim of its own success.

title: Facing Eviction, He Cant Resist a Dare
description: The actors play Cheap Thrills straight, but you should watch it as a twisted comedy. Those who do will be rewarded, especially by the films outlandish final image.

title: Exploring a New World Every Day
description: A Manhattan exhibit celebrates Chang Lees 20 years as a New York Times photographer, a career that has taken him around the world and back in time.

title: When a Hot Shower Was a Frill
description: Cold-weather blahs? Its not exactly the Caribbean, but the sun-drenched pool at the sparkling, newly renovated Gertrude Ederle Recreation Center at 232 West 60th Street is a sight for winter-weary eyes. Built in 1906 in the Georgian style, the center originally washed the great unwashed.

title: Is This Listing Real, or Just a Ghost?
description: In an era when drop-down menus and mouse clicks are critical tools for a house hunt, one scenario in particular has become all too familiar to some buyers.

title: Nonstop Carnage, Indonesian-Style
description: When a prison yard becomes a sloppy battlefield in The Raid 2, the mud-covered combatants turn gray, reduced to their essence: bodies smashing together in the muck. The pleasant surprise of Gareth Evanss sturdy sequel to The Raid: Redemption is that neither its undercover drama nor its two-and-a-half-hour length bog down the bracing, and numerous, fight fests.

title: Ten Key Questions on Health Care Enrollment
description: Answers to some key questions about health care enrollment.

title: A Tax Notion That Conceals a Math Problem
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Shes Not Heavy, Shes My Bar Pickup
description: Refuge, like a lot of movies these days about young people searching for meaningful relationships, is the old Disney fantasy reimagined for the hookup age. That leaves it feeling just as unsatisfying and unrealistic as a happily-ever-after story about a damsel and a prince she has barely met.

title: Humans First Appearance in the Americas
description: In Piau, Brazil, archaeologists say stone tools prove that humans reached what is now Brazil as early as 22,000 years ago, upending a belief that people first arrived about 13,000 years ago.

title: This Weeks Movies: March 28, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics on Noah, Finding Vivian Maier and Cesar Chavez.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Settlement in Medicaid Fraud Case Worries Health Providers
description: A major legal settlement with a childrens health provider in hand, a Texas agency investigating health care fraud says its ramped-up efforts to rein in faulty Medicaid charges have started to pay off.

title: Gang Wars, Iraq Warfare
description: A 14-year-old Latino boy falls in love with an African-American girl, and the neighborhood Latino gang does not approve, in Greencard Warriors. The girl is played by Paige Hurd, and Vivica A. Fox does a star turn as her mother. The boy, Angel (Angel Amaral), is vulnerable because his protective older brother, Beto (Mario Ardila Jr.), has just been sent to Iraq.

title: The Certainty of Donald Rumsfeld (Part 3)
description: Read Part 1; Part 2; Part 4.

title: A Loopy Stalker, Protesting Her Innocence
description: Unfolding from the viewpoint of Jennifer (Emily Fradenburgh), a batty erotomaniac, Xackery Irvings Nothing Without You might have had a fighting chance as a skewed study of a sick psyche. But by embedding Jennifers mental issues in a murder mystery of unmitigated tedium, this low-budget drama essentially cuts its own throat.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Dreamy Postcards From Limbo
description: Several years in the making and seemingly unfolding some hundred years in the past, Aaron Schimbergs black-and-white pastiche, Go Down Death, is a curious foray into lo-fi anachronism. Shot on 16-millimeter film, this staccato ensemble of vignettes shuffles among the fatalistic inhabitants of a run-down hamlet who have little to cling to but crackerjack philosophizing.

title: When Egyptian Just Meant Egyptian
description: Amir Ramses, the 34-year-old director of Jews of Egypt, says in publicity notes for his documentary that the contradiction between modern intolerant Egypt and cosmopolitan Egypt in the first half of the 20th century led him to focus on the period from 1949 to 1956, when many Egyptian Jews left or were forced out of the country. The film consists of archival footage and interviews, primarily with people who remember those turbulent years.

title: Potential Crackdown on Russia Risks Also Punishing Western Oil Companies
description: As the United States seeks to strengthen sanctions on Moscow for its occupation of Crimea, energy experts say the powerful Russian oil industry would make a robust target. But any penalties on energy investments, technology transfers and financial transactions would most likely also punish Western oil companies like Exxon Mobil that are investing heavily in Russia.

title: Candidates Views on Drilling Begin With Glance Back
description: Greg Abbott and Wendy Davis have sparred over education. The issues of officeholder ethics and equal pay have also surfaced.

title: Disabled Borrowers Trade Loan Debt for a Tax Bill From the I.R.S.
description: Six months after his wife learned that she had a rare vascular disease of the brain, Frank, now 66, lost his job as director of sales of a telecommunications company. His wife, to whom he had been married for 36 years, died just two months later.

title: Microsoft Unveils Office App for iPad
description: Microsofts chief executive, Satya Nadella, and the general manager of Microsoft Office, Julia White, announced the new Office app for iPad, part of an effort to expand to other devices.

title: Iraq: Bombs Kill at Least 33 in Baghdad
description: A series of bombings in Baghdad killed at least 33 people and wounded dozens more on Thursday, Iraqi officials said. At least three of the bombs struck Adhamiya, a largely Sunni neighborhood in northern Baghdad, and killed 22 people, the police said. Other blasts in western Baghdad killed 11 people, officials said. Ghazwan Naji, a resident of the western Baghdad neighborhood of Amiriya, said his 7-year-old son had heard so many explosions that he could distinguish the different kinds of bombs. Weve become experts in this, in death, Mr. Naji said.

title: Alstom of France Cooperating in U.S. Bribery Inquiry
description: PARIS  Alstom, a French industrial conglomerate, acknowledged on Thursday that it was cooperating with the United States Justice Department. Its stock fell nearly 5 percent in Paris trading after a news report that it was facing a large fine in a bribery investigation.

title: Jury Has Case in 08 Killing of Manhattan Therapist
description: There does not seem to be any doubt that David Tarloff is a schizophrenic who sometimes believes he can communicate with God. And no one involved at his murder trial contests that he bludgeoned and stabbed a psychologist to death during a botched robbery six years ago on the Upper East Side.

title: Human Rights Panel Criticizes U.S.
description: A United Nations human rights panel has called for more oversight and transparency in the program of targeted drone strikes carried out by the United States and recommended the prosecution of all those involved in unlawful killings and torture overseas, particularly persons in command positions. In a report released Thursday, the United Nations Human Rights Committee, a panel of 18 independent experts from different countries, expressed concern that the United States government had not clarified the criteria or legal basis for drone strikes and called for independent oversight of the program. It also drew attention to the limited number of investigations into unlawful killings and the use of torture in overseas operations by the American military and private contractors. It said the responsibility of those who provided legal pretexts for manifestly illegal behavior should also be established and urged the government to declassify and release the Senate Intelligence Committees investigation into the Central Intelligence Agencys secret rendition activities.

title: At Big on Mars, Trying to Get a Handle on Tomorrows Tech
description: A LEADING digital agency is starting a unit devoted to mobile technology in another example of efforts on Madison Avenue to keep up with the fast-changing landscape embodied by the term the Internet of Things, shorthand for a world of connected devices, sensors and applications.

title: Smartphones, the Disappointing Miracle
description: Smartphone users are frustrated and deprived by bad service, including slow application load times and frequent service crashes.

title: U.S. Investigates Brothers From Ecuador With Ties to Campaigns
description: MIAMI  Two fugitive brothers from Ecuador, whose relatives have contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to American political campaigns, are being investigated by the Department of Homeland Security to determine whether any of the millions the men were accused of pilfering in their home country made it to the United States, according to a federal law enforcement official familiar with the case.

title: Silence Is Deafening in Bridge Report
description: The original plans for the George Washington Bridge called for its two mighty towers, each 60 stories high, to be clad with granite facing, but that was deferred to save money. To this day, the steelwork is as bare as when the towers rose above the Hudson in the late 1920s.

title: Pakistani Gets Death Penalty for Blasphemy
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A court here found a Christian sanitation worker guilty of blasphemy on Thursday and sentenced him to death, in a case that set off rioting and the torching of a Christian neighborhood last year.

title: A New Facebook Lab Is Intent on Delivering Internet Access by Drone
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Watch out, Google. Facebook is gunning for the title of Worlds Coolest Place to Work. And its arsenal includes unmanned drones, lasers, satellites and virtual reality headsets.

title: Conviction of Bin Ladens Son-in-Law Doesnt Halt Debate Over Terror Trials Venue
description: About four years ago, the Obama administration rescinded its plans to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks in federal court in Manhattan, and left the men in military custody.

title: A Triple for Baseball Fans
description: Major league baseball, with its focus on statistics, a barrage of regular season games and highlights that are easy to follow even on the smallest of screens, is an ideal fit for mobile.

title: A Fierce Rivalry Divides a Kentucky United by Basketball
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  How deeply is basketball a way of life in Kentucky? Consider Richie Farmer. A star shooting guard for the Kentucky Wildcats in the 1990s, Mr. Farmer was elected state agriculture commissioner, before being convicted of corruption last year. He was to report to prison on March 18, but a federal judge in Frankfort, the capital, granted a one-week delay so Mr. Farmer could watch his son in a high school basketball tournament.

title: Fate of a Picasso at the Four Seasons Hangs on a Court Case
description: They were the best of friends, Aby J. Rosen, the white-haired prince of commerce who stands astride an empire of real estate and art, and Peg Breen, the inexhaustible preservationist who heads the New York Landmarks Conservancy.

title: In East, Rematch of Classic Is Possible
description: If fourth-seeded Michigan State and third-seeded Iowa State win on Friday, the 2014 East Region final will be a rematch of the 2000 Midwest Region final.

title: Failing Stress Test Is Another Stumble for Citigroup
description: Something didnt quite seem right to Citigroup earlier this week.The banking behemoth could show that it had enough capital to ride out an economic storm, but a regulator was refusing to approve its plan to increase dividends and stock buybacks, steps intended to please shareholders and build confidence in the banks turnaround.

title: Obama Seeks to Calm Saudis as Paths Split
description: CAIRO  Over seven decades, the United States and Saudi Arabia forged a strategic alliance that became a linchpin of the regional order: a liberal democracy and an ultraconservative monarchy united by shared interests in the stability of the Middle East and the continued flow of oil.

title: Court Panel Upholds Texas Law on Abortion
description: A federal appeals panel on Thursday upheld a Texas law that has forced several abortion clinics in the state to shut down, saying the law did not pose an undue burden on womens rights.

title: Irate Friends See Sexism in Report on Former Christie Aide
description: She seemed emotional. She was habitually concerned about how she was perceived by the governor. A boyfriend had ended a relationship.

title: Without Tenure or a Home
description: In the classroom, Mary-Faith Cerasoli, 53, an adjunct professor of Romance languages, usually tries to get her message across in lyrical Italian or Spanish.

title: Americas Taxation Tradition
description: As inequality has become an increasingly prominent issue in American discourse, there has been furious pushback from the right. Some conservatives argue that focusing on inequality is unwise, that taxing high incomes will cripple economic growth. Some argue that its unfair, that people should be allowed to keep what they earn. And some argue that its un-American  that weve always celebrated those who achieve wealth, and that it violates our national tradition to suggest that some people control too large a share of the wealth.

title: Welcome Help for Ukraine
description: After weeks of crisis in Ukraine  the upheaval in Kiev, the Russian occupation of Crimea, Vladimir Putins intransigence  the country just got some encouraging economic news. The International Monetary Fund tentatively approved up to $18 billion in badly needed lending assistance over two years. And the United States Congress, overcoming its habitual dysfunction, voted for a $1 billion package of American aid.

title: E.U. Tries to Assuage Fears Over U.S. Trade Deal
description: BRUSSELS  The top trade official for the European Union sought on Thursday to soothe opposition to a planned deal with the United States by imposing a 90-day period for the public to comment on protections for investors and companies.

title: Determining the Legal Rights of Slaves
description: Q. I recently read the memoirs of a woman who fled the French Revolution, settled for a while in New York State and wrote of what slavery was like there. She said the slaves had rights: For example, if they thought their owner was treating them unfairly, they had the right to demand that they be sold to someone else. Is this true? Did slaves have legal rights in New York?

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 27, 2014
description: March 27, 2014

title: A Whitewash for Gov. Christie
description: Lawyers hired by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey at public expense issued their findings Thursday on the traffic jams at the George Washington Bridge in September, apparently engineered as a bizarre form of political revenge. To no ones surprise, Mr. Christies lawyers have found his hands to be clean. He was without fault, they declared. This glossy political absolution cost the taxpayers of New Jersey more than $1 million in legal fees.

title: Dissent in Milledgeville
description: Thanks to the particularities of the Confederate Constitution, President Jefferson Davis had no real claim on the loyalty of his sitting vice president, Alexander H. Stephens, who was selected by the Confederate Legislature. Even so, Davis recognized Stephenss appearance before the Georgia Legislature in early 1864 as an act of utter betrayal  and not only because it fell the day after the Ides of March.

title: De Blasio Picks 5 Members for Rent Board
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday put his long-awaited stamp on the board that sets rents for about one million rent-regulated apartments in New York City.

title: Christian Charity Backtracks on Gays
description: World Vision U.S., an evangelical Christian charity known for asking donors to sponsor a hungry child, set off an uproar when it announced this week that it would hire Christians in same-sex marriages.

title: For College Players, Gaining Rights Amid Guarded Words
description: Sitting in his Manhattan hotel room on Wednesday night, the Connecticut senior Tyler Olander saw on television that a group of Northwestern football players had won the right to be considered employees of the university and did a little cheer.

title: Judge Urges Dismissal of Mortgage Suit Against Bank of America
description: A federal magistrate judge on Thursday moved to toss out a Justice Department lawsuit over a soured mortgage deal at Bank of America, dealing a potential setback to the governments pursuit of Wall Street misdeeds.

title: Sisterhood of the Noodle
description: Its a little before 1 a.m. on a bitterly cold Monday night and youre suddenly in the mood for ramen. Of course you are. It is a scientifically proven fact that human beings are hard-wired to crave ramen, pierogi, breakfast cereal and Ben Webster records in the wee small hours. But unless you happen to keep a pot of tonkotsu broth simmering on your stove, your options for fresh ramen after midnight are limited. On the Lower East Side, those options now include Benkei Ramen, which earlier this month moved its after-hours pop-up restaurant from SoHo to Hill & Dale on Allen Street, where customers can slurp hot broth and noodles amid Art Deco surroundings from 12:30 a.m. until 4 a.m., or closing, on Sunday through Wednesday nights (that is, Monday through Thursday mornings). On Monday night, a few dozen noodleists came out for cocktails, soup, loudish Ramones and the bars retro, antique-radio vibe. It should be noted that only three brayed along with the Black Crowes, but that was plenty.

title: Deadline Near, Health Signups Show Disparity
description: WASHINGTON  The online insurance marketplace in Oregon is such a technological mess that residents have been signing up for health coverage by hand. In Texas, political opposition to President Obamas health law is so strong that some residents believe, erroneously, that the program is banned in their state.

title: Scholars, Players and Union Members
Soul-Searching as Japan Ends a Mans Decades on Death Row

title: Using Flags to Focus on Veteran Suicides

Each flag represented a veteran who had committed suicide since Jan. 1, a figure that amounts to 22 deaths each day.

title: Not Much Playing Time for Kentucky Guard, but Many Famous Friends
