description: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man accused in the Boston Marathon bombing last year, said in court papers on Friday that the government was withholding a wealth of information that would show that his older brother, Tamerlan, instigated the bombing plot. The defense lawyers are seeking to show that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was under the influence of his brother, who was ideologically driven and had a history of violence, and that Dzhokhar should therefore be spared the death penalty. They want the government to release the familys applications for asylum in the United States as well as documents of F.B.I. contacts with Tamerlan Tsarnaev before the bombing in which, the lawyers said, the F.B.I. asked him to be an informant on the Chechen and Muslim communities. The government has said it has no evidence that Tamerlan Tsarnaev, who was subsequently killed in a police shootout, was solicited to be an informant.

title: Grand Leaps and Missteps on the Way to a Showdown
description: INDIANAPOLIS  I had planned to be in New York this weekend when the mens N.C.A.A. tournament returned to Madison Square Garden for the first time in 53 years. What a great scene: the East Regional semifinals between Connecticut and Iowa State, and Michigan State and Virginia.

title: Christie Ally Is Undone by Word in an Email
description: His name was well known in courts and in corporate suites across the metropolitan region and revered in the halls of Trenton. But a single imprudent word, written by a subordinate, brought David Samson more notoriety than he could have ever desired.

title: The Split of the Ages
description: Older voters and younger voters used to be largely on the same page when they went to the polls. No more.

title: In an Era of Squiggles, You Cant Tell the Players Without a Handwriting Analyst
description: The walls of the steakhouse at Yankee Stadium are decorated with signatures of past Yankee greats. David Robertson, the teams young closer, marvels at the fact that he can read the names.

title: Remembering a Tournament Final at the Garden
description: Fifty-three years ago, Billy Packer played in the last N.C.A.A. tournament game at Madison Square Garden before Fridays Connecticut-Iowa State East Region semifinal. A point guard for Wake Forest, Packer did not have a memorable night, as St. Johns Ivan Kovac effectively defended him throughout the game, but the Demon Deacons prevailed, 97-74.

title: A Flurry of Travel, Across the World and Beyond
description: This was a week in which travels told the tale. President Obama went to Europe and Saudi Arabia to try to shore up old alliances; the first lady, Michelle Obama, and her daughters went east to woo the Chinese; President Xi Jinping of China headed west to be wooed by the Europeans; and Joe Kaeser, the chief executive of the German engineering giant Siemens, went to Moscow to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin, saying that his companys lucrative relationship with Russia would not be sidetracked by short-term turbulence.

title: New York Sanitation Chief Closes a 54-Year Career
description: John J. Doherty, the longest-serving sanitation commissioner in New York, keeps a century-old pith helmet on a shelf in his office, a relic of the White Wings, the first uniformed army charged with cleaning the citys streets.

title: Daytons Triumph of Togetherness
description: MEMPHIS  On Caldwell Street, steps from the Dayton basketball teams practice facility on its campus in southwestern Ohio, the players shuffle in and out of one anothers apartments as if the three-story complex were one grandiose townhouse.

title: Local Voices Arent So Eager to Go National
description: Joe DAmbrosio has called Connecticut mens basketball games on the radio for 22 years. He knows the team well. He loves speaking directly to a fervent audience of local fans.

title: Security Official in Charge at World Trade Center Resigns
description: The head of security for 1 World Trade Center resigned on Friday after a series of recent breaches raised concerns about security lapses at the site.

title: Its as if the Huskies Never Left the Garden
description: Madison Square Garden, an arena known for its championship prizefights as much as its rich college basketball history, was the site of a highly anticipated East Regional semifinal matchup between Connecticuts Shabazz Napier and Iowa States DeAndre Kane.

title: Balanced Attack Powers Nets 12th Straight Home Win
description: Returning home seems to solve whatever issues the Nets are having.

title: Video Notebook: UConn Beats Iowa State
description: Connecticut guard Shabazz Napier talks about teammate DeAndre Daniels, who scored a team-high 27 points in the Huskies victory against the Cyclones.

title: Felix Fibich, Dancer and Choreographer, Dies at 96
description: Felix Fibich, a Polish-born modern dancer, choreographer and teacher who specialized in dances drawn from the Jewish heritage of Eastern Europe, died on March 20 in Manhattan. He was 96.

title: Jockey Club Wants U.S. Anti-Doping Agency in Charge
description: The Jockey Club, one of horse racings most influential groups, said it would support federal legislation to put the United States Anti-Doping Agency in charge of bringing law and order to a sport that has been unable to eradicate a pervasive drug culture that has put horses and riders at risk and alienated some fans.

title: Hoping to Hear Play Ball in Montreal
description: MONTREAL  Olympic Stadium looked just as it had when the Expos last played, in September 2004. The creaky yellow seats, the concrete concourse and the strange roof remained, conjuring some bad memories.

title: Historic Double Walkover in Florida
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Tennis has had plenty of high-profile days descend into duds through the years because of rainouts, routs or mid-match twists of fate or ankle.

title: Once a Source of Entertainment, Now a Rival Coach
description: Arizonas Sean Miller and Wisconsins Bo Ryan are usually near the top of any list of the best coaches who have never reached the Final Four. But their ties go beyond that.

title: Strumming Through Four Centuries
description: There was some trepidation in the ranks of the Vida Guitar Quartet a few years ago when one of its members, Christopher Stell, announced that he was planning to transcribe George Gershwins jazzy symphonic work Rhapsody in Blue into a piece for four guitars.

title: Tatia Pilieva
description: Tatia Pilieva is a filmmaker from the Republic of Georgia, now living in Los Angeles, who gained notoriety earlier this month when First Kiss, her short film of 20 strangers, kissing awkwardly and erotically, went viral. She hopes to debut her first feature-length film, Forever, later this year.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Sundance) MARGIN CALL (2011) J. C. Chandor wrote and directed this film in which a young Wall Street risk analyst (Zachary Quinto) predicts the 2008 financial crisis, setting off a chain of events at his investment bank, where his superiors (played by Kevin Spacey and Paul Bettany, among others) desperately try to save the company and their own skins. There are no hissable villains here, no operatic speeches condemning or celebrating greed, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Just a bunch of guys (and one woman, Demi Moore) in well-tailored clothes and a state of quiet panic trying to save themselves from a global catastrophe of their own making. He added: Watching them going about their business, you dont feel the kind of fury inspired by Inside Job, Charles Fergusons great muckraking documentary on the origins of the financial crisis, but rather a mix of dread, disgust, pity and confusion. And also, above all, admiration for an extraordinary feat of filmmaking.

title: Kentucky Ousts Defending Champion, Louisville
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The gauntlet was thrown down early. The run-and-gun Kentucky Wildcats were on the break, and James Young, looking for the 7-footer Dakari Johnson, threw a lob pass. Louisville forward Montrezl Harrell leapt, stretching his hand as far as it would reach. He swatted away the ball, past the Louisville bench and nearly into the first row of the stands. Then he screamed.

title: With Win Over Virginia, Michigan States Izzo Is Again One Step Away
description: In Tom Izzos tenure at Michigan State, the achievement has been as inevitable as a sunrise: Every one of his senior classes reaches at least one Final Four. He discussed it with his team early this season, back before all the injuries and the illnesses, but had not since.

title: Earthquake Rattles Los Angeles Area
description: An earthquake nearly five miles deep shook the Los Angeles area on Friday night, federal seismologists said.

title: In Hunt for Lost Jet, New Sightings of Debris Are Promising but Inconclusive
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 resumed in earnest on Saturday as surveillance planes returned to the skies above a newly defined search area in the southern Indian Ocean and spotted floating debris for the second day in a row, and a flotilla of vessels began arriving in the zone to find and identify the objects, the Australian authorities said.

title: Knicks Are Dealt a Rout by the Suns and a Blow to Their Playoff Hopes
description: PHOENIX  With the Knicks engaged in a playoff chase that has become one of the N.B.A.s more captivating sitcoms, Coach Mike Woodson needed two sentences to sum up the season before the Phoenix Suns demolished his team Friday night at US Airways Center.

title: Video Notebook: M.S.U. Defeats Virginia
description: Michigan State forward Branden Dawson and guard Travis Trice talk about Trices 3-pointer in transition with 9:09 left in the game. The Spartans never trailed again in their victory over Virginia.

title: Baseball Autographs
description: A collection of autographs from baseball greats.

title: Obama Ends Overseas Trip With Award for Saudi
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  President Obama ended his weeklong trip to Europe and Saudi Arabia on Saturday morning with a brief private ceremony in which he presented an International Women of Courage award to a Saudi woman who works to prevent domestic violence in the kingdom.

title: Analytics: Judging Woody
description: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the March 30 issue of the magazine.

title: Taliban Attack Election Panel Headquarters Before Afghan Voting
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban fighters unleashed a barrage of gunfire and rocket-propelled grenades at the headquarters of Afghanistans election commission on Saturday, a week before Afghans are to vote for a new president in an election that the Taliban has vowed to disrupt. There were no immediate reports of casualties.

title: Cloud Computings Watershed Week
description: In the technology world, March 2014 went out like a plan.

title: 1918: Germany Takes Control of Crimea
description: BALE The special correspondent of the Mnchner Neueste Nachrichten telegraphs from Sebastopol on May 10.

title: As Diplomacy Steps Up, Ukraine Candidates Narrow
description: MOSCOW  A day after the Russian leader Vladimir V. Putin proposed to President Obama that they boost attempts to resolve their standoff over Ukraine, Secretary of State John Kerry scrambled his travel plans to meet with his Russian counterpart in Paris on Sunday, according to a State Department official.

title: Did Facebook Buy Virtual Reality Too Soon?
description: I wasnt in the room when Mark Zuckerberg tried on the Oculus Rift virtual reality goggles for the first time, but if it was anything like my experience, Im pretty sure I can guess how he reacted.

title: State Budget Deal Reached; $300 Million for New York City Pre-K
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced on Saturday an agreement on a state budget that would provide $300 million for prekindergarten in New York City, but also undercuts other educational policies of Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has championed prekindergarten while trying to slow the spread of charter schools.

title: Setback for High Blood Pressure Treatment
description: A promising treatment for severe high blood pressure has failed in a large, rigorous study, doctors reported on Saturday.

title: The Skills Zombie
description: One of the most frustrating aspects of economic debate since 2008 has been the preference of influential people for stories about our troubles that sound serious as opposed to those that actually are serious. The reality, all along, has been that our economy is depressed because there isnt enough spending, and that what we need is something, almost anything, that increases total spending. But policymakers and pundits want to hear about tough decisions and hard choices, and they just recoil from any suggestion that terrible problems might have easy answers.

title: Variety: A Diagramless Royale
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Is it just me, or was this diagramless by Ed Stein and Paula Gamache a bit harder than some of the recent ones weve solved? I know where I got stuck, but your mileage, of course, may vary. I dont follow auto racing, so I was not familiar with A.J. FOYT, so that took a while, but at least the crossings were kind.

title: The Health Insurance Answer That Took 3 Months
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: All Public Comments Are Welcome. Then What?
description: Do federal regulators really pay attention to public comments before they adopt new rules? A group of researchers says it has developed a tool that can answer that question  with the goal of providing an extra layer of accountability in government.

title: The Mines Have Shut Down. The Miners Havent.
description: Down a homemade mine shaft in southwestern Poland, a would-be comedian sang in the faint glowing light.

title: Polands Rathole Miners
description: Digging coal illegally, often called rathole mining, proliferated in the late 1990s in Walbrzych, Poland, after the state abruptly decided to shutter coal plants in the region. It continues today.

title: Warners C.E.O. Is Bullish on the Big Screen
description: When a quiet and courteous DVD executive named Kevin Tsujihara ascended to the Warner Bros. throne last year, Hollywood did not know quite what to make of him.

title: A Communal Space, but Still My Own
description: In my single years, I was quite content doing a variety of freelance work at home. Some people cant do it. The temptations of television, the refrigerator or laundry are just too strong to resist. As for me  Im cool with typing while in my boxers and have no problem ignoring a Pisa tower of grimy dishes.

title: For a Cattle Rancher, a Legacy on the Range
description: Manny Encinias, 40, is an Angus cattle rancher in Clayton, N.M.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, March 29
description: This is the best shot virtual reality has ever had and probably will ever have.

title: Economists and Philosophy
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Lone Ranger of the 401(k)s
description: The arithmetic could not be simpler. The more fees you pay in your 401(k) plan, the less cash youll have for retirement.

title: Tom Erickson of Acquia, on the Philosophy of Ready, Fire, Aim
description: This interview with  Tom Erickson, chief executive of Acquia, an open-source software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: In Audiences on Broadway, Fewer Guys Among the Dolls
description: More men are steering clear of Broadway, and not even this springs ultimate bro show  Rocky, the new musical about the beloved boxing underdog  has found a way to fill seats with them.

title: In Some Ways, Its Looking Like 1999 in the Stock Market
description: It sure looks like a bubble.

title: Costs, Benefits and Masterpieces in Detroit
description: Most of the paintings on my walls are by artists I know personally. And although some of these works are hauntingly beautiful, they wouldnt command much on the open market.

title: Putins Reckless Gamble
G.M. Recall Total in 2014 Reaches 4.8 Million
description: General Motors announced on Saturday morning that it was recalling 490,000 trucks and 172,000 compact cars, meaning the automaker has now recalled about 4.8 million vehicles in the United States during the first three months of the year. That is about six times the number of vehicles it recalled in all of 2013.

title: Found in Mud: Precious Links to Loved Ones
description: DARRINGTON, Wash.  Gently, Dayn Brunner reached into the mangled car and lifted his younger sisters lifeless body out of the drivers seat and onto a waiting tarp. For almost a week, he and his teenage sons had slogged through the muddy catacomb of what had once been a neighborhood, scouring the pulped homes and broken earth for some sign of her. Now, it was time to say goodbye and wait for the helicopter to take her away.

title: Celebrate? Sorry, Were Studying
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  On the eve of their West Regional final Saturday against Arizona, the Wisconsin players were ensconced in a hotel down the street from Disneyland, in a meeting room with two walls of floor-to-ceiling windows.

title: Help for Hearing
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Season Opens. But Who Closes?
description: Koji Uehara got the first call to the bullpen for the Boston Red Sox last season  and the last. He retired the side in the sixth inning on opening day, and in the ninth inning to close the World Series. Fenway Park rejoiced, and the St. Louis Cardinals went home.

title: The Artificial Leaf Is Here. Again.
description: General Electric is promoting a feel-good collection of videos these days.

title: How to Harm Investors
description: Before Facebook paid $2 billion last week to buy Oculus VR, a virtual reality headset maker, 9,500 people donated $2.4 million via Kickstarter, the crowdfunding website, to get Oculus off the ground. Those early donors got thank-you notes, T-shirts or prototype headsets, but not a piece of the company. Donations through Kickstarter are just that, donations, not investments.

title: The Christian Penumbra
description: HERE is a seeming paradox of American life. One the one hand, there is a broad social-science correlation between religious faith and various social goods  health and happiness, upward mobility, social trust, charitable work and civic participation.

title: How to Think About the Risk of Autism
description: A  STUDY published last week found that the brains of autistic children show abnormalities that are likely to have arisen before birth, which is consistent with a large body of previous evidence. Yet most media coverage focuses on vaccines, which do not cause autism and are given after birth. How can we help people separate real risks from false rumors?

title: Sunday Dialogue: Easing Parental Pressure
description: Readers respond to a letter lamenting that many parents see schools less as places for children to learn and grow and more as incubators for college applications.

title: Abstract Ideas Dont Deserve Patents
description: The Constitution gives Congress the power to grant inventors a temporary monopoly over their creations to promote the progress of science and useful arts. But in recent years, the government has too often given patent protection to inventions that do not represent real scientific advances.

title: A Mudslide, Foretold
description: DONT tell me, please, that nobody saw one of the deadliest landslides in American history coming. Say a prayer or send a donation for a community buried under a mountain of mud along a great river in Washington State, the Stillaguamish. Praise the emergency workers still trying to find a pulse of life in a disaster that left 25 people dead and 90 missing.

title: Can We Close the Pay Gap?
description: LONDON  The issue of pay ratios has become the latest front in a worldwide debate about inequality and the widening gap between the top 1 percent and everyone else. In the United States, the financial reforms of the Dodd-Frank Act contained a provision that would force American companies to disclose the ratio of the compensation of their chief executive officer to the median compensation of their employees. Yet fierce criticism from the business sector has succeeded in delaying this measure for four years  and counting.

title: McDonagh Is on Rise, but Not Yet at Peak
description: Last week a lot of people were saying Ryan McDonagh belonged in the Norris Trophy conversation: his Rangers teammate Brian Boyle, Coach Alain Vigneault, the NBC hockey commentator Pierre McGuire and plenty of local hockey writers, among others.

title: Halfway Back to Society
description: In 2013, about 30,000 federal prison inmates were released to more than 200 halfway houses around the country. These facilities  where an inmate can serve up to the last year of his or her sentence  are meant to ease the transition back into society by way of employment and housing assistance, drug treatment, and other programs that make it less likely an inmate will end up reoffending and returning to prison.

title: N.C.A.A. Players Ignore Advice on Mouth Guards, Often at Their Own Peril
description: As one of the three doctors who travel with the U.C.L.A. mens basketball team, Ray Padilla had a seat behind the bench throughout the Bruins run in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Amid Egypts Sweeping Crackdown, North Sinai Residents in Crossfire
description: MAHDEYA, Egypt  Shadi Meneayi left his hometown here in North Sinai more than eight months ago to help lead a campaign of terrorist attacks against Egypts new military-led government, his relatives say.

title: With a Star Back in Form, UConn Women Shake Off B.Y.U.
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis fell on her right elbow and began screaming:

title: Aftershocks Follow an Earthquake Near Los Angeles
description: A total of 115 aftershocks jolted the Los Angeles area by Saturday morning after a magnitude 5.1 earthquake on Friday night, a federal seismologist said.

title: When Accountability Is Only a Word
description: Steve Masiello sat across a table from me before Manhattans opening game in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament in Orlando, Fla., and preached the importance of accountability.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Parallel Parking in the Arctic Circle
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. NEW MEXICO IN THE ARCTIC

title: A Metronome on the Mound
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  In some ways, the hardest part of Jerry Dipotos job should be the easiest. Like all general managers, Dipoto, of the Los Angeles Angels, has struggled to predict relief pitchers performance from year to year. Yet none of his peers had what he did from 1993 to 2000: a career as a major league pitcher.

title: Wrigley Field Turns 100, and Other Milestones Arriving in 2014
description: For some people, time can become abstract. If you say that Wrigley Field will celebrate its 100th anniversary on April 23, the milestone resonates, but much of the context is lost.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 30
description: The White House announced a legislative proposal for an overhaul of the National Security Agencys bulk domestic phone records program. If Congress approves the changes, the N.S.A. would only obtain specific phone records with permission from a judge and would no longer systemically collect data on Americans calls.

title: Is the Lime an Endangered Species?
description: LOS ANGELES  WERE used to the elusiveness of certain scarce and seasonal gastronomical treasures like black truffles that are priced and meted out accordingly. But no one could have predicted the strange twist that threatens to turn guacamole, Key lime pie and margaritas into rare delicacies.

title: The Fight for Wisconsins Soul
description: WISCONSIN has been an environmental leader since 1910, when the states voters approved a constitutional amendment promoting forest and water conservation. Decades later, pioneering local environmentalists like Aldo Leopold and Senator Gaylord Nelson, who founded Earth Day in 1970, helped forge the nations ecological conscience.

title: Cuban the Firebrand, and the Futurist
description: Mark Cuban has a way with words, a natural ability to incite with insight. He is a self-made maverick, keeping it real with a well-planned rant.

title: Free Craft Beer!
description: CRAFT breweries may be a big story in the media these days, but they face much tougher challenges than most other small businesses.

title: How Businesses Use Your SATs
description: THE news about the SAT has been confusing lately. On one hand, so many colleges and universities have opted not to require it that the College Board, which administers the SAT, has announced a top-to-bottom revamp because the test is out of step with todays academic expectations. On the other hand, many employers are still asking job applicants for their test scores, even if they are years out of date.

title: Why Fund-Raising Is Fun
description: ONCE, I asked a class full of aspiring social entrepreneurs  all with business plans and ambitions to start nonprofits  how many of them were looking forward to fund-raising. Exactly zero hands went up. The consensus was that raising money might be a necessary evil, but it was a distraction from a social enterprises real work.

title: When the College Door Shuts, a Minor League Beckons
description: FRISCO, Tex.  Moments before a recent game here, season-ticket holders for the Texas Legends, an N.B.A. Development League team, gathered in the owners box at Dr Pepper Arena.

title: Dignity Is a Constitutional Principle
description: WITH gay marriage litigation moving forward at warp speed  federal judges have struck down five state bans on same-sex marriage since December  we may soon witness one of the worst shouting matches in Supreme Court history. Passions were already running high last June, when a divided court struck down federal, but not state, laws defining marriage exclusively as a relationship between a man and a woman. Justice Antonin Scalia denounced the majority opinion, which cited the demeaning and humiliating effects of the Defense of Marriage Act, as legalistic argle-bargle lacking any basis in our constitutional tradition. Writing for the five justices in the majority, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy countered that the assault on human dignity should be decisive in condemning the statute as unconstitutional.

title: Civilizations Starter Kit
description: IM an astrobiologist  I study the essential building blocks of life, on this planet and others. But I dont know how to fix a dripping tap, or what to do when the washing machine goes on the blink. I dont know how to bake bread, let alone grow wheat. Im utterly useless with my hands. My father-in-law used to joke that I had three degrees, but didnt know anything about anything, whereas he graduated summa cum laude from the University of Life.

title: Sundays Highlights
description: Michigan State, seeded fourth in the East, will be playing in its eighth regional final since 1999 when it goes against No. 7 seed Connecticut on Sunday at Madison Square Garden. The Spartans are 6-1 in their previous appearances.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 75
description: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: A Quiz: Do You Speak Dictator?
description: After the recent actions of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, its time to test your dictator skills.

title: World Series Champions Have Surprise Endings With Closers
description: The last three championship teams clinched their World Series victories with closers other than those who started the season, underlining the unpredictable world of ninth-inning relievers.

title: Orioles May Keep Verlander Waiting
description: The Detroit Tigers have reached the playoffs four times in Justin Verlanders eight full seasons. Every time, Verlander has helped pitch them into the American League Championship Series.

title: Serena Williams Falters Early but Captures Title
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  As usual, Serena Williams had all the answers against Li Na. But there was at least one question that left her stumped Saturday after her 7-5, 6-1 victory in the final of the Sony Open.

title: Same Old Cardinals, With New Look
description: This is the power of depth and versatility. The St. Louis Cardinals have just two starting position players, catcher Yadier Molina and left fielder Matt Holliday, in the same spots they held in the majors for most of last season. The team shuffled the other pieces without trading any pitchers from its vaunted postseason staff, or the farm system.

title: A Passion to Pitch
description: ITAMI, Japan  Masahiro Tanaka, the Yankees $155 million import, grew up in a nation where joining a baseball team was like entering a religious order. The field was hallowed ground, the equipment sacred gear. Coaches were obeyed with bowed heads.

title: Ukraines Hopes Riding on a Chocolatier
description: KIEV, Ukraine  After a leading contender dropped out of Ukraines presidential race on Saturday, the hopes of many Ukrainians and their Western supporters are now riding on a man known as the Willy Wonka of Ukraine, the billionaire owner of a chocolate candy company.

title: Seeking Political Revival, Christie Joins 16 Contenders at G.O.P. Forum
description: LAS VEGAS  Gov. Chris Christie, eager to revive his national political fortunes amid a scandal back home in New Jersey, joined other leading Republicans at a forum here Saturday in complaining that President Obama had weakened the United States stature in the world. He bluntly warned that when America does not play an active and vigorous role in the world, bad people do.

title: For 2014 Races, G.O.P. Hunts Its Own
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Musical Interpretation
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Now this is a clever idea. A lot of people who read Wordplay are also music lovers, so Im sure youll like this puzzle by Peter A. Collins as well.

title: Howard Schmertz, Millrose Games Director, Dies at 88
description: Howard Schmertz, a lawyer who for 29 years presided over the Millrose Games in Manhattan, long one of the worlds most prestigious indoor track and field meets, died on Thursday in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 88.

title: A Push in Laredo to Raze Abandoned Houses Used in Drug Deals
description: EL PASO  In an unusual partnership, the South Texas city of Laredo is teaming with the United States Border Patrol and the Texas National Guard to help rid itself of abandoned structures that have been labeled eyesores and havens for criminal activity.

title: Growth Tests San Antonios Conservation Culture
description: SAN ANTONIO  To understand the culture of water conservation that this city has cultivated in the last 20 years, consider that a 11-foot-tall model of a low-flow toilet adorns the lobby of its water utilitys headquarters. The toilet recently was the subject of many photo opportunities when a group of more than 80 lawmakers, legislative staffers and water planners toured the citys water facilities.

title: An Icon of Football Is the Muse for Arias
description: When the legendary coach of the Houston Oilers, Oail Andrew Phillips  everybody knows him as Bum  was approached in 2012 with a pitch to make an opera about his life, he responded in trademark fashion, I cant sing a lick.

title: Court Halts Sale of BlackBerry-Style Keyboard for iPhone
description: Some early success has come to BlackBerrys attempts to shut down sales of a case that gives iPhone 5 owners a physical keyboard that looks as if it fell off a BlackBerry.

title: California Farmers Short of Labor, and Patience
description: HURON, Calif.  When Chuck Herrin, who runs a large farm labor contracting company, looks out at the hundreds of workers he hires each year to tend to the countless rows of asparagus, grapes, tomatoes, peaches and plums, he often seethes in frustration.

title: Mets Pick Mejia for Rotation; Decision Shocks Matsuzaka
description: MONTREAL  The Mets announced Saturday that they would send Daisuke Matsuzaka to Class AAA Las Vegas, making Jenrry Mejia the fifth starter.

title: New G.O.P. Bid to Limit Voting in Swing States
description: CINCINNATI  Pivotal swing states under Republican control are embracing significant new electoral restrictions on registering and voting that go beyond the voter identification requirements that have caused fierce partisan brawls.

title: South Koreas Sea Women
description: Enduring and tough, the female divers of Jeju Island have been a tradition for centuries. Most are over 60 now, and their numbers are declining fast.

title: Jeter Is Honored as Yankees End Spring Training With a Rainout
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As some of the darkest clouds settled over the stadium and large drops of rain pelted the field, a member of the grounds crew made a farcical effort to paint the third-base line white. With only a few minutes before the scheduled first pitch Saturday, the Yankees were still maintaining the charade that a game would be played.

title: Hardy Divers in Korea Strait, Sea Women Are Dwindling
description: HADO-RI, South Korea  On a recent morning, as she has for 60 years, Kim Eun-sil carried her diving gear to a rocky beach on the eastern side of this island to spend the day free-diving in water more than 20 feet deep to harvest seafood by hand.

title: Debate Over Palestinian Prisoner Release
description: Israel has released 78 Palestinian prisoners as part of a deal to restart peace talks. The prisoners are welcomed by many Palestinians as heroes, but many Israelis feel their release is an injustice.

title: Hailed as Heroes but Facing Challenges
description: Palestinian prisoners freed from Israeli jails struggle to rebuild their lives.

title: Nine in G.O.P. Vie to Succeed Arizona Governor, With Party Identity at Stake
description: PHOENIX  State Treasurer Doug Ducey takes every opportunity to highlight his real-world experience as the former president of a chain of ice-cream parlors. Christine Jones, a former Internet company executive, says her technological sophistication is just what Arizona needs to become more efficient. Al Melvin, a state senator, asserts that the Tea Party saved the United States as a country in 2010, when it took control of Congress, and will save the country again this year.

title: Repercussions and Reprieves at Health Insurance Enrollment Deadline
description: WASHINGTON  Americas health insurance marketplace closes on Monday night, the deadline for most people to obtain coverage or face a penalty.

title: A Team of Maestros Takes Hold
description: In October 2007, Joshua Worby was just a year into his tenure as executive director of the Westchester Philharmonic, and the signing of Itzhak Perlman to a contract as its artistic director occasioned Champagne toasts. This month, a somewhat chastened Mr. Worby sipped water from a paper cup in his modest White Plains office and recalled that, less than three years later and with money running short amid a recession, the contract was dissolved.

title: Remaking a Life, After Years in an Israeli Prison
description: BURQA, West Bank  Muqdad Salah is a man in a hurry.

title: Credibility of Afghan Vote in Doubt as Observers Flee Violence
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Usually, an Afghan election  a $100 million, Western-funded exercise  draws foreigners to Kabul like flies to honey, with incoming flights full of consultants, international monitors, diplomats and journalists.

title: Don Reitz, Who Made Dirt and Salt Into Art, Dies at 84
description: Don Reitz, an internationally renowned artist in dirt and salt, died on March 19 at his home in Clarkdale, Ariz. He was 84.

title: Leo Bretholz, 93, Dies; Escaped Train to Auschwitz
description: Schoolchildren sometimes asked him why he did not have a number tattooed on his arm, like other Holocaust survivors who visited their classes. The answer was in the story he was about to tell, Leo Bretholz replied.

title: Kentuckys Five Freshman Looking to Separate Themselves From Michigans Fab Five
description: INDIANAPOLIS  With a win against Michigan in Sundays Midwest Regional final, Kentucky would become the second team to reach the Final Four with five freshman starters. The only other team to have accomplished that, of course, was Michigan. In 1992, the Wolverines starting lineup included Jalen Rose, Chris Webber, Juwan Howard, Jimmy King and Ray Jackson. Kentuckys freshmen  James Young, Dakari Johnson, Andrew Harrison and Aaron Harrison and Julius Randle  are familiar with that Michigan team, known as the Fab Five.

title: Deposed World Champion on Track for a Rematch
description: When Magnus Carlsen sits down to defend his world title this year, it appears that he will be staring across the board at a familiar face: Viswanathan Anand, from whom Carlsen snatched the crown last year.

title: Poised, but Shes on the Verge
description: Dont believe everything Dr. Juliana Smithton says.

title: Death Toll Climbs to 18 a Week After Landslide
description: OSO, Wash.  A week after a devastating landslide tore apart this small town, officials on Saturday said that 18 people had been confirmed dead and 30 others were still missing or unaccounted for, with the task of identifying bodies complicated by the condition they were found in.

title: Florida Tightens Defense to End Daytons Run and Reach Final Four
description: MEMPHIS  On his way out of FedEx Forum on Saturday night, the college basketball radio analyst Will Perdue looked back out on the floor where Florida had just cut down the nets in celebration of a Final Four berth. He shook his head, marveling over the Gators, and said, I havent seen anybody yet that can beat these guys, not with that defense.

title: Despite Conflict and Repression, Creativity
description: In assembling Art Amongst War: Visual Culture in Afghanistan, 1979-2014, the current exhibition at the College of New Jersey Art Gallery, Deborah Hutton discovered works that evoked feelings ranging from dismay to guarded hope.

title: De Blasio Announces Push for Hurricane Recovery
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced on Saturday a major push to assist residents affected by Hurricane Sandy, saying that his administration would cut through the red tape that plagued the recovery process under his predecessor.

title: Contenders For the Derby Bring Historic Possibilities
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  Constitution, unraced as a 2-year-old, made up for lost time Saturday, rallying to defeat Wildcat Red by a neck in the $1 million Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.

title: Pied Piper Bonds With the Faithful
description: Six years into the supernova phase of her career, Lady Gaga is already a nostalgia act. Not in the temporal sense  even in her prime she wasnt a particularly modern artist, but one bowing at the altar of early 1980s Madonna, toying with the arena camp of the 1970s or winking at 1990s club land  but more in terms of place.

title: My Quiz on Dictators
description: My Sunday column takes the form of a quiz about world affairs, focusing on Putin and various autocrats. Its also a bit of an experiment, because although Ive done quiz columns before this is the first time Ive used an interactive web version. It tells you immediately whether your answer is right or wrong and information pops up depending on how you answer. So let me know what you think of the experiment. Im always interested in trying new tools to engage readers.

title: Two Key Contributors Were Teammates Long Before They Were Spartans
description: Branden Dawson said he was not surprised when Travis Trice, with no Michigan State teammates near the basket, decided to shoot a 3-pointer in transition Friday night.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 29, 2014
description: March 29, 2014

title: Vows: Leader of the Pack
description: Raising sled dogs together in Manhattan has taught Samantha Berkule and Scott Johnson to value the bond between them.

title: Final Shift in Momentum Puts Wisconsin in Final Four
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The ball was in Nick Johnsons hands again. Just as he hoped it would be when he and his Arizona teammates were given a late reprieve, a final chance in a game that had been full of missed opportunities.

title: With Rare Success, 76ers Fail to Break Record
description: PHILADELPHIA  Something strange happened Saturday night in Philadelphia. The 76ers won. In fact, they won easily.

title: Video Notebook: Bert Miranda
description: Bert Miranda had always wanted to see a Broadway show, but found that Rocky was easier to relate to than some other productions.

title: Video Notebook: Jim Abate
description: Jim Abate, an audience member at Rocky, says that he appreciated the use of props in the show.

title: Rookie Award for Tanaka
description: Masahiro Tanaka, a right-handed pitcher, has won the James P. Dawson Award, given annually to the outstanding Yankees rookie in spring training, the team announced. Tanaka, 25, signed in the off-season to a seven-year, $155 million contract, went 2-0 with a 2.14 earned run average over 21 innings. He recorded 26 strikeouts and 3 walks.

title: Rebecca Frank, Aaron Mehta
description: Rebecca Ann Frank, the daughter of Belle Frank and James A. Frank of New York, was married Saturday evening to Aaron Noshir Mehta, the son of Dara R. Mehta and Noshir R. Mehta, of Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi David Saperstein officiated at the Park Hyatt Washington.

title: Amber Sutherland, Thomas Namako Jr.
description: Amber Rose Sutherland and Thomas Joseph Namako Jr. are to be married Sunday at Rebar, an event space in Brooklyn. Todd Wright, a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism, will officiate.

title: Julia Finkelstein, James Rosoff
description: Dr. Julia Beth Finkelstein and Dr. James Steven Rosoff were married Saturday evening at Guastavinos, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Mara S. Nathan officiated.

title: Mary Chen, Joey Zhou
description: Dr. Chen Chen and Yi Zhou were married Saturday at the Harvard Club in New York. Laura Gabriel, a minister ordained by the New Age Fellowship in New York, officiated.

title: Planes, Dog Sleds and Automobiles
description: Samantha Brooke Berkule and Scott Stuart Johnson were married Saturday evening in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla. Cantor Jill E. Abramson officiated at the Acqualina Resort and Spa on the Beach.

title: Alexis Hoag, Brittany Soler
description: Alexis Johara Hoag and Brittany Jill Soler were married Friday at the Brooklyn Municipal Building. Marie R. Lennon, a deputy city clerk, officiated. On April 13, Terry A. Maroney, a friend of the couple, will lead a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions at One, an event space in Nashville.

title: Walter Lowry, Craig Thompson
description: Walter Shackleford Lowry and Craig Elliott Thompson were married Wednesday evening at their home in Los Angeles. Brenda Freiberg, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Tali Arbit, Jonathan Eskreis-Winkler
description: Tali Chava Arbit, a daughter of Sheara Avital Arbit and Dr. David L. Arbit of Englewood, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Jonathan Mark Eskreis-Winkler, the son of Dr. Jeffrey D. Winkler of Wynnewood, Pa., and the late Dr. Beverly D. Eskreis. Rabbi Abraham A. Levene will officiate at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., with Rabbi Zev Reichman participating.

title: Victoria Stuss, Brian Bones
description: Victoria Mary Stuss, a daughter of Judith M. Stuss of Boonton, N.J., and Konrad F. Stuss of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married Friday to Brian Lee Bones, the son of Marsha L. Bones and Barry L. Bones of Medford, Ore.

title: Jennifer Levine, Edward Maas
description: Jennifer Perry Levine and Edward Sean Maas were married Saturday evening at the Waters Edge, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Irwin Huberman officiated.

title: A Continent Didnt Get in the Way
description: Elizabeth Kelly Murray and Webster Granger Marquez were married Saturday at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco. James Joseph Meeks, a friend of the couple who was named a temporary deputy commissioner by the City of San Francisco, officiated.

title: Chrystie Perry, Kenneth Holmstrom
description: Chrystie Hale Perry and Kenneth Robert Holmstrom were married Friday evening at the Yale Club in New York. The Rev. Laurie Sue Brockway, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Melissa Rooney, Thomas Geggel
description: Dr. Melissa Heather Rooney and Thomas Miles Geggel were married Saturday by Mark Giller, a Sanctuary of the Beloved minister, at the Woodlands at Woodbury in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Samantha Ulmer, George Enstad
description: Samantha Michelle Ulmer and George Philip Enstad were married Saturday evening at the Knowles Memorial Chapel at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla. The Rev. Richard Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Alexis Weinerman, Jason Fishkind
description: Alexis Meredith Weinerman and Jason Ian Fishkind were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia. Rabbi Joseph M. Domosh officiated.

title: Amanda Ross, Jonathan Zakheim
description: Amanda Sara Ross and Jonathan Ari Zakheim were married Saturday evening at the Essex House in New York. Rabbi Benjamin H. Spratt officiated.

title: Amy Kleger, Jeremy Koven
description: Amy Lauren Kleger and Jeremy Robert Koven were married Saturday evening at the Le Mridien Philadelphia hotel. Rabbi Lauren G. Herrmann officiated.

title: Twice Bitten, Still Smitten
description: Kathleen Faye Donovan, the daughter of Carol Crabtree Donovan and Daniel P. Donovan of Dallas, was married Saturday evening to Kenneth George Alfred Coffin, a son of Joann M. Coffin and Kenneth J. Coffin of Bulls Head, Staten Island. The Rev. John Libone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Aquinas Catholic Church in Dallas.

title: Jennifer Solomon, Joshua Alexander
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Solomon and Joshua Andrew Galiard Alexander were married Saturday evening at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. Rabbi Joshua Strom officiated.

title: Caroline Thompson, David Dubick
description: Caroline McRainey Thompson and David Abraham Dubick were married Saturday evening by Rabbi John A. Linder at the Arizona Biltmore in Phoenix.

title: Corrections: March 30, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: More Ships and Planes Join Search for Jetliner
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  With no trace of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 more than three weeks after it disappeared, the international search effort intensified Monday, with 10 planes and 10 ships expected to scour the latest search area about 1,100 miles west of Perth, Australia, officials said.

title: In Our Pages: March 31
description: 1889: A Steamer Cut In Two

title: Large Crowds Fill Taipei Streets in Protest Over China Trade Bill
description: More than 100,000 demonstrators took to the streets of Taipei on Sunday to protest efforts by the government to approve a trade pact with China and to show support for the students who have occupied Taiwans Legislature for nearly two weeks.

title: A Sperm Donor, Uncertain of What It Is to Be Bio-Dad
description: But  Im so short!

title: North Korea Vows to Use New Form of Nuclear Test
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea threatened on Sunday to carry out a new form of nuclear test, a year after its third nuclear test raised military tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula and prompted the United Nations to tighten sanctions against the North.

title: A Tax Break to Anchor Tech Growth in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On one side of a long, wooden table at Zendesks offices here, 80 software engineers who are collectively worth tens of millions of dollars stood with empty paper plates waiting to be fed.

title: Review: 2014 Toyota Highlander Limited
description: Many automobile manufacturers have abandoned minivans over the last 10 years because crossovers are where the money is these days. Need proof? Porsche now makes two of them.

title: Harold Rosenbaum Wins Conductors Award
description: The Ditson Conductors Award, an annual prize presented by Columbia University for contributions to the advancement of American music, is to be presented to Harold Rosenbaum at a concert by the New York Virtuoso Singers at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Rosenbaum founded the ensemble in 1988, and is also the founder and conductor of the Canticum Novum Singers and the director of the Harold Rosenbaum Choral Conducting Institute, held annually at Columbia and the State University of New York at Buffalo. The award, which was established in 1945, includes a citation and $5,000.

title: Brazil Moves to Expel Drug Gangs From Rio Slums
description: Police officers and marines move through the Complexo da Mare in an early-morning surge.

title: European Lawmakers Prepare to Vote on Net Neutrality
description: LONDON  Vodafone gave Chris Herbert a package deal he found too tempting to turn down.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 3 P.M. (BET) LOVE JONES (1997) The first meeting between Darius (Larenz Tate) and Nina (Nia Long, above, with Mr. Tate) at a Chicago poetry club goes so swimmingly that Darius dedicates his reading to her. They are smitten, and a courtship ensues, with plenty of heat, in this film written and directed by Theodore Witcher. Along the way, it spins an enjoyable web and suggests that its characters, in addition to knowing how to woo each other, also know how to have other kinds of fun, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times.

title: Christie Addresses Republicans
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke to the Republican Jewish Coalition on Saturday.

title: The ACA Surge Blackout
description: Update: And the 4th-ranking Republican in the Senate is already accusing the administration of cooking the books. I really think the possibility that the ACA might actually work never occurred to them.

title: Is Facebook Too Big to Care?
description: Facebooks chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has always followed his own instincts when making decisions about the company he founded 10 years ago. But several events over the last week make you wonder: Has the company gotten so successful that it doesnt care what other people think about it?

title: A Movement to Protect Food Markets in the Bronx, and Beyond
description: Baron Ambrosia, the Bronxs culinary boulevardier of stout heart and insatiable palate, made the rounds of Hunts Point recently, sweeping into ethnic restaurants to urge people to come to the big table. Granted, some of the joints he visited were barely big enough to contain his oversize persona. But the table to which he was rallying people was one where food was both on the plate and on the agenda.

title: Promises of Diplomacy but No Advances in Ukraine Talks
description: PARIS  Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart agreed on Sunday that a political solution was needed for Ukraine and said they planned to continue discussing ways to de-escalate the crisis over the countrys future and Russias annexation of Crimea. But neither side claimed a breakthrough, and Russia did not commit to pulling back the more than 40,000 troops the United States says are massed near Ukraines border.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: March 28, 2014
description: President Obama is trying to isolate Vladimir Putin through various sanctions against dozens of politicians and business leaders close to the Russian leader. This week on Money Talking, Rana Foroohar and Joe Nocera consider whether the sanctions are going to have any effect. What would mean if Russian billionaires cant buy New York City penthouses? Plus, Rupert Murdochs plans for succession at Fox and News Corp involves his sons.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 74
description: To call Guus Hiddink peripatetic would be an understatement.

title: Noah Is No. 1 Despite Complaints
description: LOS ANGELES  Viewers went to Noah, many in pairs, like the creatures in Genesis; but they quickly erupted in disagreement over the films action-packed, modernist rendering of the biblical flood.

title: Connecticut Defeats Michigan State to Advance to the Final Four
description: Kevin Ollie, the Connecticut coach, organized a field trip during his teams jaunt through Texas in early January. Taking a break from basketball, the Huskies visited AT&T Stadium, the site of this years Final Four.

title: A Case of Ill Have What Theyre Having, Even if It Might Be Worse
description: Its actually not a bad strategy that Friends With Better Lives is employing: Make your first episode so gratingly awful that as the series progresses, you have nowhere to go but up.

title: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 1
description: Last year, Churchill Downs adopted a points system to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in designated Derby prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturdays Florida, Louisiana and U.A.E. Derbies can be found here.

title: Prevailing at the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams
description: DALLAS  The 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here, was played on Sunday between Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell; and Team Monaco: Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. (Pierre Zimmermann and Franck Multon were on the team early in the tournament.)

title: U.S. Agency Knew About G.M. Flaw but Did Not Act
description: Federal regulators decided not to open an inquiry on the ignitions of Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars even after their own investigators reported in 2007 that they knew of four fatal crashes, 29 complaints and 14 other reports that showed the problem disabled air bags, according to a memo released by a House subcommittee on Sunday.

title: Pick Your Weapon, Your Moral Path and the Response of Your Public
description: Video game designers like to talk about the verbs in their games, and those verbs  jump, shoot, punch, run, hide, talk, listen, watch  are what give their work meaning.

title: Vanya and Sonia Writer to Take the Stage
description: The playwright Christopher Durang, who wrote Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, is set to star as Vanya in a coming production at the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., the producers announced. The comedy, which takes place in Bucks County and won a Tony last year for best play, is scheduled to run from July 17 to Aug. 10. Marilu Henner (Taxi) has been cast as Masha, a role played by Sigourney Weaver in the Off Broadway and Broadway productions. Vanya was originally played by David Hyde Pierce. The production is to be directed by Sheryl Kaller (Mothers and Sons).

title: Heideggers Notebooks Renew Focus on Anti-Semitism
description: It has long been one of the most contentious questions in 20th-century intellectual history: Just how much, and what kind, of a Nazi was the German philosopher Martin Heidegger?

title: Djokovic Dominates Nadal for Sony Title
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  The ever-lengthening rivalry between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal has been best defined by sweat and toil, by trophies earned after hours of titanic rallies and risk.

title: Destination Unknown
description: Francesca Marcianos magical, fleet-footed stories leap around the globe, from Rome to New York to Mombasa, from a small Greek village to a remote island off the coast of Tanzania to a fortress on the banks of the Narmada River in India. She has an uncanny ability to conjure specific places  not just the spectacular postcard vistas (a sky that looked like blue carbon paper, a moonlit beach, framed with palm fronds, that looked like an advertisement from the forties for cruises in the tropics), but also a sense of the daily rhythms of life there (the pots of basil on the windowsills to keep the mosquitoes away, the ritual of hanging clothes out to dry in certain neighborhoods in Rome).

title: Hip-Hop Radio Stars Try TV Comedy
description: This Is Hot 97  a charming trifle on VH1 set in opposition to that channels other hip-hop-theme reality programming, like the reliably raucous Love & Hip Hop and its offspring  is a workplace comedy masquerading as a hip-hop-insider tour masquerading as a reality show, and not particularly successful at any of them. To be fair, though, its not trying hard. It has different goals.

title: Rural Couple
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  A quick anecdote brought on by 41 Down, before we get into the puzzle:

title: Highlights and Analysis: Mets Fall on Baseballs First Afternoon
description: Times reporters and editors shared their insights and analysis on the coming year and kept tabs on the first full slate of games of 2014, including the Mets and the Nationals at Citi Field.

title: The Shame of the Church
description: Sexual abuse in the Catholic Church has been making headlines for years. Some priests have been punished, but what about the bishops who shielded them?

title: In an Upper-Crust World, an Ensemble Stays Loose
description: Forty years. 800 works. There was plenty to celebrate on Friday evening when the Kronos Quartet took to the big stage of Carnegie Hall with a colorful, high-energy celebration of four decades spent at the new-music frontier of the string quartet world. A diverse crowd turned out to cheer the ensemble, which comprises one founding member  the violinist David Harrington  and two longstanding members, the violinist John Sherba and the violist Hank Dutt, as well as the cellist Sunny Yang, who joined last year.

title: The Fight to Reveal Abuses by Catholic Priests
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the former Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, is in no way the principal face of the sexual abuse scandals that have buffeted the church and its priesthood almost without pause for three decades. But he embodies a certain mind-set among some in the highest clerical ranks. It is an attitude that has led critics, who of late include the authors of a scathing United Nations committee report, to wonder about the depth of the churchs commitment to atone for past predations and to ensure that those sins of the fathers are visited on no one else.

title: Is Canada Tarring Itself?
description: START with the term tar sands. In Canada only fervent opponents of oil development in northern Alberta dare to use those words; the preferred phrase is the more reassuring oil sands. Never mind that the oil in the worlds third largest petroleum reserve is in fact bitumen, a substance with the consistency of peanut butter, so viscous that another fossil fuel must be used to dilute it enough to make it flow.

title: Older and Out of Work, but Not Out of Contention
description: On Thursday, the 10 graduates celebrated over spoonfuls of yellow cake with chocolate icing. They hugged, cheered and promised to stay connected, fortifying themselves for the rough road ahead.

title: Winners Named in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions
description: This season more than 1,500 aspiring singers participated in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, thought to be the most prestigious voice competition in the field. After auditions in 40 districts and 13 regions in the United States and Canada, it all came down to the Grand Finals concert on Sunday afternoon at the Met.

title: The Case for Profanity in Print
description: LAST month, Assistant Secretary of State Victoria Nuland made some impolitic comments about the European Union during a phone call with the ambassador to Ukraine. The phone call was leaked, leading to an embarrassing diplomatic incident that was covered in multiple articles in the media. But what, exactly, did Ms. Nuland say?

title: No. 8 Seed Kentucky, Peaking at Right Time, Tops No. 2 Michigan
description: INDIANAPOLIS  As recently as a month ago, the Kentucky basketball team was being dissected by its critics, belittled for being an underachiever and for perhaps not being worthy of the mountains of preseason No. 1 hype.

title: ECO 348, The Great Recession: Austerity, Part I
description: Slides here.

title: Students in Taiwan Protest Trade Deal With China
description: The demonstrators said they feared the deal would give Beijing too much influence over the countrys economy.

title: How Public Research Underpins Private Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.R., on Static Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Rattlesnake Wranglers, Armed With Gasoline
description: SWEETWATER, Tex.  At the foot of a rocky cliff here, Riley Sawyers knelt down and peered into a small, dark hole, on the prowl for rattlesnakes. One had already lunged at him and bitten his Kevlar-reinforced boot. The venom was still drying, as was the blood on his arm from where the thorny terrain had scratched him, when Mr. Sawyers went to fetch the gasoline.

title: Families and College Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: A Crisis of Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC Sports Hires G.M.A. News Anchor
description: In a move that increases the already intense competition in morning television, NBC Sports has hired Josh Elliott away from ABCs Good Morning America, the show that displaced NBCs Today show as the king of morning programming.

title: Excerpt: King Lear
description: Michael Pennington plays the lead role in King Lear at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

title: A Lively Debate Over Outdoor Cats
Afghan Couple Finally Together, but a Storybook Ending Is Far From Ensured
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Happy endings in Afghan love stories are vanishingly rare. And for one young couple from Bamian Province, the odds of such a conclusion are getting even longer.

title: Motorcycle Crew Has One Requirement, and It Isnt a License
description: Inside a biker garage in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a red 1981 Moto Guzzi V50 Monza was beginning to draw a crowd.

title: Hopes Frustrated, Many Latinos Reject the Ballot Box Altogether
description: AURORA, Colo.  As the weather warms, Lizeth Chacon is anticipating a new season of registering Latino voters  yet dreading experiences like one late last year, when she came upon a skate park full of older teenagers.

title: Panels Warning on Climate Risk: Worst Is Yet to Come
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan  Climate change is already having sweeping effects on every continent and throughout the worlds oceans, scientists reported Monday, and they warned that the problem is likely to grow substantially worse unless greenhouse emissions are brought under control.

title: This American Life Considers Self-Distribution on Radio
description: The announcement two weeks ago that This American Life will part ways on July 1 from its distributor, Public Radio International, has set off a scramble among rivals for rights to the program, one of the most popular on public radio.

title: In Media Moguls Rarefied Realm, Its Like Father, Like Son
description: Last week, Rupert Murdoch handed the future leadership of two publicly held companies worth a combined $80 billion to his two sons, almost as casually as if they were the keys to the family station wagon.

title: Eddie Lawrence Dies at 95; Comedys Old Philosopher
description: When Eddie Lawrence first performed his new comedy routine for his agent and a few entertainment executives, they told him that they loved it but that it was too clever for most people to understand. Mr. Lawrence had more faith in his audience.

title: Feinstein Gives Tentative Nod to Data Curbs
description: WASHINGTON  A proposal backed by President Obama to constrain the National Security Agencys systematic collection of Americans telephone data drew a cautious welcome on Sunday from a key congressional intelligence leader, but she offered a few significant caveats.

title: Video Notebook: UConn Makes Final Four
description: Connecticuts Ryan Boatright talks about a trip to At&T Stadium, site of the Final Four, earlier this season. Michigan States Travis Trice talks about the seniors failing to make a Final Four.

title: Kate OMara, a Schemer on Dynasty, Dies at 74
description: Kate OMara, the British actress who played the scheming sister of Joan Collinss character on the 1980s prime-time soap opera Dynasty and another scheming sister on the BBC sitcom Absolutely Fabulous, died on Sunday in a nursing home in Sussex, England. She was 74.

title: Moroccos Mule Ladies
description: Moroccan women face a dangerous daily toil, carrying large bales of duty-free goods back from the Spanish North African enclave of Melilla.

title: Yanks First Foe Is Happy to Keep Taking Long View
description: The Yankees open their season Tuesday in the same place they ended their last one: Minute Maid Park, the home of the Houston Astros. They bring along $470 million in new players and expectations of a pinstriped parade this fall.

title: For Opening Day, a Campaign to Love Baseball
description: MAJOR League Baseball is entering the new season with a new lead creative agency, BBDO New York, and invoking the L-word  love  to describe how fans feel about the sport, and how everyone else should, too.

title: WWE Network Is Loud Introduction to the Video Streaming Ring
description: When listing the visionary media moguls of the digital age, Vince McMahon, the professional wrestling impresario, might not immediately come to mind.

title: A Weight on Moroccan Womens Shoulders
description: At the Moroccan-Spanish border, women known as mule ladies carry large bundles on their backs, sometimes earning as little as three euros per trip.

title: Hollywoods Antipiracy Efforts Add New Voice
description: LOS ANGELES  In the fall of 2012, Ruth Vitale, a sassy independent film executive, nosed her horse into a badly directed jump and crashed in the mud.

title: Question Marks Will Head North With the Mets and Punctuate Their Opener
description: Matt Harvey against Stephen Strasburg. One ace against another. Thats the matchup the Mets would have wanted, the one they could have put in lights. That is a matchup worthy of opening day. Instead, it will be the unassuming Dillon Gee opposite Strasburg and the Washington Nationals on Monday at Citi Field. Harvey, of course, will miss most if not all of this season while he recovers from Tommy John elbow surgery.

title: As Landslide Debris Slows Search, Residents Resolve to Help
description: ARLINGTON, Wash.  No sounds or signs of life, emergency responders say, have come from beneath a sea of muck and debris for a full week now since a devastating landslide roared down onto the tiny mountain community of Oso. No tale of determination and luck against the odds  an air pocket somehow shielded from the onslaught of earth and rock, or an iron-willed survivor spitting in the eye of fate  has emerged to leaven the gloom of mud and rain and death at what is called the pile.

title: Jobs and Skills and Zombies
description: A few months ago, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, and Marlene Seltzer, the chief executive of Jobs for the Future, published an article in Politico titled Closing the Skills Gap. They began portentously: Today, nearly 11 million Americans are unemployed. Yet, at the same time, 4 million jobs sit unfilled  supposedly demonstrating the gulf between the skills job seekers currently have and the skills employers need.

title: Apples War on Samsung Has Google in Crossfire
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Officially, its Apple versus Samsung Electronics in another tech patent face-off in a San Jose courtroom this week. But there is another company with a lot at stake in the case  Google.

title: Is Belief a Jewish Notion?
description: This is the fourth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Howard Wettstein, a professor of philosophy at the University of California, Riverside, and the author of The Significance of Religious Experience.

title: What Lending Rules Should Look Like
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which opened its doors in 2011, has already issued important regulations governing mortgage transactions and has established new oversight of credit reporting and student loans. Now the federal agency is formulating rules to rein in the payday lending industry, which bills itself as offering easy, short-term loans but earns its profits by luring people into debt traps.

title: Carmakers Close Ties to Regulator Scrutinized
description: There was nothing unusual about a letter with Jacqueline S. Glassmans name on it discussing life-threatening safety defects and requiring more information from a manufacturer; Ms. Glassman was once chief counsel of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, then deputy administrator, and, briefly, acting administrator.

title: The Senates Discourtesy to Judges
description: The job of federal judge for the Eastern District of North Carolina has been vacant for more than eight years, one of the longest vacancies of 83 on the federal bench around the country. Last June, President Obama nominated Jennifer May-Parker, a federal prosecutor, for the position, but she hasnt even received a vote in the Senate Judiciary Committee because Richard Burr, the states Republican senator, is blocking her.

title: Journalists Held by Militants in Syria Reunite With Family
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Two Spanish journalists held for six months by radical Islamist militants in northern Syria arrived safely in Madrid on Sunday, greeting friends and family in an emotional scene at the airport a day after one called his newspaper to report they had been handed over to Turkish soldiers.

title: For Californians, 2 Quakes Put Preparedness Back on the Map
description: LOS ANGELES  It has been 20 years since Southern California experienced a major earthquake, a powerful 6.7-magnitude temblor that rolled through Northridge, killing 57 people. But this stretch of seismic calm, though welcome in obvious ways, has undermined efforts to force Los Angeles to deal with what officials describe as potentially lethal deficiencies in earthquake preparation.

title: De Blasio Betting on Pre-K to Succeed
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio stumbled away from the first state budget battle of his administration with his mandate bruised and his political momentum stymied, but clutching a hard-fought prize: money, and a lot of it, for his signature plan to offer free prekindergarten classes in New York City.

title: Not on Ballot, Turkeys Premier Still Gets Push From Party in Local Elections
description: ISTANBUL  Even as he faced sweeping antigovernment protests last summer and a stinging corruption investigation that challenged his rule, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan held close to the notion that voters had put him in office and would do so again.

title: Graft Case Stirs Race for Mayor of Washington, D.C.
description: WASHINGTON  Campaigning at a Metro station on Friday, Mayor Vincent C. Gray quickly attracted citizens with complaints, though many had scant connection to the issues around his hard-fought re-election.

French Voters Shift to the Right in Mayoral Elections
description: PARIS  French voters dealt a blow to the government of Franois Hollande on Sunday, rejecting left-leaning candidates for local office in at least 155 cities while embracing more conservative politicians, including, in a handful of races, the extreme-right National Front party.

title: A Tale of How It Was, Retold by Women of Experience

There are 10 of them, solid wooden furniture, covered with the detritus you find at estate sales: glassware, china, bibelots, books, even a cache of manual typewriters. Its the sort of display that makes you think about your own inventory of passed-down possessions, of the lives these discarded objects might have led and of the absent owners who once animated them.

description: The tenement buildings known as A. Philip Randolph Houses take up a block along West 114th Street in Harlem and stand as a relic from the 1800s, clashing with the condos, yoga studios and cookie shops encroaching all around.

title: With Eye on Playoffs, Nets Extend Home Streak
description: The Nets have 10 games remaining on their regular-season schedule and aspirations to defy outside expectations with a deep postseason run. Entering these final two and a half weeks, the question remains whether they can ascend the Eastern Conferences playoff seeding table to secure home-court advantage in the first round.

title: 2 Killed in Shootings in Brooklyn and Queens
description: Separate shootings in Brooklyn and Queens on Sunday afternoon left two people dead, including a teenager, police and fire officials said.

title: Climate Panel Sees Global Warming Impacts on All Continents, Worse to Come
description: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has released its latest report on the impacts of global warming, projected changes under various scenarios for greenhouse gas emissions and options for limiting related risks. Justin Gillis, reporting from the meeting in Yokohama, Japan, where government officials from around the world signed off on the summary document over the weekend, has summarized the prime conclusions and statements of panel leaders.

title: Popular Demand
description: Noah, which opened on Friday, is off to a strong start. The dark telling of the biblical story suits Russell Crowe, who has played larger-than-life heroes like the Roman warrior Maximus in Gladiator and troubled characters like the math genius John Forbes Nash Jr. in A Beautiful Mind.

title: Alibaba Ventures Offline With Stake in Chinese Retail Group
description: HONG KONG  Traditional retailers have been pushing into online sales for years. Now, one of the worlds biggest e-commerce companies is heading in the opposite direction: making a big bet on department stores.

title: Greece Passes Economic Measures, Clearing the Way for Bailout Money
description: ATHENS  The Greek Parliament voted narrowly early Monday to back a bitterly contested package of economic changes, clearing the way for the release of further funding considered crucial for a financial rescue, despite a last-minute attempt by the political opposition to postpone the vote.

title: The Art of Living
description: Cassina and the Italian lighting company Nemo are adding to their selections of Charlotte Perriand pieces. The French architect and designer was unfettered by expectation or precedent  she famously brought sensual life to Le Corbusiers sometimes austere ideas  and the new pieces, available in the United States next month, reflect her commitment to functional beauty. They include Perriands Indochine swivel armchair, designed in 1943 for her personal use and based on her LC7 metal chair, which caught the attention of the world at the 1929 Salon dAutomne art exhibition; her triangular Mexique tables from 1952, shaped in response to the space constraints of student housing; and a small sconce from 1962, which shows the genius and cheer Perriand could bring to any object, however humble.

description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Whelan Plans to Depart City Ballet After 30 Years
description: Wendy Whelan, the principal dancer with New York City Ballet who became a major star of the post-Balanchine era, plans to give her farewell performance with the company on Oct. 18 after 30 years  and then to continue her leap into contemporary dance.

title: Whats on Monday
description: NOON (FLIX) MELVIN AND HOWARD (1980) Paul Le Mat stars as Melvin Dummar, a milkman with big dreams but an unsteady relationship with his wife (Mary Steenburgen, who won an Oscar for her role) and an even rockier financial situation. That is, until he finds out that a vagrant he gave a lift to years earlier was the reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes, who has left him $150 million in his will. The film, directed by Jonathan Demme, is based on the true story of a Utah gas station attendant who claimed to be a beneficiary of Hughess fortune in what came to be known as the Mormon will. Officials deemed the Mormon will a forgery, but Mr. Demme and Bo Goldman, his screenwriter, take Melvins tale at face value and present the movie as Melvins wildest dream, Vincent Canby wrote in The Times. The comic catch is that this wild dream is essentially so prosaic. Its also touched with pathos since Melvin  in spite of himself  knows that it will never be realized. This is the story of his life.

title: Knicks Hold Off Warriors and Keep a Foot in the Playoff Race
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  With the seconds melting away, the Golden State Warriors Stephen Curry tried to find some daylight for a look at a game-tying 3-pointer. What he found instead was the beefy right arm of Raymond Felton, who applied enough pressure that Curry had no choice but to throw an errant pass.

title: To Be Poor and Sick in India
description: MUMBAI  I first became interested in Indias government hospitals after my son was born last May at Breach Candy Hospital in Mumbai, one of the citys well-regarded private hospitals. The care was exceptional, but a stay at a private hospital is a luxury that only a small percentage of Mumbai residents can afford. My curiosity about what kind of care existed for the citys less fortunate babies led me to write about the fight against infant mortality in the Dharavi slum for India Ink in September.
