description: YOKOHAMA, Japan  Climate change is already having sweeping effects on every continent and throughout the worlds oceans, scientists reported on Monday, and they warned that the problem was likely to grow substantially worse unless greenhouse emissions are brought under control.

title: The Wolf Hunters of Wall Street
description: Before the collapse of the U.S. financial system in 2008, Brad Katsuyama could tell himself that he bore no responsibility for that system. He worked for the Royal Bank of Canada, for a start. RBC might have been the fifth-biggest bank in North America, by some measures, but it was on nobodys mental map of Wall Street. It was stable and relatively virtuous and soon to be known for having resisted the temptation to make bad subprime loans to Americans or peddle them to ignorant investors. But its management didnt understand just what an afterthought the bank was  on the rare occasions American financiers thought about it at all. Katsuyamas bosses sent him to New York from Toronto in 2002, when he was 23, as part of a big push for the bank to become a player on Wall Street. The sad truth was that hardly anyone noticed it. The people in Canada are always saying, Were paying too much for people in the United States,  Katsuyama says. What they dont realize is that the reason you have to pay them too much is that no one wants to work for RBC. RBC is a nobody.

title: Paradise in a Pakistani Valley
description: It was 2009 and a depleted savings account was all Edwin Koo had to show a year after he left Singapore to work as a freelance photographer in Nepal. Hungry for photos, Mr. Koo joined friends traveling to Islamabad, two hours south of the Taliban insurgency occurring in Pakistans Swat Valley. But hundreds of photographs and a handful of interviews with Swati refugees left just three words, repeated over and over, echoing in Mr. Koos mind.

title: Should Employers Be Able to Review Job Applicants SAT Scores?

title: Former Israeli Leader Is Convicted of Taking Bribes
description: JERUSALEM  Ehud Olmert, the former Israeli prime minister who was forced from office under a corruption cloud, was convicted Monday of taking bribes to ease the construction of a huge housing complex while he was mayor of Jerusalem, dashing his much-discussed dream of a political comeback.

title: U.N. Court Orders Japan to Halt Whaling Off Antarctica

title: Palestinian Was Holding Explosive Device When He Died, Czechs Say
description: PRAGUE  The Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic, who was killed Jan. 1 in an explosion in his new residence here, most likely died after an explosive device he was holding detonated, the Czech police said Monday.

title: British Financial Firms Expect to Keep Hiring, Survey Finds
description: LONDON  In a further sign of optimism about strengthening economies in Europe, financial services firms in Britain said they expected to employ 1.16 million people by the end of the second quarter of this year, adding as many as 26,000 more jobs than in the same period a year earlier, according to a survey released on Monday.

description: AHMEDABAD, India  On Dec. 5, 2012, Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia, stood on the steps of the Capitol in Washington with 25 other members of Congress and urged the United States government never to grant a visa to allow Chief Minister Modi to visit the United States under any circumstances.

description: LONDON  The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said on Monday that it would review the efforts investment banks are making to prevent manipulation of key benchmarks.

title: Kerry to Visit Israel for Middle East Talks
description: PARIS  Secretary of State John Kerry flew to Tel Aviv on Monday to try to resolve a thorny dispute over the release of Palestinian prisoners and keep the Middle East peace talks he started last summer on track. It is the second time in a week that Mr. Kerry has interrupted European travel to rush to the region to confer on the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, which had been on the brink of breaking down.

title: Austerity Memories
description: Preparing for this mornings class (pdf), I inevitably found myself thinking back to the austerity debate of 2010-2012, which was simultaneously exhilarating and deeply depressing. On one side, the critique of austerity was a classic example of high-quality, relevant economic research done in real time to respond to important issues  and it has left us with much better evidence on the effects of fiscal policy than we had before. On the other side, the nakedness of the way policymakers seized on research telling them what they wanted to hear made you wonder whether economic research can, in fact, actually make a positive difference in the real world.

title: Philippines and China in Dispute Over Reef
description: BEIJING  China accused the Philippines on Monday of illegally occupying Chinese territory after a Philippine vessel outmaneuvered the Chinese Coast Guard and resupplied a ship that has been stranded for 15 years on the Second Thomas Shoal, a tiny reef in the South China Sea.

title: The Dewey Seven Pleas, Unsealed
description: Seven former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf who pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme to manipulate the law firms finances came from very different backgrounds than many of the high-powered lawyers at the once-prominent New York firm, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. The employees guilty pleas were unsealed on Thursday and Friday, revealing that none of the former employees was a lawyer and just one was a certified public accountant.

description: A senior executive at Morgan Stanley is preparing to join the field of litigation finance, a young industry in which investment firms stake millions on the outcome of lawsuits.

title: Last-Day Rush Causes Another Malfunction of HealthCare.gov
description: WASHINGTON  For a second time on Monday, the federal website where consumers can sign up for medical coverage under President Obamas health care law unexpectedly stopped taking applications. It is the last day of open enrollment for the year.

title: Libyan Fund Sues French Bank Over $1.5 Billion in Losses on Derivatives
description: Updated, 11:41 a.m. | LONDON  The Libyan Investment Authority is suing the French bank Socit Gnrale and other parties over losses that it says were tied to tens of millions of dollars in bribes paid to associates of a son of the former Libyan dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: By Plotting Journeys, Providing a Glimpse at Citi Bike Ridership
description: Since its introduction last May, the Citi Bike program has attracted 100,000 annual members but far fewer daily subscribers than expected, a combination that has contributed to the systems precarious finances as operators look to expand.

title: Russia Raises Some Salaries and Pensions for Crimeans
description: MOSCOW  Moving quickly to envelop Crimea in the Russian bureaucracy and economy, the Kremlin said Monday that it had nearly doubled pensions paid to retirees on the peninsula, raising them to the average levels paid in Russia.

title: What Happens if You Save for College
description: A recent Op-Ed article in The New York Times argued that the cost of college could easily be lowered by cutting whats called the expected family contribution. That is the amount, based on a complicated formula laid out by Congress many decades ago, that parents and students are expected to pay for college.

title: A Blast and a Wedding
description: It is 2014, and to America the war in Afghanistan is over. President Obamas draw-down year is upon us, and as quickly as 2013 ended when the ball dropped, it seems, so did the nations memory of its longest running war.

title: Police Clamp Down on Protest Against Chemical Plant in South China
description: Residents of a city in Chinas southeastern Guangdong Province took to the streets Sunday to protest plans to build a chemical plant, the latest in a series of protests in China over environmental dangers that have accompanied the countrys rapid economic growth.

title: Yellen Says Fed Is Determined to Improve the Labor Market
description: CHICAGO  Janet L. Yellen, the new Federal Reserve chairwoman, devoted more than an hour last week talking by telephone with three Chicago-area residents struggling to find jobs.

title: U.N. Court Orders Japan to Halt Whaling
description: Koji Tsuruoka, an official from Japans Foreign Ministry, and Geert Vons, a representative of Sea Shepherd, responded to the International Court of Justices order for Japan to halt whaling practices.

title: Ordinary Decisions With Not So Ordinary Consequences
description: The Nobel Prize winning physicist Richard P. Feynman once said, The first principle is that you must not fool yourself and you are the easiest person to fool. That notion seems especially applicable to white-collar crimes that are the result of ordinary decisions by people who rarely seem to have recognized the path they were going down because they decided to fool themselves.

title: Today in Small Business: Killing DailyCandy
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Food Curated: Bacchanal Pepper Sauce
description: Sonya Samuels hot sauce recipe relies heavily on Scotch Bonnet peppers for their heat, but its the addition of fruit that sets it apart.

title: Columbia Records Executives Archive Headed to New York Public Library
description: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, at Lincoln Center, has acquired the personal archives of George Avakian, a record executive and producer who, during his years at Columbia Records, oversaw some of the 20th centurys most important jazz recordings, and his wife, the violinist Anahid Ajemian, a founding member of the Composers String Quartet. The acquisition, which the library announced on Monday, includes more than 160 linear feet of papers, including correspondence with musicians and composers, and recordings of concert performances and studio sessions, including many that have never been released commercially.

title: Video: Bacchanal Pepper Sauce
description: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

title: AT&Ts Stock Buyback May Further Signal Waning Interest in Vodafone Deal
description: If there were any doubts that AT&Ts appetite was waning for a Vodafone takeover bid, the American telecommunications giants latest potential stock buyback might erase them.

title: Weekend Gun Report: March 28-30, 2014
description: Often when a child is accidentally shot by a friend or family member no one goes to jail, the reasoning being that the shooter has suffered enough. As a result, the penalty for such shootings varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.

title: Follow The Links (Utility)
description: Ive had some puzzling correspondence, both hostile and neutral, from people complaining that I dont provide sources for my facts and numbers. All I can guess is that these correspondents dont realize that there are a lot of hyperlinks embedded in the online version of my column (and of course in all blog posts.) In fact, theres a link for almost every factual or quantitative assertion  the only exceptions are where the source isnt available online, which is increasingly rare. In todays column, for example, following the links will take you to sources for everything.

title: Bookshelf | A Member of Fashion (and European) Royalty Turns Mr. Manners
description: Its an age-old question: is chivalry dead? On the morning rush-hour commute on the F train, one could wager that it is. But if the noted fashion photographer Alexi Lubomirski  a.k.a. His Serene Highness Prince Alexi Lubomirski of the Polish house of Lubomirski  has his way, perhaps the next generation of boys will grow up to be more gallant. If, that is, such gentlemen-in-training read and abide by the simple affirmations (one per page) he outlines in his new self-published book, Notes for a Young Prince. Its about all the elements that a prince should have: charm, chivalry, courage, charity, honor, romance, he says. (The London-born, New York-based Lubomirski learned of his royal status at age eleven  and reacted by saying awesome!  though it has never amounted to anything beyond a title.)

title: Investigation of Flight 370 to Continue
description: The Malaysian defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, and Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said there is no time limit on the investigation of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

title: Flaming Lips Release a Companion to Dark Side of the Moon
description: Updated, April 1 | The Flaming Lips announced on Tuesday that the Flaming Side of the Moon recording was done as part of an elaborate April Fools prank in collaboration with the website Funny or Die. The original post is below.

title: Hobie Alter, Innovator of Sailing and Surfing, Dies at 80
description: Hobie Alter, who was known as the Henry Ford of the surfboard industry for his manufacturing innovations and who used his idle time to create the Hobie Cat, the lightweight, double-hulled sailboat that achieved worldwide popularity, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 80.

title: Hobbling Wall Street Cowboys
description: Michael Lewis writes that before he began working on Flash Boys, he had little interest in the stock market, though, like most people, I enjoy watching it go boom and crash. And like most people, he had an antiquated notion of what the stock market was. At the start of Flash Boys, his dazzling, troublemaking new work of reportorial storytelling, Mr. Lewis summons that sweet old image of a trading floor full of screaming brokers, slamming telephones and hysteria-inducing ticker tape. Picture that, he suggests. And then forget it, because its gone.

title: Nashville Cast Sets Out on a Short Tour
description: OMG, Deacon! Avery! Gunnar! Live!!

title: Ethan Browns Magic Square
description: What is mathematics? In one sense, its working with numbers: Were standing in the checkout line and realize we have only cash. Do we have enough? We start adding up the prices of the items in our cart. Thats certainly math. But we can also take a different approach, by estimating the number of items in our cart and multiplying by a rough average price. If were at Trader Joes, well multiply by three; at Whole Foods, well multiply by five. At Costco, well tally up our giant items, all in our giant cart, and multiply by 15.

title: Imperial Presidency Becomes a Rallying Cry for Republicans
description: COLUMBUS, Ga.  Republicans, poised for strong gains in the midterm elections, are offering starkly conflicting messages about President Obama to rally their voters. In one moment, they say the president is feckless and weak. But in the next, they say Mr. Obama is presiding over an imperial presidency that is exercising power that verges on dictatorial.

title: With the Thrills Come Extreme Risks
description: Despite several well-publicized accidents, like the death last year of the snowmobiler Caleb Moore, just 25, the popularity of extreme sports has soared in recent years. Participants in the X Games and other sporting events regularly perform heart-stopping tricks on skis and snowboards, skateboards and mountain bikes, all of them endlessly replayed on YouTube and television for a growing audience of thrill-seekers.

title: Bananas Poached in Vanilla-Scented Chardonnay
description: I am usually not one for bananas in desserts, but this, if youre careful not to overcook the bananas, is heavenly. Years ago, in the early days of my career as a vegetarian caterer, I made it often; it was one of my most requested desserts. These days Im as likely to spoon some of the bananas with their fragrant syrup into a bowl of morning yogurt as I am to serve it after a meal.

title: Monday Motorsports: Mercedes Sweep at Malaysian Grand Prix
description: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, teammates on the Mercedes-Benz Formula One team, finished one-two in the Malaysian Grand Prix Sunday, continuing the marques dominance in the early stages of the battle for the 2014 Formula One title. Hamilton, the pole position starter, led from green light to checkered flag, at which point he was more than 17 seconds ahead of his teammate. Rosberg, who won the season-opening round in Australia this month, now has a sizable lead in driving championship points.

title: Pears Poached in Red Wine and Cassis
description: Wine-poached pears make for a classic French dessert. I like to add a little crme de cassis liqueur to the wine, along with honey, vanilla and cinnamon. The cassis, made from black currants, adds a deep berry essence to the syrupy wine. You can serve these pears warm or chilled.

title: How to Talk to Your Teenager About Pornography
description: In Does Porn Hurt Children in the Sunday Review, David Segal pointed to the absence of definitive research linking pornography exposure during adolescence to negative outcomes for teenagers and noted the ethical impossibility of conducting the kinds of studies that might prove, or disprove, such links. In spite of the lack of evidence of harm, every researcher he interviewed felt uneasy about the messages teenagers might take from pornography and suggested that at a minimum parents should be talking with their teenagers about sexuality in general and porn in particular.

title: Dried Fruit Compote With Fresh Apple and Pear
description: This compote, which I like to add to my morning yogurt, does not involve wine, though you could add some red or white wine for flavor if you wanted to. The sweetness will vary with the type of fruit used. If you use dried sour cherries, dont use too many, because they will give the compote too strong a sour cherry flavor. Sweet fruit, like dried apples, pears and raisins, will result in a compote with a brightertaste. Apricots are great too, contributing another rich taste layer. I add fresh apple and pear for theirtexture, which remains somewhat crunchy even after they simmer.

title: Blood-Orange, Ruby-Red Grapefruit and Pomegranate Compote
description: I had a similar recipe, inspired by a recipe by Deborah Madison, about a year ago for a blood-orange compote with a delicious caramel-citrus syrup. I use the same technique for the syrup in this mix of ruby-red grapefruit, blood oranges and pomegranate, but I add a little bit of port. Its a beautiful, refreshing dessert and it keeps well for a couple of days.

title: Prunes Poached in Red Wine
description: This is one of those classic French bistro offerings that you still see on dessert trolleys in popular Parisian bistros (Im thinking Chez Georges, in the Second Arrondissement). Most recipes have you soak the prunes for up to 12 hours before poaching, but I see no need for that, nor do I want to lose the essence of the prunes in the soaking water. I cover them with boiling water for 5 minutes only; then I poach them in wine and let them steep.

title: College Classes Use Arts to Brace for Climate Change
description: EUGENE, Ore.  University courses on global warming have become common, and Prof. Stephanie LeMenagers new class here at the University of Oregon has all the expected, alarming elements: rising oceans, displaced populations, political conflict, endangered animals.

title: An Evolving View of Animals
description: Tim Flach wants us to look at animals the way we look at people. Not so much to humanize them, but to get humans to consider how they relate to animals.

title: Rights Group Says Data Suggests Mass Shootings in Nigeria
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The human rights group Amnesty International said Monday that it had satellite images suggesting mass graves in the northeastern Nigerian city of Maiduguri, following what witnesses have described as the large-scale execution of inmates by security forces at a military prison on March 14. The group said the pictures showed shapes often seen in satellite images of mass graves. Its report quotes witnesses who said they observed soldiers conducting mass shootings of frail detainees. The shootings took place after an attempted prison break by the Islamist group Boko Haram. Over 600 were killed that day by security forces, the rights group said, making it what was most likely the deadliest episode in Boko Harams five-year insurgency. Amnesty suggested that both the Islamists and the Nigerian Army were guilty of crimes against humanity.

title: An Owner Asks a Question About Offering Employees a Stipend to Buy Health Coverage
description: I read with interest Robb Mandelbaums post last week in which Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel predicted that employers will stop offering health insurance. In particular, I was intrigued by the following comment from Dr. Emanuel:

title: Competitive Birding in the Israeli Desert
description: On Tuesday, more than 100 competitors will descend into the Israeli desert, armed with binoculars, bamboo whistles and a desire for glory.

title: Push to Rid City of Classrooms That Are Anything but Temporary
description: A rotted floor in a trailer-turned-classroom got Scott Cosby his job: When it caved in, swallowing a custodians foot, officials at Public School 214 in East New York, Brooklyn, hired Mr. Cosby to fill in.

title: Want Guns With That? Chefs Find Politics Hotter Than Kitchen
description: CLEMSON, S.C.  Pete Matsko expected a little pushback when he posted a sarcastic sign banning concealed weapons from Backstreets Pub & Grill, his beer and burger bar in this college town, but he did not expect to become a national target.

title: Image of the Day: March 31
Weather Hampers Landslide Search Efforts
description: The program manager of the Snohomish County Department of Emergency Management, Jason Biermann, and Lt. Richard Burke of the Bellevue Fire Department explained how the weather has affected the search.

title: All the Rage | Just Wear It
description: Thanks to Nikes all-black take on athletic style, everyone is once again sporting the swoosh.

title: When the Unknown Republican Wins
description: Its risky to predict the behavior of Republican Party primary voters this far ahead of a presidential election, but that doesnt stop polling companies from trying to do just that, nor does it interfere with the humor value of the results.

title: Lufthansa Warns of Disruptions if Strike Occurs
description: Paris  The German flagship airline Lufthansa warned Monday that a strike planned by its largest pilots union this week would probably be one of the most disruptive in its history, threatening to affect more than 425,000 passengers across its global network.

title: Readers Reactions to Funding Tappan Zee Bridge Construction
description: There is something about a toll that can drive drivers and nondrivers alike to, well, intense expressions of fury.

title: Heres a Money-Making Strategy: Save More
description: A couple of weeks ago, I got an email from someone living nearby who wanted to talk about his investment plan. We arranged a time to meet, and I got to spend an hour being a sounding board. It didnt take long to discover that he was making a common mistake. Its one Ive made, too, and continue to make if Im not paying attention.

title: Obamacare Lives!
description: Back when rate shock, website problems and lagging enrollment were threatening to unravel the new health care law before it fully took effect, I concluded a column on Obamacares repeated near-death experiences with the following warning to conservatives:

title: Virginia Woolf Ballet and New Philip Glass Work Highlight Royal Opera House Season
description: LONDON  Some genuine surprises as well as a pragmatic eye to the box office are part of the 2014-15 Royal Opera House season, announced on Monday by Alex Beard, the chief executive of the Royal Opera House; Kevin OHare, the director of the Royal Ballet; and Kasper Holten, the director of the Royal Opera.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: AMBA Communications, Mosman, New South Wales, Australia, was chosen as the representative for Australia by Icom, Rollinsville, Colo., a network of independent advertising and marketing communications agencies.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Peanuts Come Out of Their Shells by Proclaiming Their Powerful Properties
description: A campaign that promoted peanuts as energy for the good life is being replaced with one that strives to be more energetic.

title: Times Minute | Ukraines Constitution
description: On the Minute, how Ukraines new constitution is taking shape with influence from Russia and the United States, a Republican rallying cry, and cultural divisions over rattlesnake hunting in Texas.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Appeal of Generic Drug Case
description: As the worlds largest maker of generic drugs, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries has been critical of brand-name manufacturers that try to block generic versions of their high-priced medicines.

title: Times Minute | Ukraines New Constitution
description: In the Video

title: Michael Jackson Album to Offer Eight New Songs
description: Eight previously unreleased songs recorded by Michael Jackson over the course of his four-decade career have been completed and compiled for a new album, Xscape, to be released on May 13, Epic Records announced on Monday.

title: Panel on U.N. Climate Change Report
description: Rajendra K. Pachauri, the chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, and Christopher Field, the co-chairman of the group that wrote the report, discuss its warning.

title: Japan on Courts Ruling to Halt Whaling
description: An official from Japans Foreign Ministry responds to the ruling of the International Court of Justice that ordered Japan to halt whaling in the Antarctic.

title: Russias Medvedev Visits Crimea
description: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia spoke in Crimea where he held a meeting with members of his Cabinet and local officials.

title: Made Nervous by the Doctor
description: A large review of studies has found that the white coat effect  a rise in blood pressure in a medical setting because of a patients anxiety  can be serious enough to affect treatment decisions.

title: On Canvas, Clues About Air Pollution
description: Sunsets painted by the great masters are now providing a type of information their creators could never have imagined: important clues about air pollution.

title: In Extra Rib, a Harbinger of Mammoths Doom
description: Many woolly mammoths from the North Sea had a superfluous rib attached to their seventh vertebra, a sign that they suffered from inbreeding and harsh conditions during pregnancy, researchers report.

title: Converging Interests May Lead to Cooperation Between Israel and Gulf States
description: JERUSALEM  Looking for a potential bright spot in the roiling upheaval of the Middle East, American and Israeli officials meeting in Jerusalem on Monday held out the hope of growing security cooperation between Israel and its Arab neighbors in the Persian Gulf.

title: F.C.C. to Free Airwaves for Wi-Fi and Wireless Broadband
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission approved measures on Monday that will free up more airwaves for Wi-Fi and wireless broadband. The agency also moved to help curb increasing cable rates for consumers, but in doing so cracked down hard on the ability of broadcast stations to negotiate jointly in competition with cable systems.

title: Ted Hughes Estate Cuts Off Access, Biographer Says
description: The poet Ted Hughes has long been criticized for burning some of the diaries of his estranged wife Sylvia Plath after her suicide in 1963. Now, the Hughes estate has abruptly withdrawn access from Hughess latest biographer, renewing suggestions that there may be secrets the family still wishes to keep hidden.

title: Sous Vide, Young Man
description: As part of our cover story about the 15-year-old chef Flynn McGarry for the Food and Drink issue, we solicited some advice from the pros for a kid just starting out.

title: From Dogs, Answers About Breast Cancer
description: By the time the elderly woman surrendered the 10 dogs living in her mobile home in rural Maryland, the shih tzus were unkempt and full of fleas and had gone years without their shots. A cream- and mushroom-colored female named Akyra, with a sweet disposition and a comical underbite, was in such bad shape that volunteer rescue groups declined to take her in.

title: The Read Around: Kevin Young
description: Death, birth, rebirth and the afterlife of grief are all present in Kevin Youngs new book of poetry, Book of Hours.

title: Health Care Signups Reach Frenzy in Final Day to Enroll
description: WASHINGTON  A frenzied last-minute scramble to sign up for health insurance overloaded phone lines and temporarily overwhelmed the website of the federal marketplace on Monday, as hundreds of thousands of people around the country raced to beat the deadline to obtain coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

title: Weekly News Quiz | March 25-31, 2014
description: A Supreme Court argument, a Facebook purchase, climate change and more: How many of the 10 questions in this weeks news quiz can you answer correctly?

title: Losses at Smaller Airports Are Unlikely to Be Reversed
description: AIR travel has a lot of new realities: On a cheap coach fare, if you want a seat that isnt in the middle of a cramped row back by the toilets, you are probably going to have to pay extra. Your frequent flier mileage programs are losing value, especially at the lower elite levels. If youre flying internationally, youre probably flying an airline alliance and not a particular airline.

title: On the Verge | Party Monstre
description: Paris night lifes greatest hope is a bookish bon vivant whos ready to rage.

title: Meet These New Snails. Now Say Goodbye.
description: A group of tiny snails with striking, irregularly coiled and ornamented shells are going extinct just as they are being discovered. A new paper reveals 10 new species (and catalogs all 31 species) of the snail, which belong to the genus Plectostoma. Found only in the limestone hills of Southeast Asia, with shells only a few millimeters long, the snails are losing their homes as the limestone is quarried by mining companies.

title: Reaction to Far Rights National Front Wins in French Vote
description: PARIS  News that Frances far-right National Front party was set to take control of 11 towns across France following municipal elections on Sunday was greeted with a mix of nationalist triumphalism and more than a little fear.

title: A Proposal Both Original and Cheesy
description: BACK in 2009, my now-husband, Daniel Klein, created a documentary series called The Perennial Plate, where we travel around the world filming short stories about sustainable food producers. Were a two-person team, so we both film, edit and produce each segment. For someone who has never traveled a lot, the last several years have been amazing. When we started doing this, we didnt have a clue that it would take off, and now our films are not only on our own website but also on the digital network Tastemade.

title: Video: Kevin Young Talks About Grief and the Poems in Book of Hours
description: In The Read Around, a weekly video feature, authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Kevin Young discusses how his fathers death and the birth of his son informed his new book of poetry, Book of Hours.

title: Federal Regulator Must Explain Why It Didnt Investigate G.M. Defect
description: Every week seems to bring more unsettling details about the failure of General Motors and a federal safety agency  for more than a decade  to identify a dangerous defect that has been linked to at least 13 deaths. On Sunday, a House subcommittee revealed that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration failed to open an investigation into the ignition switches G.M. used in several models even though its inspectors were aware of four deaths, more than two-dozen complaints and other reports that suggested a problem.

title: Auto Safety Agency Ready to Point Finger at G.M.
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top auto safety regulator will seek to cast blame on General Motors when he testifies on Tuesday before a House subcommittee looking into the ignition problem of Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars.

title: U.S. Is Weighing Release of a Spy for the Israelis
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is discussing the release of an American convicted of spying for Israel more than a quarter of a century ago, American officials said Monday, as it struggles to avert a collapse in peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Leader of China Aims at Military With Graft Case
description: BEIJING  Prosecutors accused a former senior military official on Monday of a litany of crimes, including bribery, embezzlement and abuse of power, presenting a first glimpse of what could be the biggest corruption scandal to ever engulf the Chinese armed forces.

title: Airline Blames Bad Software in San Francisco Crash
description: WASHINGTON  While the world has been fixated on the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, the Korean carrier involved in the crash of a different Boeing 777, the Asiana flight into San Francisco last July, raised design issues on Monday that put another question mark over the model of jetliner.

title: MetLife Reaches $60 Million Settlement With New York Authorities
description: MetLife, one of the worlds largest insurers, is paying a $60 million penalty to the authorities in New York for permitting two subsidiaries to operate without first obtaining the required license to sell insurance.

title: A Guard in a Centers Body at Forward for UConn
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  It was midway through the second half of a rare game in which Connecticuts Breanna Stewart struggled to find the basket and her accustomed dominance.

title: An Outtake From Flex Is Kings
description: Exclusive bonus footage from the documentary Flex Is Kings featuring the dancer Storyboard P.

title: Spite Is Good. Spite Works.
description: The Iliad may be a giant of Western literature, yet its plot hinges on a human impulse normally thought petty: spite.

title: Rearview Cameras by 2018 for Cars and Light Trucks
description: Six years ago, Congress mandated auto safety regulators to pass a federal standard by 2011 that would help keep drivers from running over small children as they backed up their vehicles.

title: Building Pterosaurs Down to Their Hairs, William Henry Harrisons Killer, Medical Device Loopholes
description:
A new exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History will feature great reptiles that soared over 60 million years ago; historians may be dead wrong about what killed the shortest-tenured American president; how safe are the medical devices in use in hospitals and doctors offices?
Subscribe to the Podcast

title: Earthquake Expert Uses Twitter to Urge People to Be Ready All the Time
description: As my colleague Adam Nagourney reported, the new mayor of Los Angeles and his top adviser on earthquake planning are hoping that the back-to-back earthquakes Friday night will create a sense of urgency to address concerns about the citys lack of preparedness for a major earthquake.

title: Fewer Helmets, More Deaths
description: More states are being pressured to repeal their universal motorcycle helmet laws. But when those laws are changed, the number of fatalities starts to rise immediately.

title: Obamacare, The Unknown Ideal
description: No, I havent lost my mind  or suddenly become an Ayn Rand disciple. Its not my ideal; in a better world Id call for single-payer, and a significant role for the government in directly providing care.

title: Visuals
description: This collection of columns takes a look behind the numbers to show hidden trends and relationships over a range of science and health topics from education to road safety to agriculture.

title: Hushed or Percussive, It Trumpets an Identity
description: The smallest moments in Pat Methenys sprawling concert at Town Hall on Friday night came at the very beginning and the very end, when he was sitting alone with a guitar. The biggest moments included four additional musicians, straining mightily, along with a partial reconstruction of Mr. Methenys orchestrion, the whiz-bang electromechanical orchestra that he unveiled four years ago and has kept refining since.

title: Replay Reviews First Cases Draw No Complaints
description: After months of expectation, baseball had its first regular-season use of the new replay review system on Monday. In a quiet and efficient start to the system, the call on the field of a game between the Chicago Cubs and the Pittsburgh Pirates was upheld, and the process took less than two minutes. Later, a second challenge helped the Pirates win.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup, Day 73: U.S. Down Two Against Mexico
description: Mexico is preparing for this summers World Cup in Brazil only because of a bit of last-minute help it received from the United States national team on the final day of qualifying last year. But to one Mexican club team, that is no reason to help the Americans get ready, too.

title: Building Pterosaurs, Harrisons Killer, Medical Device Loopholes
description: Models of ancient creatures; what killed an American president?; how safe are medical devices?

title: Justices Seem Wary of Software Patent Case
description: WASHINGTON  In a case with the potential to reshape the software industry, the Supreme Court on Monday seemed poised to issue fresh limits on patents for computer-based business methods.

title: The Line to Kiss Sheldon Adelsons Boots
description: Its hard to imagine a political spectacle more loathsome than the parade of Republican presidential candidates who spent the last few days bowing and scraping before the mighty bank account of the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson. One by one, they stood at a microphone in Mr. Adelsons Venetian hotel in Las Vegas and spoke to the Republican Jewish Coalition (also a wholly owned subsidiary of Mr. Adelson), hoping to sound sufficiently pro-Israel and pro-interventionist and philo-Semitic to win a portion of Mr. Adelsons billions for their campaigns.

title: Gut Reactions to Beneficial Bacteria
description: Q. When you eat yogurt or take a probiotic supplement, why arent the probiotic bacteria killed by stomach acids?

title: Italian D.J. Fights to Keep Culinary Traditions
description: MINORI, Italy  Daniele De Michele, a bearded and boisterous D.J. and performance artist who is one of Italys most inventive food activists, is on a yearlong journey to explore and document the countrys working-class and peasant culinary traditions.

title: Quick Gains After a Smoking Ban
description: The number of premature births and childrens hospital visits for asthma dropped significantly in parts of the United States, Canada, and Europe barely a year after they enacted smoking bans, researchers reported in The Lancet last week.

title: Sharp Truths Only Fiction Can Tell
description: In a society where 50 million people are caring for someone with a chronic or terminal illness, there is no shortage of literature on the subject, from academic papers to memoirs to practical guides. But in this new anthology, the first of its kind, the literature is really that.

title: Pharrell Williams to Join The Voice
description: Looking to cement its status as televisions most popular music show, The Voice on NBC will add one of the hottest stars in the music business, Pharrell Williams, as a coach for its next edition in the fall.

title: Now Screening | New Yorks Latest Dance Craze, From Street to Screen
description: Exclusive bonus footage from the documentary Flex Is Kings featuring the dancer Storyboard P. The photographer Deidre Schoo was taking pictures of a Harlem variety show in 2008 when she became mesmerized by the work of a Brooklyn performer named Storyboard P, who was described earlier this year in The New Yorker as the Basquiat of street dancing. He calls his dancing animated mutation, Schoo says, and he strove to animate every piece of his body  on the table, on the floor, using the entire bar. Storyboard was Schoos entree into world of flex dancing, a new style that originated in East New York and Flatbush, Brooklyn, with a vocabulary of movements that borrows in part from the special effects of movies like Transformers and The Matrix. Its very narrative and cinematic and inspired by Michael Jacksons videos, she says.

title: The Device Makers Shortcut
description: A few years ago, the Food and Drug Administration announced a stunning recall, saying that electrical wires in some St. Jude Medical heart defibrillators, which were implanted in tens of thousands of people, were defective. It was a rerun for cardiac patients: In 2007, Medtronic recalled its Sprint Fidelis cardiac devices because of faulty wires.

title: Corrections: March 29, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whos Behind the Cocktail Renaissance?
description: Were living in a Golden Age of creativity for bartenders, many of whom are energetically pushing boundaries in both culinary and scientific ways  as I discovered when I was researching my article Cocktail Science Simplified in the latest issue of the magazine.

title: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Drives the Last Car Driven by Elvis
description: Richard Petty may be known as the King in Nascar circles, but to many other Americans that title is reserved for Elvis Presley, the King of Rock n Roll. One of Mr. Presleys cars, the 1973 Stutz Blackhawk III he was photographed driving not long before he died, on Aug. 16, 1977, has made its way into the Nascar realm as part of a promotion for the Charlotte Motor Speedway AutoFair to be held at the track from Thursday to Sunday.

title: Democrats Scramble to Stave Off Midterm Disaster
description: WASHINGTON  If it were only President Obamas flagging poll numbers, the problem for Democrats of how to mobilize core supporters to vote this fall would be bad enough. Midterm elections for an unpopular presidents party are almost always bleak.

title: Expansion in Use of Cancer Vaccine
description: Now that Brazil has introduced vaccines against cervical cancer, more than 80 percent of girls in the Americas can get them, the Pan American Health Organization announced last month.

title: Curry and Coconut Milk Fire Up a Weeknight Basic
description: Whats for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

title: Frequent Flier Miles, for a Cause
description: Airlines dont always make it easy to use their frequent flier miles to pay for travel.

title: What Really Killed William Henry Harrison?
description: Like the Science Times page on Facebook. | Sign up for the Science Times newsletter.

title: Senate Report Says Caterpillar Used Swiss Subsidiary to Reduce Taxes
description: Caterpillar, the big American maker of heavy construction and mining equipment, used a subsidiary in Switzerland to avoid paying $2.4 billion of income taxes over 13 years, according to a Senate investigative report released on Monday.

title: Scene City: MOCA in Los Angeles Turns 35
description: Diana Ross, Pharrell Williams and other stars celebrate the new era at the Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: U.N. Climate Report Authors Answer 11 Basic Questions
description: The countries that in 1988 created the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which released its latest report on global warming impacts on Monday, have long neglected to provide resources to enable the panel to effectively convey its findings to the public. One example of that continuing communications gap is this: a helpful, and clearly written, FAQ on the new report is largely hidden from view deep on the http://ipcc.ch website.

title: 3 Jailed Journalists Deny Ties to Brotherhood in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Three journalists jailed on charges of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood to fabricate news told a judge on Monday that they had no association with the group. One of them even recounted drinking alcohol, which is forbidden in Islam.

title: Interest Is High in First Preview of Hedwig
description: The Hedheads  devotees of the cult musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch  did not disappointment on Saturday night, packing the Belasco Theater for the shows sold-out debut on Broadway. For its first and only preview performance last week, Hedwig grossed $144,194 and had an average paid admission of $141.92  high numbers by Broadway standards. The audience surely also included some fans of the musicals star, Neil Patrick Harris, in his first return to Broadway since 2004. The only show with a higher paid admission last week was the blockbuster hit The Book of Mormon at $187.20, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

title: Opener of Built and Dashed Hopes for Mets
description: The Mets were one out from a victory on opening day. Dillon Gee, Juan Lagares and Jose Valverde had had star turns. It was one game, but the team could have built some confidence and converted a few doubters. After weeks of spring training and evaluation, it was clear that they were flawed. But they talked about winning 90 games this season. A win Monday at Citi Field would start them on that path.

title: Detained Journalists in Court in Egypt
description: From left, Baher Mohamed, Mohamed Fadel Fahmy and Peter Greste are accompanied by a police officer during their trial. The detained Al Jazeera journalists spoke out in a courtroom in Egypt.

title: A Hungarian Sampler, Lighthearted to Brooding
description: While Liszt was inaugurating the concept of the bravura solo piano recital in the 19th century, the Hungarian-born virtuoso violinist Joseph Joachim took a different approach, pioneering the format of concerts dedicated to string quartets and taking a more ascetic approach to music making.

title: How Animals Think and Harmonic Stars
description: April events at the intersection of science and culture.

title: Chairman of Tax Panel Wont Run This Year
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Dave Camp, the Michigan Republican who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, announced Monday that he would not run for re-election.

title: Report Blasts Former Academy President on Pay and Rsum
description: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences issued a report on Monday condemning its former president, Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, for inflating her rsum and influencing the academys procedures in order to increase her pay far beyond that of leaders of similarly sized organizations.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, South Korea, Pennsylvania and Tokyo.

title: Reactions
description: Athletic Training

title: Ares Management Plans Public Offering
description: The private equity firm Ares Management intends to raise $100 million through an initial public offering, paving the way for the firm to join the small handful of alternative asset managers that have gone public in recent years.

title: Mayors Opening Day Toss Is a Winner, but He Misses the Mark With Mets Fans
description: The pitch was clean and smooth, if a bit slow, a Sunday-league version of a changeup. Most crucially, the ball made it over the plate, plopping into the glove of Travis dArnaud, the New York Mets starting catcher, with a satisfying smack.

title: Fast on Her Feet, and More Than Willing to Get Dirty
description: Inside Amy Schumer is a sketch comedy show with more than a few bells and whistles. Sketches are interspersed with bits of stand-up, recalling Louie and Chappelles Show, and Ms. Schumer does street interviews straight out of HBOs Real Sex. Episodes end with a sit-down interview labeled Amy Goes Deep  everything on this show is a double-entendre  in which Ms. Schumer might talk to a sex columnist, a phone-sex operator or a pornography cameraman.

title: Composing and Blending, an Atypical Artist Creates
description: It makes sense that the French composer and multimedia artist Jean-Baptiste Barrire is best known for his collaborations with colleagues, particularly his wife, the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho. Mr. Barrires work is an omnivorous blend of visual art, theater, literature and music, of live and recorded performance, so it is only natural that he plays well with others.

title: A Maestro Is Back, His Position Pending
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Dozens of audience members at Orchestra Hall this weekend waved small Finnish flags or wore variations on the flags colors: blue and white neckties, scarves, shirts or dresses.

title: Presenting Onstage the Sounds (and Faces) of the Future
description: Most aspiring opera singers in their mid-20s are still figuring out their voices and learning technique. It is always difficult for the judges to pick the winners of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions Grand Finals Concert. Are they assessing the performances they hear at the concert or the potential of still-evolving young artists?

title: Starting an Overdue Conversation About Money
description: THERE is no end to the disagreements about the importance and usefulness of the upstart virtual currency Bitcoin.

title: Makers of Bitcoin A.T.M.s See a Not-Quite-Cashless Future
description: IN addition to the Glocks and Remingtons that have long been available at Central Texas Gun Works, customers can now buy something new: Bitcoin.

title: Prime Minister Erdogans Revenge
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey got what he wanted from Sundays elections for mayors and other local officials  a strong vote of confidence for his Islamist-rooted Justice and Development Party and its 11 years in power.

title: Fleshing Out the Bones
description: In a brightly lit production studio at the American Museum of Natural History in February, 12 artists were hard at work, heads down, eyes focused.

title: New York Philharmonic to Team With Music Academy of the West
description: The New York Philharmonic and the Music Academy of the West, a music school and festival in Santa Barbara, Calif., have set up a four-year partnership under which student fellows from the academy will train with Philharmonic musicians and Alan Gilbert, the orchestras music director, both in Santa Barbara and New York.

title: Nathaniel Rateliff and Regina Carter Release Albums
description: NATHANIEL RATELIFF

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Big Ears
description: Scenes from the festival in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: They Heard Whatever They Wanted
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.  The name should give the answer away, but there is a little bit of shadow chasing in the question of the essence of the wide-ranging three-day Big Ears music festival, which finished up its third edition here on Sunday.

title: Mathematician and Matildas Humbled by Coin Flips
description: Late Sunday, when it was official that an unlikely Final Four was heading to Texas, Tim Chartier wistfully conceded that there would be no March Mathness on display in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Q. and A. | Philippe Vergne, the New Director of MoCA, on the Future of the Museum
description: Last Saturday, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles celebrated its 35th anniversary with a gala that doubled as the coming-out party for the French-born curator Philippe Vergne, the new director of the embattled institution who had previously worked at the Dia Art Foundation and the Walker Art Center. Unlike fundraisers in the past few years, there were no nude Marina Abramovic-style performers or pot passed around the tables. Instead, the soire  held in honor of the late Mike Kelley, whose retrospective has just opened at the museum  was all business.

title: Can a TV Series Get Grimmer Than Zombies? Apparently So
description: Spoiler alert!Human beings have a primordial fear of being reduced to meat in the eyes of their fellow men and women. The architects of The Walking Dead, the wildly popular television show, have exploited that fear to great effect during the first four years of the series, which focuses on a band of survivors who struggle to reconstruct community in a post-apocalyptic landscape dominated by the lumbering, flesh-eating living dead.

title: Drug Company Seeks to Be Repaid Legal Fees in SAC Capital Inquiry
description: Elan Pharmaceuticals is seeking to recoup the more than $1.5 million in legal fees it paid to comply with document requests by the federal government in its insider trading investigation of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

title: France Overhauls Its Government After Voters Rebuke Socialists
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France announced the formation of a new government on Monday, after broad losses by his Socialist Party in recent nationwide city elections that were widely seen as a rebuke to the deeply unpopular president.

title: Video of Police Shooting Prompts Protests in Albuquerque
description: The police in Albuquerque used tear gas Sunday night to disperse hundreds of demonstrators who marched downtown to protest police shootings, including the shooting of a mentally ill homeless man whose death was captured on video by a camera attached to a police officers helmet.

title: National Geographic Channel Pulls Nazi War Diggers Series
description: National Geographic Channel said Monday that it would indefinitely pull a planned television series on unearthing Nazi war graves after days of blistering criticism from archeologists and others who said the show handled the dead with macabre disrespect.

title: Egyptian Presidential Campaign Launched on a Bike
description: In a throwback to the Mubarak era, Egyptian bloggers on Monday once again found themselves parsing images of the nations most powerful man, released to bolster his popularity, ahead of a presidential election in which the result seems to be a foregone conclusion.

title: Yellen on Tackling Unemployment
description: In her first public speech as the Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen emphasized the steps the Fed has taken to spur economic activity and create jobs.

title: Pedestrian Bridge in Van Cortlandt Park Has an Obstacle: $7.5 Million
description: Before the dawn of automobiles, Van Cortlandt Park was an unbroken expanse of dense woodlands, steep ridges and meadows, interrupted only by the gentle murmur of Tibbetts Brook.

title: Macys C.E.O. Gives Up Title of President
description: Macys announced on Monday that its chief merchandising officer, Jeffrey Gennette, would become the companys new president, a promotion that may put him next in line to become chief executive.

title: Remember, Theyre Only 4 Years Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Slomo
description: Dr. John Kitchin quit a medical career to pursue his passion: skating along the boardwalk of San Diegos Pacific Beach. He calls himself Slomo.

title: Slomo
description: Slomo came into my life at an opportune moment. Having just rolled into my 30s, I was looking for both a film subject and some wisdom on how to approach the encroaching middle third of my life  the years when youthful idealism is so often blunted by adult responsibilities.

title: Pluto.tv Offers Online Videos as Curated TV Channels
description: Navigating video content online is a little like reading a good book on Post-it Notes. Each time youve watched something great, you have to plod through a number of other screens to find the next good video.

description: Caterpillar, the big American maker of heavy construction and mining equipment, used a subsidiary in Switzerland to avoid paying $2.4 billion of income taxes over 13 years, according to an investigative report released on Monday.

description: To the Editor:
